description:
I only had a Crispy Chicken Sandwich on my first visit to Town Hall. It was fairly good, but for a MealPal selection, it was a decent deal.

I got a look at the place and it seems like it has promise for a good after work stop. Going through the other reviews, it sounds like they have a happy hour, but I don't see any details about what is offered for Happy Hour specials. I will check it out and report back to you all.
author: Marvin M.

description:
RIDICULOUSLY OVERPRICED, RAW OYSTERS SMELL VERY BAD, LEFT US THE AFTER TASTE OF ROTTEN FISH. YUCK!!!
The bartender seemed like does not like his job. The pour of Old Fashioned was EXTREMELY STINGY. That very little pour should be charged 1/4 of the price!!!
Ambiance is quite nice, however, when we sat at the bar we hoped we could be greeted by friendly bartender. That for sure did not happen.

I could only wish best of luck to this business.
author: Irene X.

description:
A few coworkers and I went to try this place for the fried chicken sandwich. Glad we went!

The venue is nice, service was friendly, and the food was nicely presented and was quite good. 

We all ordered different cocktails and the fried chicken sandwich. I chose to get the Blushing Mule and opted for chips as my side for my entree.

Loved my order! Cocktail was tasty and refreshing. Fried chicken sandwich had a lot of great components to it too (taste, juiciness, great bun and chicken) though the apple slaw didn't stand out at all in terms of taste or texture. The slaw got lost in the spicy aioli and the crunch of the fried chicken breading. Chips were average, wish I was given more to go with my sandwich. 

Overall, this was a great experience! I'd love to go back to try more things.
author: Sofia R.

description:
4* rating based on their Smoke and Barrel Happy Hour. This is probably (and please correct me if I'm wrong because I want more HH before my commute!) the closest happy hour to the new Salesforce Transbay Terminal. Earlier this week, there was an accident on the bridge that prevented any buses from getting into the terminal for the start of rush hour. We were told to take BART or wait it out. I decided to look for a tipple and keep an eye on Google maps to see when traffic cleared. First check: 2.5 HOUR delay. Yikes.

I ordered an $8 HH red wine. It was the Velvet Devil Merlot from WA which I've had before. Not great, but serviceable. Also got the blackened shrimp for $9, pretty nice, would order again.

The bar was crowded, but as long as you get a seat, you should be fine. They are busy here, but it's not too hard to flag down a bartender when you're right in front of them.

Traffic was down to a 30 min. delay, so I asked for a slightly dirty gin martini, bartender's choice on gin. He opted for Plymouth, which is a solid, solid choice. A well-made cocktail, olives were tasty, and it was $12 when I got the bill--absolutely reasonable for the area.

I also tried the fried chicken tenders. Would have liked more seasoning in the batter, but the texture was good, and if you're into sweeter sauces, the Jack Daniel's BBQ sauce was fine.

Thanks, Town Hall, for making a bad situation slightly better :)
author: Lydia C.

description:
I'm obsessed with their jalapeño corn bread. 
It was effin delicious. Don't even need any of the honey butter. 

Other dishes we got:
St. Louis Ribs
Veal Meatballs - not sure I'm crazy about veal. taste was not to my liking
BBQ Gulf Shrimp - I liked dunking the toast in the sauce. Had a nice kick
author: Linda W.

description:
Come here occasionally for dinner!

Food: Usually have the shrimp app, fried chicken, fried okra, and ribs.
(1) Shrimp with Gravy App: Wow this one is my favorite. Really love the toast soaked with the gravy, and it reminds me of some of my favorite restaurants in the South. If you're not a huge gravy fan, you'll probably still like it, but not love it.
(2) Fried chicken: So good. Crispy on the outside and moist in the middle.
(3) Fried okra: So-so. They left the okra whole, but I prefer the chopped up pieces. These came out slightly stringy, and needed more salt.
(4) Ribs: Good, but could be more tender like southern BBQ.

Drinks: Had the sauvignon blanc. Reasonably priced and very good!

Service: Fast and good! No complaints.

Location & Atmosphere: Great location in an area of Soma which needs more restaurant options! The atmosphere is warm and romantic. 

Seating: Usually sit at the bar if I'm in a small group, and they have extremely fast service. Large groups do well with regular seating.
author: Michelle B.

description: We came here for a lunch on a weekday. We started off with the warm jalapeños cornbread. It exceeded our expectations. The exterior was warm and crispy while the interiors were moist making it really scrumptious. Next was the crispy okra which is crispy just like its name says! I ordered a salmon for the main course and was not disappointed at all. It had a nice spicy gravy around with lots of corn to give it some sweetness. It went really well with the Salmon. I rarely skip desserts at good restaurants  However, I was so full with the appetizers and the main course, that there was no scope to have a dessert. I would visit again to try other dishes and a dessert (hopefully).
author: Tejashree M.

description:
Yum rare chicken!

No it's not dark meat, no it's not the seasoning, it's straight up bloody rare. How can this possibly be fried chicken...

No wonder their health score is below average 74/100. I wouldn't trust this place or recommend it to anyone unless you want salmonella poisoning. Do yourself a favor and avoid this place. 

Reached out to their manager and they ignored this health issue. Customer service reflects a lot about their management, and they obviously don't care. Extremely disappointed, and never returning.
author: Angela T.

description:
Came here with the future in-laws and I will say, it was pretty good. They mentioned that the fried chicken was pretty good, so that's what we ordered. We also ordered the corn bread and mac n cheese.

Love the vibe and decor, it's inviting and rustic. They were also playing the good 90's jams!

If you want complimentary bread, you might have to ask for it as some nights they run low and will only offer it to those that ask.

Their fried chicken is soooo good! Good amount of crispy fried batter on the outside and the chicken was super juicy on the inside.

If you like dense waffles, you'll like their rendition. Over all, I would definitely come back and get their fried chicken with mac.
author: Jerrica N.

description:
Come here and get their old fashioned! They make their own bacon infusion! We come here ofter for those guys and an order of corn bread. YUM!

This review is on the dining experience in the main dining room. We didn't know what kind of wine we wanted, but the server sent over the bar manager who very knowledgeably made her recommendation based on the food we ordered.

Fried chicken was amazing. I couldn't eat it all but I boxed it up to take home because there was no way I wasn't finishing that!
author: Sarah S.

description:
If you want to come somewhere you can't help but make bad decision after bad decision and you don't even care, this is your spot. 
I had 2 whiskeys, biscuits with jam and butter and ham AND chicken and waffles. For dinner, people. I don't even know how I walked out alive. (Okay had the gnocchi, too.) 
The food is soooo good and you obviously can't say no to anything on the menu. If you are like me and have no self control (did someone say bacon infused booze?!!) you will have a hard time leaving here with your sanity and pocket book in tact. Prices are a bit high for portion size but it is San Francisco and perhaps should discourage bad behavior. It didn't work. 

If I did it again (let's be honest, it will happen), i would go for a drink and small bites and move elsewhere for a lighter meal.
author: Katie M.

description:
Microwaved ribs. This is what they served us last night and why I'm never coming back. I have been here 5 times and the food and service are super mediocre, especially considering how expensive it is. The deep fried ocre is the best thing. They don't know how to cook the $110 36oz steak. Theres no flavor in the fried chicken. 

The cocktails are super small - so that you will order more I guess.
author: Dan G.

description:
Great ambience for Southern fare!!

Great service, strong drinks, excellent food. Everything ordered was impressive!

Return soon, note to self.
author: Jana C.

description:
Location is stellar, food is mediocre, and lunch time service is slow.

I called in to make a reservation for a work lunch and was reassured that we could make it out of the restaurant in one hour. Perfect, I thought. Given the prime noon time slot, I expected the restaurant to busy. Within moments of sitting down, we immediately ordered our food and drinks just to be safe. 10min passed, 20min passed, and before I knew it, it was already 12:45pm and our food had not arrived. Even water and drinks took a while to get to our table. When we finally flagged down our server, her only response was that this was normal for the noon crowd.

When the food did arrive 50min later, I was so darn confused. I ordered a full portion of salad and a side of chicken, yet the tiny amount of salad on the plate made me question if they even got my order correctly. The salad was well seasoned but the chicken was dry and had no flavor. And of course at this point, I had 5 mins to scarf down the food and pay for the meal, which did not add to the fun. For over $30 for my portion in the end, I felt ripped off. Yes, this meal is being expensed (and I'd guess more than 50% of patrons here are doing so too) but location alone is not reason enough for customers to keep coming back.
author: Christine C.

description:
We were at a slightly disappointing HH in the area, so we decided to move spots. My group of six stopped by on Friday, September 1st around 5pm. The bar was fairly busy, but we managed to find about 4-5 chairs together, so we sat at the bar.

Smoke N' Barrel Happy Hour: Monday - Friday, 4pm - 6pm
*Anchor Lager: SF, CA ($5)
*The Nick Carraway: casamigos blanco tequila, grapefruit, lime, soda ($8)
*Sparkling ($8) x5
*Blackened Shrimp: tabasco vinaigrette ($8)
*Bourbon Bacon Caramel Corn: smoked fleur de sel ($5)
*Crispy Okra: cilantro jalapeno aioli ($6)
*Selected Artisan Cheeses: apricot-dill jam, house made olive oil crackers ($12)

Regular Menu:
*Bulleit Rye ($13)
*Balvenie Portwood ($31)
*Hendricks ($14)

For once, I just stuck to the HH drinks for the two or so hours we were there. (I think I had about 2-3 glasses of bubbly.) Some of us were hungry, so we ordered a bunch of snacks. I only tried the cheese platter which was delicious. I adore cheeses and they had a great assortment of creamy ones. Everyone else seemed to enjoy the rest of the snacks. Our bartender was very sweet and kept my drink flowing, which was appreciated.

I hear there's a burger they served during HH, but it's only during the first hour. I do find this weird, but I may be back just to try that. Sounds delish!
author: Elena N.

description:
Cute spot to grab a drink and some bites with friends. Spotty service, but delicious food. Beautiful space and great for groups early in the evening.

The Good
- Roasted Veal Meatball: Flavorful, especially the mash potato and sauce its on top of
- Warm Jalapeno Cornbread: Cornbread coated in honey and salt chunks. Great texture and flavor
- Corn Hushpuppies: Ate two of these without question
- Grilled Brocollini: The bread crumbs on this is pretty rad
- Roasted Romanesco: Good, not worth $8 for 3 halves

The Eh
- Crispy Okra: Too deep fried
- Tuna Tartare: Fish quality is not phenomenal
- Salads (Beet & mizuna): Both coated in sauce and cheese (be aware for those with dietary restrictions)
author: Steven W.

description: Town Hall has stayed consistently delicious over the years. Terrific location and atmosphere. Favorite dishes: fried green tomatoes, veal meatballs, fried okra, bbq shrimp, and cornbread--served sizzling hot in a small cast iron skillet with jalapeño butter. Not to be missed!
author: Shadi G.

description:
Ate at Town Hall w/ a client this past week. This was my first time eating here, and I think my assistant picked the place based on the proximity to both my and my client's offices. I hadn't done much research of the menu ahead of arriving, and I was catching up with a client that I hadn't spoken to in a while, so I ended up panicking a bit when it came time to order. My client chose the fried chicken sandwich, which the waitress mentioned was their signature dish and staple of the restaurant since it opened in 2003. After asking for a couple other recommendations to avoid being unoriginal and getting the same thing as my client, I too chose the fried chicken sandwich, given the other suggested options would have caused me to swell up like a puffer fish (due to my seafood allergy). She did also recommend the duck confit (which sounded a bit heavy for what I was up for that day), the Salmon, and the Fried Cod Po'Boy. 

The fried chicken sandwich was a big hit, though it was more than filling, and I didn't have any interest in trying to finish the gourmet chips that accompanied my meal.
author: Ravi K.

description: This is a great spot! I loved the pimento cheese and the jalapeño corn bread. The ambiance is nice for business or leisure. I would like to see more vegetarian entrees on their menu as I only saw the farro vegetable dish.
author: Shivani S.

description:
This place is getting worse and worse, but they don't care because they have a steady stream of customers from 5000 facebook employees (above them) and many more thousands of salesforce employees 1 block away.

The service there is pretty poor to rude. We were waiting to be seated and a cook(?) with short blonde hair comes in and just bullies his way through our group (without saying anything). He must think he's Gordon Ramsay's mini-me because he mimics Ramsay's looks and behavior (rude!).

We almost walked out but decided to check out the food. Catfish tacos for $24? Fried chicken sandwich was ok. Tritip sandwich was ok. Everyone was just going through the motion of eating the food .. This place has the feel of one of those Pier 39 restaurants. They have so many new customers that they don't care about repeat business. So their service and behavior reflect this attitude.
author: D B.

description:
My visit to Town Hall was actually a work event as we'd ended up taking several clients to dinner here.

Right off the bat I realized the space was fairly crowded and laid out strangely. I would imagine it would be great for private parties as there's several separate spaces, however the restroom is on the second floor up two flights of steps or an elevator - it's honestly the farthest trek for a bathroom I've climbed. 

Food wise I was torn between the chicken and waffles and the cod and while I enjoyed the cod I finally decided on, I probably would not order it again. The cod itself wasn't seasoned well enough on its own and relied on the salty texture of the lentils to get by. The dish didn't sing until I mixed everything on the plate together, and while that's one school of thought for flavoring, it's not one I prefer.

The service was friendly and spot on beyond the one instance of making me that person who drinks Coca Cola all evening then sends back a Diet Coke when she's served one. 

I absolutely hate being that person.

Long story short, I would definitely come back but probably would not order the cod again.
author: Meg T.

description:
Review is strictly for the Grab N Go Friday special chicken sandwich.

Quick transaction.  Under 11 bucks after tax.

Not as crunchy as The Bird a couple blocks away, but well prepared fried chicken. Pickled jalapenos were strong, unique, and paired well with the spicy homemade 1000 island-like sauce.  Fairly filling, no need for the sides.

Recommended and will visit again.
author: Matt A.

description:
Okay, so I gave TH another try after YEARS of not going because the first time was also lackluster.  I am now writing a review, 2 weeks later because the whole lunch was terrible, from start to finish. 

I brought a group of CLIENTS to the restaurant and called ahead of time to ensure (and this is something they said they allowed, I talked to a manager) that they had my credit card saved, not just to hold the reservation, but to also pay for the lunch.  SMOOTH, right?  They confirmed they would do it, and because I know they drop the ball on things, I made sure to confirm before lunch got going.  OF COURSE they were stammering and stuttering that they didn't have the info.  So instead of schmooze my client like I'm supposed to, I had to run back to the office for the company card.   FINE. I'd like to add that the manager on duty acted like he didn't care, not at all. So, I hustle back get the card and come back, hoping that the service and kitchen staff will make up for management, which is usually the case.  The workers outdo the managers...unfortunately this was not the case. 

When I returned, my group had still not been taken care of, after 15 minutes sitting there.  I had to wave someone over to come take care of us, and they acted like we were bothering them! Finally we placed our orders. 

I ordered the jambalaya, and to be frank, WHO DECONSTRUCTS JAMBALAYA?! It's like serving a quiche, by making eggs and putting on a dish, making ham and slicing herbs and placing on another dish, and then serving a small glass of cream on the side. Not to mention that it was completely devoid of any flavor at all. I will say the jalapeno cornbread was good. 

Of course service continued to be slow.  

Finally, when leaving, I expected to have some kind of discount on the bill, or an offer for a free desert.....HAHAHAHA!

NOPE.

As our group left, not one person could muster even a "Thank You" as we left.  THE WHOLE TOWN HALL IS CANCELED. 

Good day :)
author: Nathalie P.

description:
REVIEWER # 1799

Located in a beautiful old-style building, this hip restaurant is totally homey and a solid place for happy hour! First, big shout out to the bartenders: Kyle and Tara! Those two both made my first experience at Town Hall, the best experience! I met a friend here during happy hour and after looking at the jazzy reviews from my fellow Yelpers, I was quite excited to come here.

Upon approaching, I quickly noticed the construction happening around the area (don't let this discourage you, it's totally worth it). Parking is NOT the best here but it helps that BART and Muni station is 5 minute walking distance and the Temporary Terminal is literally across the street. They have a patio that is right in front of the entrance but the inside is such a great set up! A communal table located near the entrance on the right, bar area on the left, and all the way in the back is the dining area. The inside is very spacious and the décor is attractively decorated and compliments the wonderful, friendly staff. 

I hear lunch time and happy hour is golden here, meaning you won't be disappointed! They have a small happy hour menu but it's straight to the point.

THINGS TO ORDER:
Lunch time- WasSup with that Fried Chicken, tho? OMG, Flavorful, juicy and so pleasing to my taste buds! The homemade chips just compliment it even more! Don't come here without ordering the Fried Chicken, I warned you! 

Happy hour-They have a wonderful small menu of different varieties of food. I would encourage you to order the Jambalaya (although it was not flavorful) it was okay, nothing to brag about. Tuna Tartare- very tasty and satisfying! Ask for some of those house-made chips as well!

Dinner time: I am telling you now: Roasted Veal Meatballs! (That's all she wrote!) No, but seriously, that dish is DELICIOUS! It's a whole meal of its own, hurry and order it! If that is not pleasing to you and your still hungry call that server over and order the Buttermilk Fried Chicken, this was pretty good as well. Let's just face it; Town Hall serves some delicious ass fried chicken! 

The service was EXCELLENT! My food came out quickly after I ordered and EVERYTHIN' was sizzling' HOT! I had the pleasure of Tara and Kyle serving me and they were fun, attentive and knowledgeable. Make sure you chat-it-up with them! 

FYI: If you come with a big group, make reservations! The downstairs can be packed and noisy. They have a private area upstairs (near the restrooms).
author: Porsche C.

description:
Came here recently to get lunch with a friend of mine after a recommendation from a coworker of mine, since I work around the area. Now normally, I'd hesitate to come here for lunch because of their pricey menu, but Town Hall also provides a fast and cheaper option of getting select items to-go depending on the day of the week (Menu available here: https://townhallsf.com/news/blog-roll/144-new-grab-n-go-stand-now-town-hall). 

Since I went on a Wednesday, I got the Andouille Sausage Jambalaya with house-made jalapeno corn bread. First off the corn bread, it was a bit sweeter than I expected, though that might have been due to the fact that I missed the word "corn" in the menu, so I was expecting a lot more jalapeno flavor. Still, I thought the jalapeno flavor was a bit lacking, and it seemed more like ordinary corn bread. Not bad, just unexpected. Now onto the jambalaya, which was served in a small to medium-sized plastic soup to-go container. While the jambalaya did not skimp out on sausage slices, I think it could have been more flavorful; I was expecting it to be heartier than it actually was. 

Overall, I can't say that I had an amazing foodie experience thus far, but I am still looking forward to trying more of their menu, in particular, the fried chicken sandwich.

TL;DR: Jambalaya was ok, but I'm still excited to come back to try their other menu items.
author: Ed W.

description:
Food: 3/5
Service: 2.5/5
Ambiance: 3/5
Overall: wasn't too impressed and likely won't be back given the pricing for the food.

The extended review...

Food: 

Fried okra - not too bad.  Pretty plentiful portion.

Fried chicken and waffles - it was ok but not my most favorite in the city.  Also I didn't like that I couldn't pick my pieces.  

Ribs - this was probably my favorite of all the dishes.  Good BBQ sauce and tender meat.

Jambalaya - the rice was moist but the meat was a little dry.

Butter scotch and chocolate pot de creme - pretty tasty and a very generous portion.  Good proportion of chocolate to butterscotch.

Service: so first off it took about 5 minutes to get water.  I'm not sure if it was cause it was short staffed on this Friday or not.  I also wasn't a fan of the server.  When he took our drink order I mentioned we were ready to order our food and he said he would be right back rather than just taking our order down.  He was a little short when I asked if I could have specific pieces with my chicken and waffles.  

Ambiance: busy and and can get a little bit noisy.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
The restaurant is spacious and beautiful but the food was just mediocre. Most importantly, no rsvp needed on a Saturday night.

We came with a group of 6 and ordered a few items. My favorite was the cornbread. Wow it was good! A little crisp on the outside but soft on the inside. The cornbread was a little sweet from the honey but buttery with a little kick from the jalapeños. One of the best cornbread I've had anywhere. 

The chicken and waffles were not bad but I didn't really enjoy the waffles. The syrup tasted weird and the texture of the waffles were not crispy.

We also got the grilled pork chops, which our friends said it was what they were known for. The pork chips were pretty tender.
author: Caroline L.

description:
Came here with reservations for a team dinner and was greeted with a horrible stench upon entering the front doors. I think it was their compost sitting outside, but it definitely should be placed elsewhere where because the smell alone can scare customers away. We got seated a few minutes after we checked in. There's two floors and you will need to take the stairs to go to the bathroom and it's across a private dining room for the restaurant. Started with their glass of Riesling and it was delicious! 

- Crispy fried okra: not bad with the aioli sauce and the crispy flavor definitely helped add flavor to the okra.
- Jalapeño cornbread: this is my favorite dish of the night. The cornbread was perfect moisture and flavor with the jalapenos. The spice didn't overpower the bread and it was sweet goodness.
- SnapPeas salad: there were strawberry bits but the goat cheese definitely help me from trying more (not a goat cheese fan) - but if you like goat cheese, definitely try. 
- Corn hush puppies: also tasted better with the chimichurri sauce and without the sauce it was a bit too dry and tasteless to me. I was hoping for the strong corn flavor like in the cornbread but was disappointed. 
- broccolini with bread crumbs: this was a tasty side; definitely worth ordering on the side of your meal.
- rock fish: I was looking for something light and it definitely was a small piece but the flavor was not there. The crispy outer layer was too salty and the fish meat in between was too bland - it didn't do it for me so I wouldn't order this dish again.
- gnocchi: got to try my colleagues dish and it was tasty. A fan of the gnocchi so I will opt to ordering this one next time if I come back.

We were too full for desserts so we left after our meal. Overall, service was ok, but I could tell our waitress was a bit annoyed of us when we didn't have our orders ready when she first came around. I don't think the food matched it's price.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Nice little joint in SoMa. Making a reservation just has you entirely avoid the hassle of fighting for a table. Go early so they don't sell out of their specials (pastrami sandwich!!! I WILL eat you one day!!! 0 for 5 on pastrami attempts... seriously...)

Chicken sandwich is amongst the best in the city.
author: Jimmy S.

description:
I have to admit to be a little disappointed with Town Hall.  I was taken by someone who loved it back in the day, but we were both disappointed in our lunch choices.

I had the cornmeal crusted flounder sandwich.  The Texas toast was not thick and fluffy like you would expect, but it was the thickness of regular bread and toasted so hard that you couldn't cut it with a knife.  It was so hard that if I had eaten it like a regular sandwich it would have cut my palate to bits.  I took the top piece of bread off and ate it as best I could with a knife and fork.  I had to ask for the tartar sauce as it was too dry without it.

My friend had the fried chicken sandwich. She said that the bun was too fragile and fell apart when she tried to eat it like a sandwich.  She too ended up using a knife and fork.

The beet salad was excellent however.
author: Vikkie N.

description: I was so excited when I saw their Crispy Fried Chicken Sandwich on MealPal. I'm a huge fan of tender fried chicken and frequented places like The Bird and Honeybird in LA recently. This is by far the best fried chicken sandwich I've ever had!! It came with lettuce, tomatoes, pickles, and their special sauce. Even though it was prepared beforehand (as expected with MealPal) it was warm and tasty when I had it back in my office. I usually hate pickles on my burger but it balanced nicely with the other ingredients and the "comeback sauce." Honestly, this place is way better than some of the super hyped up fried chicken places. Delicious & such a steal.
author: Evelyn G.

description:
This is the local go to spot for jambalaya, cornbread and chicken & waffles. Plus they have good well drinks. Don't let the name fool you this place has pretty good southern cuisine, good service and a low key, vibrant after work vibe. 

High points 
- the cornbread is very flavorful and not dry at all; you'll want to take any remains home in a doggy bag
- the chicken & waffles is perfectly fried and moist, while the waffles are cooked to an ideal browness. Town Hall loses a point for not offering maple syrup, only honey ‍. But still mad tasty
- any well drink I've had here has been on point. I've mainly ordered Manhattan's and ye old fashioned 
- jambalaya is my go to for a quick lunch meal. Usually it does not disappoint especially with on a traditional cool in SF
author: J W.

description: I'm so disappointed--they took the Nashville crispy chicken sandwich off their menu. My coworkers and I have been going there just for this particular dish for months! It was one of our regular lunch spot. I wish they would bring it back. It doesn't feel like there's a point in going back without it.
author: Yad L.

description:
Came here for dinner with a friend after wanting to try this place forever (since it's literally one block away from where I live). I made a booking as I always see how busy it is when I walk past it and thank goodness I did, our reservation was at 6:45 and this place was absolutely packed. 

We had the jalapeño cornbread for starters - it was good but nothing I would crave again. My friend has the the fish (bass) for her main and she really enjoyed it. I had the chicken and waffles... oh my word, best fried chicken I've had in SF!!!! The waffle was good too but lacked a bit of taste. The portion was huge as well, 4 pieces of chicken and the waffle. I literally brought back more than half the meal back home. Even reheated, the chicken was so tasty. I would definitely go back just for the fried chicken and waffle dish. We had the Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Crème for dessert and I really enjoyed this, it was very light yet tasty especially after a full meal. But be warned, there is more butterscotch than chocolate so my friend didn't enjoy it but I like butterscotch so I thought it was good. 

The restaurant is a bit noisy since it's so busy so I wouldn't recommend it for an intimate dinner but for casual meet ups, it's a great spot. We had a glass of wine, a latte, starter, 2 main meals and a dessert which came to about $130. Wine per glass is pretty pricy here. 

All in all, I would definitely go back!
author: Damain S.

description: Town Hall is a great restaurant with amazing food. I had the tomato soup for lunch and it was very delightful.  The jalapeño cornbread is to die for !!!  I will be back to try more food.  The ambiance is very pleasant. I sat on the patio.  The service was beyond great !  I can't wait to return. 5 plus stars!
author: Juanita H.

description:
MEAL PAL REVIEW

Curbside pick-up by the front door - super convenient & makes it easy to add an order for drink or sweet treats

So far, this is the most satisfying meal I've had through meal pal. (still in my first month, but whatever) 
THE ANDOUILLE SAUSAGE & CHICKEN GUMBO (with cornbread)...
Coming from the New Orleans area, this gumbo exceeded my expectations for a San Francisco restaurant. Spicy, lots of good ingredients, and pretty close to the original recipe!! 
The cornbread wasn't as good as my family's, but I cant ask for it all! 

Overall, I would order this again and would love to check out the full menu in restaurant some time.
author: Rebecca L.

description: So happy I finally got to eat here! My table ordered the honey fried chicken 'n waffles, St.Louis ribs and hushpuppies. We shared everything because it was all sooo good. The chicken coating was so crispy with a flowery touch of honey flavor that paired so nicely w the rosemary leaves on top.  The chicken was juicy & hot! The waffle was light and delicious too! The ribs were amazing! Falling off the bone, I've had St. Louis ribs 3 times this year and none were fall off the bone!! The sauce was tangy and there was a little extra that was perfect. It comes w a jalapeño corn muffin that was deliciously spicy but not too spicy. Finally, I love hushpuppies & these were the best I've ever had! Garlicky but not too much w bits of sweet corn throughout. We couldn't fit any dessert but I can't wait to come back another time! Service was great too! Everyone was so friendly and efficient!
author: Noël V.

description:
I'm going to go right into the food:

Taste of Three Charcuterie Plate:  This shared appetizer is worth coming back here for if only for the biscuits.  They give you a small basket with about 8 small biscuits to go with this cured, thinly-shaved pork plate with a small round of butter and lightly spicy, sweet jelly.  The biscuits are so good, I really can't describe why, they were light, had a light crunchy outside and a comforting, moist inside.  I'm not really one for biscuits because they usually are bland & dry but everyone at the table, (there was 6 of us), said after the meal these biscuits were the best thing of the meal.

St. Louis Ribs:  6 good sized ribs with a side of bbq sauce.  The meat was perfectly tender & I loved the bbq sauce but throughout biting the ribs, there was a surprising, unpleasant tang of SALT!  If it wasn't for this, these ribs would have been perfect.  I liked the sweet, slightly gritty cornbread muffin and the not too tangy cole slaw.

Berkshire Pork Chop:  The person who had this said it was o.k., a bit bland if it wasn't for the surrounding droplets of huckleberry sauce, (I looked at her plate and all of the sauce was sopped-up, yet there was 25% of her pork chop uneaten).

Side of Fried Okra:  Everyone commented how it was good that the fried okra was light and wasn't overly greasy, but unfortunately it came to our table cold, (not even lukewarm).
author: Johnnie N.

description:
Something about that customer service wasn't right. We walked in and was ignored by 3 workers until someone finally took notice that we wanted to eat there.

Then the waiter for our table just looked annoyed the whole time as if he didn't want to be there. Overall, we just didn't feel welcomed.

Do we need to look rich or something to get a little better attitude?

Dessert was amazing though! Girlfriend and I were not disappointed by it. Expensive, but I guess that comes with the territory of being a relatively fancy restaurant in SF.
author: Jonathan R.

description: It's hard to rate something if you never get served. We were sat outside on the patio and the waiter walked by us multiple times without stopping by at all. He proceeded to help the table next to us for more drinks and getting their check for them. We ended up leaving.
author: Jana N.

description: After a grueling 18 hours of catering, we wanted to be taken care of, and this place did just that. 6:20pm and we were starving. We arrived at a nearly empty dining room, no fault of theirs, it was a Sunday in San Francisco, and the room filled up as it got later. We started off with a cocktail. I wanted something w Canton ginger and a base of either vodka or tequila. The best most lovely pinky spicy cocktail emerged. Margie our waitress said the bartender just made it up. Kudos! Sunday nite is meat and 3, a Southern thing where you order your meat and choose 3 sides. I choose fried chicken, fried okra, cole slaw and summer veggies w lebnah. My husband, prime rib w smashed potatoes, roast corn, and creamed spinach.  My fried chicken was the best I've had, crispy with a flavor that defied my ability to name it. But where fried chicken is often chicken that's been fried This chicken had an extra oomph to it. Ricks prime rib thick and juicy and very little fat very much what you would expect at one of the better prime rib houses in The City. All the sides were excellent. The really nice thing was it was an inclusive 45.00 per person, the prime rib an extra 10.00. For this we got soup or salad...the soup Early Girl tomato...pure tomato essence. I had the salad w chilled bib lettuce & blue cheese. Ok, THEN the Desert! Chocolate mousse w a layer of butterscotch pudding on top and shards of toffee candy. YOWZA. Coffee press and we were more than satiated. Loved loved loved Town Hall. Service good and the flat charge of 45.00 if not a steal, certainly worth every cent.
author: Chery C.

description:
I was really impressed with Town Hall for dinner this past weekend with A. A has been raving about Town Hall's grab 'n go counter which he has been frequenting via MealPal so we decided to try the real thing. We had a bit of a hard time finding the entrance but once we were inside, we were sat promptly. The interior of Town Hall is beautiful and warm. I wouldn't necessarily say it is modern but its not dated either. I felt really cozy here with my only gripe being that the bathrooms are in the second floor next to the private dining space but, if that's the layout of the restaurant, so be it.

Anyways, we decided to order a round of drinks in addition to our meal. We had:

-Rosemary's Baby ($13): This was mine and it was delicious and light. I really enjoyed this cocktail and especially the beautiful vivid color!

-Town Hall Old Fashioned ($13): This is what A had and he liked it but didn't really taste all of the special flavoring such as the bacon or maple. I liked it better than a usual Old Fashioned when I sampled it, personally.

-Bacon Wrapped Trout ($28): My main and it was GOOD. Especially with the cornbread stuffing. The dish was a bit rich but it was really yummy and I finished it even though it was a bit of a struggle. I highly recommend this but I was a bit freaked out by the fish head on my plate.

-House Smoked Ribs ($27): This was A's entree and it was DELICIOUS. He demolished it. The meat was tender and the sides served with it were delicious. Neither of us personally LOVED the BBQ sauce that came with it since it was too sweet but that's a minor gripe.

-Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Creme ($10): We split this for dessert on the recommendation of other Yelpers and they're right, this is a show stopping dessert. It is HUGE and with the candy on top, I felt like we were having dessert chips and dip. A bit rich but you should know what you're getting into when you order a dessert like this. We definitely looked like barbarians eating this but it was totally worth it.

The service at Town Hall was quite attentive and we got our food and drinks promptly. We didn't even have time to demolish the bread basket (yummy sourdough at Town Hall!) that we usually do which was probably better for our waistline. I am taking off a star since I think we ate something we didn't necessarily agree with at Town Hall. Neither of us had food poisoning but we didn't feel great in the middle of the night or the morning after. We did go to a few bars after dinner so that may have been a factor and I don't want to accuse Town Hall of anything. Just something to keep in mind. It also may have been that the food was so rich that we had issues since we aren't used to eating food like this. Regardless, we definitely plan to come back and recommend it if you're in the area.
author: Carrie W.

description:
Had a reservation for a group at 11:30 am on a Thursday morning. They won't take your order until everyone in the group has arrived, and the last person ended up coming around 12, so we didn't get our orders taken until about 12:15. Being that a couple of us had a hard stop at 1, this made for an extremely rushed lunch for us. By the time we got our food, we had to also ask for a box to take back half of the meal as we didn't have enough time to eat it all. I think overall they should have had more staff working. This place filled up extremely fast during the lunch rush and I don't think the service could necessarily keep up with that pace. 

As for the food, I got the Faith's Ham and Cheese toast. I guess I should have deduced from the description that it would just be a slice of toast with some stuff on it, but because it was listed under "Sandwiches", I assumed it would be more of a hearty meal. I would describe this dish like an Eggs Benedict, but with only one egg and one toast versus the two that you would normally get with a full meal. The dish was ok. The first bite was tasty, but after three bites, the sauce and the flavor became a little redundant for me. On the other hand, my bf got their pastrami sandwich which was definitely a very hearty meal. He took half of it back, and the sandwich was still good the next day, even when cold.  

Overall, while this place is a decent place to come to when you're not in a rush, I was less than impressed with my experience here and wouldn't make this my first choice if deciding on a spot to eat in this area.
author: Anita L.

description:
I ordered pulled pork with slaw and biscuits to-go for lunch. The biscuits were mediocre - small, a little dense, and just didn't taste very fresh. The bulk of the meal was sauce and pork fat, with little bits of meat floating around in it. Honestly, it looked like some kind of pet food. The meat chunks were good and tender, but the flavor was mostly lost in the overly-sweet sauce. The cole slaw was fine. Very disappointing. Maybe the lunch deals are not representative of this restaurant's potential, but I'm not inclined to return and find out.

Coworkers went for lunch today. Tried the fried chicken sandwich, which was good but not great. The slaw was bland and the pickles were very sweet, without any salt or spice to contrast them in the chicken. Turns out they used up all their spices on the very over-seasoned chips. The chicken was moist inside but not crunchy on the outside.
author: Chris M.

description: Great food without waiting! Well, I get their MealPal specials and it's ready at table outside. So I never have to fight crowds!
author: Dan N.

description:
I had higher expectations coming here from the recommendation of others in this area. I was disappointed in the dishes I had ordered but certainly not by the service and venue itself. I will have to return to try out a few other items. I came for lunch so maybe dinner would be a better option. 

Warm Ham and cheese toast - Basically was an eggs benedict which I usually LOVE. The egg was poached perfectly however the choice of bread was not enjoyable. I couldn't tell you what it actually was due to how soaked, dense, and soggy it was from the sauce. Every bite was very heavy with no elements in this dish that adds brightness or freshness. 

Crispy okra - This is a side dish so you may overlook it on the menu. This was my favorite of the three! Piping hot okra fried in a cornmeal batter. Crunchy, crispy, savory, and not too slimy on the inside. Well balance of texture.

Duck confit salad - The duck was overcooked. I didn't even need to cut into it to be able to tell. Just dry! The salad requires a fork and knife to cut into small manageable pieces with a very light dressing.
author: Tracy N.

description: Came here after work for dinner with a colleague to catch up. We ordered ordered a couple drinks at the bar while our table was being set up. We were too early for dinner!  Once seated at our table we ordered tomato and watermelon salad...tomatoes must be in season because they were really delicious...the combination made that salad unforgettable! For dinner I ordered the bbq ribs, but I think I would have been happier with the chicken and waffles that my colleague ordered. The chicken was crispy and moist...didn't have any of her waffle. The ribs were tasty...but my taste bud were too busy salivating over her chicken and waffles! Dang!! I think I'm going to have to come back!
author: Kurtesa C.

description:
I'll start by saying I'm an idiot and forgot to take a picture of my beautiful hamburger, arg. I suppose it was the fact that it looked so delicious and I lost all comprehension of time, space, etc. 

Anyway, I popped in for lunch yesterday and boy was I impressed with the food and service. It's been a couple years since I'd been inside Town Hall and forgot how legit the food was. My burger was prepared perfectly medium and the accompanied french fries were delicious! It was a good size burger and believe me, I wasn't hungry when I left. I also tried a bite of my friends tuna melt which was also fabulous! 

I don't think you can go wrong here as it seems to me that the menu is legit from top to bottom. I'll be back for the fish & chips ASAP!
author: Benjamin F.

description: This is our go-to place for work happy hours. It's close by and good for a small group of 10-20. You can reserve the big table. Their happy hour snacks are great, happy hour drinks are so so and their wines on the menu are so so.
author: Isabelle L.

description: The fried chicken sandwich is my favorite! The homemade chips that come with it  have a lot of seasoning and I appreciate that. I saw the salmon pass by a few times and that will definitely be the next thing I try when I come again. As an appetizer we tried the jalapeno cornbread and I really wish there were more jalapeno pieces. The pieces we did get were small and very tasty. I would have loved that all throughout the bread but I would still get it again and highly recommend.
author: Janet N.

description:
We haven't been here for a long time, almost 10 years. We decided to come here for HH before the holidays. We got here a bit before 5 and the bar area was packed. Luckily we were able to get a table in the patio with heated lamp. 

We ordered some food from the HH menu and would like to order fries as well. But we were told that they need to reserve fries for the customers who ordered burgers .... hmmmm ... and the server said she needs to check to see if the kitchen can make fries for us?!?!? Really?!?!? Anyways she made it like a big deal and came back with the good news that she can get us fries!!!! Seriously?!?

Anyways the fries we got was not good at all. Seems like the fries were re-fried. Other food was good.
author: Brenda W.

description: I always enjoy my time at Town Hall. They are great for both lunch and dinner. The menu is fun and the drinks/wine are great. This place can get busy for both lunch and happy hour so make a reservation or get their early.
author: Craig P.

description:
My best friend wanted to eat here.  So after the delayed charge issue last time, I decided to start fresh.  Food has never disappointed.   And hey, that was a one time thing, right?!?!   But oh man, was this time so much worse.  

Our waiter was a mess.  He asked us each thing two or three times.  Like would take a drink order, then leave for 20 minutes and come back to ask what we wanted to drink.  It was 40 minutes from seating to getting to place an order.  If it weren't for bus boys, we'd have never even had water or bread.    And even that was at the 30 minute mark.  

Every time we flagged him down to ask for the thing we'd asked for three time before, he actually rolled his eyes or seemed put out.  He literally got not one thing right all night. In a two hour stay (should have been about 50 min) we never once got refills on drinks, despite asking three times.  The order came out wrong, after him clarifying it twice after we ordered, and someone else tried to fix.   We actually heard him doing the same things to the two two tops next to us.  We were all in shock. At first we laughed. Hahaha, 30 minutes to order a Diet Coke and Arnold Palmer.  Then comedy turned to shock and then to rage.  

Then, as if this couldn't possibly get worse.  He charged us for two alcoholic drinks, which we obviously didn't order.  He came back with two manually modified receipts.  However, both charges are pending and he didn't credit the first ones back.  So, it seems, Town Hall will be charging me twice for the same meal, only this time, they'll also be charging me for drinks I didn't have and an experience that was possibly the worst in SF. 

The only redeeming thing was, as always, the food is very good. Too bad I cannot possibly go back ever again (except tomorrow to again get a fraudulent charge reversed).

Update: Nicole just called to apologize.  I appreciate that and am happy they did the outreach.  She offered a very generous dinner on them.  I'm not interested in going back.  But it was a nice offer.  Thanks.
author: Shannon N.

description:
Was at a Happy Hour downtown and looking for a place to eat for dinner. Not a ton of places open so ended up here. Womp. Not worth it and probably never coming back. I work nearby so I know this place serves a lot of the business folks (ie. expensed meals) so I don't recommend paying out of pocket.

Service was pretty bad. Slow, and our waitress seamed like she didn't want to be there.

We ordered the okra, tuna tartare, veal meatballs, gulf shrimp, and risotto. Most dishes were flavorless. Overall just a below average experience.
author: Laura D.

description: Awesome evening with friends enjoying the fabulous food this restaurant has to offer.  Wine and whiskey were served and enjoyed by all.  We will definitely be coming back since the food and atmosphere is so great. All the dishes we picked were really good.  Can't wait to go back again!!
author: Susan C.

description:
I specifically came to Town Hall, because it was one of the top picks when I researched fried chicken. It would've been a quick 10 minute walk from my financial district hotel, but somehow I missed my turn and ended up walking 3x as far as I looped all the way down to 4th Street. I called the restaurant worried I'd lose my table. They assured me it was fine and that I should take my time. Phew, that helped calm me down. 

The restaurant is smack dab on the corner of Howard & Fremont. The decor is rustic with white paneling, wooden chairs & tables, and accents of brick. Vincent, my server, was friendly, personable, and knew what he was talking about. I took his recommendation and tried the Heirloom tomato salad with homemade smoked ricotta, purslane, olives, and cucumber. It was light and refreshing, exactly what I needed to go with my hearty fried chicken w/rosemary roasted marble potatoes. The chicken lived up to my expectations. It was crispy, juicy, and oh so flavorful. I'm a big wimp when it comes to spices, so I was dripping with sweat, but I kept eating since it was so good. If you want some good fried chicken, I'd definitely recommend Town Hall. 

Pro-tip: Their Twitter handle is @townhallbbq
author: Lorianne L.

description:
This place is amazing!! The food here is unique, fairly priced, and portioned well. They have excellent starters which is a must-try when dining in. A few that I recommend is their fried oysters with glazed pork belly and their BBQ Shrimp on top of toast and spiced sauce poured on top. 

A real popular entree is their Town Hall fried chicken which comes in 3 pieces of breasts and potato & spinach salad. The chicken is crispy and fried to perfection! I think they should just serve the whole bottle of Crystal hot sauce rather than inside a small cup. I also recommend their ham selection. The Tenneshootoe selection is the best! It's served on a wooden cutting board along with four fluffy mini biscuits, honey butter, and killer jalapeño jelly. Mix all of these together on top of the biscuit and it's on a whole different level of tastes. 

I recommend trying a few cocktails of their menu as well. They have special cocktails that are definitely worth the try such as their Town Hall Old-Fashioned (bacon-maple infused whiskey). End your night with ordering a dessert. I suggest having their Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Crème. This dessert is super delicious. It's almost like a fusion between custard, ganache, and pudding. It's topped with butter crunch which is almost like toffy. 

Overall, this place is great to go with a group of friends. Order multiple starters and do the whole experience: Cocktails, starters, entree, and dessert! I promise this place will not disappoint.
author: Allister D.

description:
This place has extremely slow service, even when the place is not busy. Some of the waiters/waitresses can't even lend a smile when they serve your food or walk around the restaurant.

We were sat next to an extremely loud and obnoxious table of coworkers and squeezed in between the column and another 2-person table. I was surprised because the other side of the restaurant had very few customers. I was curious why we were all smooshed in one spot.

However, besides it taking around 25 minutes for our food to arrive (is that not long?) and never getting refills on our drinks, the food really shined. I had the New York steak and boy was it good. That sauce + asparagus covered in that yellow sauce was exactly what I wanted. I would have licked the plate clean if I could have!

If you can get a spot that doesn't make you feel claustrophobic or you're looking for some good cocktails at the bar-top accompanied by a nice meal, I highly suggest this place because the food will not disappoint.
author: Miranda M.

description: Staff is amazing, very friendly and willing to work with you on custom orders to fit your needs if you're allergic to ingredients. The atmosphere is elegant, candlelight dinner with a rustic touch. They fell short with the food. I ordered the BBQ Shrimp and it was a messy presentation, I thought the shrimp was tasty but the bread was soggy with all that sauce, which pooled on the plate in an enormous amount. It looked more like a soup with a sneezing of shrimp. We also ordered the pork ribs, it was dry and bland. It heavily relies on the sauce for flavor and was underwhelming for the price.
author: Brittany D.

description:
We live cnear by, and I have no idea why we took to long to try. I guess it was because of the 3.5 starts. 
My experience was amazing!!!!!
Our waitress was so happy and with a good vibe.Its hard to choose one option from the menu. 
So, we tried the fried chicken (pic), meat balls, srimp andac and cheese. All super yummy!!!
I will definitely come back!!!
author: Luana H.

description:
Dinner review. 

Country ham tasting - 3/5
Pimento cheese crostinis - 3/5
Roasted charred corn soup + chili oil - 4/5
Bbq shrimp + worchestershire + garlic toast - 5/5
Ham cheese toast + Poached egg + jalapeño cream - 5/5
Fried Chicken + marble potatoes - 5/5
Jalapeño cornbread - 5/5
Pork cracklings - 3/5

Overall, "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
Didn't come to this place with high expectations. My fiance wanted to take me to dinner and he knows I love fried chicken and heard good things about this place. I wasn't dying to try it, I mean i love fried chicken but how great could their fried chicken really be? it was HANDS DOWN THE BEST FRIED CHICKEN i have ever had! Here is a rundown of what we ordered:

DRINKS:

He had the RUE 342. I'm not big on Gin but he is and he really like it. 
I had the Clipperton. I loved it! it was tasty, i ordered a second!

FOOD:

FRESH OYSTERS: exactly what you would expect. Fresh oysters. I don't like huge ones so i asked for smaller ones. 

FARRO VERDE RISOTTO: i'm not big on vegetarian options, but even i ate some of this. The risoto and corn and gouda. It all went so well together.

FRIEND CHICKEN & BUTTERMILK WAFFLES: to. die. for. the fried chicken had a crispy batter that was well seasoned and the inside was so tender and juicy. it wasn't oily or greasy at all! the waffle was fluffy and the honey and butter just brought everything together.


WARM JALAPENO CORNBREAD: you must get this to share for the table. it didn't even need any butter. The jalapeno gave a bit of flavor but it wasn't overwhelming. 

WHOLE ROASTED CAULIFLOWER: i wasn't a big fan of this, but thats because I don't really like curry. It wasn't awful, i just wouldn't order it again for myself. I did have a few bites. the currants and pepitas helped, but without it the curry flavor was just too much for me.

Aside from the food and drinks, the service was great! everyone was super friendly, i didn't feel we waiting long for anything. The inside is super cute!
author: Hugh J.

description:
It's difficult to imagine a nicer experience than the one we had last Sunday night at Town Hall:
-- Delicious food. Perhaps the best BBQ ribs I've had. Fantastic mac n' cheese.
-- Lovely atmosphere.
-- Lively but not too noisy.
author: Jeff J.

description: Just had the worst meal I've had in months here. Sat at the bar.  Took 10 min to get a menu b/c the bartender was texting. Took 25 min to get a fried chicken sandwich. It was burnt. It was $18. What a ripoff, I used to love this place
author: Leigh C.

description: Healthy portions, hearty food casual atmosphere and great people. Right in the heart of the city, and a killer Happy hour.
author: Eric J.

description:
WOW, seriously never coming back again.

Had a reservation for 7 at lunchtime and did not have to wait, until we got to our table. At first our server came to see if he could start any drinks for us, and we needed a few minutes. After that, we had a horrible time. 

Drinks took over 25 minutes to get to us and food took 35 minutes. We ordered two sides of fried okra and the server never put it on our bill, so it never arrived. 

One mistake is forgivable, but we had a ginger beer that was on our bill and it never arrived. Then food  came incorrect. We ordered a turkey torta and roasted beef, but they brought two roast beef and charged us that instead of the torta. Also, they brought over the shrimp noodle dish to our table but no one ordered it, which shows how messed up the service is. We also asked for more bread 4 times and did not get it til after we finished our food. 

The big thing is that our boss asked when we ordered our food, to also bring the check as we were having a work lunch, but the server did not do it til much after we finished. 

The food itself is tasty, but the service is SO bad that I rather not waste my money. I never have this experience at Per Diem (which is the much better choice in the area), or Salt House.
author: Mei L.

description: Solely based on my customer service experience - an experience that has convinced me not to come here anymore. I reserved a large group  in advance. They have a 24-hour cancellation policy, which makes sense, especially for bigger parties. 3 days before my reservation, I tried to cancel online, but was informed I had to call the restaurant. I did, twice that day and left a message. I repeated this efforts every day, until the day of, when I finally got a hold of an individual who informed me that it would be removed and because of my efforts/voicemails, there would be no fee charge. 7 DAYS AFTER MY CANCELLED RESERVATION, I have a charge of $120 on my card. I immediately called the general manager and requested it be removed. He assured me it was. A week later, it was still there. I called again, this time a lady assured me it'd be removed. Still a charge. I understand it take a few days sometimes for refunds to go through. However, with the outstanding card charge, I called a 3rd time, again explaining my situation and wondering why it wasn't removed. Manager again confirmed the refund. It is now 17 days after my cancelled reservation, and now I am getting the refund. It took me too many phone calls to make sure that they were being responsive. It should have been addressed without my worry the first time. Every call, it seemed that people did not communicate with one another and the restaurant was rather unorganized in that sense. Mind you, they were very courteous on the phone, but I feel that they should have taken a little more responsibility for the mistake. That was time I had to take to constantly check my transactions. I've heard many good things about Town Hall and their food  (especially the mac & cheese!) and it makes me sad that this was an issue. This review is meant as a word of caution, and also as a trigger to hopefully better manage FOH and BOH operations so that any hiccups in performance are not reflected in customer interactions and/or can be better resolved. Thank you!
author: Zara S.

description:
Came here for lunch and sometimes they offer certain dinner specials during lunch. I got the trout wrapped in bacon with cornbread stuffing.

Food: in terms of the food, it was decent. I could definitely taste the freshness of the fish, but all in all, I didn't think it was that impressive for the price. You'll be getting a headless trout that's wrapped in bacon and stuffed with cornmeal I believe, so be expected for that interesting textural balance. I thought the cornmeal was slightly bland and didn't really understand its purpose, but I did enjoy the textural change

Service: also decent. The waitress checked in on us often, offered to refill our waters timely, but my only qualm was that the food wasn't brought out at the same time, which made it awkward for me and my coworker while my boss hadn't gotten his food.

Overall, I had an above average experience here and appreciated them telling me that I could order a dinner special when it wasn't listed on the menu. Will be back in the future to try out different menu options!
author: Jonathan X.

description:
Came here for a holiday lunch with my coworkers and it did not disappoint!

We had:

- tuna tartare
- jalapeno cornbread (my fave!)
- fried okra

Each of us got something different for our entree and dessert. I had:

- grilled trout with brussels sprouts
- brownie sundae.
- I rarely drink but I had to try their Old Fashioned since it was described as having "bacon-washed bourbon". 

Everything was delicious but the more I paid attention to what other people were ordering I noticed that the popular item seemed to be a fried chicken sandwich.

It's pretty expensive so it would have to be a special occasion for me to come back... but I would! tip: it gets super crowded after 11:30, to the point where it's hard to hear your lunch companions.
author: Aivy C.

description: The food has been consistently good. Each of their dishes has been quite impressive. I would def. put this one down for a business or date night regular.
author: Tiff W.

description:
I was on Check Please Bay Area a LOOONG time ago and this was my restaurant choice (episode 204 if you are interested, and that episode actually won a California Emmy award). I have been Yelping for less long and today I went here for a grab & go sandwich and wanted to update my review and I was not aware of Yelp back in 2006.

In more recent years -they have a "grab & Go sandwich stand outside. Friday is Fried Chicken and I while I was a bit disappointed they were pre-made, by the time we went across the street and found a place in the shade to enjoy them, they were still warm and I believe superior to either The Chicken Coup or The Bird.
 
My OLD review as posted on the Check Please Bay Area site in 2006 is copy and pasted below:
I've read reviews that say Town Hall is not the kind of place you should go for an intimate date, HOWEVER, I contend that anyone who takes me on a date here is a superstar!
This is one of those places that feels like a big hug when you walk in. Everyone, from the hostess, to the wait staff, to the guy who fills your water glass, is professional, gracious, and welcoming without being stuffy or pretentious. This is exactly the kind of experience I want when dining out.

Three of us started with one of their specialty cocktails, these are a treat -- beautifully presented, and not for the faint of heart, as they can pack quite an alcoholic punch.
Since I'm well aware of their hearty entree sizes, our table spilt three appetizers. We ordered the tomato fondue, which my niece and nephew promptly scarfed down, the crispy tempura-battered squash blossoms bursting with four kinds of gooey cheese, and my favorite appetizer in the world: Faith's warm ham and cheese toast with the jalapeño cream, topped with a perfectly poached egg (probably a heart attack on a plate, but worth the coronary every time).
The braised short ribs were my entree choice. As expected, it was a generous portion, fork tender, beautifully presented, and yummy. My sister had the fried chicken. Tasting one bite wasn't nearly enough, I now want to go back ASAP and order it all for myself. (If I close my eyes as I write this, I can almost taste the crispy, blistered skin, and the super tender meat -- excuse me as I wipe the drool off my keyboard). Each one of us cleaned our plates, which is no easy feat.

Over the years, I have developed a scientific "hierarchy of desserts" ordering protocol -- a gal has to have a system for important decisions.
In order of preference:
1) Anything you have to order BEFORE the meal (this is rare)
2) Anything served warm3) Anything chocolate-based
4) Anything that is "seasonal" (e.g. pumpkin at Thanksgiving time) OR anything that is a regional specialty
5) When all else fails: crème brûlée
Based on the hierarchy, I took charge of dessert and our table spilt three. We ordered the sticky toffee pudding, the jelly doughnut holes, and "SF's best hot chocolate" (I concur, it is SF's best!) Not a bite was left on the table. It's a close call, but I boldly elect the doughnuts as best in show.

The space is open with a lofty, New England feeling. Every detail is thoughtful -- from the rustic breadboxes to the way they present the bill inside an old library book. It is the kind of place I take friends who are visiting from out of town (even my snobby NYC friends!) For a few years, my quest has been to eat at every top 100 restaurant according to the San Francisco Chronicle (the count to date is 49) and this remains my all-time favorite place to dine in SF. I've been to Gary Danko, and Boulevard, among others, but there is something special about Town Hall that keeps me always wanting to go back.
author: Amy W.

description: Have been here a handful of times in the past few years and live in the neighborhood. Service was mediocre from the host staff this time,... we had reservations at 7pm, arrived on time and ended up waiting 30min anyways. Honestly it seemed the hostess just forgot about us! Table service was slow as well, our waiter was very nice and accommodating during the times he acknowledged us which saved the whole experience from being a complete bust. Ordered the cod and it came out completely raw in the middle. I really hate sending food back - but had to in this case. They seemed overly accommodating with this and very apologetic, management sent over complimentary champagne and an appetizer while we waited another 30min for our entree. They did offer to keep my date's food warm while we waited which was a kind gesture. Chicken and waffles is what he had, and it was wonderful although a very large portion! Favorites were the friend Okra and our waiter who was friendly and that's about it,... took about 30min to get our bill after finishing up. The whole dinner lasted 3.5 hours, with only 1 course and a few appetizers. Likely won't be back as there are so many other excellent and unique options nearby!
author: Ashley C.

description: Love love love this place!  Jill is especially amazing, she made our anniversary dinner extra special. The salmon and broccolini are outstanding!  I never pass up the butterscotch pudding. It is my favorite!
author: Tommy M.

description:
So disappointing, We left feeling like we just ate at a TGI Fridays - sub-par food,  lousy service from the bartender (and again from the second (relief?) bartender who helped us). 

Several times the bartender started taking our order and would then walk away as we started to respond - the f?  Who does that? This happened three times! He poured a taste of Pinot for my friend and then, after she asked for a glass, he forgot and we had to remind him (I was already halfway done with my glass of bubbly). He was rude to other servers and just seemed WAY over is head. I understand that bars can be hectic, but WE WERE THE ONLY ONES AT THE BAR and he wasn't busy making other drinks! Regardless, it shouldn't be the guests problem - get your bar in order and hire people who can handle it. He was sloppy. Period.

He didn't write down our order and then came back 10 MINUTES LATER to ask us again because he forgot everything except for one main dish (we ordered 5 items) ! Again, unprofessional and unorganized. If you can't remember an order, then write it down. Quit trying to pretend to have skills that are beyond you.

Our food was mediocre at best: fried okra (tasted like something from Denny's), BBQ shrimp (drowned in a sauce that made them sickly sweet), tuna tartar that was warm and tasteless. Sald was drenched in dressing. Yuck. The one decent items was the side of grilled zucchini.

On top of everything, I got a message from Opentable saying we never checked in - we certainly did - with the hostess - and told her we had a res but would be sitting a the bar instead - she nodded, didn't say a word, and walked away.

We expected more from Town Hall. Will never go back. They really need to hire better staff, from the hostess to the bartenders to the chefs.
author: Christine K.

description:
Back when I first started Yelping, Town Hall was one of the most popular restaurants in SF.  It felt I would hear nothing but good things about the food and reservations always seemed to be a tough get (at normal dinner hours, anyways).  But now?  Oh how times have changed.

Now, I don't necessarily mean that in terms of their food, though I have nothing to compare to.  Rather, I mean in terms of their popularity.  There still was a decent crowd on a Saturday night, but it wasn't exactly a full house either.  Not that I should really complain, since it meant we were able to snag a table for six the afternoon of.  Plus, I finally got to knock Town Hall off my list!

-- TUNA TARTARE with Cornmeal Fried Green Tomatoes, Garlic Chips, Tabasco Green Onion Vinaigrette...$17
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=2IRYGeuG-2GwCRFsKmdbWQ)
Overall, this was a pretty solid dish.  Although the tartare didn't amaze, it was still pretty decent and I liked the varied contrasts of the dish - the saltiness of the sauce, the freshness of the tuna, the spice of the vinaigrette, and the fried crunchiness of the green tomatoes.  

-- TENNSHOOTOE, TN (?) COUNTRY HAM...$18
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=IT4YBScgybGabBO4IiGuww)
I *think* we ordered the Tennshootoe ham, but I'm not sure (my friends picked).  In any case, while I didn't get to try the biscuit (my friend said it was "ehh...okay"), the ham was good!  The cuts were sliced ever so thin, tender, a bit smokey, and just slightly salty (in a good way).

-- ROASTED VEAL MEATBALLS with Potato Puree and Green Peppercorn Sauce...$15
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=Y8bVLI1u56PaeDGwU7UO1Q)
A perfectly fine rendition of a classic combo.  The sauce was great (really peppery/flavorful) and I liked how the meatballs had a nice balance between meaty and light/moist.  Despite all that, I'm not quite sure the dish warrants the price, especially since it wasn't all that amazing.

-- BBQ SHRIMP with Worcestershire Sauce on Garlic Herb Toast...$17
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=RMSpacSdBzuYyAwwaJXRGQ)
Not a bad dish, but, for $17, I was surprised it only came with one piece (albeit topped with a good amount of shrimp).  Even though the shrimp had a nice char on it, inside of the shrimp felt a little overcooked (not very juicy).  I did enjoy the toast (and sauce) quite a bit though.

-- BUTTERMILK MARY'S FRIED CHICKEN with Baked Beans...$27
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=gpEcWOBDRp1q1rYpbjUB0g)
As a whole, the sides were just okay.  I don't recall their exact description, but I do know that the beans were fairly bland.  More importantly though, the chicken was terrific!  All three pieces were juicy, moist, and delicious.  Plus, the batter was just right - not too thick, not too thin, and very crispy.  Not sure it's the best fried chicken I've had, but it's up there.

While the menu does change often, some dishes seem to stay the same or see only mild changes (e.g. the fried chicken is a staple, but the sides will vary).  In any case, there is an abundance of starters and entrees to choose from that is both modern and classic.  Just like with the decor, which makes Town Hall great for just about any occasion, from work dinners to dates.

THREE AND A HALF STARS rounded up, though I initially wasn't so sure.  Town Hall is worthy of four stars based on food alone, but the prices for the starters is a little steep (good thing we were all sharing!).  However, considering how easy parking and reservations were, as well as how nice the service was, Town Hall is still more four stars than three.
author: Mike L.

description: The food was really good but the food took 1.5 hours to come out. Way too long. I did not understand why they did not have any local seafood. We had the oysters but there was not local options. Both the fish and the oysters were from the east coast. Did not make sense when we have so many good options on the west coast.
author: Tracy R.

description: Consistently delicious for YEARS. Tonight I embraced the pork chop, bbq shrimp, meatballs and ham & cheese toast.  Not a one disappointed. The sommelier was amazing as well.  Dessert- on point. LOVE this place.
author: Lisa B.

description:
A recent trip to Seattle reminded me how little of old San Francisco we really have left. Town Hall, however, is in one of the old buildings of the financial district with soaring ceilings and old beams. It can get quite loud in here when it's full and at lunchtime it definitely is. With lots of big groups and work parties, this is one of the few places in this neighborhood where you can meet someone for a nice lunch.

My friend and I decided to share a couple of things, a cheese and ham with egg on top, and the Cobb salad. When the waitress took our order, she asked if we wanted the entree sized salad? Now, the entree sized salad is not on the menu, so we didn't know how much it was or the difference between that one and the one on the menu. So there's this awkward moment before we ultimately say yes. 

They split the salad for us and both were almost the size of an entree. A piece of fried chicken, boiled egg, fresh steamed green beans, and sweet ripe tomatoes. I think it was the best Cobb salad I've ever had but we were both full by the time the egg toast came. This was a strange dish. A ham and cheese sandwich swimming in a Chanel sauce with a fried egg, still runny, On top. There was no way this would travel so we had to eat it even though we were full.

With one iced tea, this was a $45 lunch. A bit pricey but worth it if the company is good. Our waitress was not at all attentive, and seemed afraid to talk to us. My date chose to believe that she had something going on her life and chose to believe him.
author: Angelique L.

description: Great cocktails, friendly service, something for everyone - comfort food to fish!  Cozy and hip atmosphere with brick walls and lively vibe.
author: Victoria H.

description:
After a long day at a technology conference, a couple of coworkers and I decided to grab some dinner close by. Passing this place on a daily basis, I knew this was on my list to try. What a perfect opportunity!

This stand alone building sits in the middle of what seems like huge skyscrapers. You walk in and you're immediately warned that this place is an upscale dining experience. Exposed brick with eclectic art and chandeliers show some personality. Our server was super nice. You can always tell when you're in a fancy place. Service is somewhat relaxed in that they don't really bother you throughout service. It only becomes  a problem if you really need something, as most times they're not even around. We experienced that a little during our service. Not bad though, just noticeable. 

For starters we got:
-Cornmeal fired oysters, Herbsaint spinach puree, Hobbs' bacon and preserved lemon for $15. It was served on a bed of salt. The oysters were good and I liked the fried element. Kind of thought, they did a whole lot more of presentation than what the taste was actually worth, in my opinion.
-Faith's warm ham and cheese toast with a poached egg and jalapeno cream and sides of fried green beans for $14. Now this was AH-MAZE-ING! No fluff to this dish. Just plain ole ham and cheese with eggs and cream sauce. Only difference is, the flavor was on point and so worth the dollar value. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!

For dinner I go:
-Buttermilk fried Mary's chicken, collard greens, cornbread pudding and sausage gravy for $27. I wasn't a huge fan of this dish. My chicken was a bit dry although I did like the collard greens a lot. The cornbread was interested. Huge chunks of corn and it was a bit sweet. I guess I was expecting a traditional cornbread. To me, if you're going make a spin from the classic, it better be good. 

Overall, the place was OK. I would like to try this place again and give it another shot because I didn't NOT like it. The entrees for the most part didn't WOW me as much but I will say one thing: That ham and cheese toast will definitely get me back in that door :)
author: Rockne H.

description: Visiting the area on a business trip and decided to try this place because of the patio area...weather and ambiance were great but the burger was bland,  way undercooked (even though I asked for medium) and the staff was not friendly. My friend asked for something on the side instead of on the sandwich and they didn't accommodate her even though they took note of it. Sorry, wont be back.
author: Elissa M.

description: got the cajun wings and dirty rice for lunch today.  nice portion and good taste.  in the past i've also tried the crispy chicken sandwich and the jambalaya too.  all seem to be very tasty and a decent portion.  the jambalaya was a little on the dry side.  it came with a piece of cornbread.
author: Richard M.

description: I've had really mixed experiences here. The food has always been good, but the service is often aloof or just plain rude (managers included). Once I had half of my steak dinner wrapped up but it turns out it was thrown away. When I asked my server where my box was, she told me it had probably been thrown away instead of boxed, and asked in a snotty way, "What do you want me to do about it?" Another time, my birthday dinner reservation was canceled by the restaurant. They did try to make up for it by sending us the entire menu of desserts compliments of the house, but it was a bummer rescheduling my birthday. Overall, I won't be returning, there are just too many great restaurants to choose from.
author: L. M.

description:
My wife and another couple dined at Town Hall on Feb. 11.  While the meal was fine the way they have handled a billing error is nothing short of horrible.  In short, I was double billed on my credit card for the meal.  When I received my credit statement in March I called them up to explain and they politely apologized and agreed to remove the charge from my card.  A month later, nothing.  I then called again this week, left my name and number and no call back.

We all make mistakes, how we deal with those mistakes is a measure of our character.  In this case, I find the lack of follow through and disregard for doing the right thing to speak volumes about the character of this establishment.  

I will, of course, be challenging this expense on my card, but it would have been so much easier for me and them to fix this without putting me through that effort.  

I hope they contact me so that I might update this with resolution.

UPDATE:  Town Hall has contacted me and this has been resolved.  They were apologetic and appropriate in their dealings.
author: Seth W.
