description: Some of the food dishes were really good such as the Salmon for two (kind of annoying you cannot order a single entree portion) and the prawns appetizer was very well done.  Overall you will find good food here and nice drinks from the bar.  The two star beat down is based on the service which seems to be a recurring theme from some of the other reviews I have read.  Our waitress was very attentive and gracious.  We left her a solid tip because of her attitude.  She really seemed to care about our experience.  The issue is with the kitchen.  We waited (restaurant was half full) almost 40 minutes to get our appetizers and 30 minutes to get our first round of drinks.  Enuf said.  I hope they can fix that as everything else was fine.
author: Greg S.

description: Lively atmosphere delicious food. Great service. Temperature dropped considerably when the crowd thinned. But other than being cold, we really enjoyed our dinner.
author: Heidi T.

description: Overall I was very pleased with this restaurant. We had a reservation and were seated promptly. We started out with a couple of cocktails, I ordered the Rue 342 and my friend had the Rosemary's Baby. Both were good, but for the second round I decided to go with Rosemary's Baby as well. We placed our orders and the food didn't take very long to arrive. We ordered the stuffed piquillo peppers which were by far the best thing we ordered. The flavors and textures were perfect. For my main course I went with the ribs, which were good.... Flavor was good, fairly tender.... But they weren't anything I'd go out of my way to get again, they were served with an amazing corn bread, like possibly the best corn bread I've ever had.... Which may have had a great deal to do with the butter it was drenched in, delicious! The ribs also came with coleslaw, which wasn't overly watery... But I basically took one bite and let the rest. Over all the service was decent.... But at some point between the app and the main course our waitress asked if we wanted another round, I told her what I wanted and for whatever reason she automatically assumed my friend wanted the same exact thing  or nothing and QUICKLY walked off before he could place an order. Giving her the benefit of the doubt I assumed that she assumed he didn't want anything, but a short while later two of the exact same cocktails came out. I was very specific and said "I WILL HAVE" not we, don't automatically assume that just because one person would like something the other person wants the exact same thing. Aside from that, the meal was good... But her service could definitely use improvement.
author: Iris J.

description:
Delicious food and a very helpful wait staff
The reason for 4 stars is that it is tough to get around within the restaurant due to the proximity of other tables which also makes it extremely loud during peak times.
author: Mike T.

description: Our plan: dinner at 9:45 followed by fireworks to ring in the new year. Reality: stuck in the restaurant until 12:30 eating dinner- the last table to leave the restaurant ( not by choice). After being seated almost an hour past our reservation, with extremely slow service... the kitchen ran out of the only vegetarian entree and we were told we would instead receive "a plate of leftover vegetables". They also messed up some of our order. No apologies, no comps, just a ruined NYE. No more Town Hall for our group...
author: Deanna S.

description:
I appreciated that  the restaurant was very accommodating  to host a large party for a last minute request. They sat us at the community table, which is partly cordoned off from the rest of the restaurant. Very nice. 

For the most part, the food was good. At least the food that showed up was good. The portions were very big. The fried chicken was delicious, the waffles were just okay. The drink menu had a good variety.
 
 So,  why three stars?? Our server ... mixed up the drinks, took the order for appetizers which never showed up, took order for side dishes which were out of stock, and at the end only compensated us for the cornbread, which she talked us into ordering, but we didn't want. She brought the wrong drink for someone and was arguing with him that he made the mistake,  not her.
author: Heidi Y.

description:
Awesome lunch spot! All of their food is great. They also have lots of selections for drinks. My group got the fried okra to start... So delicious! A nice, light breading and a good sauce to go with it. For my entree, I had the tuna tartare. Very, very delicious. Super flavorful and served with fried green tomatoes! Yummy!

Great service too.
author: Julia M.

description:
I came here with some coworkers for lunch. I got a grilled shrimp Asian salad and a side of jalapeño cornbread. The salad was gooood and included a lot of different fruits veggies that worked very well together. BUT the star of my meal
Was def the cornbread - I get misty eyed just thinking about it ohmygosh - it's on the pricier side but local ingredients done well make it worth it.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
This place deserves the rating it got. As far as location, ambiance, and options - it could go 3 1/2 - 4 stars - but for me the food wasn't spectacular. But you don't have to trust me, there is a lot of stuff I do not eat so my options were VERY limited. Even then, I ordered a goat cheese salad and the goat cheese came in breaded, fried balls. Since I don't eat gluten, I had to eat around it. Benefit of the doubt here - I didn't specify gluten free. But the menu didn't say breaded and fried.

Since there are so many options around, I probably won't be back. It was worth a shot, though.
author: Jess A.

description: Came here at 12:15 with a reservation for lunch. One of the girls was a little late so we sat at our table around 12:25. We were kind of in a rush, so if you are I wouldn't come here. We all ordered the beet salad and then 2 sides: okra and cornbread. We were basically done with our salads by the time the sides came out. The beet salad was ok. The beets were delicious but the greens were very hard to eat. The cornbread and okra were both delicious. The service was slow though, our waiter never came over to check on us or anything. We waited 17 mins for our check to come. So overall, if you have all the time in the world I would come here. If you're in a hurry, I would pass.
author: Michaela M.

description:
Pros:
- Came here for lunch and had the chance to sit outside. Great ambience...perfect combination of some background noise from the street but quiet enough to have conversations. 
- Servers were very courteous and came to check on us frequently. 

Cons:
- Not a great menu for vegetarians. They had only 1 vegetarian entree when I was there. it was average and the serving size was pretty small for the price.
author: Abhi M.

description: Had an outstanding evening @ Town Hall tonight celebrating two celebrations. The food was great and the service was top notch. Timothy was awesome!!!! He took great care of us and gave great recommendations. The pork chop is out of this world. The table also enjoyed enjoyed the endive salad, tuna tartar, grits with Brussels sprouts and sole. Thank you again to Town Hall and Timothy for the gr8 evening
author: Chris P.

description:
First things first. Get the jalapeño cornbread! Cut a large slice for yourself, then pass around the table. There will be none for you on the return. It is spectacular! Buttered, moist, slightly dense with a hint of spice. Oh and there are surprise bits sea salt on top. Amazing!

The food is delicious and the servings are enough to share, or bring the rest home. My group ordered the cornbread and fried okra for appetizers. Who orders okra as an appetizer? I abhor okra. As in I wouldn't touch that slimy madness if it were the last piece of nourishment on earth! Town Hall's fried okra changed my world! The batter was light, not fried to a crisp, but certainly not flaky. Right in the middle perfect. I was rehabilitated! The Aioli sauce was a nice compliment, though  clearly not needed. 

For my lunch choice I went with the Crab Cake BLT. Served on French bread, the crab cake rests in between a remoulade sauce (similar to an aioli or tarter sauce depending on your taste preference), bacon, butter lettuce and grilled tomato with a side of house made chips. Wow! One, I couldn't finish the entire sandwich because it was so big. Two, it was soooooooo good! The crab cake was moist without being watery. The bacon complimented the soft texture of the crab cake perfectly. The chips could have had some salt on them. But hey, there's always table salt. 

Based on the location you can expect most of the diners here to be lunching buddies or partaking in work meetings. I was part of the work meeting crowd. Keep this in mind, as the restaurant can easily be on the louder side. At a table for 5 I had to lean in to hear the person at the head of the table. Their service is a well oiled machine. No time for hesitation. If you even make eye-contact with a waiter, they are at your table. My kinda place.
author: Jaylena P.

description: ehhhhhh - i havent been to town hall in a long time, but decided to stop by for drinks this past friday to celebrate the end of the long week.  the bar was pretty full, but we grabbed the communal table to share with another group and it worked out beautiful.  there was a happy hour menu with some discounted drink options and some bar bites.  we ordered a round of drinks, the cheese plate, and the bbq shrimp.  the drinks were pretty weak to be honest; the cheese platter was nice and everyone enjoyed that.  the server we had looked like she hated her job and had little to no interest in pleasing any of the patrons, so...i will probably not return to town hall for quite some time...
author: Christina L.

description: Hostess asks my name - then disappears and doesn't acknowledge me and leaves me standing there. Then another hostess comes up to me and says when your party gets here we'll seat you.  Fine, I walk back up 10 minutes later and she proceeds to ask me who I am, as if I didn't talk with her 10 minutes ago.  The first thing our waitress tells us is how busy she is after not getting to our table for at least 15 minutes. Then she disappears again... it was one moment after another like this.  I won't be back. Between the noise, the narrow, packed-in like sardines, it just wasn't worth it.
author: Sheryl F.

description:
Great spot for lunch or happy hour, a beautiful space inside and a cozy patio outside. 

Cornbread is awesome as are the biscuits. 

The burger is tasty but a mess.

The fried chicken sandwich is pretty good, but lacked something. Will have to try it again to determine what. 

Did not love the chicken salad entree, the dressing was a little heavy on the vinegar. 

The smoked chicken salad sandwich was amazing. Like a curried chicken lobster roll with bahn mi veggies.
author: Patrick S.

description:
This place gets super packed, so RSVP. They call for confirmation. There's only one entrance and it's where the patio is, I didn't know and walked around.

Meatballs were really good, salad was great as well. The sea bass is super tiny and small, but delicious. Duck was so-so, very filling though. Fried chicken was pretty spot on.

Riesling and beer weren't as great. The signature cocktail was not to my liking. 

Overall, not a bad place for food, but not sure about drinks.
author: Minerva L.

description: Great dinner. I started of with the jambalaya. It's a bit more like a stew than a soup style jambalaya and had a great flavor. I would have expected it to be a little more spicy  but it was still very good. I also have the ribs and the jalapeno corn bread. Talk about a great combo. The ribs are perfectly cooked and the serving size is huge for a place in the city. The place is amazingly noisy but that's not always a bad thing. The staff was very friendly and the bartenders looked like they were very competent.
author: Dave S.

description: Came here with a group of friends to celebrate and was not let down. The food was amazing and the service was top notch. Especially the manager Graham. give that man a raise! made the entire night spectacular
author: Glen Z.

description: Quiet dinner for 4.  We could easily talk, good selection of wines and would defiantly return.  FUN evening
author: Robert P.

description:
Trying to find last minute reservations for a party of 5 on a Saturday night to a half-decent restaurant in the city? Good luck there. A (not so) quick tour through Open Table led me to Town Hall, which at least has a good quantity, if so-so quality, in its Yelp reviews.

Naturally, we arrived promptly at our reservation time, only to be told that the table earmarked for us had a group of people wholly unwilling to depart anytime soon. Thus it was that we found ourselves at the bar for about an hour, waiting for that reservation which was supposed to undermine said wait. (Somewhat) luckily for us, the manager and host were profusely apologetic. We were comped our (very delicious) craft cocktails at the bar, and brought a couple of appetizers gratis as well. I do recommend those crispy okra. Or was it green beans? My memory fades.

Yelp describes Town Hall as American (New), but fancy southern could also be apt. There's a distinct southern influence that permeates the menu, but it's just an influence, not the overwhelming taste and flavor. For example, the barbeque shrimp, my favorite of the appetizers we ordered, had that southern flair but didn't exactly scream N'awlins to me. Oysters are west coast, not Gulf, although that could just be season (or, more likely, proximity).

I thoroughly enjoyed my main course, the Yelp-approved fried chicken. Buttermilk coated, the chicken came in a faux cast iron and was thoroughly huge. Three chicken pieces atop a large heaping of mashed potatoes has my seal of approval. All the mains were big plated and hearty, which I get fits the Southern style.

All in all, Town Hall reminded me of the proliferation of comfort food slash American New restaurants that permeate Chicago. Out there, Ruxbin does it best, but Town Hall is also very reminiscent of places like The Bristol and Carriage House, and much better than overpriced downtown joints that shall remain unmentioned.

But was it worth the hour wait (even with comped alcohols), when we could have picked somewhere more lauded sans reservations while waiting at the bar anyway? I have to say no to that.
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
The last time i came here was about 8 years ago and i remember enjoying the whole experience...ambiance, food, service. 

This visit was just as good except the fried chicken wasn't as good as i remember it. It was good, perfectly cooked and standard but the accompaniment of jambalaya was delicious with great flavors and hints of andouille sausage. Yum! 

Also ordered the fried okra, along with the starter: BBQ shrimp, Worcestershire sauce, garlic herb toast which was FANTASTIC...it was grilled shrimp with a very complex tomato-based sauce which was  worth the carbs and calories!  had i known earlier, i would've just placed another order and made it my meal...it was THAT good

Service was good..waiter was 'no-nonsense' and had the professionalism for more of an upscale-french, fine dining establishment as he was on-point and of the old school on hospitality (not much interaction). Not a bad thing but different as this place being more casual, made the dining more formal.

Reservation for 6:00 and the place was half full but packed by the time we left around 8:30.
author: Cheryl M.

description:
Really enjoy this place. It's pretty solid.
Food, service, and location is fantastic.
In love with the pot de creme  for dessert- it's out of this world!!
author: Azizi A.

description: The food is good but it's located in "The East Cut", which is near the "Tenderloin" in San Francisco.
author: Tad B.

description:
***************** 1588 *************

I haven't been here for sometimes so I was excited to return. We dropped in on the weekend without a reservation but we got lucky with seats at the bar.
Salt House was packed. Candle lights, music, and a lot of laughter, we knew we were in for a good time here. 

Felina, the floor manager was greeted us nicely and recommended us a few highlighted dishes that she thought we would enjoy. Every dish was on point. She even recommended a nice red wine to pair with our steak and a nice margarita drink for my friend. Thank you Felina for the warm hospitality. 

-  BLISTERED PEPPERS - citrus infused maldon salt
pepper 

-  GRILLED LITTLE GEMS - marble potato / queso fresco 
pickled green strawberries / fava avocado purée - a must order

- OCTOPUS - cherry yuzu jus / baby corn 
snap peas / baby sweet potato, a perfectly dish in taste and presentation.

- BEEF CHEEK & RIB-EYE DUO - maitake mushrooms / bonito beef jus garlic potato purée / kohlrabi, delicious, big portion, it was perfect to share.


- CLAM BRAISED LAMB - fava agnolotti / gypsy peppers / fresno chiles xo sauce / purslane - so good.

We also got to meet 1 of the owners Doug. It's nice to see the owner serving you food at the bar. He was attentive and warm to our party. It's refreshing to see that. 

So if you love sitting at the bar, Salt House is a great spot in SoMa.
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
The tuna tartar with fried green tomatoes was amazing.  I love tuna sashimi and blackened tuna but this combination was exceptional.

My main course was good--pork loin.  Not bad but not exciting. Maybe I should have ordered the fried chicken...

The restaurant was packed on a Thursday night at 7pm.  I felt so old.  Most of the customers were younger and in the bar area
author: Joanna S.

description: This restaurant is just simply amazing.   No matter what you order you are in for a treat.  Took my nephew here for the first time this past Wednesday night, with my wife, and we ordered the chicken and waffles, steak with short ribs, and petrale sole.  Everything was cooked perfectly and then the dessert (the famous pot de creme) was fantastic like usual.  I don't want to know how many calories are in it, but at the same time, it is so good that I don't really care.  The atmosphere is always so nice in there.  The service was outstanding and we all left with a smile on our faces.  My nephew said it was the nicest restaurant he has been to for years, and he cannot wait to come again.  Thank you Town Hall for another wonderful dining experience.
author: Douglas A.

description:
A really nice dinner spot, and I was really happy to bring my good friend and boyfriend here to enjoy the fried chicken. To be honest, the chicken wasn't the 5-star-perfection dish I'd remembered from a couple years back. It was still great but I was a tad disappointed.

Service was very professional. Cost was ~$140 for 2 stars, 2 entrees, & 2 desserts - a solid meal for three.

STARTERS: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=tZ6akpkh5IHjDYODPifP5g#tZ6akpkh5IHjDYODPifP5g
* Cornmeal fried oysters, Herbsaint spinach puree, Hobb's bacon, preserved lemon ($15) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=tZ6akpkh5IHjDYODPifP5g#kUzhkv-Vs6QDxzXi35fn0w
Nice thick and crunchy-but-crumbly batter, fresh gooey oysters inside. They were a little small, but the flavors were great.

* Faith's warm ham & cheese toast, poached egg, jalapeno cream ($14) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=tZ6akpkh5IHjDYODPifP5g#3YtFhRHY-qguprmOD0PGPw
Really liked this last time, still did this time around! Definitely comfort food, done really well. A few simple everyday components, placed together to the right balance. Definitely a heavy and filling dish too!

MAIN COURSES
* Buttermilk fried Mary's chicken, broccoli, smashed potatoes, brown butter gravy ($25) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=tZ6akpkh5IHjDYODPifP5g#_Lg-9rk5P8w86hIrvBEvIA
The mashed potatoes were great: chunky, and I love the pieces of potato skin. The chicken had the same thick, crunchy-but-crumbly batter as the oysters. The breast/thighs were a tad, tad dry to be picky. Still definitely a popular dish - someone at just about every table at the restaurant had ordered it.

DESSERTS: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=tZ6akpkh5IHjDYODPifP5g#oGNx5LQQS2m2TnPASF6MJw
* Butterscotch & Chocolate Pot de Creme (topped w/ buttercrunch. $10) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=tZ6akpkh5IHjDYODPifP5g#IcZg24vlIvXIKNDZT7OuhQ
The photos's a little deceiving - there's a layer of the butterscotch on top, and the bottom is all the chocolate. The flavors came together really well, the texture somehow light yet heavy (in a good way!). But the buttercrunch pieces were WAY too hard, and when sharing the dish we had a tough time breaking them apart. They should be broken up smaller.

* Caramelized Banana Icebox Cake (toasted cinnamon filo, chocolate fudge sauce. $10) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=tZ6akpkh5IHjDYODPifP5g#XO5h_F8AqQq7QV5NuPnNNQ
I thought the banana filo cake was great, but I didn't like the frozen aspect of it. I think it would've been a lot better at room temperature, and it being frozen seemed really out of place (as if they'd taken it out of the freezer and forgotten to give it time to thaw). It made the filo a little too crunchy, the cake a little harder to bite into and break apart to share. I couldn't taste the cinnamon too well; it could've had a much stronger balance to be detectable against the strong banana flavors.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Town Hall is pretty much what you expect from a $$$ restaurant in the Financial District. The food is good, restaurant is crowded, and everyone is in business casual. I went with my mentor for lunch and had an experience worth noting.

I ordered the Farro Verde Risotto which was not at all what I imagined and yet was something I really enjoyed. The ingredients were fresh and had a really vibrant taste thanks to the seasonal vegetables. I was expecting something more along the lines of a traditional risotto, but was pleasantly surprised with what came out of the kitchen.

For dessert, we each had the Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Crème. Wow, that was a lot of sugar. I have a major sweet tooth and still couldn't finish. It was a very generous portion that could have easily been shared between the two of us. Very tasty though.
author: Cameron S.

description: This place was pretty amazing. Their food is on the heavier side but still creative with some variations that you can opt for if you are looking for lighter. The wine selection is on point, lots of variety which is what you would expect from a place like this. Service and ambiance were both on point. The lamb shank is pretty much a must have regardless of what else may grab your eye.
author: Megan K.

description: Wanted to try their most unique offering and was pointed towards the ham & cheese toast swimming in jalapeño cream. Very tasty and surely Southern! Cool atmosphere and good service. Now I need a nap at my desk to recover...
author: Andy L.

description: Very good rendition of current New American cuisine without being overly trendy. Oysters are good (so much better than in LA, which is typical of SF in general, but all the seafood we had here was great). They are known for their fried chicken, which is juicy and tender with a crisp skin. I had the cod with Manila clams; fish was perfectly cooked and the clams were little bombs of umami goodness. We split a side of the fried okra along with our oyster; it was the only item that was not amazing. I like okra but I'm not sure that tempura frying really sets it to its best advantage (as compared to pickled, sliced and pan-fried, slow-cooked with spicy tomato sauce, or in gumbo). Pumpkin cheesecake was also very good. Service is of course excellent.
author: Cage H.

description: I'm really excited to add this to the places I'd like to return to in San Francisco.  The biscuits and speck were good enough to get me thinking about reproducing this at home with their recipe book.  The cheese toast and cornbread rounded out a great meal with some broccolini.  Good stuff - this is a reminder to come back. I rather liked the large red and black art pieces hanging as well.
author: Andrew W.

description:
Nice ambiance and good service. Food was hit of miss..but most of our orders were good. We were big party so ended up tasting most of the menu items. 
Good - Brussels sprouts, BBQ shrimp.
author: Chandrika G.

description:
My buddies and I walked into Town Hall, unaware of the restaurant's demographics. Apparently, there were enough baby boomers in there to put a strain on Social Security.

And that's cool, I like dining with older folks and sponge in their wisdom. But maybe because we were three young cats, we feel like we weren't getting the type of customer service that our older counterparts were getting. The waitress just kinda frosted flaked on us for most of the meal, which made dinner a low key challenge. I had to eat my oyster with a butter knife lol.

The food was amazing grace amazing though. I suspect that they drench their vegetables in butter because the broccoli was super soft and super flavorful (comes with the Fried Chicken) My friend also put his stamp of approval on the Brussels sprouts.(comes with the Porkchop)

My favorite part of dinner was stealing my friend's apple sauce.(Porkchop) The sauce was Johnny Appleseed good. Best I've ever had. But then again, I've only had those cafeteria ones to compare it with.

But based on our experience, it seemed as if Town Hall isn't the best place for younger folks. And since I won't be cashing in my 401k for many moons, I don't see myself coming back anytime soon.
author: Ringo M.

description:
So, things generally taste better if you aren't paying for it right? At least that's how it usually goes.  But, I actually really enjoyed my lunch at Town Hall, and of course, the Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Creme did not disappoint.  After all, I ordered the Pulled Chicken Salad to make room for it.  Our server informed me that the salad can be made one of two ways: an entree-sized portion and an appetizer portion.  Needless to say, I chose the entree portion and it was HUGE and fully loaded with chicken! I think there was easily half a chicken that was included with the shredded cabbage and peanut vinaigrette dressing.  My co-worker had the Cubano sandwich and said it was pretty good, but didn't think there was anything overly impressive about it.  And then dessert.  The butterscotch layer covers the chocolate layer, so mix it up and enjoy the creamy goodness that is lunchtime dessert dining.  I

Service was fast and efficient (and the table bread was delicious with softened butter, which I totally appreciate). I'd like to come back here for dinner too.  I don't really know why there are so many mediocre reviews for this place, I actually thought that it was an awesome place to come for lunch and definitely a place I'd come back to!
author: Lisa I.

description: Southern style food with a decent atmosphere. Went with a large group and the ribs  & chicken/waffles were the hit items at the table. You can make reservations on open table which is good since so many places in the city don't let you.
author: Leah G.

description: After a morning of museum hopping, we decided to have a late lunch @ Town Hall. Since it was Valentines Day, I was sure we'd run into a large crowd. Lunchtime was surprisingly perfect! We both had delicious cocktails, ( :-) to day drinking) then ordered the fried okra as an appetizer. I love okra! It was paired with a tangy mustard-like dipping sauce. For lunch we ordered the duck salad and the trout. The duck salad was a treat to the palate. A bit salty but overall, delicious. The trout was served with Brussels sprouts and bacon bits, making it an enjoyable light tasty meal. The atmosphere had a vintage, brick saloon feel with detailed decor on the mirrors, and beautiful carved wood armoires. Our waitress was polite and she always made sure our glasses were filled with water. I'd come back, possibly for dinner the next time.
author: Janelle D.

description: Problem with the service at Town Hall.  My waiter spilled a drink on my coat.  Their response was to acknowledge the spill and offer to shake out the liquid on my coat.  No apology, didn't alert the manager, and no compensation offered to clean the coat.
author: C.J. T.

description:
Decent food, good service.  Slightly overpriced for the quality of the food.

Get:
--Tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes.  Spicy mayo on the fried green tomatoes rally ties this dish together.
--sweet and spicy chicken wings with queso fresco.  Very saucy and a great crunchy outside. 
--butterscotch and chocolate pot du creme with toffee crisps.  Generous portion size.  Didn't think I'd want more than a spoonful, but I ended up eating so much of it--it was that good!

Pass:
--sea bass.  Overcooked and flavors didn't mesh together very well.  I generally like chive oil, and this dish needed much more of it to moisten up the dry fish.
--ribs.  They looked fantastic because they were huge, however my fellow diners said they were dry and lacking some flavor.

BASICALLY, only come here for appetizers and dessert.
author: Vanessa O.

description: Stairs to the private dining room upstairs smelled poopy, I bet there's an amazing story there.  Real tea lights at the table.  The entrance has two high tables in the entrance.  Not much space to stand, they use every square foot.  I felt like a total weirdo.
author: Defn N.

description:
It was a blur of a meal. I hadn't eaten since that morning and by dinnertime, all I wanted was something (anything!) edible. I mean, a slow-simmered leather shoe would've done the trick. The craptastic pancakes at IHOP would've done just fine. Pebbles! I would've eaten a fistful of pebbles.

Thankfully, the black cod was fantastic. I mean, I think it would've been pretty good if I wasn't starving. But I was; therefore, it was the most amazing thing I'd had all week.

So go hungry. And leave happy. Wait...
author: Adena B.

description: Waited at a table for ten minutes with no service. Looked at the menu and realized that 90% of the menu is seafood. Maybe you should include seafood somewhere in your restaurant's name or description!
author: Luis P.

description:
This was our first time at Town Hall. The menu is pretty crazy.... hard
to know what to order. We were there on New Year's Eve. The server
was very busy, but did a great job. The food was good, the bread they
serve was excellent. The steak was so tender, cooked perfectly, pork not so much. 
The reason I am giving this place a 5 star was because our server and
the entire bar staff saved the day for me when my phone kept dying and
I couldn't get Uber/Lyft after Midnight. They not only offered their personal cell phone to help me out, but plugged in my cell phone at the bar. They could not have been nicer, compassionate and they even let me stay inside until an Uber came. It was freezing outside. They were closed. You could tell that they got along with each other. Every employee made sure that I was OK.... not exaggerating.
So, would I go back? Yes. When you have employee's like this, you have a super business.
author: T. M.

description:
EDIT: After my initial review, the owner reached out and was very apologetic. It was basically a perfect response that acknowledged the issues and tried to make it right. A very admirable response. I wouldn't let my previous experience hold me back from checking them out again.


So I'm going to give them some benefit of the doubt here since we were a party of 7 and it was the lunch rush...but...

The service was not good at all here. Here are some lowlights:

1. We didn't get our drinks (3 bottles of beer...not complicated) until 30 mins after we were seated. Some of the food came out before those came.
2. We ordered okra for the table as an appetizer. Never came.
3. We ordered a ginger ale. Never came
4. We asked for more bread 3 times before they finally brought some.
5. They brought me the wrong meal...twice. And they just seemed to have no clue what anyone at the table ordered.
6. Our server disappeared and never checked up on us until we were all done eating and yes we needed more water.

Maybe our server was new or something, but they need to work on the lunch time rush service. They've been here for years so this shouldn't be a surprise. Anyway, that being said, the food was actually very tasty and I enjoyed it once it came.
author: Tim O.

description: This place is really good. Like really really good...got the fried chicken sandwich with chips during a broker lunch.  The chicken was tender and juicy.  Went well with the chips.  Atmosphere is lively and bustling, I love that.  Colleagues ordered the gumbo and it looked AMAZING. but I didn't get to try...next time! Town Hall really hits the spot. Go!
author: Jill P.

description:
First things first.  Stay far away from this restaurant.  For the amount of money they charge, and the terrible customer service, go elsewhere.  There is a reason why other $$$ restaurants need to be booked far in advance, and this place you can get a reservation the same day.

Specifically beware of ordering a glass of sparkling water.  My friend did, and the next thing we know we are charged $36 for 4 bottles of bottled water.  The food was average or below average in my opinion.  The cornbread is covered in salt...shouldn't it be served with a sweet honey butter.  Salt is a complete contradiction to cornbread.  The tuna tartare was average at best and the fried green tomatoes had a terrible aftertaste.  I had the rockfish and it was so bland.  Don't they taste their food before it comes out of the kitchen?????

And don't waste your time advising them that you have a special birthday.  Because they bring you out a sort of defrosted cupcake with frosting that is still hard like a rock.  That is cheap...why wouldn't they serve you one of their fresh desserts????

Not everything was awful, one person loved her fried chicken and my other friend is on a very strict diet and they were very good about working with her...but how difficult is it to fill a plate with asparagus and arugela.

Then to top it off the restaurant manager argued with us, not once but twice and actually followed us out of the place and told us how many times we interrupted him, while waving his fingers in our faces and telling my friend "you interrupted me twice!!!!!"  If a restaurant screws up this badly, don't you think their job is to be apologetic and offer some good will...anything a free dessert, another opportunity to come in so they can make it better for us, a glass of wine...anything.  But all we got were more insults and finger pointing.

And for this our bill was over $400 - RIP OFF!!!!!!!!!

I'm telling you - STAY AWAY!!!!!!
author: Judie L.

description:
Food was great ! Service was awful.
Waiting over 30 mins after apps to arrive . Server never checked on us. 
Just not worth the $$ unless on company dime.
author: Alison W.

description: My husband I had an early dinner here and greatly enjoyed it. I am a sucker for chicken and waffles and the dish did not disappoint. My husband had the ribs and they were very tasty. Nice wine list and excellent service. Highly recommended.
author: Patricia E.

description: Had an excellent date night here! The atmosphere and decor is terrific, a really great space. The food was mostly excellent. The petrali sole entree and butter lettuce starter were fine, but the incredible (and decadent) bacon wrapped oysters and red trout stole the show! Warm and polite service sealed the deal. We will definitely be back!
author: Alex J.

description: Boom!  Bomb like donkey Kong!  Am and PM kitchen food on point and super good!  Came in Friday night semi-casual, bartender yogev and all staff were super friendly and professional!  These guys all deserve raises!!!
author: Christopher D.

description:
Best food I have had in San Francisco....and I have paid much more for less elsewhere.

Ribs, Chicken & Waffles, Blacken Salmon, etc
I have visited twice in the last month with small groups, everyone in the group raved about the food.
Hip atmosphere.
author: Tim W.

description:
I liked the ambience and decor

I ordered the fried chicken and the bf ordered the ribs.

Fried chicken comes with gravy collard greens and cornbread pudding. 3 pieces of chicken; thigh, drumstick, and breast. The skin on the chicken was great but the chicken was a little dry and they didn't have much gravy so I asked for some on the side.

The ribs were dry rubbed style with a side of BBQ sauce. They were pretty dry ribs too 

The portions were big but food is mediocre... Don't think I'll be rushing back anytime soon. It's nothing I crave for... I rather pay $2 for Popeyes chicken instead of $20 for their ok chicken with ambience
author: Josie L.

description: Decent food in central location. it's a bit on the pricey side, but Pat is a great bartender who can mix some crazy delicious drinks. Sometimes a bit too loud and may not be the best location for a first date. The shrimps are a bit on the salty side, but the tuna tartare and fried chicken are worth a try. The beans that come with the fried chicken is really good.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
2nd time coming here. First was for lunch and we had a very good experience. So, with that when we were looking for a place for drinks, thought we'd give it a try. Came last night to celebrate a colleague farewell. We ordered drinks which were very slow to come. The waiter seemed completely disinterested in providing any measure of services to us. In fact he passed by our table several times before I finally waved at him to get his attention so my friend could order her drink. 

We were in the side room (tent) which was fine but very loud with street noise. Food (we ordered several appetizers) was good but waiter never bothered to offer or bring a napkin, plates or anything. We asked for water for 4 of us and they brought 2 glasses. Overall not a great experience! Will reconsider before coming back. There are plenty of places in the area who want business.
author: Karen O.

description: Slow service. Terrible food. Unreasonably expensive. There are better places to eat in San Francisco downtown. Give this place a pass.
author: Aditi S.

description: I really wanted to like Townhall. Old School building, contemporary interior, nice beer and wine list, good looking and for the most part great tasting food but the service was just not good. Our waitress was inattentive in a bad way, other waitstaff and the manager had to help with multiple parts of our dinner. Despite the service, if you do go, get the shrimp app and for dinner the fried chicken both were standouts. Also they had a hard to find beer, Pliny the Elder IPA which was excellent.
author: Shawn H.

description:
I stopped by Town Hall for a work lunch/meeting. It's located in the Financial District of San Francisco and seems to be a place where you can easily grab a table for a good meal. That being said my meal was also on the company dime so look up the prices before you stop by to make sure they are within your lunch time budget.

FREQUENCY: I've dined at this establishment once.

FOOD: I ordered the Beer Battered Rock Fish Po' Boy. But let me back up. My boss also ordered the Tuna Tartare, the Heirloom Tomato Salad, Warm Jalapeño Corn Bread. Now growing up I was not a corn bread person but I'll say, get the corn bread if you can. That was delicious. Actually all of the starters were wonderful. I may have enjoyed them more than the entree. Not to say the entree was bad by any means. The Po' Boy was a good sandwich, I've just been to New Orleans (the home of the Po' Boy) and experienced the best. But this is still a good sandwich. High quality ingredients all around that lead to a great food experience.

DRINK: Even though my meal was on the company dime I only had water. Town Hall did have a selection of alcoholic and fountain drinks that I'm sure would satisfy anyone looking for something in that beverage category to quench their thirsts.

ATMOSPHERE: I wouldn't say anything special stood out about the Town Hall atmosphere. Just your standard big restaurant that looks fancier than your average big restaurant. Tables, a bar, and wood. Its not bad, just nothing spectacular that I noticed.

STAFF: The staff was incredibly knowledgable of the menu and offered several suggestions to a large group with a lot of questions. I truly appreciate a waiter than can not only offer suggestions but offer suggestions that turn out to be good. I was very pleased with the service.

PAYMENT: Credit cards or cash were acceptable (but I didn't have to pay!).

Town Hall was a great place for a work lunch paid for by someone else. I don't know if I'd stop by here just for a normal meal unless I suddenly get a nice promotion. I wouldn't mind stopping by again to see how they handle happy hour. But if you've got the money or are looking for somewhere to plan an event this could be a great spot for you.
author: Christopher D.

description: Attended a private party here and everything was excellent. Service was extremely attentive. The restaurant itself is nicely decorated. Food was perfect. Get the fried chicken!
author: Jennifer D.

description: Once again, the best Mardi Gras party in San Francisco. Year after year, the entire staff was fantastic. A friendly smile, prompt service, great dishes and great space makes Town Hall a place to consider not just for Mardi Gras, but every occassion. The outdoor space is especially cozy and fun for small and large groups alike.
author: Michael G.

description:
They started off on a great note from the get-go because they easily accommodated my party of four when we showed up 45mins earlier than my reservation. Always a plus!

I tried to order as many recs from my fellow Yelpers as I could. In order of best tasting to just okay:
-Cheese & ham toast
-Fried okra
-Cornbread
-Fried chicken 
-Tuna tartare

Let's go from bottom to top starting with the tartare. It was a bit too salty for me. The fried green tomatoes that came with it were a nice touch. Next, chicken. I know, I know this might be controversial because I think they're known for their fried chicken, but it wasn't too memorable IMO. The batter was too thick for my liking. Although the meat itself was juicy, the thick coating of batter made me feel like I needed ketchup or another kind of condiment to wash it down. Does that make sense? They do give you a tiny cup of gravy but I don't usually eat gravy with fried chicken (sue me). But shout out to those potatoes gratin! Best thing on the plate. If they offered that as a side I'd order it in a heartbeat.

Cornbread was good. Couldn't really taste the jalapeño but still yummy. Next, okra! That cilantro aioli makes that side! It is superb. If I were them, I'd bottle it up and sell it to the masses. They'd make a killing. Last, but certainly not least, that famous cheese and ham toast. Lemme tell you, people. It lives up to the hype! Some parts were crispy, some soft. Toasted cheese here, stringy cheese there. And the jalapeño cream, the friggin cream! I'm sure it's unhealthy as a mf'er but it is to die for. Two thumbs up!

Only gripe was the wait time for our entrees but our waitress did inform us about how packed the kitchen was and always stopped by to give us a food update. Can I just say that all service people should do this! Customers truly appreciate being informed of reasons for delay. 9 times out of 10 we will understand the issue and go with the flow. I've worked in the food industry for over a decade so I completely understand hiccups in the figurative (and sometimes even literal) machine. So service is top notch!

Bottom line, will I come back? Probably not. Alright, alright. Don't get your panties in a twist. My reasons are financial. It's not your typical diner; you have to shell out some of that paper if you wanna eat here . However, I do highly recommend this to all the full-pocketed individuals out there. If you go, can you bring me some cheese toast? K thaaaaaaaanks.
author: Abigail D.

description:
Negative happy hour experience- uneven, inattentive service. 
I joined table of 3 friends about 10 minutes after they arrived last night. They got there drinks in a timely manner. 

For the first 10-15 minutes sitting at table, server passed by me 4 times to attend to table of 8, mostly younger women. I could see he was busy. What I looking for was a quick acknowledgement that he saw me and would get to me soon. 

Finally, I waved him down. Big mistake! He responded curtly that he would get to me, and from there we had a number of hiccups. 

He brought my drink order, but not the water I requested. We ordered two items- pimento cheese and fries. Said that fries could not be ordered after 5 pm, when nowhere on the bar menu (4-6 pm) was that stated. He said he would check with kitchen. He came back and said good news, we could get fries. The fries came very quickly, but no plates and napkins were brought. The pimento cheese never came.

Again, we flagged him down, and ordered 3 more appetizers. At the end, he attempted to be friendly before bringing the bill, which  ran $150+. Hey, I get happy hours are busy times. This was just not the expected experience for the price point.
author: Judy M.

description:
Once you eventually make it inside-- the door isn't at the corner as you'd think but by the bar (if you think you are going in a back entrance you are going the right way)-- you'll get delicious food in a fun atmosphere.  Cocktails were okay, decent wine list.  The portion sizes (for appetizers and entrees) are on the bigger side.

I saw many reviews mentioning slow service- we didn't have that (we went for a Friday dinner around 6:30pm), but our server did seem relatively new to serving and was building confidence.  It didn't detract from our experience and at no point were we frustrated with the pace of the service.
author: Amy J.

description: The NY steak with blue cheese is pretty good but the service was pretty slow. Our server was inattentive and  didn't fulfill some requests we asked for like refilling our water.
author: Thomas N.

description:
A San Francisco classic...and it's a classic for a reason. 

We ordered:
- Shared appetizers: Ham and cheese toast (not easy to share) and pimento cheese and crostini (delish!)
- Quail, andouille sausage and potato cake: I wanted a healthier option than my normal fried chicken order, and this is marginally healthier, but it wasn't that great. It was fine but nothing to write home about. 

This is a reminder to myself to order the fried chicken. I always order the fried chicken for a reason, and that's because it's crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside...just like fried chicken should be. 

Service was really great, friendly and patient for our big group of girls who were spending time catching up.
author: Wendy L.

description: Eat at the bar!! Very friendly and warm. Good crowd at night.  Very good Rueben or Chicken Sandwich for lunch and fried Chicken for dinner ( get Mashed Potatoes instead of waffle).  Menu is limited.  Table service reputed very bad.
author: Richard S.

description: Awesome place, great menu, decadent desserts. Really good for work events, maybe a bit too stiff for gathering with good friends.
author: Alexander G.

description:
FANTASTIC buttermilk fried chicken!  Chicken was very moist and crispy on the outside from thin coat of batter.  It's been awhile since I had a great piece of moist fried chicken.  Last time I had one was from Craftbar NYC.  Portion was huge for a tiny girl like myself.  It came with 3-4 pieces of chicken, mashed potatoes, and succotash.  

I was there on a Thursday night and restaurant was very busy.  I suggest you make a reservation!
author: Kim S.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday night around 7:45.  The place was moderately busy and they had the outdoor section open (intimate patio with 8-10 tables).  They had the heat lamps on, but it was way too warm out for them.  They graciously turned them off upon request. 

We started with Old Fashioned's.  Later we ordered Pimento Cheese app and the Crispy Okra side.  Neither dish was spectacular. I'm not really a fan of pimento cheese so I could be biased there.  They used what seemed like a cornmeal batter (as opposed to breadcrumbs) for the okra, which crumbled off completely with one bite.  The flavor was alright though and presentation was on point.  

The old Fashioned's were some of the best I've had in SF.  We ordered a second round without taking another look at the drink menu. I give 4 stars mostly for the old fashioned's, service and general ambiance.  The two food items we had were off that night, but maybe the rest of the menu makes up for it.  I'll be back for sure regardless.
author: Jason K.

description: Wow.
author: Markus N.

description: The chef takes great care in selecting the best quality ingredients for his menu. The menu offers a variety of mouth-watering dishes. The staff is very attentive  and pleasant. I had such a lovely dining experience. Simply exquisite.
author: J J.

description: Came here a few times (NYE, friend's birthday) both instances were great for the occasion. Ambiance is wonderful, quiet music, modest lighting, and great acoustics. Get the mini biscuits with pepper jelly, butter, and choice of prosciutto. Also amazing are the cocktails, particularly those with the spicy hint--I'm guessing some sort of chili/pepper tincture all those "speakeasies" are using these days. Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Crème is a must for dessert, especially with the thick slabs of toffee garnish. Great for large or small groups, pleasant atmosphere and very friendly and knowledgable staff. Definitely on the top of my recommendations list for out-of-towners. Grab a cookbook on the way out for their recipes.
author: Alison A.

description:
4.5 stars. 

Built more than a century ago in what was originally the Marine Electric warehouse, Townhall serves up some Southern inspired, catered to the California palette, classic comfort food eats. 

Located in the heart of the trendy SOMA, this rustic building with it's exposed brick walls, simple wood seating, and dandelion-like chandeliers was dimly lit and full of the 20-40 yr old J.Crew crowd. 

Came with my boys as a group of 3 after watching the Niner game at a nearby bar. I highly recommend sharing their dishes family style. 

*BBQ SHRIMP - $15 - signature dish! 5/5
5 juicy peeled shrimp atop a crispy herb toast and smothered in this incredibly flavorful cajun lava. I say lava since the beer based sauce spiked with "worse-ta-sure" had heat! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=8RrRaFtwSD6bEdhjRJ_mKg)

*HAM AND CHEESE TOAST w/jalapeno cream - $13 4.5/5
A gently poached egg above toast smothered in jalapeno cream. Sweet, salty, spicy, creamy, gooey, crispy. Better believe we asked for more house bread to sop up the rest of that creamy white goo. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=h8hZATXdSWL4u9jLqaD09g)

*BUTTERMILK FRIED CHICKEN - $25 4/5
Perfectly cooked, juicy on the inside, crispy skin on the outside, rosemary spiked, chicken pieces (drum, thigh, breast). Escorted by garlic mashed and broccoli. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=QhK306EGa8mTUCTZqq_bmA#QhK306EGa8mTUCTZqq_bmA)

*GRILLED PORK CHOP - $29 3.75/5
Juicy, bone-in chop sitting above a cherry gastrique and apple and corn? chutney. Sounds fancy, tastes homely. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?userid=pDfL8xt8F8ls0-kQIG_ADg#QTu1Y0FEqHYnX_l7et3xaA)

*NY STEAK - $31  3.75/5
I prefer ribeyes but this leaner cut was nicely seared and seasoned and served a perfect medium rare. Topped with a fried quail egg. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=-NNXcEJt5A39k_GhO2hVaQ)

*Our waiter even hooked us up with their signature chocolate butterscotch pot de creme. Creamy butterscotch pudding layered over rich dark chocolate pudding, topped with shards of butter-crunch toffee served in an oversized bowl. 

Fancy yet unpretentious. Given great conversation we never felt rushed and we were among the last to leave. Service was both attentive and engaging. Definitely a great guys night out spot. You're going to leave well fed. My kinda place.

4.5 stars, the sum is greater than the individual parts. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=BGxwjVjDjnplpsPD-lm2Uw#BGxwjVjDjnplpsPD-lm2Uw)
author: Earl G.

description:
I ate here while interviewing for another job under the radar. I did not realize until I accepted the job that this was a hub for financial folks in the area. Man man, I got lucky.

Food was great and so was the service. And I am told you can now order boxed lunches. I have not complaints for this spot. Now that I am here, I love running into people. I'm just glad I didn't when I was a prospect! I don't need all that egg on my face. Put the egg on my plate!
author: Joseph S.

description:
I don't get why Town Hall gets an average 3.5 stars on Yelp.  This place is amazing if you love Southern comfort food.  It's also rather unique - not many other restaurants in the city that offer a similar menu.
Favorites include: the ham board (assortment of ham charcuterie) with biscuits, pimento cheese, fried chicken, ham and cheese toast, and the St. Louis style BBQ ribs.
author: Lisa L.

description:
I came here with friends after going to the theatre and I have to say-- it was an awesome night.  The show was great, but DINNER WAS THE WINNER!  This place is amazing and has an incredible team of waitstaff, bartenders, hosts, etc.  Our host was a really cool woman with short blond hair and lots of intellectual style when it came to the food and drink.  She knew how to sell the food to us, and is a gem.  The rest of the staff is great, as well.  At one point, I had to go to the bathroom, and as I got up to head down the hall, at least 4 of them pointed me in the right direction politely-- without me even having to tell them what I was looking for.

And... The FOOD!  Pretty pricey, but worth it (although this is probably because I wasn't the one paying).  The Butter Lettuce salad was divine, the bread was fresh, the Brussel Sprouts were heavenly, the Vegetable Pozole was on-point, and the Boston Cream Pie, though very untraditional, was wonderful.

Great place.  I encourage you to make reservations, though.  It's popular for good reason!
author: Christy C.

description:
Town Hall reminds me of UP, Mr. Fredricksen's house, how it is right smack in the middle of construction.

Food comes out slow but with good company, it's not so bad. We ordered the fried okra, roasted brussel sprouts and jalapeño cornbread as our appetizers. They were all good but I would recommend the okra above anything else. I split the hamburger http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco#iO98tjkOeUuDNpLx9HWq6g and the fried chicken biscuit with a coworker. The hamburger was delicious (bacon and avocado yumm), the fries were warm-ish, I prefer hot hot fries. The fried chicken biscuit, I expected more chicken and less biscuit, too much bread overall. For dessert we had the butterscotch and dark chocolate pot de creme, gingerbread?, and hot chocolate. The hot chocolate is a medley of 3 types of chocolate much like the ones you would find in France. It was rich, very rich and it came with a mint french macaron. I would recommend splitting the hot chocolate with at least 3 people, it's so rich, and don't even try finishing it yourself bleh. It's good, but all you want is a sip, not an entire cup. Butterscotch and dark chocolate pudding yummm, I could eat this for days. The gingerbread, not so much of a fan but the people I was with liked it, not my kind of thing.

Overall, I would recommend this place if you're in the area. The decor is pretty an it's nice to go downtown once in a while.
author: Kylie L.

description:
I love the western environment feel. It is a perfect place to dine if you have a game at AT&T park or checking out other SOMA bars after. I would highly recommend the gnocchi or the grilled skirt steak AWESOME! Great for group dinners or even dates.

If you're not on that diet and feel like vegetating I would recommend the Friend Mary's chicken (they're known for that).  I thought the wine selection was so-so. 

Overall great environment, great staff and good food.
author: Kunal T.

description: Came here for lunch yesterday with a former co-worker.  It is within walking distance of both of our offices, and he found out they have Pliny the Elder available.  The food was tasty, and we both had 2 Plinys before they ran out.  But it was quite expensive for a lunch. I'll come back for the Pliny, but not sure I can afford lunch here on any type of regular basis!.  Also, our server was awesome!  Very friendly and helpful (told us they were running out of Pliny after we ordered, so we immediately put in an order for 2 more before they ran out).
author: Mike O.

description:
Oh my goodness! Why did I not try this place sooner?! My girlfriends didn't quite recommend this place but I think I know why. It's more of a happy hour, after work FiDi crowd (think they are cool about this) but the issue is, they serve amazing southern style American- a.k.a disgustingly good high calorie dishes. As a self-declared foodie, I have no issue with that! 

Faith Warm Ham and Cheese Toast with Poached egg and jalapeño cream is so damn good! I was there for dinner so when this was recommended, my initial reaction was 'meh', (as anything with eggs to me feels like a brunch menu) but after a bite, I was just blown away. The smooth cream with a little jalapeño kick compliments the crispy toast and the flowing yolk from the poached egg... adds intensity to the flavour. I'm not even going to mention about the fried okra. 

Buttermilk fried chicken was so tender and cooked to perfection. Good quality chicken was used. 

Good sized meals and the bartender was very nice and attentive. 

The gentleman next to us ordered the BBQ Shrimp and I can't get my mind off it. Will be back very soon to try it out.  

I'm adding this place as one of my favourite place for comfort foods in SF.
author: Bomin K.

description:
Came here on New Years and just had a comically bad experience. Walking in the whole place had the vibe of a restaurant long passed its prime, I can't put my finger on exactly what it was, but I assume the city agrees given that we were able to get new years reservations on the 30th.  One of the waiter's was dressed in an all red outfit complete with top hat and shirt unbuttoned halfway to his navel (probably not coincidentally later in the night I heard him having a tough time with his nasal spray in a bathroom stall).  

I ordered the bacon old fashioned and asked them to go easy on the maple simple syrup. What I received was kind of a weird chalky tasting mess. My friend's girlfriend asked for a normal manhattan because she did not like bacon, the server then proceeded to put both hands on her and thank her for being the first person he had net who did not like bacon, it was just creepy and weird.

The food was unremarkable in that it was essentially bad across the board. I had the fried chicken which for 30 dollars you would expect for quality higher than KFC, sadly, it was not to be. They fried oysters were overbreaded and did not taste fresh. There really was not a single dish that we enjoyed, combined with the poor cocktails and service I don't think I will ever be returning.
author: Norman A.

description: We went for a corporate lunch recently, booked a table for eight and our party had to be split up even though they could have easily joined tables to accommodate our group. It's a huge venue so I'm not sure why they were resisting so hard. Additionally the waitress was very rude to one of my colleagues and was slamming the water glasses on the table! Just disappointed at they attitude and the food is good but nothing to write home about especially when your experience is affected by general obnoxious behavior
author: N J.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed Town Hall previously.  Since starting my current position on Treasure Island nearly 8 years ago, I have lunched at Town Hall probably 25+ times.  It happens to be the closest restaurant for me to reach directly off of the Fremont exit when crossing the Bay Bridge, but it's strength rests in it's kitchen and not just it's location. 

Over the course of my many lunch visits, I have splurged on a number of 3 course leisurely meals as well as 'in-and-out' bar counter meals, and they have always delivered on all fronts whether or not I had time constraints.  I've only visited for a few dinners but those have been great as well.  From the delicious Acme breads, to their soups, butter lettuce salads, ahi tuna tartars (w/fried green tomatoes) , jalapeno cornbreads, to delicious chicken sandwiches and fish entrees, I have never had a disappointing experience.  Of course some meals I have enjoyed more than others, but there was never a meal with any sort of disfunction- everything is well orchestrated, generously sized, very well presented, and very flavorful.  

Biggest win in the area and best bang for the buck.  Street parking isn't too bad within 2-3 blocks of the restaurant during week days.  Reservations recommended for parties of 2+ as there is a pretty packed house for lunch, but there are also a number of bar spots as well as a large shared table, so it's usually not complicated to get a spot fairly quickly.  I'll surely be back again soon.
author: Andy S.

description:
I've heard several good things about this place but overall it was quite a disappointing meal. The ahi tuna tartare appetizer was spot on, but aside from that the rest the dishes we ordered were far below standard. We ordered the new york steak, seafood stew, and the salmon. I asked for my steak medium rare and it came out medium to well done... so i sent it back. They brought it back and it was STILL pretty much well-done. At this point i didn't want to send it back yet another time, so i just sucked it up and ate it. The salmon was way over cooked as well, and the seafood stew was just alright. If it wasn't for everything being over cooked, i think the flavoring of their dishes were pretty good. 

Good thing we ordered 2 bottles of wine - definitely the highlight of our meal :)
author: Angela K.

description: I hate the napkins at Town Hall. I haven't been in a few years and now I remember why. Their cheap white cloth napkins poop lint all over my clothes.
author: Rayu R.

description:
My friends and I came here the other night because it's one of the few places in SF that will take a reservation for a party of 16. Beware, for larger parties you get a limited menu that does not have all their dishes (e.g. fried chicken). 

However, I got lucky that night. To begin with the menu isn't huge, and that night they already ran out of the pork tenderloin so I asked the waitress if there was any way I could get the fried chicken even though it wasn't on our menu. Luckily, she was able to pull through!

The fried chicken is some of the best I've ever had. It comes with three pieces: thigh, breast, and drumstick. The chicken was fried perfectly without feeling greasy leaving incredible tender meat inside. I'm all about the dark meat, but even the breast was heavenly. 

So why the three stars? Our group of 16 ordered everything on the menu and had a little taste of everything. Aside from the fried chicken, I thought everything else was mediocre southern food. Nothing was horrible, but for the price point, I was expecting a lot more. We had a huge group and I liked how we had our own section in one corner of the restaurant.
author: Cindy A.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Wednesday night, and it was PACKED (be sure to make reservations if coming here for dinner!)

Service was professional, though all of the servers appeared a bit rushed/overwhelmed. Perhaps more/better staffing would be helpful?

Definitely get the biscuits with prosciutto and pepper jelly.

Do not get the mixed green salad. It wasn't bad, but it wasn't worth the money. It's a heaping helping of greens with light dressing and slivered almonds. Nothing special. Certainly nothing worth $11.

Do get the halibut. It comes out beautifully presented and is lightly battered and fried. The texture was perfect, and the fish was very fresh. Do not wear light-colored clothing if you're a clumsy eater like me. I dropped a piece of halibut from my fork into the sauce, and it splashed onto my super-cute blouse :(

Noise level was definitely loud because it was so packed (do not expect an intimate setting here, at least on a Wednesday night). I found myself raising my voice a lot and straining to hear my date.
author: Chia-Fen Y.

description: Grabbed lunch from the stand one day. Super convenient and reasonably priced. It was pulled pork day, and I'd get it again. Opted for a side of the potato salad too, but when I got back to the office I realized they gave me two sides of cole slaw, instead of one each. Slaw looked good, but not really my thing. Next time I'll check before I get too far.
author: Jason D.

description:
The food is heavy and Southern-inspired, but I did enjoy the ham and cheese toast, with a poached egg, drenched in jalapeno cream. Dinner was mostly a disappointment after the appetizer. The main courses were anywhere from inedible to average at best. My flounder dish was overwhelmed by a spicy sauce. The food was only recognizable through its textures, while the flavor was completely one note. The soft shell crab and pork belly had the best flavor, while the duck breast entree had the largest portion size. The cigar-shaped jalapeno cornbread was tiny and not worth the $6. 

Waiters are a good reflection of how good a restaurant is. When they stop caring, the restaurant suffers. We were largely ignored and our waiter even forgot to bring us our side order until I flagged him down. When we had finished our entrees, he dropped off the dessert menus and took off without saying a single word I'm not sure if our bad service was due to the fact that we were on the patio, but it was awful.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
Food is really good! But if u like marys chicken go to rn74. Their marys chicken was ok. The ribs were just amazing! I totally recommend! 
Server was sophisticated and such a pleasant person!!! Excellent service! 
Crowd - older people. 
Dim light and romantic atmosphere! Good for big crowds too!!! Very nice and fancy decors...4.5 stars because not my type of crowd but everything else was great!
author: Anudari K.

description:
Town Hall serves up some really good Southern comfort food with a little SF flare in a rustic, casual and lively atmosphere.  The food served up here is very flavorful, presented artfully to entice the palate and are also pretty healthy portions.

Ordered the cornmeal fried oysters as the appetizer which were a little disappointing, probably wouldn't order them again.  Entrees were the duck over lentils with mushrooms and apricot marmalade and the softshell crab with pork belly.  Both entrees were delicious, plain and simple.  All of the flavors of the respective dishes complemented each other part of the dish well.  Shared dessert order of the brownie with flambeed bananas and ice cream with caramelized rice krispies was sweet perfection.

Town Hall can definitely expect to be the future venue of my public and social meetings with friends where we will undoubtedly voice our respective and collective opinions on how good the food is here.
author: Erich D.

description:
Travelled back in time in this joint...nice layout! Very inviting atmosphere with huge windows and nice lighting. Great bartenders (huge bar set up when you walk in). You can host large party, with that oversize table by the front door. 
We had a 8pm reservation but had to wait 15min as the place was jammed packed on a Friday night. We had a corner table right by the kitchen so it was a little loud and busy. But our lovely waitress made up for it, she was sweet and fast paced. Honestly, i don't recall what we ordered or what i ate so the food wasn't as memorable as the place itself.
author: Vee V.

description:
I like Town Hall. No longer is it a "hot restaurant" of SOMA, however, the choices are solid and predictable.

The ambiance is contemporary and upscale. Have taken clients here before for lunch and it's the typical new American cuisine fare -so it won't disappoint anyone. 

Service is good and they do have seating outside, inside, and upstairs!

I ook forward to returning for HH - from 4-6PM - $6 Cocktails, $8 Wines, and $6 Snacks & Light Bites!
author: Veronica S.

description:
This place is amaze!

I came in hungry and looking for a really good meal and that is exactly what I got. 

We were seated in the far back. By a very nice waiter. Then we ordered. 

For a drink i just stuck with water. A simple, boring choice. I have to say. 

When it came time to order the food I got ham with buttermilk biscuits. On the side I got some butter with strawberry jam. The jam went perfectly to the biscuits and the butter went puurrrfectly with the ham. It was like Romeo had met his Juliet, except for in my mouth. Then to finish it all out I washed it down with some water. 

What a perfect meal 

The service here is very helpful. Our waiter was somewhat elegant and very nice to us. He had some very nice tips on what food we would or would not like. And boy was he right about me. I loved my meal. 

I would recommend this place for anybody looking for a puuuurrrrfect meal. And the puuuurrrrfect service to go with it.
author: Ford W.

description:
American food in a nice setting but without anything special for lunch. The seafood chowder was a good size and tasty. 

The cubano sandwich was a new addition to Meng apparently but I found it lackluster. The ice tea was well done here though.

Service was nice though they didn't prepare the dish as requested but they did acknowledge their mistake without any protest.

Totally fine for a business lunch but it didn't leave me yearning for more.
author: Victor W.

description:
We went to Town Hall and although I will go back my review is somewhat mixed.
On the negative side, I am not at all sure how to take the maître d' who looked at me and my girl when we entered as if we had clearly come into the wrong restaurant. She was awkward in asking if we wanted to be seated ahead of our other guests and I could tell she knew that she had made a bad first impression. I think she needs to decide whether she wants to be a runway model or maître d'. The restaurant is a bit loud for my liking, the main dishes are unnecessarily overpriced by about three dollars each and I did not care for the way the broccoli was seasoned.

On the positive side the décor of the restaurant is terrific and I highly recommend the crispy okra, apricot soup, fried chicken, and the smoked St. Louis ribs. The biscuits are superb and you will not leave hungry because the portions are huge.
author: Chocoolate I.

description:
VERY disappointing meal. 

The duck that the waiter highly recommended was almost inedible (VERY dry and overcooked) and the ham and cheese toast appetizer was drenched in sauce (multiple people in my group commented that it looked like soup). 

I tried about 8 different things and the only one that pleasantly surprised me was the veal meatballs. Everything else was meh. 

With so many great places in SF to go, don't waste your time, money or calories here.
author: Sean B.

description:
BEST TROUT EVER!! Seriously, can it get any better than "bacon-wrapped red trout"?! Genius dish, and everything about it was perfect. Served with red quinoa, asparagus, rhubarb, English peas, pine nuts, and Meyer lemon ($27). Highly recommend!

My dinner companions enjoyed their entrees too -- one person got the "Grilled Pork Tenderloin and Belly with red pepper jelly, poblano grits, and spicy jus" ($28), and the other two got the "Chef's choice" vegetarian dish which looked like the side veggies for my trout entree. 

Since the Yelp reviews raved about the "Butterscotch & Chocolate Pot De Creme topped with buttercrunch" ($8.50) -- I ordered one for our table. Wow not only did I experience the best trout ever, I had the best pot de creme ever too! :) And due to our food coming out late (the restaurant was packed so it was understandable), they comped our dessert plus brought out brownies and ice cream :)

Overall, great food -- definitely recommend the bacon-wrapped trout and for dessert, the butterscotch & chocolate pot de creme. Just be prepared for a long dinner if the restaurant is packed. We came on a Wednesday evening and it was hopping!
author: Addy C.

description:
My boyfriend and I went to Town Hall looking for a romantic, nice dinner.  

We went on a Monday and we didn't need a reservation, but the restaurant was pretty busy even at 9:00.  We were promptly seated and our waitress was very sweet and pointed out her favorite dishes on the menu.

We started off with the tuna tartare and OMG, please order this.  I'm not even a fan of fish, and definitely not raw fish, but this was so good.  The fish was really fresh and I love the fried green tomatoes on the side of the dish.  We both later agreed that this appetizer was the best part of our meal.

As the main course I ordered the fried chicken and he ordered the steak.  My chicken came with mashed potatoes with bacon gravy and ham fried collard greens.  I told our waitress that I don't eat pork and she quickly offered to replace the collard greens with their special broccoli and remove the bacon gravy.  Our food came out promptly and I was impressed with the chicken.  It was obviously fried yet it was extremely moist and juicy.  The mashed potatoes were great but the broccoli was disgusting :(  They were so peppery and the peppers ruined everything they touched, so the piece of chicken that touched the broccoli was inedible.  My boyfriend enjoyed his steak, but said that he wasn't blown away.  

Our dinner ended up costing about $95, which is kind of steep considering the only thing about the meal that we seriously enjoyed was the appetizer
author: Jenn T.

description: Came here with a few friends. Had to walk past the insanely packed happy hour, but we had a reservation and the actual restaurant was fairly empty. We started with the shrimp and toast. It was delicious. I had the halibut and my husband ordered the much requested fried chicken. I felt like my dish was spot on, something I would expect at a five star restaurant. The chicken on the other hand, seemed kinda bland to me. We also got the pot de creame...which was good, and plenty full.
author: Bevi K.

description:
Situation: Table for 4, late night dinner around 9pm.  The place was actually still quite packed when we got there, to our surprise.  It was a happening place in the bar and at the shared table.  The big downside was that due to how crowded it was and despite the high ceilings, it was incredibly loud inside and we had trouble hearing across our table.  

Food: I ordered the Guinness braised short ribs, which was very good (hard to mess up after braising in beer for so long).  My bf said his dish (the orange glazed duck) was only mediocre.  

Service: Quite good. Definitely the highlight of the experience. Bumps it up to 3.5 stars but everything else just couldn't get it to a 4.
author: Janet Z.

description:
Beautiful interior, great service. 

Drinks - mmm....perfect.

Started with the ham and cheese toast and butter lettuce salad. We shared it between the three of us, and both were great, but the ham and cheese toast was one of the best things I've ever eaten.

For dinner, I had the pork tenderlion. The greens that were next to the pork were fabulous as well as the pork met my expectation.

Table also ordered the chicken and waffles. The chicken was cooked perfectly, but the dish was under dressed and dry.

Gnocchi also ordered...filled with seasonal veg, tasted great.
author: Amy O.

description: My family and I visit San Fransisco at least one weekend every month, as it is our favorite city in all of the United States, and we always reserve one night for dinner at Town Hall. This restaurant is one of my favorites in the city and never fails to satisfy everyone at the table. I recommend the fried chicken and waffles, jalapeno cornbread, and cauliflower soup. Also, all the desserts are amazing!
author: Ailish R.

description: Insanely expensive for the quality of the food. Slow service and a rude host tonight. I'd never go back. Downtown SF dining at its worst. But the icing on the cake was me asking if they really charged me $30 for two beers. The host tonight said "i guess so" and then turned her back on me. I stood there a moment and left - never to return.
author: Will S.

description:
Valentine's dinner.  We started with a butter lettuce salad and a cheese plate.  Our entrees were wonderful.  I had the buttermilk chicken and my wife the Mahi.  The service was good.  The environment warm and friendly.  

The food was 5 stars.  The seating a little close to our neighbors.  Not a complaint, just a consideration for a party of two that might like more privacy.

We will be back.
author: Ken M.

description:
My friend and I had dinner there a couple of weeks ago and it was a mixed experience.  

My salad looked delicious, except that I never got to taste it.  Upon its arrival to our table, I immediately spotted what looked like a beard (or pubic) hair on it... that disgusted me and I didn't touch a leaf of that dish.  
I did mentioned it to one of the serving crew member -  We never heard back so either that person didn't think it was important to mention to our waiter OR our waiter didn't care enough to address the issue.  

The second dish came; I had ordered pork chop.  Thankfully it was a very large portion.  The middle was pink/bloody so I only ate the fully cooked sides of the piece of meat.  It was plenty of food, so I was fine - not sure if I was supposed to mention "well done" when I ordered my dish.  I assumed pork was always cooked through but from what I could read online, it sounds like the new trend is to have it medium cooked!  Dully noted for the next time I order pork! 

The space is amazingly warm and inviting which contributed to me adding a second star to my rating.  Too bad the waiters don't share the welcoming attitude ...
author: Severine C.

description:
What I did not like:
-My husband & I were the first ones there for lunch but the 3rd party to be seated.
-We were seated in the farthest back corner of an empty restaurant.
- Our server asked if we wanted dessert or coffee but had to return (after a long wait) with a dessert menu.
-After we were done with our meal, we had to wait a long time for our bill.

With that out of the way...the food was pretty delicious.
-Butter Lettuce salad:  very generously dressed.  The dressing alone is kind of bland.  You really need to have a bite-full of blue cheese, apple and walnuts.
-Pan Seared Chicken:  juicy.  The mascarpone & poblano chili grits was creamy and not too spicy.
