-My husband loved the seafood chowder as well as the blackened catfish.
-Butterscotch & Chocolate Pot de Creme:  silky smooth with just the right amount of sweetness.  Loved it.
author: Rose A.

description:
Ok, I used to LOVE this place.  And don't get me wrong, the food is still amazing.  (The Kobucha salad, the pulled pork, the fettucine, seafood, you can't go wrong with any of it...the iced tea is also incredible)

But WOW the service has gotten slow.  We came for a work lunch with 6 people yesterday.  It took almost 2.5 hours to get out of lunch.  I like a good, long lunch to get away from work, but man that took up my whole day!

Also when I asked for a box for my half a sandwich left and the fries that I had barely touched, they didn't pack up the fries.  They dumped them!  Seriously!?! :(
author: Amanda B.

description:
We had a $100 gift card for this place since we recently moved close by, however, our meal didn't seem worth the $160 that we paid.

I had a glass of pinot noir and 3 oysters - those were really good. The mignonette that was served with the oysters was ok (very very acidic) - but they were very fresh and delicious. 

My date had BBQ shrimp appetizer and it came out cold. It was ironic because the server came over and bragged about how they make each sauce to order, and how that takes a bit longer - but the sauce was colder than room temperature. I had the white bean soup with kale, it was OK...nothing memorable. 

We ordered the steak and sea bass for dinner. The glaze on the steak was really good and the sea bass was good as well. While everything was good, we probably won't come back because nothing about the meal was memorable. So many delicious places in SF to eat this place is not a go to. I may come back for oysters near my house and a cocktail.
author: Jazmyn W.

description: Been here twice-always ate at the bar-absolutely the nicest bartender works there-I wish I could remember his name-he actually remembered me-and he's cute too LOL-great food-especially love the butterscotch pudding dessert-to die for-try to make it there whenever I'm in the city-can't beat it!
author: RACHEL M.

description:
I've always enjoyed Town Hall. The food and drinks were good as expected, but the service has really gone downhill. 

This really caught me by surprise ... My experiences here have always been beyond reproach.  I was surprised to find out order forgotten (twice) with no apology, and prolonged waits, punctuated by having to call for service.   And to top it off, charging my card for twice the amount indicated on the bill just highlighted the inattention we felt this evening.  Of course it was fixed, but it highlighted the sloppy, distracted service we experienced this evening.  

I can understand mistakes, but I really expect higher standards from Town Hall.
author: Dan B.

description:
Has this place really been around for 10 years now? I guess I owe them a review...my friend calls this the last conference room since the folks in here office meet here so damn much as they are down the street. Came here with the ex a while back and I remember some drunken shenanigans. Too many cocktails on an empty stomach i guess.

I've always liked this restaurant group's places and TH is no exception. Unlike the others, this is much larger and it caters to a greater cross section of folks. A mid week dinner consisted of:

-Roasted veal meatballs, potato purée, green peppercorn sauce
-Nantucket Bay scallop, chestnut, sun choke puree, Savoy cabbage, citrus brown butter
-Mary's buttermilk fried chicken, roasted squash, smashed potatoes, bacon gravy
-Blackened New York steak, roasted garlic potato puree, pimento butter, bordelaise

Everything was solid. I think being slightly buzzed certainly helped accel the experience but as I said, I've always enjoyed this groups concepts. It's been a while so Ill have to go back and see how they're doing now that they're a decade old!
author: Kim N.

description:
The food here was far below my expectations based on reviews. The service and ambience were fantastic - and the reason this is two stars, not one.

I love spicy foods and can eat jalapeños raw (just for reference - I know that's not some magical accomplishment), but the steak I ordered was so spicy that it had no other flavor. I could tell it was a delicious cut of meat by the texture, and it was cooked perfectly, but I could barely taste anything besides the overly spicy glaze (that had hints of sweetness, which if anything made the steak taste further disappear). The squash and beans as a side were minimal and unremarkable.

My SO got the mahi-mahi, which he said was good, if too mild, but the broccoli rabe was too bitter compared to the other tastes in the dish. The tuna tartare was fantastic, thankfully. The cornbread had good texture and was delicious with the salted top, but it had tiny chunks of jalapeño that could barely be sensed. (Where is the spice there??) The two specialty cocktails were unique and tasted great.

Regardless of price, I thought the food was far below average. Great service and ambience are fine, but frankly I don't go out to eat because of great service. I go for great, unexpected, interesting food. We paid $100/person, with two drinks each, which I think is fine for great food. However, this was a true disappointment, at any cost really.

I've had surprising, interesting, even engaging meals at places for half the price. At these prices, I expect strong results at least. I definitely won't be returning, which is too bad because the service and ambience were great.
author: Samuel F.

description:
I'm pretty into the appetizers here, and while the mains I ate/sampled were solid (rack of ribs, fried chicken), here are my favs:

- Heirloom tomato salad
- Roasted veal meatballs
- Ham and cheese toast
- Crispy okra
- Blistered shishito peppers

The blackened shrimp and jambalaya are both just okay for me.

Generally, a nice spot to visit after work, but I do have to say that the service really varies. Some of the wait staff are super unresponsive to people clearly waiting to put their names in/be helped. Highly off-putting.
author: Shendi X.

description:
To continue our "Date Night Thursday" routine, S.O. and I came here for dinner... and since he knew I'm going on my "pork chop" phase. 

We walked from my work, convenient since it was a beautiful Thursday and of course everyone was out and about in downtown = saved us from looking for parking!

We walked in around 5:30 and I was quite surprised to see that their Happy Hour crowd wasn't even quite there yet. It was dead. A sign of recession or were people still at work? It was both.

We waited by the bar thinking the host was going to come back anytime and one of the servers did say that the host was coming back. However, after waiting and standing for a good 15 mins without the infamous host coming, the one of the token male bartender told us that they don't open their dining until 6. Hmm, that would have helped... communication folks!

We then decide to seat at the bar to get drinks. They had all of Hanger One's goodies so that was plus. However, their female bartenders...perhaps it was their time of the month but damn, they were snappy and not at all "happy" - we waited until two of them finished talking (of course, how dare us patrons, interrupt their conversation!) In my head, they're really scoring points in my book!

We get our drinks, then finally gets seated. Our moods changed since our server and bus boy that helped us were far more friendlier than those bartenders! Thank goodness!

S.O. and I ordered the following:
- Buttermilk biscuits, Prosciutto de Parma, red pepper jelly = Wow! This was delicious! They gave plenty of prosciutto...it also came with two buttermilk biscuits but you can order more if your party is bigger.

- Beeler Farms pork chop, creamed spinach, crispy cheddar grits, white peach chutney, tasso = S.O. and I both ordered this... and my gosh, it was a freaking pork chops! It was huge and looked good BUT looks are deceiving. Our pork chop was tasty and flavorful but it was hard. I wished it was tender... chewing was chewy but the white peach chutney did add a new flavor to the dish so that was good. 

- Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Crème topped with buttercrunch = WOW oh WOW! This was delicious! Our server told us that this is one of their signature dessert so we had to get it and boy, that was a good recommendation! The butterscotch just melts in your mouth and it was creamy and just the right sweetness. Having the buttercrunch to scoop the butterscotch, divine!

- Town Hall's Coffee and Doughnuts warm brioche donuts, Blue Bottle coffee ice cream, chicory streusel = MY FAVORITE! Our bus boy told us that this is his favorite because it just melts in your mouth and he wasn't wrong! The doughnut holes was a good portion for two and the ice cream just went hand in hand. I actually wanted to finish this but opted to share it with the S.O. 

Overall, it was a good evening shared with my  S.O. but I'll probably opt out to go here for drinks/dessert rather than dinner. 

Big props for the S.O. for doing research and for continuing our date night routine!
author: Cath M.

description:
Although technically in SOMA, Town Hall is not far from the ferry terminal, Embarcadero, and Financial District, and attracts a well-heeled business crowd with new takes on American favorites. I'd been here before on a business lunch and left feeling pretty satisfied, so when a good friend of mine swung by town last Thursday and mentioned Town Hall as a good option near where he was staying, I was eager to try it out for dinner.

I arrived early and grabbed a drink at the bar. Service here was quick, courteous, and efficient, and there's an extensive menu of cocktails, local and French wines, and local and mainstream bottled beers. 

There was a bit of a wait to get seated in the main dining room. Other guests remarked upon this too; although the restaurant was fairly busy, it was not seated to capacity. We were greeted promptly and ordered quickly after sitting down. I opted for a tuna tartare starter; the only thing I noted was that there wasn't much flavor to it except a notably spicy kick to it. Although the starter was served quickly, the main courses came about 45 minutes after we were seated. I opted for the pork tenderloin, and it was a solid and fulfilling, if not particularly memorable, choice. My friend appeared contented with his choice of the ribs. For dessert, my friend had the key lime pie, while I had the chocolate almond torte. Although the torte seemed a bit small in portion at first, its sheer richness more than made up for it. 

My friend, who is even more of a discerning foodie and global jetsetter than I am, agreed that while Town Hall is a good, dependable choice that is usually worth 4 stars, our particular visit merited 3 stars because of the slower service and an okay, but not exceptional, taste/quality/value proposition. There are many other good options for dining or drinking, whether for business or pleasure, in the SOMA/Ferry Terminal vicinity and just a short walk away in the Financial District.
author: Vincent L.

description:
I really like this place. Convenient location, friendly staff, fresh flowers, good food...

I have tried several dishes on a few occasions and they have all been good. Try the shrimp dish, fried okra and fried oysters if you are there for the happy hour and fried chicken if you go for dinner. 

The staff is always friendly and knowledgable too.
author: Azin D.

description:
The BBQ shrimp are simply amazing.  While it is an an appetizer, I would even recommend getting it for your main meal.  They also have a nice banquet room for large party reservations/events.  The fried chicken was nice and moist.  I will say it's a bit spendy, but isn't everything in the city?

BBQ Shrimp - a must
Cornbread - a must
author: Amanda S.

description: Town Hall's staff is excellent making me feel welcome everytime I walk in to the restaurant. I first went there for lunch during the work day and sat at the bar and had the burger and a glass of wine. My coworker had the burger and was thrilled they had Pliney the Elder!  I've been back so many times since trying almost everything they have on the menu and hosted a corporate event here. Oh- And trust the bartender to recommend a great wine- they know what they are talking about!
author: Erin C.

description: The fried chicken and buttermilk waffles is an incredible dish! Cannot go wrong with any of the appetizers, each has its own creative recipe and delight to the palette. Restaurant gets pretty crowded and reservations are certainly recommended but overall one of the best places to dine.
author: Greg H.

description: Fat Tuesday party rocked! The party was held in the back patio and indoors! The biscuit and corn bread were outstanding. Drinks were merrily flowing (caiprinha, hurricane, voss water, white wine, etc.). Highlight of the evening was the Samba Ache percussion group and samba dancers who were all superb. Made my heart beat wild and fast while dancing with them! Finally tried a King Cake too! Hurrah! Staff  were all in a happy mood. Great service. Clean bathrooms. Customers were friendly and in high octane party mood!!!!! It was totally a great Mardi Gras Extravaganza !
author: Kitty D.

description:
Really enjoyable. Very comfy decor and environment in general. Menu is comforting and filling. 
Nice for a casual business meeting or regular meal with loved ones, etc.
author: Fins L.

description:
From start to finish this place was great. We got to the restaurant early, and had a drink at the bar, the bartenders were talented and personable. The drinks they made us were amazing. I think the best one was called a mink coat. 

We went to our table and had a waitress that was fantastic, she was friendly, organized, helpful and played off our sense of humor making the night one of the best nights out in a while.
author: E T.

description:
Hands down the best food I've had in San Francisco.  Having lived in NYC for three years, I've always felt that SF cuisine just doesn't compare.  That was until I ate at Town Hall last week!  

Everything we had was unbelievable.  I highly recommend the BBQ Gulf shrimp appetizer and the hush puppies and fried okra sides. I had the pork belly with golden potato gnocchi which was to die for.  I will definitely be going back!
author: Hannah C. R.

description:
Another great dinner spot in Downtown SF.

The service and the meal / wine pairings were fantastic. We had a tuna tartar as our appetizer as we sampled a few wines that our waitress brought to pair with dinner. We let our waitress suggest a wine pairing and she nailed it, the sampling of the wine options with our appetizer was just great.

I had a pork chop as my main and she had the halibut, both were just great.

I would absolutely return here, dinner for two with an appetizer and cocktails (very well made), main and glass of wine each for $160 tip in was well worth it for the experience we had here.

Would definitely go back and suggest it for that one nice dinner you have while in town!
author: Peter K.

description:
I dined here with a friend and got a lot of the food. We started with the pear and celery soup, then moved onto the bbq prawns, pork tenderloin, hangar steak, and finally the fried chicken. The food was all quite on point and the service was good even though our waiter (JD) got his whole section seated about the same time. I will admit there were a few times I looked around for someone to grab me something but that's just during the busy 8 o'clock hour so nothing to cry about there. 

After we finished the GM, Bjorn, was kind enough to wander over and chat with us for a minute. He was incredibly nice (JD was too just so y'all know) and gave us a free dessert which was pudding with maple/chocolate pieces in it. I was very happy with the hospitality and the gesture. 

Overall, each dish was good but not the best in the city. 

The soup was probably my favorite dish overall despite my love of all things meat. It had a lovely creamy texture and "thanksgiving stuffing" flavor that made me want to eat it all day. Alas the bowl was shared between my date and I and I only had a small and delicious portion. 

The bbq prawns were cooked perfectly and the sauce was wonderful. (I don't like seafood) but they were cooked very well and the overall flavors were awesome. 

Pork tenderloin came out with brussel sprouts and some sort of masa/corn/potato balls that I didn't read about on the menu but they were good(although slight too dry).  The pork was charred on the outside beautifully but pretty raw in the middle. I don't mind medium rare but it was on the rare/uncooked side. Tasted good but was a little concerning. 

The steak was cooked medium rare (much to the despair of my date who encouraged medium well) which was quite tasty. It came out with broccoli, charred peppers, and some potato cubes. Not the best steak but definitely enjoyable.  The actual piece of meat was very high quality though.  Actually I can think many better steaks in the city but that's ok becuas it's not a steak house. 

Finally, the fried chicken ....... People.... Just come here and order a soup to start and the chicken to finish. This was legit. I HAVE had better.... But barely. This fried chicken is exemplary! I would have eaten the whole portion if it had not come as the last dish. Whatever the potato cake side that comes with it is also great but the chicken.... Ohhhhhh the chicken.... I want to stuff my face with it all the time now! 

Overall our experience was great. The only reason for four stars instead of five is because we waited here and there for a few small things and there was some food that was not the best. Again, everything was great but not five star status. 

Will definitely be back at some point.
author: Nick V.

description:
Faith's Warm Ham and Cheese Toast- #87 on the 2013 7x7 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list.

3.5 stars but rounding down since it isn't quite 4 stars, but close in a lot of ways. I've dined at Town Hall previously, but wanted to come back and try the ham and cheese toast since it was added to the 7x7 list this year. I made reservations for a Friday night easily only the day before, which isn't always a good sign for a restaurant. Town Hall was pretty busy when we arrived, but they were able to seat us right away. We ordered:

-Strawberry, White Peach, Field Greens, Thai Basil, Cornbread Croutons, Balsamic Reduction ($15, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=AEYh52RZsJQAO_lp2w0Fyw#AEYh52RZsJQAO_lp2w0Fyw): Really good, and I liked the combination of the strawberry, white peach, and basil in this salad. It was perfect for a hot summer day, and I would order it again, although $15 is a bit pricey.
-Faith's Warm Ham and Cheese Toast, Poached Egg, Jalapeño Cream ($14, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=AEYh52RZsJQAO_lp2w0Fyw#cMd1n6j4aE1X2S1fElqi6A): Yum! I felt this was a worthy addition to the 7x7 list, although I don't think I could eat this dish more than once a year since it's so rich. The egg was poached perfectly, and the jalapeño cream sauce was creamy and delicious. Highly recommended if you like creamy sauces.
-House Smoked St. Louis Ribs, Texas Jack BBQ Sauce, Corn Muffin, Stevie's Coleslaw ($25.50, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/town-hall-san-francisco?select=AEYh52RZsJQAO_lp2w0Fyw#aB_lz2a0VUxiEziGWPvGiQ): They gave you a HUGE portion of ribs, which were tender, but the taste was just so-so. At least they tasted better once dipped in the BBQ, but the corn muffin and coleslaw were bland and disappointing. 
-Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Crème (Topped w/Buttercrunch, $10): We were too full for dessert this time around, but I had this during my last visit and it was delicious! They give you an entire bowl of pot de crème, which was smooth and creamy. It was a little on the sweet side, but I still managed to eat at least half. Highly recommended if you enjoy desserts.
-Bank Note Scotch ($9): I loved that they had an extensive spirits list, and I chose Bank Note since I hadn't tried it before. It was surprisingly smooth for a cheaper scotch, and I would order it again.

Our server was friendly and attentive, which was nice. My biggest complaint is the location of their bathrooms- you have to walk to the front of the restaurant and upstairs to use them, and there are only 2-3 stalls. Overall, Town Hall is a solid restaurant to dine at in the Financial District, but there weren't any dishes I feel the need to come back and eat again in the near future. However, I will be back for the pot de crème at some point along with the ham and cheese toast. Parking in this area was surprisingly easy to find on a Friday night, and we didn't have to pay for the meter since it was past 6pm (there was no Giants game that night).
author: Amy D.

description: I've been coming to Town Hall for over ten years and its always such a pleasurable dining experience. The food is off-the-charts delicious and the service, in my opinion, is on point. Wood Tavern is known for their fried chicken and it does not disappoint. My husband loved his fried chicken and said it was one of the best he's had. We also ordered the tuna tartare (yum) and the farro risotto. The risotto left something to be desired. It was tasty but in essence was basically a small mound of rice loaded with root vegetables. When I say loaded I mean LOADED. Hefty portions are always appreciated but the amount of relatively bland vegetables in comparison to the rice made the dish underwhelming.  Again, still tasty and very light but not the classic Town Hall dish I've come to love and appreciate. So my suggestion for dining at Town Hall is to stick with the classics (fried chicken, cajun shrimp, meat platter) and if you're a vegatarian/pescatarian the Sole is always a crowd pleaser and their vegetarian side dishes are awesome!
author: stephanie c.

description: Town Hall is a SOMA classic that has been around for awhile but it's not tired at all.  Great spot for lunch, dinner, or drinks.  What made our lunch outstanding today was not just the quality of the food (we both had a very tasty butter lettuce salad with grilled chicken) but the truly excellent service we received on the patio.  Major kudos to Dean Marcic (we asked him his name), who as it turns out is the Dining Room & Beverage Manager.  Service was topnotch and elevated our simple lunch experience from good to great. Town Hall is back in my regular rotation thanks to Dean!
author: Kim M.

description:
Came here for hh with coworkers following by dinner. Can't speak for the drinks since I got there late, but dinner was decent. I did have higher expectations, but won't let that get in the way of a fair review. 

The most memorable dish was the BBQ shrimp appetizers. Generally I'm not a fan of shrimp, especially ones drenched in BBQ sauce. But damn it was good. I even took a spoon and drank several spoonfuls of the sauce alone. 

Friend chicken? Must have. Moist and crispy on the outside. I will probably day dream about how good this was. I got the pork shoulder, and it was just alright. Definitely have had better elsewhere. 

Decor & ambiance is laid back, and love the brick accent walls paired with pretty clear bulbed ceiling lights. Would love to come back more often.
author: Nattie X.

description:
Went to this place for my birthday dinner and I loved it!  The ambiance was nice, we had great service and the food was delicious!

Items we ordered:
Tuna tartare
Faith's warm ham and cheese toast (So delicious!)
Mary's buttermilk fried chicken
Smoked pork chop


Everything we ordered was so good.  Our appetizers, tuna tartare and ham and cheese toast, was amazing!  The fried chicken was a big portion and really good.  I ordered the pork chop and ate it all.  I didn't care how full I was, I ate the whole thing.  Oink!

Great place for a date, birthday or with coworkers.
author: Rachel L.

description:
I was stoked to go have dinner here after my friend got some last minute reservations. SF always has great restaurants. Unfortunately, this did not meet the mark. 
Reservations were for 8:30 and we got there around then. We checked in with the hostess and I must say, she didn't seem too pleased to be there. But whatever. We waited at the bar area for a while. There were many parties who came in after us and were seated. I thought it was weird and we waited a bit longer. Finally about 20 min later, we checked in again and hostess said our table wasn't cleared yet. But then 5 min later sat us outside. Now this wouldn't be so bad, but a) it was cold and b) only 2 of the 7 or so tables were taken- so we waited for nothing. I was annoyed as a reservation should probably mean a table inside.  

We sat down and already had drinks. We got out menus and the food was somewhat Southern focused. We ordered the scallops & pork belly, biscuits, and the fried chicken to share. Scallop dish was a bit disappointing- small scallops, 2 pieces of pork belly and a cold lentil salad with it. Scallops were not as great as at other places. 
Biscuits- best part of the meal! We got 5 mini flakey biscuits with prosciutto and a spicy jalepeno jelly on the side. Amazing.  
Fried chicken- eh. Much better at Brenda's Soul Food. You could totally see the grease and there was no real flavor. The jambalaya it came with was really spicy. 
Drinks- forgot the names but both of them had a kick. 
I probably wouldn't come here again. If I was real southern food, I know I can find better. Oh, I must add our waiter was really nice & attentive.
author: Sarika S.

description:
I loved Town Hall and glad we ate here for dinner a few days ago when we were in town for the 3-day weekend.

We literally stumbled across this place since we had to get a quick bite to eat before we met some friends at a nearby club.  We couldn't find a spot that had immediate seating or a place that the three of us can agree on.  Finally after walking around aimlessly at 8:45 in the evening, we saw Town Hall from a close distance.

Fortunately, they had a table available for us, big plus!  We got seated with our menus right away, another plus.  We expressed our rush to get our meal and got it quick, big fat plus.  Our dinner was knee-buckling good...as good as it gets with the five stars it deserves!

I got the  short rib and hangar steak which came with tater tots and some greens.  It was so flavorful and left me comforting-full, not over the top that I need to go to bed full.

My boyfriend got the pork loin and pork belly dish, his was good but I was enjoying my dish a lot more.

The bathroom is a few flights upstairs, which can make you catch your breath if you're not in shape, lol.  It's nice they have a private dining room upstairs, but it's kind of away from all the hustle and bustle of the restaurant downstairs, which I would prefer to be in the middle of if I'm spending a good amount of money on a great meal.

I would go back again, the menu was simple but I loved the creativity of the pairings on their dishes.  The decor is nice and welcoming and it's a type of restaurant I like going to when I'm enjoying a night out of town with my loverboy.
author: Joanne B.

description:
Ate here just over a week ago, we were meeting friends. Arrived earlier than the rest of our party, our table was not ready which was fine as we were offered to get a drink at the bar - great we thought....only problem was that the bar area was so full it took an age to get a drink then there was nowhere to sit which left us standing awkwardly in the way of servers, staff and other restaurant goers. The place was just too noisy - you could hardly hear yourself think! I believe this is what lets the entire restaurant down - nobody wants to eat dinner in silence but there is a difference between a restaurant and a club/bar. 

Food was ok - tried the jalapeño cornbread which wasn't that spicy. The prosciutto was nice. Ordered fried chicken for main which was nice but not extraordinary, the dauphinois potatoes which came with it were really tasty. 

We we guided by the server for dessert who described it as a creme brûlée when I asked him to explain exactly what it was - it arrived but was more like a pudding (creamy thick layer of caramel and chocolate pudding - reminded me of 'Rolo' puddings we get at home in the UK from the supermarket). Needless to say nothing like creme brûlée as no caramelised top. 

I wouldn't go back again - my main was nice but for the price would say it's not worth it. (Unless they did something about the noise levels and/or revised the prices a little).
author: Madison S.

description:
High expectations, they were not met. 

I explained to the server that I was vegetarian, he brought me out brussel sprouts with bacon. 

I don't even remember what I ate that day, but I don't be going back.
author: Dimple B.

description: In town for work. Wanted to find a place nearby the hotel and stumbled across this location. Had dinner with a business associate. Service was superb I had the Alaskan halibut and it was outstanding. But a little cool for my taste. I wanted it served hot . But not worth complaining about because it tasted so delicious. I would definitely come back.
author: Kent B.

description:
Classy place in SoMa, lovely room, very gracious service.

It's famous for fried chicken, and I'm a southern boy, so I thought, "$27 dollars for fried chicken?  Why not, let's go for it."

The chicken was served wtih two lovely sides:  First there was a cornbread pudding that was heaven on a stick.  Next there were collard greens that were so good they could inspire the South to rise again (heaven forfend).  Truly fabulous greens.  

The chicken.  Well.  I've eaten a LOT of fried chicken in my day, but this was, alas, the greasiest fried chicken I've ever eaten.  It was so greasy that it literally GUSHED with grease when you poked it.  I swear it's true.  I cut into it and it squirted me with hot grease.  I have a ruined Tommy Bahama shirt to prove it.  So, wait, I wasn't eating $27 fried chicken, I was actually eating $157 fried chicken.  And no fried chicken is THAT good.  I left most of it on the plate. It was three pieces of grease sponge with batter coating.

(I'd show a photo of the ruined shirt but I'm not seeing where I can include an image with this review...hmm.)

Dessert was a pot de creme.  It consisted of a very generous bowl of lovely chocolate pudding topped with equally lovely butterscotch pudding.  A very southern, and very tasty dessert, which I would recommend to anyone.

I, unfortunately, cannot return to Town Hall -- my wardrobe cannot afford it.  For anyone else, I'd say:  BRING A BIB AND DON'T WEAR A SHIRT YOU CARE ABOUT.
author: Ray I.

description: Love this place right under my office! Great food and service. Menu changes frequently to avoid food monotony. Heated patio and everything I have ordered has been great.
author: Saf A.

description:
All the food here is great. I've been here maybe half a dozen times, and although the menu doesn't change much, I have managed to be surprised and delighted on each visit. The atmosphere is the perfect balance of elegance and rustic casualness. The wait staff is a little bit "on" for my taste (could be more laid back) but that's hardly something that most people would complain about.

The chicken and the burger are both great, as are all the salads. Everything is big enough for two and they are plenty happy to share. Great selection of whiskeys with a knowledgable and friendly bartender, to boot. I can't say enough good things about this place. I work in the area, and it's my go-to for a business lunch or splash-out dinner with friends.
author: Gary P.

description:
Tis that time of the year, Thanksgiving! Gobble.. gobble.. gobble!

Recently went to Town Hall for an incredible and memorable dining experience. I was not only thankful for the most delicious food and service, but also and more importantly, the great dining companions.

Here are the digalicious highlights:

Warm Ham and Cheese Toast with Poached Egg - Oh Mylanta! http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=FRSoGLPQI16pus03avyaSA&select=TaIN7iu7g8anh2__na4wPw

Veal Meatballs: Mouthwatering and delish!
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=FRSoGLPQI16pus03avyaSA&select=e3xYDyDgtL2OfycB5vPosg

Butterscotch Pot De Creme & Puff Pastry with Blue Cheese Ice Cream:
To sum up the Pot De Creme: "WOW" and "Orgasmic" - Trust me, I was in my own little world for a few minutes as I licked my spoon and squealed with delight. 
That other dessert was forgettable - not a blue cheese type of gal!
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=FRSoGLPQI16pus03avyaSA&select=SFtlBwZad4oKHNiTQ6jF-Q

Thanks Town Hall! Happy Thanksgiving to all!
author: Gill C.

description: Came here for happy hour and had a good time. The island mule was amazing and so were the small bites, we had the duck confit, jumbalaya shrimp, baked oysters and fried okra.
author: Jennifer S.

description: My wife, adult son, and I dined at Town Hall on a recent visit to SF, and we were very pleased. It features a great location, spacious interior, was attractively decorated and had a friendly staff. We had reservations and were seated immediately. I enjoyed the ham and egg on toast appetizer, while my wife tried the heirloom tomato salad (she thought the tomato to cucumber ratio to be a bit off--not enough tomatoes). Our son liked the fried chicken, but thought diners should be warned that the coating on the chicken was very spicy. Although we went on a busy evening (Giants were playing at home), Margie, our server, delivered crisp, professional service. We will definitely return on our next trip. I want to try the signature ham dishes.
author: MC B.

description: Nice decor, good service, but major problems in the kitchen.  Food took forever to get to the table.  Check the menu the day you go to make sure there's something you want.  Most dishes are soaking in butter, which is great in moderation.  Bottom line: nice place for a large group, but there's a reason why you can get reservations pretty easily.
author: Maximus L.

description:
This place is across the street from my office and while I've made many reservations for other people, my first time dining here was a few weeks ago. 

We had a team dinner after work and our server was great. He managed to get the kitchen to throw together a brussell sprout appetizer for our table (which weren't on the menu at the time) and we also shared the fried okra. He made great drink recommendations as well as helped us figure out what entrees we'd enjoy. I went with the fried chicken which was way better than I expected, and I had good expectations. I didn't care for the succotash that came with it, but I did like the mashed potatoes. I'd definitely return and recommend.
author: Candace R.

description: Great place for dinner or lunch for working professionals. Great service, flexible menu and wines to choose from!
author: Tina W.

description: I have been here many times and it never disappoints!! Everything I've had is good. The BF and I like to order a bunch of starters and share everything. The tuna tartare comes with fried green tomatoes, GET IT. Besides the tuna being really good, the tomatoes are my favorite! If you do get a main dish, I highly recommend the ribs and/or fried chicken - you can't go wrong - YUM!
author: Catherine A.

description: We are at our all time favorite restaurant, Town Hall in SF, celebrating the wedding of Miryam & Matt. The best for the best!
author: Cydney B.

description:
Hot Place!!

Love this restaurant, but come prepared with your loud voice! It's quite loud and filled with excitement. Great food and energy!
author: Leslie E.

description: Lunch is good here. They are super crowded and loud, making it hard to have conversations. They have really great desserts: passion fruit cake, profiteroles, creme de pot. All amazing so save room for dessert.
author: Tina C.

description:
As a note, this review (Weekend Wings!) will focus primarily on the Chicken Wings during lunch.

Menu Description: Sweet and spicy chicken wings with queso fresco, toasted pepitas, $14 for 5
Size: Medium Large
Sauce: Sweet, medium spicy, cheesey

Incredibly crispy exterior with perfectly cooked, moist tender dark meat inside, these chicken wings arrived stacked in a pile, slathered in sauce, covered in cheese, toasted pepitas, and fresh herbs. These were my first wings with cheese on top. In addition to mellowing out the spice, the cheese added lot of great flavor. The toasted pepitas added an awesome crunch, and the herbs were very refreshing on top. 

These wings got 5 stars. The toppings balanced out perfectly, hitting spicy, sweet, savory, herby, and cheese flavor notes. The wings were perfectly cooked. As a note, if you get a little nervous about seeing red near the chicken bones, you might want to ask them to cook it extra. A few of our chicken wings had red near the bones. 

I had the burger with the fried egg on top too. Fantastic!
author: Sue Y.

description: Town Hall has been an absolute surprise. I went for the first time recently and loved their seafood special and sides. I went back with another set of friends and their fried chicken dish was outstanding.
author: Shobeir S.

description:
I came here for lunch one day, and the place never struck me as a $$$ restaurant until I ordered a $24 cod and got the tiny portions! Definitely much smaller than I was imagining for the price. However, it's worth the "splurge" every once in a while because the cod was amazing! It melted in my mouth, and the chili oil wasn't spicy (thank goodness for me).

My main issue was with the erratic service. We were on a 1-hour lunch break, and our waiter was attentive at the beginning. He came back to take orders before we even looked at the menu, and then he disappeared for nearly half the meal. We resorted to flagging down a waitress after 10 minutes of waiting since we were on a tight schedule, and our waiter only came back once or twice to serve the food which took at least 15 minutes to prepare. They definitely seemed overwhelmed, so the management should think about hiring a few more people!
author: Kimberly Y.

description: I celebrated my birthday here.  The food is delicious and the service is excellent.  I especially loved the buttermilk bouquets with prosciutto and red pepper jelly.  Also the apple, butter leaf lettuce salad is top notch.
author: Kelly P.

description: Had a great night at Town Hall.  Food was great and service was excellent.  Loved the older vintages on the wine list.  My friend had the steak, it was cooked to perfection.  I had the cod, it was very fresh and delicious.  Would go back and recommend it to others.
author: Ladd T.

description:
Came here on a weekday to sample lunch with some coworkers and reps that we work with.

Looks like the place to be for a business lunch so be sure to make a reservation! 

We didn't order any appetizers for the table but I've heard great things about the tuna tartare and would like to come back to try that soon!

For my entree, I ordered the cippino (I can never spell it right? lol) and it was delicious. There was a huge piece of toasted bread that came with it which was great to soak up the broth but there was a little bit too much aioli on it so it was a bit messy to eat and it didn't go well with the flavors of the broth. Overall, it was a good dish with a good amount and variety of seafood. 

Would love to come back and try their other offerings!
author: Christine W.

description:
I had never had a negative experience at Town Hall until last Friday night. It has never been one of my favorites, but living 2 blocks away means that it's convenient and usually a solid choice. On this occasion, I booked a table for 4 to celebrate my brother's birthday with family.

I had actually checked earlier in the day to see if I could add a couple more people to the table, but was told that the restaurant was full. I was disappointed to see that the main room was almost completely empty when I arrived.

Now, I won't fault the staff for slow service because I was not in a hurry. But I did have issues with every course - from the cold, hard biscuits with the sliced ham to the stale, fishy flavor of the oysters. I then had my first real mistake when I received a salad with bleu cheese that I had specifically asked to be excluded. I waited for the server to come by so I could ask for a correction (minor inconvenience), but when I didn't see him for over 15 minutes, I found a manager and asked for some help.

Following a brief conversation with the server, the manager brought over my salad and the cocktail I had been missing. It was then that the server came by and - without a word or smile - slammed down utensils for the table, including steak knives. While I never felt threatened, I thought it was unacceptable behavior. I ask the manager for a different server and did not have any problems with service again.

But the damage was already done. As a courtesy, a couple of cocktails were taken off the bill, along with the salad. But I was already done with this place and paid the bill - forgoing the complimentary dessert that was going to be sent out.

I refuse to ever return to Town Hall. I've had entire meals comped for less egregious errors. I've seen management respond quickly and thoroughly to use mistakes as a learning experience. I have a hard time believing that Town Hall cares about customer service or employee training after what I experienced.

PROS
- Convenient location with valet parking

CONS
- Horrible service
- Drinks were on the sweet side
- Oysters did not taste fresh
- Only decent thing I ate was the sliced ham starter

TIPS
Read recent reviews carefully to see if they've addressed the problems with bad service; otherwise, avoid at all costs. Prospect down the street or Salt House are similar restaurants with better service.
author: Drew P.

description:
I came here for dinner with the bf last Saturday for a private event. This place is admittedly pretty cute. We started with drinks and apps, and I managed to sample veal meatballs, fried chicken, and some sort of mushroom spread on bread. They also had a seafood bar and I went wild for the oysters, clams, and lobster tail.

When it came time for dinner, we were all seated and went through four courses. We started with the butter lettuce salad, which could've worked well, except mine was drenched in blue cheese dressing to the point that I couldn't eat it at the end because it was way too strong. The warm buttermilk biscuits were our second app, and that was much much better. The sweet and spicy jam complemented the saltiness of the prosciutto very well, all offset by the pillowy biscuit.

My main was the Alaskan halibut. That dish was spectacular, quite possibly the highlight of my day. The fish had a wonderful crispy skin and the texture of the meat was perfect. The sauce was so delicious that I just wanted to lick it off the plate (which I didn't obv, that would be improper). My bf's new york steak was also pretty good, but I was quite pleased with my fish and left his steak alone for the most part.

For dessert, I ordered the pumpkin bread pudding but switched it out with my bf's pot de creme because the whisky was too strong for me. Both were too sweet and we couldn't finish either dessert, although the pot de creme was marginally tastier. 

Overall, it was a great meal with a lovely ambiance. We had a set menu, so I was a little sad that I couldn't try their signature bbq shrimp and grits, but it was still quite lovely.
author: Helen S.

description:
Wow, really impressed, especially with the service. I was greeted so warmly from the moment I walked in... They must really look for the best people. It was so welcoming and noticeable.
The food was great too... Loved the fried chicken and tuna tartare. 
Thanks for a great dinner!
author: Leia V.

description:
3.5 stars relative to price.  

I came here with a large group to celebrate New Years day.  It was one of the only restaurants open that day, so bonus points for that.

The food was amazing.  With my friends, I had:
-- Seared scallops, roasted butternut squash, chanterelles, quince, pumpkin vinaigrette ($29)
-- Red snapper, "pepper pot", dirty rice, spicy peanuts ($26)
-- Tuna tartare, cornmeal fried green tomatoes, garlic chips, Tabasco green onion vinaigrette ($15)
-- Roasted veal meatballs, potato purée, green peppercorn sauce ($14)
-- Chocolate and hazelnut crunch torte ($9)

The tuna tartare was average, I wasn't a fan of the chips at all.  The veal meatballs with mashed potatoes were absolutely amazing, the best part of the meal.  The snapper and scallops were also delicious.  Even the dessert was excellent.  Overall, the food was delicious - but given the high price tag, didn't exceed expectations.

The service was okay, though not as attentative as I'd have liked.  I had to ask many times for a refill on my soda.  They were good about taking 10 credit cards, which I always really appreciate.  Decor and ambiance was also quite nice.

Overall, an outstanding experience, but with the total price tag of about $70 without alcohol, it's hard to give it 4 or 5 stars.
author: Greg B.

description:
soul food is tasty enough and service was nice 
the restaurant itself feels outdated and has a weird smell of oldness
i hope they update the place and maybe add some freshness to it
the cornbread was awesome!
author: Marie r.

description: This is a great place! I love going and eating at the bar. Decent wines by the glass. Some are a little pricey but that's what you get in sf. The food is great. I love the shrimp appetizer (ask for extra bread on the side for dipping) and the pork chop is really good! The crab salad is okay but pretty much everything else I've had there is really good! I would recommend it and I continue going back.
author: Ariana H.

description:
I've been here 2-3x now and I've never had a bad experience.

1. The complimentary bread & butter is on point. 
2. Their jambalaya - a specialty of theirs - is hard to beat (4 stars).
3. Their little gem salad is just mehhhhh - I mean it's a giant iceberg lettuce with a sprinkling of other vegetables (2 stars).
4. Both the salmon and the cod are delectable. A perfect balance of flavors - including just enough butter to taste like heaven (4.5 stars).
5. The butterscotch something dessert impressive - not too sweet/just right (4 stars).
6. The establishment itself and the service was 5 stars-worthy.
author: Lilian W.

description:
Have been to Town Hall many times and have never had a bad experience. Front of the house is very friendly and accommodating, and the wait staff is professional and just plain wonderful. Love love love their fried chicken. This is just good (fancy) comfort food with a nice southern touch. Great to see this kind of place on the W coast. 
Their dessert selection was nice too.
Four stars because the food quality can be variable. Any time I'm in San Francisco, I will gladly go back.
author: Alena W.

description:
Had pork chop on 8/8/16.  Severe food poisoning all week ever since.  

The food tasted good on the way down, but be warned.
author: T. G.

description: I typically just eat appetizers and have a few drinks at the bar. The few times I've had a full meal I would say 4 stars. However they are one of the few places to get Pliny the Elder on the regular so an extra star is in order.
author: Cory P.

description: Had an absolutely fabulous dinner here at a corner table with great privacy.  Oysters were delicious along with the steak and scallops.  Service was outstanding.  Great place for a romantic evening.  Call drinks seemed watered down.  I would love to attend the Town Hall Mardi Gras dinner next year.  A bit pricey.  Will dine here again.
author: S C.

description:
We always pass by here when we get off Fremont and always wanted to try this place. We finally did and I do not regret it. I am a definite fan of this place. The portions are small with lots of flavors but at the end of the meal I was full. For guys, I would recommend a snack before eating here, just in case.

Had the Tuna Tartar and Piquillo Peppers for appetizers which were excellent! Dinner was Seafood Etoufee (YUM) and short rib hanger steak. Dessert was butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme was very good and would be enough for 4 people as it was very rich.

The place is not for kids since it has the romantic scene. The building is very old and has a musty smell to it. The bathroom was upstairs and can use the elevator or stairs. The place was clean but going to the second floor, the smell was awful! There is bar for happy hour and only one section for a large group.

All in all, I recommend this place for the service and food.
author: Edna G.

description: I can't remember much, but the food was good. It was a celebration for one of our friend's company getting funded, so high spirits, that's for sure!
author: Sau y.

description:
I recently took my partner to Town Hall for his birthday. He loves fried chicken and this place is definitely known for it.

First off, the food here is amazing! Every dish we ordered was fantastic and didn't disappoint. Rest assured that you're guaranteed a great food experience.

Unfortunately less can be said about the wait staff. Upon being seated, our waiter was friendly and gave us an overview of the menu, telling us that "everything on the menu is wonderful." However, when we expressed interest in ordering some sides for appetizers instead of their starters, we had the oddest experience. To be clear, two of my favorite southern foods are hush puppies and jambalaya. And there, listed amongst their sides, were those two standout items! Of course I wanted those instead of their less impressive starters! So when we suggested that, our waiter shut us down. He told us "the chef has crafted the menu in such a way to match the sides with the entrees." And with that he left us to reconsider. That indeed soured the mood. He then came back and gave us permission to order the sides first...which really set us off.

Here's how it should have been handled - you tell us how wonderful the menu is and how well crafted it is, but let us order any item we want when we want! :)

For the rest of the meal we were courteous but to the point about things. No doubt our waiter could tell, but I was trying not to let it ruin the meal. Thankfully the food was amazing, including the sides.

In the end, the waiter did apologize for the incident with the sides. It actually went a long way to making us feel better about the dining experience. I've been to many a restaurant where the service has been lackluster and with no apology whatsoever.

But I can't stress enough...I'm the customer. I want to eat your yummy food. Please let me eat it. Thanks!
author: Greg S.

description:
I had high hopes for this place, but this place was just okay.... probably won't be back for lunchtime as it is busy and we could only snag a place at the bar. 

For lunch I ordered the duck tacos (~$18). The flavors didn't mesh well together and the tortilla was a bit too thin. The duck was too dry and for the price, I expected it to be better. Portions were too small (to be completely full, I would suggest ordering an appetizer to go with this). 

The plus side to Town Hall is that they give their checks in books!! How unique is that?
author: Emily C.

description:
I went here with my husband and some friends on Friday night for the first time and was impressed at every level. 

The service was just superb.  Our server was really helpful with recommending cocktails, wine and food.  She was really friendly and had a super positive vibe.  She recommended the Town Hall old fashioned which has a bacon/smokey infused flavor and it was really great.  The smokiness was yummy but not overpowering; definitely one of the better old fashions I've had. 

The food was really something special.  The shaved ham was good but the freshly baked rolls that came with it were the stars of that dish, would highly recommend as an appetizer.  The foie gras was also delicious.  Me and my husband split the ribs which were a pretty large quantity with a side of the brussel sprouts.  Everything was so good.  Unfortunately, there wasn't any room left for dessert.  We will definitely be back.
author: Ashley M.

description: Food was bad.  Service was worse.  My friend got food poisoning.  Didn't know that parasite infused rare pork was legal in the state of California.  How is this place still in business?
author: greg d.

description:
Wow...where do I begin?!?! We came here for our anniversary on recommendation from a friend. The atmosphere was a great start. It is a little loud but we prefer a vibrant setting. Ordered oysters and tuna tartare for an appetizer....brillant! Oysters were delicious and the tuna tartare was so light and delicate that it just melt in your mouth! Bring on the entrée! Pork tenderloin, honey grits, mustard greens, rapini, apple cider pork jus was amazing (honey grits are out of this world). And the local King salmon, farro, English peas, fava beans, ham Dijon jus was cooked perfectly and a definite must if you go the fish route. And don't even get me started on hush puppies!!! Probably the best I ever had!

Everything was so light and just the right amount of food that we didn't fill weighed down so we went for dessert! The butterscotch and chocolate pot de crème, as our waiter put it was "mind blowing" and boy was it!!! So rich and creamy with pieces of chocolate caramel....seriously?!?!? We were also able to try the Swanton Farm strawberry balsamic tart. The peppercorn shortbread was so delicious my husband almost didn't get to try it.

Now onto the staff. Our waiter Aaron was so attentive and knowledgeable. Never felt like we had to flag him down or was waiting on him to come around for another drink or question. We even had a little incident that he and the manager handled above and beyond our expectations!!!!! So appreciative for their efforts!!!!

We are DEFINITELY coming back! Such a great experience! Oh and if you are a vodka drinker the smash with the elderflower liqueur and cucumbers cannot be passed up! Thank you for such a wonderful night!!!
author: Shanan V.

description: Awesome dinner tonight at Town Hall! Excellent service, great ambiance and the food was delicious! LOVED the bacon covered oysters, the pork chop, okra, corn bread, rib eye, corn bread & butterscotch dessert!!
author: Vanessa G.

description: Hands down my favorite restaurant of all time! I wish I still lived in SF just so I could eat here again regularly.
author: JB B.

description:
$17 for soggy duck confit and lazy service? Nah, I'm good.

I rarely write a review after a single meal, but I feel I need to in this case. There's literally one attribute of duck confit that truly matters, just a single thing: crispiness. Had lunch there today to "enjoy" a plateful of tasty, but not crispy, duck confit on greens. Granted the portion was fine, etc etc etc but the duck was SOGGY! My only mistake was not returning it instantly - I could even *see* that it was a bad piece. And if I can see it, so could the chef, waiter, etc.

Also, service is friendly, but slow considering the place seems teeming with staff.

Too many better options to make this worth it.
author: Jeremy T.

description:
I'm a spoiled employee, I admit it. 

Nothing like being paraded by dining in various San Francisco restaurants for no reason whatsoever, except to "bond" with colleagues. Since Town Hall is fairly close to the office, I've done my fair share of "bonding" in this establishment. Highlights of my visits:

1)  Warm Jalapeno Cornbread: Read the words again: warm, jalapeno, and cornbread. You cannot go wrong with this piece of fluffy goodness.

2) Hanger Steak: Such a flavor-packed main course offering with buttery mashed potatoes and a hint of nuts.

3) Spicy Mac And Cheese: When I see mac and cheese on a menu, I am in instant suck for the stuff. This place will not let you down if you're similarly inclined.

We normally don't order wine (or any alcoholic beverages) since we go there for lunch and people look at each other thinking "I'll get wine if you get wine" and no one has the balls the make the first move. I'll update you on that later.

Highly recommended place that really hits the spot on so many levels. A perfect place for a lunch in the heart of the financial district.

---

Distinguishing factor: Great atmosphere, great food, and great overhead conversations: "business business, munch munch, business business.. cheers!"
author: Nick A.

description: Meh. Expensive and wasn't super impressed with the menu
author: Liz S.

description:
Caught the tail end of happy hour, so the crowd was the "beer and apps" crowd. Not that there's anything wrong with that. Guess I just wasn't in the mood. 

Waitress was awesome! Totally hooked us up with recommendations. BTW... don't order the burger between lunch and dinner. It's inconsistent and you may be disappointed, according to her. Totally appreciated the honesty. Guess what? We'll be back to try that burger for lunch!

Apps were good. The sliders and chicken wings rocked! Can't beat the price. 

Also it's a good place to run into billionaires! That was an added bonus. All in all, not bad. I'll be back.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Dine About Town Lunch: 1/28/2010

I've heard of it. And it seems that I've passed by it numerous times. But I just never noticed it. An ordinary building on the outside. Inside, it's big and bright and makes you forget that you're in the financial district. 

Gumbo (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Tyn-UqOTpVHtZAgrB0lWyQ?select=4juk0PY4kzAb8p36oD-o3A): The gumbo was a bit watery compared to ones I've had in the past. The ingredients and texture reminded me more of a wild rice soup. Still, I enjoyed its peppery taste. It was good, but just didn't taste like gumbo.  

Blackened Catfish with Jambalaya (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Tyn-UqOTpVHtZAgrB0lWyQ?select=ODCThfoWQILaeTxKCLLvqA): The catfish was delicious! Nice smoky flavor with a hint of sweetness. Moist. The jambalaya was okay. The rice was a bit soft and lacked spiciness.

Coffee & Doughnuts (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Tyn-UqOTpVHtZAgrB0lWyQ?select=1RXoyJxXFOpzxhSFMgnZnw): Beignets with powdered sugar, espresso ice cream and hazelnut streusel. The combination of the warm beignets and cold ice cream was heavenly! The streusel added a crunchy texture and chocolaty taste. Yum!

I was quite surprised by the Southern food choices here at Town Hall. Overall, a good meal but probably won't be back until the next DAT. =)
author: Marti L.

description:
Met a group of friends from work for dinner here. It was pleasant - not too loud, so we were able to chat at the table. The ambiance was nice and the starters and sides were fantastic (really excellent fried okra, brussels sprouts and roasted beet salad). 

For dinner, I had the hanger steak, which was... fine. I was a little surprised it was not outstanding, but it was fine. A little tough, and I was surprised they didn't ask anyone at the table who ordered any of the steaks how they'd like them prepared. I also thought the way they priced champaign was a bit odd (bottle price for the table seemed the same as per glass price). The person who ordered fried chicken was pleased, and shared a bite - this SC native thought it was pretty good. 

I will come back. The overall experience was pleasant, they handled a shellfish allergy very well, and the service was great. They had a great private room for up to 40 people - a rare find in the city.
author: Leslie P.

description:
Went for lunch with a group of 8 coworkers shortly after noon, no reservation, seated immediately at a large table. Great natural lighting, and supremely friendly and helpful service. No draft beers apparent, and bottles were a bit pricey. Cheapest glass of vino was $9. 

I ordered the Pork Loin Sandwich (Roasted pork loin, apple, poblano chili, Swiss cheese, garlic aioli) and subbed yucca fries for house chips ($16). I was a little miffed about the thought of a $16 sandwich, but the grub was pretty phenomenal. Crunching into the crisp apple was fantastic with the melted cheese and perfectly roasted pork. All of the breads are warm & delicious. Very rich; I could only get through 1/2 of my meal, and was very happy to have some leftover for later. :-)

For special occasions, this place is beautiful. Great place to take someone you care about. I'd love to come back for dinner! Not a terrible plan to get wined up before & save some coin on the drinks.  ;-) 

In a word: Yum.
author: Laura B.

description:
3.5 stars... Bitch please! The atmosphere is comfortable, well-appointed, and very engaging. The food was INSANE!

Our experience started with the hostess greeting us warmly. Then the server Ronnie, was one of the best servers in San Francisco! The service here was the highlight of our week long trip, the food at Town Hall was a close second.

We began our meal with BBQ Shrimp, if you skip this mass of deliciousness, you'll kick yourself! The Kumamoto oysters were fresh and delicious. If you like tuna tartare, this is a great rendition!

I had the ribs, they were mouthwatering fatty slabs of awesome that were too much for this Shrek lookalike to complete. She had the fried chicken, and it is hands down the greatest fried chicken in the country! Moist and tender inside (even the seemingly inferior white meat was EPIC!) with crusty crunchy breading that was neither greasy, or overpowering! 

All in all, ask for Ronnie and he won't let you go wrong!
author: Russell P.

description:
Went here with my in-laws for dinner and overall it was pretty good.  

For a starter I had the tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes, which I really enjoyed.  It was a little on the spicy side.  I also sampled the pimento cheese, which was also good.

For my entree I had the fried chicken. It is served with collard greens and a cornbread pudding with a gravy.  The collared greens were the stand-out item.  The bread pudding was not my favorite, more of a texture issue for me.  The chicken was pretty delicious, but for the price it was not amazing.  My husband had the pork tenderloin and it was excellent.  

For dessert I ordered the pineapple upside down cake, because it is one of my favorites.  Too bad this was not that great. It was dry and overly down. I would probably skip dessert if I went back.
author: Amelia V.

description:
Five stars, just because FiDi needs a place like this and it's open on Sundays.

I'm from Texas, so finding a place like this within walking distance in California is a real treat.

They have fried okra.  It's really good!  They actually fry the whole okra, and not in little sliced pieces ... but no complaints, it really tasted great.

The fried chicken was good.  Maybe could have used a few more spices, but the mashed potatoes and corn along side really had some flavor of their own going on, so we were pleased.

My St. Louis ribs ... can't go too wrong here.  Some Texas Jack sauce included (I assume based on whiskey) rounded them out.

As you might hope from a southern style place, the portions were big.  We took half of each dish to go.

The price was higher than I'm used to paying for this sort of food, but with the location and the quality, I won't complain.  We'll be back.
author: Richard K.

description:
Town Hall is a very beautiful and pleasant place where the prices are slightly high, the food is A-OK or better and the service is impeccable and highly orchestrated.  I'd describe it as a little corporate.

I had the sunchoke soup and then the fried chicken.  Both were perfect: I have nothing to complain about.

Here are three negatives:

1. I ordered a half-bottle of a 2008 Sancerre that turned out to be over the hill, almost to the point of being unpleasant.  It was certainly the least-best Sancerre I'd had in a long time, even including the specials that I've been seeing occasionally at Trader Joe's.  The Sancerre came in at $30 (plus tax plus SF health surcharge plus tip); I didn't feel that this was money well spent.

2. It's very loud in there.  I sat across from two people and had to lean over across the table to hear what they were saying.  I guess that this creates "buzz."  Surely it's deliberate.

3. The tap water was pretty bad.  What do they do to make it taste that way?
author: Kenneth R.

description: This is the place you go to when you are SICK OF WORKING! When you are fed up with clients and employers and sitting behind a desk.  This is the mid-day break from the headaches, worries, and problems. I came here on my lunch break with a friend who worked nearby and the atmosphere was so....perfect. I didn't have to deal with the lines or crowds that fidi is known for during lunch. And I didn't have a ton of options to chose from, which is perfect when your brain just needs a break. And the food wasn't too expensive.  Atmosphere was great. Service was wonderful and their BLTA was D.E.L.I.C.I.O.U.S.
author: Julianna I.

description: This review is just for the cornbread, and yes, you should spend the money on an entire meal and drinks just so you can have it...with the perfect amount of crunchiness on top yet soft and moist on the inside, just enough jalapeño for flavor, and that sea salt on top!!! All cornbreads will never be the same again. Ever.
author: Abby H.

description: Okay, but overrated, somewhat expensive, and rather noisy. I lived in New Orleans for 3 years, have traveled (some) in the South, and was not impressed with the Southern dishes (or the other food, although the restaurant did use good qulaity ingredients).
author: Jethro B.

description:
Took a client here for lunch, good thing for clients who are foodies and don't mind sharing!

Food: 
Baby spinach, crispy Hama Hama oysters, bacon lardons, shaved red onion, Herbsaint dressing...

Fried oyster salad was a perfect start. The oysters were not greasy, they were plump and a nice size. The dressing wasn't heavy and the greens were crisp.

Cassoulet, duck leg confit, Spanish chorizo, butter beans...

Shared entree number one.  How can you go wrong with chorizo and duck, smokey and rich.  The butter beans were huge and despite their size, creamy.  I could eat butter beans all day!!
author: Cari L.

description:
My husband and I made a reservation on open table after getting a reco from a friend. In the comments section I had just written "10
Year anniversary". When we arrived we were congratulated by the hostess and given a semi private room in the dining area. Our waiter also started off with a congrats a and then took our drink orders. He was fantastic, and while we 
agree with other reviews that it wasn't the fastest service, the service was great as was the food. Tuna tartare and halibut awesome. Husbands steak was cooked perfectly, although too sweet for him. The waiter even noticed he didn't eat much and offered to get him something else, which he declined. The managers congratulations and complimentary champagne and dessert was a perfect end to the evening. Would definitely recommend and will be going again soon!
author: Crystal S.

description:
I worked with Marissa Duncan for a large, private dinner of 30 people.  She was awesome!  Very responsive, handled all of my questions quickly and efficiently, and was great with special orders (one gluten-free guest).  Feedback after dinner was that everyone had a fantastic time and the food was wonderful (we ordered corn fritters, veal meatballs, organic greens salad, chicken/seabass and strawberry shortcake for dessert).  Highly recommend Town Hall/Marissa for private events.
Thanks!
Reid
author: Reid E.

description:
Love, love, love those biscuits and red pepper jelly. Ham plate is huge, but worth it. 
I simply adore this spot. Service is always friendly and prompt.
author: Valerie C.

description:
It has been 6 years since I been to this place. I ordered their gumbo, their rice is very undercooked. 

I had chipotle marinated pork tenderloin, which is very good. That makes up the gumbo. 

The atmosphere is great here. It's nice to see the place here. People are awesome here.
author: Adam J.

description:
I feel like SF has the worst service compared to other cities like NY. The other night definitely redeemed itself. 

Our waitress Cynthia was the BEST -- and I normally don't put a high price on service but she was awesome and made me realize how much more other restaurants have crappy servers. I won't bore you with details but she was attentive and even brought out b-day desserts when she realized it was all of our b-days.

Oh, and had the chicken 'n waffles and cornbread and it was really good.
author: Karen S.

description:
Initially walked in with high hopes, but was sorely disappointed. Two different servers couldn't agree who would wait on us - it felt as if we were quite an inconvenience to their evening.  Once they settled who would take the table, service was ok. 

Being from the south, I was excited to try their pimento cheese (one of the best parts of the meal) and was really glad we did. The rest was ok. Nice crunch on the fried chicken, but drinks were medicinal, too much overwhelming sauce on the pork. 

Nice portions, but way too expensive for mediocre tasting food.
author: Jen N.

description:
My coworker chose this spot for his birthday. I was up for it since it was going to be my first time. 

However I wouldn't call my experience anything to shout about. Our waitress was friendly but servers did not look very happy.  We ordered the tuna tartare, gem salad, jalapeño cornbread for starters. Of the starters the jalapeño cornbread was really good, then the salad and then the tuna tartare. 

For our entrees I ordered the grilled mahi mahi with fingerling potatoes. Overall it was alright. I would have liked it to be more flavorful, but it was kinda just there if you get my drift. Coworkers got the ham and cheese which they were happy with. Worth noting is that food came out in a reasonable time. 

A little more thought could have gone into presentation and service but for what it was, it was alright. 

Would go again if someone else was buying ;)
author: Shell I.

description:
No waiting for brunch and easy reservations bumps Town Hall from three to four stars.  Dinner is probably still three stars for me.  

The chicken 'n waffles topped w/ Hobbs' bacon is a great deal at $16. I didn't try the waffle but the chicken was moist.  Our group also ordered the scramble and purgatory eggs.  I had the chicken-tasso hash with poached eggs, topped with pimento hollandaise for $14. This was not good...the bell peppers, yams and onions together created too sweet of a dish.  I had to balance this with a lot of salt.  Bluestem and Slow Club make better hashes.  

Best dish of the visit was the cornflake-crusted brioche French toast with caramelized bananas, whipped cream and bourbon caramel.  This was $12.  It was moist in the middle but the cornflake-crust gave it some texture.  It was very similar to bread pudding.  Went well with the Blue Bottle coffee.  It's similar to the banana French toast with bourbon syrup/caramel that Slow Club and Mission Beach Cafe both serve up, but Town Hall one-ups them in execution.  This is one of the better French toast dishes in recent memory; this and Canteen's blueberry French toast with whipped cream cheese are at the top of my list.
author: Erika C.

description:
Had a fun evening with some friends from the office here. Looks like it is a pretty popular spot, it was crowded and the customers were young and well dressed.  

It is pretty big and they have separate rooms for large parties which is pretty rare in the city. Note that it does get loud. Service was really good and attentive. 

Now let's talk about the food. I had my eyes set on the friend chicken which had received glowing reviews but was surprised to see that it was not on the menu. The waitress then let me in on a secret. They apparently have limited capacity to make that dish and had left it out of the menu for the large parties. A ha! I was persistent and she was nice enough to make an exception and put in an order for me.

I had an appetizer which had ham, cheese and a poached egg, I forget the name of the dish. It was yummy but really heavy with all the cheese and gravy. It was a meal by itself. The fried chicken was good but not great. For dessert I had the Chocolate Pot De Creme. This was decent but not that great either. Maybe it was too much of a good thing since it came in like in a soup bowl. 

Overall, really good experience and the food was above average. Huge plus is the size and the ambience.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Food and wine were mediocre but on the pricier side. Interior was nice looking, Service at the bar (where I ate) were fine. 
Restrooms were upstairs two flights. 
I probably won't come back though -- many other places to try in the city.
author: Meredith G.

description:
Mediocre Southern food with a classy ambiance and friendly service in a convenient part of town. 

Town Hall is the embodiment of a classy business lunch or dinner spot to head to with clients and/or co-workers for a celebratory dinner. However, I just wish the taste of the food matched the ambiance and impeccable service. There are a handful of Southern restaurants much better than Town Hall in quality (Front Porch, Hard Knox Cafe, Boxing Room to name a few). 

We ordered the meatballs, the fried chicken and the pork shank with ravioli and grits. The meatballs were juicy but lacked much flavor. The fried chicken was crispy but lacked juicy-fattiness. And the pork shank was dry, chewy and moderately hard with a very sweet-glazed flavor overpowering the entire dish. So I'd give the meatballs 3 stars, the fried chicken 4 stars and the pork shank 2 stars. 

The cocktails are a bit on the stronger side - so don't expect to find a refreshing and fruity drink here. But having said that, they're pretty solid.
author: Priya S.

description:
Mediocre food. Way too loud during lunch time. I took my clients to lunch and it was way too loud we couldn't really talk. Bad for business lunch. 

Servers were not attentive and took forever to get us in and out.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Went here for a work celebration, and it's a good environment for that - which is the most important thing. The food is good but not great. Fried chicken was juicy but breading wasnt as flavorful - frankly the colonel's 11 spices are much tastier. 

The collard green accompaniment wasn't my thing, strnge tasting veggie that it is. The flat iron steak was solid as expected. Tried a bunch of appetizers, nothing stood out although they were all fine.  I wouldn't come here to spend my own money, but it's a fun place for groups.
author: Philip L.

description:
Town Hall was good. Not great and certainly not amazing. 

I had dinner with clients here. The food was good, but the atmosphere was so loud. I lost my voice by the end. Client dinner, out with friends, it doesn't matter that was sooooo loud. 

Also, the wait staff seemed to be a bit helter skelter. 

For the price I probably would have expected a bit more in terms of the service, but the food was good.
author: Sam M.

description:
I'll throw in my two cents and sweeten the pot with Town Hall review number 1279. Everyone has done a five star job of yelping Town Hall, especially Markus N with his review and photo. Sometimes a single exclamation and an empty plate signify all that needs to be conveyed.

I'm prone to being wordy, but I'll keep it simple. I've only been once, but after a year of dining out post TH, my recollections often converge on this experience as the exemplar of what I want in a meal. That warm glow you see emanating from TH at night can be tasted in the food, felt in the service, and imbibed in the cocktails. I didn't want to go into specifics, but I must tell you about the bbq shrimp (especially you, Rene C. I'll cover your cocktails if you will try even one of these.) You must order these and eat with a side of their piquant andouille jambalaya.

I've said too much. Take this little lagniappe and come. Eat, drink, laugh, and say 'Wow'
author: Joanna M.

description: Had the fried chicken, my boyfriend had ribs. They were both to diiiiie for. Timothy was an amazing server and made the experience wonderful! He was so helpful and made great recommendations. It was pricey, but worth it. You get a lot of food for what you pay for too. Great place!
author: Melissa M.

description:
Ooooh, I love Town Hall.

It reminds me of Wayfare Tavern which I also really enjoy. The interior is cozy and comfortable. The ambiance is casual, but trendy. The food is homey, yet delicious thanks to the simple one page menu! And the price is more than fair. Make reservations, because this place gets busy! The long and high dining tables are classy and can easily transform an ordinary group dinner into a more intimate one. The dim lighting paired with the wood work and brick walls makes this place all the more wonderful.

Mrs. Palmer - Peach and black pepper syrup, tropical tea, and lemonade. Ahhhhh :)

Buttermilk biscuits, prosciutto, and red pepper jelly - OMG, make sure to order this. A-m-a-z-i-n-g!!! The balance of sweet and salty was perfect.

Buttermilk fried chicken with bacon gravy mashed potatoes and collard greens - I loved this dish a lot. Big portions. Collard greens were really good and so was the bacon gravy! The fried chicken was great, but Wayfare Tavern does this better.

Pork belly and pork tenderloin over poblano grits - Mmmm, pork belly was super flavorful and melted in my mouth. So good!!!

Side, jalepeno cornbread - cute presentation, warm, light, subtly spiced 
Side, tater tots w/ bbq suace - small portion, good, but didn't like the bbq sauce

Butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme - I don't care for butterscotch, but had to see what the fuss was about. Surprisingly, this was oh-so-good! The butterscotch portion was light and not too sweet and the bottom chocolate portion was perfect. This is definitely for sharing, though.

Lemon meringue pie with candied kumquat - pretty presentation, light and lemony! 
 
The service was superb from the hostess to our waiter. My bf and I thought everything tasted fantastic and we are already looking forward to our next visit.
author: Cindy T.

description: Although the food was excellent and the wait staff was great, the manager is a complete idiot. I had arrived at the restaurant for a business meeting and the manager stated I was the first to arrive and seated me at the bar. Over an hour went by and nobody came to get me. I finally inquired again about whether the rest of my party had arrived only to find out they had been there the whole time!! I ended up missing the meeting. Don't come here if you have a professional meeting or dinner or you might have to deal with the moronic manager who quite frankly should be fired.
author: Saradha C.

description:
Came here for a company outing and was able to try out the menu. 

The best part of dinner was the appetizer, the tuna tartar; which I had to myself. The fish was really fresh and was placed on top of deep fried green tomatoes?! I also ordered the corn bread and it was amazing.  It came with about 6-7 individual finger size pieces and I was able eat the whole portion to myself.
