The entree I ordered was BAD.  I had the halibut and it was the most expensive entree on the menu.  The halibut was really salty and it could have been the olive?! juice/salt that was on it?! It just wasn't worth the money nor the consumption of the calories. It tasted just like fish that I can buy from trader joes, prepackaged fish with overloaded seasoning.  

Entree ruined it for me,. will not be back.
author: Chanel L.

description:
Actually there are two good reasons for me to update my Town Hall review from two years back. The first is the new lunchtime option of an open BBQ in the adjacent courtyard. Available weekdays from 11:30AM to 2:30PM, it opened a month ago with free BBQ for anyone who knew about it, so the line was down the block on that day. Lines have been more manageable these days since thy charge $8 for most of their items like a quarter-slab of the Smoked St. Louis-Style Ribs or the Grilled Andouille Sausage Po'boy. 

Since my workplace is very close by, I've since had a chance to try the Pulled Pork Sandwich and the Hobbs Calabrese Link Po' boy with Peppers and Onions - both awfully good though my popularity back at the office dipped considerably with my post-meal gaseous state. I say if you're nearby in the FiDi, you should check it out because it was a smart ploy on the part of Town Hall to encourage traffic to their somewhat out-of-the-way location. Kudos for that decision. 

Nonetheless, my second reason to update my review is that I have finally had dinner here after years of work-related lunches and happy hours at that community table. Jamie W. was rewarded by his boss with a $100 gift certificate, so we decided to have a full three-course meal there. Shoot the works, sorta speak. We went at the last minute, so we took advantage of their front red-tented area where you can sit amid white tablecloths, heat lamps, and like-minded procrastinators who didn't think to make a reservation. And best of all, you get more elbow room and are not treated like second-class diners. 

For our appetizers, we went for two - one a hit, one a marginal miss. The hit was the $12.50 Roasted Veal Meatballs, Potato Puree and Green Peppercorn Sauce - unadventurous but hearty fare with the ground veal nicely prepared (see my photo). The near-miss was the $13 Crispy Squash Blossoms, Four-Cheese Filling with Basil Pesto and Cherry Tomato Sauces - overpriced and oversalted despite a nice concept and rather soggy considering all the effort placed on making it a more delicate treat (see my photo). 

Sogginess proved to be a slight problem with Jamie's entree of choice - the $23 Buttermilk Fried Chicken, Toy Box Squash, Smashed Potatoes and Home-Style Bacon Gravy (see my photo). It looked like a home run, but I think in their effort to make the poultry moist, they steamed the crispy skin as well. It was still better than most fried chicken you would find in such tony establishments. I went for the $26.50 Peanut Tasso-Crusted Pork Chop, Spicy Dirty Rice, Fava Beans and Ham Hock Pepper Jelly (see my photo). That was one huge piece of pig saturated with way too many peanuts, but it was very juicy regardless. I just wish they warned me about the twine that was holding it all together. I was able to get an unexpected pre-flossing had I not noticed it pulling on my fork. 

As a side, we had the $6 Warm Jalapeno Cornbread, which came country-style in a corncob baking plate. Really addictive. Dessert, usually their hallmark, was also hit and a semi-miss. The miss was the $8.50 Butterscotch & Chocolate Pot de Creme with Buttercrunch Pieces - a well-made but bland concoction more fitting at a retirement home along with jello parfaits and tapioca bowls (see my photo). Nirvana came with the $8.50 "Rocky Road", which combined small Chocolate Ice Cream Sandwiches with Smoked Almonds and three Toasted Marshmallows (see my photo). Perfect in its homespun, nostalgic simplicity. We ended up $20 north of the gift certificate, but that's OK. I'm glad we finally had the full dining experience. 

FOOD - 4 stars...have to admit dinner was a mixed experience, but if I weigh it with the new-fangled BBQ and previous work lunches, it's still at four stars 
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...still like it inside or out 
SERVICE - 4 stars...consistent for sure 
TOTAL - 4 stars...Town Hall, you still have life in ya
author: Ed U.

description:
I came here for an Alumni event so we started out in a private dining room and sampled several appetizers. The duck confit with cranberry tasted like a bit of Thanksgiving. The braised short rib on a creamy biscuit was delicious.

We moved on to dinner and it was quite good. I had the sea bass with mushrooms. It was good but could have been helped with a side dish. Sea bass is also my favorite fish so this was not the best I've had but good all the same. My friend had the pork and she liked it.

The server was the only disappointing part of the evening. She wasn't too friendly and went through mood changes throughout the night.

The selections are also a bit pricey.
author: Patience H.

description: The food was quite good (jalapeño jelly biscuits were divine, BBQ brisket sandwich was splendid, veggie sandwiches were quite flavorful, and the burger was great).  However, the service left much to be desired - our server, Mark (?), was snarky, slow, unhelpful, and did not pay attention to our requests (providing fries specifically after being asked to skip them, for example).  Also, it was a little too loud for a business conversation.
author: Barnali D.

description:
I'm SO happy that we chose to visit Town Hall for a lovely Valentines Day dinner.  The ambience was great from the moment we walked in the door with exceptional host staff that were all smiles and spirited. The space is beautiful and spare, but the beautiful chandeliers set the tone.  
Our waiter was extremely friendly and a pleasure through each course.  We had the tuna tartare and the ham with poached egg toast as starters.  AMAZING! Honestly I thought I was full after that but then the Rockfish and Pork tenderloin was presented and they were the perfect portion size to the starter.  Flavorful and delicious,  we cleared our plates and were easily tempted to stay for dessert.  Couldn't be happier about our special night choice.
author: Jeffrey K.

description: I have been back to Town Hall 2 times during the past 2 months. From what I can tell you, they have only gotten better. The fried chicken- still the best anywhere- and I mean ANYWHERE. The Butterscotch and chocolate Pot de Creme- still out of this world. I wish my tongue were not tied so I could lick the bowl! The drinks, amazing. The appetizers- always amazing- try something new-the staples/stand-bys are awesome too! The best part about Town Hall though is the service. Yes, yes the food is excellent, but I swear I come back here because I am treated like a human being. It's real here and that is difficult to find in this City. Bravo!
author: Sherie R.

description:
Food was delicious! I had  the pulled  pork, roasted peach-ancho chili BBQ sauce sandwich with bacon macaroni salad. The pork was really tender. The balance of pork and BBQ sauce was perfect.  We ended our lunch with their banana split desert.


Service was GREAT! Great way to start my week.
author: Giovanni C.

description:
Southern food in a classy restaurant!  The rabbit gumbo was amazing.  It had shredded  pieces and bacon wrapped pieces sopping the dark roux.  The okra was crispy.  The thinly sliced Broadbent ham came with flakey biscuits and pepper jam.  Think sweet, salty, and savory all in one!

Service at the bar was great.  The Old Fashioned didn't even taste like alcohol.  And my TL Sunset was so well balanced that I didn't detect a hint of Bulleit rye or Fernet Branaca.

I can't wait to try more next time.
author: Elise G.

description:
Lovely to sit outside on the front patio on a warm night (even if there's construction nearby). Everything is so hearty and good that it's best to come with a group of friends so you can all share. 

The best thing we had, this is going to sound crazy...was the spiced cauliflower side. DAMN. You're missing out if you don't get that. It had currants or cranberries and almonds and was just amazing.

Other than that we had the fried chicken, halibut, frogstew (VERY SPICY), ribs, and guinness braised short ribs. Also the tempura fried okra (OK) and the prosciutto with cornbread (amazing). Pepper jelly is the jam. No pun intended! 

Expensive but nice for a good occasion. Great ambience and service.
author: Sonya Z.

description:
Loud and busy atmosphere for lunch. Seems like it's a popular place for business lunches. 

Bread - The complimentary bread served was actually pretty good. It was really soft!! 

Seafood chowder - Good consistency, but mainly filled with fish rather than other types of seafood. There was many one clam in there. Kind of disappointed. Also would have liked more of those oyster crackers to compliment my soup.

Risotto - The portion was HUGE, probably the largest risotto I've had at any restaurant... and this is only the lunch portion. The risotto was too watery and had too many different ingredients incorporated into it that didn't go well with each other. Definitely not a fan.
author: Michelle L.

description: Excellent dining experience , the staff is friendly , the food well balanced with a good portions ... We had 2 appetizers and a main entree . The desserts are amazing . Noise level good you feel good eating here and walk away happy . I hear the fried chicken is good , I had the pork chops - amazing !
author: Ali S.

description:
in the mood for southern food:
The fried chicken is cooked to perfection, 
The ribs are served with sauce on side, I decided to try the ribs sans sauce, they were so tasty.
This is a true taste of good freakin' ribs, the sauce was spicy, yet good,  added a different element to the ribs. I ate them with and without the sauce.
Jalapeno cornbread served straight from the oven in cast iron pot.

Appetizers:
veal meatballs over mashed potatoes--AMAZING
BBQ shrimp- good but did not stand out for me
Fried green tomatoes with tuna tartare- ok

Service great very attentive
author: Sofia D.

description:
Had an excellent meal here on Tuesday. I had the ribs, wow were they good. The bbq sauce was great and the overall meal was outstanding. I'd definitely recommend this place for any business gathering since it's close to most soma businesses. Between the hush puppies and the ribs I'm not sure what I liked more. Truly an outstanding experience. 

The only improvement to be made is that the staircase to the bathrooms smells weird, I would get some scented candles.
author: Michael S.

description:
With only a few weeks to plan a client dinner, I searched for the perfect place.  The room had to be fairly nice with a view or good lighting, had to be intimate to allow for inclusive conversation (no 20 ft. table!), and of course the food and presentation had to be the finest.  I searched the City, but was coming up short.  Either the rooms were "semi-private" (not quiet the same, folks!), high F&B minumums for our small party, or booked for the date/time we wanted.

I finally nailed it down to a few and am I glad we selected Town Hall.  From my initial email inquiry to my site visit to the actual event, Marissa Duncan, the Director of Events & Marketing, was on point - answering all my questions and accommodating our needs.  She worked with me in putting together pricing to maximize our experience within our budget.  She's the best.

The feedback I received from my Executive (and he's no easy sell) is that the food was excellent, the room and venue were nice and the clients seemed to enjoy it.  I'd say I hit a homerun with this one and I couldn't have done it without Marissa and Town Hall. 

If you're looking for a place to have a nice, intimate private party - this is your place.  And by the looks of it (did my site visit during the lunch hour), it's the place to be with friends or colleagues for lunch!  Man, did the plates look good!!

(By the way, 54Mint was my other choice, and I believe it is worth exploring for future.)

[I say "not good for kids" only because I'd hate to ruin the experience!  While I'm sure it's kid friendly, It's a nice getaway AWAY from the kids!]
author: Vira E.

description:
This was a find by my husband. They serve fancy southern style food. It was pretty easy to get to... but there is no parking lot near by (as far as we could tell) The valet parking is $15 (which is why it gets only 4 stars) but luckily it was after 6pm & we found a spot on the street. The front door is not evident (it looks like the dining patio). Once inside, it is a nice variety of tables & decor. 

The servers and staff were all great- friendly and attentive. The food & drink choices are a good selection. We picked 5 things on the menu:
Tuna Tartare- spicy & tasty with fried green tomatoes on the side
BBQ Shrimp with garlic toast- by far the highlight of the meal... the sauce is bread dip-able
Fried chicken & greens- delicious 'nuff said
Flat iron steak- cooked perfectly & tasty
roasted brussel sprouts- my go-to veg lately

I would suggest this restaurant this restaurant and may go back there. The prices are not bad for a SF restaurant!
author: Dawn R.

description:
My partner and I decided to try a restaurant neither of us had visited before for our third anniversary.  Townhall is well-reputed and down the street from where we live, so we decided to check them out.

Well-known for its level of service and great food, Townhall definitely lived up to its reputation for service and quality.  The food was great.  Excellent selection of wines.  Our waitress was a total pro; super helpful and extremely friendly.

My two-star deduction is because we were of course sat at the cliche table next to the kitchen.  The table was so awful and in the way that the four top could only accommodate two chairs because its basically in the path of everyone in the restaurant.  Your choices were to either face the busy and noisy kitchen or have your chair basically in the walkway (either way, you had to sit next to your dinner guest because sitting across from each other was not possible).  My sophie's choice?  The kitchen. I can't tell you how many crotches and asses squeezed past our table that night.  It wasn't like we got a discount for sitting there either - this restaurant is expensive.  This table completely diminished the entire experience.  Its really beneath them and they should rid themselves of it.
author: Daniel H.

description:
This coming Tuesday an old old old friend is coming into town for a conference. I have known since before kindergarten and have been close friends all this time. He's now a detective in the town we grew up in. Whenever we sit down to catch up, he tells me stories of all of our old friends from school that he has hauled off to jail. "Hey, you remember blah blah blah?" "Well we busted him for making crystal meth in his mobile home"

Town Hall is just like that old friend from home, frying some very tasty chicken just like mom used to make. Well, actually Town Hall's is better. Sorry Mom but that is truth. 

Town Hall is perfect for a group of your more rowdy and noisy friends. Feel free to spill your cocktail and roll around in it.
author: Rene C.

description:
Ambiance: Restaurant looks like a town hall lit up with large unique chandeliers bouncing off of red and white walls. it gives you a warm cozy feeling. Good for groups with reservations. Good for dates and friends. 

Food: I will never forget their butterscotch chocolate pot of pudding. That is why I've been here 3x already. I prefer to come during lunch as dinner is a bit of my price range. 
1. smoked Louise ribs- The smoked flavor was just right and the sauce was tasty. The ribs were decent.. tender with some chewy parts. Cornbread and coleslaw were decent.. nothing special. 
2. fried chicken- Not sure what all they hype is.. $24 for a plate of probably healthier chicken with no grease and lots of batter. However, I would prefer to have greasier chicken if I'm going to eat fried chicken at all (i.e. Golden Bird, KFC). I'm not fond of collard greens especially when spicy. My fav. was the mashed potatoes whipped with bacon.. Mmmm...
3. Fish- I've had seared fish with salad for lunch and it was good.
author: Grace C.

description: Extraordinarily delicious! Yummy. A fabulous meal. A very close friend of mine from San Francisco told me this was his absolute favorite restaurant so I immediately came down. I let the bartender order for me I need to have a fabulous job. I highly recommend this place. Great atmosphere, great food what more could you ask for?
author: Scott J.

description: Attended a company party there last night. Service was great! Very attentive. Open bar and servers walked thru group asking guests if they wanted drinks b4 cocktails were finished. Myself not drinking, I was probably asked a dozen times throughout the night if I needed anything to drink. Food, however, was mediocre. Salty. Seems they pride themselves on presentation more than flavor. We had seabass and prime rib entrees. Seabass came alone on a large plate making it look bare. Prime rib came w greens which were too salty to eat. Apple dessert was OK. Nothing special.
author: Tami L.

description: The food is really good. Had dinner here in a group of five, so got to try a little bit of everything. Highlights: Fried chicken with mac 'n' cheese (with enough broccoli thrown in to ease the guilt just a little bit), shrimp and flouder etoufee (a delicate fish in a hearty stew, somehow it works), and really cute, flaky buttermilk biscuits. Not that we needed more carbs, but both the hushpuppies and cornbread were really good as well, both had just enough sweetness to make them interesting. For dessert we had the butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme, topped with a thin piece of delicious toffee - crispy but not sticky enough to get stuck in your teeth.
author: Wing Y.

description:
We were visiting SF and my childhood friend who is a nurse in Napa took us to this restaurant for a special celebration dinner with her two daughters.

We sat on the heated patio and loved the ambiance.  The beverage manager (Erin) was so attentive and creative and she worked with the bar to get us some very special drinks. 5 star experience.

We decided it was a tapas night for us and so ended up with basically one (or two) of everything from the appetizer menu.

The highlights were the grits (with cheese, fried egg, and dotted with small chunks of their amazing fried chicken).  This was my personal favorite.  Hands down.

But they also had so much more: brussells sprouts (amazing), cornbread crusted fried oysters, hushpuppies (wow!), warm ham and cheese sandwich (great cheese sauce and lots of it), bbq shrimp (in a GREAT worcestershire (sp?) saucy bbq sauce), okra, meatballs, and for dessert, the pumpkin brioche bread pudding (great) and butterscotch pudding (they call it "pot du creme").

And they know how to make a great classic martini without teaching them.  

It was all very New Orleans, southern, and exceptional. I gotta get back there for the grits alone. I am a big fan!
author: Mark P.

description:
We hosted a rehearsal dinner at Town Hall in August 2015. We reserved the private dining room on the second floor for about 50 guests. Booking was easy (via email), but we booked several months in advance to ensure we got the date that we needed.

==4.5 Stars: Staff and Service==
Bar staff, wait staff and Marissa were all amazing. 

When planning the evening, Marissa was ultra responsive with answering all of my questions, and she made herself accessible that evening in case we needed anything. In addition, we had several guests who had food allergies, and they ensured that they would be able to get food that would fit within their dietary needs.

We had a few food shortage scares and some small hiccups, but the staff were so accommodating by offering us some extra food, drinks and dessert to make up for some of the small inconveniences.

==4 Stars: The space==
The private dining room consists of a small bar area that leads to a larger dining room on the second floor. It's nice because it is separate from the main dining area, so it feels more intimate. The area is accessible via a staircase and an elevator. In addition, there are restrooms located on the 2nd floor, so guests do not have to go up and down any stairs. 

The space can definitely accommodate a standing reception of around 50 people. If everyone needs to sit, the space would probably hold more like 30-35 people. We had a few tables with chairs set up. As we were serving dinner, people had to take turns sitting down to eat, but it worked out. I wouldn't recommend any more people than that simply because it can get a little crowded. 

==4.5 stars: The food==
The food was absolutely delicious. In fact, it was kind of hard to control our guests because they were so ravenous. 

We ordered the veal meatballs (4 stars), the salad (4 stars), the fried chicken (5 stars), biscuits (5 stars) and glazed snap peas (4.4 stars). All of it was delicious. 

One thing that we would have done differently is tried to have been a bit more organized with our guests. We set up a buffet station in the middle of the room, and guests definitely were not taking turns. 

There were a few hiccups that evening (mainly the fire alarm going off), but all in all, it was a great place to host our event.
author: K K.

description:
Love the setting!  Rustic heavy wood chairs and tables, funky chandeliers, and open kitchen.

Fantastic server - helpful, patient, and accommodating. Very smart to offer that the bartender create a drink for me rather than wait for me to make up my mind about what type of Vodka drink I wanted.

Fried Okra app: I was thinking yummy, sliced up pieces of breaded okra like my mom makes.  Instead, a cup full of beer battered whole okra came out.  Wasn't the same and the crunch certainly wasn't there. B+ for effort. 

Pork Shank: oh so flavorful! Probably $4-$5 more than it should've been but the experience was worth it and the company of friends make it more palatable.
author: Lance A.

description:
Going there for lunch it was great to see an interesting menu (which seems to change a lot as what I ordered is not on the web site) and on it I chose a tuna sandwich with fried green tomatoes amongst other things with a side of chips.

Definitely a very different experience than I think I could find anywhere else and I took the leap of faith on it since I do not like canned tuna. Not that this was -- actually, I do not know what it was, but it was outstanding!

Being from out of town I wish there was a place like this near me. Bottom line, go there, see what they have -- and don't go by the menu you see online.
author: John R.

description:
Last Friday a colleague and I had lunch at Town Hall to celebrate her 60th birthday. We arrived on time at 12:30 and were seated shortly. The place was completely packed and it took a good ten minutes for the waitress to take our order. While we were catching up and having some delicious bread, the time passed so quickly. A total of about forty minutes later, we still didn't have our food. The waitress had apologized a couple of times that there was a mix up and the kitchen was preparing the chicken of our grilled chicken salad. 

Finally the food arrived, by then it's almost 1:20. As we started to eat, my friend asked if my chicken was spicy and salty. A lady manager came over to apologize for the delay and my friend complained that the food wasn't very good. The manager asked how she could compensate for the mishap and offered some sorbet to us. We declined simply because we had to return to work by 1:30. We didn't have time to finish our food and asked the waitress that we would like to pack the rest to go. When she returned with the bill, she said the manager had removed one of the salads to compensate for the delay and that the food was not to our liking. We thanked her for that. I took the bill to the front and gave my credit card to the waitress to pay. All of a sudden the guy manager came over and apologized for the mix up and our bad experience of the food, that the entire meal was on the house! We were pleasantly surprised by his professional gesture. I asked the manager to pass my tips to our waitress. 

I've been to the Town Hall many times and honestly it was the first time of such a mix up and the food was seasoned a bit too strong. I applaud the management of their quick decision to compensate us with the entire meal and the waitress who tried her best to get our food delivered to us. That's excellent customer service! 
Bravo! I'll be back!
author: M L.

description:
I really just liked the feel of this place. It's laidback but classy and has a quirky vibe, like when they bring you your check in an old book.

I got the cheesesteak sandwich, which was pretty good -- and the sandwich was huge! The jalapeno cornbread was pretty solid as well. I only have one tiny tiff w/the place and it's that the waiters are a little stiff. They're kind of robotic and aren't really personable, but with good food and good company, they weren't that important.
author: Rowena L.

description:
To preface: I am not a cranky/disgruntled/impatient person...very, very, very far from it.

This is a genuine review of good food, but terrible kitchen/restaurant organization, service that was way too slow, and an awkward handling of it.

I'm used to slow food.  I'm used to restaurants that cook with love and time.
But if you want to shoot for that level of care in your preparation, but at a large restaurant, you'd better have killer kitchen and seating organization...and good luck if you're attempting a menu as large as Town Hall's.  You can't have it all.

We arrived at 8pmish on Friday night and I think the root of the problem was that from the pristine tables, it looked like 75%of the tables had just been seated at once.

After being seated we waited ten minutes to order. We ordered the veal meatballs to start.  Fifteen minutes later they arrived. Delicious.

And. Then. We. Waited. An Eternity.

40 minutes at least.  (Which can be fine...but maybe a disclaimer by dishes that take so long? And apps should be delayed to be better timed with mains.)

In the meantime it became freezing cold where I was by the window/vent (I was already wearing a wool sweater) and we had to spend a good 5 minutes flagging someone down.

Time goes by and by.  Our waitress kept walking straight by... and believe me we were trying to make eye contact.

Finally she comes by and explains that the trout I ordered takes 45 minutes to make.  Really?!  It's fish.  I cook a lot myself, I'm not an idiot.  She's super nice about it, but still.  

Then it comes out: the kitchen only cooks for 6 tables at a time. So if you're in that last batch of tables...you're out of luck.

So 5 minutes later my trout, some hush puppies, and the bf's ravioli comes out.  But his is cold. 

We look around for help...send it back...and wait some more.

The trout was really great.  The hush puppies are not like the North Carolina ones I'm used to.  They said they were New Orleans style...to me they were just too-dense cornbread deep-fried.

His ravioli comes back out, I think freshly prepared again, not just reheated, and it was good. The waitress couldn't have been more apologetic and I believe it was genuine. The ravioli ended up being NC, but at many another restaurant, I would have thought the hostess would have come by to offer another glass of wine NC.

Diners: sorry this review is so long...the food was good...but super slow, and a bit too noisy.

Management: please take note.
author: Petra N.

description:
I'm going to quote from a Yelp review for Town Hall circa 2007: "The thing that really got me yelling is the lack of vegetarian entrees on the menu.  It is 2007 and we're in San Francisco! "

Fast forward five years, and Town Hall hasn't advanced.

I had a business lunch here and asked for a vegan option. It was quinoa and a side of greens. Totally unfilling and unsubstantial. I can almost hear the kitchen's thought process: "Oh, she's a vegetarian, right? She must want rabbit food for $15 a plate."

I could barely restrain myself from stealing my lunch companion's fries.

Yoo hoo, Town Hall? It is now 2012, and you really might want to consider that MANY people, not just vegetarians, are including more meatless options in their diet. 

And if I may appeal to your self-interest, you are probably missing out on a lot of dining parties, period--because vegetarians veto places like yours for group outings.
author: Elinor A.

description:
Very awesome -

Great food, great service, friendly manager and employees.   Showed up early, before they opened, they let us hang a the bar and have a drink.  

Even the coffee was very good.  Great liquor selection too, at least the bourbon and rye section, which is all I cared about.

Will definitely be going back.

Great Date location too

Must have:

Faith's warm ham and cheese toast, poached egg, jalapeño cream  is PRICELESS-- very awesome appetizer
author: Steve B.

description:
Alright so had a company lunch to go to and as I was scanning the 7x7 list I noticed that I had not been to Town Hall even though it was close by and wanted to cross another item off by finally eating the Faith's Ham and Cheese toast, poached egg, and jalapeño cream sauce. But before I get ahead of myself, this joint is located right near the corner of Howard and Freemont. It is right across the street from a Charles Schwab Building and has a brick structure from the outside so it is hard to miss. The inside is a long hall and there are lots of tables that fill up quickly during lunch time so definitely try to make a reservation. It also gets quite noisy once people fill up so something to keep in mind. 

We arrive and are promptly seated and the servers come over immediately and were very friendly. They were smiling constantly and were very enthusiastic. After perusing the menu, decided to order the tuna tartare to start and of course the Ham and Cheese toast. They serve a basket of bread which is nice and soft so plus there. The tuna tartare is solid here I would say but the spice overpowered the tuna a bit. After a few more bites I realized that the tuna may lack a bit of flavoring which is what causes the overpowering spiciness. Now the Faith's Ham and Cheese toast is very solid and I was surprised when it came out because it basically was drowned in the cream sauce. There is sweet, spicy, salty, and all other types of flavor emotions that come with this dish. As a warning it is SUPER rich and because of that I am not sure how often I could eat this but it was an excellent item to cross off for the 7x7 list. I would say my experience was Ok and definitely a joint i will check out agian for business lunches.
author: Dan M.

description: Anthony is a great server. Chicken is the best dish. BBQ SHRIMP dish is the best. We had the steak and it marginal. They were receptive and took the feedback.
author: Jose A.

description:
I hate to write a review like this but I feel like I have to to provide fair warning. Roaches. That's pretty much it. Two of them in the space of twenty minutes on a Saturday evening over the holidays along the wall in the dining room. 

I'm from New York where roaches are a common scourge but here in San Francisco I'm not sure that I've ever seen one pretty much anywhere. And in a restaurant, they are a deal breaker for me, as they would be for, I'd imagine, pretty much all diners. The first one crawled along behind me on the wall, noted by us and another table and dispatched discreetly (but without comment or apology) by a bus boy. The second appeared along the same wall behind the table next to us a little while later. That one seemed to get the attention of the maitre'd and I believe he apologized to a table beyond ours. Not that an apology really covers it, but still. 

Before the insects arrived, we'd enjoyed our cocktails and salad, but the main course was ruined by the realization that they have a roach problem and how far that might go (into the kitchen even?)

I haven't been to Town Hall in ages and we won't be back anytime soon. I hope they sort it out. 

(I did email the restaurant via their web site before posting this and got no response.)
author: Emma C.

description: Ok seriously. Never reviewed anything on Yelp. But you need to get in here. The food is ridiculous.  Ribs fried chicken. But seriously do the ham and cheese toast.  And Pat the bartender rocks.
author: Julie T.

description:
I had an enjoyable meal with colleagues last night.   We had the veal meatballs, baked cod and to finish, the Butterscotch dessert.

Service was excellent.  Food was notable - particularly the cod, which I liked.    The veal was a bit grisly hence the loss of a couple of stars.  

A nice place for business dinner or even a date.
author: Max K.

description:
The review is mainly based upon their service.  Went there yesterday with friend Barry during lunch.  Yes, it was pretty busy..okay, no problem, to be expected.  Stood at the entrance next to the bar, servers walking by...should we ask for a table?  nope..continue to wait...  Hostess, in her blue muu muu looking dress finally returns, but doesn't SAY anything.  I guess expecting a "hello, thanks for waiting" was too much.  Not even a "hello".  She walks up, and looks at me and give me this "Yes?" look, as if I'm bothering her.  Obviously, we want a table.  Usually people who stand at the entrance of restaurant aren't just standing there for fun.  So I say, "HI, can we have a table for two?"  Seats us on the patio, and then does say something like "enjoy your meal."

We sit and finally the waiter shows up with some water.  By then, we are ready to order, and as he's asking us if we want anything drink besides water.  We tell him, we are ready to order..all the while, he is looking to his left at another table?  What he's looking at?  I don't know.  Perhaps birds in the sky?  Who knows??  Anyways, he takes our order.  appetizer and sides come out pretty promptly:  fried okra, french fried potatoes, and seafood chowder.  Food at least was decent to good.  I wouldn't say they were anything out of the ordinary.  Soup was scaldingly hot.  i actually don't mind that.

Being that it's lunch, and knowing a place like this won't be a quick eat..understandable.  Our entrees TAKE forever.  All the while, we are waiting, our server says nothing.  I finish my iced tea, and figure they don't give refills, until he comes by 10 minutes later, and refills my glass..oh NICE..they DO give free refills!  Too bad his service sucked.  Maybe he's having a bad day..he wasn't particularly nice or friendly to any of the others seated on the patio either.

Our food finally comes, I ordered the open faced Ham Sandwich, Barry ordered the risotto.  I must say, his portion was quite sizable!  Too bad, neither of us ate any of our entrees..boxed them to go. Our server comes with the check and apologizes for the wait, and takes off both sides off of our check.  Heat lamps were not working either..so yeah, it was nice and chilly :P  Great meal (i hope you can sense my sarcasm.)
author: Lucy K.

description:
We've been here twice and both times we were not impressed. Not worth the hype or the price. There are way too many options in SF to overpay for just OK food.

This place is supposed to be known for their fried chicken. And while not always listed on the menu, it is apparently understood to those that love this restaurant that you can always ask and get the fried chicken.

On our first trip, my husband did try the fried chicken. Just OK. Was not sure what the rave was all about. 

On our most recent trip, our friend who loves the chicken and chose this place specifically for her trip to SF from New England asked for the fried chicken and was told they did not have it. Keep in mind we had an 8:30 dinner reservation and did not actually get seated until closer to 9 so by the time we ordered it was after 9pm.

We wrote off the fried chicken and moved on. I ordered a sausage appetizer which had a fried egg on top. Nothing in the description of this dish stated peppers or spicy. I don't mind a little spice, but this dish was so spicy it was inedible. The egg which should have been runny, was a bit overcooked. I also ordered the hush puppies and a salad. The salad was very good. The hush puppies were good, but not traditional so a little disappointing. 

A few people in our party ordered the ono fish dish. My husband says his was cooked perfectly and very good. My friends mother-in-law next to me had the same dish and I could barely tell by looking at it that it was fish. It looked so overcooked. She did not finish her dish and said she was simply full. Could be true and she was just trying to be nice, but I consistently saw her nibbling off of others plates and she ordered dessert. 

After we had received our meals and had finished eating, we noticed a party of 6 next to us all being served fried chicken. We asked the waiter what gives and he said they did not have the chicken prepared when we tried to order over an hour earlier. WTF? You are known for your friend chicken and you didn't have any ready by 9pm but you had plenty ready by 10:00? I totally don't get it. 

Bottom line and final conclusion, service is good and attentive, restaurant is noisy so hard to hear people at your own table for conversation, food is over priced and not worth what you pay for it. We will not be going back again even if our friends insist.
author: Kristie K.

description:
I've only been there for lunch, so I am not ready for a full review, but I thought to get out what I ate/saw.  First of all, Town Hall is one of the closest restaurant to where I live, yet I didn't dine there for close to a year.  I've made multiple attempts to eat there, but I was unsuccessful in getting a reservation at the time I wanted (I often call last minute).  

DECOR:  Wood flooring with country side decor with tall ceilings.  Small out door patio seating with effective heating equipments.  

FOOD:  Their burger comes with chips, but no french fries!!!  Hey, you pay a lot for a burger and you don't even get fries?  I've tried their whole trout with grits ($17).  Taste was excellent.  Fish was done just right and they didn't over salt it.  Grits had a nice subtle sweet flavor to it.  Very nice.  Portion wasn't big, but they give you nice sourdough bread, so I kept eating that.  

SERVICE:  It was bit too slow for my liking, especially for lunch.  It took 30 minutes for our dishes to come.  For weekday lunch, that's bit too slow.
author: トモ T.

description:
We should have known better when we found out that they had lost our reservation. We even gave them the name of the person who took our reservation and yet they still didn't seat us. We had to settle on eating at the community table since there was no place for us. We actually wanted to give them a one star. But faith's warm ham and cheese toast dish was so good, we added an extra star. It had this nice jalapeno cream sauce and poached eggs topped on this ham and cheese toast, making all the flavors blend together very well. 

Everything else was about as bad as a nice restaurant can get. It took them 20 minutes to get our initial drinks and appetizers. Once those came out, it took another 25 minutes for them to take our order! The food finally came and we all agreed that the food wasn't worth the price. Fried Chicken for $24! Give us a break. 

Even after losing our reservation and making us sit at the community table, they still charged us with an automatic gratuity?!? This place was a joke. 

You should only overcharge your customers only if your food is amazing.. NOT mediocre! It's disappointing because San Francisco is full of great places to eat and we had wasted our night spending it here.
author: Trang H.

description: Great place for a date, dinner with friends or hosting business associates!  I came with friends on a Monday night and it was packed so I would recommend a reservation.  The food is delicious I recommend the fried chicken and the Brussel sprouts.  The pot de creme for desert is like heaven if you have a sweet tooth.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Southern comfort food with a twist. Meals can be a bit on the heavy side, but still very tasty. I really enjoyed the atmosphere and service - unpretentious and really homey.

The BF and I ordered the BBQ gulf shrimp appetizer (really delicious, an explosion of flavor!), hush puppies (what really made these was the honey butter), fried chicken (really yummy and crispy), and the St. Louis ribs (not the best, pretty overpriced for a standard flavor). Dinner portions were actually pretty generous - ended up having plenty of leftovers for the next day.

Kind of wish I had ordered something lighter, but I gotta say I dig this place. Would love to visit again for drinks, and to give another entree a shot.
author: Katrina H.

description: It's really noisy. Feel like I'm sitting at a bar. Waited for an hour for our entree. I wasn't even hungry any more (because I'm filled with anger)
author: Danielle W.

description: I have been going here since it first opened in 2003, (do not know why it has taken me so long to Yelp!?)! It is amazing. The drinks although a bit pricey are great. The food amazing, especially the fried chicken (order it with honey, you will not be sorry). For dessert, do not neglect the butterscotch crème de pot - it is A F**KING AMAZING. The chit is brought to you in an old book, which is always fun to see what the book is and where it came from ( the last one from some public library in an obscure small town in the mid-west). GO GO GO
author: Sturgis Q.

description:
Amazing food and huge portions.  Tried all the classics and they were amazing; ham & cheese toast, fried chicken & pot de creme.  I also gave the rabbit a shot and it blew me away!!

Happy Hour is also a good deal.  Great cocktails on special.
author: Louis C.

description:
We had a great meal at Town Hall a couple Friday's ago. 

We ordered:
- Nickel & Nickel, Syrah, Russian River Valley, Darien's Vineyard 2007  
- Turley, Zinfandel, California Juvenile 2009
- Buttermilk biscuits, Johnston family country ham, red pepper jelly 
- Seafood étouffée, Louisiana shrimp, scallop, rockfish, crispy rice, scallions
- Buttermilk fried chicken, Anson Mills grits, bacon gravy,collard greens
- Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Crème topped with buttercrunch
- 'Coffee and Doughnuts' warm brioche donuts, Blue Bottle coffee ice cream, chicory streusel

I was surprised by the teeny tiny biscuits that arrived. We had no problem inhaling them. The fried chicken was yummy. Crispy and super salty - just how I like it. My husbands reaction to the greens... "it's like a 5 alarm fire" It definitely brought the heat but was a nice accompaniment to the chicken cause I usually like mine with some hot sauce but it was not necessary when eaten with the greens. The grits were creamy and delicious but the bacon gravy needed more bacon.

I can't say how the étouffée tasted because my hubby devoured it but it did look good. It's a deconstructed version. 

I'm not sure why everyone is so hyped up about the Pot de Crème (it's pudding) the dessert not to miss is hands down the coffee and doughnuts! That rocked.

Service was fast but not overly friendly.
author: Nicole W.

description: I didn't want to come to Town Hall for dinner (I don't know why) but ended up pleasantly surprised.  The appetizers and meals were all really good, and I very much enjoyed the staff and atmosphere.  Would recommend.
author: Matt R.

description: Have been to Town Hall before but tonight's dinner was very disappointing. We had reservations and did get right in but that was pretty much the end of our good experience. We ordered 3 appetizers but when  they arrived they got the order wrong so we had to wait another 30 minutes just to get the jalapeño cornbread that we actually ordered. For an entrée my daughter and I just ordered a bowl of the corn chowder for each of us.  The rest of the family ordered regular meals..... We waited a good hour for our waiter to come back and tell my daughter and me that they were out of the corn chowder. By then we were extremely hungry and very disappointed. Not sure what took them so long to let us know that they they were out of soup. They did try and compensate with a free dessert. I feel at a restaurant of this quality they should be prepared for busy evenings. If they run out of something they should let you know right away and not let you sit there hungry. There are too many other great restaurants in San Francisco to choose from!
author: Melissa A.

description: I called earlier in the day and made reservations for myself and three other girlfriends. We were going to eat light before we celebrated one of our best friend's birthday. For some reason the reservation wasn't in their system. The restaurant was clearly packed. Even though they couldn't find our reservations they immediately accommodated us with champagne to go around and something extra special for our bride to be. Town Hall DEFINITELY exceeding our expectations and the manager Aaron was more than amazing. He truly set the bar high for excellent customer service. Even when a friend of mine from LA was being an extra diva.. He handled it professionally and courteously. Thank you for a rememberable night, for myself and my friends.
author: Olivia B.

description:
I've been to Town Hall dozens of times over the years, starting not too soon after their original opening in 2003. My office was located on Spear between Howard and Mission so it was a convenient after work happy hour or dinner spot. The food is fantastic and so is the service. 

Wifey and I are in the city tonight (Sat) to see Book of Mormon. She always bugged me to take her to Town Hall due to my ravings.  So I booked a table before the show. The food was great but there were some significant problems with Wifey's main course. 

The management addressed it though. They took responsibility for the error and, in my opinion, very much over compensated to make amends.  This is what separates a truly good establishment from a poor one from a service standpoint (see my review on Applewood Pizza in San Carlos for the opposite). 

Life sometimes throws you curveballs. It's how you handle those things that are key.
author: Andrew M.

description: Loved our evening at Town Hall. Service was wonderful and the restaurant still looks great after all these years. One of my favorites in San Francisco. Great cocktails program and wine list.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Come for a business lunch or dinner, where you're paying more attention to what's being said than what you're eating.  For all the hype, I thought it would rock my socks off, but sadly, it was not to be.  Had several dishes, including the fried chicken and an order of biscuits, but was disappointed in the taste and delivery for the price tag.  Good food, maybe a 3.5 stars, just not outstanding.   Nice unpretentious down home atmosphere, akin to a hustle and bustle of a Lark Creek or another restaurant trying to be a gussied up American standby. Nice service. No surprises, but no wows either.
author: Alittle G.

description:
Okay, I went back to Town Hall even though my last few experiences were sort of blah, and I'm so glad I did.  This experience was definitely back up to the excellent standards that made me fall in love.  The food was all excellent and the service was great. 

My in laws were in town, so I'm glad we had such a great experience!  Everyone loved everything we ordered, and I am happy to say I will not be writing off Town Hall.  Hooray!
author: Meghan P.

description:
Food: Total 5 stars. Their use of bacon had everyone at the table smiling. I had the gumbo which was awesome; the level of spice and medley of flavor was perfect. The bacon wrapped trout was also fantastic (my wife had that and I stole a bite). Dessert was flavorful and perfect , but I am known to love anything based on bread pudding. Others at the table were wowed by the butterscotch chocolate pot de creme. And, the flight of dessert wine is a great finish.

Service: 2 Stars; our waitress was not super attentive, and was clumsy in her interaction with us. This started when she stopped us from trying to order starters (and sides as starters) so she could inform us that they like to have starters and mains ordered at the same time. What she worked her way around to was that we could experience a longer than standard gap between starters and mains. (1) we ordered a starter per person (2) there was a better way to approach the subject. Either way we were going to wait, either for starters or for mains, as we hadn't made up our minds.
author: Christopher K.

description:
I really like this place.  It has good "cooks food" - the kind of grub that cooks love.  Simple, straight forward, hearty, dare I say - not health food.  Also its a restaurant with a great room - warm, inviting, and good buzz. 

Stay away from the safe New American options (steak, chicken, salmon).  Get the ribs, BBQ Shrimp and grits, and the ham and cheese toast.
author: Michael S.

description:
One of my most memorable dinners in SF. it could have been the company I was with but the food was unforgettable and with competition from it's own sister company Salt House I had pretty high standards.  I have had frog legs before but my friend was a little hesitant to try them so we told the waitress to grab us a great bottle of wine and surprise us with some of her favorites.  Frog legs being one, and they were delicious!  I think that other restaurants win on decor but the food here is pretty matched with the likes of it's other companies.

I've heard the jalapeno cornbread is out of this world.
author: Kevin J.

description: Just found my new spot. Superb. End of story. Dinner was exceptional; however, the cocktails absolutely unexpected. This review is basically all about the cocktails. The Town Hall Old Fashioned is perhaps the best cocktail I've ever had. In my entire life. Had a few, but never as delicious as this. Bravo!! Stunned, I tell ya.
author: Elizabeth Q.

description: We had an event at tiwnhall and was connected with Marissa and she did an amazing job making sure everything went well. The food was terrific, the service exceptional, and the space amazing. We would definitely go back. Be sure to get the bbq shrimp, it's amazing.
author: Kellie R.

description:
I don't know where to start. There is nothing I can say that will embody the sheer fabulousness of this place, and no way to describe the stellar food.

I came with lofty immeasurable hopes - dangerous in the restaurant game, to be sure. Your dreams for a dining experience are all too often dashed, but not so here, not so!

From the structure to the exposed brick to the expertly crafted cocktails to the charming waitstaff to the book that your check will be presented in, you will fall in love.

Then there's the food.

Even if it were served in an abandoned tin mobile home, you would go back for the FOOD.

Chicken & Waffles; fluffy salty sweet and gorgeous.

Chicken Tasso Hash; sweet potatoes onions and peppers caramelized to scrumptious bits topped with poached egg and a deluge of hollandaise. Fantastic.

Biscuits & Bacon Gravy; this is so much more that flour and fat. The biscuits are crisp and flaky on the outside, steamy and soft inside - perfect for gravy sopping and bacon gravy is NOTHING like your standard Thanksgiving Turkey gravy. It is light, bursting of flavor and delicious.

Cocktails; not a one will disappoint and because the entrees are on the richer side of things, you will love their refreshing and clean taste - all the better to clear the palette for more, my Dear.

Since it was a super special occasion, with our stomachs beyond full and our hearts soaring as high as the ceiling (adorned by those exquisite chandeliers!), our waiter then presented us with a row of mini cupcakes; carrot cake and chocolate both with cream cheese frosting, what do I say? If it is possible to be in love with an experience, this, is it.
author: Katie W.

description:
I was really excited to try this because I'm a fan of salt house. I think they're owned by the same group.

If this place was not in the city I would give it a higher rating. The lack of creativity and the $$$ makes it hard for me to give beyond a 3 star. It's a pretty modern american restaurant but nothing about it really stands out to me. 

I would skip the tuna tartare - it's soaked in tabasco sauce. I couldn't even make out whether or not the tuna was fresh. 

The mini corn bread is worth ordering. It's comes in this cute miniature baking pan and each corn bread came out like the size of a lady fingers. 

I ordered the roasted half chicken. It was juicy and perfectly seasoned. I'm not a fan of really salty food and this one took me by surprised. It was served with mini pieces of bacon/panchetta bits - let's face it, anything with bacon is good so overall I was happy with my dish. 

In summary, the food is of high caliber and competitive with other $$$ restaurants in the area but I wouldn't come here more than once.
author: Keara C.

description:
I love Town Hall's mission of being a testament to New Orleans living. They have a big annual Mardi Gras party, raw or fried oysters, stiff drinks, sheltered outdoor seating...I could go on. 

Regrettably, my appreciation for Nola doesn't carry over to Town Hall's fried chicken. Wow, is it salty, and I generally like salty food. In any case, you'll be happy with anything on the menu and the overall vibe. I've eaten over half of the menu and would feel confident voucing for anything that catches your eye.
author: Mike H.

description: Good food! The pork was amazing. Salads were yummy and best part is you can bring your own wine in. ($20 corkage fee but it was worth it!)
author: Emily A.

description:
I'm still blown away by the NY steak I had this afternoon for my company luncheon. We reserved the second floor dinning room and got great service and privacy. 

The hors d'oeuvres were delicious but the one that stood out the most was the tuna tar tar. A mini bite of heaven. The tuna was fresh, you get crunch, you get a nice kick from the sauce and it's just perfect.

The salad were quite typically good. The steak with mashed potatoes and spinach is on a-whole-nother level. I'm usually not a steak person though I've been to quite a few steakhouse and this is one the best steaks I've had. Cooked perfectly, it was juicy, well seasoned. Run it through some of that creamy-buttery mashed potato and you would just want to eat this for dayssssss.
author: Foodi C.

description:
We went here last night after walking by it many times. We gave it a 6/10. The BBQ shrimp was good (not amazing), the seafood étouffée was SO spicy I couldn't enjoy it... However, the fried chicken and the cornbread were the best parts of the meal. 

Service was poor - slow, I was constantly out of water and the waiter told me he would bring me something and never did.

Atmosphere is awesome. Loved the inside of the restaurant, but not enough to go back again.

Also overpriced.
author: Katie H.

description:
This review is based solely on their dessert dish I had and Town Hall's bar area.

I had their pot de creme dessert and it was really rich and delish. I really enjoyed the friendly bar staff and easy ambiance of the spot. I would recommend TH for groups and special occasions because of the large venue and also accommodating private areas that Town Hall provides. 

However, I will have to stop by again to try the full menu.  See you soon, TH.
author: C M.

description:
Unfortunately for Town Hall, I only got as far as Happy Hour at this place and even that lasted a mere 5  or so minutes this past Friday thanks to their lovely rude hostess...

I always wanted to go to Town Hall, it's right next to my job! Finally after about 3 years of 'wanting', I decided to meet a new just -recently-moved-to-San Francisco acquaintance there. 

I strolled in, saw one free table at their patio area, then kept on going inside to find the hostess...Bar area was full, side area was also full for a party of some sort...

No hostess in sight...OK....another guy strolls in behind me, we kinda just stand around...no hostess still...finally he grabs a waiter and gets pointed to the empty table I saw when I walked in on the patio...so much for me being polite and well mannered and waiting for a hostess to guide me...OK...I let it go...I talk to the waiter about being here prior to the guy he just seated...he apoligized...but then moved on...

Then, I turn back inside and the M.I.A. hostess has appeared...talking to an older couple this time..looking around for spots for them...OK, now that's 2nd time I feel to be cut off...I (politely) wait till she's done with them and I approach her...I let her know that I've been cutoff 2x at this point...

SHE (snide, sarcastic tone): What do you mean? You've been cut off from the bar?

Well...she's lucky I did not demand to see the manager because that ATTITUDE and comment really ticked me off...

But no, being the ever polite person, I explained to her that I have been waiting around for a while now...She then stated 'oh, well you just find your own seat'..great...thanks...now that there AREN'T any open spaces...

TO MANAGEMENT: Maybe a sign out on the patio saying PLEASE SEAT YOURSELVES would be helpful ..or a hostess that's PRESENT

Plus with her prior snide comment...I just turned around and walked out...

There are plenty of other bars around for me and my friends to take our money to..and we SPEND $$$$ and not on happy hour specials either.....I'm sure RN74 and Prospect will be happy to assist me POLITELY! 

I will never EVER eat lunch or dinner or step into this establishment again. And will make sure ALL my friends /coworkers/relatives do the same...
author: Denise V.

description: Great meal is an understatement. Best meal. Fried Chicken is AS advertised. Ribs are great and the Ribeye was fantastic. Butterscotch & Chocolate Desert is also well done.
author: Zackary F.

description:
I had a pretty awful experience here for dinner. We arrived about five minutes before our reservation and approached the hostess desk. The hostess was cordial, telling us our table wasn't ready, but she wasn't helpful in telling us how long it would take, that we could decide to eat in their covered area outside (that area doesn't require a reservation) if we preferred, or that we could grab a drink at the bar and wait by their communal table across from the hostess' desk. As a first-timer, none of this was relayed to us -- we simply realized it after waiting around in a really cramped area by the hostess' desk for 20+ minutes and watching others do their thing. 

We saw other groups getting seated before us and saw another couple who came in after us take a seat in the outside area. We finally asked a server in the area if we could sit there since we didn't want to wait any longer and our hostess had disappeared. We were told that we could (and that's when we learned that those tables don't require reservations, so we basically could have sat down a long time ago...). Right when we got seated, our hostess rushed over to us and said our table in the main dining room would be ready in a couple of minutes but we decided to stay in our seats since we were starving and just wanted to eat. 

I wish I could say that the seating was the only issue we had at dinner. Unfortunately, it just continued downhill. Our server was quick to drop off some waters and menus when we got seated, but he literally disappeared for 15 minutes before we could finally flag him down. I ordered the catfish and my husband ordered the pork chop. Then we had to wait another 30 minutes for our food, which is pretty ridiculous. We got no updates from our server and had to flag down another server to check on our food for us. Once he did that, our food came out right away.

I dug into the catfish...only to find that it was not cooked thoroughly (it was hard to cut through the catfish meat because the inside was still raw). Our server did check in on us momentarily after we received the food so I told him what happened and he did take care of it by sending it back to the kitchen. By the time I got my food back, I would say that the catfish was just OK--it was nothing to rave about. After all these missteps, I would not go back here. There are way too many good restaurants in SF to have to deal with all these missteps.
author: Pauline S.

description:
Rounding down from 3.5 stars...

Came here for lunch and it was solid. Nothing blew me away but everything was good. The fig app (figs, prosciutto, manchego cheese, balsamic, etc) was good but you can easily make that at home. Japaleno cornbread was decent but nothing to write home about. Seafood chowder was solid. I ordered the cheese/ham sandwich for my entree which was very much like an open-faced croque monsieur served with fried okra on the side. Super rich and delicious but the portion was smaller than I expected.

On the way out, I bought a salted caramel brownie they had at the front of the restaurant and that thing was delicious!!! skip the 8 dollar dessert and pick up a few $2.50/each brownies!!
author: Erica L.

description:
The Town Hall you remember and hear about is on the decline. My wife and I and another couple dined last night at what used to be one of our favorite spots. We loved the atmosphere and the staples on the menu which we have always enjoy. While I still highly recommend the Cajun Shrimp Toast, Fried Green Tomatoes, Fried Oysters the entree Pork Chop and Steak were dry, tough and not good cuts of meat. 

Alos the lady at reception had an attitude when one in our party had not yet arrived.

With so many options in SF I would reserve your next Town Hall visit for lunch not dinner to ensure you can order the Burger which is excellent but only served at lunch :(
author: Matt F.

description: Came here with a large group for a work dinner. Service was slow and waiter was impatient. The reservation had specifically requested a vegan meal for one guest but there was nothing on the menu that would work. The food was generally good.
author: Roy T.

description: For me, Town Hall is synonymous with choco/butterscotch pot de creme and Conan O'Brien (see Natasha S. review circa 12/11/2006).  This time around, although Conan was no where to be seen, the pot de creme (decadently creamy and sweet) was still good  . . . as were the wonderfully and incongruously moist fried chicken, the old school style veal meatballs, and the fried oysters.  Now, if only Conan were there, my dining experience would have been complete.
author: Peg S.

description:
Came here for a late lunch. Place was quiet around 2pm, REALLY easy to get a table. This place seems to have this dressed-up southern comfort food style. Elegant, yet comforting.

I had the Jerk Chicken and a side of okra.

First thing to come out was the okra. And if you like okra, it was definitely enjoyable. Little deep fried okra slivers with a nice aioli to dip them in.

The Jerk Chicken plate was pretty good as well. Tender meat, flavor was pretty good as well. The black eyed peas went well with it too.

I wasn't blown away by anything I ate, really. I have probably had okra and jerk chicken elsewhere that I've enjoyed a dash more. I'd say 3.5 stars, but it wasn't an option so I went with 3.
author: Zeel J.

description: Fantastic! Love the old school brick exposed walls. Great light fixtures. Old school server vibe. From appetizer to entree (lunch) the meal was delicious! The Brussel Sprouts with yummy chunks of bacon were simply amazing. Loved the bread too. Will definitely be back. I happen to be with another fellow foodie co-worker but this place is great for a work meeting, date or I even saw some nice banquet rooms upstairs. Highly recommend! I will be back!  Must have the Brussel Sprout recipe!!
author: Karri T.

description:
This is your average, a-little-too-fancy-but-not-so-good restaurant in the Financial District.

I went there a couple of times and it was enough.
author: Virgilio P.

description:
Well, I suppose I came in with pretty high expectations given the reviews and hype about this restaurant.   The food was good, but didn't blow me away.  We started with the corn and crab cake soup and the BBQ shrimp - those were probably my favorite dishes of the night. 
For my main course I ordered the flounder - it had a lot of sauce (which I like) but the flavor seemed to missing a balance between the spices.  I ended up trying to mix sauces from other dishes to create the burst of flavor I was expecting from this dish.
The fried chicken had great flavor, portion is huge, but I try not to eat a plate of fried food. 
Overall, decent but not on my fav list of restaurants in SF
author: Pooja S.

description:
Let me first start by saying that the service was EXCELLENT. Even though it was pretty packed, we got a table right away. Our Waitress was friendly and prompt. Just like most upscale restaurants, they are very precise with the placing of utensils and rearranging them depending on what course it is. As well as things like folding your napkin for you when you crumple it up.

As for the food, I understand that it's San Francisco, but it's a bit pricey. I don't mind spending a good amount of money for fancy food, but I wasn't happy with paying $25 for fried chicken. It's not that the chicken wasn't good, it just didn't stand out from the rest of the fried chicken that I've had in my life...there just wasn't any kind of distinct flavor. Another thing is that the fried chicken was pretty close in price to a more fancy dish like the duck. Other than that, the side dishes that it came with were good...which were mashed potatoes with a bacon gravy and some sort of corn succotash like dish. 

I'm not going to name all of the other dishes that my party had, but I will get to the desserts. Since I didn't order them, I don't know their exact names...so I'll do my best at describing them. The first was some kind of "sticky bun", it was good...not great, but good. The other dessert was some sort of butterscotch/chocolate pudding concoction. Now that was utterly DELICIOUS..

3/5 stars
author: Chad S.

description: I don't know where to start, we ordered A LOT of food and everything was phenomenal. Some of the more noteworthy dishes are the tuna tartare, pimento cheese, fried chicken, and of course the prosciutto. Even though I'm still full the next morning, my mouth is watering thinking about that salty, smokey prosciutto with the homemade biscuits (good even in their own) and the peppery jam. Also, can't forget the dessert. The chocolate butterscotch pot de creme is to die for. Love the fun, casual atmosphere and friendly staff.
author: Allan S.

description:
I wish I could remember how good Town Hall is ... unfortunately we had a fire disaster that totally wiped my memory of the dinner!

Fried Chicken was the hands-down winner of the evening. Hot and crispy, fall off the bone with mashed potatoes and corn. Yum.

The Étouffée was good, but it could have had a punch more seasoning. And I'm not a huge fan of St. Louis ribs, but theirs wasn't saucy enough and nothing to write home about.

I'll come back if only for the fried chicken dinner. YUM!
author: Vivi T.

description:
Always have a good time here, be it lunch, drinks, or dinner!  Make a reservation.

Met a customer here for dinner around 7 pm and the place was packed.  Have to love a guy who orders a shot and a beer as soon as we sit down!  Fun crowd, fairly dressed up, but everyone in a festive mood.  Great service, cocktails, and food.

The meatball apps are GREAT, and I loved the ono for an entree.

1 Butter Lettuce    11.50
Meatballs   14.00
Tartare   15.00
Crab App    16.00
2 Black Bass   54.00
Ono   28.00
3 Stella   21.00
2 Tumer Pils   12.00
3 Patron Silver
1 Gin Quincy Adams   11.00
2 Jamo   15.00

Total (for 3) = $274.28***

** just noticed something on the bill I have never seen before - 4% surcharge SF Employee mandates - anyone know what that means?
author: Matthew W.

description:
Had a salmon dish yesterday for lunch. The salmon itself was perfectly cooked and very delicious but the sides were just strange. The mustard greens, kholrabi, blackberries, and walnuts didn't go very well together and didn't seem to be seasoned so they were just blahh. I suspect they were all cooked separately and I think it would have helped if they had been cooked together in some sauce or something that tied them all together. 

The butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme was AMAZING, however. It's almost too large a serving for two to share but my dining companion and I managed to finish off nearly all of it.
author: Sydney L.

description: So freakin good. Everything was amazing. Well it was a challenge to go to the 2nd floor for the bathroom after a few cocktails. I will definitely be back to indulge again.
author: Ryan S.

description: Food is great but nothing to write home about. However, the last three out of three times I've been the service has been soooooo slooooowwwwww.  Wow. Get it together!
author: Rada I.

description:
Food: 3
Decor: 3
Service: 3

Came here for a company event. We reserved the entire restaurant, and we had a cocktail hour before dinner with various appetizers, seafood (mussels, oysters, lobster), and of course, plenty of booze. Nothing that amazing, although the mushrooms on baguette slices were quite good.

Dinner was 4 courses:

1. Butter lettuce salad with candied walnuts and blue cheese dressing
~Disappointing. Lettuce salad was more like half a chopped head of lettuce, so it had some bitter ends.

2. Warm buttermilk biscuits with country ham and pepper jam
~Disappointing. Ham ended up being prosciutto, which was too salty. Weird combination with the biscuits and pepper jam.

3. Grilled Creekstone New York steak, fingerling potato puree, fall vegetables, red wine sauce
~Pretty good. Steak was cooked nicely, potato puree and veggies were good, and the red wine sauce was excellent.

My gf got the Alaskan halibut, salt roasted fingerling potatoes, cippolini onion confit, chanterelles, sweet vermouth, and it was quite good as well.

4. Pumpkin bread pudding, whiskey sauce, maple-cinnamon marshmallows
~Disappointing. Way too sweet, and the whiskey sauce drenched the bread pudding. Only ate about a third.

Butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme was slightly better, although it was also too sweet.

Service was pretty good, but I had to flag a server down when my gf didn't get her 4th course.
author: David L.

description:
Seriously terrible service. Ate here on a Tuesday night. We had a reservation, and one person in our party had to get to the airport but we had a full two hours to eat our meal. We let our waiter know that, and he joked "if I can't get you out of here in two hours I have a major problem." Great. We got our apps, But then, over an hour later, still no entrees. Our server was blatantly avoiding us, and finally sent a manager over to rudely ask if we wanted the food or not, since it was cutting close on time. We learned that our server never put in our entree order!! The manager was snappy and rude and would not take responsibility for the situation.

We did get our food which was ok - lots of temperature issues, like cold veggies on the dishes. The manager comped our food too which was a nice gesture but done so rudely, I honestly would rather have paid in full but be treated kindly.

I used to love this place, but between the bad service and the deafening noise level, I'll never be back.
author: Rehana A.

description: Good food and drinks. I found it to be better the first time around. A little heavy for lunch but good. Good alternative to restaurants in the FiDi.
author: sarah R.

description:
Went to Town Hall for lunch today, and while it wasn't bad, it won't make my best of list. Here's the breakdown:

I had a butter lettuce salad for an appetizer, and it was pretty tasty, but... no mention on the menu of the walnuts in the dish. The walnut flavor was somewhat overwhelming (which was odd, because there were maybe five walnuts on the plate). As someone that has an allergy to certain nuts, this rubbed me the wrong way.

For the main course, I went with their pulled pork sandwich, which was served with coleslaw on the sandwich, and a side of house made chips. The chips were OK, but over salted and tasted like the oil they were cooked in could have used a change. The sandwich was decent -- the meat was tender and delicious, but the juxtaposition of the meat to the slaw was unsuccessful. 

Overall, a decent meal, but I'm not rushing back. Parking in the area is pricey, which is a bit of a bummer. I will note, however, that the service was very solid. Overall, a decent choice, with better (and worse) options available.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Romantic, great cocktails, southern inspired food. 

Service is stellar, the ambiance is romantic & rustic, food is good but not great = 3.5 stars

Reservations are a must..we went on a Thursday night at 8:30pm and it was a full house. The hostess, servers, & bussers were all friendly and wonderfully accomodating including the female bartender/mixologist (wish I remembered her name) with her stiff drinks and gregarious charm.  

On to the food: 

Starters/sides: 
- Jambalaya - Not memorable
- Biscuit w/procuitto & jalapeno jelly - Delicious, great balance of sweet/salty
- Fried okra - Fried to perfection but breading needed some seasoning. 
- Hush puppies - Too dense. Expected a little more fluff in the bite.

Entrees:
- Duck breast over lentils - FABULOUS. Duck was seared perfectly making the meat incredibly juicy & flavorful and the tiny lentils with the blackberry puree was an excellent compliment.
- Flounder w/shrimp - Overly sauced, one-note flavor throughout dish

So...

Was the dinner worth wrecking my calorie counting for the day? Yes. 

If I were in the area, I'd come back for the cocktails & the duck breast.
author: Susie O.

description: Town Hall is a solid choice for drinks and apps.  On a nice day, you can enjoy stiff drinks and good food in the covered patio area.  The must have dish is the biscuits with prosciutto and red pepper jelly - a fantastic combination of sweet, buttery, and salty.  Hard to beat.
author: Chris C.

description:
I went to Town Hall for late Sunday brunch (~1:30pm) and found plenty of space in this spacious and well furnished restaurant. We found ourselves in a corner under whimsical light fixtures and next to a wall adorned with vintage photographs. Lots of natural light came in through the windows.

Our waitress was super friendly and well-informed. We jumped on her recommendations for food (you should, too).

1) The cornflake encrusted french toast with bananas on top. I will with certainty be ordering this again. It's rare to find french toast that isn't too overwhelmingly sweet, but here it's accomplished simply without too much fruit.

2) The chicken and waffles (disclaimer, I am a huge chicken and waffles fan). It was boneless and skinless, which translates to low effort and healthy. The chicken was great quality. They put some bacon on top which went well with the syrup. The waffles were of the Liège variety (if you, like my waffle connoisseur brunch buddy, care).

They were nice enough to split both plates for us and bring them out one after the other.

I sipped on a bellini and my brunch buddy had a glass of their rosé.

I don't want to give it all away but I enjoyed this too much: they bring the check in an old book. We spent 5 minutes reading an Albert Einstein review on our book's jacket and leaving scribbles inside. Anyway, definitely go! It'll be fun.
author: Emily Z.

description:
Another lunch choice for me while in SF for work, and another great experience. We sat at the community table since we were a small group and I have to say I'm a fan of places that include this option. There's nothing like forcing people to interact with one another in day-to-day life. The atmosphere here is quaint and lovely, sort of like being at your cousin's farmhouse for lunch in my mind.

I ordered an appetizer and a side for my lunch because when I saw jalapeno corn bread I couldn't pass it up. And I'm so very glad I didn't. It was served in a little pan and was shaped kind of like fingers. Imagery is gross, taste is delicious. It was long and thin and so moist I wanted to order another pan to go, but I was staying in a hotel so I had no place to store it.

The other part of my lunch was a very refreshing tuna tartare. It was served with fried green tomatoes which gave my whole lunch a very Southern feel. Since I'm from the South I loved this.

I could see this place being great for so many occasions, lunch or dinner, friends, business or date meetings, etc, etc. And I would easily come back for any of those meals if you care to invite me.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
I had been waiting for years to try this place, but to be honest I liked Salt House and Anchor & Hope much better (all 3 have the same owner, I believe). It has a Southern flair, which I didn't realize, and I think could have gone either way. My flounder was good, but it came in a southern style sauce/dish and I had just hoped for a nice grilled filet. My date's fried chicken was good for fried chicken and the service was great, but there are so many great restaurants in the city that it's hard to rank this one alongside the others.

The bathroom is also all the way upstairs and around the corner and I kept getting lost on the way back, which is annoying, or maybe just speaks to my misguided sense of direction... 

I do like the communal table idea in the front though - might check that out if I go back.
author: Alex H.

description: A very good dinner here on 24 July. Nothing vegetarian on the entre list but kitchen prepared something nice. Excellent rob roy.
author: Philip S.

description: My ham appetizer with Johnson County ham was excellent. The cornbread was fantastic. My friend had a hanger steak that was also very good.
author: Francisco M.

description: This place was a definite surprise in San Fran. Described by the waiter as a bit of Cajun with some seasonal options. Had an andouille sausage jambalaya to start and a pork chop with summer squash as a main dish. Excellent. A colleague of mine had a seafood stew that looked very tasty, but mussels are not my thing. Another colleague got a buttermilk fried chicken with mashed potatoes that looked great as well. I would definitely recommend this to anyone in the area to check out for a meal that will not let you down.
author: Patrick F.

description: A nice place where hipsters and baby boomers can be found waiting for tables or lounging at the bar. If it is really busy there is a covered patio for outdoor seating as well.  Town Hall serves elegant french cuisine with a twist.  The food is solid but nothing overwhelmed me, maybe I just dont like French Cuisine.  Prices are average to above average for San Francisco.  A solid place to eat if your in the area.
author: Douglas Y.

description: This is my all time favorite spot and I've been eating here for about 12 years.
