The best spot to eat solo is at the bar--there's plenty of people to meet and talk with if you try to start a conversation.  This is also my top recommendation for people visiting the City or coming in for business.   I love this place!!
author: Josie R.

description:
Honestly I don't know what to say. I got the basics soup, hush puppies and a few sides.

It was the most disappointing meal I have ever had for the price. I think if we hadn't paid $140 for the two of us I probably wouldn't have cared that much but for that price you expect a little more.

I won't be back.
author: yukongin K.

description:
It has been a while since I have been and I enjoyed my meal. The place was super loud (now that I think of it, our party contributed to that so I should probably pipe down) and a bit dark, as others have confirmed. 

The fried chicken is to get caught not washing your hands after using the bathroom for, not to kill or die for. It's really good is what I am trying to mumble. I think I am going to head out there again to see if it's still as good as I remember.
author: Hector G.

description:
This place has been on my list for a while and i was looking forward to a great food/ experience there but it turned out to be just ok. Nothing super. Had the fried chicken and few appetizers. Fried chicken: meh, wouldnt order it again. Appetizers : fried green tomatoes, tuna tartare, really good!
Also, it was the slowest service ever. Literally an hour just to order our food!
author: C A.

description:
I've been to Town Hall on more than one occasion, and they've all been delightful experiences.  Maybe I'm biased because I work right across the street, so convenience for me is a given.  We've taken clients here for lunch and dinner, and met up w/ co-workers and friends for a quick drink right after work.  So here's what I have to say about my experiences:

Happy Hour:  They have a cool cocktail list & are even willing to concoct something new for each guest.  The waiters are great and I get lost in translation when they start describing their drinks.  I get mesmerized w/ the vivid details and quite honestly, it makes me curious to try them all.  After our waiter recommended the "Black Beauty", I HAD to try it.  It had Gin, Antica, Honey, and Lemon Juice.  After each sip, the flavors just burst out everywhere...so good!  Other than that, I usually stick to their wine list: Chardonnay.  :)

Lunch/Dinner:  I love their food here, both entrees AND desserts.  Kudos to each entrée I've tried.  The Tuna Tartare to start is delectable, especially w/ the fried green tomato.  I've never had it served w/ tomato but it's such a good pairing and tastes SO good.  It's really not meant to share... call me greedy but order 2 appetizers if there are 2 of you.  Their salad w/ buttered lettuce, Fuji apples, and candied walnuts does not disappoint, either.  My FAVORITE dish is their Guinness Battered Fish & Chips w/ Tartar Sauce.  It's ALWAYS good and the portion is plenty.  

Dessert:  I've tried the Butterscotch & Chocolate Pot de Crème and Beignets w/ Espresso Ice Cream.  Both are so DELISH!!  The Pot de Crème is something you definitely have to share because it is so sweet, and I will probably never be able to finish one on my own.  The Beignets, on the other hand, are so delightfully sinful... this I can devour all by myself!!  They are served warm and filled w/ yummy goodness, and pair extremely well w/ the espresso ice cream.
author: Joy A.

description: Seriously love this place! The food is great, the decor is fantastic and the service is impeccable. They do Southern cuisine with California ingredients and preparation which is the best way to describe their menu. You cannot go here without trying their version of tuna tartare which is served with fried green tomatoes and a tasty tabasco, green onion vinaigrette and you MUST have their buttermilk fried chicken which is served with mac & cheese with bacon & broccoli as it is phenomenal! (Please note that the sides for the chicken will change upon season). Of course, for dessert the must have is their chocolate and hazelnut torte which comes with an amazing espresso buttercream on top. Highly recommended.
author: Jared C.

description:
Overpriced, overpromised, and underdelivered.

Dinner for two began with a bang: Buttermilk biscuits with chili aioli and prosciutto. When stacked and eaten together as a sandwich, it's amazing sex. This was THE one thing Town Hall got right.

Our entrees however took a tremendous, sloppy-seconds nose dive: Fried Chicken, St. Louis Ribs, and a side of Crispy Okra. Chicken was terribly dry, and ribs were covered in fat. The okra was passable, but lacked the salt and spices to push us to Yelp-three-dollar-sign par. A six-piece combo from KFC would've done far better.

With a final tab just north of $80, this was an absolutely absurd "southern dining" experience. Colonel Sanders would've razed this place to the ground.
author: Ray H.

description:
I came here with a group after my round of interviews with my current firm.

We were given quite a large budget per person and we used every bit to our advantage.

I started with the Seafood Chowder and the Butter lettuce,Fujiapples, radishes, candied walnuts and Pt. Reyes blue cheese dressing.  Both were EXCELLENT!

I than had a chicken sandwich (I no longer see on the menu) which was also excellent.

My favorite part: Dessert - I had the Warm Peach and Blackberry Galette
toasted almond frangipane, sweet corn ice cream.  WOW! This dessert was one of the best desserts I have had.

Definitely a great place for colleagues to come an enjoy a meal, or even bring out a client.  I would definitely recommend and come again!

Staff was friendly and knew the menu inside out!
author: Tom L.

description: I really loved the vibe of the place: the cozy, modern space and the food! The bread was soft wheaty sourdough, the seafood chowdah was AMAZING - no corn starch, just the right hint of sherry, veggies were the perfect texture (mmmmm), and the salad really was divine - butter lettuce, slivered apples, blue cheese, candied walnuts, and radish - refreshing. Last but not least, we had admired the pbj (grape) bar as we walked in and they made an exception for us and let us eat it at the table. SO GOOD. Gives Wayfare Tavern a run for the money.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I really only came here for the Butterscotch and chocolate Pot de Creme but the other stooges wanted more substantial grub.
Waiting for the rest of my party, I wished the bar area was a little bigger. My margarita kept me good company and was quickly drained only to reveal another one at the bottom of the glass. But shuffling between the door and hostess station is a little awkward while waiting for the others.
We started with Cornmeal fried oysters which were deliciously crisp and juicy inside. Not having enough fried food, we shared the fried chicken and halibut. The chicken was excellent! Super crispy and not oily at all. Fantastic. 
I would definitely come back again but I wish the bar area was a little bigger.
author: Lawrence T.

description:
So, I made a mistake!!! I used Open Table to make reservation, for that same night, at 9pm.  When we got there and I gave the hostess my name, she couldn't find it.  Ends up, the reservations I made, were for the next evening!!  I felt bad, but she said she'd get us a table in a few minutes, so my husband and I went to the bar and had a drink.  They have an extensive collection of liquors, including an award winning rum, from Guatemala that I love! 

We started with some oysters...My hubby loves them, so he ordered half a dozen.  I'm usually not an oyster girl, but these were delish!

starters were also good, a risotto and a crostini with cheese and pickled veggies... yum!

My hubby had the Cuban marinated pork chops and I had Wild King Salmon, both were delicious...cooked to perfection.  I also ordered a side of hush puppies because who doesn't like those? 

I'm a dessert girl.  I won't finish my dish,deliberately, so I have room for dessert!

And, I have to try two, because, why not?!  The warm peach sticky bun was amazeballs and the Butterscotch and Chocolate pot de creme was also good.  I had and after dinner drink and I convinced myself that I had eaten enough for the next 3 days!  Very delicious and I really enjoyed the ambiance.  I hope to go back soon!  Would definitely recommend for date night!  Service was great!
author: Denice P.

description: We had an amazing dinner celebrating our 7th anniversary. They were kind enough to seat us at a nice private "nook" table (which was perfect because I lost my voice and was afraid we wouldn't be able to talk!). We had champagne, delicious deep fried oysters, the ham sandwich was to die for, awesome halibut and THE...FRIED...CHICKEN!! The food was outstanding and so was the service. They made us feel special and made it a point to congratulate us and surprised us with a complimentary plate of dessert bites since we were too full to actually order a dessert. We will be back!
author: Heather G.

description:
Great Overall Experience.  Service was attentive enough and luckily I was with a fun, entertaining bunch so I barely noticed our waitress (perfect).  My biggest complaint about Town Hall is the acoustics, it is WAY too loud during their dinner service. 


We started with...

  * Bloody mary oyster shooters - Meh... the spicy definitely overpowers the oyster on this one.
  * Biscuits w/ Prosciutto - DELISH.  Definitely worth getting, the red pepper jam has the perfect blend of sweet & spicy that pairs well with the biscuit and prosciutto.

As for entrees... 

  * Buttermilk Fried Chicken -  Great crunch, nice and moist on the inside, the smashed potatoes were great as well, however the brussel sprouts were nothing special. 
  * St. Louis Ribs - I looove ribs, and these were pretty good, but not amazing.  The sauce really added much more depth so slather that sauce!  The cornbread muffin was much better - recommend getting a side of 'em! 
   * A Side of Hush Puppies - These sound tasty, but I didn't feel the hush puppy itself was very flavorful.  I didn't get any of the honey butter on there, but was hoping the puppy would have more of a flavor bang. 

And finally dessert....

  * Pot de Creme - delicious jones.  So thick, rich and creamy, with layers of butterscotch and chocolate, surprisingly large portion for dessert and very tasty, get this one to share with the table. 

Overall - Head to Town Hall and give it a shot!
author: Renae K.

description: This place is super cool but the service is AWFUL! I was seriously appauled at how rude they were. I went here for a company dinner and the bartender and hostess were both so rude. The waiter was also very forgetful and brought us the wrong drink. Shame too cause this place is really cool and the food is great.
author: Brittini S.

description:
I am not a big fan of southern food, so the first time I came here, it was just a confirmation that I don't belong to southern food restaurants.  

I happened to come here again since my partner wanted to try and the location is walking distance from our house.

The food was actually better than I expected.  The bread was good, and the pork chop I had was nicely cooked while the portion was enormous.  I guess the reason why I dont like southern food is that I feel so unhealthy eating it.  And the pork chop was exactly that.  (fried chicken wouldve been worse)  The meat was so thick, and the sauce had a lot of flavors, and there was beans, and the portion was so grand...aaaahhh overwhelming.  

Our waiter was a bit rude.  Our table was unstable and we asked 3x if they could stabilize it.  I guess it wasn't "the waiter's job," and one of the dishwasher guys came at the end of our dinner to fix it.  Well, that was so too too late.  We already had inserted a napkin from the next table.


eh.
author: Shine W.

description:
Totally blown away by Town Hall - sublime dining experience for a reasonable price!

From start to finish, this was probably one of the best dining experiences that I've had in a while. Service was so attentive and friendly - the food was SO GOOD.

Appetizer:
Tuna tartare - deliciously fresh and fun - the fried green tomatoes were genius!

Mains:
Wagyu flat iron steak - how were they able to make a flat iron steak as tender as they did is beyond me. Ordered medium rare - served with a creamy potato puree and a fabulous succotash relish. PERFECTION!

Buttermilk fried chicken - just get this...do it...get it and enjoy each and every tender, juicy, savory bite. I dream of this chicken. Really, I do 

Side:
Fried okra - What do you mean you don't like okra? Really? I bet you'll LOVE this okra! Tender fried bits of yumminess!

Dessert:
Butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme - it doesn't get anymore perfect that this. I really need to learn how to make this because it's decadent, delicious and devilish!

I can't wait to go again =)
author: Christy L.

description: Worse place ever to eat all the waiters and hostesses are jerks. Especially the lady in the front, she seems as though she really hates her job. We had made reservations for 8:30 when we came in she was rude just in her demeanor. In addition to all the other people working there they seem a little off the wall. When we were sitting down they took forever on a simple thing such as bringing out a soda or refilling water at our table. It was about 15 minutes before I even was handed my soda. They have an excuse for everything!! While they try to cram so many damn tables in a tiny place, with no room to move just so they can make an extra buck. Just overall worse place for customer service with decent average food.
author: Austin S.

description:
This place was so thoroughly mediocre I am seriously shocked it's on Bauer's Top 100. Maybe because there are few Southern places?? To start we split the fried okra, some fried green tomatoes (we asked for them a la carte without the tuna) and hush puppies. The fried okra was bland although the batter's fried texture was light and crispy. The green tomatoes were decent although only good because of the dipping sauce. The hush puppies were something any Southern woman could do better. 

For dinner I had the strawberry frisee salad and a side of cornbread. Cornbread was very good, strawberry salad came... without the strawberries. When I pointed this out rather than take it back and plate it properly they just brought me a small cup of strawberries, maybe a total of 2 or 3 chopped. Big No No. My husband and his mother had the fried chicken, which was perfectly cooked and seasoned. My father in law had the blackened catfish, which he said was good but nothing to write home about.

Next we ordered dessert-- the pot de creme and coffee. The coffee pot our waiter used was obviously faulty as it deposited a large amount of grounds into the cup. When my husband pointed this out he asked if Dan wanted a new cup, and after an awkward moment (because what an absurd question) he realized his mistake and just insisted on getting him a new coffee. Somehow it didn't occur to him that my mother in law's coffee was from the same pot (despite the fact that he had served her?!) and left her with the cup with grounds. At this point she didn't want to "bother" the waiter again, as if it were our fault as diners that my salad had been served without the main ingredient and that the coffee pot they used was broken. She drank a cup full of grounds. The pot de creme was very good, but kind of overshadowed by our less than stellar experience.

To boot my mother in law had asked for a box for her fried chicken as she had only eaten half, and it never came. Once the check came and we had paid my husband remembered and asked the waiter. "Stand by," the waiter said, and returned a bit later with some fried chicken. It was more than had been left on my MIL's plate, which is great, but it was once again something they had dropped the ball on. 

To end I would say this may be a great place to grab a cocktail and a couple apps at the bar, but do yourself a favor and skip having an actual meal here.
author: Kathryn M.

description: Amazing, personable service. Rich food, hearty portions. Town Hall really made our night, especially the bar staff. We came in at 9p on a Friday after RN74 failed to seat us for our 8:30 reservation. We were tired, hungry, a little cranky, and had few options nearby, but Town Hall hit the spot as the picture of hospitality, warmth, and delicious food. Get the well-sauced shrimp toast, the duck, and of course the chicken, but save room for dessert.
author: Chris B.

description:
I came here last night with a big family group, and we had a pretty great experience. The service was extremely efficient (I could float home on the amount of water they gave us, since our glasses were never, ever empty), and I liked the atmosphere. While it was a bit noisy, it certainly wasn't unbearable, and I didn't feel like I had to shout. However, there was a Giants game going on so that may have contributed to the quieter atmosphere. 

While I liked my snapper, and everyone at the table seemed to like their entrees (pork chop, flounder, and fried chicken), I thought that the stars of the evening were actually the appetizers and desserts. I loved the tuna tartare and heirloom tomato salad, and we ordered 2 of the pot de cremes for dessert, both of which were hastily passed around and devoured. I also liked my drink, a peach puree with thyme leaves that was extra refreshing after a hot day in the sun at the 49ers game.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Don't go for the Fried Chicken during lunch. It's basically a giant chicken finger. Double breast of chicken cut thin & breaded. Tasted about like Tyson brand chicken fingers. Luckily my friend ordered a burger so I was able to steal some of that which was pretty good.

I've been for a couple lunches but never dinner. Maybe if I ever make it back I will try the real fried chicken that they serve at dinner. I'll be surprised though if I go back anytime soon. It's sort of too fancy for me. As I took the big serrated knife toward the bread (I was going to cut a piece off because all the slices were still connected) the waiter said something like "you do have a butter knife as well". Well yeah no shit.
author: Noah K.

description:
Alas, I cannot give this review more than 3.5 stars, and I can't bring myself to round up.  While my lunch was a solid 4.5 stars, both of my wife's dishes left much to be desired and she thought Town Hall deserves 3 stars, at best.

I guess you could say her expectations were quite high.  Town Hall was, after all, opened by the Rosenthal brothers who basically "made" Postrio what it is today.   Apparently my wife was a good acquaintance with the pastry chef at Postrio back in the day, so she's got all the inside scoop (My wife is also a pastry chef so they used to trade recipes and know how.)   Anyway, she's been talking my ear off about Town Hall ever since we met six years ago.   Since my work is now less than 2 blocks away, I suggested we have lunch at Town Hall and my wife was elated.

Service was impeccable.  I must say that first and foremost.   Our server was friendly and our glasses were topped off without us having to ask.   They fold your napkin when you step away from the table, a nice touch.   5 stars for service.   Absolutely.

For appetizers, I started with the Tuna Tartare, Fried Green Tomatoes, Garlic Chips and Green Onion Tabasco Vinaigrette.  My wife went with the Roasted Beet Salad with hazelnuts and blue cheese.   She thought it was a bit pricey at $13, but apparently the high end blue cheese would explain the price.   While my raw fish was absolutely buttery and succulent, my wife was very disappointed with her salad, seeing no blue cheese on her plate whatsoever.   She was actually going to ask our waitress about it but then backed off in shyness.

As main course, I went with the Chicken fried pork chop, caramelized pears, creamy polenta, watercress and cider jus.   Again, I got lucky because that was a beautiful entree.   It tasted very creamy and warm, the perfect comfort food for a brisk and cold January lunch.   My wife was, yet again, disappointed.   She went with the House smoked corned brisket sandwich with melted fontina cheese on levain bread with sweet potato chips.   While her chips were very good, she thought the brisket was insanely salty and she couldn't taste anything else.   The bread, while oiled on both side, had apparently only been toasted on one side.   She'd also expected it to be a warm sandwich, which it was not.

All in all, not a spectacular experience for a first time.  That said, my wife assured me she'd be willing to try this place again, so let's hope for a little better food next time we come to Town Hall.
author: David O.

description: Negative one star for serving raw meatballs.  But they redeemed themselves with the BBQ Shrimp in Worcestershire sauce.. AMAZING!  So amazing we ordered a second one!   The sauce is just so good!  I'll be back to explore more menu options.
author: Jennifer V.

description:
4 stars for corporate happy hour event

The server, Apollo, is a shining star with an amazing memory!
We come here often and can always count on superior service.
author: Edi B.

description:
Town Hall puts on an amazing Mardi Gras celebration.  This was the 4th year that friends and i have attended and it seems to just get better and better. The staff is always great, the food is outstanding...and they just organize it really well.  

Always hard to decide if the bbq shrimp & grits or the fried chicken is my favorite..although some of my friends would argue that the ribs are the best.  Tough dilemma, guess i'll have to return and try them again.
author: Dilly M.

description:
Loved this place. Did a search for 'American' & 'romantic' and this came up.

We had reservations @ 5:30 (recommended...this place fils up fast) and got there early to hang at the bar. Read Cajun on the menu and was a little skeptical (after growing up in SE Texas...the bar is pretty high)....walked away VERY impressed and looking forward to coming back.

I had the BBQ shrimp (awesome) and jambalaya. Mrs had fried okra (aioli sauce was great), hush puppies and cornbread...all fantastic. Desert was the butterscotch & chocolate cream de pot...again, great.

Staff was very nice. Perfect date night and look forward to coming back.
author: Grant B.

description:
We came to Town Hall recently for a work dinner (so no I didn't pay for it). I know I'm a little late to the band wagon. Town Hall was really hot like 5 years ago and yet I never visited so I was pretty excited to catch-up.

Overall the food was good but the service was really lacking. When we showed up at what we thought was the front entrance there was a bunch of people milling about with no apparent host or host station. It felt like we walked into some corporate event so we walked out and around the building thinking we were just at the wrong entrance. Nope. That was it. So we went back inside and still not host. Took a while for anyone to walk over and greet us. Our entire party wasn't there yet so we opted to wait at the bar. When they finally arrived and we wanted to be seated - again, the hosts had disappeared. After a few minutes I spied her chatting and talking with some friends to the side, pointedly ignoring us. Other people showed up looking confused and I had to let them know yes there was a host and they would be here eventually but they still look unconvinced. After 10-15 minutes she finally extricated herself from her socialization to come and seat us at our available table. So this was how the night started and how it continued. You know that feeling at a bar when the service is so slow that anytime the waiter appears you order another drink even if you still have a full one at hand? That's how it felt here. Service was slow. Food came out slow with long gaps in between.

Now on to the food itself. A bunch of appetizers was shared by the table. Overall for $15 I would expect to get more than 3 tiny servings (approx 6 bites).

* Tuna tartare - as expected, really can one go wrong with tuna tartare? I'm not a big fan of fried green tomatoes in general and Town Hall is no exception. Really hard green tomatoes with no flavor

* Cornmeal fried oysters - best appetizer of the evening by unanimous vote and also the best fried oysters I've had. Super juicy and clean flavor.

* BBQ shrimp - just plain weird. A few shrimp on top of a huge piece of toast soaked in sauce. Took people a while to figure out what this brown thing was under the shrimp. Looked very unappetizing so I didn't try it but it did disappear.

* Buttermilk biscuits - pretty awesome if you make a sandwich by spreading the jelly on the biscuit halves and wedging the prosciutto in between. Only 3 tiny biscuits though for $14. Could really use more biscuits given the amount of prosciutto.

Main courses are more solid. I had the soft shell crab with a side of crispy okra. The crab was really good. The crispy okra came out whole and the breading was a little too oily. Other people ordered the pork chop, duck breast and fried chicken and everyone liked what they ordered.

Desserts were the opposite of the appetizers. Too much of a good thing. I got the butterscotch and chocolate pot de crème which was more like a bowl de créme. Gigantic cereal bowl of pudding. No one was able to eat more than half on their own. Couldn't even take it home. I mean, I'm sure I could but how do you box up a layered pudding in a doggy bag?

Overall food is 4 stars, service 2 stars, value 3 stars if you avoid the appetizers.
author: Jean K.

description:
I came here when they first opened, and then came back again recently.  i am pleased to say that the food is even better than I remembered.

A bit of cajun and spice to their cooking in my second tour, and i have to say all of that was a bit different from the other restaurants in the area.  Maybe it was just the chef's whim at the time, but it was really terrific on the tongue - very very well executed.  It was some of the best jamabalya (side), blackened fish and dirty rice (main dish) I have ever had in California. 

I also had the best pot o'creme (dessert) I ever had here.  

Really, all in all terrific.  Kudos to the chef.  A very pleasant surprise, and it was overall a much better experience than some of the Michilin restaurants in the area.
author: Mark M.

description:
One of the few options in the city for business lunches. 

I tried the following: 

Appetizer:
Crispy Hama Hama Oysters - decent although the breading was a little too heavy for my taste

Main Course;
Ham and cheese toast - It was very unique. The ham and cheese toast was covered with cream and a poached egg. It was delicious but really heavy. I couldn't have anymore after the first few bites. It would have been good to share this dish.

Dessert: 
Butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme - Very creamy and probably the best dish of the meal. 

What really brings Town Hall down is the service. Very slow and clueless service. We waited 20 minutes for every course and then again, for the check. At times, we didn't even know who was our server and every server ignored us and avoided eye contact. Multiple times, busers came out with food and had no idea what table it belonged to. Town Hall really needs to up their game. 

The food might be better than others like Salt House and Roy's, but no one has two hours for a business lunch.
author: Lily S.

description: The food was amazing - the cornbread is the best I've ever had- and the wait staff are very, very nice. We opted to sit outside under the heat lamps and had the whole patio to ourselves. It was great!
author: Kara A.

description:
Craft cocktails are the best thing about this place. Had the gnocchi, bbq shrimp, and lamb meatballs. All good, but would not say that it was exceptional. Average for the Bay Area. 

Building is historic, bar is vibrant, service is slow.
author: chris G.

description:
This restaurant is just opposite the SF office of the company I used to work for, so whenever I spent time in San Francisco I would end up here at least three lunch times in a week with various colleagues. 

The place itself is light and airy, with a good buzzy atmosphere. It has a small covered garden part which is nice to sit in on warmer days. 

I found the entrees to be a little heavy for lunch, so usually stuck to a starter and a salad. I must have eaten their tuna tartare about twenty times, and I still love it! The butter lettuce salad is also fantastic. 

I tried the burger once or twice, and it was perfectly nice, but just too much for a lunch time. 

I usually found the service here to be pleasant. There is always a little ritual when walking in without a reservation - a kind of "well we'll try and fit you in". I have never been turned away, even on a Friday lunch time.
author: Emma M.

description:
Delicious! 

My friends and I were looking for a mid-week place to hang out at a bar and ended up at Townhouse. The bar scene was looking quite slow, so we decided to grab a table instead. After looking at the menu we decided to grab a second dinner here and dessert. 

FRIED CHICKEN was so juicy on the inside, crispy on the outside and the portions were huge. We also had the butterscotch pudding which was nice and rich. We were able to share between three of us. I would definitely come back for a full dinner.
author: bernice c.

description: Came here for a delicious dinner after work. Had their fried chicken. So good. Desserts were great too. Recommended for sure!
author: Garett N.

description:
My boyfriend and I ate here on Saturday evening and I was excited because I'm a real Southern food lover.  Street parking was easy to find, and we were seated about 5 minutes after arriving.  The decor is nice, sort of rustic with all of the wood and retro lighting.  We were seated in a corner, which was just fine because the tables are pretty close to each other.

We ordered 2 appetizers:  the tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes and the oxtail ravioli with english peas and shitake mushrooms.  The tartare was good, nothing special, but tasty.  The fried green tomatoes were, well, red.  They were obviously not green anymore, but more like underripe red tomatoes with a greenish tint (you know, the kind you avoid buying at the grocery store).  They didn't taste bad, but I always think if you're advertising green tomatoes, that's what should show up.  Also, the dish didn't really flow for me.  Why did they pair the tuna and tomatoes?  I thought it might be interesting, but it was just sort of ... meh.  My boyfriend liked the ravioli, but I was unimpressed.  Oxtail is delicious... but not in their ravioli.  It was ok but I definitely wasn't left wanting more.  

I ordered the fried chicken for dinner, he ordered the gumbo with shrimp and sausage.  The chicken was great, and the smashed potatoes accompanying it were fabulous.  We make fried chicken at home every once in a while and it's fabulous, and this was almost as good, but not quite.  We had planned on sharing entrees and I was really bummed that I had to take the gumbo.  It was not good at all.  Having been in the south and cooked a lot of Southern food myself, this dish was just plain undesirable.  The flavor felt thin, and I just wished my boyfriend would give my fried chicken back.  

We also ordered hush puppies which were yummy on the outside (the part where it was crispy) but the inside was just kind of bland.  Also, there was no sauce served with them, so you ended up with a dry ball of cornmeal and nothing to dip it in.

Lastly, I ordered a latte that was just... weird.  I drink lattes daily from lots of places and this one tasted a bit burnt.  I can't remember the last time I sent a latte back, maybe never.  

The server was nice and very prompt, as were the bussers.  The atmosphere was nice and I had a great date, but it wasn't enough to win me over - the food just left something to be desired.
author: Jessica A.

description:
Being just under three blocks from my office, this has become our go-to place for taking out of town colleagues and clients, or celebrating new hires and new business wins. It's pricey, without being over priced and the atmosphere is hip and lively but comfortable. Lots of light and open space, with exposed brick and wood. Makes for a classy but un-stuffy place to dine and talk with friends and colleagues. They have a fairly extensive bar menu, with lots of creative cocktails that intrigue the palette and their menu is streamlined, but thoughtful, with fancy-fied twists on southern comfort food. 

You can't go wrong with the ham and cheese toast, the Town Hall burger or the cuban sandwhich with a side of crispy okra.
author: Laurel S.

description:
Town Hall Restaurant

We went to TownHall Restaurant last week for lunch with a party of 4.  I have been several times but never have rated the place for some reason.  The food is always good as was this visit, but the service plagued us.  I have known one of the owners of the restaurant for quite some time who is a great guy, but may not be aware how strange some of the staff behaves.  Andrew, the host was really nice but doing a lot of damage control recovering from our waitress who was the pits.

Two of us ordered the flounder including myself which was amazing.  The blend of flavors was to die for.  Another one in our group ordered the burger and the fourth person ordered the chicken salad sandwich.  We all traded bites and there was one thing we all agreed upon.....each dish was divine.  For starters the seafood chowder and Green Goddess Salad were both superb as well.  Even the fries and bread taste awesome.

On the service side, we showed up six minutes late for our 12:30 reservation and then ended up waiting to almost 1:00 pm.  Regarding the attention from our waitress, we had little to none.  She forgot my bosses' tea twice and then blamed it on the bus staff.  She didn't return my bosses' credit card with the receipt when paying.  And it took some time to hunt it down.  When we departed the restaurant we exited to the alley behind the building only to find none other than our waitress having a cigarette in the "smoking area".  Ugh!

https://www.townhallsf.com/flash/
author: Chris F.

description: 5 stars based on the brussels sprouts alone.  Those were the best I have ever had in my life.  John was a fantastic waiter as well and the ambiance was relaxing.
author: Kat R.

description:
Town hall is not my go to place.  Luckily though it is someone I know's go to place.  And when he plans dinner we generally end up at Town Hall.  He has good reasons for this.  He can usually get a reservation (though you really do need one), its kind of a power lunch/dinner atmosphere, has a decent wine list and has items on the menu you don't see a ton around here...think southern diner but expensive and fancy.  

The little biscuits on the appetizer list are superb, especially when you also order the amazing BBQ shrimp and dip one in the other...pork chop with grits and cherry gastrique, yum, duck breast...looked amazing and the ribs not too messy.
author: Kierstan G.

description:
I'm in town for a few days was given a list of places to check out, this was one.  I walked seven blocks to get here, through a neighborhood that was so thick with crazy people, I had to strike up a conversation with myself to try and fit in.

Was it worth it... yea I guess it was.  Of course I'm finishing all my partial reviews so it easy to remember only the good times.
author: Gjon C.

description:
Mardi Gras party was amazing!!!!!   Go next year. I've been a regular New Orleans visiter, coming from the ATL. Best Cajun food I've had in the city during that party. 

As far as Town Hall's regular menu, great just like salt house and anchor and hope. Great restaurant owners. Check them all out. 
But at Town Hall... Make sure you have an  espresso martini.
author: Patrick W.

description:
Came here for a business lunch with a co-worker, and the ambiance was quaint and appropriate for the meeting. There seemed to be other tables that were also there on business. However, I could see this place being great for dates or birthdays as well. 

I had the tuna tartare as the appetizer, which was a bit spicy, but overall very tasty and met my expectations for what a good tuna tartare should be. Something a bit annoying was that the waiter kept on asking us if we were finished with our appetizers, and seemed to be rushing us to get to the main course. When we actually did finish though, the main course didn't come for another 15 minutes! 

Moving on to the main dish, I ordered the soft-shell crab sandwich to try something different, and this I wasn't very impressed with. The taste was a mixture of bland and starchy. The crab was crispy though, but it just didn't have much of a savory flavor to it. Disappointed with the crab, but some of the other hot entrees looked like they could be worth trying. 

The best part was that check came in an actual book that some of the customers had even signed in the front or back. It was a very cute touch to the end of the meal!
author: Audrey L.

description:
***This is only for the Town Hall BBQ***

I remember walking to work one day and smelling something smoky.  Then it got on my clothes and my hair.  Later I found out Town Hall is opening a BBQ stand behind the restaurant, in the alley.  I thought to myself : this better be worth the smelly clothes.

It's really not.  I had high hopes to really, really like this place, especially since it's across the street from where I work.

They offer:
*House smoked St. Louis ribs
Quarter slab for $8, half slab for $15, full slab for $25.
Platter (with two sides) for $12.
*Grilled calabrese sausage po boy $8
*Fried chicken sandwich topped with spicy cole slaw $8

Sides:
*Cole slaw $3
*Potato salad $3
*Potato chips $2

Desserts:
*Butterscotch chocolate pot de creme $4
Texas sheet cake with fudge frosting and salted pistachios $3
*Butterscotch chocolate chip cookies $1.50

Drinks $2:
*Sodas
*Lemonade
*Iced Tea

*The fried chicken sandwich can be hit or miss.  I've had both.
*The potato chips are crunchy, but extremely oily.  Good deal for $2 though.
*Cole slaw and potato salad were both runny in texture.
*Pot de creme just wasn't to my liking.
*Lemonade is really good, but sometimes a bit too sour.  Maybe they haven't perfected the recipe yet?
author: Jenny L.

description: Pretty standard financial district/ SOMA fair - a notch up from the Salt House and a few down from the Wayfair Tavern. Quality, if a little boring menu, good service and a lively fun feel to the place. It can get a little 'suity' on weekday nights (but I wear a suit most of the time so I can't complain!), and don't bother when there's a big conference in town.
author: Sam E.

description:
Town Hall does the nawlins thing - sharing a similar vibe with its downtown siblings Anchor & Hope and Salt House.

Our orders:

-Smoked chicken sandwich - $16 or so - BOOM! - I ordered this after the waiter told me it shared best-sandwich-on-menu honors with the burger.  Deeeeee-lish.  Don't hate it for showing up on Wonder Bread.  Love it.

-Shrimp & Grits - $23 or so -  NOT WHAT YOU MIGHT EXPECT, but very nice.  A surprise dish, sort of, because the shrimp show up with their heads on and the grits are griddled as a solid bar - almost looking like french toast made from brioche.  Anyway, it's a visual WTF moment when it comes to the table and you have to reconcile it with what you'd anticipated.  I didn't taste this - but you should be aware of its preparation and plating.

-Mushroom and/or veggie sandwich $14 or so - looked decent.  No comment - though please note that, as implied by my chat with waiter, this is at best the third greatest sandwich of the ~six on the menu.

-Risotto - looked nice.  No other comments.

Thanks, Town Hall.  See you guys- and your shrimp heads - sometime soon.
author: Kevin A.

description:
I've been here for both the dinner and lunch service, and both experiences have been pretty good. 

LUNCH: I came here with my co-workers for our Manager's going away lunch. They have a long table in the front of the restaurant for huge parties. In the evening they use it as a community table where it's first come first serve. The food at lunch is a different menu than the one they give at dinner, although, the portion sizes are just as large! I had the burger for lunch and could barely eat half of it. They served it with fries, so it was a large meal to eat during mid day. I definitely went back to work feeling sleepy from a food coma! 

DINNER: I came here for a Pre-Christmas dinner with my boyfriend before I flew to Seattle. I heard a lot about the fried chicken, but didn't end up getting it. The table next to us ordered it, and surely enough, it was a large portion! I ordered a steak dish which was cooked to perfection. It wasn't too large, in fact, the portion was just enough for me. I guess it really depends on what you order. Not every dish is "large" as I would expect since the lunch portion and the fried chicken was considerably large. 

The decor inside is upscale, enough for a cute little date in the evening. You'll want to make reservations ahead of time if you are coming in the evening on a weekend, as they can get pretty busy. I don't know that I would come here again for lunch, but I would come back to finally try the fried chicken for dinner.
author: Jennifer R.

description: Town Hall over all seems nice, my two stars are for the bartender who humiliated me when I ordered a certain drink and his reply was, "Oh, we don't do that here", like I'd ordered a glass of dog pee. All I wanted was a martini that was apple flavored, like an Appletini.....does that deserve public scorn? I don't think so. Not going back.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Good food overall - had the ahi tuna tartare as a starter. The Tuna Tartare is a must-try for anyone coming to Town Hall for the first time. Flavors, textures, and everything all come together beautifully. Ordered the Duck Confit tacos for lunch; they were very tasty and not too heavy but probably not the best thing on the menu. While they were tasty, they just weren't amazing. The Pot de Creme for dessert was delicious. 

Perfect place for lunch meetings if you work in SoMa.
author: Reem A.

description:
The Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Creme was amazing. Though definitely big enough to share between two people. 

I went for lunch during the week, a great place for a work lunch, but you definitely have to make a reservation!
author: Georgina G.

description:
Fried Chicken Fried Chicken.... well ok.  I have to say I am super spoiled with friends and family who make amazing fried chicken, so I really had high hopes.  I ordered the friend chicken extra crispy.  It was good.  I thought it could have used a bit more seasoning, but it was moist and extra crispy.  The fried green tomatoes were really good too.

Go check it out and let me know what you think!
author: Cynthia D.

description: We had a wonderful meal at Town Hall and the service was exceptional.  Shared the ham as an apetizer, the biscuits and red pepper jelly were the perfect pairing and the ham was served thinly sliced like proscuitto. Husband had the Fried chicken and I had the pork loin....we decided the pork loin was better.  Pork was cooked absolutely perfectly.  The kitchen was running slow so they even bought us another round of drinks on the house.  I perfer a leisurely dinner so I wasn't even concerned about the timing but it was an excellent gesture for them to offer.  Would come again just for that Ham though!
author: Kendra B.

description:
After a day touring about the city with my kids, we were in need of a nice meal. I had heard of Town Hall after attempting to schedule a business meeting a few months back. Thought we would give them a try.

Outstanding cuisine with a wonderful selection of down home, American dishes. I had the red snapper, my wife had the ribs (unbelievable), my youngest daughter absolutely LOVED the macaroni and cheese. The best part of the night was watching my oldest daughter take her first bite of the halibut. I think her exact words were, "This is heaven on a plate!!"

An excellent meal and a great dining experience. Service was spot on - Margie was our server and she ROCKED! We were pleased to get right in with no reservation (8 PM on a Sunday evening).

Locating the restroom was an adventure, however, the hostess was kind enough to direct us through the labryth of stairs, hallways and corridors. Very clean and inviting. Great for a family dinner, place to reconnect with friends or a business meeting of 8-10 people.
author: Tim D.

description: Not great service. Order was wrong and my waiter tried to charge me for it.  Saving grace was that the manager removed the additional item when I asked.  I could have easily paid $30 for fries and a salad 3x at another place and had a better experience.  That said, when I went back to share my experience with the manager, but i will not go back for the food or service.
author: Farkhanda Z.

description:
I am going to preface this with the fact that we barely got to eat here ...which is why I am giving them three stars (benefit of the doubt), but the service was humorously bad. I came here with a few co-workers at around 4pm for a few glasses of wine and maybe some snacks. We were told we can sit outside, which we did, but the waitress didn't seemed to interested in brining us menus. After 15 minutes we had to go ask for some water and maybe to see a menu. Got a bottle of wine, some oysters (very good), and some shrimp skewers. Given the speedy service, by the time we got the appetizers it was close to 5, so we asked if they could make us a salad, the answer was no, we'd have to wait until the dinner menu at 530. ok. 505 we get ahold of the menu for the happy hour that apparently just ended and learned that there was a salad option, when we  inquired we were told that we just missed it and have to wait until 5. 

I'm sorry but what in the world? Three stars is generous and based solely on the wine which was pleasant and oysters which were good ... but not sure if I'd give it another go. FiDi has other options where the service is attentive and don't waste your time.
author: Katya B.

description:
Not sure what the big rave is about here.  I've tried their famous fried chicken and their thigh was too salty to eat.  I had to put it down and dipped my hands/fingers into my friend's plates...which weren't that great, but at least edible.

On the plus side, they do serve large portions...so keep eating porkies!

The restaurant is overly noisey and dark.  And the waiters were not as prompt.  I'm sorry to the tables next to us who had to hear our yelling because we can't hear ourselves.  And waiters, please don't keep us waiting 20-30 minutes between entree/dessert/check.  We came in at 8:30 and left at 11.  That's how LONGGGG our dinner dragged out.  

I expected much more from a restaurant in the FIDI with these prices...

I wouldn't not go back.  If you're in the area, I'd highly recommend Prospect instead.  Same price range with better atmosphere, wait staff, and food!
author: Janet L.

description:
Came here on business lunch with a budget of 30 bucks per. 8 people.
Reservation was at 1:30 and we arrived on time. We ordered about 15 minutes in and got our food around 40 minutes later. 

I had the Cuban sandwich + 2 sides, french fries and FRIED OKRA (16+7+6=$29 base). Needless to say I had a whole ton of fried stuff and it was all I could down before I was full. I would've rather gotten 2 portions of the fried okra instead-- the yucca fries with the sandwich were just like the french fries anyway. And yeah, fried okra is awesome with all its crunchy slimeyness.
 
I took the sandwich home to eat for dinner. They give you nice paper bags along with the containers with your leftovers. The sandwich was way too salty for my taste but not bad otherwise.

Overall, just another overpriced, conversation-noisy eatery in SF, but a good option for those company-paid meals. I sat right across from the kitchen door and constantly saw waiters coming in with dishes full of uneaten food from other customers. I don't like wasting food, so it caught my eye every time. :P

I'd put 3 Stars, but service was excellent. Nice waiter, so an extra star for that.
author: Ivy H.

description:
Gorgeous, casually elegant interior of a restaurant with wonderful service and really, really good southern-inspired food in San Francisco. These were my favorites:

TUNA TARTATE: I don't like raw, I barely like tuna and I'm a "texture" person -- but the tartare was amazing and I am so glad I ordered it. Perfection.

FRIED OKRA: Just get these. Crispy delicious. The cilantro aioli for dipping is yummmy.

BUTTERSCOTCH POTS DE CREME: This dessert took me back to childhood. It was creamy, sweet and very comforting. 

COD with OXTAIL RAVIOLI: Really creamy, light entree. Loved it!
author: Autumn N.

description:
A gorgeous day in San Francisco is always made better by a lovely brunch experience, and that is what I consider Town Hall to be - absolutely lovely.

Sitting quietly in downtown San Francisco is a brick building where Mitchell Rosenthal puts together some of the best food this city has ever seen.  This was another instance of knowing the cook's recipes before having tasted the food.  "Cooking My Way Back Home" is filled with rustic, comforting and tasty dishes that will inspire anyone into the kitchen.  It was satisfying to know that Town Hall lives up to their reputation in ambiance, service and culinary creativity.

Walking into Town Hall is an experience worth the trip in and of itself.  It's a different world, where the southern drawl, sweet tea and Louisiana blues all make sense.  The restaurant has an incredible décor -  a perfect match for dinning with friends or drinks after work.

This is not your grandmother's food.  Rosenthal's attention to detail and love for each dish shows clearly in its presentation and flavor.  The food is down home good cook'n - the best kind as far as I'm concerned.
author: Jessica C.

description: Went here on a Saturday night 9 pm had a nice server lots of great apps corn bread was fun and tasty BBQ shrimp plate was licked clean lol yummy fried oysters main dish was duck finished it all ! Then did my exercise up the stairs to the restroom lol
author: Coral S.

description:
We had a private event on the 2nd floor.  The service was attentive, and the food was pretty tasty.  Portion size was moderate - with a 3 course meal, you will be pretty full, but portions are not large enough where you will have a doggy bag for leftovers.  I had the mixed salad, spiced rubbed mahi mahi, and the torte for dessert.  Everything was tasty, though the spice rub was a little too strong in flavor.  The acoustics on the floor amplified conversations so even though we were only one party, the room got quite loud.  Note that there is no restroom on teh ground floor - only on the 2nd floor, which is a bit inconvenient if you are eating on the ground floor.
I probably wouldn't come here on my own dime, but for a corporate meal, it's a treat!
author: Bebe W.

description:
I love this place. I have had many functions here, work dinners/lunches/birthday dinners and all my out of town visitors. Cool vibe, excellent food and every waiter is well trained and excellent at their jobs.
I was a little disappointed last time I was there. I mentioned to the waiter that I thought the corn muffin that came with my yummy ribs. He offered to bring me another one. I was delighted, thanked him twice. He said "my pleasure". Then the bill came $3 for a tiny itsy bitsy muffin/cupcake. $3 is not much when you are out for a lovely dinner, but I wish he would have told me there would be a charge.
author: Marie L.

description:
Can you say pretentious?!?!?

But I think the restaurant knows it's awful, the people going there know they're awful, and everyone is happy sitting there absorbing each other's pretentious, pompous awfulness. The menu is intentionally bewildering with an array of too-obscure-for-no-good-reason ingredients.

Food portions are tiny and extremely expensive. The waiters are angry if you ask what their unnecessarily obscure liquors taste like and... well, the fried okra was good.
author: Zach S.

description: p.s - I received a message from the manager and general manger. I really appreciate that they care about their clientele and am looking forward to experiencing the real Town Hall. I will update my review soon!
author: Leanne S.

description:
AWESOME PLACE. Pricey, but not overpriced. Expect a two person meal to be $85 on the cheap end and $115ish on the average. I spent about $95 and had a very filling meal. 

The interior design is awesome- super modern but in an old building. Well lit. Very friendly service. Our waiter was super informed as to how the food is cooked, which is helpful. The seafood potpie is huge portion for very hungry folks, but not their best dish. 

Get the meatballs for your appetizer. Can't go wrong. Also, you should know, their butterscotch dessert is one of the top 10 desserts in San Francisco. We got it and it was amazing.
author: Nick H.

description:
This restaurant's service is definitely one of the worst I've experienced. Met up with someone there for business lunch, we had one hour. It took 15 minutes to get seated (no big deal), another 15 minutes to get a glass of water (we had to ask 3 different staff members), and another 15 minutes to get someone to take our order. After over an hour, we still had not gotten any food (even though all the tables around us did). We asked to speak to the manager; he did not come out. 
We left, absolutely insulted.
author: Ali G.

description:
This is fairly upscale dining that lives up to the price and expectations, sort of.  I love the diverse selection of entrees (I've enjoyed the catfish and fried chicken) and appetizers (I had the fried oysters and calamari, both also very good).

It's a pretty small space, but cozy.  The servers are friendly, responsive, and will give you suggestions if you're stuck.  Everything from presentation to taste are excellent.
author: Angel S.

description: The fried chicken and corn bread are amazing. The corn bread is dripping in butter.... and I'm okay with that. Good service. Bustling, good atmosphere. Will return to try the ribs!
author: Lauren D.

description:
After years of wanting to check this spot out for dinner, finally had the chance.

Bonus #1 - Parking spot right in front (score!)

Bonus #2 - Was kindly convinced to give oysters a shot again...It's basically been a 5-year hiatus since I was bamboozled by a bad oyster packed with gut-curdling brine and sand...blahhh...that was the impetus that sparked my half decade ban on oysters.  Thankfully, the Oregon oyster offered up by Town Hall was flavorful and completely blahhh-free.

Bonus #3 - The Tuna Tartare was excellente.

Bonus #4 - The Peanut Tasso Crusted Pork Chop & Dirty Rice was well-portioned and bursting with spicy flavor that was balanced and not too overwhelming.

Bonus #5 - Hazelnut Chocolate Cake with Cinnamon Ice Cream was a perfect slice of dense, rich, sugary sweetness.

It was overall a night of pleasantly unexpected bonuses and I'm all good with that.
author: Justin L.

description:
So worth the wait!  We got there 45 minutes early and pretty much knew we would be waiting to be seated for our reservation, the place was packed.  But the hostess was so nice, she sat us at the community table and we ordered some wine and the frog legs.  I was so excited, the last time I had frogs was in Paris.  I wish they had more of them on the plate, but it was a nice size appetizer for two to share.   She was so friendly and truly enjoyed her job, which was a refreshing way to be greeted and start off our dinner.

We were seated promptly for our reservation and ordered the fried chicken and the sole, as well as the corn bread.  The food was amazing, great flavors, presentation and execution.   I can't comment or say anything wasn't done right.   The service was friendly, professional and you could tell the servers were trained and enjoying their job and were helpful with selections and explanations.

The space is also a very unique and beautiful, it's a brick building with great natural light and fixtures, has a very nice urban feel mixed in with modern and a hint of industrial.  The noise also filters very well so you don't hear other people's conversations.  They have a great drink and wine list.

We only had coffee for dessert but the menu looked great,  the espresso was great and so many places don't get it quite right or hot enough.

We would definitely come back and bring some friends.  The menu is very diverse and there are lots of dishes on it that I still want to try, which is another great feature, so many places now only have four to five items on the menu.

The price wasn't bad either, with wine, appetizer, two entrees and coffee we paid $110 with tip, not a cheap dinner but for the quality of food and atmosphere very reasonable for San Francisco.
author: Inga W.

description:
meh.  I suppose I had very high expectations and it was fine but not great.
The staff and service are great - nice and efficient.  The disappointment was really the food.  So the low down..
Tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes - DELICIOUS.  A very promising start.
  Fried chicken - disappointment. Good flavor, but very very dry.
  Mashed potatoes - not great.
  Sea bass - skip, not good. Didn't taste fresh, not much flavor
  cat fish - also not great.
  pecan pie - miss (medjool dates, whipped topping), not good
  cheese cake - not good at all, what the heck... does not even hold a distant candle to Junior's
  bread pudding - the "best" dessert on the menu, but even then.. nothing to write home about.

All in all, it was okay - it's a busy, happening restaurant, but the food missed its mark for me.
author: Madison W.

description: In an old building that dates to the old industrial past of SOMA. This place has been open for over a decade and most entrees are good, if not particularly original. Most interesting menu items, and mainstays of the menu are the japapeno cornbread, served in mini loaves in their own special ramekins. The warm cheese and egg toast in Jalapeno cheese cream (Faith's ham and cheese) are the other must order. In fact order more than one of each as you will not want to share. Also feature fish, seafood and steak entrees. Same owners as Anchor and Hope and Salt House. Just a few blocks from Moscone Center, Embarcadero and Transbay Terminal.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Went with two friends after a long day of workshops.  Reasonably priced for the location/ambience.  Close enough to walk from Moscone.  Nice crowd/atmosphere.  Service was great.  Tuna Tartar, BBQ shrimp, Veal meatballs were all great.  We had the fried chicken (since everyone's been raving about it), Manhattan Steak and Pork Chops.  All of which were great, plates ended up completely bare...  The steak came with eggs over easy and creme fresh with siracha for a sauce.  Interesting, but it worked.

With two bottles of wine we ended up around $300 ish for 3 of us.  If you've got an expense account, a great place to take clients.  However, a bit pricey for a casual dinner.  Definately would take the wifey there if we were in town.
author: Tony E.

description:
I am not sure there is much for me to say that hasn't already been said, but I went here last night for my friend's birthday.  I made a reservation the day of for 10 people and they were able to accommodate us.  

The atmosphere was nice, it wasn't crazy busy, but it was a Thursday night and not the weekend.  Even so, it was way less crowded than a place like Nopa.  The food was pretty good.  Everyone seemed to really like the fried chicken, the risotto was good, the ribs smelled amazing, but I didn't actually eat any, veal meatballs also good, and the jalapeno corn bread...mmm.  

The service was good, but not great.  Our server yelled, like he was loud.  Also I really wanted to try some of their dessert after seeing some of the comments....the server brought us the dessert menu, but never came back to ask if we wanted dessert, because the kitchen was closing.  Which is a little bit of a bummer.

All in all, I enjoyed my trip here and will keep it in mind for future dinners.
author: Kimmy G.

description:
Been here 3 times. 2 of the 3 times would have received 3 stars.  this one gets 2 and that is being generous. 

Great biscuits and good fried chicken.  OK ribs. But tonight the seafood pot pie was more or less inedible. First there was no seafood to be found. I'd say there were potatoes and carrots and maybe just maybe a miniature shrimp. But the real problem was that dish was overly spiced with both black pepper and some sort of chili pepper. And I like spicy food.  Very disappointed.
author: John B.

description:
We came here for lunch around noon, but had reservations at least a few weeks ahead of time. It's such a short walk in SF! It was my first time and I was just really impressed. We came in, and were seated. We were seated in the back, and I love the whole design of the place. Really rustic, comfort, and modern. 

I'm not gonna like, it ain't cheap. But I ended up ordering the pulled chicken salad (chicken, cherry tomato, green cabbage, mango, cilantro, mint, peanut vinaigrette) which according to the latest menu is $14. But it is a moderate size though. The waiter was very nice, checked in on us, filled up our drinks. 

And for dessert, I had their butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme topped with buttercrunch ($10). MMMMMM. Yum, it was divine. Except for some reason I thought it was going to be a hot dessert. Guess not. And the buttercrunch isn't a "topping", they were pieces of buttercrunch that I used to dip. I would come back to Town Hall for the dessert menu only, so delicious. 

The waiter came with our bill too. Um, how cool is that your bill is given to you in a real, hardcover book?? It's so unique, and I would recommend this place again. It gets really busy around lunch though, so try to make a reservation beforehand.
author: Lola H.

description: The food itself would probably get a five star here, nobody at our table of five had any complaints. However, the service left a sour taste in our mouths. Minus one star:The host was condescending and rude when we asked for a different table because of the loud and distracting service entry way. Minus one star: Then the host and our waitress were witnessed talking and laughing about us during our dinner. Minus one star: To top it all off the waiters never brought back our leftovers to take home. Did not feel like a valued customer in the least. No warm and fuzzies at this place. There are plenty of other great restaurants to eat at and spend your money on in The City.
author: Maria D.

description:
Just tried Town Hall for the first time. Excellent food. Cozy, warm interior. Attentive service. Overall, a very enjoyable dinner. We had:

Bread:
Crusty Acme loaf 

To start:
Veal meatballs over mashed potatoes

Entrees:
St. Louis ribs
Dungeness crab gnocchi

Dessert:
Butterscotch / chocolate pot de creme

Everything was delicious and well-seasoned. Even the leftovers held up well for lunch. The crab gnocchi dish was the star. I'd go back for that in a heartbeat.
author: Amy C.

description:
Town Hall is a good spot for your Casual American Dining experience.  The menu had a pretty decent variety, with most of the dishes seemly inspired by the southern United States.  

Appetizers ranged from various salads, to seafood on through meatballs and biscuits.  Entrees consisted of your BBQ ribs, Buttermilk Fried Chicken, to a few different flavors of steaks & seafood dishes.  Portion sizes for appetizers were relatively small compared to the entrees.

I enjoyed this place and would be willing to return if ever in San Francisco again.  I'd give this place 3.5 if there was an opportunity for a half star.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
What a great place! Wonderful staff and nice to the meat adverse :) I can't say much about most of the dishes, but seasonal items and fried okra were amazing!

Advice to my fellow vegetarians: ask specifically for what you want, or you may end up with a whatever dish, I recommend getting as many seasonal veggies as you can, the chef will probably throw together a few sides from the other dishes. I had my server talk to the chef, and I LOVED what they concocted!
author: Lana L.

description:
My first ever "fancy" restaurant in San Francisco. Brought by my fellow coworkers and developer team (awesome team and very friendly might I add) me and two other interns had lunch here. The first thing I noticed was how you have two forks and two knives. Damn, seems too fancy for me. The menu came in a sheet of paper, kind of neat but most likely because the menu keeps changing so they don't have a permanent menu. 

Anyways, we ordered some cornbread as appetizers and I personally ordered the smoked salmon on rye with a green salad. The bread arrived first and holy crap was it good. The crust was crunchy and the bread was definitely fresh and moist. Absolutely delicious. The corn bread with jalepeno (I know kind of strange) came shortly after but wasn't spicy even though there was jalepeno in it. It tasted great but came in very small portions, but hell it's a fancy restaurant you kind of expect that.

When the main course arrived, everyone ordered a burger with avocado mmmm and some fries that tasted just like chips (mmmmmmm even more). My sandwich came with a salad while everyone had burgers and fries which made me feel kinda hipster, but whatever I'm in SF health is kind of important here anyways. I took the sandwich and took a big bite out of it and my mind was absolutely blown. The bread was crispy and crunchy yet it was complimented with the smokey and savory taste of the salmon alongside the sour cream and avocado smothered on the bread. It was one of the best tasting sandwiches ever. I devoured the both halves and finished the salad which was fragrant and fresh. I helped my friend finish his fries which were very crispy and tasted really good.

Fancy? Definitely. Worth the price? I'd guess so. Service and speed? All the food came at the same time and the wait staff was friendly and quick. One of the top places here in SF? Not sure, but definitely something to check out. I would give this place a 3.5 as it definitely isn't the BEST place to have dinner or lunch for it's price but I'll be nice and give it a 4.
author: Aaron P.

description: Good service, atmosphere, must get: fried chicken, BBQ shrimp and butterscotch dessert.  Everything else was just okay.  We had to return the steak as it was not a good cut of meat.  I would go back for the chicken and the ribs looked good!
author: Lisa N.

description:
Holy Sodium Intake Batman! The chef here isn't afraid of causing a little high blood pressure in diners of Town Hall. Not with the way he throws salt around in his creations. It was Thursday night and me and my girls needed a place to dine. I have heard so many great things about Town Hall so I called them first to see if they could accommodate. 8:30pm reservation for 3 was no problem for them. Booked!

We arrive and wait about 15 mins before being seated. Once seated we order pretty quickly. We started with: 

Stuffed Piquillo Peppers - had a slight fishy taste, but thanks to all of the salt, it was muffled a bit. Other than the taste, the texture reminded me of baby food. MUSH. 

Cornmeal Fried Oysters - SO DAMN FISHY. Took one small bite and couldn't bare another. Oh and don't forget the salt! 

Cheese & Ham Toast - this was actually really good, but it was DROWNING in the jalapeno cream which was of course, salty. 

These all came out pretty quickly and dinner seemed to be off to a good start, despite the constant need for water due to the saltiness of everything. A note to the wait staff - please leave a little room in the small glasses for water. There was so much ice in my glass that after 3 gulps I had no more water. 

So we're girls, we're chatting, we're catching up. The time got away from us until finally someone stopped the talking and said "where is our food?" Indeed, over an hour had passed and we still didn't have our entrees. One gentleman, I'm assuming he was the floor manager (sorry I can't remember his name), but he came over and gave us the biscuits w/ prosciutto and red pepper jam appetizer - on the house. Nice gesture. He was actually very nice and apologetic and we appreciated it, but we wanted our food, not an app. 

Finally the entrees come out:

Wild Flounder - didn't personally try it, but my friends were complaining about it being too salty. 

Grilled Porkchop - overcooked to hell! The flavor was good and I loved the fried cheese grit cakes, but holy hell. The meat was so unbelievably dry that it was hard to swallow. And yes... VERY SALTY. 

Fried Chicken - actually probably some of the best fried chicken I've ever had. Moist, juicy, tender and all that jazz. Coating was a little soft and not as crunchy as I'm used to, but still good. This dish actually had just the right amount of salt too. Shocking. 

We were already there for almost 3 hours so we ended up skipping dessert. The night guy who brought out the biscuit app ended up comping some of our food and the 2 glasses of wine, but somehow the bill was still $155... Ridiculous. 

I have to say, this was one of the most disappointing restaurant experiences ever. To hear about a place for 3 years and to have people keep saying how "YOU HAVE TO GO" and then to have this kind of experience and terrible salty food. Just sad.
author: Jen D.

description:
Hear ye!  Hear ye!  It is by decree of the Lady Amy R that this restaurant is to be given 5 stars, henceforth!

I have only been here for dinner but I can imagine that it would be pricey for lunch (as mentioned in other reviews).  I have always had great service and great food here.  Last time I went, I ordered one of each of the 5 different oysters on the menu and my favorite was the Blue Point oyster which isn't on the online menu but worth trying if you see it.

I've tried the trout, the fried chicken and the steak and they've all been fantastic.  The various soups of the day are always worth ordering.  They also have a number of gigantic sides that are great.  I'd recommend both the macaroni and cheese and the jambalaya.  I haven't tried the other ones, but I'd imagine they are also huge.

...but the whole reason to go to Town Hall is really to have the Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Creme for dessert.  I love that dessert.  If they ever discontinue that dessert, I will cry and cry and the seas will rise and it won't even matter if the polar ice caps melt because I will flood the earth with my tears.

Where's the bill?  Take a look.  It's in a book.  Reading Bill...bo...hmmmmm.
author: PrincessPeac H.

description: Best fried chicken in SF for fine dining. I have been to several places in the city including Firefly and Foreign Cinema for fried chicken and nothing compared to their dish.
author: Nohe M.

description: We have come to to Town Hall a couple of times and love it.  The atmosphere is very open and welcoming and the food is amazing but you have to like southern cooking a bit to enjoy it.  I always get the fried green tomatoes to start (very few places in SF offer these) and the ribs for my entree.  The tomatoes are green and fried to perfection and my ribs are always meaty and a large portion with fluffy cornbread.  The servers are very professional and attentive and make sure we have everything we need.   Great place in SF for dinner.
author: Justine A.

description:
Visiting for the weekend from Los Angeles, we heard about this place and it was walking distance from our hotel (W Hotel) so we decided to check it out. Overall, I didn't think anything was as special as it's been made to be. 

The fried chicken is the obvious choice if you're reading all of these reviews, which I got, but I probably wouldn't get that again. It was good, but really, should a 3 piece fried chicken meal really cost more than $20? You be the judge on that, but I'd rather get a 3 piece at KFC for under $7...but that's just me. I'd pick the coleslaw over those greens any day of the week. 

Other than that, they do have a pretty good wine selection and the other choices on the menu are good. Again, I didn't think anything was special, but it was good. In my opinion, it's a bit overpriced but the ambiance of the restaurant makes up for it. 

Only thing I remember and will take away from the food from here is the BBQ shrimp, Worcestershire sauce, garlic herb toast. That was pretty delicious.
author: Jason A.

description:
Ate here last night around 9 p.m.   The service was the only negative, very slow ( we sat for at least 20 minutes before anyone acknowledged us) throughout out the entire meal.  They don't seem happy to be working there,

We loved the food.  We had the asparagus salad, stuffed peppers, side of jambalya and a side of okra.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Seriously had high hopes for this restaurant.  Booked on Open Table because I saw them on Bay Area Check Please.  Was excited to try the pork chop and some of their other flavors.  I don't really want to get into it because to each his own, but from the hostess, to the waiter, and the food, the experience was awful.  

Maybe it was just an off day for everyone there, so I'm not gonna get into it and rip on them because overall most people seem to enjoy this place.  Guess it's just not a right fit for us.  :-)
author: Arman B.

description: Came here for the Creme de pot. Pretty good. Goes very well w the toffee bars. Creme is not too sweet and comes in a laugh bowl enough for two to share. Servers are nice and venue is romantic and cute.
author: Carrie T.

description:
REALLY love this place.... wonderful service, consistently delicious food, and a great atmosphere. I decided to branch out of my comfort zone today and try their Albacore Tuna dish. I've never gotten really into ordering fish when I go out, but I thought I would try it here and see if they could make a believer out of me. 
They DID!

Perfectly cooked, tender without falling apart and being messy- and the flavors in the stewed vegetables/orzo that the fish filet was set upon were complimentary without being over powering

3 things I dont like in one dish: cooked veggies (I like my stuff fresh!) rice (orzo), and fish... Why I ordered it? I dont know... but they surprised the heck out of me and it was DIVINE.

I'll be back time and time and tiiiime again.
Also, their music reminded me of New Orleans, blame my fond (and somewhat fuzzy memories), but I left this place absolutely beaming.
author: Julia T.

description:
Pepper stuffed with crab, topped with rock shrimp - way overseasoned and the pepper was too soft and with the crab, it didn't have a good balance of texture (would not recommend it)

Ham and cheese toast with poached egg - This was probably the best dish of the night.  It did feel more like brunch food though.  Flavor was good and great combination.

Fried chicken - tender and juicy, skin wasn't as crispy as what I'd expect given all the rave, and it was underseasoned

Butterscotch & chocolate pudding - it's good and not too heavy, but never the less, it's rich; i'm not sure how anyone is suppose to finish it after a meal.  It was more than 2 people can eat.  The table next to us couldn't finish it either

Coffee and doughnuts - the beignets weren't as fluffy as i'd prefer it, but overall, i liked it; it wasn't overly sweet and the espresso ice cream and chocolate struesel was good.

Conclusion: I can say that I've tried Town Hall.  Nothing to rave about.  Would not go back again given all the great restaurants in SF.
author: Irene C.

description:
Amazing food and service. White table cloth place and excellent fare.

Duck was amazing
Beet Salad was amazing
Gumbo was amazing
Halibut was amazing-blackened.

wine selection is great as it has all price points and I think this place has a great vibe and atmosphere.

Definitely a very good place.
author: Stephen R.

description:
Great atmosphere. Cozy spot for gathering with friends or family, and not so loud you have to shout to be heard.

The ahi appetizer was amazing, I wish it had been bigger. I got the fried chicken and my husband had the scallops. Both were delicious, although the collards that came with the chicken were misleadingly spicy.

We all shared the Chocolate and Butterscotch Pot de Creme and I have to say it's now up there in my top 3 desserts of all time. 

Staff was very friendly and helpful, especially with wine pairings!
author: Katherine B.

description:
One of the best things in the greater Bay Area: Faith's warm ham and cheese toast, poached egg and jalapeno creme.

Cheesy, creamy, savory, dip-py.
author: James G.

description: Good food, great drinks.  Had the Ahi, and the ribs.  No complains.  Cant make a bad move with regards to food or drink here.  Two thumbs up!
author: Brian S.

description: This is a great restaurant that mixes Southern and Californian cuisine.  I have never had a disappointing meal here.  The menu is ever-changing, which makes each experience fresh, but some classics do seem to remain on the menu.  The ahi tuna tartare topped fried green tomatoes really hit home with me.  I also love their sides so much that sometimes I'll make my meal out of them.  They have a good wine list and a solid bar.  Definitely one of my favorite restaurants in the City.
author: Scott E.

description:
Not bad- but not great. Another example of a $150 dinner that was forgettable (and I brought wine - $20 corkage)

The Good.... the butter lettuce, fuji apple,walnut salad was simply outstanding-
one of the BEST dinner salads I've ever had
* Service-- very efficient-friendly

The BAD-- the fried chicken was just OK, moist Yes. Tasty-No--- a few notches above KFC The cornbread pudding was bland / inedible.Collard greens- FORGET IT

Wife had the coho salmon (she Loves salmon- I don't) Her comment - 'I've had better' Sides were mediocre.

Will I go back-- I guess- but menu is limited.

My mantra - once again... so many restaurants  are fine for lunch-- but fall short for dinner. Town Hall is no exception. Better to Splurge on a great restaurant once vs 2 dinners at place like Town Hall where you don't even remember
what you ate 3 days alter
author: W K.

description:
I had been to Town Hall a few times about 4 years ago when working downtown and always thought highly of the restaurant. So when a childhood friend of mine came to town to visit, I thought this would be a good choice for a nice dinner. I was a little nervous about bringing our 2 year old son with us, but we couldn't get a babysitter.

After I made a reservation, I decided to look at some reviews here on Yelp and was disappointed to find that some recent reviews were less than stellar and one reviewer was treated harshly after bringing a 2 year old nephew to dinner. Feeling uncomfortable after reading these reviews, I tried to find another venue for dinner but couldn't get a table on such short notice for Saturday night.
