Thankfully, our dinner experience turned out to be quite wonderful. As soon as the hostess checked us in, she asked if we would like some crayons and paper for our son which we gratefully accepted. We had to wait perhaps 10 mins for our server to appear, but after that our order was taken promptly and we didn't have to wait long between courses. 

The food itself got a huge thumbs up, every dish we ordered was flavorful and generously portioned:

- heirloom tomato salad - very fresh, loved the mint and yoghurt dressing
- tomato mascarpone risotto - creamy yet refreshing. The fresh tomatoes made all the difference.
- buttermilk biscuits with prosciutto and Red pepper jelly - a lovely savory/sweet combo
- Ham, cheese and egg toast with jalapeño cream - decadent goodness!!

We shared ou mains family style and got to sample the best of what Town Hall has to offer:
- BBQ Ribs - meat fell off the bone, the sauce was a standout
- Pork cooked two ways - perfectly tender pork medallions and pork belly, paired perfectly with nectarines
- fried chicken - juicy, nicely seasoned classic

Dessert was also great, but my favorite will always be the butterscotch and chocolate pudding, which was exactly as I remembered it years ago.

Overall we had a thoroughly enjoyable evening and I was grateful that the restaurant accommodated our 2 year old as this is really a place for adults to enjoy and linger over dinner. (Another bonus was that the adjoining garden courtyard at 199 Fremont ended up being the perfect playground for my 2 year old when he couldn't sit still after we finished our mains.)

I'm glad to say that I would still highly recommend Town Hall as a dining destination!
author: Melissa S.

description:
In from out of town, I wanted to try a great SF restaurant.  After doing some research, I settled on Town Hall.  I couldn't get a reservation so the concierge at my hotel got one for me (after arriving I realized that I could have just walked in).

The service was awesome!  She was very knowledgeable about the food as well as the drinks.  5 stars for service.

I started out with a squash and pear cream soup which was nice.  After the server warned me about the bacon wrapped quail being too meaty, I settled for the pork chop, per her suggestion.  I think the idea was there, but overall it was pretty tough.

The decor seemed a bit dated for what they were going for, could use a slight sprucing up.  I thought bringing the check in a book was a cute idea.  If I lived here I would go again, but being a visitor, there are too many other great places that I want to try.
author: Zach M.

description:
Southern Food with San Francisco sensibilities.  The portions are not obesity-adjusted, but right-sized to fill you up without feeling gross.  The restaurant is more FiDi power lunch than molasses slow service from someone you call ma'am.  The take away stand in the back provides much more exciting lunchtime options than those horrible Chinese steam table and deli sandwich shops polluting the FiDi.  Town Hall is a great way to experience the South without all the red.

Buttermilk Biscuits: A few tiny biscuits with prosciutto-style ham and peach jam topping options.  I really appreciate the ham and peach condiments since it adds a new sophistication to the biscuits.  The biscuits were a bit dry and needed some external butter addition, which is unfortunate.  It may be declasse, but I love me the butter-level in Popeye's biscuits!

Seafood Étouffée: Excellent spicy broth with tasty crawfish.  More places in San Francisco should serve crawfish (especially the shelled version for us lazy folks).  The shrimps were a little shrimpy, a much better presentation would have had a few jumbos in there.  

Fried Chicken Sandwich (Take Away): You might dislocate your jaw on this one.  Two deep fried chicken breasts, spicy coleslaw and a thick rustic roll make this sandwich a tower!  The coleslaw adds a nice tangy contrast to the fried chicken since it is vinegar based without cream.  The chicken breasts are like adult-sized chicken tenders.  Very tasty and moist, but I wish the chicken was fresh out of the fryer instead of at room temperature.

Butterscotch Chocolate Pot De Crème (Take Away): Butterscotch, amazing how butter and brown sugar can create such magic.  Butterscotch on top of chocolate makes this two layer pot de crème a force to reckon with.  Thin toffee with dark chocolate covering add a nice crunchy contrast to the smooth base.
author: Adam B.

description:
Town Hall continues to deliver.  It is right up there with our favorite classic San Francisco restaurants -- Zuni Cafe, Boulevard, etc.  Started off with raw oysters, barbecue shrimp, biscuits with ham, and a paquillo pepper special appetizer.  We always get the fried chicken (among the best in the city), but also tried the fish dishes -- trout wrapped in bacon and the flounder; as well as the soft shell crab with pork belly -- all amazing.  Then we had the classic chocolate and butterscotch pot de creme, the fruit galette and some mini-cupcakes provided with a candle for our special birthday celebration. 

Taking the advice from Dyan Y. re: service -- Be sure and ask for Cynthia as your server -- she and her trainee, Margie, were top notch!!  Attentive, made knowledgeable recommendations; and were fun to boot!!  A great dining experience all around!!!
author: Kevin G.

description: I have to say that despite all of the hype that I heard about this place, I was a little underwhelmed.  The oyster appetizer was okay, but not particularly thrilling and I'm not entirely sure that they were as fresh as I would have expected being right near a huge body of water.  The pork was okay, but again, not particularly flavorful.  I don't know that I'd go back. One interesting incident: they had a bottle of wine that was particularly low priced given the quality of the wine.  My dad pointed this out to them and their response was mild surprise; when we ordered it, they then came back to us and told us that they didn't have any.  Not entirely sure if that was the truth or they simply were trying to cover the fact that they had seriously mispriced this wine.  Service was okay, but not quite as good as one would expect for the price.
author: Elliott D.

description:
Went for Mother's Day brunch a couple weeks ago. 
Food was good - my mom had the brioche french toast, my dad had the stuffed peppers, I had huevos rancheros. All good.  
And service was fine until after the food came, and we saw neither hide nor hair of our server. Couldn't order another round of drinks if we wanted to. We waited and waited, then it got ridiculous, and I literally waited with my arms crossed for about 15 minutes, and ended up asking a hostess where our server went. 
Good food, so-so service.
author: Lily K.

description: No chicken and rib combo plates!!!!  Period.  Chef's rules!  Yeah, not even for my 50th B-day dinner......unless I wanted to order TWO entrees.  Really?  You can't just put a rib or two on the plate with a piece of chicken and come up with the same amount?!  Or, better yet, offer it on the menu.  Ever hear of "chicken n ribs?" It's a classic southern combo.  You'd think a "southern" themed menu containing the two main meats individually would offer it as a combo or maybe a rib a la carte to add to my chicken plate. It's my 50th B-day and the chef can't make one little concession for that????  WTF?! Great way to make my special day "special."  Thanks, pal!   Great service at the door, at the table and with the wine.  Chicken was OK.....not "great." As a disappointed local, I am not going back and telling others to avoid.......
author: John B.

description:
The noise was very annoying, so I don't recommend for team lunch or dinner with your client. You have to scream even with a small group. They should do something.
The food and desert was good.
author: Max M.

description:
I was really excited to try this place out considering all the good recommendations and reviews. We had a party of 6 for lunch and they sat us relatively quickly. The server came and took our drink and lunch orders rather fast as well. And, then, the waiting began. The place didn't seem to be at capacity as it was lunch, and there weren't any particularly large groups. So I was surprised that it took so long. 

Right before the first meals arrived, the server took my diet coke for what I thought would be a refill. He forgot and it never came back. Not a big deal though. 

Then the first meals came out. 4 of the 6 meals came out and of course, we decided to wait for the other 2. The 5th meal came out a few minutes later. And then, we waited and waited and waited for the last meal. Meanwhile, the other meals are getting cold. Finally, the last meal came out and the staff apologized for the delay. They asked if we needed any more drinks. Someone order a fresh Coke and another some more iced tea.  They never came!

Overall, the food was good, but I have to bring down the rating because the service wasn't up to par. I will admit they did take off some of the meals so that helped salvage the lunch.
author: Ricardo M.

description: I took my dad here on Sunday night for an early Father's Day dinner. We had one of the best meals we have had in a long time. We tried the Fried Chicken and the Ribs... The chicken was so flavorful and moist! The waitress said the menu changes pretty often but I would describe it as kicked up comfort food, which you can never go wrong with! It is also pretty reasonable priced for the city.
author: Jenn M.

description:
Town Hall is our favorite San Francisco dinner spot. We have been visiting for years, and never been disappointed. 
* Cocktails: Seasonal offerings that are tasty and creative, without being hokey.
* Food: Great selection of dishes that are super tasty and well presented
* Service: Our servers have always been extremely polite, attentive, and knowledgable. Town Hall seems to go out of their way to find staff that genuinely like talking about food.
* Heated outdoor seating is a nice option when the weather is right
* Atmosphere: Hip, but not trendy. Extremely tasteful and comfortable. Great art by locals like Hugh Shurley.
TIP: Try the Faith's Warm Ham. I often get it as my main dish so I have room to try a couple appetizers.
TIP: They have a room upstairs for private events.
author: Dennis V.

description:
We met a couple of friends at Town Hall for Dine About Town lunch.  Three of us got the gumbo for appetizer. For entrée, we got the cat fish jambalaya, chicken pot pie and one entrée off the DAT menu - the oyster po' boy. Surprisingly, flavors were on the bland side except for the oyster po' boy, which was average. Y'know how some restaurants offer salt at the table?  Town Hall needed that. Portions were decent; the chicken pot pie was probably enough for two!

Service was a little awkward. When the hubby and I first arrived, the hostess said she couldn't seat us until everyone in the party has arrived. Then a slew of other people walked in, and she sat some without the entire party being present over the next 10 minutes. We were the only ones left waiting at in the front.  I was just about to ask her when she offered to finally seat us, though we were still missing 2 in our party of 5. I don't understand why she made us stand that whole time and seated others?

Food was slow to the table.  It took almost 2 hours for this whole lunch. Since the hubby had to get back to the office, he took a photo for us girls before he left. After the photo, my friend Jackie was about to continue to work on her jambalaya. A bus boy came up and asked her if she was done; she told him no.  Not two minutes later, the same bus boy returned again and asked to take away her dish.  WTF?  

Parking is a bitch in this area too during weekdays lunch. Meters right in front of/close to the restaurants are not too difficult to find, but they have a 1-hour limit and costs $3.50/hour (that's a lot of quarters!).  Doesn't work too well for a 2-hour lunch for sure.  A close by lot on Natoma (between Fremont and 1st - less than a block away) charges $2 for the 1st hour and $8 for up to 4 hours.
author: Christine C.

description:
3.5 stars This place has been on my "To-Try" list for quite some time. A last minute Dine About Town lunch enabled me to cross it off my list. However, the food was just okay.

Yes, service was great, it had a great atmosphere (very loud though), and a menu that changes daily, but the food was mostly just okay.

- Gumbo: delicious & very flavorful! they put the rice in last so it doesn't get soggy, it has a slight spiciness to it and the smoky sausage is tasty!
- Blackened Catfish over Jambalaya: the fish was nice & crispy, the jambalaya was a bit sweet and too creamy, if it had the same consistency/taste as the gumbo, it would have been good
- Grilled Gulf Shrimp: shrimps were good sprinkled with a little chili powder, the grits were too watery and buttery
author: Linda C.

description:
Move over Wayfarer Tavern... Townhall I do believe (in my book anyway) has the best Fried Chicken in SF... sorry, but it was incredible and SO, SO moist - I could have had 2 servings! And tuna tartare was great... very fresh and amazing that a chef actually thought to leave the tuna tasting as... well tuna and didn't try to mask the taste with oils and marinades. 

Love the building in and out, the interior decor (check out and TAKE pictures with ALL the red and black artwork in the hallways on the way to the restrooms) and vibe is very cool SF, and the interior table configuration is great. 

Bellied up at the bar with my tall drink of water and were served by John and Tabitha (who were so great). You ALWAYS get the best service from bar staff hands down. They have a great wine list (they were spot on with their Sauvignon Blanc and Cabernet Sauvignon by the glass offerings). I'm a huge fan now and will be back this week-end hopefully!
author: Tsuni S.

description: Ok, everything was a bit rich and "American" tasting.  The Faith's warm toast sandwich on this year's Big Eat was a bit repulsive - basically a combination of salty ham, jalapeno-laced hollandaise sauce (possibly with some Kraft singles melted in) and some fried bread.  This place lacked the sophistication I expected and the price point was a bit steep compared to what you could get elsewhere in the neighborhood for the same price.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
Went there on a busy Saturday night with the girlfriend. We started with some oysters, which were better than the average oysters we've been getting since moving to SF. We opted for the oens from Washington state, which is the GF's state of origin.

Then, we had the stuffed Pequillo peppers, which were also very tasty. The crabmeat was very tender and fresh and the peppers and sauce accented the flavor very nicely.

For the main course, I ordered the Fried Chicken that the waitress and hostess both recommended. The chicken was perfectly cooked and the skin was flaky and crispy and fantastic. The potatoes and bacon gravy were great but they skimped a little on the gravy. No problem though, because our thoughtful waitress asked me if I wanted more and brought me a little side dish of it! Tip secured.

The GF got a Special menu item that I don't remember exactly, but I know it was Monkfish and that it tasted great. Super fresh, flavorful and accompanied by a wonderful sauce.

For dessert, we split the Butterscotch Pot de Creme and loved it. Would recommend it to anyone who likes butterscotch pudding like we do.

Their tequila cocktail (The 212 I think it was called) was also very good. It probably accompanies fish a little better than fried chicken, but tasty none the less.

The only reason there is a star missing here is because everything is VERY EXPENSIVE. We had a great time here and may come back again someday, but the pricing will really hinder us. We can get high quality food at a lot of places in SF, without paying $200 (after tip). So while we had a great time, we could have just as much enjoyment at another place for half the cost.
author: Corry F.

description:
So my friend Vickie asked me to come here since she loves it here.  Usually she comes here once a month so I figure that it must be decent.  So sit down...look at the menu and it's a one page seasonal menu which is nice.  I'm always a fan of the simplified menu...and I noticed that they had a scallops dish with risotto and they had Cowgirl Creamery fondue appetizer.  The scallops were baby scallops but tasty and he risotto was a bit on the crunchy side than I preferred. Maybe a little too crunchy...as for the fondue, it didn't really wow me.  I heard that this brand does excellent cheese but perhaps the kind they used for the fondue really didn't come over well.  The taste seemed off for an aged white cheese.

And of course the noise level...we ate at 9pm but still the noise in the place was still at ear deafening levels akin to rock concerts and sporting events.  Our service was good as they brought out our main courses after we finished our starters.  

All in all, a decent place to go for a group meal if you don't mind the noise.  They have the 4% surcharge here added to your meal FYI so don't be surprised to see it.
author: Ben H L.

description:
When I play WoW and my level 30 Draenai Shaman is low on mana, she either gets Ice Cold Milk or Fresh Spring Water--and that's if she's not in combat anymore, which sucks because if the boyfriend's level 30 Draenai Hunter forgets to put his pet back on Defensive and pulls 6 high-level mobs at once, we're fucked. 

If she's low on health and she's out of combat, she can either a) eat some tough hunk of bread, red-speckled mushrooms, or use mana to heal herself. I'm pretty sure that if I was her, I'd rather use the mana to help me feel better because the food options suck.

I'm pretty sure that if my Shaman had a choice, she'd rather come here to Town Hall to eat their delicious food rather than some fungus that will probably make her sick. Hey Blizzard, can you include "Sticky Pumpkin Toffee Cake with Toffee Sauce and English Toffee" on my list of things to heal her with? How about 623 health over a period of 19 seconds. Okay, I'll compromise--she has to remain seated while she's eating it. 

Maybe include the lemon curd filled crepes too? And instead of Fresh Spring Water can you have her drink Baileys on the rocks? Because running without a mount or a flight path from Ironforge to Menithil Harbor can kiss my ass, and she needs something to hold her over.

No? You can't? Well fine. I'LL go to Town Hall instead (and drink my bailey's while putting her on "Follow")

Anyone who hasn't been here is seriously missing out. And so is my Paladin but she's only a level 10 right now and doesn't deserve it. That bitch has had me rez more times than I care to count. You're not even on a PVP server! Stop DYING!
author: Jaime L.

description:
Wow, what an experience we were offered at Town Hall. 

Seating and Reservation: PROBLEM 
First of all, we made a reservation for 10 people. In this economy you think they'd be thrilled with 10 people, but no, we were told we could have a table at 5:30PM or at 9:30PM. We finally were able to negotiate a 10 top at 7pm, after many, many discussions. Since they had made such a stink about our group size I figured this place was tiny. Not so, huge rooms, huge bar and upstairs seating as well. I have no idea why seating 10 was such a problem. 

Corkage: PROBLEM 
You can only bring in 2 bottles of wine, for the entire group. There was 10 of us, 2 was not going to cut it. Also, there is a $20 corkage fee, you'd think since they put a limit on how many you can bring in it would be free. Also, our server told us that if we ordered a bottle the fee would be waived. We did, the fee was still there when we got the check. 

Service: PROBLEM 
It literally took 30 minutes for us to get our bottle of wine, most of our drinks took the same amount of time. The server spent the entire evening telling us how much her coworkers sucked. It was awkward to say the least. The rest of the staff was rude and also bad mouthing everyone else. The owner approached our table to tell us how horrible she thought one of the servers was, I would think you would do something about that instead of just complaining to the customer. Not to mention, one of our party was practically pushed to the floor by a server while walking back from the bathroom, she was appalled and offended. 

Menu: PROBLEM 
We were given menus when we were seated, 10 minutes later those menus were taken away and we were told that we'd be ordering from a smaller menu due to our party size. We were never told this when we booked the reservation and the issue was handled rudely and unprofessionally. 

Food: SMALL PROBLEM 
Really, really overpriced. The food is decent, not the best I have ever had, but pretty good. But, the prices are unreal. $28 for 5 ribs and a small cup of cole slaw. Really, seriously? 

Overall: WE WONT BE BACK. 
I would suggest spending your money else where. There are 1000 restaurants in the Bay Area that can offer the whole experience without having to break the bank.
author: Blake W.

description:
Reservations are a must as they may or may not have room to take walk-ins. Also make sure to make your reservations ahead of time if you want to dine here on the weekends.

The ambiance is mixed with soft lighting in a large room that is loud and vibrant. The food is excellent... but the thing I remember most about dining here is the dessert. I love... did I say love... I long for their pot of chocolate. If I could have them ship this to me I would have it each and every single day, but sadly they don't ship so I come here everytime I visit and save room for dessert.
author: Debbie P.

description: Absolutely amazing. My duck was perfect  and I love the ambiance. The tuna tartar was good. Awesome spot to take a date and I was just so lucky!
author: Colleen F.

description: Town Hall has some tasty burgers.  I don't know why but this place is so much better than their sister restaurant Salt House.  The place is packed at lunch time and given the size of the crowd today I guess you can say we are all part of the 1%.  Clearly no down turn in business here.  Fish and chips are good as well.  Try it....
author: Robert H.

description: Gotta say that I was pleasantly surprised. A friend recommended this restaurant and when I sat down and looked at the menu, at first glance I couldn't find anything that sounded good.  After I studied it further our table ordered the rib eye and salmon. The rib eye was delicious!!!!  We ordered sides: shishisto   peppers and the cornbread. The cornbread was to die for and I highly recommend it. In fact, I was tempted to order a second and then thought better of it. All in all, I enjoyed my dinner.
author: Bonnie R.

description:
Pretty good, but not great. 

Overall it seemed they were trying a bit too hard.  More passion and less calculation would have helped this place be better.   It's meant to be a chic country setting which comes off as more Napa than New Orleans and then they pipe in loud blues music which caused a couple of couples to ask to be relocated.  In hind site, we should have asked to eat outside on such a nice day to make more romantic environment away from the crowd inside.

The waiter was excellent as was the Ham/Toast/Egg appetizer.  Even though it was rich, I knew then that it probably wasn't going to great.  There is something lacking that makes the best kind of American cuisine that has such a robust complexity you just can't stop tasting it.  

The seafood ettouffe was pretty good, but probably over stylized.  And the best aspects were surprisingly my date's swiss char and mashed potatoes that came along with her fried chicken. 

With so much to try in this city, we probably won't come back, but we don't regret giving it a go.
author: Zack S.

description: Oh sooooo Goood! Southern Fried Chicken, fried Green Tomatoes, Fried Okra & appetizers to die for......  This place makes the Southern Boy in me feel right at home. Love it!
author: Kevin R.

description:
Lovely food, service and setting. The decor is very enjoyable, and the waiters are really attentive. Sometimes the owner  even comes around asking how your meal was. He might tell you something interesting about that night's dishes.

I had a seafood risotto (not the actual name) type of dish the most recent time I went there, and it was tasty! My boyfriend had ribs and they were DELICIOUS. Their menu offers interesting selections, with spins on classic dishes. Very nice!

A great place to wine and dine, to see and be seen, but I wouldn't cry about it if I couldn't eat there.
author: Juichia C.

description:
I thought the food was pretty decent, but it did take quite a long time to arrive. 

The manager was also extremely nice and polite and made us feel welcome. However I believe one of the hostesses as well as the waiter we had were less polite and cordial.
author: Mike S.

description:
Super well done...

Wednesday night dinner with a friend.

Here's the flow as I saw it.

Super nice hostess, waited one cocktail for a table on a wednesday night.
Got an awesome table in a nook in the middle of the restaurant.
Phenomenal service by both waitress and busser.
Note: Jonathan the busser/backwaiter was super-pro and added big time to my experience.
Then the food:
Shrimp creole situation, amazing
ham & cheese, with poached egg...f'ing amazing
butter lettuce/blue cheese salad...real good
steak/short rib duo...so perfectly cooked, good sauces, the braise was spoon tender, and the house made tater tots...well the house made tater tots should be available by the dozen, cause I could mack a s-ton of the them.
Dessert: coffee and donuts, nearly made me cry...so good.

Oh yeah, and the chef sent us out a scallop which was AWESOME...

All in all...fantastic dining experience...

BTW: I'm from New Orleans, born and raised, and they absolutely nailed the flavors.

If you don't eat there  its cause you're stupid and you'll end up eating some garbage somewhere else...
author: Matt G.

description: It is known for the fried chicken but I found it to be too oily. I really appreciate the personalized service - even though it wasn't on the menu, I had a craving for ice cream and casually mentioned it to the waiter. He surprised me with a scoop!
author: Lana C.

description: I'm going to go against the grain here and say that I wasn't really that impressed with Town Hall. I struggled to find inspiring options on the menu that were not merely a modern twist on fried carbohydrates. Went with seared tuna and a butter lettuce salad but neither were anything to write home about. Mixt Greens makes better salads.
author: Erin W.

description: Loved the tuna and faro salad. Very fresh and delicious.
author: Kimberly C.

description:
DAT Lunch with friends. I'm just glad it wasn't my choice of restaurant or I would have been embarrassed.

Took an hour for our food to arrive. I felt like a diner on Gordon Ramsey's Kitchen Nightmares. Luckily I didn't have any early afternoon meetings!

The food, when it did arrive, was less than stellar. 

A "med-rare" burger (not mine, luckily) was well done and dry and the patty covered only half the bun. It looked like one of my home BBQ rejects. Who has time to send food back when you're already going to be pushing a 2 hour lunch? As an added slap in the face it was $17 w/ bacon & cheese.

My pulled pork sandwich tasted OK, but the layer of pork was so thin, i couldn't see any pulled pork between the bread crusts when it arrived on my plate. I was like "Ooohh! 2 thick slices of toasted white bread and cole slaw! Yummie!!" And the pork was chopped, not pulled, but now I'm picking nits.

The best dish on our table was the BBQ gulf shrimp w/ Worchestershire sauce sauce. The sauce wasn't that flavorful, but the seasonings on the shrimp were very good.

The chocolate butterscotch pot de creme was delicious. I should have gotten a few of those for lunch and called it a meal.

On the plus side, I wasn't refused service this time (see my previous review) and the server was friendly and apologetic about the backup in the kitchen so I guess I'll bump them up to 2 stars. 

Come here when you've got money to burn and your taste buds are failing. Yes, a rousing endorsement, to be sure!
author: Andrew C.

description:
TLDR:
- A really good plate of fish - halibut steak on top of creamy polenta and corn succotash. So simple, yet so many other places screw it up.
author: Christopher L.

description:
Finally had the chance to come back for the 2nd time and had to try the fried chicken!   

the first time we dine here and we were sitting close to the kitchen. i was shock how many fried chicken were coming out.  so finally had the chance to try fried chicken and it was pretty damn good.

all the food we've tried were good and will definitely come back again.

must tries:
piquillo peppers
tuna tartare
veal meatballs

fried chicken & greens
jambalaya

butterscotch dessert
author: Ronnie G.

description: The heat lamps don't really work here. Froze my bum off at lunch the other day. But after you get some soup in ya... or alcohol.. you're fine! This is right downstairs from my office so I was there twice last week for lunch. hehe. Had the seafood chowder, which was just so so. I was freezing so I ordered it again the 2nd time. Also had the tuna tartar with fried green tomatoes. I love anything fried so even tomatoes tastes good. We also had the fried okra (good), flounder (soooooooo good!!) and the pulled pork shoulder (meh.. dry)... Never had dessert here yet... Sure I'll be back here soon since it's so close by.
author: Cynthia C.

description: The food is good but I had a horrible service experience last night. We went for apps and drinks so we were sat at a table. When the waiter took our order and realized we weren't ordering dinner (mind you it wasn't busy so not like we were taking up a table that could have been ordering dinner) he could not have been less interested. He was the most unfriendly server and it was clear he wanted us out of there ASAP. We had to ask someone clearing our plates for a 2nd round of drinks and then he brought us our check before we could even ask for a 3rd round ... Which would have ordered. There were three us so the bill came to $165 ... Still a decent tip so no clue what was his issue!  I would say he was having a bad day but he was all smiles to the table of 6 next to us who ordered bottles of wine and dinner. Maybe he forgot he was in the service industry when it came to our table...
author: Ashley D.

description:
3.5 stars is about right. had the stuffed piquillo peppers, ham and cheese toast (with an amazing jalapeno sauce on it), and the texas ribs. The first two were delicious, but the ribs were just ok. Far from fall off the bone tender and the flavor was alright-- nothing to rave over that's for sure, but the jalapeno cornbread was amazing... it was crispy, had just the right amount of sweetness that i like and with a little kick of the jalapeno in it. 

NOW, on to the thing that topped off my night. their butterscotch chocolate pot de creme. it was delicious. the chocolate wasn't too sweet and the butterscotch added a slight sweetness to it. soooo smooth and rich. totally going to attempt making this one for myself! :)
author: Kimberly F.

description:
Came here last night with hubby for dinner and a play. Cynthia was our server. The service, food and atmosphere were perfect! It was $$$$ but for a date night it was a treat:)

Food: 
ham sandwich app:  creamy heaven
ahí tartar: cold with a hint of onion

salmon: med-rare and mouthwatering
fried chicken: best hubby has ever had!
fried okra: yummy in our tummy (needed a bit of salt)

music, fun and great service! Cynthia was professional and had great recommendations. 

if you have not been GO!
author: Dyan Y.

description:
Date & Time:  Thursday July 3, 2008 @ 2:30pm
Company:  Michael
Crowd:  FiDi Professionals
Atmosphere:  Comfy
Decor:  Rustic yet Contemporary.  Huge Mirror. Communal Table & Bar as you Enter.  Wooden Tables in The Dining Room.  8 Inox Aluminum Tables & Chairs plus Heat Lamps for Dining Alfresco.
Service:  Attractive, Professional, Personable
Imbibe:  Wine
Devour:  We Missed the Lunch Menu Again(stops promptly @ 2pm)- From the Bar we've had the Croque Monsieur which gets High Marks & Today we had Burgers w/ White Cheddar, Heirloom Tomatoes & Butter Lettus(accompanied by a Pickle & Yummy Chips)-The Best!
author: Genevieve Y.

description: We recently celebrated our anniversary at Town Hall.  The restaurant has casual rustic modern atmosphere.  For our appetizers, we had three mini buttermilk biscuits, la Quercia speck (prosciutto) and red pepper jelly. We enjoyed the combination of the salty prosciutto and sweet pepper jelly on the warm biscuits.  I also had the roasted butternut squash soup and parsnip purée which was creamy and delicious - it's my favorite fall soup.  My hubby had their famous Mary's buttermilk fried chicken with mashed potatoes, bacon gravy and broccoli rate.  The chicken was crispy and juicy, and the mash potatoes and bacon gravy was delicious.  He really enjoyed his meal.  I had the bacon-wrapped Mt. Lassen trout, caramelized cauliflower, honey crisp apples, mustard-walnut vinaigrette.  I was surprised it was a whole trout, and I couldn't finish it all, so hubby helped me.  The fish was moist and full of flavor. We shared our entrees with our daughter, and she had an extra side of the mash potatoes and bacon gravy.  For dessert, we had the butterscotch and chocolate pot de crème topped with buttercrunch. It was creamy, rich and so smooth. It was yummy and was the perfect amount for sharing.  We really enjoyed the Southern comfort food, dining experience and friendly service.
author: Racquel E.

description:
"Hey that fella looks a lot like Conan O'Brien!" remarked Peg S. last night.   

Promptly 9 heads swiveled in unison and unabashedly gawked at said fella.  After a brief consultation (aka stage whispering like starstruck teenyboppers), we ascertained that yes indeedy, the distinctly pompadoured man was the one and only Conan O'Brien.  This was reaffirmed when I passed by his table and overheard his oh so seductive nasally voice.  I repressed the inexplicable urge to brush up against his oddly attired bod (red hoodie - wha?  Doesn't the man have a stylist?) but just barely.

It was a little present to Natasha S. from god as we celebrated her birthday at Town Hall.  And speaking of god, thank god Conan O'Brien left because otherwise I would have had to make a Sophie's Choice between two equally enticing options - ogling Conan O'Brien or ogling fried chicken.

For around $20, I got 4 pieces of pipin' hot chicken fried goodness along with some tasty brussel sprouts.  The biscuits and gravy were disappointing due to the fact that they were cold and they put an unwelcome dent into my food buzz.  My friends ordered the snapper, pork chop, and lobster and rabbit pot pie.  All received favorable reviews.

But the unequivocal piece de resistance was the butterscotch pot de creme.  It was silky smooth chocolate and butterscotch layered deliciousness.  The pieces of brittle in the dish were quickly inhaled as well.  The candle that was placed in the center for Natasha to blow out was a nice touch.

All the other desserts by way of comparison were a let down ($8 each).  The pumpkin cheesecake was ok and the hot chocolate was too rich.  It had almost a fondue-like consistency so we were looking for things to dunk into it.  The devil's food cake was unfortunately like some men I've known.  Tasty looking on the outside, dry on the inside. 

Service was solid and the wreaths and lights decorating the place got me in the holiday mood.  Especially since Christmas came early for me this year in the form of Conan O'Brien, fried chicken and butterscotch pot de creme!

----------------

Update 10/2013:  Happy 10th Town Hall!

http://insidescoopsf.sfgate.com/blog/2013/10/18/town-hall-celebrates-its-10-year-anniversary/
author: Amy C.

description:
When I was first heard about this place, I really thought it was a "Town hall".. turned out to be a very nice and elegant restaurant. It's quite a romantic place since it's very dim. 

I tried their jalapeno corn bread and it was the most delectable corn bread I have ever tasted... I ordered the mushroom gnocchi ( I added it in the pics).. It was the first time I have ever tried gnocchi (potato pasta) it practically melted in my mouth. 

Boyfriend had the famous fried chicken (also in the pics).. Now I've only tried KFC's and Knotts berry farm's fried chicken, and when I had a taste of Town hall's fried chicken, it blew me away! Thank god it wasn't pouring oil when you bite into it. Crunchy and satisfying. 

I also had a glass of Reiseling, first time, and it was so sweet :) I'm not from SF, and there are still many many places yet to be tasted... to say the least, if I happen to be around Town hall next time and I'm hungry, I'll be back for more!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Just had a lovely dinner at Town Hall on a Saturday Night.
Got the buttermilk fried chicken (I thought it was better than Wayfare Tavern - Sorry Tyler!). Those that thought it wasn't seasoned enough I feel missed the balance of the whole dish.  The crispiest, juicy fried chicken (3 pieces) with the creamy mashed potatoes and bacon gravy with the tangy, spicy collard greens. 
In addition, we ordered corn bread, jambalaya, hush puppies (kinda dry), & friend okra (a must order!!).  Cousin ordered the pork belly, which was basically like buttah!
Ended the evening with butterscotch pudding & salted caramel brownie.  Both delicious and very large portions.

Saw the critics regarding service, but we didn't feel neglected at all. Our waiter was very low key, the meal was nicely paced, all our requests were met promptly, and after a 3-hour dinner, not once did we feel rushed.  Even the hostess remembered to wish my cousin a happy birthday upon our departure.  All in all, a great night at Town Hall! A solid 4 stars.
author: S. C.

description:
On my first visit to Town Hall, I found the food good but not particularly inspired. All that changed over lunch.

The seafood chowder with sourdough cracckers knocked my socks off, only to be outdone by the chicken salad. This folks, was the chicken salad of all chicken salads- crisp green beans, lovely lettuce with lovelier dressing, bacon, baked tomatoes, all atop a perfectly seasoned chicken breast. So freakin' good, it was!

Town Hall, I finally realize what all the hype was about and I will be back soon!
author: Miriam W.

description: I had a great dinner here a few nights ago for my mom's birthday.  The service was excellent and the food was awesome.  Loved the waiter and the sommelier; you felt like you were the only people in the restaurant.  I would definitely go back and definitely consider their upstairs room for a private dinner.
author: Kirsten M.

description: I've been here three times. The first time was for dinner and the food, service, and atmosphere were all top notch. The second time was for a company lunch - we reserved the upstairs space and spent a couple of hours eating, drinking, and talking. The service was good but the food was only okay.  The third time was for dinner with a group of five. While I enjoyed my food, my companions didn't seem like theirs. What we all did agree on though, was how horrendous the service was. Our server was a bit odd all night - a little too casual and jokey (but not in a good way). The worst part though came at the end of the meal - we accidentally calculated the tip wrong and he came by, looked at it and said "you realize you're only tipping me ____?"  We were confused and asked for a moment to recalculate and he said "Sorry but i have to split the tip with the busser and if you only give me __.... "  It was a very uncomfortable conversation and I think it could have been handled much better on our server's part.
author: Peggy N.

description:
I don't know If I would call this real southern comfort food but I will say it is some good food!!!  Be sure and make reservations they fill up fast for dinner.  I ordered the Beeler Farm Pork chop with the grits, it was soooo YUMMY.  Finished my food in a matter of 15 minutes, I barely spoke.  I would definitely go back and try the other menu selections.  

I dont remember what I had for dessert which tells me it didnt leave the greatest impression.
author: Monique M.

description:
Ambiance: The decor is gorgeous and definitely feels like an escape from San Francisco.  If you arrive early enough (6-ish), you can snag a farm-style table with a group of friends.  Otherwise, there are other smaller tables around, but be prepared for a huge crowd.  Waiters are pleasant, at best, and deliver food in reasonable time.

Drinks: Most everything is A+, especially the Corpse Revival.

Food: Definitely nothing to brag about.  The dishes friends and I have ordered always seem to come out too small, covered in too much sauce, or so "creative" that they no longer look appetizing.

Dessert: YUM!  I've had a bite of everything on the list and it is all SO GOOD.  I'd definitely recommend the grapefruit cheesecake or the coffee and donuts.
author: Ashley O.

description: Came for Mardis Gras. Great selection of food for the price. Fresh oysters, shrimp, mussels, etc. Also Kalua style pig, ribs, fried chicken, etc etc. The shrimp and grits were the best!
author: Jon B.

description:
Was there Saturday Night September 29th 2012 with a friend. We had a lot of appetizer includes: Half shell Oysters (3 different types) friend oystrs and more. For dinner I had BBQ Ribs and my friend had veggie.  The services was outstanding. The waiter explained the types of oysters we did not know.  They will take good care of you, very friendly stff member and very clean restaurant.  

Reservation was taken carer of promptly we were on the road making reservation told them we be there at 6:15pm and as soon as we arrive, out seat was ready!!!!!!!!

The restroom was the only drawback. It was clean but, you have to walk down stair and walk into the private dining room and another left the restroom.   

Highly Recommend it
author: Mat Z.

description:
Town hall wasn't bad... just can't say with the prices they offer that it was good.  Most of the food I felt didn't inspire great taste and probably done better at other restaurants.  It did have potential as they combined inspired comfort/south food with a higher end flair..but the execution of the food is lacking.  Service however was great and met expectations of the higher prices.


I had the fried oysters and the fried chicken and also tried the tuna tartare and the pork chops from my dinner partner.

The fried oysters were good... but how can anything fried not be. Maybe the batter was a little softer and not as crispy as i had... a theme that will carry on later.  Oysters were fresh so you can't go wrong.

Tuna tatare was also good... as nicely executed fresh tuna tartare can be.  I've had better in other places with the supplementing ingredients but it was good.

Now the true test was the chicken.  I've had fried chicken at other pretty decent places and bogangles in charlotte (fried chicken chain in the south)... so had a pretty high standard for comparison...and i have to say it was only okay here.  Good but far from great.  For one thing, the batter was not as crispy.  For another, the meat was juicy and moist, but lacked seasoning...almost like they didn't marinate the chicken overnight or just not enough.  Overall good...but i've had way better... even bogangles in charlotte in uptown was better and not even close to the chicken at ad hoc.  Looks like i see need to reserve me a chicken knight to ad hocs to satisfy my chicken fix...or next time I'm in the south.

The pork chops were good that my friend ordered... big portion and moist..but again to me the seasoning just isn't there.

All in all not bad...just not great. Too many other places that serves better food in SF at this price point.
author: Vien C.

description: Went back at lunch for their burger.  It was as good as before, however I had to send back the 1st one since it was well done instead of medium rare.  It came back medium rare but they left out the cheddar cheese.  Still a great burger just not perfect.  I still highly recommend their burger.  Just make sure you check it by cutting in half to check if it is done correctly before biting into it.
author: Jim J.

description:
I've been here twice now, and had the same impression both times.  Great service, great food, but so noisy after 7pm that you have to shout at your table mates (and waiters) to be heard.  Recommend it highly if you're feeling upbeat, energetic and looking for good eats but don't need to have an intimate conversation!

For an appetizer, don't miss the tuna tartare.  This one is really well executed and full of flavor. The addition of fried green tomatoes and Tobasco vinaigrette is inspired.

Seafood stew was chock full of fresh seafood and had a really unusually flavored tomato broth, almost like a very thin mole (think dozens of different spices).  I would wager you could not find another like this at any other restaurant.

Fried chicken - if you are at all inclined, order it!  Really crispy on the outside, juicy on the inside, and very generous portion.  I had to share mine with my husband because it was just too much, and too good not to share.  He was not as thrilled with his halibut, as it seemed rather ordinary compared to the dishes others at our table ordered, so he was happy to help me out.

We are looking forward to returning and trying more of the goodies on the menu.
author: Virginia K.

description:
YAY!!! I finally made it to this place and was pleased!!!!
I did a business event here for 40 people last month.
I was pressed on space for 40 people.  I called all over the place for private dining and couldn't find anything until my friend suggested Town Hall.
I contacted the event coordinator and within no time I had a reservation.
We were seated in the upstairs private dining and it was wonderful!!!
My team loved it!!!
We had passed apps.  They had a crab cake that was to DIE for!!!
The spanish wine was a hit that night.  YUMMY!!!
For dinner I ordered the Salmon.  Though I care for my salmon to be cooked a little more, once I spoke to the server they quickly assured me it was no problem and took care of it.  It came back out PERFECT!!!

If that wasn't it, OMG, OMG, OMG...the pumpkin cheese was nothing less than decadent!!!!!!  I can taste it now.  

I must also commend the servers. They were the BEST BEST BEST servers I've ever had. They were so friendly and full of smiles. Just my kind of people. 

After the event was a huge hit, I hugged and kissed them all.

I had a great time there ;)
author: Sandra S.

description:
Great food.  Fiancee said that it was probably the best fried chicken that she's ever had in her life.  I tried some, and it was insanely juicy and tender.  My ribs were good, though not the best I've ever had.  The ham and cheese toast was amazing.  One of the best things I've eaten for a while, and I'd come back just for this.  The coffee and doughnuts were good for dessert as well.

Drinks were interesting and different, and worth a try.  I had a bourbon cocktail with jalapeno peppers in it.  Not sure I'd get it again but was definitely worth trying.
author: Ken L.

description: Greeters were not always available. However, the rest of the staff was pretty good on the night we were there. I had both the Duck Leg w/Farm Egg. A 2-star meal in my opinion. I also had the Ribs. 4.5-star meal. Generous portions, tender & tasty. Definitely recommended meal. The restaurant, as a whole, was very average, but crowded. Make a reservation.
author: Ord-Sf O.

description:
I have enjoyed the food, ambience and the wait service at Town Hall on each of my previous visits. But I will no longer be recommending them or giving them my business due to ineptness and rudeness of the reservations staff and management.

I was excited when my company moved to a new office south of market and realized that Town Hall was so close. At the first opportunity, I booked a lunch there for our CEO and 3 of our new hire executives. Today when we called to confirm the reservation - we were told it did not exist. The person looked it up via our phone number and said that the reservation was for last week and yes, people showed up to dine. (Not from our company, they didn't.) She said, well somebody used the reservation. Ok. Mistakes happen, can you still fit them in today, they are walking over now. Yes, but they will have to sit on the patio. OK. That's fine. Thank you.  2 minutes later, the phone rings and it is our CEO telling us they have no reservation for him. Really? We call back and ask to speak to the manager. After being grilled by the person who answered the phone about WHY we want to speak to the manager, we were connected. The manager listened to about 2 sentences and then tried to hang up. When we persisted on telling him the whole tale - his only comment was "Well, they seem happy now."  Wow. I am sure it was just another customer to him and he wasn't mean about it. Just unconcerned and unapologetic. So, now we are a former customer and recommender.
author: MaryAlice C.

description:
This place is awesome.  Enough said.  My boyfriend and I have been here twice and are already plotting the next time we can return.  He has had the fried chicken twice as he says its the best fried chicken he's ever had.  I'm a pescatarian so I've had the gnocchi (DELICIOUS.  More veggies than pasta which works perfectly for me) and the fried rock fish, which was also amazing.  Their sides are phenomenal.  Jalapeno cornbread.  BOOM.  I've ordered it both times I've been there.  Mind blowingly delicious.  Their desserts are out of this world.  We've had the pecan pie, frozen banana cake and the butterscotch pudding.  I want to swim laps (albeit they would be very slooooooow laps as that pudding is THICK and WONDERFUL) in the pudding.  I'd be a very happy lady in that pool of goodness.  
The service has been excellent.  Ronnie served us last time and he did a great job.  Funny and helpful; the perfect combo.  
We've only been on Sunday evenings and both times it hasn't been overly crowded.  My boyfriend works next door and he says that place is constantly swamped at all hours of the night every other day of the week, so I would DEFINITELY recommend a reservation.  
We can't wait to go back!
author: Lynne B.

description: This is one crowded, hopping restaurant.   I went for dinner and had the fried oysters and the soft shell crab with mango salsa and avocado.  Oysters were great but the salsa was too tart for me.  My bf had the rice crusted snapper with stuffed peppers and peas and tasty sauce.  He thought it was pretty good.  We enjoyed the jalapeno cornbread.  Overall it was good but given how popular it is and how my friends rave about it, I was disappointed.  Service was tremendous.
author: Vivian W.

description:
The manager is nice enough to write me and told me how seriously he is taking this. Thanks Curtis Y. for doing that! All I want is a positive response. 

I don't really want to give a 1 star review to a restaurant based on one impolite staff.
author: C Y.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE. I couldn't get a rez before 9pm on a sat night, but we showed up early and the host seated us. The only snag was that he forgot to mark us as seated on our open table rez and then Open table thought we were a no show..

Food was delicious and the vibe was really great too.
author: Natalia S.

description:
Loved it!

Decor was very cute.  Great ambiance. Friendly staff.

Food was delish: biscuits and ham, mac and cheese, the trout, stuffed peppers, and the ribs... damn right we ate well! Cooked to perfection. 

Wine list is fantastic and dessert; cheesecake and lemon souffle  was just as amazing.  Will glady return.
author: Patricia G.

description: We came and we all chose the tri tip steak. It was delicious. It came with fried okra, peas, baby carrots and some greens and a really decadent potato gratin. The service was friendly, the restaurant was big and airy and I could hear my dining companions.
author: Susan B.

description: I was there for a business lunch.  Quite decent place!
author: Shell J.

description:
Been here twice now.  Eh, it's aight. 

The food is good and service is nice.  The ambience feels very corporate and not particularly unique though.   It's pretty pricy. 

Nothing special though.  My advise - you can get more for your money elsewhere.  I'd skip Town Hall.
author: Monica T.

description:
Came here after lovin' Anchor & Hope and Salthouse. Made a reservation over the phone for 8 at 6pm on a Wednesday. Found a parking spot right in the front. the hostess was friendly. crowded noisy atmosphere. there were so many delicious choices on the menu, i really couldn't decide.. but my cousin was right - some things sounded delicious until the last ingredient.. i really wanted to order the ham and cheese toast, but the jalapeno creme didn't sound to appetizing. So I got the pulled pork sandwich with ribs and pickles. the sandwich was kind of bland. I should have gotten the toast.. or the cornmeal fried oysters with spinach, cheese and bacon which my cousin ordered and mmmmmmm. my mom got the sweet onion fondue and that was MMM. Like a creamy, cheesy, sweet french onion soup. 

for entree, i had the scallops. again, i should have ordered something else. fried chicken? braised ribs? the jambalaya was super tomato paste infested. fried mac and cheese - ok. 

i was so excited to try this place, but i ordered all the wrong things. good think we had a party of 8, and so i tasted the other yummy dishes here and there. 

thumbs up: some dishes
thumbs down: the dishes i ordered.... which means, i must come back.
author: Lauren Y.

description: We went to Town Hall last night to celebrate our 18th Anniversary.  What a terrific pick!!  The interior itself was very old-time rustic with antiques in spots and mission style tables and chairs.  Our bread arrived in a real antique wooden bread "basket".  I thought they were reproductions, but when I asked our waitress, she said they were the real thing. Looking around, I realized every table had a different one.  A really nice touch!  We started off with my boyfriend ordering Cabernet and me ordering one of their signature drinks "Witches Knickers".  It was tequila based and fantastic!  We ordered the butter lettuce salad with Point Reyes bleu cheese dressing and one was enough for both of us.  For our meals, my boyfriend had the salmon which was perfection and I had the rice crusted snapper which was one of the best fish meals I ever ate.  We ordered sides of tater tots with barbecue sauce and jalapeno corn bread, both of which were terrific!  For dessert, I couldn't pass up the butterscotch Pot de Creme and I'm glad I didn't!  The smooth butterscotch pudding atop chocolate pudding with 3 pieces of buttercrunch wedged on the top was one of the best desserts I ever had.  My boyfriend had the Salted Carmel Tart Moon PIe and that was also excellent.  I have to specially mention our waitress, Hillary, who was nothing short of a fantastic waitress who met our every need with a smile.  As a special suprise, Hillary came to our table with a plate that said "Congratulations" written in chocolate with 3 mini cupcakes and a candle for our anniversary.  An extremely nice touch!  We will be back!!  We will tell others not to miss Town Hall!
author: Sandra P.

description:
I finally made it to Town Hall for dinner last week, and it was long awaited! I thought the service was pretty good, no complaints there. It's a little loud in there for my taste as I was about to lose my voice by the end of our meal after shouting throughout our conversation. 

But food wise, I really enjoyed the oysters -- I think it's the Miyagi oysters that are my favorite because they're small but the meat runs deep in the shell and is oh-so tasty! I had the fish entree (can't remember what it was exactly actually right now - senility sets in) -- pretty good. And we had the caramel pot de creme - yum-o! Must try that one!

My bill+tax+tip = $65

Once-a-week dinner w/ Geraldine # 1
author: Maile N.

description:
Delicious. Lovely. Loud. Pricey.

The food was absolutely delicious - the crab-stuff pequillo pepers were exceptional, with a wonderful sauce that should definitely be sopped up with the bread they provide. The cornmeal fried oysters with a bit of bacon were a hit - cooked perfectly, and served back on the shell (with a spinach puree that adds color, but no real flavor).

Dining companion had the steak, which he reported was good, but it was small. I kept waiting for my large serving of fried chicken to walk off me plate and go eat his steak. The fried chicken was excellent, included a breast, thigh, and leg, and came with good mashed potato9es, and greens.

Get the butterscotch pot de creme for dessert. I was skeptical of it because the menu didn't mention the chocolate amazing hidden in the dish. Out of this world excellent dessert!

The cocktails are expensive, and good, but nothing special for $11.
author: Jacqueline W.

description:
i can't believe that this restaurant is one of the most booked on opentable. after reading rave reviews and hearing through word of mouth that this is a great restaurant, i decided to take my fiance here for his birthday dinner.

when we first entered the restaurant, i noticed a putrid smell...like urine? but i guess it was due to the pine wreaths the restaurant used to decorate the walls since it was the holiday season.

in general, the food was edible and nothing more. the flavors were terribly mismatched and all the dishes that you'd expect to be savory were covered in a tangy "sweet and sour" sauce. the spinach and other veggies were overly salted.

the butterscotch toffee cake wasn't bad but i was told that i must try the hot chocolate. on the menu, it is claimed as "the best hot chocolate in san francisco". i'm sorry to burst the bubble, but this is far from the truth. the hot chocolate came in an oversized mug accompanied by some shortbread cookies and a dollop of whipped cream. the hot chocolate was thick, and by that, i mean it was like drinking MUD. i always thought that hot chocolate was for DRINKING...not EATING. i was fairly disappointed in such a highly rated restaurant.

sorry but there will definitely not be a second visit.
author: Charmaine L.

description:
I came here for a department lunch with my company. We were actually trying to reserve a table at Salt House. However, they were not able to accommodate our large group. Town Hall was good. They sat us upstairs in a private room. It was just perfect. 

Prior to coming to Town Hall, I drooled over the menu on their website. I already mentally selected what I wanted for lunch. However, I arrived at Town Hall and found out that our private room came with a private specialty menu with a few items. I begrudgingly settled for the tuna tar tar, pork and clams, and mud pie. All the dishes were good. The pork  looked a little dry, but was surprisingly so moist and juicy I wanted to eat the bone. The only disappointment was what appeared to be a mud pie. No ice cream. No chocolate cake. Just 2 dry brownie looking cakes smooshed together in a marshmellowly white fluff drizzled in chocolate sauce.
author: Sue L.

description:
I will give 5 stars for the beautiful and elegant yet casual dining room and the DELICIOUS butternut squash soup.  

HOWEVER, and this is a big HOWEVER, the gulf shrimp, Anson Mills grits, and scallions and Creole-bacon demi was just TERRIBLE. The grits tasted gross and the shrimp did not look very appetizing. The presentation was so very amateurish with the shrimp just circling the plate. I don't expect to come back again. Sorry, I don't see it.
author: Rose J.

description: Went here for lunch with a friend, she had the Beet Salad and i had their signature  Faith's Warm Ham and Cheese Toast.  It was great, must have fit my palate well, I stopped short of licking the plate, very enjoyable, and recommended by our waiter.  He told us it's been on the menu since they opened, I can see why.  Service is great, very attentive, and we did not have to ask for anything.  I can't wait to go back to try another dish.
author: Darwin L.

description:
Came here once on a date. it is extremely nice and very fancy. That being said, I had their fried chicken, and it was amazing. 

It is a little pricey, but it is a really nice restaurant, so you get what you pay for. Plus, the service, and the cocktails, are excellent.
author: Sam A.

description:
I went for an all seafood meal. Well, I didn't have the oyster bread pudding, but that's not on the menu either.

My app was really good, my entree slightly less so. Nice but not sure it's worth the big bucks.

I do like the brick poetry garden that wraps around the building. It's a little urban oasis.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
My friend took me to this restaurant for my birthday and it was YUM YUM!  I always wanted to go here but never did and I don't live that far from it.  The food was great and the service very friendly.  It was like home comfort food with alittle twist.

For starters, we had the butter lettuce salad and the ham & cheese toast - the toast was a suprise to us as we heard great reviews from yelp...good advise.  The waitress agreed that the toast is yummy.

For dinner, she had the fried chicken and I had the cod.  The fried chicken was awesome and the cod was great.  The fish was flakey and very light.

For dessert, we ordered the butterscotch pot de creme AND the Sticky Toffee Cake.  We didn't realize they were big desserts when it arrived or maybe cuz we ate alot already...hhhhmm.  We should have shared one of them, but it would been hard to choose which one.  It was worth it!!  Both were great desserts and finished the night off right.

The place did not disappoint!!  Great food and great service.  Only problem was that it was noisy, but I was there to eat not talk..JUS KIDDIN!
author: James L.

description: Great, solid, quality food I highly recommend the oysters and fried chicken. I came here one time and the host informed us they were closing but gave us several recommendations for nearby restaurants, he was very nice about it and even remembered us when we came back giving us a complimentary dessert for missing them last time. Great service and friendly staff  will definitely be coming here again!
author: Amanda C.

description: The food was outstanding, service was great and the Duck was superb. Environment is a little crowded.
author: Manuel A.

description: Came here for lunch with co-workers, and while the atmosphere and service were great, the options for vegetarians were pretty poor -- even a number of the salads had meat in them. I ended up getting the "little gem" salad, which was okay, and a side of jalapeño cornbread, which was tasty. I actually bumped my review up from two stars because of the cornbread. Bottom line -- unless everyone in your party eats meat (and when does that happen?), there are better options in this area.
author: Gaelen X.

description:
I went here with two others a couple weeks ago. The food was very good. The service was good, friendly. My only complaint is that the food took a long time to be brought out.

We ordered:
Tuna Tartar
Veal meatballs (delicious)
Bacon-wrapped Trout 
Pork chops (delicious, tender, juicy through and through)
St Louis Ribs (very well prepared- they use a tobasco flavored BBQ sauce)
author: Alvin L.

description:
Schmancy lunch for sure. 

Luckily it was a nice day out and with the wooden tables and lots of windows the sun was streaming in. 

Came here with my work team and we got a bottle of white wine, good conversations, and got the check in a book which was unique. 

Everyone seemed satisfied with their food. 

I got the Soft Shell Crab Po Boy which came in hard French bread so I decided to just eat the insides which was good.  It came with chips but wish I had subbed in a salad instead. 

We also had tuna tar tar for an appetizer which was yummy. 

The soup of the day was the gazpacho which looked good.  The salads that were under starters were pretty good sizes too. 

American fancy food for lunch.  Perfect if thats what you are going for.
author: Anya R.

description: When I left Philly & NYC, I was told by my 'foodie friends' that San Fran has just as amazing food. After a few disappointing dining experiences at other $$$ restaurants, our server, Troy showed us an all around wonder night. The wine list was fun. We played it safe with our first bottle- a Côtes-du-Rhône Blanc which I enjoyed with a spicy tuna tartar. Then Troy suggested Jurancon Sec Cuvee Marie 2008 which was great with my pescatarian dishes! The Pot de Creme was, well, I'm still dreaming about it and the cheese plate was the perfect salty way to end the night. Thank you, Townhall.
author: Jillian A.

description:
This place is good it makes me laugh sort of though.   If it wasn't such good food.   For example you pay a lot for fried chicken and a pork chop.   And then the appetizers we're good too.   The oysters and the cheese, poached egg, in jalapeno cream. (eggs benedict like) :) 

The butterschotch dessert is what I loved the most.
author: Homer S.

description:
One of my favorite meals ever. 
Goat cheese and asparagus appetizer, fried chicken, jalapeno cornbread, ribs, cheese plate and "coffee and donuts" dessert all blew us away! 
The ambiance was perfect for a nice little weekday date (it was busy for a Monday), the hostess was incredibly nice and our server, though not overly enthusiastic, was discreet and speedy.
Fantastic, can't wait to go back!
author: Kenzie P.

description:
Expensive American food doesn't impress me as much anymore.  With such a vibrant food culture, if you don't have a unique appeal or  "wow" factor then you're just another place that appeals to minute portion of the population who can afford to eat here and no longer the people.  In the end, it does serve its purpose but it really is all about the people.

I do commend the service though.  I needed a private dining room for a party for a Thursday night and I had called on just that Tuesday before.  The coordinator was extremely efficient and quick in getting my menu set, contract approved, and even the tiny details.  Service on the day of the dinner was excellent was well.  They noticed that one extra person had showed up and swiftly set up another setting. 

You should know that the private dining room upstairs requires a $2000 food and beverage minimum before tax and tip.  I wasn't sure if a group of 17 would be able to meet this but it did.  We chose a 4 course meal, 4 wines (multiple bottles of it), mixed drinks (from the full, standard bar), coffee, and tea.

Now the reason for the 3 is because of the food.  I started out with a normal salad with peaches and a champagne vinaigrette which I thought was still too tart.  You have to each a bit of peach with every bite to balance it out.  Second dish was the tuna tartare which wasn't seasoned that intensely and you eat it with thinly sliced potatoes which doesn't add much to it either.  Third dish was the filet mignon which was cooked medium-well (I forgot to indicate how I wanted it) but still flavorful and tender.  Fourth was the infamous chocolate butterscotch pot de creme.  I was literally looking forward to this and this alone!  I was impressed because it's the richest, most delicious upscale version of pudding you'll ever have.  Sitting in the center is a double sided piece of chocolate and toffee.  Maybe I was too full or over loaded with sugar but I could only eat 1/4 of this but I wanted to finish it!  I really did.

Another entree option that night was the sea bass which turned out more like sea bream.  Usually this is served white, flaky, and plump but this was more like pan fried and like something you make at home.

In the end, I enjoyed my time here.  The room is slightly bare bones, probably because we didn't have the amount of people to fill it.  I wouldn't recommend going under a party of 15 since this room can supposedly fill up to 40.  I do like that there are bathrooms and a bar just for us since we were upstairs.  It's nice to be removed from all the noise downstairs.  My only suggestion is to spruce it up a little and provide an area for peoples' belongings.
author: Shannon L.

description: Salmon was good but not great, and the cuban sandwich was also eh. Great chips though, and excellent service.
author: Rohan S.

description:
My lovely husband took me here for my birthday, realizing as foodies it was on our must-check out list and we hadn't been. We had an amazing meal. He was concerned about the noise volume after doing his yelp research, but it was perfectly fine, just normal restaurant buzz (it was a Sunday night at 8pm, but all the tables were full). Our waiter was pleasant and attentive, we ordered two rounds of wine and he let us know midway through, "just let me know when you're ready for your next glass." We did, and boom! There it was. We had a great time here, and enjoyed:

*Oysters, those little Kumamoto ones don't freak us out, which were fresh and served with a delightful garlic/oil
*Barbecued Shrimp on Toast with a divine Worcester-based sauce
*Amazing bread with the salted butter (Give me a break I am a huge bread girl, this is important!)
*The Sliders...umm YUM pulled pork, and chicken with jicama? I forget the 3rd one but they were totally finished!
*The short ribs with gnocchi, total melt in your mouth AMAZING, but so rich I couldn't finish it
*The squash, fresh and very tasty
*The Quail, cooked to perfection, totally not shared with me at all because my husband ate it all

We were so full by dessert we had to order the sorbet to keep it simple, it was amazing aqua fresco/horchata flavors, YUM! 

We will definitely go back. Much more pleased with this one than salt house, now I am very excited to try their new one: Anchor and Hope.
author: Nikki M.

description:
Dessert is often the reason I want to go out to dinner and I aspire to be a pastry chef in my next life....if I can produce desserts as exceptional as those I sampled at Town Hall on a recent visit.

I uploaded several pics, including one of my "2008 Dessert of the Year" which was absolutely astonishingly good (not to mention rich)! The chocolate and butterscotch pot de creme with housemade slabs of toffee literally made me moan with delight, so creamy, so rich but such well balanced pure flavors and contrasting creamy/ crunchy texture.
author: Alison B.

description: Fried chicken! There for lunch and they don't have it? Had an amazing 'po boy' type sandwich that was the daily special. YUM! The place is great for work lunches.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Anchor & Hope, Salt House, and Town Hall are all owned by the same folks. In the last three months I have been lucky enough to sample each of them. Town Hall is probably my favorite.

This restaurant reminds me of New England, where I spent a chunk of my college years. Town Hall looks like a colonial town hall but classy. In fact, it looks like the Great Hall in Boston from the outside (google it).  I digress--I don't miss the East Coast at all, but I love memories of the East Coast conjured up on the West Coast.

Anyway, I came here for lunch. For an appetizer I had the tuna tartare, which was light and refreshing. The garlic chips were a nice touch. For my entree I had the crispy soft shell crab sandwich with sweet potato chips. There was a solid amount of crab in my sandwich and the sweet potato chips were addictive. As if the good food wasn't enough, the server was not bad to look at either. I generally don't like servers who recommend the most expensive items on the menu, but as I thoroughly enjoyed my food, I forgive the server for his unsavory behavior. Haha.

Thanks to fellow Yelper dan h. for this great meal!
author: Liz T.

description:
Very trendy place. Not a usual spot for me but a friend is good friends with one of the waiters there and let me tell you- He hooked it up! Between 3 of us we had about 6 or 7 drinks, and shared an appetizer and a few desserts. Fortunately, we paid for well less than half of that and tipped big. It's a bit too pricey for my usual tastes but the food and drinks were quite exceptional! 

Must try the "Buttermilk Biscuits, Prosciutto de Parma, Red Pepper Jelly". Amazing!
author: Spencer Y.

description:
Went on a Friday - may have ended up happier on a week night.  Service didn't start (meaning water and greeting) for 15 min after being seated.  Busy time of night, but I'd rather stand by the door or drink at the bar than sit somewhat awkwardly waiting for service.  The (likely) manager came around and took a drink order, bless him.  And the night was off and running.

We had an odd plan for eating - our friends just wanted drinks and dessert, my date and I were there for some grub.  Our waitress didn't let on the usual "just that, nothing else!?" annoyance, which was appreciated.  

The pepper jelly biscuits and jalepeno cornbread were excellent starters and like others, we really liked the fried chicken, and were happy that we opted to share it.  The pot de creme and donut desserts were perfect and delicious.  Our drinks were unique.  We aren't likely to return, as there are many places to eat in SF and this one didn't have the atmosphere and bang that brings me back around.  Glad we went, but wished service was a little more on point up front.  But happy that it recovered fully.
author: Lindsay B.

description: An update - went back with friends, had a great dinner, laughed a lot, food was wonderful. The rude female bartender was no longer there. Awesome. 5 stars.
author: Annie D.

description:
Creative delicious New Orleans-inspired food (try BBQ shrimp for sure), great ambiance, great wine's by the glass. 

I will say we had the most petulant, rude waiter I think I have ever had to deal with (to the extent that I contemplated whether this person had a personality disorder).  If it hadn't been for the waiter's attitude, this would have been a 5 star review. The management should have the insight to get rid of rude staff members.
author: Blake G.

description:
Pros:
Great clam chowder and mahi mahi.  Very good lunch spot.  More modern than I was expecting.

Cons:
A little pricey especially for lunch, but good food costs dinero.

Fun:
I hear the owners of this place also own Anchor & Hope and Salt House.  Maybe if you go to all three on the same day you get some kind of hat trick prize?
author: Mike G.

description:
Really delicious meal!  

Came here on a Sunday evening and it wasn't particularly busy.  We were greeted and seated immediately upon arrival about 15 minutes in advance of our reservation.  

I loved the ambiance.  Great interior decor, especially the light fixtures.  Others have felt the tables were a bit close together but I found it very comfortable.  

While many have raved about the fried chicken and pork chops, my dining companion and I were more intrigued by a number of the starters and we decided to compose a meal of them.  Our server was amenable to this and suggested  creating two courses of our small plates.

We started with the biscuits with prosciutto and the tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes.  I absolutely LOVED the biscuits.  They were SO delicious.  Sadly, they were very small, though adorable!  The portion of prosciutto was so generous, I wish there had been several more biscuits.  The tartare was good as well.

For our next "course" we had the peppers stuffed with crab, jambalaya, corn bread and veal meatballs.  All were yummy.  I could have had a much larger portion of the stuffed peppers.  It was a starter so I don't fault Town Hall for the portion size.  It was just so delicious that I wanted more!  The portion of meatballs was very generous and could be billed as an entree if it were served on a different plate.  

We ended the meal with the butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme.  Very tasty, especially the absolutely delicious butter crunch on top.

Overall, it was a delicious meal.  The service was unimpressive, hence the lack of a fifth star.  It took far too long to get our water, drink orders and check.  I'm fine with some time during a meal but the elements before and after should be attended to in a timely manner.  Still, I would absolutely return to Town Hall.
author: Shauna F.

description: This place is a great find! It's somewhat hidden, and you wouldn't know how amazing it is till you actually step in. We live in SoMa and couldn't believe this place is within a 3-4 block radius. Food taste is uhhh-mazing! We had veal meatballs - whether you like meat or you like balls, get em!!! Also, their butternut squash soup - one of the best I've tasted! It's like a cream of scrumptiousness with a hint of roast and side of crispness. Spicy duck salad - also SO good! It was a gallimaufry of interesting items in a salad. Fried chicken - finger licking good (as colonel sanders would say it and probably agree if he were alive....may his soul rest in peace). But to really experience what the kitchen has to offer, be prepared to use that wallet of yours (or your man's:)). Great crowd and environment. Very happening.
author: Reema M.

description:
There is no doubt the food is good. Rather tasty in fact. The service, however, was horrible. My friends and I made reservations a week or so in advance for Dine About Town during our lunchtime. When we arrived on time, we still had to wait 10-15 minutes to be seated. When we were finally seated, it took another 10-15 to get our drink orders and probably another 10 minutes AFTER that to get our entree order. At this point, we are all concerned about getting back to work on time. When our appetizers arrived, we were cutting it short, but when the apps were taken away, and we waited another 15 minutes for the main entrees. I had to ask for the check, which came before the food from our very reluctant waiter. I let him know this was a problem, and not with a hint of concern, he just said, the food takes 25 minutes, and shrugged his shoulders. 

I finally spoke with the manager who apologized, but that was it. Nothing to make up for that horrific waiter and unnecessary long lunch.
author: Allison B.

description:
Food five stars....service one star.  I take that back; service three stars server one star!  We went in with a reservation and waited thirty minutes for our drink.  We watched the server talk to other tables as our beer sat  in his hand on the tray.  When the beer arrived it was delicious.

The server made absolutely no eye contact with me as I ordered and didn't bring bread until we had ordered entrees even though we had ordered apps and drinks ten minutes before.  He also touched his face and hair during the entire evening as we watched him on the dining room floor...gross.  Our bill was $160+ ,($130 with a $30 tip), for two of us on a random weeknight, in our city of s.f., without dessert...at this price point I expect to be taken seriously and we weren't.
