We ordered the ahi appetizer and the scallop appetizer.  Both were delicious.  The ahi was fresh and translucent with a nice lingering spice that was almost undetectable during consumption.  The brown butter and citrus combination with the scallops were divine on the cabbage and the citrus wedges were definitely paid some extra attention to as the citrus flavors were muted and balanced pleasantly with everything else. 

The server didn't write anything down which is fine...if your going to actually remember.  He had to come back and ask us what our entrees were.

I ordered another beer and it took ten minutes...come on!

Our entrees were the ny steak and the bacon wrapped trout.  The steak is the best I've had in recent memories including boboquavaris and spruce.

Overall we really enjoyed the ambiance and overall vibe, the runners, the bussers, the hostess upon entry and departure... We will go back for the food but will make sure that we don't have the same server.
author: Orayo C.

description:
Gah, this one is really tough for me to write.  I used to live a few blocks away and I've had some real great experiences here, eating wonderful food with my family, meeting tre cool of Green Day (who apparently frequents their bar) but my experience there last night will probably prevent me from returning.

My girlfriend and I arrived around 8pm last night (7/22/12) for dinner.  At first, the doors were locked, which was kind of strange, and instead of someone coming to open them, we got stared at for a few minutes like we were aliens before someone came to help, which was pretty lame on its own, but then to get the "oh, do you have a reservation? no? wow, well let me see if something is available" when your restaurant is half full at best and maybe 5-6 more tables were sat all evening is pretty annoying.

So we sit down, order drinks, veal/pork meatballs and entrees.  The drinks and meatballs come out pretty quick, but my girlfriend and I each cut one in half and the center was raw, not medium rare, not rare, but raw, like you can pick an individual strand of cold pork out of it.  I call the waiter over and he takes a quick look, agrees they are massively undercooked and even says something along the line of "wow thats not good, especially with ground pork!" (a+ for our waiter btw, he was incredible).  So he takes the meatballs back to the kitchen.

A minute or so later a woman, who I assume was the manager (and also the same person who greeted us fairly gruffly) comes over and tells us that they normally serve the meatballs medium rare and shes sorry we expected something else.  (As I said, they weren't medium rare, they weren't even rare).  After this I went over and grabbed the actual recipe for the meatballs which is sitting right on the desk by the entrance and it clearly advises as the final step in cooking the meatballs "cook the meatballs to medium", as someone who cooked meatballs last week, this is very clearly correct.

So, in return for going to this restaurant, waiting for them to actually open their doors, starting with gruff customer service, not only do I get uncooked food, I also get attitude about it?  I mean, I've sent back maybe 3 plates in my entire life, but this was a no brainer, to have someone come tell me I'm wrong in this situation just really is unacceptable.  What is the point?  To protect your chefs?  To protect your reputation?  Honestly if there was a simple "wow we undercooked these, our mistake", it would be fine, but they made a very clear mistake and then went out of their way to make it sound like we were being dramatic by sending back an uncooked meatball.  I spoke with a friend who is one of the best chefs I knew about the incident and he said he would have made it very clear to this person that he would never be back to their restaurant, I was just a little too shocked at the treatment we received to even think about that honestly.  Hugely unfortunate, I wish we had just walked away at the locked doors and not had a chance to deal with this manager.  I genuinely wonder how she got the job.
author: Ryan J.

description:
We came here for dinner last night before going to watch Cirque du Soleil.

The service from the waitress was fantastic.  Very friendly and attentive.  Our entrees took a long time to come out but she stopped by to let us know they were on the way, which was nice.  She even noticed that the bus boy had taken my butter knife and brought me a new one.

The appetizer we shared was flavorful--boneless chicken wings with grits and farm egg.  No complaints there.

The entree, however, was a disaster.  I ordered potato gnocchi with fall harvest vegetables thinking it would be something light and healthy.  The presentation on the plate was nice, but that was it.  Every single piece of vegetable and gnocchi tasted like it had been slow stewed in grease.  I've never tasted anything that had been so thoroughly permeated with grease.  I had to drink a lot of water and eat bread to even be able to eat any of it.  I asked my husband to eat some of it since I hate to waste food, but we couldn't finish it.  I realized later that it was a big mistake to have eaten any of it, as my stomach became quite queasy later that night.
author: Michelle J.

description: This place was recommended to me by a friend that grew up in SF so I thought I would give it a try.  The food was mediocre at best.  I had to return my pork chop that was overcooked.  They kindly replaced it with a steak and charged me ten dollars more for their mistake.  Bad business!   Overall it was ok, but I will not be returning here unless I'm desperate.
author: Allison L.

description: First, the ambiance in one of their private dining rooms is way too bright; the temperature is hot and uncomfortable and there is a giant picture of a woman who looks like she has just been f----d hanging awkwardly in the dining room. The servers move at a snails pace. The crab cakes, and corn fritter appetizers are the size of a dime with a microscopic dot of sauce in the center. It probably took hours to make something that miniature. I found the portion sizes slightly humorous. My salmon was undercooked and it was presented on top of three tiny new potatoes and to the right were two slices of cauliflower. The after dinner coffee was mediocre at best and the dessert, "pot de crème" was an actual jar with butterscotch and chocolate pudding with a broken piece of candy stuck in the middle. Total pretentious garbage, very mediocre.
author: Michelle V.

description: My dog can cook better than this and I don't even have a dog! Something called "gumbo" had a whole can of chile powder and salt in it. What's more insulting is that the few crawfish that were in the "crawfish gumbo" were whole! After spending a fortune, I went home hungry. Definitely will not be back.
author: Nikki M.

description:
I was here with our department to celebrate a major milestone.  We had reservations and was seated promptly shortly arriving at around 6:00pm. on a weekday. The place was packed by 7-8:00 pm   

We were able to have a great time together as a department. It was complimented by the great food and drinks at this restaurant.  

Ratings (out of 5)
Food:  **** 
Staff: ****
Value: ***
Restrooms: ***
Location: ****
author: Ed H.

description:
On my very first trip to Town Hall, I ordered "Faith's warm ham and cheese toast, poached egg and jalapeno cream," expecting a fancified version of a croque madame - or, essentially, a simple grilled sandwich.

I was thoroughly unprepared for what I got. First of all, the actual "ham and cheese toast" part of the entree is rather pitifully small. This was contrasted, however, by the flood of jalapeno cream that smothered both my toast and the rest of my plate - to the point that I was eating a small cracker floating in a pool of sludge. I ate about a third and felt so incredibly and overwhelming full, I was grateful when my plate was cleared.

More than anything, I was just blown away by how utterly inadequate the menu description was for what I actually received. "Jalapeno cream," to me, sounded like some sort of a side condiment. To receive a sandwich utterly smothered in the stuff was more than surprising - and I thought I was going to pass out at my desk when I returned to the office.

I might give Town Hall another shot (with another menu item) should I be forced inside at another date, but as long as I'm calling the shots, I'm not going back.
author: Amanda F.

description: Elegant, laid back and not snobby. Had the pork belly risotto today for lunch and it was excellent. This place brings in an awesome lunch crowd.
author: James W.

description:
Just had lunch here with the coworkers because the boss was treating.  Ordered the seafood etouffee here and it was soooo good!  Loved the shrimp and crawfish that came with it.  I've been craving southern food and this place has definitely satisfied that.  Got the St. Louis drink also.  Wasn't too strong and had an interesting bell pepper taste to it...I'd get it again.  

I wish we had more time to try their appetizers and dessert but sadly we didn't.  It gets pretty packed but we went right when it opened so had no trouble whatsoever.
author: Jane N.

description: I had a really nice experience here.  I dined with a friend pretty early in the evening on a Saturday evening.  The restaurant was not busy at all when he dined.  The restaurant space is lovely.  It's large and the dining room is really well done.  We had a cod fritter appetizer, which may have been a special, as well as a tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes.  Both were great, especially the cod fritters.  They were like little dough balls of fishy goodness. I had the fried chicken and it was very, very good.  I feel the breading could have been a bit more flavorful (spicy, etc.) but the texture was perfection and the chicken was moist and perfect.  What really won though was the mashed potatoes and gravy.  Unreal.  I'm not sure what the green was, but it was good.  My friend had the steak.  I don't think she was blown away, but no complaints.  We passed on dessert and had cocktails instead.  I believe it was an Island Mule and a Tiger Lily.  Both good, but not amazing.  Our server was a bit on the cheeseball side and I honestly don't think he brought any of the food to the table, although that may just be how the restaurant is set up.  He did comp us our cod fritters for some reason we couldn't understand - they came out too soon?  (not exactly a problem for me). I really liked Town Hall - I plan to go back.  Honestly, I have had dreams of the fried chicken and especially the mashed potatoes since!
author: Megan W.

description: Phooey. The food's good but overpriced (shocking, I know). My food was prepared with skill and sensitivity to the ingredients. But I ask you: do we really need another mosh-pit of over-educated, self-important "chefs" cranking out food that people think is good solely because they're paying a lot for it? That may be a trifle harsh, but for chrissake.. this crap is really getting under my skin.
author: John H.

description: I was disappointment with the food.  Service was good but we wait our food for over 30 minutes. The manager comp us drink to keep us happy.  I would not go back.
author: Chris L.

description:
This review is for Happy Hour:

Pretty good deal cheap drinks ($3 pils as compared to it at $7 regular). The good was pretty good to and at a decent price for happy hour. I would consider heading back for this but I am not sure I would go any time out of HH.
author: Andrew M.

description: I have eaten here three times, and the service and food is consistently good.  Very helpful, nice wait staff.  Fried chicken and the ham and cheese toast are definitely the highlights.
author: Brynley W.

description:
Food was really good, the desert was unbeatable, the service was awful! Well...yea awful for what I paid. Had a small lunch for 2 and it cost me $100. The lady was slow and ignored me, I think because I am 23 and she thought she could get a better tip from other patrons. I HAD to ask another table for their menu just so that I could order, because I couldn't get our server to come over. I was really embarrassed to have to do that.

I think most people would only give a star for a place that did that. I'm just hesitant to screw a place because on one person being terrible at their job.

The deserts were great. completely wonderful! The food was good. My veggies were perfect, a rare feat.

How do you rate a place that has great food, but treats you like crap? I'm pretty sure it was an age thing though, the table next to us (had two older lawyers) got fantastic service.
author: Cory D.

description:
Simply delisioso!  Their tuna tartare might have been one of the spiciest things I've ever eaten, but dang it was good.  

When you combine it with the AAAMMAZING "donuts and coffee" it made for the perfect "ladies who lunch" afternoon.  

And to boot ... our waiter Benjamin was adorable and very attentive.
author: Sho O.

description: Very much enjoyed our meal with friends last Friday night. The food was great (My wife andI had the seafood stew, while our friends had the pork chop & halibut).  All was first rate, the halibut was especially tasty. The bbq shrimp appetizer was crazy good! The service was excellent and the staff very knowledgable. Looking forward to your next visit.
author: James W.

description:
The restaurant is in a brick warehouse but yet it has a contemporary feel on the inside. Plenty of off street parking after 6PM on a Friday evening. Each time we go there the place is vibrant and busy. This time we were there for a company function. 

The hostess and Manager greeted us immediately. We waited at the bar for the rest of the party.The bartender was cheerful and friendly. Later we went upstairs to a private dining room. The room was just the right size for a private party. 

It was a perfect evening, fantastic service, great food and drinks, great company; definitely will be going back soon.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
Great restaurant!!!  

We went here on a saturday, made reservations for 8 and were seated within 5 minutes of us getting there.  The ambiance was lovely and I think we were the only real loud ones :) 
Service staff was great!  Very informative, never let the water glass get low, and made terrific recommendations.  
We ordered oysters to start which was fresh & delicious, then on to the veal meatballs which were absolutely amazing with the sauce and mashed potatoes served with them.
I ordered the lambshank, served hot and just fell right off the bone it was so tender!  My boyfriend had the pork chop with the peanut butter apple crust which was also mouth watering delicious!  
I would definitly go back to Townhall, everything was amazing here!
author: Lauren C.

description:
Food: 
The fried chicken was great with a crispy battered outside and juicy inside. The drinks are really great; the bartenders are super friendly and conversational and put a lot of effort into making the drinks. The DESSERTS are out of this world. I've had almost all of them and they are all heavenly. The fig cheesecake really made an impression on me, but be aware they recently switched up the menu - definitely check out the gingerbread cheesecake instead! 

Service: 
The majority of the employees here are great and provide SUPERB customer service; however, both times I've encountered the HOSTESS (long-haired brunette, bigger boned) she has been unwelcoming and unfriendly. Poor customer service leaves a foul taste in your mouth! Our first time here, my bf and i made a rez for 8:30 and by the time we sat down, we decided that we weren't hungry enough for dinner so we just order drinks and dessert. Once we told our waiter that, the hostess walked over to our table and curtly told us that they only took reservations for dinner. Fine, inform us of your policy but there's no need to be rude about it! Further, as we looked around, about half the tables were empty so I knew we weren't causing them be short on tables. Awful customer service. 

Overall: 
+5 stars for the food, -1 star for poor customer service.
I will definitely be back for drinks and desserts at the bar!
author: Jenny C.

description:
Dine About Town 2011. I wanted to take a friend out to a nice lunch.  My suggestion for this DAT menu - pass on this one.  While the clam chowder was heavenly, the main dishes of pork chop or jambalaya were both a miss.  Both plates came out cold.  It tasted fine, but certainly no wow factor.

Within the short hour, the staff asked us 5 times if we were done with our dishes.  My mamma taught me to finish my food, but heck, after the 5th request and the mediocre meal, I saw no reason to hold onto it.
author: Stella K.

description:
I've been here many times since it opened, including hosting private events upstairs, but I think I am going to pass on going back.

Its not the food, the new chef Vernon is producing great dishes, we enjoyed the fried oysters, BBQ shrimp and the amazing veal meatballs and our entrees of sea bass with chorizo and trout were excellent.

What put me off is how LOUD the place has become.  Don't get me wrong I do like a vibrant dining scene but when you can't have a conversation its makes the whole experience disappointing.

Even the wait staff had to ask us a couple of times to repeat our order since they could not hear over the roar.

The upside of eating in the City is that I have options, so my option is to pass on Town Hall (sad) and move on to other places that produce great food and I can walk out without damage to my ears.
author: G R.

description:
Went in to Town Hall for a late/last minute dinner last night for the first time, and thought it was great.

The atmosphere is inviting, classy, and lively without being too loud for conversation.

The service was great from start to finish, with friendly and professional staff members. 

The wine list has a lot of great offerings in an array of price ranges, and we loved the Rioja we ordered (and when I broke a glass like a total dumbass, no one made me feel like an idiot about it).

We shared 3 appetizers and loved them all:

-Cornmeal fried oysters served over an Herbsaint-Spinach Puree and topped with bacon: DELICIOUS, and the cornmeal batter was not too heavy, and not at all oily or greasy. The oysters were wonderful, and the puree with which they were served complemented the oysters perfectly.

-Warm Ham and Cheese Toast, Poached Egg, Jalepeno Cream: This was STELLAR. Comfort food at its best, with a unique kick from the jalepeno cream. 

-Crispy goat cheese and herb stuffed Squash Blossoms: These were new on the menu, and the best of the night. The light soda batter on the blossoms was barely existant, and gave the dish the texture it needed without making it too heavy, or compromising the delicate Squash Blossom.

I will be back for sure.
author: D S.

description:
I've passed this restaurant for years but never went in. So when a coworker planned lunch here, I was excited to try it. 

I had the duck confit cassoulet because they didn't offer their famous fried chicken today. The dish was good, good portion, but the duck was overlooked and dry. I prefer my duck juicy and tender but this duck leg was over-roasted and burnt in some places.  Nevertheless, on the whole it was good. 

For dessert, we had the red velvet cake and ice cream. It was good but not as good as the red velvet cake at Cheesecake Factory.

Don't know what the hype is because the food was OK.  But I give an extra star for their impeccable service - fantastic! So attentive, courteous and professional.  The setting and ambiance is nice too, but it can get noisy.
author: Chilly W.

description: Amazing food! Amazing service! The general manager and bar staff really made our night. We would definitely return.
author: Bobbi H.

description:
We had a late reservation and the place was extremely packed on a Saturday night! 

We ordered 2 appetizers, an entree each and split the dessert. The server was very helpful, he gave us the option to serve our appetizers as courses instead and also let us know the popular dishes. So for example, we each got a plate for our tuna tartare dish which was awesome! Note: there were only two of us so maybe that's why we were given this option.

For the appetizers, we got the 'Tuna Tartare with Cornmeal fried green tomatoes', the flavors were so interesting and we were more intrigued by the fried green tomatoes. We also got the 'Ham and Cheese Toast, Poached Egg and Jalapeno Cream', one of their specialties and this was extremely rich and delicious! It sounds just like what it is but so much better, it was completely topped with jalapeno cream. 

For the entrees, we got the 'Pork Chop' (a specialty) and the 'Rib Eye', and we were both VERY happy with our dishes. The meat was juicy and extremely flavorful and the sides served with the entrees were very good. We also got the warm jalapeno cornbread served in it's little baking dish. 

For dessert, we shared the 'Coffee and Donuts' and got fresh pressed coffee, it was the best way to end our meal. 

The service was great, the servers as well as the bussers were very friendly and delightful. 

Great experience, wish i was rich so i could go back again soon!
author: Eva L.

description:
Really good experience. The only reason I knock a star is a few silly things that were enough to rub me the wrong way.
Anyways....

First of all - the drinks were spot on. The full liquor menu was teeny tiny print (made me wish I had my grandma's magnifying glass w/torch attached) but the selection itself was good.
The wine list was perfect for our taste - I find it hard to get good Spanish options here; and I get it - northern Cali, Napa valley etc etc etc. But I grew up on my Rioja's and Tempranillo's and there's a real fondness there.  I really enjoyed the Rioja here.

In terms of food we split a tuna tartare, BBQ shrimp and 8 oysters between 4 of us, then I shared the duck prosciutto and the steak with the hubs. Both were delicious.  The waitress has described the portions as being generous so we felt confident splitting an app and entree would be enough. In all honesty the portions weren't that generous, but the food itself was rich - we actually couldn't finish all our food and we are folks who can eat. We love to eat.

Service and everything else was fine. We were there late and we were the last to leave; I know and I'm sorry about that. But we were catching up cousins after almost a year. Don't make 7 people hover over us. We genuinely got it and we were drinking up and wrapping it up. Sometimes it just takes a minute to wrap it up when it's been that long with frousins.

Dessert was delish - we did 'coffee and donuts' screw the ice cream, the donuts were yum! So much so we asked for a side of donuts. Of course they said yes but went ahead and did the whole dessert. And charged full price. But that's neither here nor there.

The only other thing that got to me was that my wine glass sat empty for a minute or two at the beginning of our meal and so I asked my husband if I should serve myself or wait for our server....he said serve yourself. Wrong! As soon as I grabbed the bottle and was about to pour she came jogging over doing a 'tut tut' at me. Not appreciated. My girl caught me straight away and said she knew what I was thinking but thought I was not properly understanding. Ok; I'll take a step back. Um - don't let my glass get empty when we're getting a buzz on. Or perhaps a slightly different approach when reprimanding a customer?

All in all I had a great night and will be back here.
author: Kym P.

description:
I feel awful giving Town Hall only 3 stars because they treated me well, but not well enough!

There are a couple dishes here that you can always count on to be good - the jalapeno cornbread is a MUST. Fresh out of the oven, cute little bite-sized pieces, the jalapeno is so subtle yet adds just enough kick so you feel that zing on your tongue.. I am determined to steal and recreate this recipe! Also, the cornmeal fried oysters are absolutely beautiful. Crispy on the outside, gooey sloshy creamy goodness on the inside. I must warn you that one oyster was incredibly salty - I guess the chefs are a bit sloppy with the salt distribution - but again, this could have happened with any dish, so do not let this deter you from getting those oysters!

The biggest disappointment was the Tai rice-crusted snapper. The fish was soft and the texture was just how I liked it, but sadly, it was completely flavorless! The blue crab etouffee (the whole reason I chose this dish in the first place) left me underwhelmed, and the "zuchini marmalade stuffed piquillo peppers" tasted like they were pulled straight from a cheap caprese sandwich. My friend ordered the St. Louis ribs - they were nice and tangy, but not too different from the $12 rack of ribs from Sizzlers'. 

Dessert - warm brioche donuts and blue bottle coffee ice cream - was a very creative play on "coffee and donuts" (how appropriate, since my friend is a cop!) and actually very delicious! Sadly, I could not get over my disappointment in my entree, which for the first time at such a restaurant, I did not finish and brought home as leftovers. The service was also so-so. Upon seating us, our waiter joked, "yea... the service here is not so good". Well, turns out he wasn't kidding! Come here if you must, but please don't have your hopes up!
author: Shawna C.

description: I am a Southern girl, so I KNOW Southern food. I had the fried chicken, obviously. Great dish. Good service. Quite pricey to pay for a meal my momma can cook better BUT it's a nice little gem to have in the neighborhood when I crave a little piece of home.
author: Candi M.

description:
I like restaurants that do the combination of bar area and restaurant well. I think they do it pretty well here: the bar folks are able to be their semi-rowdy selves as the restaurant folks enjoy their proper, sit-down meals.

Two lady friends and I came here a couple of months ago, and I can't believe we ate all this food.

My two favorites of the night:
+ Faith's warm ham and cheese toast, poached egg, jalapeno cream: the egg was poached perfectly and the jalapeno gave it a nice spicy kick. It was really hard to split this three ways though, mostly because it was so finger-lickin'-ly tasty, our stomachs and taste buds were fighting with our Asian polite "no, you have the last bite" brains.
+ Piquillo peppers, Dungeness crab-Bienville stuffing, vermouth lobster cream: nice unique stuffing of piquillo peppers. It is pretty hard to mess up stuffed peppers though.

Other dishes:
+ Buttermilk fried chicken, Anson Mills grits, collard greens, bacon gravy: REALLY good, but am I the only person who hates paying $23+tax/tips for fried chicken? ...damn it, I would totally still get it again.
+ Butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme with buttercrunch: loved the buttercrunch, but I've had better chocolate pot de creme.
+ Buttermilk biscuits, country ham, red pepper jelly: yay, it comes in 3 mini-biscuits and delicious thinly-sliced ham!
+ Petrale sole with butternut squash puree, beech mushrooms, pomegranate sauce, potato gnocchi: *blinks* yeah, I don't quite remember this dish; probably not a good sign, eh? o_O
+ Warning: the smoked andouille jambalaya is SPICY! It tasted good but I could only have a couple of bites :(

I wouldn't come here with too large of a party, since everyone will want a bite of every single dish (it's THAT good!), and it was already a struggle making sure each of us had a decent bite of each item.
author: Tina L.

description: Had a wonderful dining experience. The waitress Rachael was efficient and courteous. I had the venison chops and my wife had the ribs. Both were excellent. We will be back. Excellent job to all.
author: Joe F.

description: Spent 8 days in Napa and San Fran and ate at some great restaurants but this might have been my favorite.  Upon a recommendation from a bartender (Cynthia at Market in St. Helena whom we also enjoyed very much in Napa) we decided to try Town Hall in San Francisco.  We arrived on Thursday evening and were fortunate to find to seats opening at the bar when we walked in.  Our bartender Bob greeted us immediately and got us our first round.  He recommended one of their new cocktails (Normandie Rises, very good) and that we try the BBQ Shrimp which was insane.  Although the bar was slammed the entire time we were there, Bob and the other bartender Jamal were always focused on their guests with a sense of urgency and maintained a friendly smile and conversation throughout.  Next we split the fried chicken for our entree and finished with butterscotch chocolate pot de creme with toffee.  Everything we had was memorable.  A real treat to eat at Town Hall.  We had fantastic food in Napa and San Francisco but this may have been our favorite for the whole trip.  The room, music, service, food and drink preparation all made Town Hall a great place to eat and have a cocktail.  Doubt I will ever return to San Francisco with stopping in at Town Hall.
author: Harley H.

description:
Cute restaurant and lots of space.  I came here cause my friend was raving about how great the fried chicken is and of course I had to taste it for myself.  The fried chicken was so juicy and perfect crispy skin.  OH how I love fried chicken.  I couldn't help notice that there was these warm jalapeno corn bread.  Yes, you guessed it.  My phat butt ordered the corn bread and well worth it.  The corn bread came out in the baking pan they were in and they were shaped as lady fingers.  The only thing I have to say is I wish they were bigger and dang I really love the butter! 

Definitely will come back again :)
author: Ying F.

description: Everything was great just wished I saved some room for desert
author: Phillip M.

description:
3.5 stars.

Town Hall has an extensive wine list and a wonderful cocktail menu. The lamb carpaccio and their oyster shooters are a must try. The service is and the food are both extremely good. So why the 3.5 stars?

I was here with 4 people and the bill came out to be roughly $400. Granted, there was a bottle of wine involved and multiple cocktails, but I feel like paying that much money for what essentially is bbq ribs, fried chicken and other classic American staples is way too much money. 

There are restaurants that have comparable ribs and fried chicken (sans the more refined dishes like oysters and lamb carpaccio) that have far better prices.

The take away from my review is that terms of service, drinks, and fine dining elements you are most definitely getting your money's worth. However, when one takes away the glitter, glamor, and sommelier Town Hall might as well be a neighborhood bbq joint.
author: Carlos V.

description:
The service was unacceptable with a waiter who must have a bad day and wanted to go home early.
I noticed that he memorized the menu and of course managed to forget a side order.
As far as the menu I ordered the rabbit.
The dish was more like a soup and I was wandering where was the lapin hiding !. The sauce was definitely too profuse and totally overwhelmed the flavors of the rabbit .
Anyway with dishes that command these type of prices I would expect better service and definitely more flavorful dish.
I was just very disappointed by the whole experience.
author: Marie G.

description:
For all the hype I really wanted to be able to give this place 5 stars, but I can't and it's mainly due to the ambiance. The tables along the wall are REALLY close to together. When I got up to leave, I practically sat on the table next to ours trying to get out and I'm a small person. The acoustics in the main dining area suck - once it got busy it was so loud my dining partner and I practically had to yell to be heard. We finally had to give up and communicate in non-verbals. Wine by the glass is overpriced. 

That being said, the food was excellent. I had the blackened catfish and totally cleaned my plate . . . I mean there was nothing left! I shared the frozen meyer lemon soufflé for dessert and it was spectacular. 

The service was OK and the period décor did make one think you were in an old town saloon. I would definitely go back and recommend this place for the food, but would prefer to sit outdoors or in the bar area. Not ideal for a romantic evening, but good for a group. Reservations are recommended.
author: Jenn T.

description:
The dessert here is amazing. AMAZING. I got the butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme and my friend got the coffee + doughnuts. They both deserve more than 5 stars.

We ordered a couple of sides, and an appetizer (mac & cheese croquettes, jalapeno cornbread, and a salad/crostini) which were really good too, but not as amazing as the dessert, and the salad is definitely not worth the price tag.
author: Richa A.

description:
Service: timley, courteous, patient, knowledgeable, descriptive, attentive, classy
Food: Good quality. A little uninspired at times. Nice flavors. TINY tasting portions. Could benefit from rotating more often and focusing more on seasonal ingredients. Best dishes are fried chicken (if you like it a little spicy and tart), the rotating selection of pork product (ham/prosciutto/whatever) with pepper jelly and buscuits (all three elements are impeccable), tuna tartar (perfectly cubed whole pieces of tuna delicately coated with avocado pieces and a spicy dressing served with crisp but not greasy sesame wontons), the pork chop (JUICY), the warm ham & cheese toast (too decadent for one person and really creamy), all of the salads (very whole, amazingly fresh ingredients put together in an elegant balance), and the sides - my favorite are the little finger sized cornbread. Always great fish dishes, accompanied by nice, light, seasonal vegetable ragus (like salmon with corn maque choux)
Ambiance: southern, mixed. I really love the building, the warmth of the decor, and the liveliness of the dining despite a large older, very wealthy and conservative looking crowd. A lot of young professionals visit, as well as many regulars by the couple and stag.
Bar: nice and big. Very friendly service, upscale appearance ,and can obtain full service there.
The only complaints: not really a waiting area in the restaurant, and cocktail selection can use a little refinement and complexity, perhaps a little more extensive selection. Wine program is OK; selection is pretty limited and on the very pricey side.
I really did not like the house barbecue sauce they serve with the barbequed prawns and the ribs. It has too much chili, cumin, vinegar, and something else I can't pinpoint.
Excellent rotating dessert selection, and always such a pleasurable dining experience.
author: Y K.

description: It wasn't my first time at Town Hall, but my first time with dinner reservations; the other times had been lunch, a couple times at the bar.  It's definitely a first-class restaurant in a city full of first-class restaurants, but I can't count it among my favorites.  To start with, the tables are very close together and the noise level is barely tolerable -- my friend and I have to shout our conversation the whole time, about as bad as it gets in SF.  The service generally is very good; our waiter got a couple of minor things wrong, but the maître d'hôtel/host is very friendly, gracious and competent.  And I really enjoyed my 'Suavecito' cocktail and my friend loved her martini.  As for the food, we both thought the starters were better than the entrees.  The fried okra is awesome, and the jalapeno cornbread and tuna tartare are both very good.  I was pretty disappointed with the fish stew, though.  No fish, for one thing, and just three shrimp and four small littleneck clams.  Not much broth, and the vegetables were zucchini and green beans -- who puts that in fish stew?  All in all, it's too expensive and noisy, and the food isn't good enough, for it to be on my list of every-time-I'm-in-town favorites.
author: Tim K.

description:
Town Hall has been the WORST place I have EVER eaten in my entire 4 year stay in San Francisco, KFC even does a better job than Town Hall! 

1st TRY of the NIGHT:I ordered their "Southern Fried Chicken Breast" which was $25.00. My order came and as I forked into the Chicken Breast (One Single Breast) blood starts oozing out of the fried chicken. I politely asked the server to please send this item back and redo the item so it would be cooked. Chicken is NOT supposed to be RAW or Medium Rare! My 1st date and I sat there for 10 minutes until they returned with a new chicken breast-

2nd TRY of the SAME ITEM: STILL Raw and Bloody Chicken Breasts!

3rd TRY of the SAME ITEM: RAW and BLOODY!!

I work in the service industry in a hotel as a Front Desk/Concierge and I part of my job is to go explore the city and try many different restaurants to refer to our guests. This is ABSOLUTELY NOT one of them! The server and the manager were rude and did not do anything about the situation except resent 4 RAW Bloody "Fried" Chicken Breasts. We waited for over 2 hours until they sent us the 4th Fried Chicken Breasts and guess what...?

4th TRY: They cut off the breast and served me the BONES!!!!!!!!!!
I was absolutely horrified by this, I was not rude about it because I know how it feels to be yelled at during your shift. I told the manager that this is extremely unprofessional and not worth $25.00. How can you serve me the side bones of the chicken breasts? 

I decided to STOP ordering the same bloody chicken breast (Even KFC can Deep Fry Good Chicken Breats!!) I told them I wanted the fish dish which was $28.00 ($3.00 more) and it took 30 mins to come out...of course it was DRY! They DID NOT comp me the fish dish! 

My date and I spent $200.00 there and I was very very unhappy! All they did was comp me a glass of wine...What do you have to say about that? You certainly left me speechless...
author: Khoa N.

description:
I had an amazing time at Town Hall last Saturday for my partner's Bday celebration. 

I made our reservation for 9:30pm for 10 people but was seated after 10pm ... I would normally be furious but the host would stop by where we are to chat with us every few minutes to let us know they are trying their best to have the other party leave .. graciously of course. They gave us wine while we wait. And  their staff would ask how we are whenever they pass by us.

The place is huge and has a good vibe to it. Although you have to go to the 2nd floor for their restroom (huff / puff ... lol!)

Appetizers were awesome. My fav would be the fried oysters! 

Our server suggested red and white wine for us and i wish i was able to get what those were. It was REALLY good!

I got the crusted thai snapper ... which was too boney for me but the flavor and sauce were really nice. Some of us had the Blackened Catfish, Duck and Ribs. 

The meal was O-K but the was experience was memorable. Thanks to our friendly server and staff ... who also gave my partner 3 mini cupcakes for her bday!

Thanks Town Hall!
author: RED C.

description:
OK, it's easy to be enthusiastic when you have a pretty young waitress who is enthusiastic and very competent.  An it's even easier to be enthusiastic about Town Hall when their food is on the money.

The tomato soup was near perfect.  Why?  It tasted like tomatoes.  That's the trick.

Butter lettuce salad.  Well-portioned with very fresh lettuce.  Perfect.

And fried chicken with an heirloom tomato salad.  Really great food.
author: David D.

description:
Went to Town Hall on a recommendation from a friend.  

On a Monday night, there was an approximate 1 hr wait to get a table -- so you know the place must have something going for it. 

Rolled up to the bar and ordered a bottle of Stag's Leap Riesling.  Bartender -- she was very cool -- let us taste a few bottles that she had open before we went out on a limb and went for the Stag's Leap.  Nice selection.   

After an hour, we sat down.  The inside of the restaurant is quintessential San Fran -- classic, stylish, crowded, warm, etc.  Love the inside especially the brick building inside -- no doubt a very cool vibe packed w/ hip San Franciscans (however, not pretentious).  

A group of us -- 6 -- ordered the tuna tartare and fried oysters as appetizers.  Great presentation and tasted quite nice -  4 stars.  

I had the blackened salmon - I thought it wasn't the BEST blackened salmon I've ever had, but it was quite good.   I made sure the salmon was washed down with ample amounts of pinot noir........

Some opted for desserts -- I sampled the campfire s'mores tart -- really nice.   

The service was pretty much, flawless.  Service is top notch in San Francisco -- I hope the servers are reading this -- thank you!

With regards to the volume level at this place -- it's fairly loud but -- I kindof like the energy level -- people are really enjoying themselves and lost in conversation about politics, work, life, personal interests -- I completely lost track of time when I was eating here.  It's a real pleasure in life to enjoy food and drink w/ good people surrounded by other people doing the same.  

Salud!
author: John O.

description:
This is by far my favorite restaurant in the city... 

Service is always friendly and fantastic. Food is consistently awesome and the cocktails are the best! You must try the Sazerac... its to die! 

Every time I have a visitor in town, I take them here and also to Anchor and Hope for their dollar oyster happy hour... both SF institutions!
author: Katie P.

description:
I'd been wanting to go to Town Hall for years and it was great to finally go (well worth the wait).  I was there a few months ago but the memories of that amazing meal are still fresh in my mind...

The setting is chic: exposed brick, sexy candlelit tables and antique hardwood floors...it's elegant, but not over-the-top. There wasn't too much to the decorations in the space, but I liked it that way - it made the food speak for itself. 

My appetizer was a small plate of buttermilk biscuits, fresh sweet/salty smoked ham with apricot preserves.  Although this may sound a bit strange for some people it was actually very good: a savory blend of salty and sweet.  The biscuits were a balanced combination of being soft inside and slightly flakey outside - who knew bread could be so amazing?  I'm not a huge ham person, but I really enjoyed this version: thin slices with a heavy pork flavor that really melted in your mouth.  The apricot preserves were amazing: sweet, but not too sweet, yet full of unadulterated apricot flavor.  Having all three items in your mouth at once was a marriage of several flavors that, amazingly enough, worked very well and made a boring appetizer something amazing.

Next up was my entree and it was near perfection.  It may sound boring: buttermilk fried chicken with mashed potatoes and grilled vegetables, but it really wasn't. The chicken was fresh and cooked to flawlessness - juicy inside and crispy outside with a lot of flavor.  The mashed potatoes were incredible since I can tell it was loaded with butter and cream (this is why I never make mashed potatoes at home).  The vegetables tasted like they had just been plucked from a near-by farm earlier that day especially for me...I really enjoyed the fact that the zucchini was not over-cooked and still had a bit of "crunch" to it.  The presentation was great, but it looked even better once the plate was clean and I had eaten every morsel.

The evening finished with what I can only describe as something sinful: caramel toffee bread pudding.  I almost always get chocolate for dessert, but I'm glad I changed my mind at the last minute.  First of all, it's a huge portion, second of all it was swimming in caramel and that was enough for me.  As with everything else I'd eaten there so far, it tasted fresh...someone had made bread pudding literally when I ordered it and I could taste the milk and eggs and cinnamon and other yummy goodness that went into the dessert.  The pudding was soft and decadent, yet hearty and wonderful.  Toffee encrusted the top of the pudding and oozed into the upper nooks and crannies - it was syrupy-sweet and buttery goodness. Did I mention it was swimming in caramel?  I've had homemade caramel before, but this stuff was something else: sweet, rich, slight salty and completely amazing.  

I would definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone...I'm not sure if they can completely accommodate those who are finicky eaters, but if you enjoy American Comfort food, this place takes the ordinary to extraordinary heights.
author: Ken G.

description: Clever dishes and helpful service. Tuna tartare on fried green tomato was amazing. Hush puppies did not remind me of Louisiana but were nonetheless pretty tasty. Some dishes weren't amazing but most were on the spot. Beverage program appears to be on the rise, with creative cocktails and a growing selection of wines and beers. The sommelier provided excellent wine service.
author: Paul S.

description:
A very solid 3.5 stars... or maybe even 3.75 stars if I can be picky about it.  I had dinner here on 10/31 to treat a friend visiting from out of town for an interview. The restaurant was not very busy at all, but comfortable in its ambiance and noise level.  The waiter was friendly and attentive, but not intrusive, and gave fairly honest opinions about his recommendations, which I appreciated (regarding one of the dishes, he said, "honestly, I believe we have a lot of other dishes that are way more interesting and delicious.")

My friend had the Duck Cassoulet and I had the Mahi-mahi.  I thought her duck was extremely flavorful, tender and delicious.  I quite liked my fish as well, as the fish was tender and perfectly cooked, and the sauce was also rich and flavorful.  One of those sauces that you take your bread to sop it up.  We finished by sharing the pumpkin bread pudding, which my friend quite enjoyed. I thought it was delicious, but actually slightly a bit too boozy for my own personal taste.

It is on the more expensive side, so not necessarily the best value for your buck with regards to portion size, for those price-conscious people, but definitely on par with many other restaurants in the neighborhood, and I would be open to returning again.
author: E F.

description:
Went to Town Hall last night - one of the worse dinners ever.  Portions were extremely small (like, way beyond unreasonable) at a very expensive price.  The wait staff were annoying and rude;  at one point, one of the waiters was confused about what table to place our appetizers.  When the table behind us told him they didn't order appetizers, I looked over and noticed they were ours, so I told him so.  His response?

"Yeah, right.  I need to check it to make sure."

Oh c'mon.  Are you kidding me?  I'm in your damn restaurant paying for this damn overpriced food for yuppies that can feed a mouse.  Give me a break.  (he eventually came back, without an apology).  One of the wait staff would also keep using the back of my chair to balance himself when serving the table behind us as well.  W.  T.  F.  

The sound levels were over the top LOUD.  My little party-of-three had to SCREAM at each other in order to talk.  

When our waiter came by to ask me how my miniature Halibut tasted, I looked at him and said, "eh, it's "cute"".  He inquired about what that meant, and I told him that the fillet (and lack of ANY sides to go with it?) could probably feed my mouse at home, he had nothing to say about it - no "sorry," no "would you like something else with it?"...  NOTHING.

This place sucks.  I do realize its a yuppie hangout, waiting for the next new restaurant.  But THIS iPhone-carrying-tech-worker-banana-republic-wearing yuppie just can't fall for this restaurant's crappy attempt at fine dining.

D-
author: Michael D.

description:
I hadn't heard much buzz about Town Hall but came here on the recommendation of my uncle. He deserves major thanks! This is one of the best meals I've had in awhile, both in terms of food and service. I like honesty from my wait staff and our server was open about the good and bad on the menu (nothing was bad per se, some things were just overhyped in her opinion). Our table ordered:

Peppers stuffed with crab: I don't normally like peppers but these were fantastic

Chowder (soup of the day): Creamy without being heavy, good flavor

Tuna tartare: I am not the biggest raw fish fan but this was delicious

Steak: Fantastic cut of meat with amazing sauce!!!

Salmon: Also very good (though I was happy I ordered the steak...)

Coffee and doughnuts: WOW

Butterscotch dessert: Good, but really rich so I could only eat a few bites
author: Amy F.

description:
Been wanting to go here for a while. Showed up on Friday night to find a nice atmosphere, great waitress, cool vibe. Passed by a bunch of trendy folks (with really nice shoes) at the bar on the way to be seated in dining room. 

Drink menu was interesting but a good example of all of the the restaurants that are trying too hard to be unique.  My wife had a drink that was like a mix between concentrated lime juice and battery acid. I had a froo-froo drink which was OK and then went to the old standby, a Hendricks Martini straight up with xtra olives which was good. They make their own soda as well and Wylie requested one of the sodas with a little Absolut and it was good. 

I had the butter lettuce salad with bleu cheese (yum) and the flatiron steak mid rare. Steak was cooked nicely and tender with a very rich and tasty mushroom based (?) gravy on it. I know a lot of people don't like sauces on their steaks (me, too, most of the time) but this was a good fit and went down nicely with the pureed potatoes on the side. 

To be fair, my friend Wylie gives this place 5 stars (he had the butter lettuce salad and the app BBQ shrimp as a main). But, it's my rating so I'm going with 4 stars with the right to change my mind on subsequent visits. Overall, a nice experience and a place that I would put in the Top 20 rotation for SF.
author: Robert W.

description: "Fancy" joint for brekkers and tea. Good food and able service, but it doesn't make much of an impression at all. A place, potentially for when someone else's parents are visiting and you'd like to play it safe.
author: Luke M.

description:
This popular Soma eatery was just okay for me. 

Can't remember much about the food other than the dishes were rather mediocre for the price. Some of the flavors were off putting to me like the sweet beef tongue. I do remember liking the BBQ shrimp.
author: Derrick V.

description:
I've come here several times, only because it is so close to the bus station.  Every time I have been here, the staff is loudly gossiping and complaining about each other, other patrons, and life in general.  Having worked in the service industry myself for several years, I understand that we all need to bitch to our coworkers.  But can't that be done in the back of house?  Or quietly, out of earshot of customers?  It's bad enough to here about how annoying so and so is for calling out again and how someone else's boyfriend is a jerk, but then to be bad mouthing  customers within 2 feet of other customers?  
The staff here needs to be retrained in appropriate behavior when on the job.
author: Denise H.

description:
3.25 stars is more appropriate.  First my beefs with the place:

-what's with the decor?? it reminds me of a victorian mansion at disneyland meets abstract art collector meets bad taste.
-the bathroom is like 1.5 miles from the restaurant

Anyhow, the food is pretty good (decor aside).  I went a few months ago so according to my recall, I really loved the tomato and mozzarella salad (it was heavy on tomatoes, had variety of tomato, and light on cheese - the way i like it).

The main dished I ordered were tasty but since I can't recall much more than "steak" - I'll go ahead and say they didn't blow my mind.

Good cocktails though!
author: Priscilla T.

description:
I was able to make a same-day reservation for three using their online system. We were seated a little late, and as we waited for our table to be ready, we sat at the bar and had pricey but very tasty drinks. 

The food was good, not amazing. Service was great. Bathrooms were really out of the way. Overall a fun dining experience.
author: Natalia F.

description: I live a hop skip and a jump from this place and I have to say its starting to become a fav of mine! Sit at the bar, that's what I love to do- order a bottle of wine because if there's two of you....I mean one glass isn't ever enough! I have to say the ribs are amazing and just perfect- slide off the bone with sauce on the side and the yummiest corn muffins are served with it. I like the butter lettuce salad too! But I tried the fried okra last Friday with the most amazing dipping sauce and was in love! awwwwwwwwesome. The amount of ribs are plenty- have shared this dish with someone else twice now, just make sure to get a salad or something else with it.
author: Ricquel N.

description:
Sunny and warm spring days call for a BBQ. But when you're working downtown, and lunch means 30min between one meeting and the next, a grilling session is out of the question.

Unless you work close to Town Hall.

I do, and in less than 30min I left my desk, walked over to their seasonal BBQ behind the restaurant, grabbed a freshly grilled shrimp po boy, and was back in time for my next meeting (with a few minutes to spare!).

Loved the concept, loved the friendly service, loved that they customized for me (shrimp only instead of shrimp and sausage), but didn't quite love getting only three shrimp on my sandwich. For $8, there should have been more.

What I did get was tasty. Stomach wants to give four stars, wallet wants to give two, so let's split the difference.
author: Jason B.

description: We recently were looking for a mid-week restaurant location for out of town guests.  We were surprised at how hard it is to get a reservation anywhere even on a Wednesday night.  Lucky for us, we snuck into Town Hall.  From our cocktails at the bar delivered by our smooth bartender (my champagne cocktail was the best ever), to our informative server, unbelievable fried chicken and through coffee and dessert...we were thrilled.  Our guests pointed out that it is rare to have a meal that end-to-end, is something you can rave about-there is usually some area which is a weak link, but at Town Hall, it was an amazing meal throughout.  We will be back soon!
author: Joyce D.

description:
My husband and I dined here last night for dinner and had a wonderful meal. I didn't know much about the restaurant, but had read the positive reviews and wanted to give it a try. It exceeded my expectations!

We were seated promptly at our reservation time and received immediate attention from our waitress. The table was not great as it was small and right up against a wall on one side, but we loved the open space, brick walls and big windows. Service was very good.

We shared two starters- a corn soup and Bibb lettuce salad with apples and candied walnuts. After our first taste of the soup I had high hopes for the rest of the meal. It was creamy but light and flavorful.

I had Salmon for my main course and my husband had the Flat Iron steak. We also had a side of cornbread, which was not noteworthy. The Salmon was cooked perfectly and had a delicious sauce and corn relish. The steak was served over potatoes and also had a rich sauce that was very good. We then had coconut pound cake with a peach ice cream (it wasn't really ice cream but had a texture like it)  and peach and blueberry compote that we finished because it was so yummy!   

There are many things I can't wait to get back and try!
author: Suzanne G.

description: Oh where to begin...... The cocktails, the Acme bread, the corn soup, the strawberry and white peach salad!  AMAZING in every respect.  While the restaurant can be a bit noisy, the vibe is fun and festive.  Not only were our starters great, the friend chicken with mashed potatoes and gravy were moist and juicy.  The tuna tartar with fried green tomatoes was not only beautifully presented, but delicious as well! We ended the night with the butterscotch and chocolate pot de crème and that just about sent me over the edge.  This restaurant never disappoints and you should go!
author: Tina D.

description:
Came here for a work related lunch and had just the best experience. Perfect blend of upscale casual, quality food at reasonable prices.

My work colleague is a recent transplant from Australia and he wanted to try some real American food...Town Hall was perfect!

I had a nice glass of rose upon the assistance of my lunch companion as he was having a beer and did not want to drink alone. Even though I usually leave my libations till after the work day is through I thought why not. It was ovely and crisp, light on the alcohol... perfect.

I orders the tuna tartar with fried green tomatoes to start! OMG the fried green tomatoes were the perfect blend of acidic crunchiness and the tuna was good although I would say a little less tabasco might be called for.

I had the tomato soup with cornbread as well with the butter lettuce salad for my entree. The portions were huge, the food had the perfect seasoning and the service was prompt yet not overbearing.

My colleague had the chicken breast and LOVED It. 

GREAT LUNCH~ Easy 5 stars

They have gained an official regular considering my work is a block away; can't wait to come back for happy hour so I can enjoy some of their delicious cocktails!!
author: Mikaela s.

description: Yumskies! The food here is rich and unassuming. Not anything to be WOW'd by, but it was good!
author: Loc H.

description:
It's been quite a few years since I've been to this place.  My boss and I were treated lunch here today by our co-worker, who I'm covering for (while she's on a medical leave). 

Every time I've been here, the food and service were great. This time, I had the old bay shrimp on ciabatta sandwich. It was delish! My boss had the pulled pork burger, and our co-worker had the TH burger. 

I'd come back to try their other items on the menu, but probably for special occasions.
author: Annette L.

description:
Overrated. I don't understand the hype for this place. It's good but its hit or miss considering the prices. We come here since it's near the office but I'd never bother without the expense account. 

The tuna tartare is quite good but my duck was way oversalted and the white beans were hard. The second time my pork chop dry and the beans undercooked. My third time the ettouffe of duck and rabbit was pretty good but the crawfish and shrimp on the side were watery if that makes any sense. They sometimes pair ingredients that don't always go as well together.

The butterscotch pot de creme is huge and good but not worth the orgasms half the reviewers are having. We ordered the fluffernutter cause it sounded funny and it was actually pretty good too. Devil's food cake was ok but even Cheesecake Factory has better cake.

Service:  The service can be inattentive and lacking. Expect to wait awhile...
author: Lainy C.

description: The first time I went here was for my boyfriend's birthday last year.   The food was good and the service is great but the food is a bit overpriced!  Our mayor, Gavin Newsome stopped by the restaurant that night too. Oh - they also have great desserts!
author: Christine P.

description:
Haven't had such tastey American fare in ages. Everything was divine. This is a meat lover's paradise. The veal meatballs were insane as was the simple steak. Cooked and seasoned to perfection. 

Only downside was the wait. They ran over a half hour behind, but have no fear, the hostess was very accomodating and set us up at the bar w/two glasses of wine on the house. Any quality restaurant who wants a repeat customer will do that. I agree with someone else's post below, don't remember the service much. They are there but not very interactive. Go there for incredible food and friendly host service and ignore the in between; you don't need server help with the menu.
author: Meredith R.

description:
With 398 reviews, we probably don't need another one for Town Hall.  But I figure that if one has an experience that is positive or negative, might as well share it.  

Really enjoyed the decor and space with high ceilings and nice furnishings.  Tables were spaced a little tight, but fortunately, we ate early and it was not too crowded.

Really loved the glorified comfort food concept.  I really like restaurants that have a vision and execute well.  Nothing is more disappointing then a fusion restaurants that tries to do everything and something from each continent.  Think cherrystone clams with breadcrumbs, lemon, parsley, and garlic.  Perfectly seared scallops are served with a very filling and comforting jambalaya.  One of the best fried chicken dishes in SF was served with mashed potato and gravy and corn.  And the most decadent toffee cake, which being heavy and super sweet, we were able to polish off entirely because it was that good.

The wine list has some good choices, and I really appreciated that they had a decent by the glass selection that included some for $7 or $8.

Service was professional, although a little on the slow side.  But I also saw our waiter manage at least 5 other tables, so we were understanding given the work.
author: Peter L.

description:
Town Hall is really overrated but I'll give it four stars based on the fact that it is an accessable restroom stop right off of the bridge and there is always parking.

I finally got to eat at Town Hall after months of not being able to get a reservation at a convenient dinner hour. Granted last night's reservation was for 8:30 (boo... us Californians eat early!), I was still excited and ready for my fried chicken fix.

Town Hall did not disappoint. The buttermilk fried chicken was really good. It was perfectly battered. Not too much and not too oily. It was crunchy on the outside and the poultry was juicy on the inside. The pieces were tiny but enough for a serving. It was a tad on the salty side but when you just want to taste something satisfyingly unhealthy, it's really good. I coulda licked those bones clean, but alas- we were in public, worse yet a fine dining establishment in SF.

The chicken was served with yukon gold mashed potatoes and brussel sprouts. Very good sides. Very comforting and a nice precursor to Thanksgiving. I can't wait for more of this. Overall, I would have to say Chez Panisse has the best buttermilk fried chicken, but Town Hall makes a nice second. 

For dessert, the only thing that caught my eye was the pear cherry crisp with ginger ice cream. But did I get it? No! I'm embracing the life of a minimalist. No appetizers and no more dessert. No need for all those excess calories or pretending I have an dispensable salary. I was full enough on the main course. Quite content actually.

My friend had the duck and it was smothered with gravy. It reminded me of the mole sauce at Colibri. I'd like to go back to Colibri. She ate half of her meal and asked for the rest to be boxed up. Later in the car, way up on California Street, she had realized Town Hall never gave her her left overs. 

As for last touches, instead of the lame black bill fold emblazoned with Amex logos, Town Halls serves the check in between old books. How cute! How cool! The title of the book was "In Need of Change." How fitting for me. The dinner reminded me of a lot of things past and how much I need to go forward. I even shed a few tears. Good-bye Town Hall, good-bye SF, I'm going take a bite out of the Big Apple for dessert.

-This review is dedicated to Lorraine D for being such a gracious host.-
author: Rachel A.

description:
I've been here twice for work-related functions, once at the main restaurant, once in the upstairs private room.

The service at Town Hall is flawless, 5 stars for that.
The food is good, ingredients are fresh, but doesn't completely blow my mind in that "oh, I've got to have XYZ dish at this restaurant again and again".  A pretty complete wine list and good variety of beer are mandatory for a restaurant of this caliber.

Prices are on the higher side, and I honestly don't know that the ambience justifies coming here for a special occasion when you could go somewhere "nicer" for around the same prices.  

So overall, a positive experience, but I'm not sure if I'd make a special trip here on my own dime.
author: dan s.

description:
What I had there: 
Duck Leg Confit
Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Crème
Mrs. Palmer (drink)
Coffee and Doughnuts
Some S'mores Dessert

Duck Leg Confit was very delicious, but it's a small portion for its price. The best dessert there was butterscotch and chocolate pot de crème. Everything else was normal. I liked this place I guess. It's pricey, but I didn't have to pay :).
author: Vera W.

description:
A recent dine on a Monday evening turned up that, in fact, Town Hall is not always packed.  But it's easy to see why it would be.  The menu is superbly planned, the staff is wonderful (aside from the fellow who bid us "good afternoon" at 10:00 p.m.).

Oysters were wonderful and the server recommended a fantastic pinot grigio.  She did not steer me wrong.

Veal meatballs were OK.  The green peppercorn sauce wasn't as exciting as I'd hoped.  The salmon got a thumbs up from a fellow diner (even though I think she was more excited about the quinoa that came with it - ha), and the ribs were received enthusiastically.  

The warmed jalapeño cornbread side dish isn't different from the corn muffin in terms of content, just presentation (or at least not that we could tell) - the side dish comes in 'fingers,' the muffin as, well, a muffin.  

The trek to the bathrooms is something else, but if that's my only complaint about Town Hall, so be it.  This would be a place I'd return to.
author: Evan G.

description: Went here late after a Giants game. Staff was great and our waiter was a true foodie. Happy to make recommendations and they were all spot on. We had BBQ Shrimp and Veal Meatballs for our appetizers and Buttermilk Fried Chicken for our main. Everything was crazy good. The plates leaving the kitchen all looked great. Our dessert was  butterscotch & chocolate cream de pot, so so good. We are going to make this place a regular and explore this menu.
author: Mike P.

description: Delicious dinner here celebrating my kid's birthday.  Buttermilk biscuits were melt in your mouth.  Loved the fried chicken, and the ribs were good too.  My husband is a big bourbon drinker, so he was happy with the extensive Bourbon choices.  The waiter was excellent, and made my daughter's birthday special with a mini dessert and candle.
author: Marie B.

description:
I came here around lunch time 12:15pm with coworkers. Made a last minute reservation a few hours prior and was lucky to get a table. We requested outside seating but it wasn't guaranteed and unfortunately it was full when we got there so we had to sit inside. It was a really nice day in the city (high 70's) but I sat under a vent so I got really cold half way thru the meal.

We got seated right away but the service was kind of slow. Our waiter didn't come over very often. The bus boys came over more to fill our water and take plates more than the waiter. She was super nice but didn't come check too much. I know it was lunch time but it wasnt crazy busy but it took us like 40 mins to get our food.

Only reason Town Hall gets a 4 is because i loved the food! My friend and I ordered the pastrami reuben and seafood etoufee (like gumbo) to share. Both were really delicious and the flavors were really spot on. The etoufee was kind of a small portion but for lunch I guess you don;t want to overeat anyway but it was delicious.

We also ordered the coffee and donuts and hazelnut chocolate tart. they were good. i like the donuts more than the tart.

for those arnold palmer fans, they have a mrs palmer drink. was kind of sweet but very mellow.

i would definitely go again, maybe for dinner. i want to try their fried chicken. it seems they have a lot of dishes with a southern twist to it.
author: Pauline H.

description:
I love Town Hall.  I haven't been in a while, but I always used to send people there (or take them there) when in SF.  It can get a little crowded, so make a reservation.  I never had anything bad there or really anything that was not excellent.  

An excellent pick for both business or a nice date.
author: Amber S.

description:
This is my and my husband's favorite restaurant!  We love it so much that we decided to rent it out and have our wedding reception here!!!  The food, drinks, staff, service, ambiance were all outstanding--better than we would have ever expected or even imagined.  Each of our guests was able to try our ALL-TIME favorite fried chicken (my holy grail search is finally over!!!); we got so many compliments on that dish alone with people saying it was the "best chicken [they] have ever tasted."  It really is the perfect restaurant and we couldn't be happier that we threw the biggest party of our lives at Town Hall.  

P.S.  Mardi Gras at Town Hall is ridiculously fun and they serve all their famous Southern dishes (gumbo, etoufee, fried chicken of course, etc)...such a great deal!  Can't wait to get some summertime BBQ grub now.  Gotta love how Town Hall keeps it fresh.
author: Marina S.

description:
Overall, I was not impressed with Town Hall. Some of the items are just mediocre for the price you are paying. The pork enchiladas, chicken fried pork cutlet, and tuna were underwhelming, small-portioned, and way overpriced. The only standout dish that had any real flavor was the Shrimp and Grits and Corn Bread. The Pot de Creme was also pretty good. 

Service was friendly, and they certainly have some character, but definitely a hit or miss for me. I won't be running back here any time soon.
author: Donna H.

description: Great place for lunch - you can have a normal voice conversation without having to yell or speak so close to the other person.  Nice menu options - had their chicken salad sandwich with bacon - very tasty.  Another person had their salmon which was prepared well enough served with veggies, etc.  The restaurant's atmosphere is great too.  Service is timely enough to get you out within an hour.  PS: they don't have the fried chicken sandwich for lunch during the week.
author: Ketan D.

description:
Started w/ Faith's warm ham and cheese toast w/ jalapeno cream and poached egg... AMAZING! A perfect app to share w/ a few others as it is very rich and creamy. 

Also started w/ the roasted veal meatballs which were served on mashed potatoes and had a pan gravy drizzled on top...also very good, but a bit on the dry side. I won't let this dish take away a star though.

Each of us had fish for dinner. I had the blackened salmon, which was very very good, and had a lovely bbq flavor to it (less cajun than I expected). One of us had the trout, another had the halibut. All three of us had clean plates at the end of the meal, and that was after eating apps. We were stuffed.

Moved on to sharing the butterscotch pot de creme and the smores tart. Oh wow, sooooo good. Both were delish, but the pot de creme was amazingly good. One of the best desserts I've had in a long time, and a very big portion so it is perfect for sharing.

You should go NOW because the menu is out of this world. 
It is a pretty expensive restaurant. We ended up spending about $85/person including drinks. I guess it is not horrible by SF standards though. I didn't mind the noise too much- it was a lively restaurant and has a wonderful ambiance, decor, and home-like feel. Lots of wood, natural light, and a bustling atmosphere.
author: Sonal B.

description: Fresh approaches to Southern New Orleans style dishes. The buttermilk fried chicken was perfectly cooked and juicy. The fried batter was crunchy and light. Served with corn bread and brussels sprouts, both excellent. The seafood was equally delightful. From the fresh oysters to the seared scallops with roasted butternut squash and pumpkin vinaigrette, all awesome. Comforting classic flavors and ingredients. Maybe a bit on the steep side when it came to the check, considering the simplicity of the menu. But worth the try.
author: Clarke W.

description:
Man, I have not been here in some time but glad to return...

Went with friends ( party of five ) great because we had lots mMm

Apps:

Fried Oysters w/ bacon - Great

Egg, Ham, and cheese - fantastic

Biscuits,homemade pepper jelly - superb

Main:

Shared St. Loius ribs, Fried Chicken, Fish, And Flank Steak ... Everything was great ... my ribs where the stand out for me though. paired with the corn break and slaw it just plain hit the spot ... oh and the blood orange soda they make is really refreshing as well. 

Dessert: 

Donuts with blue bottle coffee ice cream : yes yes yes!!! loved it

Butterscotch pudding thing : also another yes!

Pb butter coco cake thing : meh ... 

All in all not that much has to be said about this place that already has not been said ... the decor is cool .. kinda  old, rich, cabin like, southern plantation feel ....  very comfy nice lighting ...

I enjoyed my time will be back.. :)
author: Anthony S.

description:
I have been very happy with everything I have tried here.

Definite highlights:
- Tuna Tartare and fried green tomatoes(spicy, flavorful, unique; I normally skip tuna tartare but this one is absolutely worth it!)
- Ribs (UNBELIEVABLY GOOD!)
- "Coffee and Donuts" - I tried this on my first visit and now I can't not have it! Warm homemade donuts and that mysteriously delicious chicory topping.
author: Orla Rose B.

description:
Bring ear muffs.  Too often my meals are ruined by a place being too noisy.  I cant even remember anything about the food.

Seriously - Everything was great.  The quality of the food and the ambiance was outstanding.  The noise was a huge distraction.  Try and go there when there are not a lot of big groups dining with you.
author: Duanne G.

description:
We went to Town Hall for dinner on a Thursday night, and it was packed. Luckily we made reservations, so we were able to get seated when we got there.

Appetizers:
Buttermilk Biscuits, Johnston family ham, red pepper jelly, butter - comes with 3 small biscuits. Really yummy!
Piquillo peppers, dungeness crab-bienville stuffing, vermouth lobster cream - comes wirth 3 peppers, really yummy too!!!

Main courses:
Buttermilk fried chicken, anson mill grits, collard greens, bacon gravy - Chicken was awesome! Grits were creamy and yummy. We weren't a fan of the collard greens, but I don't think we like them in general.
Wagyu beef short rib and grilled hanger steak, broccoli rabi, tater tots, anchor steam beer sauce - short rib was like BUTTER!!! so good! The hanger steak had great flavor, but was kinda tough. Tater tots were okay.

Dessert:
Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de creme - fancy pudding. Probably good for 3 people to share.

Service was great. The only complaints we had was that it was pretty loud in there, and you are sitting really close to the party/table next to you.
author: Joanne W.

description: We had a birthday celebration here, and everything was on point; from cocktails to food to service. Our table had: fried chicken, ribs, pan seared duck, trout, an an array of appetizers. The Boston Cream Pie and Pot du Creme were superb, and I judge deserts with a critical eye (having been a pastry chef). I'd go as far as to say that the pie was both inspiring and memorable.
author: E B.

description:
I have never met a meal here I didnt like. I have been here at least ten different times and not once have I ever been dissapointed. 

The decor is soothing, the food is amazing, the drinks are exactly what you need after a long day at the office, and they throw very fun parties  (Hint Hint: Mardi Gras) 

One down side: It can get REALLY loud in the restaurant. The place is brick and wood and sound doesnt tend to get absorbed  in that type environment...On a nice day or night, sit outside.

Here is the list of my favorites: These are usually on the menu however they do tend to change it up depending on the season:
Faiths warm ham and cheese toast (OMG)
The Fried Chicken
Mac and Cheese
Jambalaya
Red Beans and Rice


Wonderful wine list
Knowledgeable and friendly staff
Does not deliver, Does not do take out

Enjoy!
author: Sandra M.

description:
I've been wanting to try Town Hall for ages. It was Zac's birthday and since the restaurant we wanted to go to was closed, we swung by Town Hall on a whim. It was 9:30 on a Sunday and they closed at 10, luckily they seated us. We had Hillary as our server and she was amazing. Outstanding service. She was attentive, polite, suggestive- but not pushy. All of her suggestions were spot on and she listened to what we wanted. She made Zac's birthday special and was one of the best servers we have ever encountered. Please give her a raise or something! If you go to Town Hall ask for Hillary as your server! 

The food was awesome. We had the shrimp, petrale sole, hangar steak and short ribs, smoked andouille jambalay, and for dessert the donuts with blue bottle ice cream and chicory streusel. I loved Town Hall and loved the service we received from Hillary. She gave us recommendations for next time and let us pick her brain for other restaurants to try in the city. She's amazing. I would definitely recommend Town Hall for anyone looking for a special experience or some good Southern food. The Kentucky Gun was also delicious. I will be back very soon!
author: Kristy H.

description:
A reunion does not necessarily have to end in the same place where it started (see review below) but the libations you indulged from the beginning must continue on to the next place... Since we often visited Town Hall for lunch and had never tried it for a light fare dinner- 
we decided to give it a go.
 
What a great evening venture it was- completely intimate and dare I say romantic with soft lit lighting from the rustic chandeliers and twinkling bougie candles on all the tables-- inviting, not as noisy from the hustle and bustle of the working patrons during the day.  
 
 
Roasted Veal Meatballs, potato puree with peppercorn sauce
Delicious, picant and juicy 
 
BBQ Gulf shrimp with Worcestershire sauce with garlic toast- the sauce was outstanding- tasted like adobo and bbq sauce all in one with lots of garlic...

Dayboat Scallops- Sweet buttery fresh briny taste with nice caramel sear ....sigh
 
Archery Summit, Premier Cuvee, Willamette Valley, Oregon, 2007

There's no doubt here that some of the best Pinots come from this area of Oregon.  Lots of berries- black ripe cherries and strawberries, hints of luscious exotic spices with a long silky finish.  Memorable wine memorable evening.
 
PS- As always the staff provided outstanding service.  Attention to detail and consistency is why I think we love this place.
author: Arissa C.

description:
So this restaurant is usually a solid place to eat.....and their legendary "Pot de Creme" dessert stands out and has lasted as a memory for a few years......so it must be good if I seem to remember it!

This time around I had the skirt steak and tater tots, pretty cool and tasty. One of our friends however ended up with a not-so-great oyster and boy did we all know about it.....you could likely smell it a mile away.
