Guess that statistically can happen......so luckily the "BLUE BOTTLE COFFEE ICE CREAM" made us forget about that for a second. They had great dessert wine also......but they get a B+ for bringing some ice cream my way that I haven't seen anywhere else in the city!
author: Lee M.

description:
This place is the bomb dot com.

I was in SF for work and we made 8:15 p.m. reservations for a Tuesday night. We got there at about 8 and it was packed. The place is pretty big - there is an upstairs and a downstairs dining area. The ambience is pretty nice - lots of oak wood and trendy accents. We waited at the bar for them to get our table ready and I ordered the tastiest drink. It's called the Life of Riley, which consists of Skyy vodka, muddled watermelon & basil, and a bunch of other yummy goodness served up with sugar on the rim of the martini glass. It was delicious!!!

When we were seated about 15 minutes later, we ordered a mix of their oysters on the halfshell. Would have been a good appetizer had the waitress not forgotten to put in the order. She was honest about it though and told us that she had completely forgotten and she was going to bring them to us on the house. Score! Waitress- you are forgiven. Oysters were fresh and worth the wait.

For my main course I ordered the Buttermilk Fried Chicken. What. The. Eff. This was so freaking amazing. The skin was so crispy, not greasy like a lot of the other fried chicken dishes I've had. The chicken was very tender as well. I can't speak to the sides besides I ate all 3 pieces of chicken first and could only manage a small taste of the sides because the portion size of the chicken was pretty large and by that time I thought I had to be wheeled out of the restaurant because I was so full. I ain't a small girl, either.

I would definitely come back to this place next time I'm in the bay area. I would order the fried chicken again too. Mmm.
author: Carol L.

description:
3.5 stars

I came to Town Hall for a work celebratory lunch so we had the private dining room upstairs.  It was a mostly predetermined menu with 2 options each for the appetizer (tuna tartare or heirloom tomato w/ feta salad), entree (salmon or chicken paillard salad), and dessert (butterscotch/chocolate pot de creme or smores tart).

The verdict:
Tuna tartare - came w/ lightly fried green tomatoes, green onion tabasco vinaigrette.  I thought this was prepared quite well, with just a hint of kick in the tartare itself.

Salmon - It's not on the main lunch menu (i checked the website) but it came with a fruit-oriented sauce, over a white corn macque choux and okra.  I think this was favored over salmon, and it was delicious!  

Chicken Paillard Salad - tasty, but a salad is a salad.  It was a huge mountain of lettuce studded with big thick chunks of bacon (yum!), good ripe avocado cubes, and a mustard-based vinaigrette.  

Pot de creme - pretty much awesome in a jar.  The toffee was really the highlight, delicious and not to sweet.  I couldn't taste too much butterscotch, but it might be because the chocolate portion was pretty rich (and so good).

Smores Tart - this is definitely for someone who loves chocolate.  It's really rich, as it's a wedge of essentially solid mostly bittersweet chocolate with a graham cracker crust and salted caramel marshmellow on top.  Most people that ordered it couldn't finish the chocolate part but seemed to enjoy the marshmellow and the crust.

The service was fine, though the server's quick movements when pouring water ended up in some water/ice getting flung onto my appetizer plate.  She didn't notice and I didn't complain since I was pretty much done with the app, but I think she did do some water spillage from not waiting to finish pouring before moving her arm away on other occasions.

The food is good but the options seemed pretty plain and without too much inventiveness.  Granted, as I said it was a fixed menu so I didn't get to see the full range of the kitchen's skills.  That said, they used really good quality ingredients and the plates were executed very well.  

I'll just have to come back again to get the full Town Hall experience!
author: Naoko M.

description:
There are a couple things that kindof turned me off from our meal and has dropped it from 4 stars to 3.  

Since the last time I've eaten here, I've had a chance to eat at a lot of great restaurants in the city.  The past year has seen an explosion of restaurants that are of exceptional quality and value, and value is the key here.  

A couple of thoughts:
1) The BBQ shrimp appetizer was served with the shrimp uncooked.  Yes, uncooked.  You did read that right.  They actually served the appetizer with the shrimp uncooked.  I know a slight oversight, especially with all of the delicious sauce served on top of it.  But, what the hell!??  The sauce they serve it in is a beautifully tastying worcestershire and butter and its dark.  Its lathers the shrimp and yes, at times, it can be hard to tell if the shrimp is cooked or not.  But obviously someone has prepared this so many times that they didn't even realize it.  Who is handling this stuff?  None of shrimp was warm.  Quite the egregious oversight.  Yikes.

2) Prices for appetizers and prices in general are a little high for the portion sizes.  The food here has a certain American comfort feel to it.  Its definitely creole and Louisiana flavoring, and this is unique in this city.  Despite this however, it just comes off as a little overpriced for what you are getting.  The cheapest item on the menu is still the delicious fried chicken, and that is 23 dollars.  Not too bad, but everything else is closer to 30. 

Chicken is still one of the best in the city.  

Dr. Louis drink is excellent....way too much ice though.  Had probably 5 sips and I was done.  Disappointing.  Went with the beer, and that was 6 dollars for a bottle.
author: Mark K.

description:
I can't remember everything I ate, but I remember I loved all of it.  Most of all, I had the pork main course and it blew me away. Loved it.  The waiter was also top-notch friendly and professional.

I didn't get to try the desserts (belly too full) but apparently they are great.
author: Chris G.

description: I love Town Hall. Since its inception they have come out with consistently good food that nourishes the soul. Yes, it may take years off your life but who wants to live forever with out gumbo? If you like upscale soul food and a boisterous atmosphere Town Hall is your place.
author: Andrea C.

description:
Ham / Cheese Toast YUMMM.
Good service, not great, but the food will forgive anythng.  The chicken is always the bomb and the biscuits, OH GOD, yum!  I really enjoy thier take on American fare.  So good.
author: Troy C.

description:
A friend of mine recommended this restaurant because I was having a guest from Tokyo.  The experience at this restaurant really reminded me how it is difficult to find a good restaurants like in New York and Tokyo in San Francisco.

I had butter lettuce salad with apple and walnut.  I was hoping to get a similar salad I had at the Chez Pannise.---a gem salad, indeed it was a gem salad, unlike other dished I had at Chez Pannise.(I cannot still believe Chez Panisse has one star. Do they deserve?)
Well back to TH, it was too heavy.. I felt like eating Cezar salad I have at one of the pizza place, La Val, near my school.  Reason?  Too much dressing.  I love butter lettuce because it crisp, but when it is soaked with blue cheese dressing too much, it just lose its freshness.  Big mistake, a huge mistake.  It need light dressing such as only olive oil and lemon, because if the salad is fresh enough, it is good enough,  dressing should not play the lead role, let the veges play!

I had Crab Ravioli with some fish, I do not remember.
One thing about how to cook fish... maybe because I am from Japan, where we cook very simple... You guys overdo fish too much...
I am not French, I do not want my fish to be swimming in butter or oil. I think what they should have done is to crisply grill with olive oil. so that the skin or the surface of the fish can have a good harmony of crispness and moisture.  Instead of that, my fish was swimming... in a white sauce... The Ravioli itself was good, but I wanted more. I only had two piece. I would rather have more raviolis than my fish swimming in butter.

For desert, I had chocolate crisp bar with peanut ice cream.  It was ok, nothing that would blow mind, though. 

Overall, I am very disappointed by the experience at TH.. Maybe I did not go there when they had dishes of my taste. But over all, I would never go back here, unless somebody pays for me.

Definitely overpriced for what you can get!
author: Ayako M.

description: Came here for a late midweek lunch. I had made reservations but didn't need the, as the place was nearly empty. Nice atmosphere. Delicious butter lettuce salad. Good bread & butter. My husband had the steamed mussels & clams - delicious, hearty but not too rich. I had the Reuben - huge, smoky, good, comes with delicious homemade potato chips. Attentive service. I'd return given the opportunity.
author: Katie E.

description:
The food rates at a 4 star. The highlights were the veal meatball appetizer, the Fried chicken and the butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme. The signature cocktails were very good as well.

The service on the other hand was a 1 star. Our waitress had an attitude and an overall sense that she had a better place to be than work and it showed. The guys delivering bread and water were cool though.
author: Cassandra C.

description: Very solid lunch place. Great for client meetings. Really pretty restaurant with character. The burger was really good.
author: Jim H.

description:
Food is great and service is amazing but the kitchen is crazy slow. Give yourself 2-3 hours for dinner and you'll be fine. 

Cornmeal crusted oysters are amazing
Tuna tartar is eh
Duck liver pate is good
Fried chicken is good. Milky instead of spicy. It's different but good.

I would come back but without planning anything after dinner.
author: Christopher L.

description:
Great Starters. The Main Course dishes are just OK. Skip the sides.
Therefore I'd recommend going for a list of starters to replace the need for the main courses. Family style works well.
The BBQ Gulf shrimp in a Garlic, herb and Worcestershire sauce is Amazing, incorporating strong flavors. The Tuna tartare and Veal meatballs are super good.
author: Raanan K.

description: If it wasn't for the location, not sure why any would bother. Bar service is efficeint although pretty unfriendly; drinks OK but very small and crowded bar area right by the door. Dinner staff miserable and pretensious. Have been twice and will not go again. Don't remember the meal as the attitude must havde stifled it.
author: Timothy S.

description:
I dropped in here for lunch with a friend of mine from Portland and had no problem getting a table on short notice. I was particularly pleased by the adorable self-promotional cards they have next to their entrance/bar area that we checked out while waiting for a table. See, this place has got one good creative marketer working for them. Instead of plain business cards laying out waiting for customers to grab as they leave through the front door they have recipe cards that do the same trick. On these cards, recipes for dishes such as Tuna Tartare, Roasted Veal Meatballs, and New Orleans BBQ Shrimp are printed. I really liked this idea for a restaurant calling card and its something that I can see myself keeping and sticking into a recipe file. Totally smart marketing on Town Hall's part.

As for the food - my friend and I both ordered the fish and chips and it was so so so good. The fries were just perfect - probably double fried and the fish was absolutely light and moist. The fish was almost too hard to pick up and dip in the tartar sauce, because it was so delicate. I considered that to be a sign that the battered piece of fish was high quality. 

I definitely I like this place and will try and go back when I have a good occasion to enjoy myself at lunch. On the frugal side, it's not a place I'd go everyday, but once in a while - definitely.
author: Laura G.

description: Great food and decor. I had not been to Town Hall since my first time about 4 years ago. It was well worth going again and occasionally as they change their menu based on the ingredients available. We had fried chicken with macaroni & cheese all around which was great. The tuna tartar on fried green tomatoes - nice spice to it. Will go there again and is a good go to spot to start a night out.
author: Raj P.

description:
I just came back from a delicious lunch with a dear friend, and am in such a fantastic mood that I feel I must share our lovely experience with my fellow Yelp!ers.

While the service can always be better, they were attentive enough (no warm fuzzies, more lie lukewarm 'thanks for coming in').  I was looking over the menu and focused on the jalapeno cream sauce that came with the ham and cheese toast. After the waiter described the dish a bit more (bread with thin ham slices, topped with a slow poached egg and then topped again with the sauce), I was sold. It didn't have a side, so we ordered the tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes as a starter.

The tuna/tomatoes were a pretty decent.  While I prefer a firmer tomato, the batter was lovely. The tuna was not overly dressed, which was nice because the actual fish flavor came through.

Our sandwiches came out, and instantly I fell in love.  I have always been a sucker for a good cream sauce, and this did not leave me wanting.  The jalapenos were quick fried with that same lovely batter as the fried green tomatoes, and the egg was done perfectly.  The bread was a bit crispy and required cutting with a knife, but all in all a fantastic dish.

To reward ourselves for picking such a great place, we shared the coffee and doughnuts...OMG. To die for. The chicory was the perfect complement to the coffee ice cream, and the doughnuts were just little fried flour balls of heaven.

I first learned about Town Hall on Check Please Bay Area, and have walked or driven by many many times.  I'm so glad that I finally was able to come in for a meal, and look forward to many more in the future.
author: Valerie V.

description:
I have been here twice. Each time the food has been really good but the service has been very poor. We had the same pushy waiter both times. He wasn't pleasant at all when we asked questions about the menu, and was really kind of a pompous jerk.

On my most recent visit, WE HAD A RESERVATION AND WAITED 50 MINUTES TO BE SEATED!!! I don't care how good your fried chicken is, that is absolutely absurd. No restaurant, especially in SF, can afford to rest its reputation on its food alone. Probably won't go there a third time.
author: Harry A.

description:
this type of restaurant is right up my alley...the red brick decor, the perfectly dimmed lighting, the even hum of conversations, and properly prepared dishes.

i very rarely make my way to san francisco, as i no longer live in california, but i wouldn't hesitate to recommend town hall to any of my other friends who may be passing by the embarcadero looking for a nice place to sit down with a glass of wine or cocktail and enjoy some fine american cuisine.
author: Andrew H.

description:
I went here under the auspicious warning that the food was great but the service was terrible, but my sister wanted to go here for her birthday so we obliged.

I enjoyed every single aspect of this place. Absolutely wonderful experience.

The food was fantastic from start to finish. I started with the frog's legs which were very good. I had never had frog's legs before so I wasn't sure what to expect, but they turned out to be tasty and the risotto that they were presented on top of was duly excellent.

I went for duck as I often do when restaurants offer it. This was easily the second best duck I have EVER had. Only Spruce has impressed me more with duck, and I think they win because they used the breast as opposed to the legs (as Town Hall does), so there were no bones to contend with. The flavor was amazing. 

I also sampled some of the fried chicken which was a tad uninspiring, but nevertheless pretty good. I suppose any other meat after that duck was going to come up short.

Dessert was pot de la creme which was epically good. I feared it would be too rich but it was nicely balanced and ever so delicate. Simply put: awesome.

I want to give an extra special shout to our server Hillary. We were a party of 7 and she treated us with top notch attention and friendliness. She knew the food, she knew the wine, and she left us wanting for nothing. So the warning about service turned out to be false for us, because this was much better than I've experienced at super premium eateries.

One complaint: as others have mentioned, it is a tad noisy in their. Like slightly too noisy.

5 stars. What more can I say? Eat here!
author: Stephen R.

description:
It was Saturday night and packed. Fortunately, my wife and I had reservations and were greeted and seated immediately: a plus. Water, bread and a menu were brought to our table as we sat down: a plus. Our waiter, Christian, was friendly and attentive without being overbearing. He gave us a really good tip: On busy nights it is a good idea to order the entree and starters at the same time otherwise, there could be a long wait between courses. 
To start, we ordered the fried oysters floating on a green sauce (I think it was parsley) placed in the shell. A nice presentation and delicious, even without the green sauce, which was tasteless. Another appetizer we had was the muffins and prosciutto presented with a unique peppery jam. I had my doubts but the combination and quality of ingredients worked really well together. 
We didn't wait long for the second course (Thank you, Christian) For entrees, we ordered the signature dish of fried chicken with mashed potatoes and roasted Brussels sprouts. A yelp reviewer called it the best fried chicken in the city. It was really good - crispy skin and juicy interior - but a couple of places in Oakland would give it pretty good run for its money. 
I ordered the pork ribs cooked Memphis-style that was accompanied by a killer sweet sauce, fried cornbread and roasted string beans. I loved it. Six meaty ribs with a spicy dry rub dipped that was enhanced by the BBQ sauce. It was really, really good but judging BBQ is so subjective because of the different sauces and methods of cooking.
I was surprised that by late Saturday they had run out of a couple of desserts but the chocolate and butterscotch pudding topped with chocolate and butterscotch brittle was one of the best desserts I've ever had. Needless to say, it was eagerly consumed.
The beer selection was adequate and complemented the dishes we ordered. (I'm not sure wine would stand up to the spicy nature of the food.) 
On the negative side -- and I'm being really picky here -- down-home southern food and upscale seem to me to be a contradiction in terms. I'm talking about peasant food - ribs and fried chicken - that should be eaten with the fingers not daintily cut with knife and fork, which was being done by most of the restaurant's clientele. I'm not a snob or anti-snob or a pinky-in-the-air type of guy. I know that's more a reflection of me and not Town Hall's customers but at the very least, a wet towelette or wet-wipe should have been offered after those mouthwatering ribs. 
The other major negative was the noise level which was at least 5 bells. I thought I was at a Giants game it was so loud. Would I go back? Definitely - in spite of the overly mannered clientele and the feeling of sitting in the ballpark bleachers there are some interesting dishes I'd love to try. I love the casual dress and down home food. Prices were reasonable for the quality of food and ambiance. A good place to go to if you prefer to avoid the tuxedoed hoity-toity atmosphere some people seek for a night on the town.
author: Ed D.

description:
Meh...I'm not particularly impressed or ecstatic about this place, especially considering the prices.  It's too bad that there are a few factors that can mess up a good thing... 

We came here as a group of 8 for for dinner and while I liked the ambiance and almost old-school industrial feel, there were several key points that were lacking.  Service was slow, even when they knew about our time constraints.  Not that the food took awhile, it was the nice waitress that took awhile to take our orders.  Another lacking quality was their drinks.  Their sweet tea "something something" was not good.  I guess it was supposed to taste like peach?  No.  I rarely EVER return drinks, but this one, I had to.  As a replacement, I took the safe route and got a beer.  Can't go wrong with that...  

My dishes were disappointing...The tuna tartar with fried green tomatos was okay...nothing spectacular.  I found myself trying to pawn it off onto other people because it was too much of a mediocre thing.  Of course, I had the bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin...The pork was oh so tender, but I would've liked the bacon to be more crispy, rather than baked with the pork.   

Fear not, not everything was under par.  The fried okra side was super yummy, not too fried, but perfectly crispy.  A highlight of dinner would definitely have to be the catfish.  It was tender, a bit charred on the outside and flavored to perfection.  Another highlight had to be the fried chicken.  It was crunchy and juicy on the inside, but a bit on the undercooked side near the bone.  The ribs were alright, although the BBQ sauce was sweet, tangy, spicy and delish. 

Overall, I could've said that it was a "Meh, I've experienced better" rating (because I HAVE experienced better at better prices)...but I feel I need to give it another shot.  There is a bacon brioche french toast dessert on the menu...pass that up?  Are you crazy?
author: Jennifer L.

description: I don't love it, but not too shabby. We had the oysters yum! I had the steak, it was massive and filling and the side potatoes were really good. My friend had the ribs, they look good but not great...I like the atmosphere and bar area a lot. We ended up getting a drink there. The bartender who was female was a little weird. My friend wanted to get her check separately...and she made a comment about not having to pay what she didn't drink. She didn't seem to understand what she meant. She was really friendly to the people sitting next to us, but was still a little strange...LOL!
author: K T.

description: We came here for a birthday dinner for me one Friday night.  We had the pulled pork sliders with a drink at happy hour while waiting for our early reservation time.  After we were seated, we had the buttermilk biscuits for an appetizer (which were good, but small!) and then the husband had the fried chicken, and I had the schnitzel - apparently new on their menu as of that night.  Both were fine, but we've had better elsewhere.  That pretty much sums up our experience at Town Hall - it was fine, but we've had better elsewhere.  There are a lot of restaurants in the city, and we'll be trying those.
author: Megan V.

description:
Don't really understand what the hype is about and don't think that I'd ever return.
Pros:
interesting building
service was attentive
Cons:
pricey, which would be okay if the food was good but it wasn't anything special
fried chicken - dry and too much batter; smashed potatoes - cold; collard greens - inedible (bitter taste)
trout - just okay
crispy okra - dry but sauce made up for it
jalapeno cornbread - not substantial/too thin to be "warm" and couldn't really taste the jalapenos
wine - too much of a markup
butterscotch & chocolate pot de creme - guess you have to like pudding
author: Marcia S.

description: I'm only posting about happy hour, I had the pulled pork sliders, which were yummy.  I did have a problem with the waiter, who didn't have much personality at all.  I originally asked for a house Cab, usually available at all bars.  He said they didn't have a house, but could recommend two others.  I didn't have my readers with me so he recommended one from Napa valley.  It was enjoyable, but when I got the bill and saw I paid $18 for it, I knew I had a problem.  How did we go from requesting house range to $18.  I then looked in the bar menu and saw there were many other options he could have suggested around $11 or $12.  He apologized at the very end, but I'll just find another place in the future.
author: Cheryl H.

description:
This place is a great for lunches in the financial district.  I came with some coworkers on a weekday and the place was extremely crowded, good sign! The menu was extremely hard to choose from, I really wanted the skirt steak but I ended up choosing the seafood chowder and the jambalaya.

Loved the seafood chowder- you know how restaurants normally skimp on the seafood and you end up with like 3 shrimp? It didn't happen here. It was filled with mussels and a bunch of different seafood-very hearty.  To be honest, after the bread (which was mediocre) and the soup I was already full.

My jambalaya was pretty good, I liked how they put okra on the top which gave it a nice touch.  We also ordered jalapeno cornbread to go with it.  I liked the spices- gave it a larger kick than normal.  I had about two bites of it before I called it quits because I was so full..
author: Rachel L.

description:
After mixing up my nights, Town Hall graciously worked us in on Wednesday night (our reservation was actually for Thursday night, but I had a brain fart and thought our res was for Wed night) Anyways, they were very nice and had a table ready for us in no time.

To start, we were all in the mood for a nice refreshing cocktail from their recommended cocktail list. Mom and I had the Dorothy Parker (think lemony martini) and my sister got The Fine Line (tequila concoction). All drinks were superb and definitely refreshing.

As an appetizer we ordered several of the oysters recommended by our very nice waiter as well as the sardines. We had mixed reviews on the sardines, Dad and I really liked the smokey flavor, sister was not sold. The oysters were very tasty and fresh. We also split an order of the roasted beet salad (SO GOOD) but it definitely could have been bigger, or used more greens, there were just a few measly pieces of mache lettucs with beets mixed in with one goat cheese croquette to be found. Great flavors just lacking in size.

As an entree we all stuck with fish dishes, I had the grilled catfish with rice and okra, Dad had the fried Buttermilk Chicken (one of their staple dishes), sister had the Grouper and mom had the Sole. Everything was delicious but the real winners were the side dishes!! On the side, we made a game time decision and ordered the smoked andouille sausage jambalaya (salivating as I reminisce over this dish) as well as the cheese grits (so smooth and creamy). For a family of southerners, we were thoroughly impressed with these two side dishes, dishes that are hard to find this well done outside of the south. Next time I go, I'm just going to get the beet salad and a side order of jambalaya and I'll be set! I ate more of the jambalaya than I did my entree, honestly... if you love spicy and you love jambalaya... this is it!! Whew, okay, I'll stop.

On to dessert, we split an order of the 'Coffee and Donuts' as well as the Butterscotch and Chocolate Pots de Creme. Honestly, I could've done without both, neither of them knocked my socks off. (I actually wanted to try the cheesecake, but being the nice host that I am, I let the other women in my fam pick the desserts). They weren't bad, but when you're going to partake in consuming extra calories in dessert, I want to be floored ;)

All in all, the staff and service was excellent, water glass was always full, waiter was full of great recommendations and was very attentive. Now go try to the jambalaya!
author: Emily S.

description:
I have been hinting to my bf for the last 9 months or so how I really, really want to try Town Hall out. So finally for our one year anniversary he finally took me there. Great meal. Great ambiance. We were lucky enough to have good weather the night we were there so we sat out on the patio. We probably lost some of the ambiance of the beautiful interior, but who can turn down sitting outside on a warm sf night?! 

Food- We had the veal meatballs to start. Melt in your mouth good. Great flavors. Then I had the Grilled Creek Stone Rib-eye. Cooked perfectly. Amazing sauce. Yummy potatoes. Good portions. 

Service- not so great. But we were out on the patio and the poor waiter had probably too many tables then he should have, so I'll give him a little slack.

Overall- Good food. Good menu. Good scene. Ok service. Little pricey. Will definitely go back!
author: Lauren S.

description:
I was expecting this place to be better for the prices they were charging.  i ordered the liberty duck and it really wasn't all that good.. the foie gras sauce was kind of weird tasting.  the duck leg was good, but it's nothing i can't get for a fraction of the price elsewhere.  

was originally gonna give it 2 stars, but then i added one because of their corn muffins (they ran outta cornbread) with a side of jalapeno jelly.  mmmm!
author: JUDY L.

description:
After a somewhat disappointing evening out the night before, I'd spent close to an hour on Yelp and Open Table, searching for the right spot for our family Valentine's dinner.  Our evening at Town Hall was nearly perfect.

I arrived first, was greeted immediately and checked in.  When I apologized for the rest of my party being a bit late, I was assured there was no hurry, and that I was welcome to sit at the bar until they arrived.  As I warmed the barstool, the informative bartender encouraged me to try new samples of things, and through her I discovered a new favorite - Old Tom gin.  When my family arrived, all smiles and joy, we were shown to our table.

When dining out as a family, we always take the early seating (5:45 in this case) so other diners can enjoy some adult-only time afterwards.  We never felt rushed by the waitstaff despite lingering longer than most of the other family tables.  For this reason I rate this restaurant "Good for Kids", but note that there is no kids menu, or crayons on the table tops.  It's not that kind of a place.  Nor should it be.  But if your kids are well behaved, and good eaters you can add this to your list of go-to spots.

Note: often the difference between a good and a bad rating simply depends on the waitperson one gets.  Surprisingly, I saw a textbook  example of a bad one on the payroll here.  Had he been assigned to our table, my rating would have been drastically different.  Luckily our server (John? Sean? - it is a bit loud inside the charming brick walls) was excellent - though enthusiastic and cheerful, he never crossed the point of appropriateness.  

And his guidance on the menu was honest and accurate.  Our 8 year-old daughter wanted the tuna tartare but was concerned the wasabi would make it too hot until we were assured that it could be toned down.  In fact, the waiter returned with the dish and news that the chef was so happy a kid had ordered this dish that he would more than gladly tone it down even further if she still found it too hot.

My wife's beef was tender and perfect in every way, as was our daughter's duck breast - she even ate every bite, which is sometimes rare at that age.  My pork medallions (wrapped in bacon) were perfectly done, moist and tender, and drizzled in a reduction sauce that featured an Asian five spice that paired beautifully with a 1994 Napa Meritage (Rubicon) that had aged perfectly.  Drink these now, if you find any!

Speaking of the wine, the Sommelier (who helped create flawless service by assisting in other roles as needed) offered to decant and filter the wine, as there was a fair amount of sediment.  He did this away from the table, likely due to the lack of aisle space, but had I been paying attention I'd have requested table-side decanting just to keep an eye on things.

We'll be back, and I encourage you to go soon!
author: Dave C.

description:
As with its political namesake, money buys influence at Town Hall. It's good food at a high price with a dash of pretension. The crowd is classic San Francisco - I walked in with a hipster sweatsuit top over jeans, and all the SF sportcoats looked at me like I just yelled, "What up fools, get me some ribs up in this piece!"

Which I didn't, but I did get the ribs. They came piled like Lincoln logs and hit the spot with what might be the first piece of cornbread I've ever enjoyed. My buddy got the fried chicken, which was maybe better than the ribs. We also had the calamari starter, which came laid out in three little squids stuffed with a mince and topped with a black bean sauce. All delicious. We also had the "doughnuts and coffee", which is sort of a cheeky dessert of fried dough squares with powdered sugar and coffee ice cream. 

And I must say, the service was great. One of those rare times the server gets it right at every point.
author: rob g.

description:
So I have to say I was somewhat annoyed when I went here for lunch yesterday. We waited 30+ minutes for our food (I think
 the kitchen may have lost our order)  but I have to keep their rating high as the manager knew they made a mistake and quickly did what he could to fix the situation. I respect that.

The food was really good. I ordered the seafood chowder with a side of fried okra. The chowder was really good but the Okra was fantastic. My friend had their house made chips... mmmm.. very good.

The server was very nice and apologetic, it was a little slow, especially when you're on an hour lunch. 

If you order the tacos, make sure they put two tortillas per tacos. My friend had that and the stuff was falling through the one tortilla they provided. He wasn't happy.

Their cupcakes and butterscotch pudding thing are delicious. I'd go back again just for those.
author: Analisa S.

description:
Had a work dinner there with 8 colleagues.  Overall, good and would happily go back.  Probably 3.5 stars if I could give it that.   

apps - fried oysters (good), meatballs (v. good), duck proscuitto (less than average)

dinner - I had the venison loin which was excellent.  Nice and tender, with lots of a flavor.  Portion was medium sized and good given all the other things we had ordered.  Also tried the fried chicken which lives up to the hype and the short rib which was very good as well.  

sides - fried okra (v. good), mac n cheese croquettes (less than average), cornbread (ok)

dessert - vutterscotch pot de creme - good but didn't knock my socks off, really more of a pudding.  Could have used a little saltiness which would have been yum.
author: matt o.

description:
Peppers with crab starter was delicious!

Ribs were half fat and half dried out. Bleh.
author: L B.

description: This spot holds some sentimental value to me, but despite that, I really love this place. I've never actually sat at one of their tables but their bar and communal table have always been an enjoyable place to have a fine meal. Always have enjoyed their tuna tartar and the butterscotch pudding.....
author: Janel A.

description:
Town hall is typically the type of restaurant you would go to when you are in search of fried chicken, ribs or fried okra...meaning you want some delicious and hearty comfort food.

Town hall's social atmosphere is a great restaurant to go with a group of friends and even as versatile of a venue to go on a date. 

The menu has a great range of small plates to share and entrees to feast on.
I most recently went to Town Hall for their mardis gras event and it was amazing!
All you can eat and drink and live entertainment!
Super fun and needless to say i left very full. 

By far, one of the best restaurants in San Francisco. 

A few final recommendations:
Fried chicken
Faith's warm toast
Tartar
BBQ shrimp
Pequillo peppers and the best server ever...
Hilary!
author: David D.

description: Absolutely LOVE this place. We've went here on New Years twice and other random occasions and its become one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. The service is awesome; the staff is friendly and the food comes out quick and hot! The ambiance is perfect. It's cozy with dim lighting, classy and fun all at the same time.  The food is the best part of course. I'd recommend any appetizer. The ham and cheese toasts and shrimp are my favorite. And of course every time I go, I get the friend chicken with a side of jalapeno cornbread. It's so good, I'd eat it every day. My favorite dessert is the pot de creme. It's the perfect ending.
author: Natalie O.

description:
I love dining and this is as good as it gets. Impeccable service, every dish has exquisite detail, perfect little touches like fresh peas and pea tendrils, tiny carrots carmelized along side a few savory mushrooms. My advice: come with at least three other people so you can try everything! The cornmeal fried oysters you might want for yourself though. To share: Faith's ham and cheese toast with poached egg and jalapeno cream (omg). Every salad is the best salad you've ever had. The rib eye (not always on the menu) will melt in your mouth. The butterscotch pudding is not to be missed. Although tonight they debuted a new dessert - a sort of playful take on a banana split: cheescake light as air with strawberries and dark chocolate and almond rocha crust. What?? I don't drink and I really appreciate a restaurant that takes care to craft a few non-alcoholic yummy bevs

It's a loud restaurant, which can either feel lively and festive or a bit overwhelming. I have a friend who is hard of hearing, so I would only come here very early with him.
author: Barbara P.

description:
Food was hit or miss.  Nothing special, but not bad.  The venison was well-prepared despite not being a quality cut.  The sauce could have had more flavor.

It's a fine place if you're working in the area and need to take a client out to dinner on the expense account, but I would not go out of my way to venture back in the off-hours to eat here.
author: Mike B.

description:
A friend and I went here for lunch. We had an OpenTable reservation & were seated immediately. Our server was slow to come, but when she did she apologized and spent time with us answering our questions and telling us if she really liked a dish, then she took our drink & food order. 

The drinks came right away, the food not so much. I think we were at the end of the lunch crush since the place was packed when we sat down. The kitchen must have been backed up with orders since it took more than 30 minutes before our food showed up. 

My friend had the ham & cheese sandwich with a poached egg and jalapeno cream. I was surprised how small it was for $13, but she really enjoyed it. Cheesy goodness. I had the blackened catfish tacos for $15. They (3 tacos) also had guacamole & a spicy aioli. Good. Dessert is what threw us into a state of bliss - Butterscotch & Chocolate pot de creme. So chocolaty, so butterscotchy, so smooth. The flavors just burst in your mouth. You have to try this, & it's huge, coming in a soup bowl & is easily shared by 2 or more people. 

Town Hall is a solid lunch spot with fairly easy metered street parking, though you will have to go out & feed the 1 hour meter at least once.
author: Barbara P.

description:
I've been hearing great things about this restaurant for awhile so I was excited to try it.  The atmosphere is great with wide open space and table spread through.  The downside is that restrooms are upstairs along with a private area for dining (which I was told holds up to 40 max).  

The service was ok.  We probably waited a good 15 minutes before we got our first drink and then another 15 before we ordered.  Other than that, the server was able to offer some good recommendations which we took advantage of.  For starters, we tried the jalepeno cornbread (so good I can't even tell you!) and the bbq shrimp.  Both were excellent and I would order again, although there were other things that sounded amazing as well.  For dinner we had the buttermilk fried chicken & the pork tenderloin.  Both were excellent!  You could not find one bite on either my boyfriend or my plate.  We loved the food, but one less star because of service.   Definitely a great place for groups or for people coming in from out of town.
author: Kim D.

description:
Overall, the food, service, and atmosphere were great. 

Minus 1 star for over-salting everything...

BBQ Shrimp app: Delicious sauce! I wanted to lick the plate, even though it would've been akin to a salt lick...

Scallops w/ Butternut Squash puree & brussel sprouts: perfection.

Fried Chicken: Good, not too greasy, but nothing special. I prefer the fried chickies at Blue Plate!

Butterscotch + Chocolate Pot de Creme: my favorite dish of the night! It is sinful and smooth...and huge! We weren't able to finish it, although I really really wanted to...

Service: Excellent
Atmosphere: loud, crowded, and energetic....love it!
author: Jeannie C.

description:
we came promptly for our 8:30pm reservation but still had to wait a while before they could seat us ... not sure why ... then we had to wait 15-20 minutes before our waitress came to greet us or give us water.  that definitely soured the experience a bit.  not sure why she didnt tend to us but i did notice she went to other tables who sat down at about the same time as us first and maybe twice before getting to us.  maybe we look young?  not sure.

the soup of the day which was parsnip and something else i cant remember was pretty good.  i liked it.  beet salad with goat cheese crouton also good.  i had the scallops and they had sand in them!  they tasted very good and were cooked perfectly.  but sand?  yuck!  by the end of the meal i was so full  that i had the hiccups.

bf ordered the ribeye which the waitress recommended.  of course the most expensive thing on the menu.  i wonder if wait staff training includes a session of "always recommend the [most expensive thing on the menu]"  that seems to be the trend.
author: claudia y.

description:
So the first time I came here, I went to their annual Mardi Gras party, the entire restaurant was transformed with mardi gras decor. Every level of the restaurant was open to the party, balloon and face painters were present, several bands had been staged to play throughout the night, and samba dancers danced indoors and outdoors. Several food booths were set up throughout the restaurant, so you could sample many of the different dishes. Some of the all you eat meals included: fried chicken, oysters, gumbo, etoufee, jalapeno corn bread, hurricanes, abita beer caipirinhas, and New Orleans style King Cake.
Not only was I impressed the first time I came here, but I always knew that I wanted to come back to see if the grub was really as good as I remembered it to be.
Second time coming here, with no reservations, and primetime (thursday at 7pm) they fit us in without any problems. 
And guess what? The second visit was just as good as the first time.!
We started out dinner with an appetizer of tuna tartare with cornmeal fried green tomatoes. Sooo good, the tartare reminded me of being back in Hawaii and having fresh poke.....ahhhh my mouth is watering as we speak.
My main course: bacon wrapped pork tenderloin, beans, grits and peach chutney....A M A Z I N G!!! Now I may be biased bc pork happens to be my favorite type of meat, but damn was this meal delicious..and I know that anything wrapped in bacon can not not be good, but seriously, this combo and was just so. The meat was cooked perfectly, moist and tasty. The grits were just tasty enough to really taste it with the meat and the peach chutney (which at first I was convinced was mango) was just sweet enough to go along great with the bacon. My gf had trout, spinach and shoestring potatoes. Her fish was light and accompanied my bacon wrapped pork perfectly! haha
Next time:....fried buttermilk chicken.!!
author: Jenn H.

description: This place consistently exceeds expectations and the only downside from my perspective is the noise level. The staff is modest which makes the experience great.
author: Bryce F.

description:
My mom and I were in the city and was planning to go some place else but couldn't go in, so a friend said to check this place out for the fried chicken. We go in with no problem on a Thurs evening.

Overall the atmosphere, decor and service were ok. Nothing spectacular, sort of a business crowd, so it was just ok.

For an appetizer we had the soup of the day which was a chowder and the Crispy Stuffed Zucchini Blossoms, they were both pretty good, the Zucchini was on the rich side so I didn't end up finishing them.

We both ordered the Buttermilk Fried Chicken. They gave us each 3 good sizes pieces of chicken, breast, thigh and leg. I have to say it was very good, very moist and rich as well, we didn't even finish half the plate! 

For dessert we had the Campfire S'mores Tart. This was soooo rich, but very yummy. Tasted just like a S'more but couldn't finish it either!

Again overall pretrty good, the food was very rich of what we had and couldn't finish any of it! I might go again if there is nothing else nearby.
author: Tara H.

description:
I have been here 3 times, 2 for lunch and once for dinner. I think I prefer the lunch experience. Have tried a lot from the menu and all the food is quite good, but in San Francisco that is fairly normal for a restaurant of this type. Their meat dishes seem more special than the fish, this last time for dinner we had tuna tartare and Monterey Sardines both were excellent,
dinner was duck confit ( way small portion), Pork tenderloin medallions (melt in your mouth good), grilled trout, & halibut good, but not standouts.
Their desserts were excellent on all counts Butterscotch and chocolate Pot de Creme was killer and the others we tried were outstanding. 

The service was very professional and the wine list well paired  for the food. They do have the total package, interior is well designed, contemporary space that gives a cosy welcome feeling like it's been around a while but does not overwhelm,  it's a fairly upscale crowd & prices are on the high side, average cost with some wine was around $ 80 per person incl tip.

Noise level is bearable, a lively vibe, not too rowdy and the interior absorbs some of the  din. It's the kind of place where you are not intimidated by the food or the servers, but everything kind of falls nicely into place and supports you enjoying the people you are with, rather than noticing everything around you.I'd recommend starting  first with a  lunch experience. 
 All in all, one of the better upper end but casual places to visit. Every city deserves to have a restaurant that hits so many of the right notes as Town Hall, but unfortunately many do not.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
Sept 2012
Context: we have been coming here for about four years mostly for lunch with several dinners as well. We have had such better experiences in the past that our expectations are petty high.  This was our anniversary dinner on a Saturday night at 7:30.
Atmosphere: town hall has an enclosed, heated patio, which was empty the night we were there, a bar area with a large communal table in the bar area, and then a cavernous eating area with some tables abutting the windows, looking out on a not very nice street, larger tables in the middle and then two tops against the wall. Decor is contemporary neutral with large, unusual light fixtures.  When we arrived, they were about half full with steady business all night.
Service: we were greeted promptly at the door, our reservation confirmed, the guy went to see if the table was ready and we were taken to our seat. To the extent that service can improve, remain neutral or subtract from a dinner experience, this was sadly in the later. This has not usually been our experience here, but from the greeter to our server to the water person, I don't think we saw one smile.  Our server was efficient and reliable but not much else. From my perspective, good waitstaff is adapt at tuning into the diners needs and responding to them. This server was simply doing her job competently if somewhat impatiently. A few minutes after we sat down she showed up asking "did we need advice on drinks?" which I was totally not ready for. We hadn't even had a chance to look at the menu, so we indicated not quite yet which seemed to irritate her and she went off.  The remainder of the night continued in that vein with repeated requests for when we're we going to order the next course, etc.
Drinks: we started with a glass of wine, a Barbara syrah mix recommended by the server. At no point did she ever suggest we try the wine, which I found unusual. In the past, if I ask what might go with a particular dish, the server will say a suggestion and then say, would you like a taste. She never did this and never once asked if we liked the wine either.  The wine was okay. She suggested it as a pairing for BBQ shrimp but it did not seem to go. I picked the seghesio zin for my next glass because I knew I liked it. This wine experience contributed to our disappointment because usually we come here for the wine. We like to have recommendations and try new wines. In the past, my favorite white wine glass came from town hall and a server's recommendation. I don't know if staff has changed or we just got a bad night.
Food: the BBQ shrimp and truffle risotto were stand out dishes. Both were wonderful and I wish we had stopped there. The BBQ shrimp has five or six large shrimp served on a piece of bread covered in an incredibly rich, luscious sauce that I would call more of a,Louisiana hot cream sauce then BBQ but I would have licked the plate of the generous portion of sauce if it weren't quite so rich. The risotto was also incredibly rich and generously portioned.
For our mains,  I asked if the ribs or catfish was richer. The server said definitely the ribs because, she said, the portion was huge. But, when I got the catfish, literally covered in pork belly, I couldn't imagine anything richer. It was blackened but did not have much flavor other than salty. The other main we got was the pacific salmon with eggplant on potatoes. It was almost tasteless, not a good salmon prep.
Dessert is always the butterscotch budino and it was as good as usual, but also rich.
Overall: big disappointment because of high expectations and because we know we can go elsewhere and get a much better experience. Felt like a wasted dinner out.
author: Vivek V.

description:
GOOD PLACE TO GO AFTER WORK IF YOU ARE ALREADY IN THE CITY  FOR A DRINK AND SOME LIGHT FOOD WITH CO-WORKERS/ FRIENDS.  NOT A PLACE TO GO IF YOU HAVE TO DRIVE. ALSO ON THE EXPENSIVE SIDE AND THE FOOD IS A BIT OVER SAUCED. 

Decided to go to Town Hall at the last minute after work to meet up with a friend for dinner.  The place was packed at 7:30 with afterwork diners.  The restaurant is very spacious with a covered outdoor seating area, which looked cozy.  Since my friend and I couldn't make reservations, we sat at the bar area, which isn't too bad.  

We weren't too hunger, so we ordered four appetizers to share - butter lettuce, soft shell crab, barbecue shrimp, and Piquillo peppers.  My favorite was actually the butter lettuce salad - the portion was generous and very flavorful.  I wasn't too keen about the rest of the dishes - too much sauce on everything.  

The best thing about the experience was probably the ambience.  The place has a lot of character - it's urban and upscale without the slick polish of places that are trying to hard to be trendy. There is an upstairs, private dining area as well.  The restroom area is a bit inconvenient for people dining downstairs since they are all upstairs.  Also, parking is a hassle if you are driving in since it is difficult to get street parking at night.  I used the parking lot on Howard and 1st, which cost me $20 dollars.  Also, the price is on the high end.  Four appetizers and two glasses of wine came out to be well over a hundred dollars (including tip).  

Overall, not a bad experience.  Glad I went, but probably will only go back if I'm already in the area without my car.
author: Chegi P.

description:
I've only been here twice for lunch, but both times the food was phenomenal.  The meatloaf is amazing and they have a great burger if you are willing to spend $15 for it.

The only knock I have for this place is that you pretty much need a reservation.  It would be nice to be able to drop in for lunch, but I guess that's just a reflection of how good the food is.

I'm looking forward to a dinner here.  After my lunch experiences I'm sure dinner will be even better
author: Ken B.

description:
Considering how Town Hall is positioned, it (barely) gets 2 stars. If pricing reflected the value, I'd give it 3. 

We were a party of 6 well traveled diners tonight. Everyone ordered drinks and apps, and main courses. We shared two desserts. Split the bill after adding a 20% tip (although the waitress was borderline pushy) and it came to $75 pp.  Pretty much what we expected to spend.  That said, we did expect to eat for that price.

Food-wise, Town Hall really fell short for our party. Particularly the Cajun seafood pot pie which two people ordered. Neither diner found much in the way of seafood in the meals. There were carrots and potatoes, and one pinky-sized piece of whitefish. Between the two meals there were no shrimp or scallops or crawdads. If there was any crab, it was a strand here or there -- most certainly not any discernible lumps.  You might get more satisfaction watching your $56 swirl down the toilet bowl.

On the plus side, the tuna tartare and fried green tomato app was fantastic, and I understand the butternut squash soup was fantastic!  

The veal meatballs and dates were nothing to write home about, and the desserts were okay. Don't order the scallop dinner if you have an appetite. The three scallop dinner (for $29) was not nearly enough food for the guy who ordered that entree. There was an artistic spec of vegetable something on his plate, but come on, spring for a carrot or two, folks.

We won't be going back, and suggest you keep looking.
author: Suzanne K.

description: Town Hall catered a private dining event for 25 people for a corporate event that  I was helping to plan. Our executives and guests were all so pleased with the entire event. It went off without a hitch thanks to the incredible organization and planning of Marissa (the event coordinator). They were so attentive to detail and made sure to get clarification on all of our preferences prior to the event:  the table orientation, the beverages we wanted to offer, the menu title created specifically for us...ect... Also, the service was 100% perfect thanks to Matt and Maritza.  They were so attentive and accommodated any special requests/questions and ensured that everyone was happy and comfortable.  I also need to add that what impressed me the integrity and ethics of this business. Apparently there was a small charge that was added in error to our bill the night of the event.  This was certainly not noticed by the event host who signed the bill and left.  Two days later, Marissa contacted us to let us know that they caught this mistake and that they corrected it by crediting the host's credit card with the appropriate amount. This is a breath of fresh air!  They could have easily said nothing and no one would have known, but the fact that they went out of their way to correct this speaks volumes about how trustworthy and honest this establishment and its' employees are.  Thank you so much, Town Hall, Marissa, Maritza and Matt!  We will absolutely plan future evens there.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
This review is for their lunch time BBQ during the week.

I LOVE it when summer time in SOMA rolls around 'cause that means it's BBQ time at Town Hall. A must have is the pulled pork sandwich. But buyer beware you'll have to run a few marathons to burn off all that yummy goodness but it's SO worth it. 

Other dishes I've has are the Fried chicken sandwich. I think it's quite tasty with the spicy slaw but I kind of wish they served the chicken hot. Though it's nothing that a microwave oven can't fix. 

They have a rotating special and today's was their steak sandwich. Usually it's quite tasty but for some reason today it tasted a bit bland. I should have gotten some BBQ sauce on the side to jazz up the flavors a bit. 

oohh and the best part of grabbing grub from Town Hall's BBQ are the chocolate chip cookies. They are SOOOO yummy and gooey.
author: She R. A.

description:
This was my first and fourth San Francisco restaurant experience. As such, the first encounter (went with some friends) was a total "WOW!", and I found myself thinking what a great place it was, how great was the food, etc. 

The second visit (I had already been to other places) was still a nice two thumbs up for the food (if I'd had three thumbs it would be a "three thumbs up"), but started noticing other details that went unnoticed on the first visit: our waiter had a bit of a snob attitude (i.e. my missus and I got the "how would you not have dessert" look). Anyway, I'm splitting hair here, the service was still alright... it's just that look that bothered me. 

This is the only reason why I didn't give the place the awaited 5-star rating. The food was still amazing, the portions were perfect (which is something I was gladly surprised... coming from Barcelona I found the US' version of a "portion" something we would use to feed 5 people for a week), and the atmosphere was great. Wine was a bit expensive (much more expensive than in Europe), but that seems to be a US thing and not necessarily something related to Town Hall. 

My top recommendation? The BBQ shrimp over a garlic herb toast with Worcestershire... in three words: A-MA-ZING!
author: Roberto B.

description:
I wish I could give this place more stars as it's only 3 blocks from my house but the last few times I have been here, the wait between courses was interminable.  At one meal, they even brought over fries to tide us over.  Guess they forgot to put in the order?  
The menu is an interesting mix of new takes on southern classics and some usual new-California fare.  It doesn't change often though and is somewhat limited.  I am sure I will drop in again but it's not my favorite place in the 'hood.

I think most people go for the bar and that is quite a happening scene, especially Thursdays after work.  They have some great cocktail combos on offer.
author: Maria T.

description:
Went here with my bf and his mom last week and it was amazing. We sat at the bar at first and had drinks while waiting for a table. I would probably recommend making a reservation. We went at like 8 on a random weekday and it was packed. 
For food:
BBQ Shrimp: the gravy/sauce used is the best!
Scallops: mmmmmmmm
Fried Chicken: if you like fried chicken this is what you should get

Everything was great. I will definitely be returning and trying other dishes!
author: Sara P.

description: Everything -- fried chicken, hangar steak, meatballs, tuna tartare, the ham, shrimp toast -- was as good as it gets.  Very helpful server and accommodating wait staff.  Could not recommend more.
author: Tom W.

description:
I was going through my reviews and was astonished that I haven't reviewed Town Hall. If you don't intend to read on, all you need to know that Town Hall is on my short list of favorite restaus in SF. 

If you're only going to order from one section of the menu, have one of each from the starters. You WILL NOT be disappointed. If you can only sample a few DEFINITELY go for the BBQ Gulf Shrimp with Worchestershire reduction, Piquillo Peppers, and buttermilk biscuits. 

In the main courses, I highly recommend the fried chicken and pork chop.

You can't go wrong here. With a good wine list, great service and reasonable prices, you get your money's worth here. And that's just something that's not common in San Francisco.
author: Douglas L.

description: Food was pretty good, just shared small plates with friends. Meatballs were amazing as was pot du creme for dessert. Cool place, pretty good food, not amazing though
author: Beth G.

description:
I came here for dinner last weekend. We came mainly because it was in the same area that we were meeting friends later. 
We we seated immediately and our server was great. He answered all of our questions and made great suggestions. We had the Trout and the halibut. Both were super delicious and not dry at all. 
For desser we had the french toast. You would think this would taste like breakfast but it came with a side of ice cream and it was soooo good!
Over all, the ambience and the service assures me that we will definately be back for more. :)
author: Adriana M.

description: This place was awesome! The food is super-calorie laden but in a good way - that sort of "I'm so full I can't have another bite....ok maybe one more." The atmosphere here is great too - very friendly and warm.
author: Laura B.

description:
Town Hall....yet another city favorite. 

A wonderful explosion of elegant country goodness! I can go on and on about my favorites but I strongly urge you to try EVERYTHING. Each dish is a well thought out little masterpiece of comfort food. Definitely make reservations, it seems to be an incredibly popular place.
author: Courtney C.

description:
Definitely worth a visit!  I came here last second because a reservation at another restaurant fell through, and I am happy it worked out the way it did.  Good feel, pretty basic decorations but suits the space, and the staff is friendly and professional. 
      We ordered a bunch of food, but the highlights are definitely the fried chicken, (as good as I have ever tasted) and the jalapeno corn bread.  Not the cheapest place ($250 with tip for two people, including a bunch of drinks) but Ill be stopping by this place again.
author: Matt C.

description:
I went here with 3 other friends for dinner.  I had tried to schedule a work team dinner here at a friend's suggestion, but booking out even 2 weeks in advance for a party of 10 + is very difficult.  Yet, for 3 individuals, it was not a problem at all.  The space is OPEN and the decor, definitely does remind me of a southern town hall meeting space.

The food is contemporary American comfort food.  Our table started off with a mixed blend of the oysters, which were fresh and delightful.  One friend ordered the Osso Bucco (melt in the mouth delicious).  I ordered the Fried Chicken, which was good, but I'm a hard sell b/c I will ALWAYS remember the fried chicken in the South where I grew up being succulent on the inside and crispy goodness on the outside.  This chicken was not anything to write home to mom about.  My friends ordered scallops, which were well seasoned and prepared.

My favorite was the osso bucco.  

With 3 glasses of wine and 1 iced tea and the 3 entrees with oysters, the cost with tax = 154.08.   

The service was SUPERB and ON POINT that night.

I've only been there once and that was last year in 2009, but I would go back again to check it out with a group.  Unfortunately, the acoustics of the space are conducive for table conversation.  It is very difficult to talk about the roar of the other tables.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
I have a friend who works across the street from Town Hall who has been raving about their new lunchtime BBQ, especially the fried chicken sandwich. Since I'm a fan of all things fried we decided to head down there this past Friday since we both had the day off. Unfortunately, Town Hall decided to take the day off as well - no BBQ for you! Since we were already there we decided to stay, bellying up to the bar for some lunch and a beer. 

My fish & chips were a fancy pants version, three pieces of fish cooked perfectly, sitting atop a mound of just average fries. The chicken enchiladas were pretty good, though probably not worth the $16 price tag.

Overall, we had an enjoyable lunch at Town Hall though I would need an expense account or sugar mama to eat here more often. As for the fried chicken sandwich, I'll have to make a special trip down here to give it a shot. Not to worry, it will be mine (strokes goatee while laughing maniacally)
author: phil h.

description:
HUH?! WHAT DID YOU SAY?! I CAN'T HEAR YOU!! ITS TOO LOUD IN HERE!!

 No seriously. It was effing loud in this bitch.

Anyway, back to my review. Holy mother of hell- I think I just had the best fried chicken ever! Oh my jeebus, that fried chicken was soooo mouth watering!  Each and every bite was very succulent and cooked to perfection. The breast meat was the best part. It was nice and juicy.  Oh ,and don't forget about the skin! Flavorful and crispy.  *Drools* I still can't get over how good it tasted. I bet they deep fried it in lard. 

My meal also came with mashed potatoes. OMG, it was sooo rich and creamy! I think I just ate a pound of frickin' butter. It was damn good.  I LOVED it!

We also ordered their jalapeno cornbread. I was expecting a huge portion or bread. When it came out, we got this warm iron mold with 7 bite sized pieces of cornbread. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Tyn-UqOTpVHtZAgrB0lWyQ?select=Nh6IrYoIL_mxWnvOQKtS5g My first reaction was OMG, THAT'S IT? But these bite sized pieces are packed with so much flavor. It was sooo cute! They were shaped as tiny pieces of corn!  I could probably eat one loaf of those. 

We also tried their jambalaya and fried mac n cheese. Delicious.  BTW, this place is VERY LOUD and crowded! Not a good place to take a date. Wait, I take that back. You can actually sit outside. They have heat lamps and its not as noisy. Oh, and our server was very helpful and nice. 

I forgot to mention this place is kind of expensive. Expect to pay over $20 for an entree. I believe my fried chicken dinner was around $22-$25. Damn, that some expensive ass chicken but definitely worth it.  I got to sample everyone's dish. Their dishes were not as spectacular as my fried chicken though. I'll be dreaming about that chicken tonight. 

I think my arteries are clogged from eating all that food. I feel like I need to go jogging right now. Eh. Forget jogging. Excuse me while I play with my Wii Fit. Gotta burn off all those calories ya know. =T
author: B B.

description:
My wife and I visited this place on 01/01/2011 for a late dinner and were very impressed.

The host/manager greeted us immediately at the door and asked if we had a reservation (we did.) We were seated immediately. There were a few empty tables and I believe some walk-ins arrived and were promptly seated, too. The community table at the front was packed.

Everything from top to bottom was spot on. Our waitress (Taylor) was very knowledgeable about the menu, and we had lots of questions. She actually UNrecommended something because of our particular tastes. Service was prompt and efficient without being overbearing or intrusive. Plates and silverware left and arrived at our table unnoticed. We did not want for anything.

I see a lot of people on Yelp complaining about 'bad' or 'slow' service, and I can understand that Americans (of which I am one) are bred to expect fast, discourteous service. If this is you, then by all means do not go to Town Hall. We were there for an hour and a half and were allowed to enjoy all facets of the meal at a pace more akin to an afternoon in the park, instead of a drive-through. I would not go here if you are in a hurry but this does not indicate 'bad' service. It was paced so that you could enjoy yourself, have some conversation, get some people watching done and have that dessert hit your table at just the right time.

The food was delicious, too. I had the ribs and they were grilled to perfection. The sauce on the side was good but unnecessary. My wife had a steak and it was way better than Epic Roasthouse. Those tater tots were ridiculous(ly delicious.) Also, try the house-made cranberry soda. Yum.

It was pouring rain outside on New Year's day and we didn't want to leave the warm comfort of this place, and we didn't feel under pressure to do so. The host/manager thanked us on our way out.

My wife and I are not, uh, 'classy' people and though there was a certain hipster vibe to the patronage, I felt like we were treated just like anyone else. Friendly and professional, even though I was just wearing a T-Shirt and flannel (a T-shirt that one of the bussers recognized and complimented me on.)

We loved our experience here and will certainly be back.

UPDATE: My wife and I have come back to Town Hall several times since the original review, and each time the experience has been perfect. The staff is well trained and professional, yet amicable. The food is always fabulous. This is our go to place for special nights out because there is no doubt you'll have a wonderful time.
author: Matt J.

description:
Town Hall is a good, reliable favorite. I've been here several times, though this is my first time for dinner. Everything was quite good, though I think Town Hall risks being overshadowed by other, newer restaurants in this price range and genre (e.g., Wayfare Tavern) if it does not mix things up a bit. 

Pros: 
- Quick seating, attentive service. Our reservation was at 5:30 on a Saturday, so anything else would have been inexcusable. But nonetheless, the service was good. And even during a busy lunch rush the service is usually pretty good. 
- The food is solid. I think everything I had was well-prepared. The croque madame (they call it something different) appetizer was actually really inventive and a bit decadent. The ribs were fall-off-the-bone good and the portion was HUGE. My friend ordered the excellent fried chicken (very flavorful, not greasy at all) which was also enormous.  Finishing three courses at these sizes will be a challenge. The crispy okra side is always a favorite. We didn't order dessert (even though we'd intended to) because we were full. 
- The waiter gave great alcohol recommendations for my friend who had a lot of things he liked and didn't like. I ordered a glass of zinfandel (the only one on the by-the-glass menu) and thought it was a really great representation of the varietal. I'm sad I didn't write down the label. 
- They were accommodating. We shared an appetizer, and the waiter suggested one suitable for that purpose. I hate cilantro, so the waiter asked the chef to prepare a lemon aioli along with the cilantro aioli. 
- The pricing is solid for the quality and the type of restaurant. 

Cons: 
- The food isn't the most inventive. Perhaps this is a niche they are filling, as not everyone is into the latest molecular gastronomy and having savory foams cover everything. I prefer a balance -- such as Range. Or even Wayfare Tavern. But the food is really solid, just not the most interesting thing in San Francisco. 
- The location isn't ideal for weekends, or even weeknights. Great for a business lunch or dinner, but I tend to stick with neighborhood places for dinner. Nothing they can change, but a consideration. Parking can be a pain. I'm not sure whether or not they have valet. 

Overall, a solid four stars. I'm a fan, though with a couple of reservations.
author: Tom P.

description:
We had a 9 pm reservation and was quite astonished how many people were still eating dinner.  Anyhow, we waited about 15 minutes so it didn't really take too long.  I had the baby back ribs.  It was difficult to eat but not too bad overall.  I still think the buttermilk chicken is the best in town

Definitely make reservations when you go.
author: Marilyn W.

description:
This review is based solely on the Butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme that we came to try because it was on the 7x7.com list of 50 sweets to eat in SF before you die (3rd item we tried from the list thus so far) but the ambiance of the place was nice too. 

The Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Creme was definitely the best out of the 3 items (refer to my reviews of Miette and Slanted Door) we tried on the list that day and would be the closest so far to dying for. 

The chocolate layer below the creme layer was a wonderful surprise and they're both so creamy and smooth. And of course the pieces of butterscotch that were on top of it gave it the perfect crunch factor. The overall taste and quality of this desert definitely rich and elegant and was just right for sharing between the 3 of us.
author: Mona Lisa M.

description: Nice homey atmosphere and decor. I like this place. The ribs were excellent... with practically enough for two! A little on the expensive side, particularly the wine. I will be back though.
author: Nicholas B.

description:
Definitely not as good as salt house their sister property
Decent wine list
Server outside on the patio was terrible. Unattentive, rude and completely uninterested. If the management is reading this - he is bald/shaved head.
wouldnt go back

update 12/2012
Well....I did go back thanks to a team dinner that I had no idea was being scheduled there. The service at the table was much better. Food was still very average but this guy at the bar was just the most clueless unattentive and down right uncaring person. For the fact that we had ordered over $80 in drinks in 10 minutes and were easily going to do another round - it is pathetic. This time I am definitely not going back and neither is any member on my team.
author: Neil B.

description:
A new favorite when I am in San Francisco. A reminder of my beloved Jack the Horse Tavern in Brooklyn Heights. (If you are a fan of Town Hall and find yourself in Brooklyn, look up JTH.)

Butter leaf lettuce salad and fried chicken were delicious -- and typically I have an aversion to poultry! I can't wait to return and try the rest of the menu. The duck entree may have to be next...
author: Claire A.

description:
I have eaten here several times and always found it to be a great experience. That ended abruptly on Saturday night. Unable to get a reservation, we opted (with regularity) to sit at the bar. T
Service was polite and professional by the bartender. That's where it went down hill.
Signature Lamb meatball dish was undercooked and tasteless. ZERO seasonings. Then we waited 40 minutes to get our entree; buttermilk fried chicken and a side order of Gumbo. Gumbo was ridiculously hot and again unseasoned. Chicken was mediocre at best and the 2 sides bland, luke-warm & unseasoned. 
For that kind of money this was a total disappointment. Spoke to the manager about it and she told me to contact her later instead of addressing it there and then. 
Too bad as this was a place I often looked forward to coming back to.
author: Jimmy K.

description: Visiting SF I tried the Town Hall and ate at the bar. The Tuna Tartare was great.  Spicy sashimi grade tuna with fried tomatoes. About 10 minutes after I finished my appetizer the bartender told me that two large parties had just ordered ahead of me so there would be a wait. He also told me my whiskey was on him. It took another twenty minutes to get my pork chop.  When I got my bill, they had comped both my drinks.  Very well received. Delays are sometimes unavoidable but I like being informed and am then ok with a wait.  The tuna was great, the pork chop was good. A bit expensive for a good meal. $55.
author: Stefan F.

description: Just a few words... St. Louis ribs!! Atmosphere is loud so don't bring your elderly grandparents but for the young ones, it's pure enjoyment.
author: Kendra S.

description:
I love this place. Great vibe, great location, and a menu that I would describe as sort of "new American upscale comfort food". 

You aren't likely to lose weight eating here (except that your wallet may get a lot lighter), but you'll have a delicious meal in a very lively, trendy setting, and enjoy an excellent wine selection as well.
author: Bret W.

description: It's fine.  Open Table lists it as "fit for foodies" - I disagree with that. When we walked in there were about five staff standing there, not one of whom acknowledged us.  It was one of those awkward moments when you wonder if you've come in through the wrong door and everyone is so confused by that that they just ignore, but alas that was not the situation.  It seems they merely felt it wasn't their job to welcome us, so they didn't. The food was average. The waitstaff was average.  The wait was almost an hour for our main course, with not even a half full house.   When we mentioned that we had theater tickets the waiter went a little overboard stepping up the pace.  Overall a fine place to go, but we were trying to make it an exceptionally special evening, and Town Hall is average at best.
author: Cori D.

description:
Came here to celebrate a Birthday and was pretty satisfied. Their appetizers are very delicious, we ordered a bit of everything, but the roasted veal meatballs were my favorite. 

We ordered:

-veal roasted meatball
-tuna tar tar
-crispy stuffed zuchini blossoms
-other things I don't remember

For dinner I had the:

wait for it...  Grilled bacon wrapped pork tenderloin

Can that sentence cause any more salivation? 

It was great - definitely pricey  but well worth the ambiance, great drinks, and tasty food.
author: Roxy G.

description:
Deceitful. Found overages totaling close to $100 on our bill. 

On 12/17/13, our team went to Town Hall for our Holiday Get Together. For a group of our size 13, I had to sign a contract with the date, time, amount of people, agree to pay a 20% gratuity that would be automatically added to our bill, and provide a credit card number. I emailed the completed contract back. I received an email confirming they had received my contract and were confirming my reservation; however, it was the wrong date and for 14 people. Later I received an email from another person confirming the date, time, and number of people and that it would be at the communal table. I thought " I guess they got their act together and must have noticed their error and were now confirming the correct information." No, the following week I get a phone call confirming my reservation but the lady rattles off the wrong date and wrong number of people so I asked who she was trying to reach, that she may be calling the wrong person. To my surprise, she said my name. So I told this lady, the information was incorrect and that I could resend (email) a copy of my signed contract with the details of my reservation.  All this time, we are still on the phone. She then says she received my contract and tells me she will correct the info and email me a confirmation. We are still on the line but when I receive her email, she has 14 people. I tell her my reservation is still incorrect. It's for 13 so she corrects it and we hang up.
If that wasn't enough drama, on the date of our get together, we place our orders and most of the food comes out except two orders of salmon. Those orders don't show up until almost everyone else is finished with their entrees. After all that waiting, one of the salmon orders comes out well done. It was supposed to be prepared medium rare. So that order has to be returned to the kitchen. While that's being done, three okra appetizers are being brought to our table.
