We say, " we did not order these, most of us are finished with our meal. The hostess says they are COMPLIMENTARY so we accept them. They were not COMPLIMENTARY. And when the returned salmon order is replaced, the salmon is too rare and the person did not bother eating it. The drama continues...
Being that we have a large group, it was hard for me to know what people ordered so I went ahead and paid the bill. However, the next day when I was reconciling the bill and found out what each person had ordered, I saw that we were charged for those three orders of supposedly complimentary okra. Price for the okra is supposed to be $6 per order. We were charged $36 for the 3. So besides charging us for something that was supposed to be free, they hit us with a double whammie. 3 X $6 = $18. On the receipt, it shows 3 okras for $36. You think that was bad enough.
In reviewing the receipt further, I found that we were charged twice for the two orders of salmon. Each order is $22. On one entry on the bill shows 2 salmon = $44 which is correct, but further down there is another entry for 1 salmon for $44. So here we are double charged again.
So $36 + $44 = $80 that we are overcharged. This is not even including the 20% gratuity which makes it almost $100 that we were overcharged. So I emailed Town Hall and told them I would be in that afternoon to have them credit my credit card with these overages. When I get there, they took off these overages no problem.  When I said this was unacceptable, the two ladies apologized and then offered to invite us back. So I asked if this was going to complimentary. I said they can't expect me to have everyone return and expect them to pay for everything and probably get overcharged again. There was dead silence. Then Marissa said she would speak to the manager about maybe sending us a gift card. Well, here it is Jan. 21, more than a month later and no word from the manager. Not even a formal apology.
Our food bill was $484 (with their overcharges) and our liquor bill was $638.40. A total of over $1,000. I guess they don't value their customers. They should have at least deducted the two salmon orders that came out so late. 
So BEWARE people. Be sure to review your receipt. When I asked how this could have happened, they blamed it on the computer. But someone has to key in the orders of okra and salmon that weren't supposed to be there and why is the amount so inflated on the incorrect items. 
A very dissatisfied customer, actually many dissatisfied customers since no one from our group will return. Poor customer service, deceitful, and not very organized with taking reservations.
author: Joanne B.

description:
The bread?  Good.
The food?  Good.
The service?  Terrible.

My friend and I went at 5:30 to avoid the major dinner rush, and the hostess told us that she couldn't seat us because all the waitstaff were in a staff meeting.  Really?  Who has a staff meeting at 5:30?

After we were seated, we each ordered an appetizer as our main course: eggs and ham toast for my friend, the tuna tartare for myself.  While we were waiting, a waiter brought us a salad.  We had no idea what to do with it, since we weren't sure if they were going to charge us for eating something that wasn't really ours.  When our waiter came by to bring us our food, he looked at our salads with an expression that read, "who the fuck brought you those?!" like it was our fault.  He then took away the salads without any explanation or apologies, plopped our food down and left.

The tuna tartare was wonderfully seasoned and delicious with the cornmeal-fried squash (I normally don't even like squash).  My friend's toast was very rich and probably heart-attack inducing if ingested to an extreme.

After we finished our dinner, there was still some bread left over in the basket, so I took another slice and buttered it up.  While I was chomping away on my bread, our waiter came by and cleared our plates very quickly and wordlessly, taking our bread basket (which still had about 5 slices), my bread plate and knife, and everything else on the table.

I sat in shock, because I still had my half-eaten buttered bread in my hand, hovering over my bread plate, which had just been snatched from under me.  What?!

Our waiter then swooped in and dropped dessert menus on our table.  After having our little girly chat about the drama in our lives, we decided to both have dessert: the chocolate and butterscotch pot de creme and the chocolate brownie.  Both were absolutely delicious - I may come back here just for dessert.

Overall, the price of this place just isn't worth it.  It's cute inside, but for a LOT of money, the service just wasn't up to par.  Thanks, but I'll take my money elsewhere, where I can probably get double the amount of food and more smiles.
author: Tori S.

description:
Came here for lunch and ordered off the DAT menu. We had reservations and were seated promptly, after entering the brick building with red awnings.

Here's what I got:
-Soup of the day (potato leek soup): YUM. Smooth, rich, buttery and topped with olive oil and almonds.
-Pulled Pork sandwich with french fries: Okay. The panini was nicely toasted and gave out a nice crunch when you bit down. The pulled pork was stringy and with a good amount of flavor.
-Butterscotch & Creme Pot de creme: Rich. It was topped with 3 pieces of butter crunch and was super rich I took about 5 spoons and I was done. The color threw me off...the top layer was the same color of Thousand Island dressing and then there was chocolate underneath. I liked the chocolate better.

The food was okay, but the surroundings were awesome. I loved the feel of the place: rustic with lots of character. Loved the wooden tables and chairs. The light fixtures were unique and I LOVED how the bill came in an old hardback book. The place had a lot of charm and was filled with a lot of the business-type of folk. Service was slow, but our server was warm and friendly.
author: Janel Y.

description:
DAT Review

I'm very dissapointed in losing the photos I was hoping to attach to this review, and especially since I hardly take photos!  Which is why this meal deserving of visual compliments drives me crazy.  Nonetheless, the meal was excellent for Lunch.  For $22, I got the following:

-Asparagus Soup - Rich and creamy and simple to the eye.  It was full in flavor and lightly spiced.  It looked absolutely great just on a simple white bowl and plate.  Bread dipped makes it even greater.
-Pig Shredded sandich with chips - chips were awesome....I can't look at kettle chips another way ever again.  The sandwich was humungus and I had to take leftovers.  The coleslaw in the sandwich made it even better.

My big sis had this which of course I had to HAD to try
-Fish and Chips Garlic fries - excellent.  lightly breaded, it made up for my dissapointing failed attempt at fish and chips in SLO this past weekend.
-Tuna Tartare on fried Veggie thing - the veggie things all new to me and it was perfect while taking bite sizes of it and spotting a few spoons of the tartare. 

-Butterscotch Mousse - dessert finished off with this very rich yet too thick for my taste dessert.  It had chocolate mousse on the bottom with a nice layer of butterscotch on the top.
author: Vincent K.

description: Six of us went for drinks/dinner after work at 5pm. No seats at the bar, so we asked if we could get a table. Were told to go stand over by the hostess stand until someone arrived. Really? Totally empty restaurant, and the person we talked to couldn't help us see if there was a table available? Whatever. We left and went to RN74 one block away. Sat right down for drinks, had a GREAT meal, were treated like gold.
author: Aimee C.

description:
I gotta say, I was not impressed.  Food here is not bad but definitely not worth the price.

Party of 5, we made reservations so luckily the wait wasn't that long, about 10 minutes.  

They're famous for their buttermilk fried chicken which comes with collard greens, smashed potatoes, and home-style bacon gravy. Taste like.......fried chicken. The difference, you gotta pay $23 to taste this fried chicken. I've had better at much much cheaper prices.

If you're ordering sides, I recommend the warm jalapeno cornbread.
author: Emmie N.

description: Happy with my experiences here. Ordered a bunch of dishes and shared it all family style. The stuffed quail is a must and so are the veal meatballs. Will have to come back for the fried chicken I keep on hearing about and never getting around to ordering! Love the loft conversion style homey ambiance (bricks and beams are where it's at), even though last experience had us out on the patio... also a nice option on a more balmy night. Bonus that I can walk to it. Solid SF classic is true.
author: Diana F.

description: Nice plate in the heart of the financial district. I came here for dinner one night on a wednesday and this place was packed. Most of the people in here were your typical business people just getting off of work. The food is a little pricey, but proper for the type of compatriots who visit this establishment. I had the halibut, and the key lime dessert. All were good, but very tiny portions. The service was wonderful and very attentive.
author: Phan H.

description:
So glad we walked the extra blocks and had dinner here. Sat at the bar - which is one of my favorite things to do at good restaurants (that's where all the action is). Service was great our bartender was exactly what you wanted your bartender to be - friendly, open, creative and likes cocktails!  Not drinking but i had sips from my husbands drinks - the tequila mockingbird was SO good (uses apricot jam to sweeten it - OMG!) and the bitter end was more than fabulous ... it was full on dangerous in that it went down so easily. 

we split the BBQ shrimp app - wow was that sauce amazing, luscious and perfect in its complexity or lack there of; we asked for bread so we could sop up the sauce.  

we also split the pretzel encrusted pork chop which was tender and well cooked; the dish was all about being crispy so not much in the way of sauce and i kinda felt like i wanted a little something like that - but i get it that is not what the dish was about. good flavors, good textures and mostly awesome. 

had to ask myself "why don't i come here more often?"

R
author: r m.

description: Town Hall has really great food at decent prices. Their Southern Fried Chicken is amazing and the portion is huge. Be warned, the menu offerings are the antithesis of low calorie food. The food is just plain delicious, visit after visit. They have great ribs and I love the fish dishes. Their side dishes are also scrumptuous. They also serve good wine at a reasonable price. The staff are friendly and attentive, while leaving you alone to enjoy the meal. I also love that many patrons at a table next to you are often happy to answer a question you have about something they've ordered.  As far as I'm concerned, the food and the desserts are worth every calorie!
author: SFer O.

description: Great place for gourmet sandwiches. The honey crisp chicken wings were memorable
author: Adeeb S.

description: This is a cool place. Lots of action at the bar, and the menu and food are quite nice. I've been here twice and really enjoyed it both times. I had a nice pork chop last time, which was well seasoned and flavorful. Some folks got the trio of ribs, and the ribs were really nice. The fried chicken had great flavor. I recommend this place.
author: Josh B.

description: I came here for a business lunch and I quite enjoyed the atmosphere of this place.  Pretty cool looking decor...the bricks, light fixtures and paintings.  For my meal I ended up ordering the house smoked St. Louis ribs which came with fries, bacon baked beans and cole slaw.  Oh goodness, the rib meat just fell apart.  The sauce on it was oh sooo tasty...made the meat even more delicious!  Yeah, it was a bit messy but they give you a damp cloth on the side to wipe off all the leftover food on your face.  Heehee, I needed two...I can't help it I'm a messy eater!  The beans and cole slaw were good.  But the fries were WAY too salty....over seasoned.  Made me soooo thirsty!  That was probably the only thing bad about the meal.  The waiter was great...very attentive even with a full restaurant.
author: Denise M.

description:
Their unsweetened iced tea is insanely good, enough to net 5 stars on its own.  Expect to drink a gallon of it, since the food takes forever to come out.

Start with the butter lettuce, but be sure to ask for dressing on the side or that they go light, otherwise it comes out dripping in blue cheese.  (Which for some people isn't a bad thing, but I love blue cheese and still think it's overdressed.)

Fish and chips are consistently good and I find that they pair with the iced tea perfectly, so I don't even bother with the rest of the menu anymore.  I've also had the burger and the ham & cheese, both good too.

Biggest gripes: The unsweetened iced tea isn't available from the to-go BBQ stand, and if you sit down to eat there's no chance you'll be out within 90 minutes, much less 60.  Brutal for a workday lunch but not bad with good company and time to relax.

Also, the restroom is up the stairs and out of the way.  Stairway smells a bit mildewy, and trekking up there on a full bladder is not cool.
author: Gary D.

description:
The cutest place, your check will be brought to you in a vintage book.  Cocktails were yummy, but the food was fabulous.  As a table we had tuna tartar, seafood chowder, black cod, fried chicken, cornbread, and mac cheese.  All were yummy, especially the chicken w/gravy.  

For dessert we had pot de creme, beignets and some apple or pear crisp thing.  All were nice sized portions.  Even our server was fabulous, attentive, animated with cool glasses!  

If you live in the city or are visiting this is a great place to stop and grab a meal!
author: Brandy I.

description:
I've been to Town Hall before and loved it.  We had guests this weekend and decided to go again.  I can't say I loved it this time.  

We Started off with cocktails, Manhattan for me and wine for the others in my party.  Excellent, 5 stars. 

Appetizers -  we shared the veal meatballs and tuna tartare. Both were good but not noteworthy. 

Then came the main course. On my last visit I had the pork chop and raved how it rated among the top I'd ever eaten.  Tonight I ordered it again and was disappointed. It was crusted with this odd pretzel and mustard mixture which sounded interesting but was a complete failure.  after I scraped it off....the meat itself was good but ruined by the pretzel mixture. 

Other entrees in our party included ribs which were good and halibut which was decent. Again, not inspiring. 

The service was okay but not what you would expect from this caliber of restaurant. 

I hope my experience was the exception, however I will likely not return soon to find out.
author: Scott R.

description: Our office booked in for our 50 guest oil day party. The food was fantastic as always, but the wait staff really made the experience! Thank you Danny the bartender and Rebecca! So professional, responsive and warm.
author: Anne F.

description: I had an awesome burger w/ Blue Cheese and served with french fries. Nice, fat, and juicy burger cooked exactly as ordered and served w/ butter lettuce, red onions, and a nice slice of tomato. The place is also nicely decorated with exposed brick and a modern style of lighting.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Fantastic food!  Service was great as well.

The fried oysters were out of this world.
We did receive our food at room temp which was a bit of a shock to us seeing as the kitchen was 10 feet from our table but when we complained the staff graciously took care of it.

The Cocktails were some of the best I have tasted as well.
author: Kasey E.

description:
Fourscore and ten (aka pre-Yelp era)....

Tha' Sushizzle actually at some point, ate out at tons of non A$N restaurants once a week with the folks. GASP, OH THE HORROR you are wondering (considering I strangely and literally review nothing but Chinese and Japanese places.......)

Whether it was via Dine About Town, Entertainment '9x, or other A$N Cheapne$$ excu$e$ just to $neak an el cheapo di$counted bite, I'm sure there are at least 50 places under my belt that I have long forgotten about to the point where there's literally nothing to write.

Dinner at Town Hall was definitely not a memorable one for me. But one thing that I remember very clearly, was their hot chocolate


                                           
                                \\   WAY TOOO SWEEEEEET //
                                 \\~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ //=====}
                                  \\             X            X               //              }                                  
                                   \\                  O                      //======}
                                    \\           ------------              // 
                                      \\               U                    //
                                       ================              

A dark, robust, really rich, and unfortunately overly $weet cup of literally molten cocoa.

Some espresso would probably go very well with this, or if they turned it into a fondue in a cup & saucer. 

But to drink it straight? Eeeeeeeeeeek!  I think I was on a sugar high for a week.
author: Ken K.

description:
I've dined here once for lunch, once for dinner. It's good American food; the ham and cheese toast with poached egg and jalapeño cream is my go to. On the food alone, I'd give 4 stars. An experience I had with the service was unacceptable.

At a high end restaurant, you're paying for high end service too. At dinner a few weeks ago, my girlfriend and I were enjoying our first courses - both of us still at work eating. Next, to our surprise, someone who appeared to be a manager (dressed nicer, and not who served our apps) comes out with our main courses. 

He stands there looking kind of annoyed and confused - realizing we're still eating and that there is no room on the small table for more plates - gives a half apology and turns back around with our mains in tow. 

Immediately thereafter two servers come out to take our appetizer plates. I let them take my plate as I had finished, but my girlfriend declined their offer. (I noticed them both look at each other like "Why did the manager insist on us coming out here to take their plates? If they were ready to be cleared we would've cleared them." 

Next, our mains come back out. There's room in front of me now for mine, but my girlfriend's dish gets to cool down off to the side. 

Discount for this ordeal? Nope. Apology? Nope. Pretend like nothing weird happened? Yep. 

Service like this would barely make the grade at Applebee's let alone a $$$/$$$$ establishment.
author: Alex A.

description:
SInce there are millions of other reviews for this place I'll make it short. Some of the stuff was meh, but when the dishes were good, they were GOOD. 
1. The ham and cheese toast with a poached egg starter was BOMB. A delicate flavor of ham and cheese with a perfectly poached egg in a delicious creamy, spicy cheese sauce. A close second was the BBQ shrimp atop a crusty slice of bread, a party of flavors in your mouth. Equally good were the beets and goat cheese, slightly sweet beets with tangy goat cheese, YUM.

2. The fried chicken, wow. Juicy and fully cooked inside, crunchy and delicious on the outside. Comes with delicious mashed potatoes and gravy. Also with some collard greens with alittle meat in them. So tasty. I tasted the scallops and the triple pork dish which were meh. 

3. The best dessert by far was the pot de creme, so smooth and creamy with pieces of toffee (i think) but you must definitely share this. It is deliciously rich. Close second was the beignets, yummy puffy, sugar coated pillows with espresso ice cream and little crunchy coffee bits. Another good one was the pear dessert, kinda bread pudding like. 

Also, the coffee was very good, as was the bread, and especially the butter. Mmmmm. The mac and cheese and jalapeno cornbread was meh.

Wow, I tried to be brief, but I did stick to the facts. All in all, a great place for a nice dinner.
author: gabby m.

description:
Town Hall is a solid 3 or 4-star dining experience, but I don't think I will be going back any time soon.  The fried chicken is out of this world, but other than that, the menu is a tad bland, if you ask me.

I have dined here several times, but the most recent visit (a week or so ago) was on a business meeting.  Since we were a group of four, we requested a private setting within the restuarant conducive to conversation.  Much to my surprise, they had an excellent table (that almost seemed like a private dining room) setup and ready for our guests.

The pork tenderloin and cod are worth ordering.  The butterscotch pot de creme is great for dessert.  I hope the menu changes around a bit.  I am probably not going to go back until it does.
author: Ryan W.

description: Really good food. The fried chicken was memorable. Service was a bit slow and our waiter needed better training, but the som really knew her stuff - it was worth taking her advice - the Qupé Grenache she highly recommended was a perfect match for our food
author: Terry W.

description:
To be fair, I went for the takeout barbecue, and not the actual restaurant. It seems like a great deal though, $15 for a side, sandwich, and dessert.

I thought everything was very good (I got the pulled chicken special), especially the fact that you can get a pot de creme at a take out barbecue place. I didn't think this was as incredible as everyone else said, but maybe that was because they'd been sitting in the fridge all day. I also wish they'd give you the option of using metal spoons and returning them, the plastic spoon also might have affected the taste of the pot de creme. 

If I worked in this area (which I don't), I'd probably frequent the bbq take out quite a bit. The actual restaurant seems a bit pricey....
author: Mark A.

description: Nice facility. It is a cozy place amongst tall glass buildings. The food was OK, but not fabulous . The service was spotty.
author: Leslie S.

description:
Dinner for two please. For my boyfriend's birthday, they seated us against the wall closest to the street. The dim-lit setting again glowed with him for his birthday dinner. He was so nervous, so out of his comfort zone at Town Hall, excusing himself every so often to handle a birthday call outside then rushing outside. That's just my boyfriend being nervous. The staff were all so cordial with him and nice. Maybe even a little amused at this boyfriend who felt out of place. They have excellent customer service.
This was the second time I've had the House-smoked St. Louis ribs, Texas Jack BBQ sauce, corn muffin and coleslaw meal was as amazing as it was the first time. Still, the meat drips off the bones. The King salmon, with corm maque choux, chenterelle mushrooms (which were delightful and eaten first) over spicy red pepper sauce was good as well. The star of the dinner was the Ribs again.
The side of smoked jambalaya was just the right serving size for a table of two who just wanted a taste. Perfect serving size selection.
For his birthday, Doug had foreseen I was coming, I good guest of ours, and had given my boyfriend the Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Creme. One of the top 5 desserts I have ever had. I get this again next time I am here.
author: Jacqueline L.

description: Finally got a chance to try this place for a coworker's birthday.  The only thing on the  menu that popped out at me was the burger, which was juicy and savory. The fries were also super crunchy and went perfectly with my plate. All others were picking at my fries too!!
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I thought Town Hall was a super fancy place that only super fancy people went to dine and be more fancy. Then, when MG invited me to dinner at Town Hall, I decided it would be ok, especially if I went with MG. 

Well, it turns out this is a super fancy place where super fancy people go after work. Everyone is gorgeous and fit, especially the wait staff. The decor is beautiful, my only complaint is the 3 story hike to the bathroom. 

I had the gnocchi and MG had the fried chicken. The gnocchi was so delicious I felt high afterward and floated out of the building. MG told me he wasn't going to eat his entire meal and even asked for a to go box. When I came out of my delightful food coma, I noticed MG gnawing on a leg bone and there was nothing left on his plate. Where did the rest of the bones go? Anyway, my gnocchi was only $24 and the chicken was $21 which was a total bargain for stellar food.
author: Mitsi M.

description:
Please note - this is just a review of their outdoor weekday lunch BBQ.

Delish. De-freaking-lish.  Quite a walk over from the office, yesterday, but it was beautiful, so we figured why not?  The guy yelling our orders to the staff that was standing right beside us (and him) was hilarious.  Very entertaining way to order a meal.  The pulled pork was yummy, even if messy and the potato salad was no joke.  Ordered a pot de creme as well, but was too stuffed to eat it.  I don't know if I can justify that long of a lunch too frequently, but damn was it fun.
author: Adam T.

description:
Our server was horrible.  I brought my friend here to celebrate her birthday and this place was definitely lacking service.  

To our server: 

When we ask you "how's a certain plate", pleae do not respond you like everything on the menu.  Hmmm....

Please do not come to our table for  third consecutive time to ask if we want another glass of wine when we specifically just told you we were okay.  It's evident you only came to our table to sell us your wine when you didn't even ask us if our food were okay. 

I think it was rude to even say,  " I don't know whose birthday it is, but here you go".  Are you serious?

Seriously the last comment killed it for me.
author: Sophia S.

description:
Food was pretty good.  Service was excellent and very attentive, not to mention personable.  My only problem was the seating arrangement.  We were with a lot of tables along the back wall and I was seated within an arm's length of the person's shoulder sitting next to me.  Zero privacy.  And when a server has to scoot between the tables to serve someone, their butt is right next to your table.  Not good.

Although the restaurant was only half full, it was loud.  Must be rocking with a full house - and an end to any meaningful conversation.

The veal meatballs were ok, a bit too salty for my tastes.  The fried chicken, stuffing, and Mexican squash was good, as was the rib eye steak.  The mushrooms with the steak were full of flavor.  The smores for dessert were ok, but the chocolate and butterscotch creme was very tasty.  

Lots of street parking if you get there right at 6 PM.  Otherwise, good luck.  

Private dining room for 30+ upstairs.
author: Doctor G.

description:
Come one come all...the BBQ is open! 

Today I walked by right before the 12:00 lunch hour. It was me and one other bellied up to the BBQ line. I had to go the crispy chicken sandwich, layered with coleslaw. The only thing it was missing was a bit of zip from some hot sauce or jalapenos. But that didn't stop me I just tore through my little package of goodness. 

And then it happened...the lunch bell rang..BRRRRRNGGG! 

That line came out of nowhere. It was 15 deep and growing when I left. I guess word is out on the street that you can get a GRRREAT lunch at Town Hall for a reasonable price. 

Check it out but I suggest you do what I did and sneak in before the lunch bell rings. You go any later and you risk waiting in line and perhaps not getting your first choice for lunch because they may just run out!
author: Scott P.

description:
Town Hall is our go-to restaurant every time we visit SF.  We even have the owner's cookbook "Cooking my way back home" so we can recreate the recipes at home.

The ambiance and service are always top notch.  The cocktails and wine list always deliver.  Our favorites include the BBQ shrimp appetizer.

I would note that the noise level can be loud since it is open space--ask for a table in the corner of the restaurant if you'd like a quieter experience.
author: Sarah B.

description:
it's not their fault I'm a blonde  under this dark brown hair. I walked to the corner of the 300 block of Howard and there it was, right there - Town Hall. I walked one way and I walked another and could find no door - it was shut like a vault. I could only peer inside and see the people enjoying themselves, like I was in the movie "Carnival of Souls." I even walked under the red awning and through the empty outdoor dining area without noticing the main doors and did a complete full circuit of the building muttering to myself before trying again and finally seeing the front door where I'd just been. I attribute it to hormones, but I'm not so sure there wasn't some hoo doo going on.

Once that was all straightened out and I actually made it through the front door, I was ready for a drink to settle my nerves. The bartender was awesome and made my beverage exactly as I specified even though she'd never made it before. Why have Campari drinks fallen off the roster of even the top bartenders in this town? The hostess swept us up at the right time without our having to think about anything. 

The waitress was great, friendly and informative. She did undersell us a little - I was out for total gluttony but she kept suggesting we just have one app or one entree. That was befuddling but I have no complaints about the service.

As for the food it was expertly prepared and presented. My dining companion loved the ham and cheese toast appetizer. I liked the fried oysters a lot - very small oysters with lots of crispy batter on them, including a thick slice of bacon and some herbal and creamy sauce. Nice bites. 

We split the ribs entree. They were very good but not spectacular. I think I'd prefer that same bbq sauce applied to a pork loin and sliced, to avoid all the work with the sauce/finger/licking. The macaroni and cheese croquettes can be skipped. Though very well prepared, the outer crust and the inner goo just didn't go well together, and the tomato sauce they're served with - salsa? - just doesn't have much flavor. That one is a thud. The asparagus were very tasty and very thick.

The only bad touch to the meal was that though they did bring wet towels for us, they were basically soaking wet cold napkins on a plate with a  couple of lemon wedges. They brought them when we weren't even close to finished, so by the time we picked them up they were ice cold and still very wet as opposed to warm and cozy like you'd want. Well they were very busy and were eager to please us so that is rather nitpicky. But this compounded the problem of getting very cold for the last 1/4 of the meal, probably because a door was  opened somewhere in the back of the house. 

For dessert we had the butterscotch pot au creme. It was cool to eat with the layer of butterscotch with chocolate underneath, and the toffee was delicious. They bill it as their signature dessert and though it's fun, I don't think the flavor merits all the brouhaha over this dish. 

I was really looking forward to Town Hall. I had poured over the food porn pics on Yelp, and had high expectations. With regard to quality, my expectations were met, but in terms of having a completely unique restaurant experience, not so much. I'm glad I finally tried it. It's a very well executed restaurant and plainly has a lot of fans. That said I don't think I'll make it  a destination again unless several things are in confluence, in which case I'd  have no problem being there.

Wow, what a wishy-washy review!!
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
i didn't realize how busy this place gets when they open at 5:30. we arrived there around 5:40 and almost the entire bar and group tables were filled!

we tried the following dishes:

starers:
fried oysters & bbq shrimp
great dishes.. these were a bit heavy for appetizer but they tasted great and served in good portion. apparently bbg shrimp is a common dish in new orleans.. little did i know.. anyways, i found it very tasty.

entrees:
fried chicken: this was really good.. the batter was crispy and nicely seasoned. i didn't care for the mashed potatoes though.
pork belly & shoulder: yummy. it's hard to go wrong with pork dish.

dessert:
we ordered two dessert dishes.. but i can't remember the names of the dishes. we really liked the chocolate and nutty pie we got.. it was heavenly.
author: Sung C.

description:
I had a fantastic meal while vacationing in the Bay Area. Started with oysters, shared some asparagus soup, and had the fried chicken for an entree. 

Service was great and our server suggested a tremendous bottle of Sauvignon Blanc (Pascal Cotat, Sancerre, La Grande Côte 2008) - one of the best bottles of white I've had in ages.

The fried chicken -- served Southern-style with smashed potatoes and collard greens -- was exceptionally juicy and tasty without being at all greasy. There are a number of more civilized options on the menu, but I would highly recommend trying it if you're a fan of the fryer. 

The room was packed and was a bit on the loud side...but it didn't hinder our enjoyment. I wish they had more restaurants like this in Boston!
author: Ben Z.

description:
I wanted to like Town Hall.

I was meeting a friend for dinner and showed up at 8:15 on a Sunday night. The place wasn't very crowded, but I stood at the front without anyone acknowledging me for a few noticeable minutes. Then one of the waiters (I think) who was folding napkins came up to me, I asked for a table for two, and he said he would go check for a table. Along the way, he tapped the hostess who was standing by the bar and told her about me.

But I was still standing there, still waiting. Finally the hostess left the bar and came up to me, saying "How can I help you? Sorry it took so long, I was stuck chatting with so many people!" Somehow I feel it should have been a higher priority to seat me than to continue chitchatting?

My friend joined me at the table a few minutes later, and still no one acknowledged us. I couldn't understand why, it wasn't busy at all and I was visibly ready to order. Our waiter finally came to take our orders and proceeded to tell us that they had ran out of the fried chicken. I think I gasped out loud. How does a restaurant run out of chicken?! With two hours before closing? He also told us that there were several other substitutions on the menu (probably because they had run out of things too).

The food was fine, but overall the service was exceedingly disappointing for the pricey-ness of the place. Even waiting for our check and our credit cards took a long time. 

I wanted the fried chicken, but I'll just go back to Hard Knox Cafe.
author: Adrienne L.

description:
I "really liked" to "loved" our meal here--I'd give 3 1/2 if I could! The cormeal crusted oysters with bacon and the butter lettuce with candied walnuts in a rich bleu dressing--both were solid. I wasn't crazy about the peanut crusted pork chop (which was recommended by our server) but that's likely because I'm not a big cumin fan, which is all I could taste. 

Server was lovely, and she recommended a nice wine. Of lesser importance, the cocktail I had was really too sweet (I think it was the Dorothy Parker). We also had to wait about 20 minutes after we arrived on time for our 9:00pm reservation.
author: John A.

description: My husband and I had a very nice dinner here, a bit belated for my birthday. They made great cocktails ( I love a sidecar) and we both had delicious entrees as well. He had the fried chicken and I had the Halibut. Both were really lovely and capped off with a dessert tray for my birthday.
author: Rachel W.

description: With this many reviews, I doubt I'm adding much here, but I did want to call out the exceptional service from Troy, our server. Very attentive and fun. Minus one star (should be a half-star) since my blackened catfish could have had just a bit more bite and the fried chicken could have been a smidge crispier - both were still good enough to come back for though. Everything else was pretty incredible. Original apps and cocktails. Solid desserts. And, like I said, great service.
author: Jay N.

description: Expected much more from Town Hall and was really disappointed. Please do everyone a favor and keep the fish and chips as a regular lunch item. $110 lunch for 2 and left unsatisfied. The waiter was not attentive and acted like he had more important things to do than serve us. Our desserts took 20 minutes, which caused me to be late for a meeting. Think I will pass on Town Hall from now on.
author: Jim H.

description:
I'd come back, food was good..... not as good as Salt House thou!
Give it a try.
author: anna p.

description: Delicious menu and a nice beer selection. Knowledgeable service, classy interior, and a good vibe. I've been looking for a nice sit-down spot to take visitors, both personal and professional. I seem to have found it.
author: Andy H.

description:
A LITTLE BIT DISAPPOINTED :(

I had high hopes for the fried chicken with mash potatoes because I heard really good things about it. I brought my 4 close friends and told them they have to try the best fried chicken ever. Two of us ordered it. The chicken was dry, flavorless, and disappointing. My other two friends ordered fish and steak and it tasted better.
author: K L.

description:
My advice is to make reservation! 
but it you were like me and didn't... you can get there early enough, sit at the shared table or the bar and still enjoy a good lunch. 
I don't remember exactly what I had but the salad had ruby red grapefruits in it. and we split that. it was small but enough to satisfy our taste buds. 
since it was lunch, i had their version of the Reuben. i was craving pastrami... i love pastrami... and their sandwich was absolutely delicious. I hear that they change their menu and sandwich often so next time i go and order a pastrami, it probably wont look the same but as long as the quality is the same, i wont mind. it was great. i definitely will go back!
author: Katelyn M.

description:
In a nutshell - not worth the price.

The ambience is cool. I also liked the type of menu they are going for - Southern fusion. But two plus hours for dinner is too much especially when the food is just mediocre. We ordered fried chicken, short ribs and hanger steak. Only the steak was what I would consider great. The others were OK. For appetizers we had veal meatballs, BBQ shrimp and tuna. Not great.

The service was OK - Our waitress was very nice and knowledgable but she disappeared for long stretches at a time.
author: Alan S.

description:
I really like this place.

It's got a bustling ambiance with a soothing home like interior that removes you from the hassle of the SOMA workday.

I came back recently with a group of friends, and while we didn't have reservations, we didn't wait long to sit at their communal table. It was fantastic.

There's a clean, contemporary feel to Town Hall, but the wood floors and classic American feel of the menu and tables lets you feel like a modern day cowboy coming in for a pint and fine dining. 

The cornbread here is a must and the ribs were mouthwatering. A bit of heat in the bbq sauce came to me as a nice surprise, but it complimented the bed of mash it was on.

We shared the meatballs at the beginning which were quickly devoured, and the service was warm and welcoming.

This is a great place to catch up with friends, have a beer at the end of a long day, and enjoy the treat that classic sf dining is.
author: Mike K.

description: The butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme is as good as everyone raves about. So happy I have the recipe so I can replicate at home.
author: Lee H.

description:
The quality of service provided at a restaurant can either make or break the dining experience.  Unfortunately, the latter held true on a recent visit to Town Hall.  A few friends were visiting from out of town and we decided to eat at Town Hall since our first choice was closed on Sundays.  I had previously dined here before and had enjoyed that experience; expecting this visit to be similar.  I was dead wrong. 

So what ticked me off?  It was a slow night and we were blatantly ignored by the waitstaff.  Like little school kids trying to avoid picking a particular person for a team, the servers seemed to be bickering amongst themselves to see who would get stuck with our table.  This was done right in front of us, oblivious to the fact that we could see everything.  We finally had to flag down the bartender to help find someone who could take our order.  

While they tried to make up for it by bringing a free appetizer and a desert, the damage was already done.  I would have appreciated service levels befitting the caliber of restaurant they appear to be; rather than to be appeased by free food.  I can afford to eat out and always tip well for good service.  

While the food at Town Hall is good, it's not spectacular or prepared in any truly innovative way.  They are known for preparing high quality staples of American fare -- and they do execute this very well.  But they better provide some decent service to go along with that, considering that a big portion of the menu is not unique.  What we experienced that night was totally unacceptable.  

Sadly, Town Hall will no longer be on my list of places to entertain.  They still have an awesome desert menu though, so extra star for their consistently amazing butterscotch pot de creme.  At least one thing there hasn't changed for the worse.
author: Wei K.

description: Amazing food! My favorite is the fried chicken waffles and the veal meatballs are to die for. The service is great when it's not super crazy crowded and they have some great events there. Absolutely great place to take a date or your visiting friends cause the food is so outstanding. I have been there three times and would love to go more often but it's pretty expensive and if you order drinks it really adds up. However, it's worth treating yourself with Town Hall every so often. They are one of the reasons SF is known for such fantastic food.
author: Hayley H.

description: As good as it has ever been.  Great food, excellent service, strong wine list.  Some restaurants come and go, but town hall has served amazing experiences consistently over the years.  Cassoulet was delicious.  Worth the trip from LA.
author: Las V.

description: First time visitor to Town Hall. The food was very good, I would return again. The service could have been better - waiter wasn't super friendly, but might have been respecting our conversation.
author: Lori H.

description:
My birthday dinner was held here and the overall experience was great! There were 8 of us and the space is big enough to accommodate large parties without feeling like we're sitting on ea others laps. 

We had to wait over 30mins over our reservation to be seated but the staff was very gracious and comped us sparkling wine to thank us for our patience. By the time we were seated it was past 10pm and so we practically had the restaurant to ourselves which allowed us to cause a lotta raucous! 

Our server was super friendly, knowledgeable and prompt which made the experience very pleasant. The table ordered a couple of apps:
- Fried Oysters w/fried green tomatoes
- Tuna Tartare
Of the 2, we all really enjoyed the Fried Oysters.

Most of us ordered either the Thai Red Snapper or the Blackened Catfish. The Thai Red Snapper had a LOT of bones and so they ended up removing it from the bill which wasn't necessary but very kind of them. The Catfish was nice but nothing memorable. 

Overall, the food wasn't to DIE for but I'd return just for the excellent & pleasant service we received as soon as we stepped into Town Hall. THANK YOU for making my birthday celebration a special one!
author: Soozie H.

description:
Well, I guess I can confirm a lot of what has already been said.

My goal was to feed 8 - with three potentially difficult guests in the mix.  Not so much the discerning palette type of difficult, but the suburban parental type of difficult.  Yes, you know the type!  They favor restaurants with large menu's and larger portions.  They return to these restaurants month after month, only to order the exact same thing...so I knew no matter what  was coming--that this would be a challenge.

And, as a whole - Town Hall rose to the occasion.  However, the table was 15 minutes late.  As other reviews dictate that this seems to be a trend, I have to deduct points for it.

Food was pretty good, but in this price range I've found far better.  I started w/ the ham n cheese, which - thank you yelpers - was fantastic.  I followed w/ the Ossobucco on the waitress's recommendation.  The sides were tasty, and the meat was good, but it was a little flat.  My wife started w/ the squash blossoms which were forgettable at best, then opted for the famed fried chicken.  It was good, as friend chicken usually is, but unsure if it was worthy of the high acclaim it has received below.  Other guests had the New York steak, tai snapper and seafood etoufee, and all were happy.  

I'd return to Town Hall, but not on my dime.  At roughly $60 for 3 courses, my dollar would rather walk over to one market or boulevard for better food and atmosphere.
author: Chad K.

description:
AMBIANCE:  Old brick school house building meets chic elegant old school decor.

NOISE LEVEL:  Quite loud because people tend to social alot by the bar so if you end up by the tables near there then you'll have to talk a little bit loud to be heard.

FOOD: Appetizers:  You HAVE to order the ham/cheese toast with the poached egg and jalapeno cream.  When the waiter brought it out I was thinking to myself "what the hell is all this what gooey stuff?"  But it turns out this gooey stuff is just like a symphony for the mouth is what it is.  The ham and cheese toast was really crispy and the poached egg dripping yellow was something my artery might complain about but my mouth and stomach was screaming YES!

The only reason I set foot in Town Hall is my good friend/foodie Michael R. told me the fried chicken here is delicious and this coming from a man who makes the best fried chicken ever, I had to go and try.  How the hell can Town Hall make their chicken so tender?  The crispy outside crunchy layer as you bite through into the flesh morsel of meat that is just so tender!  The chicken breast that I ate had no dryness to it.  Each bite was succulent and juicy.  Just perfect.   Paired with the mash potatoes, finger licking good gravy along with collard greens.  This is a dish you can't eat everyday but would love to.

The chocolate/Toffee creme depot is fantastic.  At first bite I thought it was way too sweet, but when my spoon reached all the way to the bottom then I realized the chocolate was slightly bitter which balanced the overly sweet layer on top  to make it a very interesting combination.  Just order this one dessert to share with someone because it's actually pretty huge.

*Town Hall has some good picks and bad picks.  However, I have to say folks you gotta come just for the fried chicken.  I am taking away one star because I was so sad when I came back for my chicken meal instead of heavenly layered of fluffy mash potatoes and gravy now you have two biscuits with a smidge of gravy scattered on it.  Bring back the mash potatoes and gravy!!!!!!!!*
author: Vinh P.

description:
It has been a year or so since I have been here, but I definitely feel like this place deserves a review.

I used to come here 2 - 4 times a month with my family because we loved their fried chicken and sticky toffee cake.  The last time I went there, there were changes made and the sticky toffee cake wasn't the same.  It is a pretty pricey place, but regardless, their service was good and I have yet to come back here to see what has been updated on their menu.
author: LilyAnn N.

description:
Maybe it was the special occasion I was celebrating, or maybe it was the dinner company, but my meal at Town Hall was outstanding.

I came here for an engagement dinner/surprise wedding reception for my dear friends, and they chose an excellent group menu.

I started with the salad, which had butter lettuce, blue cheese and asian pears.  Good times.

Then for my main course I had the filet mignon, at that point it was a bit of a blur because all of a sudden I looked at my plate and the food was gone.  SO GOOD.  The meat was perfectly cooked and the onions and mushrooms were savory and tender.  Just writing abotut it is making me hungry.

For dessert I had the ice cream sandwiches which were divine, and I also got to try the sticky date cake which i thought would not be something I would enjoy, and well guess what, of course I liked it.

All in all, a great dinner with great friends.  I would return for a special occasion, or any occasion for that matter.  The space upstairs was great for a small-mid sized dinner party, and you get your own bar up there which is nice.

Well played Town Hall.  I am a fan.
author: Lu E.

description: Went for a business lunch. Server did not come by for at least 20 minutes. Then, the food took forever. At the end of the day, we had 10 minutes (out of a one hour lunch break) to eat. To add insult to injury, the restaurant did not comp anything and the food was terrible. I ordered the pulled smoked chicken sandwich. It was like something that one could get at Wendy's or burger king, but worse. Felt nauseous afterwards. Absolutely avoid this place at all costs.
author: Marc P.

description:
I was here on a Wednesday night sort of late so it wasn't super crowded.  I tried cornmeal oysters, Rabit ravioli, faith's ham and cheese and the Wild Bass as a Main. Food was good and I really enjoyed it. 
The hostess was really friendly. I would give this place 4* but when a Main is $24 I expect way above average food. That's the only reason I gave it 3*'s. the food and service was good but didn't blow me away.
author: Jeff H.

description:
I should start by saying I love comfort food and food from the south. The place is loud, but we had great service and a delectable meal. We actually ordered all apps and sides because we had too much trouble picking. I was extremely pleased with just about everything we got. Fried oysters, stuffed calamaris, jumbalaya, cheese grits, lobster raviolis. Whew, I am getting hungry just writing about it.
My only complaint would be that the wine list doesn't offer any real values. Their glass list was good enough for me, but to only have one or two wine bottles below $50 seems a bit off. Fix this and its five star for me.
author: Sean Q.

description: Walking in, I get the sense of a vintage SF.  Charming and inviting.  The food was just wonderful and cooked to order.  Lots of choices as well.  One of the best meals in the city in quite a while.  Great for a business lunch.  The only issue was the waiter.  He got one of our orders wrong and as we were talking, he just walked up and interrupted us.  He was hurrying us the whole time and it was very annoying.  The Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Crème worth a visit as it is just so good!
author: Robert L.

description:
They seated 8 people on a Friday night with no reservation in JULY!  I was grateful for that so gave 4 stars. 

The food was good but not stunning. The Veal meatball appetizer was the best thing we had. Wish we would have ordered more of those instead of the other appetizers. The squash blossoms were tasty but I think it was just the cheese! Fried chicken was good smashed potatoes even better.

Very friendly service, the waiter spilled a glass of water and after my nephew spilled his wine we were sure it was us!

The rocky road desert was the best, the butterscotch/chocolate pot was not as fab as other reviews indicated. 

Beautiful room and yeah a bit noisy but not as bad as all that.
author: Sue B.

description: Was in town for business and happened to be close by. Stopped off for some dinner and could not be more impressed. Everything I had was delicious and i liked the ambiance quite a bit. Would definitely recommend.
author: Grant P.

description:
Everything from the food to the wine to the service were exceptional.   This place is one of my new favorite restaurants.

The prices are very reasonable as well.  Although, not necessarily cheap, what you are getting is worth every penny.  Plus unlike most other "nice" restaurants, the portions here are very generous.

The fried chicken pretty much blew my mind and made me question everything that I thought I knew about chicken.  It was very moist and juicy yet crispy as well, I don't know how they did, but I think that maybe they marinate the chicken in  broth before they fry it.  Regardless of how they do it, the result is delicious.

I could write forever on everything else we had, but all I would be doing is repeating myself, when all you really need to know is that this place is amazing.
author: Hungry D.

description:
Overall, I would say I'm a fan. The food is above good and the drinks are fantastic. So,  if you're looking for good southern food, this is a good place to start. Also give Hops and Hominy a look.

the good:

Southern Food :) , drinks, atmosphere

The bad:

Don't come here looking to get in and out. The service in general is a bit slow. However, they comped our appetizer, so I wasn't that annoyed. I was expecting a longer dinner.

Conclusion, you could do a lot worse. I wouldn't say this is a MUST, but it's a good spot for a dinner with friends. I would recommend Salt House and Hops and Hominy over Town Hall.
author: Bryan P.

description:
How have I not been to Town Hall yet?  Such an established and well known about restaurant seems to have slipped under my radar....up until NOW!!!!!!!

I'm glad I finally got to make a visit here, and I'd say it's the best out of the Salt House, Anchor & Hope and Town Hall trio.  I loved the ambiance, the variety of items that were right up my alley on the menu and the drink menu looked fab as well.

In addition, after calling on a Sunday night and asking the hostess for a 2 top reservation in an hour, she informed me that they were booked until 9.  "On a Sunday??!?!" I feverishly replied.  Almost ready to give up, she then told me that she'd be able to squeeze us in and then asked for my name and told me to ask for Chloe at the door.  Now that's what I'm talking about!  Customer service!

Although I didn't really like the entree we ordered (seafood etoufee), the other items we ordered including Faith's warm ham and cheese toast, the cheese fondue and fried mac and cheese were all very delicious.  There were also many other items on the menu that looked like they had potential as well.  AND, they had GREAT bread and SALTED butter!

I'll be back my friends, I'll be back.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
Went here with a few friends and, yeah, it's expensive. But as far as I'm concerned, my food was absolutely spectacular from start to finish. 

My friends' reactions were a little subdued next to mine. Everybody agreed it was at least "extremely good." I think I was the only one to really rave about it; I may have gotten the lucky best dishes. Or I might have had one too many Dalwhinnies. I started with the BBQ shrimp and moved on to the stuffed sole. But by far the highlight of the meal was the dessert, which I often try but don't usually rave about. The Butterscotch & Chocolate Pot Du Creme is mind-blowing. It would be unwise, young padawan, to avoid it.

Remember to bring your Mission hipster crew in force because even on Saturday evening you are outnumbered by suited dullards that look like they're anxious to cut their next million-dollar deal.
author: Dave P.

description:
This place is located across the street from my work place so it's a very popular choice for business lunch. During one of these lunches, I tried the burger.. don't ask me.. i just wanted a burger that day. The burger itself was a decent size, and taste ok. Nothing special about it. Next time I will try something else. 

Parking here is difficult. They are tearing down the old over pass so parking is even more limited. 

Either take public transportation or a cab. There is some parking meter available but good luck finding an empty one. The meter maid are quick to give you a lovely surprise upon returning to your car.
author: Aimmee W.

description:
I really like this place.  I've only eaten here once and stopped by the other day for wine at the bar, but the interior really makes me feel like i'm in a place of refuge...it's just so..NICE, and the employees are so service oriented -- the whole ambiance makes me feel so great when I'm there.

Normally, I don't eat at such nice spots; when I came here for wine the other day, they gave me a lunch menu in case I were to have lunch.  I wasn't sure at the time because I was waiting for someone.  I took a look at the menu, and expected to see meals priced way out of my budget for the time, but they actually had a good mix of items to choose from.  They had meals down to $11 or so.  I kind of assumed everyone in there was a financial district person with a fat wallet, but 'ey regular folks like me can afford to eat there, too!  Sadly, the lunch didn't pan out, but the smell and menu descriptions had me yearning for it badly!

The time I had come for dinner was with a couple of friends, and we all had different items.  I can't even remember what I had, but it was good, as I expected! We all liked our meals.  My memory of that was the ambiance/interior/decor really impressing me as well.  It kind of makes me feel like I'm in another place.

Another thing I like is that this restaurant has a few nooks/spaces that allow that allow varied experiences in different parts of the restaurants; it provides a degree of privacy as well.

I overheard the bartender telling someone that they have two other restaurants, one being the Salt House, which I've passed before and have wondered about...I forget the name of their other restaurant, but she said it serves mostly seafood.  Exciting!  Anyway, when I have more money to splurge, I'll be back to all of those.
author: Liz C.

description:
The best fried chicken I have ever had.  it was crispy on the outside and yet so moist inside.  I dont usually like non-spicy fried chicken, but these were different, it was mainly just spiced with salt and other mysterious spices, but it was not over powering, because i can clearly taste the chicken.  It was so good, I almost started crying.  

We had dessert too, we got the pumpkin toffee cake and the pot de creme.  They were both very good.  the toffee cake was warm and it was so comforting when i ate it.  The creme de pot was not too sweet and the butterscotch tasted like true butterscotch.  The desserts arent small either, we couldnt finish after eating our fried chicken dinner.
author: Janet S.

description:
The Backyard BBQ is awesome and is open for lunch on weekdays.

I got the Fried Chicken Sandwich - it was great. The chicken is nice and crunchy on the outside and moist and juicy on the inside. They give quite a bit of meat on the sandwich. The roll was fresh and delicious. They add some vinegary coleslaw over the chicken.

They also had a sausage po boy, ribs, some dessert options, homemade chips, water, lemonade and sodas.

I love the that they have this new quick lunch option.
author: Chili B.

description:
Interesting location. I have passed 100+ times but wasn't ever on the top of the "to try" list.  

Can't say there is much allure to the neighborhood, but we were surprised within the restaurant. 

Food was good: 

- Salad had a good mix, and the Pt Reyes was excellent. 
- We split the Sole and the NY (medium rare)
             - Sole was incredible with the gnocchi and butternut squash 
             - NY was just OK. Never a fan of slicing good cuts of meat upon serving as they loose flavor. 

The real treat was the dessert: 
- Coffee ice cream and donuts were well worth the trip. 

Kudos to the service as well. 

*side note: main dinning area could be an excellent place a large event.
author: Dexter R.

description: Good quality food. But don't come hungry unless you can expense your lunch - portions tend to be small!
author: Pascal L.

description:
I often judge a restaurant by how well it rectifies its mistakes--and Town Hall hit it out of the park in this department yesterday.

I was in town for a family event and made 2 separate reservations on Open Table so that all of us would have a seat in the restaurant (and you can only reserve for parties of up to 5 on Open Table). Long story short, when I called to confirm the resos a couple of hours before dinner, the hostess said she had no record of one of them and she couldn't guarantee our seating. I had email confirmations for both of them, so I knew they were there, but the hostess persisted in disagreeing.  She wasn't exactly rude, but not exactly helpful either. So I was worried our big fun family dinner was going to be a disaster.

Flash forward to two hours later when the loveliest maitre'd was awaiting our arrival. He had ironed out the whole mess and had reserved a big table where we could all sit together. The service was phenomenal--one waitress and two helpers working their asses off--and the collard greens were the best I've ever had.

My brother communicates with hand-gestures--he is disabled--and it takes patience to understand and engage with him if you've never met him before. The entire staff at Town Hall was gracious and warm to him and for that alone they get my 5-stars.

Definitely check out this place.
author: rebecca d.

description: Just had lunch at Town Hall and was really disappointed. For starters, I was seated 20 minutes after my reservation time (boo). Then, once our table was seated, the service was only "okay." But the real reason for the post is that I ordered a "Town Hall Burger" and, given they named the burger after the restaurant, I was expecting some pride of ownership. It was hands down the worst burger I've ever had. Why? The meat was terrible! I'm not joking when I say it may not have met FDA standards. It was incredibly chewy - yes, chewy - and when I sent it back to have it cooked a bit more, assuming the chewiness was due to it being undercooked, it came back JUST as chewy, only greyer. Yuck, yuck, yuck. I'm no hater, I have enjoyed Town Hall's patio and drinks in the past - but this was just so gross that I'm hoping this review will encourage the buyers to step up their ground chuck procurement.
author: Carrie S.

description:
So, I was playing a light-hearted game of Word Association with a friend of mine. It had started off well and most answers were predictably benign. Things started to get a little uncomfortable when the mention of "sex" elicited the response, "child." In a desperate attempt to put a halt to the psychoanalysis, we carried on: 

"Air."
"Plane."

"Happy."
"Sad."

"Pudding."
"Bill Cosby." 

...."What the hell? Bill Cosby? Come on! I say pudding and you shoot me back some guy in a sweater?" 
"Haley, what the hell is your problem? It was the first thing I thought of and so I just said it - "
"Yeah. Ok. Fine. It's just that if you had TASTE, you would have said TOWN HALL. You would have said BUTTERSCOTCH POT DE CREME. WITH CHOCOLATE. But you didn't. You didn't say any of that....you said BILL COSBY!!!" 

I went to Town Hall with my parents on a whim. For a Wednesday, it was surprisingly busy, but we found a seat right away. The host was considerate and let us know that the table was open due to its close proximity to the kitchen, but that was icing on the cake to my restaurant-industry father, who never ceases to bring on the chit-chat with everyone involved in the dining process, much to my embarrassment. 

For instance, they bring us some bread. It's good bread, sure. I dip mine in olive oil and carry on with my conversation. My dad gets up from the table and heads over to the guy slicing the bread. My mother and I glance at each other, amused. If I were still going through puberty, I'm sure I would have turned beet-red and hid under the table, but as I get further past the braces-and-acne phase, I find these moments more endearing than mortifying. He comes back and sits down, pleased with his correct identification of the bread. The bread guy he assaulted swings over with another basket, and slaps a hand on my dad's shoulder, chuckling. This bread guy is my father's new best friend. 

So, we get down to the Real Food. Butter lettuce salad, tuna tartare, fondue to start. Salad had slices of one of the crispest Fuji apples I've had in a while (I am a stickler for firm apples and have had horrible luck finding one the past few months). Tuna tartare was fresh and light, complete with fried green tomatoes, which I wanted to bury myself in, they were so delicious. Fondue was forgettable. 

And then, like a ton of bricks, they hit us. Both at the same time, both to share and fight over, both in the hands of a waitress who could not walk fast enough. 

Fried chicken with corn, biscuits and gravy.
Steak with white bean puree and a delectable, artery-clogging sauce. 

The perfectly-breaded chicken was deceptively inviting; a knife through the center released a sinus-clearing cloud of steam, taunting my hungry stomach. The roof of my mouth was pissed, as I defied the thought to let it cool off, and inhaled the chicken. Unlike many, I've never been head-over-heels for fried chicken, but I can (did) definitely appreciate the combination of crispy outside, juicy inside. 

Well beyond full at this point, I ventured towards the steak. I rarely (HA. GET IT?) order a slab of meat for myself and so I didn't anticipate wanting much more than a few bites. One fork-to-mouth exchange and I was questioning why I would have ever made that assumption. Perfectly medium-rare, nice burst of mushroom and wine. I snuck the last bites before my father could slurp up the sauce. 

Manufacturers make elastic waistbands for these occasions. We sat there in a communal food coma, waiting for someone to clear the empty plates that could have gone without a wash, they were so thoroughly cleaned. This is a good place to mention that service was sweet, but slow.  Part of why I had decided it suitable to eat anything presented to me (and more) was due to the fact that it took a LONG time to get it all out. Our waiter would zip by and apologize, but even my patient mother was getting a bit peeved. The only time this worked in our favor was after we had eaten the entire zoo, carousel, and gift shop. 

With the passing time, we were able to digest and plan ourselves to further discomfort. My mother insisted we had to get the butterscotch pot de creme, based on her recent visit. 

I love my mother. 

The majority of the food I mentioned above could be found elsewhere for a lesser price. However, the butterscotch pudding was worth every ache and pain my stomach growled out later that night. I considered getting my bag, silently unzipping it, tossing the bowl of rich butterscotch and chocolate into my bag, and RUNNING to the nearest alley so that I could be alone to lick every last drop. 

Not really my "scene," I probably wouldn't go back just for a dinner. I would prefer to drop the dough in one of the many eclectic, smaller, just-as-delicious venues the city has to offer. 

That said, if someone says "pudding," you can rest assured my answer would be: "TOWN HALL!"
author: haley d.

description: Good rustic ambiance.  The tuna poke and raw oysters were fab.  The fried chicken was just ok.  Seems like a good place for happy hour or to split an after work meal.
author: Juliana X.

description:
I was having trouble finding a reservation in San Francisco on short notice (coming from outside the city), until I called Town Hall. They were very accommodating for my group of 8 people. The restaurant itself is gorgeous! The service was fantastic, we were given every attention. 

The food way exceeded my expectations. The menu is unique and well presented. For an appetizer, I had the tuna tartare that comes with lightly fried green tomatos. I would never normally eat these, but being I had no idea what they were until after I tasted them, I went for it. SO DELICIOUS! The wine list was great, we got a couple bottles :) To be honest, I can't remember the type of fish I had for the main course, but I do remember it was cooked perfectly. And dessert, oh boy, they had little donut holes with fresh coffee ice cream. Very elegant and unbelievably tasty. 

I absolutely recommend this restaurant for dinner 100%
author: Dana V.

description: Nice room, professional servers and creative menu. We had the duck, scallop and gumbo entrees. They were all fine, but not spectacular. The portions were small, which was fine for me, but guessing not most. We did have an excellent rosé with dinner. But what put me off the place were the cocktails before dinner. Tiniest martinis in SF. Haven't seen stemware this small outside of the 1.00 drink bars in casinos. And then an olive in the glass the size of an apricot. I had 2marts in ten minutes and was nearly stuffed from the olives. Seriously, why does an otherwise nice place scrimp on cocktails?
author: k m.

description:
This restaurant gets 3 stars because when I ate here about 5 years ago I had a transcendant experience.

When I ate here this week however, we were totally disappointed.  The service was horrible.  I can't tell you how many screw-ups we had, and how much we were ignored by our server.  The food was still pretty good but so is a lot of food in SF with much better service.

I did think some things were overplayed.  We ordered tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes and crispy okra.  Both were fried the exact same way.  I expected more (or at least for our waiter to tell us we should diversify - he also let us order fried chicken.)

The pot de creme for dessert is still good but I was just so offended by how we were treated by the staff that we won't be back.
author: Chelsea O.

description:
This place was so much better 2 years ago.
      I went here on 7/22 with a 6:15 reservation.  The host was nice and we were sat right away.  I noticed the tables were way I close together.  When the waiter was waitin on the other table his ass was pretty much on my table ( this is also a fire code violation).  Our waitress was unremarkable. Attentive but blah.  Appetizer was good ( ham and egg on toast).  I ordered a Pliny the elder ( beer) to drink and was surprised by the markup. The wait for our food wasn't too bad. I had the pork chop and my gf had the bacon wrapped (fish).  My chop was cooked perfectly but the flavor was unremarkable. It was a cherry gastrique.  I was expecting a nice sweet slightly tangy taste but it was blah.  Nice char marks though.  There were peppers on the dish that I couldn't figure out why they were there. They didn't go with the supposed " flavors" and there was 5. The peppers were not hot but just really earthy. Booring.  The bacon on my gf's fish was barely cooked. Came off rubbery and adhered to the fish skin.  Our desert was decent. Bread pudding and the chocolate cake.  The. Read pudding was super sweet and the chocolate cake was not.   We came back here for our anniversary. We were here 2 ish years ago and it was awesome.  What happened?
author: Ryan P.

description:
Came here recently.  I kept driving by this place on the way home and always thought it looked really warm and inviting.  We came without a reservation and they found us a table right away.  Not that they had no business, but the place is pretty big.

The interior IS warm and nicely lit.  There's just enough lighting too what you're eating, and give people a nice candle-lit glow.

The space is flanked by two brick walls in a long and narrow space.  

The bread was great.  Though not heated (I like warm bread), it's still moist with a slight chewy bite to it and crunchy on the outside ... just the way I like 'em.  Aside from the texture, it also has nice flavor.  My dining companion and I polished off two baskets of 'em.

We each had a salad (butter lettece with candied walnuts, apples and blue cheese; beet salad with fried goat cheese).  They both came out looking amazing.  The butter lettece was dressed and stacked pretty high with the walnuts and apple "sticks" on top.  While it looks great and all, it's hard to mix them together with this big stack of ingredients.  Flavor-wise, it's quite good, it's unfortunate that the apples weren't really sweet enough to complement the punginess of the blue cheese.  The beet salad was also pretty good.  The beets were a bit "muddy tasting" but that's probably more of a seasonal thing.  The piece of goat cheese, however was quite delightful.  It was covered with panko and deep fried.  When you bite into it, you get some gooey melted goat cheese with a bit of crunchy panko.  All in a nice warm bite.

We had the bacon wrapped trout and day boat scallops for our entrees.  The trout was an interesting choice as its flesh is usually pretty sweet and delicate.  While I love anything with bacon, I found that its smokiness was too heavy-handed and overpowered the trout.  The day boat scallops came on some chantrell mushrooms, brussel sprouts and over a puree of sweet potatoes.  The flavor of the mushrooms was almost non-existent, the brussel sprouts were great, the sweet potato puree was really rich.  One of the scallops was a bit over cooked (just a bit, but still ok ... it's more of a looks thing).  I found it unusual that they had only seared one side of them, not both top and bottom.  Perhaps they don't have a burner with enough btu???

We skipped dessert.

Overall, it's a nice meal and one that I enjoyed.  But for the price, I think I can do better elsewhere.

BTW, if they seat you toward the end of the dining room, go use the washrooms first.  It's quite a trek to get back there.
author: Winnie C.

description:
Overall: very slow service.  And quite pricey for the food we got.

Tuna tartare was so-so.
I got the special (halibut, I believe it was) and it was also just so-so.

I don't think I would go back.
author: Austin C.

description:
Wanna take your significant other out for a nice quiet romantic dinner?
Gaze into each others dimly lit eyes while love songs coo you on?  Eat mouth watering food that makes you hunger for some passionate monkey luvin dessert?  Hubba Hubba. 

Davids Bottom Line-  Then dont come here!!!  Something about the acoustics of this place makes it impossible to hear your hot mama date sitting just a few feet away.  It becomes terribly embarrassing having to say "What?" every other word so I resort to just nodding my head and throwing in an occasional shake.  

"Are you enjoying your food?"   *nod*   "me too"
"Are you having a good time?"    *nod*   "me too"
"Are you going to take me home for some hot monkey luvin dessert?"   *I shake my head*   "oh...ok then... =("
*oh darn shes frowning...she must be having a crappy time...I guess no monkey luvin for me...sigh*

Been here a few times.  Only thing Ive liked is the fried chicken meal...but then again I love all fried chicken.  Im easy *nod*
author: David L.

description:
Some friends of mine and I went here one Friday night for dinner.  We're always up for trying new restaurants in the area.  We had recently been to Foreign Cinema and had pretty good expectations about this place.

Pretty average in my opinion.  There were some great things about the meal, and there were some pretty bad things about the meal, and mixing the two together gives an average meal.

First, the service was pretty mediocre.  We were all starving, and bread took its sweet time getting to our table.  We had to ask several times for refills on the bread.  

The wine was good.  The starters were pretty damn amazing.  I had the scallops which were pretty delectable, and my boyfriend had the BBQ shrimp.  Honestly, it was probably the best starter on the table.  The scallops were a close second, but the sauce the shrimp were served in was divine!  Someone also had the seafood chowder, which was pretty good as cream chowders go (I'm pretty damn picky about them honestly, no one uses pepper these days!), and someone else had the ham and cheese sandwich which looked great, and he said was simple and had a nice flavor profile.

Now for the main courses.  These were a huge disappointment.  I had steak.  It was perfectly cooked, and probably the best main that we had, but it was lacking something.  I mean the steak at Catch (a SEAFOOD restaurant) is far superior to this steak.  Two people ordered the fried chicken.  Honestly, I've had better.  My aunt made better fried chicken.  It just was lacking something it needed, but I'm not sure what.  My boyfriend ordered the ribs.  Don't get them.  They overcook them, they are tough, and ridiculously tough to get off the bone.  It was pretty disappointing.

For dessert we had two orders of the pot de creme, and I got the apple galette.  The tart was pretty boring.  Also the crust was super soggy and a bit burnt, which I think is only possible by cooking in advance and reheating them.  The only good thing about mine was the blue cheese ice cream.  I've never had it before, and it was pretty damn tasty.  I'm gonna have to try it on my own sometime.  The pot de cremes were ok.  Nothing spectacular.

I don't think I'd go back, when there are far superior restaurants in the city.
author: Grant T.

description:
I used to frequent Town Hall when i worked at StubHub/eBay and loved the Burger for lunch. It was either Soups, Sushi, or TH when it was sunny and i could sit on thier outdoor patio. The Burgers are one of the best in town. The fondue is gone and at that point i was very basically too (as a place to have wine and cheese after work). Sooo bummed. 

For Dinner: Love the short ribs, the lamb, and great wines. Some of my fav Vino's although they rotate. Malm Pinot... Yum. 

4* - 1 for missing fondue on the menu and Street Parking only. 

But the management, waiters and bartenders get 5 stars so dont think this is any reflection on service. the Hosts are the Best in Town.
author: Adam X.

description: The food and atmosphere were fine.  I had to ask twice for drink service and it was an hour between appetizers and entrée.  Too long.  The food and atmosphere would have to be really, really to make up for begging to be served and waiting for dinner
author: Mike D.

description:
thumbs up:
great spot for post americano happy hour eats
outdoor seating on a rare & perfect temperate evening, not as loud as inside
fried chicken super crispy outside, juicy inside
house smoked country ribs
very friendly and jovial waiter

thumbs down:
tater tot side too oily (i prefer oreida or burger king hehe!)
i never make it to the butterscotch pudding!  always too full.  

need to return for dessert trip only.
author: Josie M.

description:
It was my girlfriend's birthday last week. I planned on getting her a gift and a nice night out to a place we haven't been before. We had to go to  Cirque de Soleil after dinner so we wanted to keep it close to the hood. In proud fashion that any man would be proud of, I waited to the last minute to make a reservation.
