I got an early reservation so my procrastination did not cost me my relationship:)

When you walk  inside, it was very "boys club" feel. There are a bunch of guys and a few women in business suits sitting in the lounge/host area having a drink after work. It was funny, this was the night that I told my girl to dress down as we tend to overdress when we go to restaurants. We did fine...we decided last minute not to wear our tracksuits.

We made our way through the small crowd  and realized that we pretty much had the whole place to ourselves. The hardwood floor, brick, and dark and light contrasts on the wall gave it and the semi rustic feel. I felt like I was in a New England restaurant that has been around for years. All it needed was a weimaraner lying on an animal skin rug. The dog and rug of course are in front of the fireplace with a gun hunting rifle on it.  

No fox hunts or LL Bean here. We had Apollo: the super waiter. He was really warm and once the section filled up, handled it like a pro. He was attentive, funny and multi-tasked well (I was a waiter and appreciate the hustle). The menu is definitely New American but with a new-found twist on the classics. I love rich food. It makes me think of a grandmother cooking food to taste good; not an uptight LA cook appeasing moviestars with egg whites. By recommendation, we had a few starters and shared an main. It was more than enough. We had the tuna tar-tare, veal meatballs, and the butter lettuce salad. For a main we spit the Ribeye and fries. The whole portion must be for that dude on the front of Brawny papertowels. It was perfect for two. Desert was great....but of course everything looks great with a candle sticking out of it.  

I would go back here in a minute. Just to have a side with few drinks. It's not a typical SF scenester hangout. Although the Bob Marley soundtrack was a bit weird, it beats thumping house during dinner any day.

Go.
author: Bill M.

description:
I WAS GOING TO WRITE THIS ENTIRE REVIEW IN ALL CAPS BECAUSE AT TOWN HALL, YOU HAVE TO PRACTICALLY YELL AT YOUR DINING COMPANION JUST TO HAVE A CONVERSATION...but I'll spare you.

Had lunch here with Sooj O. mainly because she had been raving about one thing...the sticky toffee cake (we'll get to that later, since we actually ordered lunch, too). 

I'm a burger purist at heart, but I'm not averse to having a new-agey gourmet burger. I ordered the Town Hall Burger, which is served on foccacia instead of a bun with some really good crispy fries. The foccacia was really good and went well with the meat, but if you're going to "reinvent" the burger by serving it on square bread, why not a square patty? Yeah, it sounds like Wendy's, but at least you wouldn't have four meatless bites of burger. 

I also had a bit of Sooj's fish (she ordered fish and chips) and it was really good...a nicely battered and fried piece of fish paired with malt vinegar always hits the spot.

Now we didn't have time to eat dessert because my car was parked at a woefully underfunded parking meter, so we got our sticky toffee puddings packed to go (and I wanted to bring it home for my wife anyway). Our waitress said it would keep in my car all day and simply heating it for around 30 seconds before serving would be fine. Well, it was more than fine, it was awesome. It's a small brown disc that kinda looks like the honey oat bran muffin from Mimi's Cafe but tastes like pure, sweet toffee. It's incredibly rich and was actually a bit too sweet for me, but my wife loved it even though I didn't actually get it home to her until 9 hours later.
author: Arnold G.

description: The poor attitude of the hostess (surly brunette who's clearly not a fan of going to the gym) pretty much ruined the experience.  She dropped a lousy attitude because my reservation didn't include my baby (even though the restaurant was pretty much empty at 5:30 pm).  She has to realize that she sets the tone for the initial dining experience.  I won't be going back here as a result, and will counsel my co-workers to do the same.  I'm sure Wayfare Tavern will appreciate the additional five figure business that my firm brings.
author: David S.

description: The best dessert in the world? Town Hall's Pot de Crème. Enough said.
author: Jen S.

description: Pretty decent place, nothing too special.  Ordered mostly from the happy hour menu (fried oysters, pulled pork slider, wings), as well as the whole fried chicken.  The happy hour drinks are very watered down.  Very gastropub-y feel, though perhaps that's the idea of happy hour.
author: Josh Q.

description: I love this place!  The shrimp appetizer and tuna tartar are amazing.  The fried chicken is light and crisp and the jambalaya is delicious.  The ambiance is wonerful the drinks are superb and the service is fantastic!  A+
author: T T.

description: The service left much to be desired, and this place is always insanely crowded and loud. But I love the food, so I will be back. The tuna tartare and fried green tomatoes were excellent, as was the bread pudding.
author: Candice P.

description:
I almost came here last time I was in San Fran and I regretted passing it up.  Back in town on business so I stopped in for dinner at the bar.

Had a very nice potato leek soup followed by fried chicken.  Very good time.  Chicken was crisp and flavorful and the collard greens were very tasty.  The potatoes were eh in comaprison.

As for the other stuff...had a very nice beer...Pliny the elder which was new to me as an east coaster... Decor was nice...bartender was very helpful in picking my meal and recommeded other restaurants for my stay.

I would definitely come back next time I'm in town.
author: Mike R.

description:
time for an update.  This place is a freaking well oiled machine!  It's so packed and so yummy.

So they have BBQ out back you can take to go.

or you can power lunch it and get in and out in exactly one hour.  It's like they know somehow that you only have an hour. Oh wait they probably do, since EVERYONE in here dining is in a suit.

My iced tea was refilled over 4 times. I had on black slacks and my white napkin was traded in for a black one without asking.  The food was delivered promptly and it was delicious....It ALWAYS is. Always.

and can we take a little timeout to just squeal over those little jalapeno cornbreads served in a ladyfinger baking tray??  Oh yes and the Tuna Tartare with fried green tomatoes?  It was a match made in heaven.  

I love you town hall.  Pretty please can you come to Marin???
author: Jackie M.

description:
Finally!  This place is no longer the most reserved restaurant on Opentable!  Maybe because the food is unimaginative and the service aloof at best?  Or maybe because it's so LOUD in there that, when I'm ordering, I feel like I'm in the middle of Dave Chappelle's "A Day in the Life of Lil Jon" skit???

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iLFtEp1v9cE

Waiter: "Are you ready to order?"
GK: "WHAT?"
Waiter: "Are you ready to order?"
GK: "WHAT?"
Waiter: "Are you ready to order?"
GK: "OKAAAAAAAAAY!"

GK: "I'll have the pork chop."
Waiter: "WHAT?"
GK: "The pork chop."
Waiter: "WHAT?"
GK: "The pork chop?"
Waiter: "YEAAAAAAAHHHH!!!!!!"

Waiter: "Sometimes when I'm alone, I sit on my hand, wait til it gets numb and masturbate. I call that the stranger."
GK: "Yeah, I've done that."

Well, okay, that didn't happen.  But anyway, I find the food here quite boring and I just can't stomach the decibel level.  A varied and affordable wine list, but that can't save this place.  I simply do not understand the popularity of this place, although its location is good for FiDi entertaining and accessible to B&T getting off at Fremont Street.  

OKAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAYYYYYYYYYYYYY!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Geoff K.

description: Liked it. Not much too say. Food was good. Loud and cozy atmosphere.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Recently I went to Town Hall for a dinner with the bf. 

Here's the deal: 
Town Hall offers an array of modern American dishes as well as traditional Southern fare. I ordered the pan seared scallops and they were perfectly cooked and paired with butternut squash puree. I highly recommend this dish. We also wanted to try something different so we opted for a side of the smoked andouille jambalaya. It was good, but my main dish was definitely the star! 

Overall, great, attentive service and nice ambiance. Since we ate there close to Halloween they showcased a nice, festive spin on lighting: creative jackolanterns all aglow.
author: Lauren T.

description:
I came to Town Hall after a few merry hours of drinking at 83 Proof (my favorite bar in SOMA). I was on a long streak of caipirinhas so I ordered one when our waitress came by to take our order. It came quickly and I drank it down fast -- too fast. I noticed that when I'd finished the drink there was still ice brimming over the top of the glass. When our waitress came back again, I requested another caipirinha. I asked for a larger one or just less ice and I mentioned that I wouldn't mind paying more for it. 

A few minutes later the bartender came over to talk to me. "Is there a problem?" she asked. "No," I said, "I'd just like a bit more drink in the next one." She proceeded to list off the ingredients in a caiprinha -- cachaça, lime juice and sugar -- as if I didn't know what's in a drink that I frequently order. "I know," I replied, "I'd just like more of those ingredients." Then, seemingly, there was a breakthrough. "I could put less ice in the next one?" she asked helpfully. I smiled in approval thinking I'd finally got the message across. What happened next was simply ludicrous. When my next drink arrived the cocktail glass was half full of liquid with a small amount of partially melted ice in it. I actually laughed at the absurdity of it. The rest of my group was amused as well. It was borderline unbelievable that they could present that drink to me straight-faced.

Let me pose a question. For a restaurant that charges $12 for toast and $20 for fried chicken, would it really be an enormous travesty for my cocktail to contain more than exactly one ounce of liquor? We had about fifteen people in our group and probably spent $700 or $800 there (I don't know the exact bill since one member of our party graciously picked up the entire tab). Shouldn't I get a drink made however I want for those prices? If I were the owner of Town Hall it would certainly be worth it to me to spare a few cents worth of rum rather than serve a ridiculous insult to my patrons.

In short, the cheese toast was good but I won't be rushing back to spend $12 on it. The fried chicken was good but nothing special -- any professional chef should be able to make decent fried chicken. The incompetent bartending, however, means I'll be avoiding Town Hall like the plague.
author: Aaron V.

description:
I'm sure other people who have visited Town Hall must have really had a good experience. Unfortunately, I can't say the same happened for me. I took an out of town guest here (it was my first time as well as hers) and I really wanted to like the place.

I don't think our waiter was bad in any way, rather he just took our order and brought us our food. I would call him "aloof." You have to do alot more to give great service than just taking down orders and bringing plates to the table. 

The jambalaya was overly salty and actually somewhat mushy (it's a side dish). I wondered if the waiter didn't like us and added salt to the plate before bringing it to the table. The fried oysters were good, but the bright green sauce on the bottom didn't add anything at all. The waiter didn't even ask how we liked the food. Everything else was just mediocre and we didn't even eat dessert here since the rest of the meal wasn't really spectacular.

I should have stuck it safe with the fried chicken, or other restaurants I know are always good.
author: Lindsey H.

description:
Excellent spot.

Fantastic humm of the patrons chatting, laughing, sharing stories and imbibing.

Perfect location - a short walk from my dinner companions apartment made for even a rainy night walk pleasant.

The staff are all very nice, informative and willing to 'work with you' on any substitutions you may desire.  Good to know I'm not the only tough one to please... ;)

Flexible.  We had dinner reservations for 8:30p, but due to my inherent issues with being anywhere on time, we didn't show up until 9p.  Not a problem - they had our table ready!  5 stars!!!

As my dinner date said, "you really want to hate this place, but you just can't."  Hmmmmm I thought.  Why might that be?  Is it that the food is dubbed as American Comfort food?  I dunno.  Maybe.  But it is quite delish.  Is it because there is always a crowd?  I dunno.  Maybe.  But then again, who wants to hear the sound of the knife hitting the plate at the only other table at the restaurant?  And just as he spouted that out he also said "See, you just can't dislike Town Hall.  For some reason, it's just too good."  I agree (even though I didn't walk in trying to dislike it ... That's just not in my DNA ... Okay, well sometimes it is ... But not this time.

Enough of the blabbing and down to the nitty gritty ...

I had the rainbow trout wrapped in bacon with green beans.  Need I say more -- bacon!!  The only thing, personally, I would change about this dish was the fact that the fish comes pretty much whole - well, no head, but the tail is there ... And the skin.  I'd prefer neither.  Not that it stopped me from eating - the fish was soo moist and all the flavors and aromas of the prep and cooking seeped into the tender fish.  Definitely a 5 star here!

My dinner date had the Pork Chop, substituted the fruity accompaniment with the long grain rice.  Personally, I think this substitution was excellent!  The pork chop was moist to the taste and full of delicious flavor!

Sadly we didn't try a dessert - we reached our maximum food intake.  And while I tried to order the Hot Chocolate, they were out?...  Boo!  Guess that's what happens when the weather drops to 39 degrees with rain around here!  Next time - for sure!
author: Nicole Rynee B.

description:
What a beautiful restaurant!! The decor/ambiance is very warm and has sort of a holiday-ish feel to it without the cheesyness.

I came in yesterday for lunch and had such a phenomenal time. The service is great and attentive, all smiles from both front and back of house employees. 

The food itself is also great. We started off with two cups of butternut squash soup which was rich and creamy. They garnished the soup with pomegranite seeds, julienned persimmons, and even some balsamic. For our entree's my cousin had a butter lettuce salad with bleu cheese dressing and ahi tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes and jalapeno cream. I didn't get to try the salad or the tartare but I had a couple sliced of the tomato and it was TASTY!!! For my entree I had a lemon-seared sole with chorizo-y risotto. I never order fish but it sounded so good and it was! 

For dessert we had coffee [comes in a french press so points for cuteness] and the "coffee and donuts" aka espresso ice cream, cookie crumbly bits, and beignets. Dessert was also very, very good. 

There is a fair amount of street parking during lunch hours BUT it'll cost you $3.50-$3.75 an hour at the meters :(
author: Grace C.

description:
My measure of a great waiter is one that knows good food and is willing to share his or her knowledge with the customer.  Apollo was the perfect waiter.  Friendly and nice, and when asked to pick the superior of two dishes he answers quickly and decisively.  

Fondue or seared tuna? FONDUE!
Trout or etoufee?  ETOUFEE!
Short ribs or steak?  SHORT RIBS!
Fried Chicken or petrale sole?  FRIED CHICKEN!
Butterscotch pot de creme or bread pudding?  POT DE CREME!

Lovely atmosphere and great food.  I had the duck etoufee and the richness of the dish was oh so satifying on a rainy night.  Apollo's decisiveness was well appreciated by me and my friends.  I cannot wait to go back!
author: Nat H.

description:
Someone get me a corset...I am going to need it soon the way I've been eating.

So it wasn't enough to eat at Koi Palace on Sunday, but, it being a good friend's birthday, we had lunch at Town Hall.  The entrees look small on the very large plates, but they are certainly filling.

So, what did I have: the tri tip in a soy marinade and thin slices of maybe turnip.  The tri tip was good, but nothing to swoon over.

One of my friends had the pork tenderloin which turned out to be a structure with potato fingerlings at the bottom, pork tenderloin, chard, mushrooms, and pork slivers on top.  Really lovely sauce drizzled over the whole thing.

My other friend had the Atlantic char.  But what was amazing about her entree was the grits with spring garlic.  Just the creamiest grits ever...and I've made grits before with a whole cupful of heavy cream in it, but this beat out any grits I've tasted.  I don't want to know how much heavy cream and butter they put into it.  I could easily eat a large bowl of those grits and be content...well okay, maybe the grits and some of those lovely slivers of pork.  If only they would serve that as an entree.

Desserts: we got the chocolate chiffon cake and sticky toffee cake to share.  The chocolate chiffon cake slice was large, but nothing to extol.  Get the sticky toffee cake.  It's like having a cake drenched in hot melted toffee.  

God help me, I am going back next week for another friend's birthday....soon, I will need a giant shoe horn to fit me into my clothes.
_____

Update: I went back for lunch with Arnold G. and ordered their fish and chips.  I have to say that the fish was quite tasty, but I think it's the most I've paid for fish and chips (which I tend to think of as solid Irish bar food).  Another weird thing: if you get reserve a regular table, it's louder than the communal table (where I was seated for my meal above).  Town Hall really needs to reconsider its interior design in terms of acoustics.  

But let me state again: that Sticky Toffee Pudding is culinary genius!  Get it.  You want it.  You must have it.
______
Upate again:
Their prime rib comes on a really nice puree of white beans.  However, if you like medium rare, order rare.  I am not sure when all the categories of steak doneness has changed...it seems no restaurant does rare anymore.  I ordered rare, and it was really medium rare.

Mississippi Mud Pie: Fantastic when you are craving chocolate that is even more intense in richness than chocolate.  Beautiful little ice cream bon bons garnished with a small puff of marshmallow top the mud pie...which is two very intense chocolate fudgy brownie layers separated by a layer of marshmallow.  Divine chocolate fulfillment.
author: Sooj O.

description:
There's a reason I was [by far] the youngest person in this joint:
The Price Tag.

During my lunch there with a older (read: richer) family friend, I spotted my boss.  He was actually wincing as he perused the short but tasty menu.  And this guy owns Patagonia Clothing, Esprit Clothing, and a good portion of Paraguay.

Price aside, the food was pretty good.  Mine at least.  I had a trout wrapped in bacon with green beans and beets ($17).  We also split a salad that had a little too much raddiccio and some bomb jalapeno cornbread, which turned out to be the shape (and size) of baby corn.  Clever.
BUT GIVE ME MORE!!!

Hers was a pulled pork sandwich that looked very -eeehhhh- and cost about 15 clams.  I win.  I'd eat here again, but wouldn't pay for it.  The menu didn't really have anything that set my tastebuds into overdrive, but a joint like that probably changes their menu frequently.

It's fancy and good for impressing people, but overrated.
author: Mari C.

description:
My experience here was very acceptable however a bit disappointing.

I drove, expecting Valet, but there was none.  I was bit put off before I found a parking spot outside of the restaurant. I'm not sure if it is usually this easy.

We were promptly seated and assisted with drinks.  My company seemed very satisfied with the bar selection.  I was happy because they had good ginger beer.

For appetizers we had the BBQ Shrimp, Oysters, and Meatballs.  All of these were quite delicious, especially the BBQ Shrimp.  The sauce was very tangy and succulent.  It had a lot of flavor, which set a high expectation for my entree.

I ordered the Fried Chicken for dinner, and this was very well cooked, but lacking flavor.  I was expecting much more quality of taste for 23 dollars.  Perhaps it was missing the amount of gravy I desired?  The collard greens were decent, still missing the flavor I would imagine from Southern cooking like this.

Service was friendly, quick, and attentive.  

I doubt I will go back because of high prices and lackluster taste of my entree.
author: Peter G.

description:
I've been here twice: once a few months ago, and again last week with some co-workers.

Last week I made a reservation for six for lunch and was required to leave a credit card number (you must do this for a party greater than 5).  Not too happy about that.  We had reservations at 11:30 and were seated promptly, given menus and asked for drinks within a reasonable time period.

After drinks and bread came, the waiter disappeared for about 15 minutes.  Our waiter took our order, and we waited for probably another 15 minutes before he came by again to check on drinks.  He came by a third time to give us free cornbread while explaining that the kitchen was "having trouble."  Long story short, we sat down at about 11:35 and didn't get our food till 12:40.

The food here is good, but I don't like waiting an hour for food, least of all when I have to get back to work.
author: Em S.

description:
I went to a great Mardi Gras party here sponsored by the A-List (go Val!).  The food was very good, the crowd fun and the live music upbeat.  Considering how much I enjoyed it, I'm surprised I haven't been back for a meal.  

Town is a great spot for a drink and a meal, but there's nothing too impressive about the ambience.   If you're looking for solid come here, if you want something a little exciting head over to Americano where you can take in the views and have sit on the patio.
author: John M.

description:
I've wanted to come here for a while (let's just say I have a looooong list of restaurants to visit in SF), so I was glad when my friends said they wanted to check out some eats in SOMA on a Friday night.  

We went to 83 Proof for a cosmo before coming here - a good idea since our reservations (which we wanted to be for 8pm) could not be scheduled until 9:15!  Our waitress was attentive, but not exceptionally friendly.  My friend's napkin was picked up and folded for her each time she left the table.  Waters were constantly filled.

We did notice that the prices on the menu were about $4-6 higher than what is listed online - bad form.  The food, however, was very excellent.  Among the three of us, we got the fried chicken (had to), the fried mac and cheese (I MUST learn to make this!!), the seafood bisque-y soup, and I got the bone-in pork chop.  The chop was encrusted with flavorful nuts and spices and teetered atop a bed of spinach and butternut squash.  The chop itself was in-effing-credible.  The butternut squash was hard to maneuver since the skin was still on.

THANK YOU, Yelpers, for steering us directly to the butterscotch pot de creme for dessert.  While you could easily label this as butterscotch and chocolate pudding, in all my years as a consumer of various hospital and nursing home pudding there is NOTHING like this one.  Melt-in-your-mouth, heaven-in-a-bowl, creamy-as-all-get-out pudding.  The bits of toffee piercing the surface added an exceptional crunch and fantastic flavor.  I will try to duplicate it at home, but I already know it's a futile attempt.

mmmmm HMMMMM!
author: Laura B.

description:
three weeks later and i'm still fantasizing about the grilled steak. i'm not even a steak person and yet my obsession has reached slightly unhealthy levels.

the steak came in some crazy sauce (red pepper sauce, to be exact) that was both sweet and salty, and the meat was so tender that it almost quite literally melted in puddles around my fork. 

before drool short-circuits my keyboard i would like to add that i took away a star because the other three things we got (crispy okra, tuna tartare, and grilled mahi-mahi) were just OK.
author: cecilia y.

description: Southern inspired dishes with a modern twist...loved the food and the overall aesthetic...highly recommend! Definitely get the red velvet cake, it's amazing!
author: Jane G.

description:
Talk about a near-disaster.  This review was almost a 2 star, but I am glad to report it as a four-star with a major story involved!  My wife and I met my brother and his wife for a long overdue dinner on Saturday.  We arrived a bit early for our 7:30 reservation and got a nice 4-top table in the middle of the ground floor.  I ordered a bottle of Bordeaux for us (more on that later). 

Based on Yelp reviews, for appetizers we got two orders of the shrimp.  My advice - skip the shrimp and just eat the artery-clogging bread that is soaked in the sauce UNDERNEATH the shrimp - wow is it FANTASTIC!!   

Three of us had a glass of the Bordeaux poured so we could drink it with our appetizers.  Our waitress, seeing a crowded table told us, "I am going to put this bottle of wine on the window ledge over here so you have room."  One of us joked back, "make sure nothing happens to it!"  Her reply was, "I will keep my eye on it!"

So, of course, about 10 minutes later, an employee managed to knock over our bottle of wine.  AHHHHH!  Even worse, he knocked it over the back of a woman wearing a white outfit...  Double-AHHHHHH!  Even worse, when our waitress came running over, we told her "our bottle was spilled", and she replied, "Oh no, it was not your wine, it was wine from her glass."

Stunned into silence, at this point, our dining experience was toast (and no, not that YUMMY toast with the shrimp...).  My brother and I both began deep breathing exercises and assumed our waitress would realize her mistake, but no, we ended up only getting a glass each out of the bottle.

Back to the food:  the entrees came, and they were excellent.  The bone-in pork chop was an incredible meat-eater feast with wonderful flavors from the grits and some green stuff that may have been a vegetable.  Fantastic.

Back to the wine:  after the entrees, not seeing any change, my brother (go Dan!) attracted the attention of the manager and told him what had happened.  He was nearly as stunned as we were by the service flubbing.  He offered us another bottle of wine, but we refused since we were done (except for dessert).  He profusely apologized and sent our waitress over to apologize as well.

We accepted their apology, and ordered the dessert.  Faithfully sticking to Yelp standards, I got the butterscotch pudding (whatever they call it).  It was great.  The chocolate cake across the table was not as good.  Stick with the butterscotch.

The save:  the manager came over again after dessert, apologized again, and comped us on the wine and desserts.  He really was horrified, and did a great job of convincing us that Town Hall does not usually operate that way.    His sincerity was obvious, and his handling of the check was the right thing to do.  In short, he took a near-disaster of a griping, negative experience and turned it into a very good dinner.  We will be back.  And we will NOT let the waitress put the wine on the window sill!!!!!
author: Patrick G.

description:
My shweetie took me here and it was SO ...especial.  Not just because  the fried green tomatoes were so light and non greasy and DELIGHTFUL on mi lengua, and the apple beignets with prosciutto were DELISH, and the jalapeno cornbread fingers are just DARLING....But particularly because my late-20-something crush CONAN O'freakin BRIEN was sitting at the table next to us, with his cute lil elfish smile. *SIGH* (Oh but E-DUB you are SOOOO much cuter my love!)
Entrees were rib eye (fatty, but juicy) with heavenly baked potato and almost inedible wilted greens, AND the pork chop (tasty but a bit too rare) wih mustard greens and creamy mashed taters. 
Do not waste your time with the butterscotch/chocolate pot de creme.  Have a glass of port or ice wine instead.
author: Joyhan S.

description:
T earfully delicious barbeque shrimp
O rgasmic veal meatballs (sorry baby cow)
W atchful service that didn't miss a beat
N umerous visits in my future - I hope

H elpful waitress who recommended amazing food
A stonishing amounts of flavor throughout all the dishes
L uminous atmosphere with cool chandeliers
L ove is all I have for this place
author: Derek B.

description:
So, I have this thing... I can't really eat desserts unless I have milk with it.  If you put a plate of cookies in front of me with no milk, I wouldn't eat one cookie until I have milk.  Usually when I order a dessert at a restaurant I ask for a glass of milk and the server (and whoever I'm with) look at me strange and think I'm joking.  Then they realize I'm serious.  I don't know why this is so bizarre, but it never fails to garner peculiar looks.  Well, Town Hall has come to my rescue... they have a chocolate cake dessert that comes with a shot of milk.  I can now order dessert, get my milk and not look like I'm regressing back to childhood... thus fooling my date just a little longer than I am in fact a normal mature well adjusted adult male.

So, aside from the GENIUS dessert pairing, you can't go wrong with Town Hall.  It is a bit loud, so you'll find yourself shouting across the table to be heard.  On this visit to Town Hall I had the pork chops, which were quite good.  However, they were no match to the pork chops I had a NOPA a couple weeks ago.

I've been to Town Hall a few times now and each time was a good experience.
author: Jeff S.

description: Came at 7:45 for 8pm reservations. Sat at the bar while waiting, then got seated at 8:15. Ordered and appetizers came out with a medium wait time but food didnt come till 9:05. Service was kind of slow and waiter wasnt too helpful or familiar with the menu. Ordered the fried chicken, jambalaya, fried oysters, corn chowder. Food was alright. Chicken was nice and tender, the rest was pretty ok...Main complaint is that it was way too loud. I felt like I was yelling across the table to my fiance the whole dinner. the waiter couldnt even hear me when he was taking the order. not really a place you want to take a date....but ok for loud groups/ hanging with friends.
author: Ratigon L.

description:
3.5 Stars.

Meal consisted of the Tuna Tartare app, Filet Mignon and the Butterscotch & Chocolate Pot de Creme.

The Tuna Tartare was good but not really memorable.  The Filet Mignon was amazingly tender and it was served with the creamiest mashed potatoes.  Again good but not great. 

So the meal at this point was so-so... 

Then the Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Creme came out.  Holy Crap that was day-am good!  Its like a creamy cup of nostalgia.  Remember those plastic cup of butterscotch pudding your mom used to pack for you for lunch? (Ok, being Asian my mom never packed me one of those but they looked darn good and I've had a spoonful here and there thanks to some charitable friends... Thanks Billy.)  The dessert saved the meal thats for sure.  I highly recommend it.

Service was excellent - polite, and attentive staff.
author: Alex P.

description:
I am quite impressed with Town Hall after my first visit last night.  The food was great, a lovely wine selection, and a tasteful, classic atmosphere (exposed brick walls, white boards, and golden gate bridge colored supports along the back wall).  

After reading a ridiculously large number of Yelp reviews commenting on the noise level - I was expecting it to be nearly deafening inside, but now I suspect that maybe this frequent comment is a result of the echo chamber (or maybe I just had a good table).  Either way, the noise level is no more than should be expected at a normal, popular restaurant.  

Most importantly, the food was fantastic.  Kasey ordered the slow roasted duck, and having a bite or three or four of her entree, I can avow that this dish is a culinary juggernaut - sweet, savory and tender.  

Because I was in the mood for something light, I ordered the sea scallops.  I was a little concerned that the sea scallops (a delicate, light food stuff) were being served on top of an andouille jambalaya.  In my mind, that pairing seems something less than obvious.  I'd normally expect the spicy jambalaya to overpower the taste of the sea scallops.  Here, the dish certainly walked a fine line, and I felt the jambalaya was definitely in danger of overpowering the sea scallops.  Nonetheless, I was pleased with my dish, and wouldn't hesitate to order it again.  

Oh, and if you like chocolate - you'll love their chocolate cake.
author: Matthew H.

description:
A romantic weekend in the city began with dinner at Town Hall.  A nice, comfortable place to start.  Not overly noisy, but with plenty of "buzz" in the air. 

Our waiter was a very nice young man, friendly and attentive, but not so we thought he was going to ask us to come over to his house or become best buddies.  

We started with some reasonably priced cocktails ($7.00 for a Beefeater Martini and $8.00 for a Stolichnya Martini) both well made and brought promptly.  We opened our dinner with their Stuffed Peppers ($15.00) delish, and a Grilled Lamb Carpaccio ($15.00) a nice twist on the good old Beef Carpaccio.  For our entree my hubby had the Etoufee ($29.00) a nice assortment of fish, but I thought there could have been more; I had their FAMOUS Fried Chicken ($23.00) a delicious half chicken that was fried to perfection.  Along with this they served a mashed potatoes (I love mashed potatoes) and "bacon gravy" misstep.  If I was to have this dish again, I would ask for the gravy on the side.  First of all, it tasted to me like Cambell's Bean with Bacon soup, and that on mashed potatoes does not sound like good eats.  And it over-powered the potatoes, all I could taste was the gravy.  So order it "on the side".  The Panna Cotta ($9.00) was, Panna Cotta.  I mean it is what it is.  

LindySez: I'd go back.  And the fact that they waived our corkage on the wine we brought in gives them an extra "yeah" from me.
author: Lindy B.

description:
Town Hall

-noun) a hall or building belonging to a town, used for the transaction of the town's business and often also as a place of public assembly.  

A city hall or town hall is the headquarters of a city or town's administration and usually houses the city or town council, its associated departments and their employees. It is also usually the base of the city, town, borough, or county mayor.
+ + + + + +
Since I found nothing quite noteworthy with regards the food and/ or service at Town Hall - with the exception of it's unnecessary pretentiousness - I figured a true definition of a town hall was in order.  Thank you Wikipedia!

The Tuna Tar-Tare was okay.  It's served with Fried Green Tomatoes, which I always had wanted to try.  They were drizzled with some type of creamy Tabasco-esque sauce...not completely unlike the sauce found on Burger King's Spicy Tendercrisp Chicken Sandwich.  Is this an endorsement?  I dunno - you decide.  

The jalapeno cornbread was next to impossible to remove from its cutesy little baking pan.  It was, however, adorable to look at.

The greatest disappointment for me was the fillet Mignon cheese steak sandwich.  It was about as bland as my sex life.

As a Town Hall usually houses the city or town council (see above) - I thought it a good idea to look around for my local government representatives so I could formally lodge a complaint.  Alas, none to be found.  What else is new?  They were probably all at Burger King.
author: Mc Matty b.

description: Not a culinary adventure, but a staid SF classic. We started with the oysters (perfect) and I soon moved on to a juicy steak. A fine piece of medium rare flesh was delivered at the optimal temperature; piping hot. I wrapped up my flawless meal with a cup of the "ultimate hot chocolate" a glass of liquid Scharffen Berger...  Mr. & Mrs. Town Hall, we will certainly be back.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
***2 Days Later***
Upgrading to a full 4 stars after its sister restaurant, Salt House, has under delivered my expectations.

***ORIGINAL REVIEW 9/16/07***
3.5 stars and rounding up just because their veal meatball was the best I'd had so far.

I only give 5 stars to restaurants that I volunteer to dine again.  So I'm perfectly fine with never returning to Town Hall, but it is for sure a safe bet.  If you want to eat quality modern American food in SOMA without spending Boulevard amount, this is the place.

I didn't think their wine list was impressive, so I suggest to pay a $20 corkage and bring your own bottle.

P.S. Stick to their non-seafood dishes.
author: Mami T.

description:
FINALLY enjoyed this place because I'm not on a diet!

This was my FIFTH time to Town Hall, but the FIRST time I enjoyed myself because I wasn't boring and didn't just order a freakin salad. 

I take my consultants here for lunch every now and then and today (even though you lost my reservations, oops) it was incredible... our waiter was great (so cute and patient with my non stop questions) and food delicious - ahi tuna with fried green tomatoes, beer battered fish/chips (OMG) and salmon were excellent. 

Will definitely return again (but once summer is over my diet returns... so I probably won't see you until the spring... ).

***THIS IS AN UPDATE*** Sept. 21st

Alright so I'm back on my annoying diet but that's not why I was perturbed:

I went to Town Hall again today for lunch with a group of 3... of course everything was delicious (healthy salmon with fresh veggies, corn chowder soup, ceviche, and the salad with figs *not crazy about the butter lettuce salad, for some reason it didn't do much for me*) and our host was very friendly.

BUT our waitress I think completely forgot about us in the end... we sat there for a good 10 minutes after she cleared away our plates with nothing.. no check, no dessert menu, no water... all we had were our napkins. Even after we flagged down our host (who left to go look for the waitress) it was a good 5 minutes until she appeared without so much as a care in the world.

Tip TH- most people who lunch during the weekday are workers and have a strict 1 hour time limit... please don't leave your patrons twiddling their thumbs wondering where the check is. Or if delays happen (I understand it gets busy sometimes but it was 1:45 and the crowd had basically left) just apologize to recognize the inconvenience it caused. I'm not asking for a free appetizer, discount, etc... just a quick explanation. That's all.

And now that's it's the end of the day I realize I was too nice... I tipped her my customary 20% and in retrospect I really should have tipped lower.

***UPDATE TO MY UPDATE***
ok, I've been back 3 more times since the last and have not experienced any of the previous delays... I think the key is making sure you get a reserved table and don't sit in the Communal Table, or if you do be prepared for a long-ggg wait... anyway, they changed their menu (again, yum!) and we had the fish tacos (no that was the last time).... eggplant sandwich, crab louie salad (um, that looked delicious but a little small, thank god I don't rely on foul weeds for my nourishment), and of course the tuna w/ fried green tomatoes.

Can't wait to check out the newest sister restaurant! :)
author: Nenette Y.

description:
Yelp you deceived me. Coming back from New Orleans I was hoping to find the great food I found in the pictures. Unfortunately, this was not the case when we ate here at Town Hall. I overheard another waiter saying, they changed their menu. no doughnuts, no blacked catfish served with jambalaya, no gumbo, no grits, and no oyster po'boy.

We arrive on time for our reservation. The hostess was nice, inviting, and sat us promptly. Our waitress was not as inviting. In fact I don't think she smiled once. Our appetizer, the fried oysters, came out fast and was very good. However, the main courses took a really long time. We ordered the chicken, which was moist and crunchy but I've tasted better. The jambalaya was a side and was good.  The drinks were good. We asked for our food to be boxed up and requested the sauce and the waitress never put it in the bag. Overall, Town Hall would be great for drinks, but the service bumps it down to a two stars.
author: Amy M.

description:
This place serves up some tasty food.  I actually went here like a year ago but forgot to review the dang hot cocoa!  :)

FOOD
Went here simply to have the croque-madame.  It was fantastic and only like 10 bones.  God bless.

HOT COCOA
IMO - it's too much... I LOVE hot cocoa but this was like a soup.  Actually starts off pretty exciting like (ummm ummm chocolate) and as I got 1/3 of the way down... I just couldn't drink anymore.  That's not a quality I admire in my hot cocoa... I want to be able to finish the whole cup!  Oh, that may be part of it as well.  The portion was comically large!  It was like being served cocoa in an Udon bowl.
author: Dan M.

description:
This restaurant and I went through a roller coaster of stars today... 

At first, I wanted to give them a low rating, because they "lost" our reservation, but our host was very nice, and seated us as soon as he could during the crazy lunch hour, so I can't chew him out for that (he later "found" our reservation and apologized, which I thought was really courteous also).

Then, their rating came crashing down again, because we had to wait 20 minutes for our food to arrive and I was starrrrvinggggg (I ate three pieces of bread waiting for my "warm ham & cheese toast")! 

So, at this point, I'm not sure how accurate my rating is, because I was so hungry, gum would have gotten five stars. But seriously, I really did enjoy my sandwich. It came swimming in a dish of jalapeno cream sauce with a perfectly poached egg sitting on top. The bread was soggy, but in a good way. The ham was a little salty, but that's just how ham is supposed to taste. All in all, I loved my dish, but I was also envious of my co worker's order of "battered fish & chips," because she had heaps of fries (my plate was so measly compared to hers!). Bless her heart, she shared some of her fish and fries with me, it was delicious (next time, I'm going to get that, fo' sho'). 

We also had dessert and I cannot for the life of me remember the name of it, but it was basically vanilla ice-cream with bread pudding. Excellent. I couldn't have asked for a better meal...oh wait, I also didn't have to pay for it (on the company's tab!). YES! FIVE STARS ALL THE WAY!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I'd heard mixed reviews about Town Hall, but my experience last night brushed those skeptics aside and moved Town Hall to quite possibly my favorite restaurant in SF yet.  The ambiance was reminiscent of my former stomping grounds in Boston, with lots of exposed red brick and a handful of communal tables (though there were private tables too).  The best thing by far, however, was our food.  

The group of us started out with the tuna tartar, BBQ/Cajun shrimp and the veal meatballs.  All were heavenly in their own unique way, but the shrimp was the star of the evening. After we had finished everything on the plate we proceeded to dip our bread in the sauce, which was some kind of creole/southern mixture - so good. For an entre I had the seared scallops with barley and some kind of beer/butter mixture, which was quite filling but worth every calorie.   For dessert we had the butterscotch and chocolate pots de crme... again - so good!  I can't wait to go back!
author: Nicole C.

description:
Great Southern comfort food with a Californian twist. Checked this place out for our anniversary dinner. Made it another year baby! It was my first visit, the wife's second and I must say I was impressed by the food & service. I love Southern Cajun food so this was just up my alley. 
We started off with the tuna tar tar. Wow super good we could eat this all day every day!
Fried oysters was next on the list and while I enjoyed it the wife was a little skeptical of the after taste.
For our entree she had the world famous pork chops and after I bit into a piece it was the juiciest pork chop I've ever had! YUM!
I had their popular fried chicken, also very good. Perfectly fried and seasoned.
To finish off the night we ordered the caramel pot de creme. It was alright in our opinion, my advice skip it. 
Our service was excellent and he even surprised us with an extra dessert plate consisting of 3 mini cupcakes with congratulations written on the plate. 
This is a must place to check out if you're into southern food. They even have a private room upstairs for your special events.
author: T L.

description: Tasty american fare ,personable staff and hip ambiance. Wine list could use some improvement. RECOMMENDED ITEMS: Watermelon And Yellow Pear Tomato Salad  and Buttermilk fried chicken
author: aj s.

description:
This perennial Open Table hotspot is brought to you by the Rosenthal brothers, the same fine people who brought you Salt House.  Just like Salt House, this restaurant is housed in a very cool building - the historic Marine Electric warehouse, built after the 1906 earthquake.  

Food:  5 stars.   This place fails to disappoint, unless you are a vegetarian.  The menu changes frequently, but I wouldn't mind if the following dishes were mainstays:  the bbq shrimp, squash blossom, and tuna tartare (where the accompanying fried green tomatoes actually outshone the tuna) as appetizers and the buttermilk fried chicken, pork chop, and ribeye as entrees.  I also tried the heirloom tomato salad and mushroom risotto and have this to say:  IT SUCKS TO BE A VEGETARIAN!!!  The desserts were all good, especially the chocolate and butterscotch pot de creme and toffee cake (I'm a big sucker for toffee).

Service:  5 stars.  Unlike Salt House, you're likely to get unpretentious good service at Town Hall.  Our server happened to be Sayid from the ABC show "Lost."  Clearly, Sayid must have thought his show was in trouble (first half of season 3, anyone?), so he got this second job as insurance.  Sayid was spot on in his recommendations for appetizers and entrees (hello, bbq shrimp!) and was polite, courteous and engaging throughout the entire meal service.  

Atmosphere:  5 stars.  The restaurant is appropriately housed in an historic electric warehouse with natural brick walls, ebony floors, perfect lighting, and beautiful spidery chandeliers.  The restaurant attracts primarily a 20-40 something GQ crowd.  Don't drink too much, because getting to the bathroom is a trek.  You may not make it if you have a sudden attack of diarrhea.

Hits:  BBQ shrimp, squash blossom, buttermilk fried chicken, chocolate and butterscotch pot de creme.

Misses:  Mushroom risotto, bathroom breaks.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Salt House, Nopa, Zuni Cafe
author: Keith C.

description:
Town Hall is a good restaurant.  Not  destination dining great, but good.  But good in the right ways: mix of SOMA residents & suits in after work mode (ie: more congenial than douchebag), helpful staff, attentive bartenders, decent drink menu and a good dinner menu.

If short ribs are on the menu of a restaurant 9 times out of 10 I will order it and the short ribs at Town Hall are a winner: comforting, tender & savory.  Both of my co-workers had the Fried Chicken and cleaned their plates.  I had a bit and thought the chicken good but salty.  We all  *tried* to share the pork appetizer but its not meant for sharing.

Side note: Town Hall has, queue scary music... the ubiquitous communal table.  Am I the only person who wishes this restaurant trend would die... right along with truffle oil everything?

Short Ribs Rating: 4 stars
Fried Chicken Rating: 3.5 stars
author: Natasha R.

description:
This is a great restaurant by the same group that owns Anchor and Hope and the other one that I can't wait to try.  I LOVED my halibut entree here, and the generous portion of butterscotch pot de creme.  

I was really disappointed by my tuna tartare starter, which was soaked in some unappetizing vinaigrette.  Tuna should be dressed very lightly, if at all.  I got a few slices of fried green tomatoes along with the tartare.  These were well made with cornmeal.  I wish there was more of the aioli to dip them.  

Anchor and Hope is my favorite so far, but I am a seafood fan.  Town Hall is a safe choice to take out of towners who would like a taste of San Francisco.
author: Amy D.

description:
As is the case with most fine dining establishments in the City, I expected Town Hall to offer relatively small plates. Was I wrong...

I left this place happily full and fully satisfied. 

First of all, I urge you to arrive long enough before your reservation to have a drink at the bar. Town Hall is usually lively, which makes having a drink before dinner a pleasure. The hostess who seated us was very polite and promptly sought out my friend and me when our table was ready. Decent beer selection on tap and nice bartenders, too.

Now to the food. As an appetizer, I had the crab cake, which was seasoned just so and was light and delicious. I highly recommend it.

For an entree I ordered the short ribs which were tender and (I'm going to use a word rarely used to describe meat) DECADENT. You're missing out if you don't get them, or at least steal a bite of them from someone else's plate at the table. 

For wine, our waiter had the decency to tell us outright which wines stood out, and which we should avoid. if i remember correctly, he recommended a fine California Cab'Sauv. 

As far as desserts, I can say that the menu looked enticing, but I made the mistake of going with the hot chocolate. This was a bad choice. I mean, they do advertise it as the world's best cup of hot cocoa or something, but I mean seriously...end of the day, it's just an over-priced cup of hot chocolate. And it was also cold (even after I requested that the kitchen heat it up). That being said, I would encourage you to try one of the many tasty-sounding selections from the dessert menu; I'm sure you'll be getting a good deal with another item.

As for the service: punctual, friendly, and cooperative. Works just fine for me! 

In closing, you have to go to Town Hall. It's reputation suits it well.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Our server was nowhere to be found for the first 15 minutes we were seated. We weren't even offered water or drinks. When he finally did appear, he brought the cocktail list (oh, so they do have one! why wasn't it left with the menus?) that listed some pretty bizarre combinations, including a gin-based drink called The Big Easy -- um, gin? New Orleans? -- and a margarita-like tequila concotion made with cointreau, lime juice, and Falernum. They all sounded so poorly conceived that we stuck with wines by the glass.

My starter was Smithfield ham and cheese toast with jalapeno cream.... which really tasted like something you'd get at TGI Friday's. It was positively sodden with pepper-infused bechamel (interesting but about 10 times the amount needed) and sprinkled with cold, flabby rings of jalapenos that had been breaded in the style of fried green tomatoes. My husband's appetizer, billed as "barbeque shrimp" was also served on toast, also with a drenching of sauce. He definitely got the worse end of the deal: his pool of brown sauce tasted of nothing except salt and worcestershire. Ew.

My main was a peanut-and-tasso-crusted Niman Ranch pork chop. The chop itself was brined to within an inch of its life... it was overcooked but still eerily moist.... spongy, salty, blech. The elements of the crust were so large that they fell off as soon as I cut into the chop. The accompanying mashed potatoes were good, but such a small serving that I literally had to lift up the pork chop to see if they'd been forgotten.

My husband had a a trio of rabbit: hilariously tiny frenched rack of ribs, roulade of breast with unidentifiable stuffing, and another roulade of leg wrapped in bacon. What was billed as mustard spaetzle were scattered across the top as garnish. The vegetable was lightly-mashed peas and a celeriac puree. All of the meat was completely unsalted and basically tasteless, and the breast roulade was utterly overcooked and dry. Needless to say, neither of us ate much of our mains aside from the vegetables.

Since we were still hungry at this point, we split a butterscotch-chocolate pot de creme, garnished with buttercrunch. Sadly, this was the highlight of our meal, and it wasn't even good. The "pot" was actually a two-layered cereal-size bowl of pudding (nothing creme-y about it) and the top layer tasted exactly like butterscotch pudding from a box.

Service never improved from the early missteps: Plates were dropped off uncerimoniously -- it might have been nice to have an explanation of what the trio of rabbit included, for example -- and we got the distinct impression that our server would have rather been somewhere else for the evening. At least we had that in common.

The high-ceilinged space is decorated in an eclectic vein that feels historic without degenerating into old-timey kitsch. The light fixtures in particular -- including a Rube Goldberg-esque chandelier over the bar -- are particularly striking. The entry area was jammed with people waiting for tables and having drinks at the ill-placed bar, but the restaurant tables were only a little bit crowded. On the downside, the lack of booths and window coverings combined with brick walls makes for a very loud space with unforgiving acoustics -- there's no prayer of ignoring the coversations of the people on either side of you. Still, it managed to feel warm and urban and inviting... I only wish the food had been the equal of the space.
author: anita c.

description:
I like this place for their communal table, great drinks, and the atmosphere.  I don't expect much in the way of service because I always sit at the communal table (never once had a reservation and always rolled right up to the table with at least two other friends), but I always feel taken care of.  Let me rephrase that to say that I do expect good service, but lower my standards one notch given the lackadaisical feel of the communal table.

I spend most of my meal on their appetizers because they do such a good job on all of them.  I think I once ordered an entree, but can't remember if it was good or not, however I attest to the fact that I have never once been disappointed with this place.  Always save room for dessert; the pot of creme is to die for, but I would kill for the other stuff on there too.

I really love the way this restaurant feels and makes me feel.  It's fancy, but not pretentious.  They always send either the GM or the chef out to say hi and these guys are great because they usually come bearing treats.  And I never feel rushed.  I sit and eat and drink and take my time and the waiter/waitress never so much as hints that it's time to leave.

And thank you so much for remembering me.  I know $300 isn't much to a corporate expense account, but it's a pricey meal in my book, so thank you again for remembering me.  

Special final touch is the vintage books that they serve up the bill in.  Cute.  It's nice to have a conversation piece at the end of the meal as well.

http://www.cleanscores.com/3223/Townhall+Restaurant
author: Ann W.

description:
My recruiter took me here as a celebration for landing an interview. I had some kind of brie sandwich with caramelized sweet apples I think. It was way too sweet and yummy, too much sugar for my lunch appetite though. The only thing I would go back and try are the desserts, I've heard they are good, but I can't find a menu of them anywhere online.

The space is nice and large with high ceilings. The waiter was pretty cool and didn't mind us taking our time.

Maybe it would be better on a second run, we love going to The Cosmopolitan for appetizers and dessert though.
author: Lorrie N.

description:
another place good enough to make me a repeat customer. 

finally sat down at a table rather than eating at the bar.  great drinks and fantastic food.  service is a tad on the slow side, however. 

the two things i love on their menu are the jambalaya (careful, it's a "side" dish, so it's easy to miss at the very bottom of the menu, but it's also the best value on the menu at $7 for a pretty generous portion) and veal meatballs.  

Tonight I had the halibut, which is probably a seasonal rotation.  It was crusted with seeds and other crunchy items _ i cant' recall the exact name - and it was so perfect.  I generally dont' like ordering fish because it tends to come out bland to me (even at nicer restaurants out here).  But this did not disappoint in the least. 

Cornbread and biscuits are also quite good.  I'm def coming back here for more.  Still need to try the fried chicken.
author: Ash T.

description:
Came here for lunch... started with a beet salad that might have been better with the pickled watermelon that was supposed to be alongside (our server warned us that they had pulled it... watermelon is no longer in season apparently), but was otherwise forgettable.  Main course was basically a croque madame topped with jalapeno cream sauce of some kind and it totally redeemed the salad.

As any eating person knows, crispy, grilled, butter-soaked bread covered with cream sauce is basically one of the most delicious things on the planet when done well.  At Town Hall, they do it well.  When the sandwich first arrived I thought maybe I would end the meal with some room for dessert.  Little pile of food, big plate of sauce.  About two-thirds of the way through mopping up the incredibly rich jalapeno creaminess, I realized that was almost certainly not to be.  My arteries may not be thanking me at the moment, but my palate was certainly pretty pleased at the time.  I'd probably return for that sandwich alone.  Good service, seemingly extensive winelist, delicious grilled buttery bread with sauce.  What's not to like?
author: Alexis G.

description:
A group of us took our friend/mentor/former boss/all around awesome dude Michael to Town Hall for a going away luncheon on his last day with our company.  There were about 12 of us and I have to say that Town Hall was pretty darn good at accommodating our group with little notice of the reservation changed (like we called a half hour before our reservation to add three more people.)

They sat us quickly and brought us libations - a good thing for our motley crew.  The food was decent & pretty well priced... nothing spectacular - I had a pretty standard burger.  Overall, it was a good experience.  My only complaints were as follows:

-The service was kind of slow (which, didn't matter so much b/c we were planning to sit and enjoy ourselves - but, still.)
-They made me give a CC # to make a LUNCH reservation - it was just weird.

Other than that - a nice place for corporate lunches - I'm sure I'll be back sometime soon.
author: Kate R.

description:
This place is located directly in front of our office building so lots of executives find it convenient.  Today had reservations for 8 for lunch.  Last minuite reservations and they squeezed in a party of 8 - which is why they get 2 stars but...

1.  Waited 7 minutes for water and bread
2.  Waited another 12 minutes to take our order
3.  Every single person was delivered the wrong appetizer AND the wrong lunch
4.  Even though it was requested - nobody ever brought mustard and ketchup for the burger
5.  Ordered corn bread - never received
6.  Waitress brought out one entree for somebody but didn't want to give it to him because she had to "check" first whether it was really for him
7.  Brought us wrong bill

No apologies (and the wait staff was informed of the errors)...no, "let me take that off your bill", no "can I get you a dessert on the house?" - nothing.  

Like I said, this place is convenient and yes, the fried chicken is extremely good - but with service like that and the prices they charge I think I won't be recommending it to the executives at our office (which has about 300 employees) again.  I guess I'll have to send them to rn74 instead.
author: Donna C.

description:
Such a great spot for dinner or lunch! I've been here several times and have never been let down. The short ribs are definitely my favorite entree with the lamb a close second. I had a really great glass of Pinot Noir here a while ago and I'm upset that I don' t remember what it was now :( The ambiance is so inviting, it really reminds me of restaurants back in New Orleans. I really love how they present checks in books also, not sure why but I think its a charming touch.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

After going back I felt I needed to mention something. Quail. It's amazing. Comes with truffle grits. I'm from the south. I like grits. I like truffle oil. FREAKIN AMAZING! 

That's all folks
author: Sarah W.

description:
3.5 Stars if I could.
First I would like to thank our hostess and waitress. We really were a umm *fun* group last night.
First we were 8 then 2 hours before we expanded to 9 so I called and changed the reservation on a Saturday night.. uuhh I can already imagine the hostess repressed anger but she is super nice and assured me that it wasn't a problem AT ALL and they would make it happen. Hmm then our group shrank to 6 about 30 min before the reservation. So of course - bec I am such a nice girl ;) - call AGAIN to make sure that they can seat other customers accordingly and again she was suuper nice. Sure it is her job but she was just fre*king awesome at it.....

Now about the food:
Do NOT get the tuna entree. It is boooring. Ok the fish is fresh and the presentation is great but I am expecting marinated or seasoned tuna and all I receive is pretty much plain raw fish.
Everything else though was pretty good but nothing out of the ordinary. My fav were the crab fondue starter and the pork chops!!! 

Overall very good service - our waitress was great.. always around when we needed her and just super nice, knowledgeable and friendly.
Food.. umm nothing too special and I guess I expected a lot more....
I'll go back though to try some other dishes that sounded interesting.
author: Doro P.

description:
More of a 3.75 but you can't do that on Yelp. Service was great and the food was wonderful. The location can be a bit noisy as it has high ceilings. We enjoyed a version of a croque madame and it was the highlight for me. We had the slow roasted duck, it did take a while to come out, and enjoyed each bite.

A great SF experience.
author: Jeff O.

description:
Last night was very disappointing for what was suppose to be a night of celebration.  Our party of three was seated at 9pm and we started our evening with cocktails and soup, so far so good.  Then the waitress, manager and chef seem to forget all about what it takes to deliver a nice meal.  

We order a $100 bottle of Latour to pair with our fish dinner. Then 40mins later our dinners came out to which we where almost finished with the wine.  If that wasn't bad enough the waitress brought the wrong food.  

The second assault was the bacon wrapped trout; it was like a hockey puck sliding off the dish when it was placed in front of me for the first time.  After having to send back the wrong meal, the manager took the other two dinners to the kitchen to be held. Unfortunately NOT under a heat lamp, so when I got my LAME trout back it was cold!  

I finished eating the four string beans on the side of the plate, went home and put some food in the microwave and had dinner at 11pm.
author: Noelle M.

description: Very good, one of the best restaurants in the city.
author: Mike R.

description:
My Town Hall experience was soooo disappointing. The food was good, but really lacked the "wow factor." I felt like everything I tried had an interesting concept but was just out a little of the chefs' reach. 

We started out with the crab fondue, which itself had a really delicious flavor, but the accompanying things you were meant to dip in the fondue seemed like really odd choices - broccolini and sausage. We shared the peanut-crusted lamb, which was a little on the boring side and the ahi, which my dining companion said was overcooked. 

The space itself is nice - feels like a cross between a maritime museum and a prairie house - but the acoustics make it extremely difficult to hear.

I think for the price point there are far better dining options in the city.
author: Lindsey S.

description:
4.75 stars...
Went there for a team lunch as it was recommended by a co-worker.  The fish here is really good and really fresh.  I can't really describe the "kind" of food this place offers except to call it "American grill".  I swear the venue itself somehow makes the food taste better - it's got a really classy brick and dark woodish interior with clean white tableclothes.
It's pricey and hip.  I felt like I was sitting next to a lot of power brokers and people way cooler and definitely more affluent than me the whole time I was here.  That's OK, I still have my street cred.

Get the hot cholcolate.  They say it's SF's best.  I wouldn't argue that.
Oh and uh, not that I was looking at all, but my co-worker mentioned that all the wait staff were extremely hot.  The only thing I noticed was that everyone was extremely attentive and friendly.  We had to rearrange our table for some late-comers and they accomodated us with smiles even though the place was packed.
author: Joe Y.

description:
Bummer, I was hoping for so much more from Town Hall.

It was a pricey meal, although the food was nothing special in terms of flavor, creativity, or presentation. The portions were frankly, meager, not as one would expect from this style of food, borrowed from the South. In fact, the couple seated next to us, healthy, corn-fed folks, looked like giants compared to their entrees ... funny, yet not funny :-|

The atmosphere felt stiff and the crowd was something out of a Tommy Hilfiger, Ralph Lauren, or Nautica catalogue. It wasn't bad, just a bit of a culture shock to be surrounded by such a concentration of navy blue blazers and starched striped shirts. I actually felt for a moment that I may have stumbled into a frat reunion.

There is nothing about this place that beckons a second visit.
author: Kimbalee W.

description:
A good friend of mine used to be a chef here, which is why I tried it in the first place; that, and the good reviews friends have given it.

Well, I'm must agree, town hall does it right!  

I've been here once for lunch and once for dinner and both times I was wowed.

For lunch I got the bread with egg covered in the cream jalapeno sauce...I can't remember the exact name (it's been a while now) but it was delicious.  I also got the puff pastries with chocolate dipping sauce (wow...pack on the calories much...cream and chocolate in one sitting!)  My friend got the hamburger, and it looked delicious, and from the way she mowed through it, I think it was.

For dinner (seperate day), we started with the fried green tomatoes (I always thought it was the name of a movie, but now I know they are effing delicious), and for the entree I got the stuffed pork, amazing! For dessert we shared the chocolate mousse with toffee.  We left 1000+ calories fuller and a little poorer, but it was well worth all of it :)

I love this place, and really want to take my mom here...I don't know why, I just feel like she would like it.  It's not too pretentious and the food is so amazing!
author: Kristin E.

description:
OK, so it's not a perfect restaurant: Friday night's visit had food and service gaffes aplenty.  But we still walked out feeling like we had a great time, and that's what's important.  Town Hall is just one of those restaurants that's fun to go to, serves fun food, and generally encourages a good time.

So it's predictably loud and crowded.  But not in a bad way: think convivial, energetic, with an appealing hodgepodge of patrons: amusingly over-botoxed socialites, youngish preppy couples, the requisite blue blazer-wearers, a family or two thrown into the mix - and everyone feeling at home.

Sure, the crowds mean our table was not ready quite on time.  All the better to order a fantastic cocktail.

And yes, our waitress was a complete dolt.  But you could tell just by looking at her that, er, the light was on, but... so we lowered our expectations, resigned to the fact that we'd have to request bread and butter (I feel like such a chubster when I do that --- I mean, do I really neeeeeeeed crusty bread slathered with butter as a prelude to an enormous dinner?    Oh, the shame!), and got over it.

And moved on to the food: New American with a Southern twist.  How can that not be good?  

Sadly, it's possible.  Potato and bacon croquettes sounded right up my alley (fried!  bacon!) - but were strangely bereft of both bacon and flavor.  Best thing about these gussied-up tater tots was the sinus-clearingly spicy mustard dipping sauce.   Veal meatballs over mashed potatoes (yes, this was an app - see why I like this place?) were great - well, the ones that weren't overdone.

But the mains: solid.  Peanut-crusted pork chop over grits (how much do I love grits?!) with sweet potatoes and bitter greens: excellent, with perfectly balanced flavors.  BF, not a fan of the sweet/savory marriage, wasn't as thrilled, so I happily traded him my pancetta-crusted trout over scallion risotto: again, well-seasoned, rich but not overly so: equally excellent.  

I was afraid for one of our dinner companions for whom, being allergic to everything under the sun (dairy, nuts, eggs, shellfish, you name it), menus are minefields - one wrong turn into a whisper of peanut oil and it's instant death; but the kitchen readily accommodated and he pronounced his duck and wild rice entree tasty.  I love when people are happy with their food.

I do wish I were happier with dessert, because desserts tend to be strong here.  Am I kicking myself for not playing it safe and going for the sticky toffee cake, which I know I love?  Yes.  Did I think the gingersnap crust overpowered the otherwise fluffy and yummy cheesecake that I did order?  Yes.  But did I also enjoy scooping huge spoonfuls of my friend's always-delicious butterscotch pudding (the enormous serving means I can be greedy without her getting annoyed - always a plus)?  Another yes.    

All in all, I like. The room is fun, the drinks are solid, and the food is indulgent.  Good times.
author: Melissa B.

description:
Well I might be in the minority on this one, but Town Hall was a big let down.  This may be the place to go for drinks and to hang out with friends, but as far as a dining destination it was a flop.

It is definitely an interesting space, they converted the old Marine Electric warehouse into a corner restaurant with big picture windows to view the hustle and bustle of Howard and Fremont streets.  Inside there are brick walls, wood ceiling and lots of hard surfaces to help create a noisy yet festive atmosphere.   Thats about all I liked about Town Hall.  The rest of the evening was disappointing.

We were sat and looked over the menu.  As I had never been here before I asked the waiter for recommendations.  He suggested their signature warm ham and cheese toast with poached egg and jalapeno cream as a starter.  Which I had heard good things about.  I also had the Tasso-crusted pork chop which was another recommendation.

The ham and cheese toast was way overhyped.  It was interesting for about one bite.  The presenation was a mess and it was way too heavy and just tasted like messy diner food.  It didn't translate well as an appetizer at dinner.  I found I was forcing myself to finish it, the dish was just too heavy handed in flavor. 

I was also disappointed in the pork chop.  I usually order the pork dish as way of comparing numerous restaurants.  As you can tell from my other reviews I get it just about everywhere.  This one just didn't excite me.  The pork was cooked well but it lacked any interesting flavors.  It was placed a top a medley of vegetables that resembled the cubed carrots and peas you get with a frozen dinner.  Overall, for $22 it was nothing special at all.

The desert was the lone bright spot.  The butterscotch pudding was very good but not enough to save the meal nor enough to get me to come back.

I was also disappointed in our waiter.  After he took the order we didn't see him until our food arrived and it took a very long time to get the food.  It appeared as though they were short staffed or his section was just too big.  When the food did finally arrive it was just dropped off and he was gone again.  He didn't check back to see how we were doing, or to see if we needed anything.

Overall, I found the food to be very heavy and fatty tasting.  The flavors are heavy handed and not very interesting.  With the one bright spot being dessert.  The waitstaff seemed overworked and frantic.  I haven't gone back there are just too many other places to choose from.

Atmosphere:  3 stars
Food:  2 stars
Service:  2 stars
author: Geoff H.

description:
The perfect margarita, number one in a series:

353 reviews, apparently this place is popular with the Yelp set, but I'm not here to write about the food.

I am here to write about the bar, and the booze that sits behind it, and a bartender there who makes margarita's so good you want to pour them over your genitalia !

Armando I think I heard someone call him, I'd like a margarita, rocks, no goddamn salt, and I want some good tequila - expensive shit, cause I could leave here today and get hit by a fuckin bus and if that happens it better not be with a gut full of Jose Cuervo !

"No problem, Don Julio anejo (kisses the finger tips) es perfecto !"

Great, fucking pour it, let's do this.

Son of a bitch . . .  what does he do ? 

Starts cutting up citrus, lemons, limes and the like, and then slaps the halves into a juicer: 

There is no Cointreu, 
there is no Margarita Jones sugar sewer water, 
there is no bulk purchased sweet and sour !

(S.F. BARTENDERS, ARE YOU LISTENING, CAUSE MOST OF YOU CAN'T MAKE A DECENT MARG TO SAVE YOUR ASS). 

Just fresh jugo de limon, ice, and the piece d'resistance a tablespoon of glistening white C & H pure cane sugar harvested off the virgin thighs of native island girls !

It all goes into a shaker and seconds later ambrosia fit for the god's is being poured into my damn glass. That and a blowjob from a pretty girl and we could've called it a good year right then and there, yes siree.

Sure, I know what you're thinking (in a whiney voice) well that's the same way they make them at Tommy's and you're right it is, but is Tommy's in the goddamn financial district !?

No it isn't, it's out hell and gone on Geary in BFE ! 

You want a good margarita, I suggest you check this one out. 

And if you want a Miller Lite a couple blocks to the north you'll find a sign that says "BART." What I want you to do is hop on one goin east and leg out to Concord, or Pinole, where they'll be more than happy to take care of you, hell, you can even tell 'em Red sent you.
author: red c.

description: I had the catfish and the two people I went with had the duck for lunch. I thought my dish was a bit salty and flavors weren't anything spectacular. The two that had the duck really loved their dish though. I probably won't go back anytime soon- would much rather go to Anchor and Hope.
author: Youngie A.

description:
The food and the atmosphere were perfect here.  I love the high ceilings and the brick interior.  On the menu, the wine selection was great, not a ton of reds by the glass but certainly enough.  Many options by the bottle.  

They gladly made the fish dishes with meat toppings without meat.  The tuna was delicious!! The servers were attentive without being rush-y at all. And they take opentable! 

Just a great dining experience. I don't have much more to add but that I could come back again and again.
author: Megan S.

description:
Not blown away. Don't get me wrong, because you can't go wrong when you're serving mac 'n cheese and fried chicken, but I was left uninspired and felt that the overall experience lacked....dimension. 

The food is salty, greasy, warm, and wonderfully buttery - but all those things aren't necessarily slam dunks in the culinary world. For starters, the ham, cheese, and egg toast with that jalepeno cream was hands-down amazing, but the crab-stout fondue was mediocre, at best; just had a funky taste to it that didn't sit right. Plus, it felt like they made it for the sake of having another rich app - too much. 

For main courses, the sole was pretty good with lots of spice, but here is a good example of why I said this place lacks dimension. There were no distinct flavors that popped out at me - it was good, but I wasn't on a taste ride - and I like taking taste rides that take you in, out, up, down, and all around. I got that same bay seasoning in every bite, so it was just a slight texture change from the potatoes, romesco sauce, and sole. We also had the fried chicken, which was certainly tasty, but  lacked some crispness and was a little on the greasy side. The pork osso bucco was fine, but not as tender as other reviews.
The butterscotch pot de cream was delicious, but left me puzzled. There was something about it that was really well-done - but there was also something about it that reminded me of a Jello pudding snack...kind of odd. 

The real downer for our experience was the ambiance. We were seated smack dab in the middle, next to the kitchen. The restaurant has a horrible set-up, so we heard more from the kitchen expo than we did each other. It was loud, and because the servers have to run all the way around to the front to get plates out, there was just a chaotic feel to it. You can tell they know this, as there were a plethora of extra wait staff and bussers around to help where they could, but having those extra people also cause the place to feel like cramped, crowded, and more like a cafeteria than a southern dining experience...and I don't want to pay that much for fried chicken if I'm at a cafeteria.
author: Erin M.

description:
Could the Pot de Creme be ANY more amazing? Chocolate lovers, this is truly an orgasmic experience. The texture is perfect with a thin layer of butterscotch on top. This dessert alone is worth a meal at Town Hall, but luckily, you will not be disappointed by the rest of the meal either. The barbecued shrimp appetizer is equally fantastic. Our party of six was completely in love with every aspect of our evening there. 

Other selections you can't go wrong with: hamachi salad, butter lettuce and the seared ahi.
author: Carolyn C.

description:
Came here for dinner with some friends on Friday. Drinks were mediocre (manhattan), appetizers pretty good (bib salad, sweetbread ravioli, tuna tartare, and soup), entree delicious, (bacon wrapped pork) but then again it's tough not to love pork three ways.
