Dessert - WOW(beignets with espresso ice cream and butterscotch chocolate pot de creme) served up with some blue bottle coffee.  Attentive waitress and a decent wine list.  Good meal but not mind blowing, I will definitely come back for dessert some night.
author: Seth A.

description:
I went here with my family becasue we wanted to try out San Francisco Chronical's top 100 restaurants. We get there and are seating shortly after arriving. We wait and we wait and we wait till our waiter finally shows up... we order a few bottles of wine and then we wait and we wait and we wait some more. We were probably seated a solid 45 minutes before we even got our first drinks. Finally when we get back we went ahead and ordered all of our food because we werent sure we would ever see the waiter again. After finishing both bottles of wine and our apps - no waiter in sight - my fiance ordered a glass of wine from a staff member walking by and they promptly brought him the glass. As he was about to take a sip our waiter comes out of no where and snatched the glass from his hand and runs off. I have never seen anything like it. So we call over some other staff member walking by and ask what was going on and if he could get his glass of wine - they walk away and 10 min later our waiter walks back up and hands him the glass and he said he misunderstood and thought that it was for another table. I am not sure what is the misunderstanding or why you would think to snatch a glass of wine out of a customers hand?? The food finally came and we were all in a terrible mood by then bc the service was so poor hardly anyone ate their meals. We eventually had to get another random staff member to get our bill because our waiter again was no where in sight possibly because he was so embarrassed about his actions before. 

All in all the service was very poor - which is super disappointing because we love their sister restaurants Anchor and Hope and Salt House AND go to those all the time. It is sad how poor service really affects your over all meal - if we had had someone who even cared about being there, serving us and doing their job we might have gone back.
author: Kate M.

description:
I'd heard great things about this restaurant so I was ecstatic when my coworker wanted to treat me for lunch here.  We got stuck at the bar since we had no reservation, but I guess it's one step up from the community table in the front of the restaurant.  The stools were pretty squished together that I think I annoyed the guy next to me when I kept bumping him.  Oops.

My coworker and I both ordered th etouffle with rice in the middle.  The shrimp was tasty, but the whole dish was on the borderline of being too salty.  Ok I guess that meant it was just too salty.  I also had a sprite and we got the bread, plus their homemade chips.  The chips were good so we gave some to our server behind the bar.  He was nice enough to refill my glass of sprite.  When I tasted it after my refill, I was wondering why it tasted so nasty and flat.  Oh duh.  It was water.  "Excuse me sir," my coworker says to him, "her water is flat."  
"That's because it's water," he replies.  Well... ok that was kind of funny.  But he switched it out with the sprite.  My coworker insisted we get the Sprite because it was an expensive restaurant that we had to get our money's worth.

After a long wait, we got dessert, a sorbet and bread pudding.  Both desserts were so delicious.  Especially my sorbet, strawberry and pineapple flavors, which made the perfect dessert in that 86 degree heat outside.  

The ambiance was great.  I kept watching all the well-dressed patrons coming in and being seated by the hostess in the peptol bismol pink dress that kept falling off her shoulders.  I saw the waiters stare at one person they seated, mentioning he was a football player.  It's a shame I don't know enough about the football players to recognize them in plain clothes.  Oh well.  The service was ok, if not a little bit slow.  Luckily, I didn't have to rush back to work or else I would've never made it.  The prices are a little high, but the location and food are worth the price.  A great place to eat downtown , but definitely need to make a reservation.
author: Stacey C.

description:
I am kind of wary of writing this review because I think I ordered the wrong thing...Don't get me wrong, my meal was good but it just wasn't as "amazing" as I was expecting...

I guess the first thing that threw me off was the fact that almost everything I wanted to try wasn't on the lunch menu.  I was told to get the Meatloaf or the Shrimp Etouffee, neither of which were available, so instead I got flustered an ended up ordering the Warm Ham and Cheese Toast with a poached egg and jalapeno cream (which I other yelpers had informed me was amazing).  

The Ham and Cheese Toast was good, but it was more like a breakfast dish than a lunch dish, and the Jalapeño cream was very rich, delicious, but rich.  I ended up wishing I had ordered the burger or the Fish and Chips, but I always have a hard time ordering something ordinary at a really swanky place...

Although my lunch wasn't crazy delicious, the appetizers we tried were. We had the Tuna TarTare and the Perscuitto & Melon, both of which were delicious and well portioned.  After our lunch I really wanted to order dessert because I heard that the Butterscotch Pot de Creme was delicious, but no one else in my party wanted anything...so not wanting to be known as the office fatty, I declined as well.   I guess I do have to go back though...next time I'll order the right thing and I'll be getting dessert!
author: Katherine C.

description:
I came here last week for a work event of appetizers and drinks and am lucky enough that I can walk there from work and avoid parking (as you will have to contend with expensive parking meters...ugh).  When I came in for the event we were told it was upstairs - i never even knew there was an upstairs.  It's a good space for events of 30 people or so, and we had our own private bartender (nice!).

the appetizers are yummy and the wine selection was pretty good.  i really liked the upstairs area, very private and intimate.  i can't wait to come back for dinner.
author: Sonya T.

description:
This has quickly become my favorite restaurant.  For Dinner.  With the Folks.  Or Special Occasions.  
Although I would love to eat here whenever the mood strikes, it is a bit out of my price range and therefore limited to parental visits or anniversaries.  

Let me explain the ways I love...

I love the attn to detail.  
The decor is simple and elegant, the waiters are flawless, the food taste and presentation are perfection.

My mother is possibly the most anal when it comes to all of the above, so when I introduced her to Town Hall on her last visit I was beside myself to discover that she ranks TH among one of her other favorites--Cafe des Artistes in NYC
author: Hannah A.

description:
I can't imagine anyone giving this place any less than 5 stars. But I guess if you're ranking it against the rest of Bauer's Top 100, maybe they're not flawless. But we went last night and it was the most satisfying restaurant experience I've ever had. 

About me: ex-chef, would much rather have a delicious, filling meal than a 2-ounce crazy chemistry experiement for $40. I'm pretty forgiving of waitstaff, take cocktails pretty seriously, but above all else I don't let small stuff get in the way of having a good time. I'm Anthony Bourdain but I don't like to travel.

So me and my lady were on our two-year anniversary. We got there about 45 minutes before our reservation hoping they had a bar, and they did. I had a Kentucky Gun and 710 Ashbury (both whiskey-based) and she had a Black Beauty and a Pim's something or other. All 4 were house cocktails, and well made, with an interesting balance of flavors, maybe not enough booze but then, I love a way-too-strong drink. On the list, the Kentucky Gun initially turned me off with the Tabasco, but there was a nice fruit-to-spicy transition in the drink. She liked both of hers, I think the best of the four was the Pim's whatever it was called. 

We were sat on time at a small 2-person table (I'd left a note via OpenTable that we'd prefer not to get a communal table, since it was an anniversary, and it looks like they took care of us). Our server was friendly, informed, happy to give us more time even though we were seated around 9:30, and kept a smile all night. He had about the perfect balance of attention without being up our butts. I think his name was Javier -- Town Hall, if you're reading this, he was the best server I've ever had.

We ordered a bottle of Cab, not one of their higher priced ones (I think it was $55) and I think it was probably obvious we weren't wine experts -- we might as well have thrown a dart at the list -- but it was a pretty good bottle. Server even beat me once to refilling her glass (it's a sin around here for me not to fill her glass).

Like I said, I prefer to be satisfied than to be surprised, so I went with the Buttermilk Biscuits and ham starter. She had the Tuna Tartare. The biscuits were, without exaggeration, one of the favorite things I've ever eaten. The baked-to-order biscuits were deep-South-perfect, the Johnston ham was sliced incredibly thin and there was plenty of it, and the spicy, peppery jelly was an amazing complement. Slather some butter on a bite of biscuit, put some ham on there, and top it with the jelly, and I'm not kidding I may have never had more fun putting food in my mouth. She's a seafood freak, and was very impressed with the tuna. It was a bit spicier than she'd like, but she's incredibly sensitive to spicy, so that's not Town Hall's fault. It came with fired green tomatoes ( I think in a cornmeal crust or something) and they were spectacular. Both appetizers were rad.

Entrees came out just in time. I was kinda surprised at the relatively basic plating of the entrees, but I have no problem with that. I feel like if you make the visuals too important you're not paying attention to the food enough. So "basic" is often, to me, a good sign. And I was right. Shit was on point. She got the Sole, I tried it and it was really damn good, especially the Concord grape reduction, but my New York steak was king of the night. I thought the meat itself had a bit of extra fat or silverskin in there, but that's what you get when you get it bloody. It was crispy on the outside, nice and red inside, and whatever the hell that sauce was, it was great. We were drinking, and I missed that detail. Mine even came with mushrooms, and I hate freaking mushrooms...but this time I cleaned my plate. Finally, this order was accompanied with a little iron pot of potatoes au gratin, and they were the kind you wish you'd grown up on. Share some fork space with the steak and the potatoes and that's what food should be, every meal. 

We ordered the Butterscotch Pot de Creme, I got up to pee, and as I sat back down she says some other server guy had approached our table with a small plate, but turned away...she didn't know what was up...then here comes server #2 with a plate of three tiny cupcakes, "Happy Anniversary" written in chocolate. It was an awesome thing to do (I guess they did see the OpenTable note!) and each cupcake was better than the last. We ate them in the order we thought we'd like them most: first a chocolate thing, then some cocnut German corporately thing, then something with nuts on top, and tuned out we liked them in reverse order of what we thought. Just as we finished, here came the Butterscotch pot, and it was incredible. Hard to describe, some kind of mix of butterscotch and chocolate creamy puddings with some crispy buttersctoch/toffee things floating on top. It was as ridiculous. We were both stuffed, but still I scraped the bowl clean. 

I'm out of characters, so, in short: perfect night. Thanks Town Ha
author: That Was A Good Drum Break ..

description:
Home Cooking meets Haute Cuisine with great results.

The decor and atmosphere are interesting like the food.  There is plenty to feast on while your eyes feast on the decor like the pictures on the walls, the water glasses, the checks arriving in a books.

I find the hostesses a little pretentious and the table service is a bit sloppy but not enough to not make me not want to come back for the food and the place.

I just wish they were open for Brunch/Lunch at weekends because that's when I seem to crave their home cooking the most.
author: Claire m.

description:
Over 900 reviews? I might as well add my thoughts, right? We went here about a month ago for dinner when I was up in San Francisco for a conference. The place had good reviews on Yelp and we hadn't had any Southern-inspired cuisine in a long time.

The old brick loft building makes for a great environment. The restaurant is big, but still has an intimate feel to it. We arrived a little early and had a drink at the bar while we waited for a table. Town Hall serves up some excellent classic cocktails - most of which I wish I could take home with me to South Bay. That they'll make a Sazerac earns them bonus points in my book.The bartenders seem to really know what they're doing.

All of the appetizers sounded great. We had the buttermilk biscuits with ham and peach jam - heavenly stuff. Probably the highlight of the meal.

The fried chicken entree was also fantastic, just like they make it in the South! Having spent a couple of years in the South, it's hard to find fried chicken that takes me back to those long humid summers, but this did. Crisp but moist and tender on the inside. Just perfect. Too bad it wasn't what I ordered. 

The pork chop started out on the right foot (or hoof, I suppose?). The peanut crust added a nice texture, and the side of rice and fava beans complimented it. About halfway in to it, in the dim light of the restaurant, I could see that my pork chop wasn't quite dead - in fact, it was really pink near the bone. I quietly brought this to the attention of the waiter who said he would chastise the kitchen and comped our dessert, but didn't comp the half-eaten entree. I was a few drinks in and on an expense account so I didn't bother to argue. Mistakes happen to be sure, but really, if you're going to send out a plate of trichinosis, at least comp the entree.

The service was generally good but a bit inconsistent. The staff was attentive when we were first seated, but it became increasingly hard to get anyone's attention as the night wore on. It was a Sunday night, so they weren't even especially busy.

There's a thousand restaurants in San Francisco I want to try, so while I can say that *most* of the food was great at Town Hall, and the drinks were outstanding - I'd even send a friend there (just remind them to cook the pork a little more, maybe) - but I'll have to get through the other thousand restaurants before I go back.
author: David F.

description:
Uninspired food for downtown prices. Worst service ever received. Avoid. 

Our server left after taking our orders and was not seen again for 2 HOURS.  

Servers stood around while the kitchen ever so slowly produced one dish every 15 minutes (we were sitting near the kitchen and were not being served we decided to see how fast they were cooking). The floor manager decided everything was fine and left at 9pm while 5 tables were missing a server and had not received appetizers.

The abandoned tables eventually received new servers (from the group standing around) after 2.5 hours. 

Bill came out to be over $120 for drinks, appetizers & entrees. No apology or explanation was provided when we asked our new server what had happened. NEVER COMING BACK.
author: Alex L.

description:
Town Hall Haiku

Yes, fancy indeed
Food is overpriced but good
Get the fried chicken!
author: Jeanie C.

description: Great service, scallops and steak last night (REALLY good food).  Atmosphere was alive, bartenders were on point.  Continues to be a San Francisco classic.  Love!
author: Christin A.

description:
Great contemporary American food in a family hall style building, like you'd find in a small rural community.  Seemingly ordinary fare is dial notched past ten, making one's taste buds nod in approval and break out in applause.  

The seafood chowder alone beats anything I've ever had in the form of chowder in any restaurant I've ever been to.  I could be satisfied eating that for my entire meal.  Throw in the finely braised short ribs that melt in  your mouth upon entry, and the most interestingly prepared rabbit stew relaxing on a bed rice, and you'll have me coming back to try more.  

That plus the extensive wine list, and more than robust service makes this place a winner.
author: Baldwin H.

description:
One of the few places for those who work around Howard st to have a nice sit down lunch or dinner. On a recent lunch with eight of us I thought I had made reservations for Town Hall but accidently made it for another restaurant. Town Hall was able to sit us and they called the other restaurant to cancel. Way beyond! I go there a few times a month and they are constitant with the food which is very good. You get good portions without feeling over fed. The staff is extremely attentive and knowledgable. I love the soups, burger and they always have fresh fish.
Also during the summers the BBQ behind teh restaurant is a must!
author: Angela G.

description:
A wise man once said, "politics is for people who have a passion for changing life but lack a passion for living it."

While traditionally a town hall was a center for politics, San Francisco should be proud that our Town Hall is a center for delicious food at reasonable prices.

Which is good if you view life like I do -- and simply have a passion for eating it.
author: Brad C.

description: great cocktails (natural ingredients).  Their etouffee and fried chicken is off the charts.  A classic SF restaurant.
author: Dom P.

description:
I remember when Town Hall was the hot new restaurant. It wasn't too long ago. I've only been handful of times. Each time I've enjoyed the food very much. While the dining room is beautiful, it's insanely loud. You almost have to shout to be heard at the same table. The sound ricochets off the hardwood that's everywhere.

On my most recent visit, the hostess exhibited a lack of grace which created a very cold reception. The wait service was friendly and responsive.  I enjoyed the beet salad with blood oranges very much. The risotto with chanterelles a butternut squash was overwhelmed by the amount of cheese. This might be just me since I usually don't have my mushroom risotto with cheese.

Town Hall is good for what it is. The din of the place does take it down a notch. The uneven staff makes me questions whether I'll go back. The food always holds promise.
author: Dave B.

description:
The wine list was the surprise - off the beaten track and a great compliment to the menu. We had most if not all the apps and they were very tasty.
The main courses were all uniquely done and very tasty as well.
Did I had much with this review? No but you needed to hear this again.
author: Raul L.

description:
I hadn't been here in ages since the last time I dined was for dinner.  It's been so long that I can't recall what I ordered but I did come for lunch the other day and ordered the -
oyster spinach salad - the oysters were awesome!
fish tacos - tasty, but maybe at this point i had too much seafood since i devoured the oysters
butterscotch & chocolate pudding dessert and beignets - the pudding was fabulous and the beignets were a huge pass-they reminded me of sweet pizza rolls.  they looked like just like them.  

Praise the lord it was a work lunch so I didn't have to fork out of my own pocket.  Because otherwise I think I'd pass.
author: Meredith K.

description:
When I was growing up, my mom made pork chops for dinner at least once a week.  I don't eat pork chops anymore.  Except at Town Hall...peanut & tasso crusted pork chop with buttermilk smashed potatoes - how could I resist?  Delicious.  And the pot de creme....oh, it's dreamy.

Less one star because it can be loud and somewhat drafty depending on where you're sitting.  And my sister's jambalaya was just way too spicy - poor thing had to keep sipping water after every bite.  Also, on my most recent visit, the waitress could have been more attentive.  But I still really like this place.
author: DD B.

description:
It was so loud that I was waiting for my ears to bleed. Seriously. I was excited to go to the bathroom (upstairs) just to give my eardrums a respite from the #11 volume... and they don't appear to have a quieter section of seating. I did a lot of uncomfortable nodding to conversation I couldn't quite hear. Lord only knows what I was agreeing to (ala Flour The Kids). The food was delicious, so my pleasured peptides offset some of the pain. These peeps know how to cook up a fish real good like, though I'm not sure I'd put myself through it again. Tasty grub+throbbing headache=3 stars.

Horrible for a nice, romantic date. Fabulous if you're unhappily married/about to break-up and really have no desire to talk to the other person.
author: Bernadette D.

description:
It's between a 3.5 and 4 star for me.

I had lunch at Town Hall today, after not having been there for a while.  We sat at the communal table and had a perfectly civilized experience.  I remembered that I liked the space although I have spent more time at the bar and the big table than anywhere else.

I had the seafood chowder, and the tuna tartare.  My friend had the ham sandwich.  I would say that the portions were ample but not huge (her sandwich came with nothing, not a fry or a pickle to keep it company).

We eyeballed the dishes of our fellow diners, and for some reason every other person at that table ordered a hamburger.  They looked good and hearty, with fries or a salad.

It's not a destination restaurant for me, but I always enjoy my meal.  Nicer on someone else's dime.
author: Liz S.

description: Started with a tuna tartare paired with an exquisite fried garlic. Then had an amazing lightly-breaded fried chicken with extremely tender meat as a main course. All this was topped off with professional and friendly staff. Will definitely be back to try that Red Velvet cake!
author: Z L.

description:
I've only been there for the lunchtime rush, so the following is based on that:

Town Hall is very "Power Lunchy", with a strong richwhitebusiness clientele and prices to match.  If you're not put off by that, you're in for a treat because it's one of the finer eateries in the Financial district.

Their menu changes (I'm not sure how often) and comes on a sheet of thick paper.  Lamb, pork, chicken and rabbit(!) are served, along with seafood selections.  This is not a good place for vegetarians.  The portions are 80's movie rich-person-restaurant small, with a lot of plate to keep you company, but it's almost always effin' delicious and surprisingly filing.

Eat the bread they start you with - it's quality stuff.

My recommendation is the hamburger.  It's 12 dollars, yes, but it comes with fries and it's easily the best beef you're going to get short of going to a steakhouse.  I get mine medium rare (and that's how it comes!) because it's excellent meat.

You can expect to take at least an hour to eat there, with two hours being more likely.  It's not that the service is slow, but they clearly cook your order from scratch and that takes time.

If you can stand the bill (roughly $25-35 per person) it's a great place with great service, food, and atmosphere.
author: Matt H.

description:
I really really want to give you five stars because:

I love the way this place is decorated and I love the private room upstairs as well!!!!

The bread and butter was really darn good

my auqua fresa - muddled fresh strawberries and homemade lemonade served on the rocks with lime and a slash of soda was even darn better than it sounds!!!!!

Tuna Tar Tar with fried green tomatoes and green onion Tabasco vinaigrette was delightful and one of the best I have had.

I had a large bite of the meatloaf and its better than Mo Mo's

My sandwich which was my version of Faiths Warm ham and cheese toast w, a poached egg and jalapeno cream......I substituted the ham for spinach and tomatoes and it was absolutely phenomenal.

the reason why its only 4 stars is because I almost had to get up and serve myself and two others water :( bummer slow service but darn good food.
Go here when you have a two hour lunch:)
author: Setareh N.

description:
Wow - so many reviews. I really wanted to love this place, but I didn't.  The food was very good, but not amazing. The service was very good, but not remarkable. The atmosphere was nice, but not special. Normally, I would give a place like this 4 stars, but for a couple things. First, the prices - $24.50 for a pork chop? Second, not a lot of choices for vegetarians. And by "not a lot" I mean one - risotto. While a big plate of starch is good on occasion, I really wasn't in the mood for it that night. I ended up getting the soup of the day - asparagus with truffle creme fraiche. Tasty, but not memorable. I also had the butter lettuce salad, which I really liked. In addition, we had the squash blossom appetizers - outstanding. 

Here's the thing. As a vegetarian, I hate having to settle for eating cobbled-together meals of side dishes and appetizers. I want an honest-to-goodness entre - not fried finger food, not soup, not mac 'n cheese, not pizza margherita. I don't expect every restaurant to have a big selection of vegetarian dishes, but don't expect me to like it if they don't.
author: Marcelle H.

description:
I wanted to try this place because OpenTable claimed it was the most reserved for retaurant in the area.  Now that I've been there I seriously don't get what the fuss is about.  The whole "Town Hall" concept is kinda cute, until you realize it just means you're eating in a really old, not-that-attractive building, and you have to climb a few flights of stairs to use the restroom.  The place was so noisy that I could barely hear myself chew, let alone try to talk to other people.

I ordered a seared tuna salad, which was decent.  The cut of tuna was ok, and not over-cooked.  My friend had the rainbow trout (I think), which looked overdone, and not appetizing at all.  When my friend offered me a taste of her fish I seriously thought she was just trying to get me to help her finish her dirty work.

I might go back and try other entrees, maybe we just ordered the off dishes??!!
author: Rache C.

description:
I came here more than a year ago and ordered some salmon dish (not on the dinner menu anymore?) and a glass of wine. The salmon was tasty, but a little undercooked for my liking. I'll get sushi if I want raw fish. 

The glass of white wine almost made me vomit half hour after we left the restaurant. I felt like I was going through menopause with the onset of hot flashes and my face turning unnaturally red. I forced myself to keep the food down, however, knowing my friends spent 30-something dollars on my mediocre meal.  

I may come back here and order a meat dish, sans any type of alcoholic beverage.
author: Alvin T.

description:
Town Hall was amazing. Hillary was amazing. If you are smart enough to get over to Fremont and Howard and try this beautiful restaurant, you will not be let down. 
Did I mention Hillary rocked? Be sure to look at her face while you order, she is like a magic 8 ball that helps guide you to the best picks of the day. I can be sure that ordering the ham toast with the poached egg will leave you breathless. 
Oh, and for reasons that will remain private, Hillary made for a wonderful dining experience and we will be back for more! The staff are all very nice and friendly.
So go, eat, drink, and be merry and get the hot coco. 
Thanks!
author: Paul B.

description:
This place is quite convenient, located right down the street from my office in the Financial District(Market/Front). I visited this place the week of 10/22 with a good friend and co-worker of mine who suggested we have dinner here. We're both foodies and wine enthusiasts so we didn't make this decision lightly.

It happened to be a beautiful and warm San Francisco evening (70 degrees)...no I'm not kidding...so we got to sit outside in the patio area. I had a glass of the Bordeaux (but since they have an extensive wine list, I can't recall which one...however, they only have a few by the glass). Anyhow, my friend had a glass of the Pinot Noir (I believe). Their wine selection is amazing!

Their food was very good. We had an appetizer, the Tuna Tartare w/the green tomatoes--but didn't mix our red wines with it; the tuna was yummy! I just checked their menu to try and remember what we had for dinner...I can't find my friend's choice. Anyhow, I'm going on memory here. I think my friend had the rabbit?? Hmmm. Well, she said it was good, but I believe it was a tad overcooked. I had the Grilled Cedar Ribeye Steak and that was excellent. The potato bacon cheddar croquettes served on the side were fabulous!

The service started off a bit slow but got better as the evening wore on. Our server was very nice and overall it was a good experience. I would go there again (if only for the great wine!). I'd want to try the Rainbow Trout with the Chanterelles.
author: Becky O.

description: Ok, let me start by saying the food here is OUTSTANDING. The fried okra, meatballs and other appetizers were deelish. I had the steak and it was cooked to perfection. It's a noisy place  so I wouldn't advise this place for an intimate experience but perfect for groups. Now let me get into why I only rated this place 2 stars. Our server was HORRENDOUS. I guess the "The customer is always right" message never got to him. This was a business dinner for one of my top clients and it was a pretty large group. We all ordered drinks and when they arrived, several people who ordered the root beer noticed they were flat. When we mentioned this to the server, instead of offering to fix it or bring something else, he argued with us! "That's not possible" he says. When our client offered him to take a sip, he still argued! I don't care if it came straight from the bottle, don't argue! Then he says "so do you want something else then" with such an attitude. That just set the tone. We went on to have an enjoyable evening despite him. Now here's the icing on the cake...when I, my co-worker and my boss were leaving (after the client had left, thank goodness), as we're hailing a cab, this FOOL runs out the door, chases us down to say "you didn't leave the tip"! Ok first of all, it was a group of 10 so we thought gratuity was already included but more than that, did he honestly think his attitude was worthy of something extra?!?! And secondly, he actually chased us down for it?!?!?! It wasn't like we skipped out on the check, just the "extra" tip. Here's a tip, find a new profession, perhaps a debating bounty hunter where you can argue and chase people til your heart's content! I don't think I'll be back despite the stellar food. I hate to think what my husband would do if he argued with us or chased us down.
author: Shariyah M.

description:
Would have been 3.5 but we had a great waitress.

Best corn muffin I have ever had - I would have ordered a basket if possible.  Ribs were mediocre.  Fried oysters came with an amazing spinach aioli - but the actual oysters were also mediocre - the breading was crisp and crunchy (cornmeal), but you couldn't really taste the oyster at all.  We also ordered the veal meatballs which were good if a bit too salty.  

The real winner of the night was dessert - butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme.  Large enough (1.5 cups worth?) for sharing!  Absolutely delicious.
author: A C.

description:
I just had to...the other night I went to Salt House and loved it so last night I had to go to Town Hall and see which of the two sisters I liked better.  As with this and all dilemmas alike...I like them both!  

I was at Town Hall w/ a few friends to share some plates and conversation.  The conversations were entertaining.  The food...

Tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes & Tabasco green onion vinaigrette - DELICIOUS!
BBQ shrimp w/ worcestershire and garlic herb toast - NOT BAD
Roasted baby beets & shaved fennel, arugula, goat cheese & sliced apricots - YUM!
Slow-roasted duck with wild rice, pecans, spiced dates, & gingersnap gravy - INTERESTING!
Grilled Niman Ranch ribeye steak , chanterelle mushrooms, roasted garlic white bean puree & marchand de vin butter - NICELY DONE & TENDER!

Back to back nights with the sister restaurants trying to figure out which one I liked better...Hey, who said you had to like one better than the other!  Conclusion, they're both pretty damn good...at least on these 2 nites
author: Rick P.

description:
We came for Dine About Town, but I decided to order a burger based on the DAT menu.  After a very long wait, I finally got my well done burger that I had ordered medium rare.  And it was pretty small.  

For $17, not including tax and tip, I'm not impressed.  Our server was nice though.
author: hag a.

description: For me, there are very few restaurants that have been as consistently solid over the years in SF as Town Hall. It's great for any occasion (Tuesday lunch, date night, dinner with the family, etc.). You'll never have the absolute most amazing meal of your life, but neither will you walk away feeling unsatisfied. Great vegetarian options as well. The service is great, and I will keep coming back.
author: sar h.

description:
I've eaten at Town Hall twice and both times the food was excellent. 

Town Hall's food is southern-influenced and specifically New Orleans-specific. They make the best, lightest, flakiest biscuits I've ever had outside of my grandmother's kitchen and these paired with salty Virginia ham and spiced marmalade make for a really amazing appetizer. The chopped salad is ok - nothing to write home about and the calamari and andouille sausage was really, really good with an excellent balance of acidity and salt.

The fried chicken was another worthwhile dish but I quibble with the heaviness of the breading on the chicken. Gravy and smashed potatoes were authentic - the gravy in particular.

Desserts are always a treat in a southern kitchen and Town Hall's are no exception. The toffee cake was superb - a big part of the enjoyment of food is the contrast of texture and this is particularly important in desserts. The toffee cake mixes fluffy cake with crunchy bits of toffee and sweet, rich ice cream for an experience that won't leave you disappointed.

I take a star away because the noise level is out-of-control here owing to the brick walls. They could easily control this by using acoustic dampening techniques on the ceiling - but other than that Town Hall is a southern food lover's dream.
author: Shane H.

description:
I've been for lunch, dinner and for the takeaway lunch. I'd have to say that the two lunches were my best experiences - the dinner was a bit too high of a price point for the service (mediocre) and meal that we got (the food seemed off a bit). Lunch is more do able and you can get some of the marquee dishes at lunch for a more reasonable price. The decor is fun and unique -  I love the chandeliers in the restaurant - so pretty!

I'd have to say that I LOVE their takeway lunch. I had the hot sausage with pepper and onions and it was insanely good. Nice snap and heat and the onions and peppers were a perfect, slightly sweet compliment. The huge Acme roll did a good job of sopping up any errant juices. The grapefruit lemonade and sweet tea (yay, make your own arnold palmer) was a nice tart sweet accompaniment. 

My lunch companion had the pulled pork topped with cole slaw and being from North Carolina, is a de facto expert on bbq. He was in love from the first bite!!! Said the pork was perfection and the cole slaw had a great tang, without being too sodden with mayonnaise.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Nice food and nice wine.  Would prefer not to sit at a table right in the gangway next time though.  Standard of food was really good!
author: Harriet P.

description:
the food was really good, but not everything was outstanding. here's the breakdown:

the good:
-easy parking
-friendly and knowledgeable server
-a yummy non-alcoholic version of one of their cocktails
-appetizer: tuna tartare, soup of the day with heirloom tomatoes and crab
-main: crispy sweet corn ravioli with mushrooms and truffle butter
-dessert: sticky toffee cake with ice cream. YUM! probably the star of the night. my friend practically licked the plate clean!

the not-so-good:
-busboy (? not sure what to call him) didn't know who ordered what, and brought us the wrong dessert at first
-very noisy, so it was hard to carry on convo
-croquettes and jambalaya side dishes were unremarkable. i'd even go so far as to say the jambalaya was almost inedible -- too sweet and kinda wet and salty

i definitely want to go back, if only to try the butterscotch pot de creme that everyone raves about... but also because overall, it was one of the better dining experiences i've had in SF. not perfect, but pretty darn good.
author: Clara K.

description: Town hall would have been one star if our waiter was as nasty as that hostess in the tight short blue dress. Fortunately for our waiter he was very nice.  However, we were a  work team of 8. Our initial drink order took at least 20 minutes at 4:30. Not a busy time.  Nor were we ever asked if we wanted food.  We didn't see our waiter again for another 30 minutes at least.  My favorite was when we left after being there for 2 hours were rudely presented instructions to the bathroom location by the crabby hostess in the blue dress.
author: Serena W.

description:
I would love to give this place at least four stars possibly five. But I just can't do it! 

The location is fabulous - a high-walled original old red-brick building, juxtaposed with a modern steel glass skyscraper complete with shipped and installed stone monoliths in the courtyard. 

Stark simple California decor inside, with large, arty and sometime disturbing, always thought-provoking black and white prints around the walls. Excellent, polite, attentive, friendly service. Delicious food - look in the dictionary under California French Italian fusion cuisine and there is a picture of a red-brick building. People had fish, meat, salads, sides, scallops - and all were delicious. Desserts were too good to choose from - we had the lightest profiteroles I have had since I left the UK, and an excellent butterscotch chocolate pot de creme. A nice Meritage and americanos to wash it all down. MMM, MMM, MMM!!!

So, why not five stars this time, Kingpin. When this place first opened, I must have gone five or six times in the first year. Now I remember why I stopped going - just too friggin expensive! $125 plus tip for two vegetarians - it was tasty, but it wasn't THAT good!
(Need more veggie options too!)
author: Kingpin X.

description:
The first time I ate at Town Hall was about four years ago when it first opened. I was not impressed. It was probably because it was brand new and my dining experience was based off a large dinner party.

My friend and I came here for dinner tonight and I'm so glad I did! Town Hall is everything what everyone raves about. We started off with the tuna tartare. I love how restaurants actual split the appetizers on two separate plates when you order to "share." The fish was fresh and sauce drizzled on the crostini was really good.

I had the braised short ribs for my entree. The two slices of braised ribs were so soft and tender. It melted in my mouth. I ate the whole thing. My friend's Atlantic cod and mussels were really delicious too.

For dessert, I had the apple crumble. I absolutely loved it. Thin layers of spiced cake, sweeten apples, and oat crumbles were all stacked on top of each other then topped with a large scoop of vanilla bean ice cream!!!! YUMMY! Since my friend is in LOVE with the butterscotch and chocolate creme, he had to order that for himself. I had a tasted of his and that was really good too. The bottom layer was chocolate and the top was butterscotch. It was topped with crunchy pieces of hard chocolate butterscotch candy.

Every course of wonderful. The prices are fairly more expensive, but the food was worth it. Although it was a Tuesday night, this place was quite busy, so the service wasn't that attentive. So that's why only 4 stars.
author: Denise L.

description:
Been here a few times, and it has been consistent, although not everything I have had was outstanding.  I am giving four stars because certain things on the menu give me a craving that wakes me up at night.

Faith's warm ham and cheese toast with poached egg and jalapeno cream is the most amazing thing I have had here.   It is like a croque madame with Jalapenos cream...I am salivating as I write this.  

The fried green tomato with the Tuna Tar tare is pretty good, and a pleasant combination.  Everybody does squash blossoms these days, but I would have to say this one is better than most.  The cheese is perfectly stuffed and fried (I liked these much better than Batali's version a mozza in LA).  Last, although not the best fried chicken I have had, it is better than most of the restaurants in the city.

People say it is loud, and it can be.  If you come for the ham & cheese toast, you won't care about the noise, because you won't want anyone to hear you moaning with delight anyway.
author: Kapeli M.

description: We dinner here  and was great. It has a southern them but everything made fresh. We started with the meatballs and they were out of this world. Price was good for it's locations.
author: Justin B.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in the city. It's hip yet comfortable - attracting a good mix of ages and types - artsy and corporate comfortably blending together at this hearty modern American restaurant and bar. 

The communal table in the front, patio and bar area are filled with friendly, noisy [and usually quite attractive] types interested in mingling and chatting. Appetizers are inventive and prices reasonable. The noise level can be high and public areas crowded, but that's part of the appeal. The knock: the out of the way bathrooms [around the corner, up the stairs, turn left....etc].
author: John B.

description:
If you had told me that a fancy-shmancy looking place could give me a fried chicken fix for the ages, I would not have believed it.  Oh.  My.  Chicken.

The only way this fried chicken, which must bathe in buttermilk for about a month, could get any better is if they put a takeout window on the sidewalk and sold it by the bucket.  Greens?  Amazing.  Mashed potatoes?  Amazing.  How could you go wrong with "bacon gravy"?

The wife was amply satisfied with a very fresh butter lettuce salad and the pork slider plate (an app., but plenty of food for her appetite).

The butterscotch chocolate pot de creme was sick.  Not even fair.  I wanted to lick the bowl.

The space is loud and the service lagged at times, but overall this was a five-star experience all the way.  Can't wait to get back and try all the other tasties on TH's menu.
author: Daryl E.

description:
The Good:
1. The butter leaf salad was outstanding despite being a little heavy on the bleu cheese. Will try to recreate at home. 
2. The seafood etouffee was delicious.
3. Ambiance was very nice. Nice atmosphere, crowd, and feel.

The SoSo:
1. I was expecting more from the buttermilk fried chicken given it was $22. The crust texture was nice but it needed more seasoning. 
2. The service was a little slow, we had to wait around for 15 minutes despite having a 8:30PM reservation and it took a while to get bread.

Overall:
Given the prices, I was expecting a little bit more, but at least some of the dishes are quite impressive. I may bump up to 4 stars if next time is better.
author: Doug M.

description:
oh em gee.  

I'll keep this short and sweet.  Keep doing what you're doing Town Hall, because you're doing it right.  

The combination of Tuna Tartare and Fried green tomatoes with a Tobasco vinaigrette was a borderline religious experience.  INCREDIBLE oysters on the half shell.  The Fried Chicken with bread pudding stuck to every bone in my body and made my heart smile.  And finally the infamous Chocolate Butterscotch Pot-de-creme....it was everything I dreamed it would be....only larger.  

Just a footnote, Town Hall's chandelier light-fixtures are works of art in themselves.  They kind of have the shape of fireworks and are lovely to look at has you're shoveling your mouth with 5 days worth of calories.  

Happy Birthday to me.  Now I'm off to fat camp.
author: Kerry D.

description:
Amazing meal, cocktails and wine! We took two attorneys visiting from San Diego to dinner here, and they said it was one of the best meals they'd had in a long time...Here's our fave's:

-Moscow Mule Cocktail: Spot On
-Cheese Bread App: our table wanted to lick the plate...dipped bread in it. Enough said. 
-Tuna Tartar: Delicious. Fried green tomatoes best I've had. Would come and get this for lunch!
-Jalapeno corn bread: perfect little fingerling sizes with nice hint of jalapeno and sweetness. 
-Fried Chicken: Perfection
-Pork Loin/Belly: Amazing flavor and perfect balance have both on plate
-Halibut: Cooked perfectly
-Pot de Creme: OMG

Good but not something to write home about:  
-BBQ Shrimp Appo
-Gumbo Side
author: Erin T.

description:
Met friends at Town Hall restaurant tonight in SF. Plenty of free parking nearby on a rainy Sunday evening. We had great service and all enjoyed our meals - my dinner: rib eye steak, fresh veg & taters w/ Italian red wine (rosso di montalcino). Lemon cheesecake parfait. Perfection. My bf had the pork loin - not AS good, but he loved the black eyed peas...wished they served him another helping! 

I'd eat here again...
author: Jenn P.

description:
Went to town hall on the suggestion of fellow Yelpers. Made a reservation for 7pm on a Monday and were seated a couple minutes early.

Our waitress was attentive and the atmosphere was fantastic.

The food is best described as Southern cooking kicked up a notch.  The oysters were fresh, the ribs fantastic, and they even had their twist on corn bread that I finished in two bites.
author: Chad K.

description:
The point of fine dining is to enjoy yourself. From the AWFUL MARTINI to the UNDER-COOKED MEAT Town Hall has to be one of the most annoying dining experiences I've encountered. 

For example, before we sat down for dinner, I ordered a drink from the bar. I found it hard to believe that they actually had two different size martini glasses. One might expect these proportions at a tacky caberet show in Reno or Waikiki but not at a restaurant that would like to be thought of as upscale. 

They insisted that the larger standard size martini glasses were for juice martinis such as cosmos or lemon drops and the small martini glasses were for the classic martini. Either way,  they measure out meticulously, 2 ounces which they insist to be the standard. And, it may be the scientific standard but owner's Mitchell & Steven Rosenthal are penny-wise and pound-foolish.

Having just returned from NYC and frequented local pubs to renown restaurants such as Picholine, One If By Land Two If Sea, and Fiolrellos (across from Lincoln center) all these establishments served martinis in the conventional size glass that at least was a 3 to 3.5 ounce pour. Furthermore, Boulevard, Gary Danko and Hayes Street Grill in San Francisco all serve full pours around 3 - 3.5 which leads me to believe that the management at Town Hall are knowingly cheating their customers and unfortunately, not enough of them have spoken up about this rip-off or know any better.

Here is a step=by-account of how Town Hall manages to create THE WORST MARTINI IN AMERICA...

1) The bartender dumps the ice out of the mini martini glass and then proceeds to make the martini (which took several minutes) defeating the purpose of a chilled glass. (It is customary to immediately empty the glass of ice and then pour the freshly stirred martini into the glass optimizing the chilled effect.) 

2) I ask for two olives and he gives me one. 

3) Then I realize that there is no way two olives (conventional) would fit in this miniscule martini glass. (At least he did something right.) 

4) The olive is huge (the size of a walnut), thus displacing liquid and making it appear there is more vodka than there actually is. 

5) I bite into the thick, walnut-size, leathery textured olive and almost break my tooth on the olive pit (I can only imagine the olives came from one of those disgusting gallon size SYSCO cans.) Who in their right mind serves a martini with an olive that has a pit?!! 

6) This miniscule, wretched, worst excuse for a martini I've ever had the displeasure of attempting to enjoy is $12.50. I paid $14.00 in NYC but it was not a problem because the drink was 3 - 3.5 ounces in a standard martini glass and I expect costs are relatively higher in NYC.

When we sat down at our table. I mentioned the penurious martini to our waiter who sent over a two-ounce measuring cup to try to prove something to me. She then sends over the manager who introduces himself as Mr. "Can I help you with something?", instead of introducing himself by his name and title. I have no idea who this stranger is standing next to me and ask "who are you?" He then properly introduces himself as the assistant manager and basically doesn't give a hoot about the size of traditional martinis, etc. because the house is packed and you can barely hear yourself amongst the din and clamor. 

No apologies. They just do not get it. Or, they do get it as in, "We, Mitchell & Steven Rosenthal, choose to be miserly with alcohol because most of our customers do not know any better and we will ignore the periodic complaints".

We then order, and request well-done, the Beef short ribs and Hanger steak ($30). Then some random server places it in front of us and we ask "Are you sure this is well-done?" He says "Yes". (We assume he knows what he is talking about because we assume he was well-trained by the maître d' / manager and instructed by the waiter) However, this is not the case.

The beef short ribs were well-done and the hangar steak was so raw you could not slice it with the knife provided. Now, from my experience, the job of well-trained wait staff is to oversee the food as it comes out of the kitchen and if it does not meet the request of the customer or the standards set-forth by the maître d' / manager they send it back. A well-trained waiter is the intermediary between the kitchen and the customer. The beef short ribs were very good as well as the little tater-tots. The mushy blended-potato goo (a la baby food texture) was not necessary. 

The appetizers were very good. We had stuffed peppers and the Ahi Tuna Tartar. 

If you choose to go to this restaurant, only order appetizers and drink water (The wine pours appeared to be following the same game plan as the martinis) Who wants to be irritated when going out to dinner. It defeats the whole point. 

Our manager & waiter had an aloof attitude because the restaurant was packed, but with amateur service and a greedy alcohol policy the tide may turn.
author: VC m.

description:
Went to Town Hall last night.  I think that this is a very solid 5-star restaurant.

One thing that I can say is that this is a very SF restaurant.  There is a 'community' table in the front for people with no reservations or people dining solo.  

We started with the Veal meatballs.  They were (as most everyone else said) fantastic, cooked to perfection, the peppercorn sauce was a nice touch that wasn't over powering the delicateness of the Veal.  Along with that we tried the Tuna tare tare.  It was good, the fish was nice.  I think that the Tabasco vinaigrette was a bit overpowering.  Still very delicious.

We got a bottle of wine on our servers recommendation.  She hit a home run.  It was fantastic.  Paired with all of our entrees wonderfully.

Speaking of Entrees, they took forever.  I mean forever.  We are all used to waiting for our food to be prepared and having a casual dinner.  It took over an hour.  It wasn't until about 45 minutes that our server even said anything.

Then finally 4 minutes before the food came out we got a few cups of the soup.  It was a nice gesture but really, we could have used it about 20 minutes before they brought it.

I will say that the food was worth the wait.  The food here is fun.  You really want to just tear into it.  I had a Pork Chop that was crusted in Tasso ham and peanuts.  It was cooked to perfection, the starches that came with it were also good, not remarkable.

The others had a rib-eye and the rabbit.  Both were fantastic.  The steak (although cooked too rare) was really the most stand out plate.  It was served in a rich buttery sauce and a baked potato stuffed with Chantrele mushrooms, Fontina cheese and Craw fish.  The potato could have been its own meal.

The desserts were ridiculous.  Everyone here is correct.  The Pots de' Creme is off the chain.  We also had the dough nuts filled with Scharfen Burger (sp?) chocolate, it was good but I think that the pots de' creme is just too good. Go try it.

UPDATE:

Get anything with the Jalapeno cream sauce. It will change your life.
author: Thadd L.

description:
Lots has already been said about Town Hall, so I'll keep it brief....

Came here for a long lunch and the food was delicious, of course, but I must say I really enjoyed the service.  Everyone -- from the host to the bussers to the various wait staff with whom we interacted -- was wonderfully attentive and friendly in a non-intrusive way.  They really made the experience that much more memorable and enjoyable.  

After years of having Town Hall on my To Try list, I will absolutely be returning soon for dinner to sample the fried chicken.  The service sealed the deal for me.
author: daphne w.

description:
So, I just went here for my birthday (01/02) and have never eaten here before so take this for what it's worth. The service was great. A very attentive staff. However, everything I seemed to put in my mouth had too much salt on it. Ok, just the table butter (too salty) and my ribeye steak. (I was soo looking forward to this.) My girlfriend had the porkchop which came out juicy and nicely flavored so all was not lost. And the butterscotch dessert that apparently everyone in SF has had at this point was seriously - OK, but not IMHO worth the praise it's getting here. It's dressy chocolate mousse. 

Try it out but get ready to drink lots of water, unless they just made a mistake when I was there.
author: chris m.

description:
Yum.  And Free.  Thank god for client dinners right?

This place has great atmosphere, great service, great food.  Its all around great.

Speaking of clients.  They are making me work right now so this is getting cut short.  Gotta pay attention to the meal ticket!
author: Ian M.

description:
The restaurant doesn't need another review, but I have to say that I came with a particular need and Town Hall spectacularly filled it.  We had a very early morning meeting on Friday, so we needed an early dinner Thursday night at a close by restaurant that wouldn't take hours and hours.

We were seated immediately.  We started with two custom drinks, not as good as Frisson, but tasty.  James had the tuna tartare and the green fried tomatoes were remarkable.  I had the bbq shrimp. Pretty spicy, but I ate every bite.  How could I resist the duck?  I rarely can.  It was great, but so was James' quail and his came with Anson Mills grits.  I really dislike most grits, but I can never have enough of these stone ground beauties.  We also skip most desserts, but bread pudding?  Warm apple caramel tart?  We ate every bite and rolled home.

Yes, it is crowded.  Yes, it is noisy.  Yes, it is somewhat expensive.  But you should know what to expect coming here.  Their menu is posted online and with over 500 reviews there shouldn't be many surprises.  We've been here before and we can't wait to go back again.
author: Kathryn D.

description: I've been wanting to go to Town Hall for quite some time, finally made it a few weeks ago. It was a really good experience over all - delicious food, excellent service, great ambiance. I had the chicken which was great, my friend had the gnocchi and we had the rhubarb almond crumb cake for dessert. It was delicious.
author: An S.

description:
Hear ye, hear ye.
On our adenda today is American food with some Southern Twist.
Motion to go straight for the crispy, juice fried chicken, oysters and the donuts and coffee (beinets), 
Motion to skip the jambalaya, biscuits, and soup, carried.  
All opposed?  *silence*
Shall be the order of this yelper.
author: Jane L.

description: Great service and good food.  It is load.  Business dinners can be a bit challenging due to the sound.  The upstairs private room is awesome.
author: T C.

description:
Shockingly good.  I say that because a lot of restaurants with a big rep seem to just fall flat.  

Really liked the space, which is essentially divided into three sections: main dining area, bar and communal table.  There also is an outside seating area, but that looked like it was set up for a special group, and a private dining room.  Anyway, we ate at the bar, which is very warm and inviting, and very close to the kitchen so we got our food pretty fast.  Bartender was great--friendly but not in our face.  I dont know if it was because we got there early, but the noise level was very low, except for the barking orders coming from the kitchen, which was kind of entertaining.  This restaurant has great lighting fixtures.

We started out with the soup of the day, which was heirloom tomato with an herb biscuit and cream floating on top.  We also had the heirloom tomato fondu, served with fried squash, toast and broccoli.  Our final starter was the tuna tartare, served with fried green tomatos, garlic chips and a spicy onion vinaigrette.  We split the halibut, served with bay shrimp, sweet corn pudding, peas and morels, as an entree.  For dessert it was the butterscotch and chocolate pot-de-creme, with toffee chunks on top.  It was huge!  Best to split it.

Overall, the food was great and flavorful.  Portion sizes are excellent.  Very cute how they deliver the bill inside of individual books, in which people have written comments.  Kind of like a portable bathroom stall.  I really dont have a complaint about this restaurant.

Okay, one downside is that the bathroom is quite a long trekk from dining area.  However, there is an entire wall of windows overlooking a neat piece of artwork outside--a poem about an echo etched into another wall across the alley--that you can ponder on the way up and down the stairs.  Your perspective certainly changes depending on how full your bladder is.
author: brewgirl b.

description:
Ok...even though my coworkers are obsessed with the BBQ here, I have to say, I have had MUCH better for MUCH cheaper. 

I can't speak to the regular menu(s) here, but they do BBQ every day outside of my building, and people flock to this crap. I am sorry, but a teensy tiny sandwich, which has more cole slaw filler than BBQ is NOT worth $8. And a 1/4 slab of ribs for $8??? ARE YOU SERIOUS? Not to mention the fact that they WAY over-char the ribs, and the meat to rib ratio is obscenely off...we're talking you are paying $15 (1/2 slab) for about two ribs worth of meat. Fairly pathetic in my book.

I guess folks in SF are starved for proper BBQ, so they think this is a good deal, but I am sorry, I have had BBQ all over the south and east, and this is not only mediocre (at best) but the portions are ludicrous.

Do yourself a favor...go to KC's BBQ in Berkeley and have some real ribs and 'que - this place is subpar.
author: Marco M.

description: This place is warm and welcoming.  Been there twice now, both for dinner.  The waiters and bartenders are very friendly and knowledgeable.  Tight quarters.... but great atmosphere.  Save room for desert... the butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme tastes smooth and velvety.  Worth the calories!
author: Kristen S.

description:
empty.


i once wrote a special note to someone in a book. i named the book and page number in my review. apparently, people who have read my review and dined at this establishment have asked for the book by name. 

I have removed it, but I thank you all for reading.
author: Susy C.

description:
A colleague and I went to have a couple of drinks, Friday after work.  We belly up to the bar and order a couple of scotches over ice. The bartendresses seemed a bit unsettled and were inattentive. Unless another person on staff came over to the bar. The one bartender that originally took our order was running to the kitchen, taking entrees to the patio, chewing on her nails,  socialising with her co-workers, everything but looking after our empty glasses.
Eventually, I had to ask the other bartender for another round. 

When it was time to check out, the original inattentive bartender printed out the ticket and placed it on the bar. We looked it over and said "Whoa, this is not correct".  The bartender came over and said "There is a $2 charge for ice."
x4 drinks is $8 for ice.

People, I have never ever heard of such a thing!

We were so miffed about this and the bartender (with attitude) picked up the receipt, turned back around to the register, turned back around slapped down the receipt, and said "I took it off, I took off $2." Then she darted to the other side of the bar. First off the minus $2 is not even worth the energy. 

I have eaten at Town Hall several times and thing their food is good but this tacky incident of charging for ice will prevent me from ever going there again.
author: ytze y.

description:
I guess the true reason I love this place is because the first time I had dinner at Town Hall, I had met up with an old love who flew in for the night and we reignited the flame here. And for that, Town Hall will always have a soft spot in my heart. 

But despite my personal bias, it is also an excellent restaurant. The service is absolutely outstanding. The food is rich and flavorful. I think this is an excellent choice to meet up with someone special- the food is great, the wine fantastic, and the ambiance romantic -reminded me of a Boston for some reason.
author: Anna S.

description:
Came here for my work's holiday dinner on Saturday and the service, food and drinks (which was open bar) were unbelievable. We had our own private dining area located on the second floor and the ambiance was so homey. It reminded me when my brother was living in Chicago and his place, one entire wall was brick. It was cozy, warm and festive. 

The food: Our choices for starter were, house salad or tuna tartare, main entree salmon or filet mignon and dessert butterscotch toffee pudding or (I forgot but it reminded me of a molten volcano). I had tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes which were okay, Rubicon, which is closed now had the best I've ever had. Entree I had the filet mignon and let me tell you about the filet mignon. It was soft as ba-ddur and medium rare (the way I like it.) I didn't have to use my steak knife since my fork did all the cutting, that is how soft it was. The flavor was not over powering since I've been told by one of my BFF's daddy who is homegrown from Texas, "A great steak is when you throw it on a grill with salt and pepper and let it sizzle until you can barely hear the mooing." Town Hall hit it perfectly on this one. And dessert, I had the butterscotch toffee pudding and it was silky on my tongue. Mmmmmmmmmm, mouth is watering as I write this. 

Town Hall receives 4 stars from me: 

One for the warm cozy homey ambiance. 
One for the service. 
One for the food, which so far was amazing. 
And one for the filet mignon. This receive a star alone due to the soft as bu-ddar and perfect grilling.
author: Kathy T.

description:
First, let me say that I do not enjoy writing negative reviews any more than I enjoy being treated poorly in a restaurant, but when the latter occurs, I feel compelled to do the former.
I called Town Hall at around 9 pm to confirm their closing time (11 pm), and to ascertain whether or not we needed a reservation. I was told we didn't need to make a reservation.
When we arrived, the hostess (charming) pulled menus and began to lead us into the restaurant, but she was halted a man to whom she yielded, so I imagine he was a manager. He spun all of us around and directed us to a long table between the two doors, basically the foyer. I balked because one door was wide open, and the other was open, with two red curtains, and it was cold and raining. He was very pushy, calling the table "intimate," and we all finally relented so as to not make a scene. Big mistake. The door behind me led to the bathrooms, an upstairs room, and outdoors. The door to the outside remained open for the entire time we were there, and everyone in the place, including wait staff, was going in and out, huge garbage cans were dragged through the outside door, around 20 people clattered up and down the stairs (with potted orchids), one man dropped/slammed a bound pallet of dismantled cardboard boxes on the threshold that sounded like a gunshot. Meanwhile I fairly froze to death. And the wait station was right at the table, so waiters were clattering about right behind my husband and my son. We could hardly hear each other.
Meanwhile, dessert, which is what we really came for, was lackluster. The peanut butter and chocolate torte which remains on the online menu, has not been a feature of their menu "for a long time" according to our waiter. "We don't update the online stuff very often." Good to know. The pot de creme was...meh, the apple spice stayed warm only a minute situated between the January blasts of two open doors. My friend's coffee had large grounds floating on the surface. 
After we paid, I spoke to a manager (?) about the situation. She seemed sincere, but dense, telling me not once, but five times, "Oh, that door is supposed to be closed at all times," as if repeating it would change the reality.
She made no offer to comp, but she did apologize, while reiterating the other manager's claim that the table was "intimate." With a wait station 1 1/2 feet away, two open doors, and an endless stream of people coming and going...intimate, my a$$. We'd have been more intimate if we'd sat on the stones outside.
With all the wonderful, welcoming, WARM, restaurants in SF and on the peninsula, I can't imagine why anyone would go out of his/her way for this joint.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Town Hall is a good establishment for San Francisco. The food is good - and is great for a casual dinner. The restaurant is on the louder side, so if you do go there for a date, do not expect intimate conversation as you probably will spend a lot of your time yelling, or saying WHAT at the end of every thought your date says.

What this place is good for is a social gathering between friends. The food is good - I had the steak - and let me tell you, the steak was so tender, you could cut it with a butter knife...and I did! The jalapeno corn bread was a great treat.

The fun part of the experience was ironically at the end when they present you your bill tucked into, what it seemed for my friends and i was a porn novel. To which everyone signed the book and left hillarious messages - to which we all followed suit. What a good way to proclaim your disdain or love for the hyphy movement in the text of a porn novel - or to add your own thoughts to the story, haha!

Overall, this is a fun place with good food. I'd recommend this if you had not yet visited. A good addition to the SF restaurant scene.
author: Brian D.

description:
One of my *fave* SF restaurants.  I have brought many a friend and colleague here, and they dig it.  If you arrive early enough, you can try to snag the community table that rests between the front door and the bar.  It's a perfect spot for large group mingling.  There is also a private room upstairs, but that is away from the lively town hall ("th") din.  

On to food:  you have likely not tasted anything as artery-hardening, down-home good as the warm ham and cheese toast.  It is topped with a poached egg as well as a jalapeno cream sauce that I would kill for.  My favorite entree is the quail, which isn't currently on the menu because th is very picky about quality, and it's apparently hard to find a good piece of quail (get it?!--hardy har har) right now.  The fried chicken is quite yummy and comes as two pieces, a frenched breast and leg/thigh--perfect for sharing if you have a white meat lover and a dark meat lover.  

As for wine:  th's daily list (on the back of the menu) is pretty good, but if you have a pretty penny to spend, ask for the wine board.  There are some damn fine wines on that list.  I love the big, earthy Tuscan varietals, and th has been able to satisfy my cravings.

If you're table dining, as for Andrea; she is by far the best server I have had there, and she is hot and nice.   And if you're at the bar, order from Zeke. He rocks with the drinks and is very easy on the eyes as well.

th is on opentable.com, so making reservations easy.  Note, however, that they book up very, very quickly.
__________________________
Update 06/05/2008

Brought five colleagues (two newbies) to Town Hall last night for drinks and apps at the community table.  Due to the good times and vibe, we ended up staying there for dinner, and everyone loved the food (even a Texan who ordered the fried chicken).  And th had the quail back on the menu!  Yay!

Btw, not many options for vegans, but the kitchen is willing to throw something (healthy--ick) together.
author: Kimberly Q.

description:
I came in here to check out the building for a School Project years ago, and decided to stay for dinner... go back whenever anyone is down anymore.... but here's the first time, because there's nothing like the FIRST time ;)

Yes the menu is a bit lacking, and the prices are a bit inflated... but the food is still fabulous! I tend to remember the servers at restaurants, but here... not so much. Not that he didn't do a great job, but I was so entertained sitting at the "communal" table! If you don't make reservations (and I never do) then you end up sitting at a table set for 10-12... and it's really the best. A great way to meet new people and taste new foods. I have a steak (as always) and my brother the fried chicken (was very disappointed to find out that they don't serve it for lunch... darn!) and the broccoli fondue is SOOO great! 3.5 hours and a clogged artery later we left full and very content... great place!
author: B W.

description: Sat there for 2 hours after our 9pm reservation, and the only thing they served us was drinks. We arrived at 9 and were told that our table wasnt ready. We were seated at the common bar table, for 11. We ordered our food 1 hour ago, and every 15 minutes our waitress tells us "it's being plated".  They've made no accommodations for us, or acceptable reason.
author: Amy L.

description:
Take out Review: 
All was well, limited menu for the outdoor take out area. We opted for the pulled bbq chicken sandwich and their famous fried chicken sandwich. They were both ok, served on nice crusty rolls with coleslaw, the slaw had a bit too much vinegar in it. The chips were delish, with some kind of bbq seasoning, homemade fo sho. I did not care for the grapefruit lemonade it was way too tart. A-Ok really is an appropriate description.
author: La C.

description:
A pile of pork with pork on top is nice
spring grits with green stuff is truly unique
but sticky toffee pudding "takes the cake"
away from a mere veg'table like leek.
author: April D.

description:
Three stars = Fair, average

While we did not receive "poor" service and the food wasn't "that bad"....this place certainly has "opportunity for improvement."

Just hit up Town Hall yesterday for lunch. Not being too hungry, I ordered from the appetizer section as did my coworker.  However, while one is perusing a menu a glass of water would be nice.....on the second request the waters came out....but it took an additional third reminder to bring out the lemon and the straws (is that really too much to ask in a place that has a price range in the $$$ category?).

I ordered the Buttermilk Biscuits with Ham and Peach Marmalade.  My hunger palate was quite intrigued by this offering and the idea of having a little bit of a "weekend style" breakfast during the lunch hour was even more pleasing. As mentioned before - the food wasn't too bad.  The ham (aka prosciutto) was a bit on the salty side for my taste...but the biscuits and marmalade made the meal....they could have held their own with any Southern Style diner.  Of course, since I had ditched my ham and was planning to sustain my myself with just the biscuits (did I mention they are small?  about the circumference of a quarter and you only receive three of them), I would have appreciated a bit more biscuit love - maybe a double order?

All in all - will I go back?  Sure - but whether I go back anytime soon, that is another story entirely.
author: Kim A.

description:
And I thought that you had to go to a steak joint to get a good Rib Eye. I stand corrected. Unbelievably tender and flavorful... it's making my mouth water just thinking about it. Oh wait, I should've mentioned the appetizers first. The BBQ shrimp had the most wonderful aroma and the sauce was great for dipping your extra bread. The Tuna Tartare with Fried Green Tomatoes was decent but the tomatoes didn't taste as good as the ones I had while visiting the South.

I was hoping that since this restaurant had Southern influences that there would be some bread pudding on the menu but the Strawberry Shortcake with Chantilly Cream held its own.

Be sure to make reservations - it was pretty crowded even on an off night.
author: Kristi K.

description:
Plain and Simple - this is one of those places where you can't go wrong...

I've been a couple times and don't have anything negative to say.  The service was fantastic, good wine list, friendly bartender, delicious dishes, nice ambiance

Take a date, take a friend, charge it on the company's dime, just go :)
author: Nina B.

description:
I had a pretty disappointing dinner here last night.  Service was remarkably bad considering the restaurant wasn't completely full at the time (9:20PM).  We first waited some time to get acknowledged by our waitress and then we waited and additional 20 minutes to get a basket of cold bread (after we had asked for bread twice).   

We got an appetizer of stuffed fried cheese-stuffed zucchini blossoms.  The dish was quite tasty but rather small (three small blossoms) so we were looking forward to our main course.  I ordered the famous fried chicken while my boyfriend got the short ribs.  

This is the part that drove the experience from, 3  star to 2 star.  Our entrees took close to an hour to arrive. By the time our entrees arrived, around 10:30, we were ready to eat our tablecloths. 

Now for the food...I first noticed that the portions seem to be smaller than when I remembered from my first visit earlier in the year.  My boyfriends' short ribs were luke-warm.  My chicken was hot and crispy but the accompanying mashed potatoes and snap peas were just warm.  Obviously we were not going to send the food back for reheating at this time so we didn't mention this to our waitress.  The food was definitely not worth the wait and the non-present, amateur service was surprising for a restaurant of this price level.
author: Anna S.

description:
I must preface this review by saying I have this friend who has the hook up everywhere we go. Or maybe we only go places where he has the hook up. Doesn't matter. We got an in in the kitchen here so there's my disclosure.
This means we got to try a lot of things.
Wait scratch that, Lots of delicious things!
I can't decide which sauce I would prefer to drown in, the spicy Worcestershire one the prawns were lounging in or the jalapeno bechamel, wait I can't remember what the bechamel was served on, oh that's probably because my friend just ordered a bucket of it and we took turns chugging from it. 
All of our food was delicious, our servers were a delight, the atmosphere was lively and I felt that  the prices were quite reasonable.
Town Hall I will be coming back to you regularly, have the bucket ready.
author: Melissa H.

description:
When a restaurant has 323 reviews, why write another?  Because the squash blossoms (appetizer) and the stuffed pork chop (entree) are simply amazing.  Both get five stars.

I was on a business trip, so I dined solo at the bar.  Great experience all around.
author: Michael H.

description:
Ambience was satisfactory, especially in the bar area.  The beer was cold.

When we were seated, I just sat there staring at the menu for like 10 minutes.  Nothing really sounded good to me, or maybe nothing sounded really original, as all of these "New American" restaurants seem to have the same menus.  Some kind of steak.  Some kind of pork chop.  Some kind of fried chicken.  Some kind of something something.  Whatever.

I settled on the ribs.  They were okay.  Nothing special.  I forgot them as soon as I ate them; in fact, after I was done, I sat there thinking to myself, "Why am I full?"

Definitely not worth the hassle.  I suppose the restaurant must have done something to deserve the hype, but at this point, I'd say it's past its prime.    I think the two star rating sums it up best:  MEH!
author: Chris H.

description: We felt like Anthony Boudain is some quaint little corner of an amazing posh deli. Unpresumptious food presentation with unexpected deliciocity.The bartender helpful, chatty, but not too chatty and oh, hunky hunky.
author: perla d.

description:
Don't trust the web site for the menu, but come here any way.

Bread: Acme bread, maybe? And real soft butter? Yum.

Drinks: GET THE LOUISIANA PURCHASE. I love a sexy cocktail with a kick. YUM!! [Blackbird and Viscious Circle were unmemorable in comparison]

Starters: We had the Bibb lettuce w/ bleu - so good. The apples really brought another dimension of flavor. And the crispy squash blossoms were melt in your mouth good. I snagged the sauce to dip the rest of our bread in, but was content to eat the blossom by it's cheesey-delicious-lonesome.

Entrees: The NY strip was also melt in your mouth good. Collared greens and the reduction. Yum! My date had the pork chop with peanut tasso and dirty rice, which I bravely tried considering my usual avoidance of pork product when possible. The rice was so good, and the chop was moist despite being an inch and a half thick! We ordered a side of mac n cheese croquettes that were good, but not as good as the rest of our meal.

Dessert: I deconstruct things and eat them separate. The sticky date pudding was the first thing in my life I had that really was better together than separate. The cake was a touch dry, but the reduction on top with ice cream and peaches helped. The pot de creme was enough for two! Delicious!

Definitely hope to go back!!!
author: Angela H.

description:
