I had very high expectations of Town Hall after my partner raved about a business dinner he had there over a month ago and let me tell you, they absolutely exceeded all my expectations last night.  My partner and I truly enjoyed amazing New Orleans-style American food.  

From the tasty ham and cheese toast with poached egg (and fried okra!) to the amazing fried chicken dinner and the absolutely mind blowing peanut butter banana bread pudding with salted peanut brittle and vanilla ice cream, it was definitely a treat!!  Their fried chicken could possibly be THE BEST fried chicken I have had in the city.  It came with tasty mashed potatoes and collard greens that frankly was not bad at all.  It had a spicy kick to it.  The fried chicken, we were told, is marinated with clarified butter and Tabasco.  Seriously, forget about eating healthy... butter makes me happy!  We definitely can't wait to come back for more... more fried chicken!

The service was A+ as well.  Everyone was friendly and very attentive. The brick building was handsome in and out. And also, props on the chandy, they are very pretty.  Overall, Town Hall is outstanding.
author: Jun B.

description:
I find my self having a very hard time writing a review or Town Hall. Memories can be fallible and the more we think about an experience the more we are able to change what really happened in our minds. 

There were three of us and we shared everything. 4 app, 3 entrees and two deserts. What we ordered is not as important as how it was presented. We came later on Saturday night, the restaurant was packed and were offered to wait or sit at the bar. The bar it was. 

We asked for recommendations and were walked through the menu, recommendations and suggested pairings. We followed the suggestions with pairings and ordered and extra app. It was simply one of the best meals I have had in years. Course timing and service were impeccable. Seasoning was perfect and the presentations were flawless. The pairing recommendations complimented the food but were also great alone.

For me what made Town Hall was the staff. Not just our bartender but the other waiters, bussers, everyone. I've been on the other side of the bar and have a deep appreciation for those who serve us. The food aside it was the staff who took the great food and made it one of the best experiences I've had in a restaurant.
author: David M.

description: Don't bother getting a reservation because you will wait regardless. Service was completely absent.  Food was mediocre but definitely not worth the poor service...and pack your sneakers for the three flights of stairs to use the restroom. Save your money and head to Applebee's for comparable food and better service.
author: Mitch C.

description:
This place is very over-rated!!!  The food is pretty basic, over-priced and the service was awful.  We waited 45 minutes for our appetizers.  We then waited an additional 30 minutes after we were done with the appetizers for our main courses.  My steak then arrived lukewarm.  When we complained to mgt they just shrugged and basically said "oh well".

If you want an over-priced, basic meal where the service is lame and uncaring you probably can't do better............
author: Mark G.

description:
Chronic. Town Hall puts a foodie's spin on comfort food, much of which has a southern tang to it. And because of that, the flavors are huge and hugely delicious.
The room is also huge, the ceilings are high, and there are a few long tables up front giving the place a communal atmosphere, like Kimberly R. said. 
It's expensive but the prices reflect how happy you are after dinner and drinks here.
author: Marty S.

description:
Higher end comfort food is what this place seems to be about.  It's popular, as indicated by our set-in-stone 8.30 reservation that had been made 2 months in advance.  

We arrived early for apero hour prior to our dinner, and the extra star is partly for the unusual cocktail list.  I say unusual only because in South Lake Tahoe they've not starting introducing absinthe and mixers that harken back to the first part of the 20th century.  For all I know that's old hat in the big cities.

Service was fine - as I'd expect on a Saturday night - but our server wasn't able to help much on the wine selection.  Considering the markup I'd have hoped for better.  And despite record breaking heat in the city the night we were there, the 'heavier' comfort food wasn't a turnoff.  I had the divers scallops, which were good, but a bit skimpy for a near $30 plate ($10 a scallop? You must be joking).  Everyone else at the table had reasonable portions, so I'm wondering if I looked like I was on a diet or not hungry to the server.  In the end it wasn't a bad thing, as it allowed me to indulge in greater quantities of the butterscotch chocolate pudding and the *awesome* pumpkin sticky toffee cake.

Overall a fine place to eat, but nothing so memorable as to make it a must return.
author: Jenn G.

description:
Suits, Suits and More Suits....went for lunch it's your typical financial district sit down and strike a multimillion dollar deal type of restaurant.  The food is good the service attentive, but nothing on the menu made me scream "HOLY Mama... what is this amazingness in my mouth"  

I had a "dressed" up BLT, which means trade in the cheap bacon and put in one of these locally grown bacon with a hippie sounding name. But the highlight of my sandwich was a fried egg.  Fried egg's make everything better.  We also had a beet salad, which was good but how can you mess up a beat salad it's practically a dish when you yank it from the ground. Though i typically stay away from restaurants that don't get sushi grade tuna nonetheless we got the tuna tarter.  It was with garlic chips and fried green tomatoes interesting and good combo it was a keeper. 

If you're looking for a good lunch place to hold a business meeting or take a colleague from out of town for lunch this is your place.
author: Chung N.

description:
My sister, a friend and I had brunch at Town Hall on Sunday and OH MY was it good!  This place knows how to do brunch and apparently this is their first try a the brunch crowd.  I had heard amazing things about the fried chicken at Town Hall, and I was beyond excited to see - yes, it was on the menu for brunch.  Fried Chicken with Waffles (and bacon).  The chicken was probably the best fried chicken I've ever had in my life- ever.  The waffles were a sweeter treat and bacon was crispy not greasy.  
 
We all shared bites of our meals and all were delicious.   
We also enjoyed the cocktails- all really good- we had the bloody mary, the 212.... and a couple more... 

The server brought over some complimentary muffins/breads- the lemon blueberry muffin was to die for. 

AND for dessert- we put down the butterscotch/chocolate pot de creme- again- a real winner.  (yeah I was in a food coma for hours!)

Oh yeah and the service was stellar. 

I highly recommend this place for brunch, check it out- you won't be disappointed.  I'm sure you'll need a reservation once the brunch crowds in SF get a hold of this one.
author: Lisa K.

description:
I'm not going to deny that Town Hall's food is really good.  I've been there twice now - the menu changes daily - and each time my food has been delicious.  However, in my opinion, for what they serve, the items are way overpriced.  The other day I had fish and chips with no drink, and my bill after taxes and tip came to about $20... a bit much for fish and chips.  

We went at around 1:00 in the afternoon for lunch and got seated promptly, but it took about 40 minutes for our food to arrive!

It's a nice place with good food - I just think it's too expensive!
author: Claire H.

description: Strong. There yesterday. Cuisine excellent. Service efficient. 65$ plus per person with tip not inexpensive even skipping dessert and coffee  Veal meatballs, Louisiana flounder. Hush puppies not the same as in the real south but more than reasonable facsimiles. Good meal.
author: J H.

description:
I guess I'm the last person in San Francisco to go to this restaurant, but here it goes:

One star for the very decent, well priced food.

One star for sweet, sweet sazeracs.

One star for the extremely helpful and charming manager.

These pluses, however, were overwhelmed by the unbelievably poor service.  Don't get me wrong, I enjoy a leisurely meal, but only when there is actually food and drink to lubricate the experience.  We unwillingly spent three hours here, with two courses (could not imagine the time investment for dessert or, heavens to Betsy, an after dinner drink).  Here is an accurate play by play:

0:00  Arrive at the restaurant, and we are seated right away.  Huzzah.  When we get to the table, there is no drink menu.  Dizzam.

0:30  The first appearance of our waiter.  We express clearly that we are ready to order.  As soon as the words "I would like X bottle of wine to start," the waiter runs away.  Huh.

1:00  Our waiter returns with said bottle of wine.  He places it on a shelf while he sets a wine coaster on the table.  He then leaves.  Huh?

1:10  The aforementioned manager notices that we are drink free, even though our bottle of wine is on a shelf ten feet away.  He pours a very tasty bottle and smooths things over by being charming and affable.

1:30  Our waiter returns and takes orders.  I finally get a drink menu and order a sazerac right away, grabbing the waiter before he can run away again.

2:00  First course arrives.  Time for another sazerac.

2:30  Our waiter makes a rare appearance.  To tell us that the kitchen has run out of lamb.  While he says this, it seems like a moving sidewalk of waiters streams by with giant plates of lamb for tables that were seated way, way after us.  We order different entrees.  Definitely time for another sazerac.

2:40  The main dishes arrive.

3:00  "Let's get the fuck out of here."  Indeed.

In the interest of full disclosure, the charming manager comped our third bottle of wine and the two entrees that were lamb surrogates.  Thank you.  But I would prefer to pay for everything AND have an acceptable level of service.  Instead, I spent most of the night looking into the bewildered stares of my fellow diners and drinking sazeracs to dull my anger.
author: David C.

description:
As far as fine dining goes this is one of the greatest establishments for celebrating, collaborating, and reuniting. The menu is boasts items that are bound to satisfy that group of eclectic eaters making it a prime location to leave with nothing but full bellies and smiles. 
    The wine selection is not bad but if you have a great vintage you would like to accompany your meal Town Hall does allow outside bottles in accordance with a corking fee (very typical for most restaurants so don't feel like the staff is out to get you). 
      Okay now for my personal favorites. I was overly pleased with the halibut and for those looking for something a little more substantial in flavor I would try the short ribs in a mouth watering second (pardon the cliche tag line). Be sure to save room for desert and a few cocktails, the bartenders are not to shabby either!
author: Ryan W.

description:
I'm really big on ambiance and Town Hall has it down perfect.  Picture: "warm and cozy classy southern sophisticate with mass appeal."  Exposed warm red brick for walls, clunky furniture pieces for chairs and tables, dainty white lights hung over head, and colonial artwork strewn on the walls make this a great date spot.

I've been to Town Hall 4 times now and each experience has been enjoyable.  However, be forewarned that the service staff members can be flighty, at best.  The pot of cream is ~so-so -- definitely decadent and cavity-worthy, so for all you weak at heart and calorie-conscious kids out there, stay away!  =)
author: Katie C.

description:
Tonight was my 2nd time eating at Town Hall.  The first (2 months ago), I had very bad service and the food was good, but nothing over the top (except for the pot de  creme of course).

For my friend's b-day dinner tonight however, it was out of this world good!!  We had this amazing crab fondue, glazed baby back ribs, butter lettuce salad with pears and a killer creamy blue cheese dressing, and mushroom soup (this all to start!), then went on to trout, snapper, and finally the finishing touch of the chocolate/butterscotch pot de delight.
Clearly I'm not afraid of LARGE quantities of food (though maybe I should be)...

This is true comfort food at it's finest, with some creativity to boot.  I love the NYC vibe to the interiors!  The bar is a cool place to meet someone after work and the outdoor patio is heated and fantastic, weather permitting.  Best thing - you can actually hear yourself talking over dinner!  Despite being always crowded, it doesn't get insanely noisy...at least the two times I've been anyway.

The only complaint I have is that you have to go through an obstacle course to get to the bathroom, but if that's the only negative comment that I have...I'll take it.  This place rocks!!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Fun atmosphere, but the food is always so-so and overpriced.

Fish and chips: fish was great. chips were tastless and overfried, and tiny runts. $17.

Duck enchiladas: nice flavor, but the tortillas were so overcooked you couldn't cut it with a steak knife!  and TINY portion for $18 at lunch.
author: Melanie C.

description:
Sure, the menu's not that exciting, but people come here for the traditional, upscale American cuisine, right? Oh and the service is pretty stellar. Great for a business meal or to impress a date, but it really doesn't offer much for anything in between. I ordered a hamburger because I wasn't feeling adventurous so perhaps this average rating is partly my fault. Don't really understand why it was $15, though. 

My boss ordered the rabbit enchilada and said it was "dainty". But who orders an enchilada at a restaurant that clearly specializes in American cuisine anyway? And did he really think that they were going to plop a big fatty slab of rabbit--it's a delicacy for heaven's sake-- on his plate? People these days...
author: Natalie T.

description:
One of my favs in the city. 

Went there about a month ago and had the most amazing chopped salad (no lettuce) with a bunch of different chopped fresh vegetables including fresh peas and artichokes and sweet carrots in this amazing vinaigrette. it was so good i had to order another one. and then i dreamt about it for 2 days. mmmmm
author: Andie J.

description:
I liked the restaurant, sophisticated & well-mannered in many ways.  

My hus and I had 2 lunch sandwiches with local tap H2O, and the bill w tips was $39.   

After I had 1/3 of Pastrami sandwish & some potato chips, I felt heavy with my stomach for a few hours, and I took a short nap on the way back home.  I liked it, and I don't mind eating it again, but it wasn't for me.  Good quality meat, sauwerkraft, and the bread with caraway seed.  Potato chips were light & crisp, I think it's house made.  Oil is well rid of.  

My husband ate 2/3 Pastrami & a half Chicken breast sandwich.  He said, "Everything is good, but not worth the price."  I admit he's used to 'Togo's, but he eats on company's expense, hence, he's quite spoiled, and he knows what's good for what $.  

I'm usually cheap and cost performance is important for me, but I'm also a woman who likes pretty things.  So I tell you again, I liked the restaurant, and I don't mind coming back.

I don't know very much about SF eating, but I honestly wonder.  Do all young adult males get satisfied with their portion?  Or am I just a vulture (that's my name by my ex)?  Fish & chips looked huge, and promising in that aspect, just FYI.
author: Terri M.

description:
I was strolling through SF the other day, just a twirlin' my cane and whistling a tune. I figured I would do something different for the rest of my day because...
A) I had no cane so I was twirling my flaccid member around and I was getting way too many sneers from onlookers.
B) I can't whistle. Mainly I was blowing air and spit out of my mouth and spinning my junk. That doesn't paint a pretty picture.
My better sensibilities took over and I darted into a restaurant to escape the throbbing mob chasing me. The restaurant was called (and most likely is still called) Town Hall. I did have some signed petitions for legalizing Hostess Chocodiles to turn in. Turns out, they don't accept city paperwork, they just serve food and drink.
My friend Daniel Bello is the Maitre D and floor manager. I think they call him the Maitre D because his first name is Dan. Which would mean his title would translate to "Master Dan". Because the title Maitre D at a restaurant makes no sense. From French it literally translates to "Master of the hotel". Clearly I was not in a hotel. Trust me on this. I got in my pajamas and settled down for the night after a long day of spitting and dick swinging. I tried to go to bed at one of the tables and couldn't find my bed side bible. I like to decipher the hidden alien text found within. They told me they only serve food and drink. What a shitty hotel.
Finally onto the food and drink.
The menu reads like a comfort food menu. But what comes out is far more seductive and elaborate. Like a Rubik cube. But a sexy Rubik cube. Dan was kind enough to send out the toast with jalapeno cream sauce and fried egg on top. I did not even touch that mess but my friend did and she said it was amazing. She said the toast was still crispy even thought it was drenched in sauce. I am calling black magic on this one. She didn't eat the entire thing so she could save room for the entrees.
The entrees.
She ordered the Trout and it was cooked perfectly with the skin on it. I love fish with the skin on because it has way more flavor and I also like to pretend I am a bear (not the gay kind) stuffing my gut for the long winter. I ordered what sounded like a hearty soul food dish. Hangar steak, short ribs, and tater tots. I mean, they were called tater tots. No pommes tots or anything to disguise what they actually were. So I thought them to be less fancy. I was wrong. The tots were awesome. The broccoli rabe was thrown onto my friend's plate and I devoured the rest of everything. Short ribs were like butter. I shouldn't have asked for medium on my steak and the braised (or stewed) peal onion accompanied everything perfectly.
I thoroughly enjoyed everything but my portion was pretty small for the price. That would be my only complaint about the food. 
And my other semi complaint would be how quiet the staff was. They seemed like their line ups previous to opening consist of "WE ARE BORG. WE ARE BORG. ASSIMILATE!" I didn't get a fun vibe from the group. The food was fun. But the staff was too fancy. The staff should give off the same vibe as the food they serve.
Maybe in time, Dan will get them rollin'. Because I would love to see them rollin'. Just like Chamillionaire. We should all strive to roll one day like Chamillionaire.
author: Bannon R.

description:
I have been here a handful of times for work lunches, and have generally enjoyed the experience. The service is prompt for the most part, and on a nice day you can sit on the outdoor patio area. I highly recommend the pork loin, which comes with a potato pancake and braised red cabbage. 

The bill is handed to you between the pages of an antique-looking book, which is a nice touch. 

The main dining area does tend to get a little noisy at times, and the seating often feels cramped. But if you are looking for some upscale comfort food, this is the place for you.
author: lindsay w.

description:
Great service.  Excellent food.  

Started out with the appetizer that is functionally a croque madame. - bread, bechamel, egg, etc.  It was also garnished with breaded jalapenos.  Very tasty.  For my entree, I got the pork osso bucco.  Loved the pork, the sauce it was cooked in was delicious.  The beans, etc that came with were a great compliment.  

I went somewhere else for dessert, but maybe next time.

The decor at this place is great too.  Overall, a very good dining experience.
author: Angie C.

description:
I must say, I absolutely loved the food.  It made my mouth feel like it had won a million dollars.  I felt spoiled.  Delish.

Don't get too attached to the dishes, they seem to change depending on the season (though I wouldn't be too worried, as it's easy to find favorites).  Oh, but the desserts. Yum. And wine.  Double yum.

Bathroom is up a flight or two... but what else can you do with the narrow space?  The homey feeling makes up for it, as well as the friendly staff.  Not only great for groups but designed for them.
author: Giorgina G.

description:
Came here for dessert hoping that the sticky toffee cake was still on the menu.  Unfortunately, to my disappoitment, that's no longer there  =(  So, we opted to try the banana bread pudding sprinkled with peanut brittle, served a la mode.  Still very good ;)  Also tried their french press coffee made with blue bottle-  the flavor was delicious-  would definitely have it again when I return.

The host was very friendly and welcoming and so was our waitress.  If someone from townhall is reading this, please return the sticky toffee cake to the menu!
author: Vickie Y.

description: Had a great dinner.  Service was wonderful as well.  Definitely recommend the ham and cheese toast. The cream sauce is something special.
author: Marky M.

description:
The place has potential, but it lacks vegetarian options. 

I was here recently with colleagues for a business dinner. The wine with appetizers were decent. Dinner was three courses from a prix fixe menu. Unfortunately, as a previous viewer had noted, options for vegetarian/ pescetarians were very limited. For those of us who ate fish, we pretty much had a bowl of rice for the entree-- nothing additional (no fish, no roasted portabella, no sprinkling of nuts, no vegan sausages, no splash of green in the presentation (imagine the possibilities especially in a place like SF)). For another colleague who could eat shellfish, meat was included in the dish. Another friend of mine has a medical condition where meat and dairy products cause her migraines, so all instances of meat in a dish should be specified. We have been to other places in the City that have accommodated vegetarians very well at that price range. If a vegetarian or pescatarian dish has to rely on bacon fat (or MSG) to bring out the flavor. Bacon fat not only renders the dish a meat dish, but is a cop out on creativity. 

Otherwise, the servers were friendly, professional and accommodating. The ambiance was also nice for a business meal, or a night out. Three stars, however, due to issues with the food. Hopefully the restaurant can take another look at their menu and take the California/ SF palate into consideration-- especially in regards to special diets, allergies, and prix-fixe menus for larger groups where options are much more limited.
author: Anonymous M.

description:
I'm not going to lie, the food was tastey, but I left very unsatisfied. I love small portions, but this was rediculous. I got the crab salad for lunch and probably got a half mini plate of crab salad. I then spent the rest of the afternoon searching the kitchen at the office for more food.

It is loud and rather cramped. i would not recommend coming here for a business lunch. Also, be sure to make a reservation.
author: Aubrey W.

description:
Okay, so... the Town Hall.  Or is it just Town Hall?  

Went there yesterday for some lunch grub on the company dime - the boss was in from out of town, and we took her there for the usual gather-bond-eat-chat type experience; you know, like in the team building kinda way.

The space itself is ... well, I'm resisting saying that it was "neat," because that's what my Dad would have said about it, but that's probably the best descriptor for it.  Kinda eastern colonial with some modern touches: the chandeliers are real winners in this way, kind of encapsulating the feel.

The food was really quite nice; nothing really extraordinary but all completely serviceable - I had the fried green tomatoes with tuna tartare and was pleased.  My neighbor had the trout and was happy with it, another friend had the blue cheese sandwich and was also impressed.  I had the rabbit and crawfish etoufee: it was serviceable, well prepared, and so forth.

But no surprises, really -  no flavor explosions, at least not in the etoufee: it was everything I expected it to be, nothing less and nothing more.  

And unfortunately, while friendly, the service was slow and not on point in other ways.  The bus staff was definitely good on refilling my ice tea, and the water and lemonade of that other people had, but the dishes took a while to come out and ... the check took forever.  Which for is death for a business luncheon, absolute death.  And it was not busy enough to warrant waiting 15 minutes after our plates being cleared for the bill to show up.

So, three stars.  A meal that would have been really great in a town other than this one, but just mediocre here; and service just barely good enough.
author: Jacob R.

description:
Went to Town Hall without a reservation so our table of four was seated at the communal table. Our waiter was friendly, very friendly. At first I did not mind, but when we had to repeat parts of conversation to fill him in on what he'd missed I thought it was a bit much. 

The food was good; I can't remember everything we had but some items that stood out were the tuna tartare, risotto and tomato fondue.  The slider with the rib was okay; the rib was not fall-off-the-bone but rather pull and chew which is not my thing.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
I went for a work lunch and loved the interior, but that was about it. It's a converted warehouse with exposed brick walls, very cool.  It can get pretty loud during lunchtime.  The food was ok, but I don't think I'd go back for dinner or lunch again.  I had the salmon and it was too salty.  The salad was good.

I went back for another work lunch and had the steak and mushrooms; now my feelings are mixed. I think its hit or miss at this place.
author: Thuy N.

description:
I had one of the best birthday dinners I have ever had here last week.

The boy took me out for a nice dinner and that is exactly what we had. The food was delicious! I had the summer corn risotto and boy had the bacon-wrapped rainbow trout. Everything was very tasty.

Our waiter (Joseph, I think?) was so sweet and very funny. The place was extremely busy, so there was a lot of action and people watching going on (my favorite!). I would definitely recommend dinner here and will probably be bringing the fam here when the come to town next.
author: Syd V.

description:
I've been here tons of times for lunch (it's close to my work) and once for dinner (when it first opened back when it actually was okay). And every time I would think "maybe next time it will redeem itself." Now I'm convinced it will take a miracle to turn this place around.

I like the concept of Town Hall and the menu looks great on paper, but not even the fabulous butterscotch pot de creme can redeem this place. 

Some of their food tastes like the kitchen is not rotating the stock.  This might explain the nearly-turned salad lettuce (on 2 separate occasions),  the stale jambalaya (which they tried to cover up by severely overspicing it) and oversalted and undercooked salmon. By the way tiger, these dishes will run you about 20 bucks each. For lunch even! 

The service was never good at Town Hall, but recently it's become the worst thing about the place. Embarrassingly novice and awkward servers. Servers that don't even know how to pour water or serve a dish properly, and were obviously hired only because they're good at faking it or they are friends of the kitchen. They freaked when I pre-ordered dessert (because it took so long to get the mains) and asked if I wanted it at the end of the meal. Isn't that when dessert normally comes, buddy?  They sure do have a great time cracking jokes with the ghetto kitchen staff though, while we sat for 15 minutes waiting for the check. 

2 and a half hours and 94 bucks later, my lunch friend and I left, completely bummed. Even after we used our two 25.00 gift certificates to whittle down the bill we still felt ripped off. 

When it opened almost four years ago (time flies!), the food and service were the talk of the town.  It became a runaway smash which lead to legions of devoted diners that still go there today. But now that the restaurant has a sure-fire base of fans, it's milking them for all they're worth. 

For this food and service, the prices are absolutely laughable, and the owners know it too, b/c they're laughing all the way to the bank! Town Hall needs a new lease on life.  :(
author: BroSauce J.

description:
I used to like Town Hall for the decent menu and the New England like atmosphere.

Unfortunately, the last two visits have left me really disappointed. Here is the list of things that need to change before I will be back:
- Being seated 1 hour after the time of our reservation
- Getting a table that is right by the kitchen (I think it was added right for the holiday season to squeeze a few extra seats on of the restaurant floor...)
- Insanely long wait times to (a) see a waiter once seated (something like 30 minutes) and (b) getting food late and not all at once 
- Getting the wrong order once the food finally arrives
- Being embarrassed to bring visiting friends to Town Hall and then having such a bad experience

Oh, and one last thing. The stairwell between the first and the second floor stinks (quite literally!) and could use a new carpet...
author: Claudio B.

description:
So my really good friend decided to take me out to dinner for my graduation present and I picked Town Hall.  We were both really excited to try this place after scoping out their menu online, and also knowing that it is a staple here in San Francisco.

I will say that I wasn't disappointed.  I am IN LOVE with their squash blossoms.  I ate every single piece on the plate and then some.  My friend had their biscuits and gravy and although I don't eat meat, they looked delicious.  The biscuits were to die for, they melted in your mouth.

There are 3 reasons why I am not giving them 5 stars. I have worked in restaurants since I was 16 so I know a thing or two.  1) You are always supposed to clear 1st course plates before bringing our the second course.  Although my plate was cleared, my friend was still working on here biscuits and gravy.  They set our entrees down and attempted to make room for her 1st course on a small table. They should know better. 2) My halibut was under seasoned, which is better than over.  3) When it came down to dessert time, our server didn't know what the flavors of sorbet on the menu, and really was puzzled when we asked if he could check on that for us.  

I know those might seem like little things, but it is the little things that count.  I tend to over analyze things when I eat out. Seeing that I've been in the industry for years and my boyfriend is a chef. I will DEFINITELY BE BACK!!!
author: Samantha R.

description:
It's been a few weeks since I last went, so as far as the food is concerned, I just remember that the Halibut I ordered was tasty and just the right portion.  And I'm usually not a big fan of sea food, so that's saying a lot.

This place was better the second time around, but my company probably played a big part of it.  The first time I got a seat at the bar with 2 other friends and the food didn't seem as good.  

Overall, Town Hall is pretty darn good, much better than Salt House (same owner). Service was spot on and best of all my date was happy.

So I was happy.
author: David C.

description: Top notch service.  Saw famous football notable having lunch there. Ham and cheese with beschamel and poached egg was very satisfying as are the peach Danish thing and the pot de creme of chocolate and peanut butter.  Tuna tartar and the OMG cornbread too. Pork BBQ sandwich needed more Texan flavor though, somewhat lacking in flavor.  I kept thinking cilantro and pickled carrots would make it a tasty banh mi.  I assumed the pork would be BBQ'd and not just given BBQ sauce.  Think pork deli slices with sauce so kinda bland from what I think of as far as BBQ.  Plenty of business office types/ locals lunching in busy atmosphere. Would come back for the variable fish options for their entrees.  After reading other Yelps, maybe brisket BBQ chili would have been more tasty option to satisfy the BBQ craving
author: Eesayah O.

description:
The food here is amazing. Also, be aware that even though it is very fancy, the portions are large.

The pre-meal bread is chewy and sour, just the way I like it.

The ham and cheese toast was amazing. The fried peppers that go with it are perfect for some crunch and heat.

I had the duck leg confit and my date has the pork chop. Surprisingly (to me) the duck was much better. It was melt-in-my-mouth where the pork chop was a little chewy, but still very good.

We had the chocolate pecan tart for dessert, and again it was large and very tasty. The orange gelatins on the side were a great touch.

If I had to say something negative, the service was by no means bad, but also wasn't excellent like you would hope for a place as nice as this. The waiter did mention they were incredibly busy, so that might be an explanation.

I can't wait to eat here again.
author: Justin S.

description: My co-workers took me here last June for my bridal shower (at work). Good spot for groups and the food is delish! Definitely  a good place to go. The managed to get like 12 people all in one table, which I thought was nice :).  I ordered the soft shell crab sandwhich, and a Japanese type of soda or something. I'm not sure if they have either of those things still, but I'd be open to try anything else on the menu.
author: Brandi W.

description: Broken ankle and all, I had to get out of the house.  Town Hall was extremely accommodating and even found a chair in the busy restaurant so I could put my foot up.  I had the trio of beef but my husbands fried chicken was finger lickin good.  The best part of the entire meal was the french pressed coffee and coffee and doughnuts dessert; coffee ice cream with warm doughnuts and chicory coffee bits.  It was one of the best desserts I've had in a long time.
author: Angela D.

description:
Once a month my sweetie and I do fancy dinner night, and we try to get to new places (new to us). I'd been wanting to try Town Hall for years, and I was excited and eager, but it was terribly disappointing.

Because it's fancy dinner night, we tend to order a lot of food, so we had 2 starters, 2 entrees, and 2 sides: tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes, a standard beet salad with goat cheese, some kind of creole-style seafood dish, gnocchi, mac-n-cheese croquettes, and jalapeno corn bread.

1. Tuna tartare is so standard that at a high-end place it should be really stand-out and worth having on the menu. This is very mediocre, and the fried green tomatoes tasted like they were fried the day before and reheated by microwave for our dish. (Top tuna tartares: Boulevard, Aqua, Range.)

2. Beet salad. Same thing. It's such a standard dish that one should make it a signature, a reason to return for it. This was okay but nothing new or special or interesting. Frisee, goat cheese, blah-blah, forgettable vinaigrette. (Best beet salads: Chez Panisse, Boulevard.)

3. Jalapeno corn bread--come on!! Once again, take a classic and put your spin on it. I'm not a huge corn bread fan anyway--sweetie really wanted it--but I tasted it and was unimpressed. I've had better, probably even boxed stuff that was better.

4. Croquettes. There was something kind of sinfully yummy about these because it's fried mac-n-cheese, but they were still quite plain. I don't remember any kind of exciting aoli or anything accompanying them.

5. Creole fishy thing. (Sorry, I should have written this in November when we went.) Nice touch serving crawdads, which are not common on local menus. This dish was okay, probably the second best, next to the 

6. Gnocchi, which was actually fantastic. The gnocchi's the reason I debated giving this place two stars.

7. Dessert was some kind of cobbler with caramel in it. I'm not much of a dessert person, and when I am it's about chocolate, so I'll refrain from trying here.

I settled on one star because the service was nothing special (not bad, either, but they weren't helpful with wine recs) and you have to travel really far and change floors to get to the bathroom. The ambiance is nothing special, and I wouldn't really care if the food were stellar.

It doesn't even stop here. We went home separately because it was Sunday night and we had things to do for Monday, and completely alone separately in our own beds, we had major difficulty sleeping and bizarre dreams. We're sure it was the food.

Overall, I'd say Town Hall is impressive if you stick it somewhere in middle America. But for sophisticated San Francisco palates it doesn't cut it at all. I'm truly shocked it has made the Bay Area Top 100. I won't go back, and I feel completely turned off from trying their other outfits--Salt House and Anchor & Hope. Sorry, guys, I was hoping for better!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
We hadn't been to Town Hall in a few years, so decided to give it another try.  The noise level was just as we'd remembered: LOUD! The clientele was the same: Marina. But, you go to a restaurant for the food and the experience, right?  

The service started out as slightly rude. We were about 25 minutes early and the hostess snapped that we would be seated only at the time of our reservation.  So, we headed to the half-empty communal table and ordered drinks.  The drinks took about 15 minutes to arrive, at which point the waitress said that our table was ready...early. Before we could even pay for the drinks, the hostess hovered over us with menus ready to take us to our table.  She never said a word or even smiled, just hovered. Hmph!

Apps and dinner were "good" but nothing extraordinary.  Service was again sloooow.  The place seemed full, but not packed, so not sure of the issue.  Times between ordering and apps and then apps and entrees were both very long.  I didn't use a stopwatch, but the DW and I both kept asking each other, "where is our food?"

Veal meatball app was tasty, but chorizo-crusted grouper entree was a bit over-cooked and not all that flavorful.  And, by "crusted," they just mean little round slices of chorizo (like small pepperoni) over the top of the fish, which was kind of odd.  Side of fried okra was bland, but side of collards was very good.  Collards are tough to get right, so kudos to them!  DW had the soup of the day and the biscuits & ham, which were both good.  Total bill, with three glasses of wine and no dessert, was about $126 (not including cocktails - which must be paid to the bar and which I'll never understand... it seems like a total waste of time to have your customers pay twice in the same place...).

Overall, it was "good" and "fine," but there are plenty of better restaurants in SF.  I'd give it an "OK" on value.  It was cheaper than I expected, but again, you can get better food at a better value in SF.
author: Jason R.

description: Catfish and andoullie sausage jambalaya...  order it.  Please order it.  So yummy, creamy, and spicy.  Amazing.
author: Denise M.

description: Pretty expensive but totally fabulous. Went for my birthday and had an amazing time with my boyfriend. Probably won't order so much champagne next time but the food was good by my standards!
author: Morgan H.

description:
I'd give 4.5 stars for the roll of the dice service quality. Usually impeccable, but occasionally you get the trainee, or the waitress on her off-day, and the service suffers marginally.

Aside from that, the food is always amazing, the decore, ambiance, clientelle, everything is smashing!

I recommend asking for Rachid for a server. He's sure to make the experience a guranteed 5 star one! 

My favorites:
Appetizers:
Bbq Shrimp 
Squash blossoms
Tuna Tartare
Mussels
Heirloom Tomato salad

Entrees:
Town Hall Burger (Can only get during Lunch service or on the in-between menu)
(a little crumbley but the best burger I've ever had, hands down!)
Lobster Roll (Lunch service only)
Buttermilk fried chicken (best fried chicken north of the south!)
Prime Rib/Steak

I could only want for more veggetarian dishes, the wild mushroom risotto is fabu!

Desserts:

Nothing on the Dessert menu will prove to disappoint.
Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot De Creme is timelessly delicious.
Plum "Doughnuts" were my favorite from the menu.
Strawberry shortcake, or Warm Apple Pie ... the list goes on.

If you live nearby Town Hall is a dining experience that should not be overlooked.
author: TheJane N.

description:
We have been to the hall a few times now, and although it wreaks of noisy sloppily served meat and cheap drinks ala black angus, get ready for some of the best comfort (over used) food around. The place is rockin 'cause it's successful. The menu is well rounded, from the beef short rib to a great cedar plank salmon....oh yeah...they also serve a bacon wrapped quail.

The food, atmosphere, staff, drinks, and great location make this a "must do" in the City. And one final note, this is one of the few places we have been where the glassware, that's right, is great. They use suitable wine glasses for reds and whites that do justice to the varietal you order.
author: George M.

description:
Went here with a a few friends for dinner and I think we were all around pretty impressed with the place.

This night was a pleasure of indulgence. As you will soon see.

Appetizer:
Dungeness Crab Fondue w/ Andouille Sausage & Broccolini
Yes, it was as amazing as it sounds. I could have dipped in this dish all night long.

Entree: 
Bacon-Wrapped Rainbow Trout
I'm a sucker for bacon-wrapped anything but this was perfection. Nice, light crisp bacon wrapped around a delicate tasty piece of fish. Flavors were balanced beautifully.

Desserts:
Butterscotch Pot de Creme
Toffee Cake with Vanilla Ice Cream & Caramel

The desserts were delicious but large so learn from our lesson and share.

Other entree favorites on the table were the Oysters, Fried Chicken, and Quail. The only item that met with disapproval was the Ribeye but I didn't get a sample so I can't really say why.

This is not the most economic of dining experiences., it ended up being roughly $70 a person, but given the quality of the food preparation and service we received I think we were all happy to part with the money and are probably likely to make return visits.
author: Scott D.

description:
Luckily we had reservations b/c the restaurant was packed at the normal dinner hour.

We ordered:

Appetizers/Sides

-butter lettuce salad (typical stuff, good)
-warm jalapeno cornbread (yum! nice, warm, and moist...not dry at all and flavored just right)

Main Courses

-grilled ribeye (the parents who normally don't enjoy eating American food (very picky) cleaned their plates and agreed that they had a good meal. If they say it's good, then it's good.)
-short ribs (very tasty)
-halibut (fresh, flaky)
-pork chop (a tiny bit dry, but good nonetheless)

Dessert

-toffee cake (pretty good, moist cake, not overwhelmingly sweet)

Bottom line, we all enjoyed our dinner and every dish was delicious. Not exceptional, but decent service.

Minus one star b/c the noise level was just way too loud for my ears and the seating was very tight; too close to surrounding tables
author: Veronica H.

description:
East Bay folks staying in SF for the weekend...we ate ALL over SOMA and landed at Town Hall for lunch on Martin Luther King day.  Dine About Town surprised us with some TASTY gumbo...WOW!

It was the best tasting food we'd had all weekend.  The service was prompt and intuitive.  I didn't have to ask for another spoon to share my fiance's gumbo....

Pork chops were a large healthy portion and juicy.  Polenta was cheesy AND creamy...Fiance was so full from the shared gumbo taste explosion that he had trouble finishing his main course...catfish!
author: Dangerine D.

description: Remarkably tasty comfort food - superb specialty cocktails - attentive yet not overbearing service. Bueno!
author: Chaz S.

description:
2.5 stars. Just not that good. Sorry, i've been here once for dinner and it was okay so we decided to come here for lunch. 

The cream of corn soup was good. 
Tuna tartare- not much taste, but pretty fresh
Jalapeno Cornbread - new, pretty good

for the entree i had their prime rib sandwich because they didn't have the pulled pork which i was looking forward to. It was just horrible, i could probably make a better one at home myself. The meat was like roast beef deli meat. tasteless, dry, bland. IF they had some au jeus (sp?) sauce it would have been a great French Dip. Fries were good at least.

Other than that, probably won't be heading back anytime soon.

heck, i'll throw in .5 stars for their hot waitresses
author: Patrick M.

description: I would give them 6 stars if I could.  This food was amazing.  I was skeptical of southern food in California but they deliver.  I had the ham and cheese biscuit for an appetizer and it was sinful.  The fried chicken was great and the tater tots were so yummy I couldn't stop eating them which was painful as I can't over eat since my surgery.  Oh well, no pain no tater tots. :)  The desserts were awesome as were my friends pork chops and jalapeno cornbread.  Eat here now.  I'm serious.
author: Dustin T.

description:
I might be a bit outdated, as I haven't eaten here for at least 4 months, and I know these ultra trendy restaurants tend to change their quality pretty frequently... but I just loved every meal I've ever had here.

Yes the crowd is definitely a little older (luckily I was born in the early 70's, and I can hang)... But it's not a crowd that makes you feel uncomfortable... coming from the guy who had his first panic attack at 36 years old in a restaurant (not really a panic attack, but Masa's is so not my scene)

The service was fantastic... of course they were packed that night, and they were a little late on our reservation, but they were very accommodating i.e. free drink, which can smooth out just about any problem.  

The food was harmonious, I never felt that there was anything that didn't taste "right".  And I have to mention the jalapeno cornbread sticks.... wow, I have had dreams about those things.... if only I could have them as my fingers and I could nibble on them all day...

Great place to go out with friends, have a work-type dinner or just a casual night out... I think you can pull it all off at town hall.
author: Michael F.

description: Mom and I made a meal out of appetizers.  We had a minestrone soup highly stocked with vegetables, excellent ahi tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes, and an equally excellent butterleaf salad with a tangy buttermilk dressing and slices of pear and walnuts.  The bread to start with was also quite tasty.  Our lunch buddy tried the fish and chips, and he said the batter was very light and crunchy.  Service was good, although we had our lemonade glasses refilled with water by accident.  We didn't have time or room in our stomachs for dessert, but I suspect I need to reserve one star for when I can come back for the bread pudding or pot de creme.
author: Sherri C.

description:
Every time I leave Town Hall, I am pretty much floating...Having just enjoyed a delicious and exciting dinner, drank a plentiful amount of wine, and taken in the ambiance of the place. 
The bread pudding that was on the menu a few autumns ago was delicious and something I still crave and search for everytime I scour a menu.
author: Heather C.

description:
I think this place is a bit over-hyped. I was already annoyed when I tried to make a reservation for lunch for a party of 8. They don't take parties larger than 6 for lunch, unless we booked out one of their rooms. Good thing two people couldn't make it, so we were good to go. 
I really like the ambiance when you first walk into Town Hall. The decor is very soothing and New-England-ish. Too bad the hostesses aren't very friendly. They didn't seem too happy to have our party there.
The menu is a bit bland. I had the duck enchiladas which was a bit boring. The only other thing that looked interesting on the menu was the burger and the fish & chips. I also had some fish the last time I was there and it wasn't impressive. BLAH.
The only good thing about this place is that the ambiance is nice. I'm not sure if I'm going back.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
They deserve 3.5 stars, but I am forced by my morals to round down.

I ate here recently with my bro and dad.  We had a reservation, which is strange to me for lunch, but whatev.  The service was horrendous.  My pops asked what kind of beer they had, and the server replied, "It's on the menu."  This started a downward spiral of service.  The server came back 5 minutes later with a menu and I had to throw in, "So what is your beer recommendation."  Nada, he said nothing.  Seriously! 

Even if the food was unforgettable...and it's not that memorable...there is no reason for the arrogance and bad service.  My brother was wearing a yelp tee, so you'd hope he was cool enough to know what's up....obviously not.  

Food wise:  I liked my veggie panini and the salad that accompanied it was light and lemony.  My bro liked his turkey sandwich, while daddyo didn't care for the fish n' chips, mentioning the soggy factor.  Actually I ate my food plus half of his because food is not meant to be wasted, plus I thought the fish was pretty good.
author: debbie h.

description:
What I liked about Town Hall:
-The waiter was informative, passionate, and nice
-The beer selection
-The duck was perfectly cooked and delicious
author: amy y.

description:
Service Service Service Service. 

I read somewhere that the owner of Town Hall hires based upon the character of the individual as opposed to their service industry pedigree and boy does it show.  No snooty wait staff or unimpressed hostess, this place has got service down with style. 

The food is great with solid selections at good prices.  The appetizers are fairly small while the entrees are pretty much huge, which suggests getting two appetizers and sharing one entree.  You know what I'm sayin?  

I'm not a HUGE lover of southern food, I know, I know, BOOOO, but even a frenchie like me enjoyed the dungenous crab fondue.  MEOW.  My pork chop entree was fabu, but totally traditional, so while it was great to eat, it wasn't like I was transcending oral heaven.  

Bottom line.  This place is a solid choice for when the parents are in town, or you want to squire around some clients.  The service will blow you away, and your entree will provide a doggy bag for lunch the next day.
author: Claire C.

description:
Town Hall has all those staple dishes that we come to look for when dining but with one exception, they are just better. It's all the little things that makes each dish incredible.  Like the paper slice thin oyster crackers in the chowder or the spicy jalapeno flakes in the ahi. Oh and the meatball dish will leave me confined to my kitchen every rainy weekend until I can re-create and perfect that sauce! Total Heaven!

I will say that the one downer of the evening was the bartender that served us - he either seemed really out of it or just indifferent -  which was entirely human but still disappointing.
author: Yelper A.

description:
For private events only...

This was the first of many demonstration/sales lunches I planned for work this spring.  It was nice to have the training wheels on in my home town with such a great team.

Does that mean that nothing went wrong?  No.  Did I learn a lot? Yes.

That said - the food was great.  The space is a nice space for presentations - but warning...it's underneath the lower grades of a montessori school...yeah...the pitter patter of little feet went back and forth across the room and around the room during our entire program - so lunch presentations, may not be the best idea.  We had some communications/timing issues - but like I said...I learned a lot about being specific in my requests.

Long story short: This is a nice place for business-y private functions.  Great location and good food.
author: Gracie B.

description:
I don't know what happened.  

The service was great - very friendly and helpful!

Then my friend and I had dark and stormys, split some oysters, the toast with the egg on top and creme jalepeno sauce, the fried chicken, and the scallops, a bottle of wine and the butterscotch pot de creme. 

Then I woke up the following day.

I shall be back!
author: Andrew L.

description: Met up with two friends that live in the city and often do business lunches here.  I enjoyed the place well enough.  It is very open and relaxing inside, but a bit loud, as the bar and restaurant share the space.  The service was good and my fish was prepared very well.
author: Robert K.

description:
So I've been to Town Hall twice now and I have to say I enjoyed the food both times.  The first visit was during lunch and I ordered the fish and chips and the fish was light, flaky, and well battered (not too much/not too little) and the portion size was just enough.  It was during the summer and unfortunately the restaurant had a flying insect problem that day but not so much to ruin my dining experience.  I went again last night and ordered the seafood etoufee.  Very nice dish...and that's coming from someone whose family is originally from Louisiana.  Good amount of crabmeat/shrimp/and crawfish with a dark flavorful roux based sauce.  There was actually a lot of entrees on the menu that sounded tasty..and a good number of them with a southern and/or cajun feel to them.  

The only thing that I do not like about this restaurant is that it was really loud on both occassions.  Bad acoustics, combined with a packed  restaurant, combined with loud music, made the place feel energized but I had to yell quite a bit to talk to my friends.  And the restaurant is also kind of pricey....with my etoufee dish coming in at about $26.  So for that reason, I'd give this place 3 1/2 stars, rounded up to 4.  But yeah, I'd come back, just preferably when it's not packed and someone else is paying.
author: LaSha G.

description:
This place is simple, nicely lit but super loud!  Voices were bouncing off the walls... 

Thank goodness the food was really good.  I had the pork chop (cause I love me some pork).  Only thing is that I forgot to order the pot de creme, I know...me, who's only goal in life is to marry a pastry chef.  How could I forget to order dessert?  It must have been first date jitters!

P.S.  Love the biscuit, ham and huckleberry appetizer!

P.P.S.  Love how they bring your the check in a book.  Be sure to check out what people have written in yours...
author: Jennifer H.

description:
For the price, the food is not impressive. Our reservation was at 8:15 pm and our first dish was served at 9:40 pm.

Satisfied with the starters:
~oyster sample
~Faith's warm ham and cheese toast
~crab fondue

Disappointed by:
~roasted trout - too many fine bones and skin still had a lot of scales
~seared buffalo strip loin - over cooked and tough
~mushroom risotto with truffle oil - I didn't realize at first but the risotto was too undercooked and gritty 

Service was superb by Andrea as she took most of the entrees off our tab but I would rather spend my money at the Salt House.
author: Katie K.

description:
I wouldn't choose Town Hall for a personal meal, but on official business, it was a different story. The ambiance is professional and classy with excellent service. I started with an excellent beet salad with white and red beets and goat cheese. As an entree, I followed the salad with creamy butternut squash stuffed ravioli.  

Although it's an expensive lunch, I definitely recommend Town Hall for a business lunch meeting.
author: Charles B.

description: As an Executive Assistant that books many holiday lunches and events, I would NOT reccomend Town Hall. They made it a completely ackward experience. We arrived with a few extra people and they told us it would be another HOUR to accomodate - we also tried to order wine that we had MISTAKENLY NOT preordered.. a simple glass of Chardonnay - apparently this is against the rules there.. they offered " the least expensive" for $60 a bottle.. how rude.. Thanks for nothing.. we wont be back..
author: Jacque T.

description:
Solid comfort food. ribs, fried chicken, potatoes, etc.
great big brick building with high ceilings and there is space on the second floor for private parties. Service was pretty good too.

The food just was missing a little something. The ribeye tasted like it had been flatted with a mallet then doused in a bbq type of sauce. It came with supposedly marrow potatoes but couldn't really taste the difference. and the brown betty came out cold.. Bummer.
author: Tom L.

description:
I was massively excited when my office decided to have our end-of-the-year staff lunch at Town Hall. My coworkers salivated over the online menu and boasted about our good fortune.

I'm sad to report this, but overall I wasn't all that impressed with the food. I liked the brick interior and white wall interior, reminiscent of my five years on the east coast. It was freezing in the restaurant though (in a back corner no less, not even near a door), a little too remiscient of east coast winters that brought me back out to california.

I had the tuna tartare and fried green tomato starter, the portobello sandwich with arugula and brie, and finished off with the butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme. 

Starter: The tartare did not come anywhere near the top of my list in its category. It was a little too saucy somehow, whereas the tuna should be able to stand a little more on its own. I remember all the places I've had incredible fried green tomatoes--Nashville, Atlanta, Dollywood--and San Francisco is not among them. Maybe I should just give up my high expectations for good fried green tomatoes outside of the otherwise scary deep south.

Sandwich: The portobello sandwich was complemented nicely by the arugula and made lovely by the brie. I wasn't going to order the sandwich until I got suckered in by the melted brie, which makes nearly anything amazing. I opted for a sandwich rather than a regular entree because the two fish items somehow weren't working for me and I don't eat duck, beef, lamb or pork. I almost ordered the artic char dish, complete with butternut squash puree and a pomegranate reduction. But, the server couldn't tell me whether it was farmed or wild and whether that mattered. (I wasn't previously familiar with char, and our server described the char as being similar to salmon. If you're going to describe something as similar to salmon, you should be prepared  to answer the farmed or wild question. And, on principle, there's no way I'm supporting a $19 purchase of farmed fish.)

The Dessert: Oh my god, the pot de creme. I was expecting a tiny little tub of yum. I got a massive cup of hella delish. If I were to return to Town Hall, it would be for wine and pot de creme. Yes, it's like glorified pudding, but so so so amazing and I want everyone to try it.
author: reb f.

description:
I wanted to give this place 4 stars, but I'll have to give the  4 stars to Salt House instead. My friend and I went there for dinner tonight, and we were seated promptly, and I looked around and noticed that the place was somewhat empty. I said to myself...looks like the recession is hitting the Town Hall pretty quickly, but in a matter of minutes, the place was filled up rather quickly.  

The waiter was very prompt in taking our order, and I was a little disappointed when I asked him if the only vegetarian option on the menu was the risotto and asparagus with goat cheese, and he said yes. I was expecting him to tell me that the chef could prepare a vegetarian meal for me similar to what I had at the Salt House a few months ago. Anyway, I ended up ordering the Risotto, and my friend ordered the shrimp which she said was ok. We both had a glass or wine which I thought was a little pricey. ($15/glass). I also thought a small cup of decaf coffee for $5.00 was a little pricey as well.  I could have gone over to Starbucks and gotten a better deal. 

Now I am really glad that I don't drink coffee and I don't eat meat. I can't imagine what our check would have been. As it was, our meal came to $100 for both of us, and we had no appetizers and no desserts. 
I think Town Hall is a little on the pricey side.  I know that it is in San Francisco where rent is super high, bu c'mon for what they charged, I was expecting the food to be very good, and it was not all that. Salt House is a much better choice. I have no plans in going back to the Town Hall anytime soon, but I'll definitely go back to the Salt House.
author: Arlene D.

description:
I ate here with my girlfriend some time ago after seeing a positive depiction of it on "Bay Area Check Please".  We started with a dish highlighted by a show guest, Faiths Warm Ham and Cheese Toast.  This was fantastic. This came alongside the Butter Lettuce Salad feat. the great duo of candied walnuts and blue cheese.  Up until that point the service had been great and the food was quality!  It was kicked up a notch when I received my main course, the Buttermilk Fried Chicken dish.  Goodness. This was a traditional dish taken to a new level of purity and cleanliness.  The fry job was clean and tasty with only minimal grease.  It came with white corn, a biscuit, and some gravy.  Excellent.  

My girlfriend ordered the peanut tasso crusted pork chop. I had to beg her for a bite of it, but I'll be damned, it was utterly fantastic.  The chop was tender and juicy, and the coating was flavorful and surprising. It came with mashed potatoes, which are always a winner in my book, but these were top notch (plus, they call them "smashed...awesome).   Sadly, we were both too stuffed for dessert, but the sweet, sweet damage had been done.   This place is superb, no bones about it.

Dig it.
author: TJ D.

description: Yummy berry drink. Mouth watering juice steak. Friendly, knowledgeable service.  Rustic American decor.  And of course, great company.  These are all ingredients for a wonderful night at Town Hall.  Definitely made my list of top restaurants in SF.
author: Karen N.

description: I recently had dinner at Town Hall and thought it was adequate overall.  Given that the atmosphere was "city casual" and pleasant overall I decided to take my brother and sister-in-law there for lunch this week.  The lunch menu had "colorful" descriptions of each entree that made everything on the menu seem like it would be a flavor explosion in your mouth.  We ordered the pork tacos, the roast chicken, and  the cheese steak sandwich.  The pork meat for the tacos was flavorful but everything else that came with it was extremely bland.  The chicken dish was basically a roast piece of chicken with about 5 tiny potatoes and a sprinkling of shaved brussel sprouts.  The food came out cold which was evidenced by the coagulated cheese on the sandwich. Very disappointing experience.
author: Michelle C.

description:
The food is 4 stars. The service was 2 stars.

First the bad: We had reservations (for 9pm on a Thursday.)  When we arrived the hostess told us it would be a couple of minutes, which we expected as we were a couple of minutes early.  She returned a few minutes to tell us they were setting up our table and then disappeared.  20 minutes later she finally returned and at first tried to give our table to another couple (who looked nothing like us.)  Then she led us to the table where she dropped the menus and took off without saying a word.  
The waiter was competent and nothing more.

The good:  The food was good.  Considering the reviews this place gets I expected it to be better, but it was definitely good.  We started with the blue cheese fondue appetizer. It started the theme for the night, which was good but not great.  The chicken entree was a contemporary take on fried chicken wings and was quite good for what it was.  Similarly the pork chops, covered in a peanut sauce, were good but unable to live up to the hope the menu description created.

The excellent:  The dessert was delicious.  I would go back here for the dessert (and at $8 it is very reasonable.)  The pot de crme was outstanding and is highly recommended!
author: Greg J.

description:
My usual lunch date took me here yesterday for my birthday (yay!).  She really knows how to treat a girl... got us a shady outside table which was fabulous since it was like 105 degrees out - so I didn't notice the inside noise.  
For an appetizer, we split the chopped vegetable salad, which was very nice - I loved the huge parm shavings on top (and I think M knew this as she pushed them on to my plate - love ya' babe).
She had the BBQ'd shrimp (and let me have one!!) - very tasty.  I had the salmon on grits. Yes, grits.  But they were very good grits.   We ended the meal by splitting the strawberry shortcake (M had arranged to have them stick a candle in it just for me - yay!)

It was slightly weird climbing stairs and hunting down hallways for the bathroom, but perhaps I should hold back on the beer at lunch... Yes, lots of suits, both male and female.  Who cares... the food was only rivaled by my date's company.
author: Meg W.

description:
I've only been here for lunches, so maybe that's not really fair because nice restaurants tend to excel more at dinner, but I want to review anyway because I've been fairly disappointed.   The food is pretty good, no doubt.

However, at least at lunch there weren't too many things that looked that appetizing to me.  That may be my fault more than the restaurants, but normally I can find lots of stuff that looks good on a lunch menu. 

The burger was good, but not amazing...served on focaccia, a surprisingly nice touch.

Tasted the cornbread, which is good.

It would get 4 stars except that for a lunch it was very slow service.  Don't get me wrong, the service staff was on top of things when helping us. It was just very very slow.  We waited forever for our food and forever for people to come by the table sometimes when we needed stuff (like our food).

I'd like to try Town Hall for dinner, but between Town Hall and Salt House, I vote Salt House.
author: Brett J.

description:
Really liked it.  Food all good  (there were 4 of us and we all shared) - short ribs were fantastic.  We had reservations & had table seating - but community seating is convenient if you just stop by on a whim & don't mind a stranger next to you/across from you.

Not as trendy and hyped like other restaurants w/bad food that's overpriced.  Kudos for that!
author: Nana S.

description: Went to Town Hall for a celebratory dinner and had a great experience. I requested a quiet table because it can get so noisy in the restaurant and the hostess accommodated us. I was very impressed. The BBQ shrimp appetizer was good, the pork chop was deliciously tender, and the fried chicken was amazing. Our server was friendly and gave us excellent service.  Finished the meal off with the donut hole dessert and ti was good, but not  great. I will definitely go back when I'm craving New Orleans style fare.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I made reservations for a party of four on Saturday night.  We arrived and were seated right away.  Our orders included the rib eye steaks, pork shank, tuna tar tar, potatoes, jalapeño corn bread and some additional appetizers.  The food was excellent and I commend the chefs!

The atmosphere is very nice with low lighting and candle lit ambiance.  The service, at least from our waiter, left something to be desired.  During the entire evening, from when we arrived to when we left, he consistently gave us the impression he would have rather been anywhere else but serving us.  We initially thought we understood most things on the menu but did eventually ask him a question.  He literally seemed exasperated and said, "All right, I guess I'll have to explain the menu to you after all."  He was difficult to track down during dinner when we wanted additional drinks and, when the drink came, he actually leaned over the table and plopped it down while leaning with his back/side to us and no eye contact whatsoever.  The restaurant serves a bloody mary shooter and I did not see a "regular" bloody mary drink on the menu.  I asked the waiter if I could have a bloody mary and he seemed put off.  Even though there is a full bar, he told me in a disparaging tone he would have to check with the bar to see if they could make one.  I don't know if it's proper to list names in this format but if someone from the restaurant wants to contact me I will gladly let them know who this person is.  Maybe he had a bad day but his behavior certainly lessened the experience of dining here and his actions honestly would make me think twice about taking others here for a night out.

The restroom is a bit awkward to get to since you have to walk up a couple of flights of stairs, or take the elevator, to the second floor.  I don't know how old the carpet is along the staircase area but they really should consider replacing it.  The smell coming from it was awful and was very strong in that enclosed area.

They have a private company handling valet service but at $20 is a bit pricey.  You can do yourself a favor but searching the surrounding streets for empty parking spaces and save some money.  I unfortunately did not notice a free space directly across the street until I paid for the service.  

Again, the food was fantastic but hopefully the waiter we had was the exception and not the rule.
author: B K.

description:
I took my husband here for his birthday.  We both had really great food and friendly service.  Started with the beet and goat cheese salad (yum!) and then I ordered the buttermilk fried chicken (light and crispy and full of flavor - not greasy).  My husband had a crusted pork chop which he most certainly enjoyed.

as others have written - the butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme is amazing.
author: amber l.

description:
I went to Town Hall for a "dine about town" lunch (wow, was it that long ago?  Sigh.  Apologies for my delayed YELP-ing) and my reaction to the place was: ok.  The ambience was okay, the service was okay - and nothing was extremely stellar.

I ordered the salad along with the pulled pork sandwich - both tasted good, and both weren't bad.  The creme de la creme of the meal (pun YES intended) was the pot de creme with butterscotch and chocolate - but other than the dessert, I just felt that Town Hall was a pricey joint serving simple food.  

Although it's not terrible, I'm not sure it's a place I would be gung ho about returning to dine.  It feels like I'm paying more for the name and the marketing more than any sort of foody fun experience.

But maybe I just ordered the wrong thing.  It's possible...
author: Shay F.

description: This place had quality food.  The ambience is trendy but not pretentious.  I have no complaints.  This is a good/convenient place to go for lunch or dinner if you're in SOMA or the financial district.
author: barbara b.

description:
We went here a couple weeks ago. The food wasn't bad. It just wasn't great. I am a huge fan of cornbread and mac and cheese under ordinary cirumstances, but I gotta say, those two sides were not good. The cornbread was tiny, and not flavorful--how I yearned for a box of Jiffy mix when I put the first one in my mouth. The mac and cheese came in these dry little balls. Um, I'm all for innovation in classic, homey dishes, but let's try to make it taste good too, okay? The dishes we ate were not memorable one way or the other, so I'll refrain from comment--though that should indicate something on its own.

Service was sloooow (we were seated a full 20 minutes after our reservation time). We had to ask repeatedly about the status of our entrees during the meal. Not cool. The server did give us a comped dessert (which we didn't actually want to begin with), which softened our hostility, but it was kind of too late at that point to save themselves.

The bottom line: Meh.
author: Nora G.

description:
When
-you want a lively atmosphere
-good hearty fare will do
-you can't get a reservation at Boulevard
-dining with a group

Not
-for a romantic evening

The thing with Town Hall is to not go with high expectations. After reading some negative reviews I was a bit hesitant to come here and because I was not expecting much - I left happy.  The food portions were pretty large, the flavors intense (given that it is of southern creole influence), the ambiance was lively, the service was ok - nothing to write home about but nothing bad either, although the host/manager did stop by our table a couple of times to see if everything was ok. When you want good hearty american food in a lively environment then this is the place.
author: Joe L.

description:
A good 3.5 star city restaurant - but since I don't have that option - here's an "experience" breakdown:

Great service...3.5 stars
1. Hostess quickly seated us
2. Waiter clearly loved his job and believed in the quality of the menu
3. Water glass was refilled at ever sip
4. We were offered the chance to talk to the chef about our choices (!)
5. Our waiter sent my wine glass back b/c he thought the pour wasn't very generous - wow!

Tasty and fun food...3 stars
1. Good food, not amazing, average
2. Try the fried chicken - I didn't but hear I should have
3. Desserts were *interesting* - you can almost taste the full-fat cream and butter with every bite - make sure to share

A nice choice for ambiance, service and a fun meal. Would I go again? Maybe, if friends wanted to try it, but not because we *loved* it.
author: Taj A.

description:
Loved it.  Maybe it was the bottle of champagne followed by the bottle of red wine, or maybe it was the fact that I was eating with my brother and sister who always crack me up, or maybe it was because it was my birthday, but I will always have fond memories of this meal.  

We had delicious starters of steamed mussels, raw oysters, seafood chowder, and chopped vegetable salad.  We love to share so everyone's plate got passed around.  Awesome.  Followed by rib eye steak, scallops with jambalaya, and fried chicken.  Holy cow, the fried chicken was amazing.  We should have all ordered the fried chicken.  I could have eaten it with my hands and then licked my fingers if I didn't have the fear of God put in me at an early age by my etiquette-obsessed mother. 

I was anxiously awaiting the chocolate cake with the milk shooter all evening only to find out that they were all out when we were ready to order so the waitress recommended the caramel pot de creme.  It was more like a gigantic bowl de creme.  And it was delicious.  But I'm still going back for the chocolate cake.  Hopefully soon!
author: Karen Y.

description:
Went to Town Hall for my friend's birthday. The wait staff are really nice and attentive here. We ended up sitting at that huge table you see when you first walk into the restaurant because there weren't any other seats available. It was kind of awkward I suppose..since everyone else sitting there could clearly hear your conversation...but..oh well. 

I ended up ordering the Fried Chicken since my buddy told me he heard some good reviews about it. Ehh...It was alright. Nothing too spectacular..alright alright, I guess Fried Chicken wasn't the best choice for dinner considering I could have easily gotten that at KFC or something..getting to the point: I didn't think it was anything special. I tried some of my friend's salmon and it literally melted in my mouth. It was pretty good. My other buddy was pleased with his selection, so maybe it was just me.
author: Cris L.

description:
The stylish yet rustic airy interior of the restaurant's brick and timber build-out serves as a perfect setting for the generous portions of  brilliantly executed "comfort-style" inspired dishes tht make you feel glad you came.

From the moment we entered we were awash in a contagious buzz which added to the fun of our anniversary dinner outing.  While waiting for our table, we took a seat at the crowded bar to share a toast over one of the highly raved about house specialty cocktails. Both drinks were expertly crafted and served by a skilled, non-pretentious female bartender.  Upon learning this was my first visit, two patrons seated at the bar insisted we try the BBQ shrimp as a starter. (Indeed I did, and would make the same recommendation to others along with the tuna tartare ).  Deelish!

The entree selection at TownHall seemed to offer something for just about everyone, unless that is,  you are a vegetarian. Part of the night's enjoyment was spent sipping fancy coctails and fantisizing about each dish before finally making a decision. The food was 4.5 stars, perhaps even 5.   After much deliberation, we finally opted for slow-roated lamb shank and bacon wrapped Alaskan halibut.  Both dishes wree brilliantly executed and our server was as polite and helpful in her recommendations as I could ever expect.  

I dare say, for a fine dining in a comfortably stylish setting that lacks much  the uppity-ness found at other venues of its caliber, Town Hall ranks in SAn Francisco's Top 5.
author: Lady D S.

description:
After consuming an inordinate amount of alcohol at John Collins for Happy Hour, our group decided to venture to Town Hall for a bit of class and hearty food.  We had a party of 7, and it was 8:45 on a Thursday night.  I was somewhat surprised when the hostess - dear sweet gal in demeanor - said she'd try to fit us in, and put our name down for a 9:30 res.

An hour and fifteen and a glass of cab later, we were FINALLY seated, with some prodding by one of our group members.  I knew a wait was to be expected, but for those in our group who did not partake in the imbibing, they were famished and wanted instant gratification in the form of something non-liquid.  

I ordered the Niman Ranch pork osso bucco with polenta and peas and thought it was quite tasty.  Probably not the best osso bucco I've ever had, but it still hit the spot, and was somewhat reasonable at $25.  The meat was tender and slid off the bone, as is customary of osso bucco.  Most of the others in our party ordered the fried chicken.  According to them, it was "meh" and the accompanying biscuits were served cold, which did not sound appetizing.  Another in our group ordered the NY Strip Steak, and he seemed to enjoy it.  And if he didn't, one wouldn't be able to tell since he consumed everything but the plate.  Still two others in our group left because the wait for our food to arrive outwaited them.

All in all, I enjoyed it - I love the ambiance and decor of Town Hall, with its rustic brick walls and open floor plan.  The service is nothing special, but I'd come back for the food and environment, though I'm not sure if my friends would.  If you do decide to go, make a reservation to avoid a loooong wait.
author: Kira K.

description:
My favorite spot in SF.  Why? Varied, consistently awesome menu, great service, good cocktails, fun vibe.
