My one knock on Town Hall is the fact that it is increasingly feeling "corporate", which changes the feel a bit.

For desert, you must get the butterscotch pot de creme.  Phenomenal.
author: Sean C.

description: Quite delicious... Tried their BBQ shrimps (it was a little heavy but flavorful), and the pork chop as my entree (tender!).
author: Jeff Y.

description:
Based on the recommendation of a couple locals, I took a couple of clients visiting from out of town to dinner here.  All and all it was a very good experience.  I made a reservation through OpenTable the day before.  A couple of hours before the reservation I had to up our number from 4 to 5.  They accomodated us with no problem.  We didn't have to wait at all when showed up for our reservation.

I got the tuna tartare for a starter.  Truth be told, I was more interested in the fried green tomatoes that came with.  The tomatoes were excellent!  Not greasy or over battered and comlimented perfectly with the spicy orange sauce on top.  The tuna was not bad either.

For the main course I got the fried chicken.  Not something I would normally order.  It was good quality comfort food.  The mashed potatoes and collard greens were a good compliment.  

My customer ordered the ribs.  They looked good, but a little dry.  The meat didn't look like it quite "fell off the bone".  I liked the touch of the plate having a piece of brown paper bag on it.  Having watched some Food Network shows on middle of the country BBQ joints, that is how they get served.

The doughnut dessert was excellent.  The perfect little bite to end the night.

Service was excellent.  The wine waitor was very friendly and helpful.

The only complaint would be the staircase between the 1st and 2nd floor.  The bathroom is on the 2nd floor.  The staircase to get there really stunk.  Good thing I had eaten already or I may have lost my appetite.
author: Roy C.

description: On a whim for drinks after work, and an out of town guest that I was trying to impress I took her to Town Hall. The décor reminded me of an old school house and the staff was welcoming. We ordered a  Pimm's Cup, which they obliged to make since it was not on the "drink" menu  and had the veal meatballs to share.  We also shared the large group table with other after work folks and it made for an interesting time. I would not recommend it for an inexpensive happy hour, but it was a great place to share a small dish and have a good drink.
author: Sarah M.

description:
This place is great. 

The key lime pie and pot de cream are the best deserts, and really, probably the best burger I've ever had.
author: Amanda B.

description:
Food: very good. We had the tuna tartare and the meatballs as appetizers. Just reading the description for the fried chicken increased my cholesterol count by 15 points. Taste was excellent, though, especially with the country gravy.

The Viscious Circle made for a particularly nice cocktail; I'm still having a hard time believing that basil in a cocktail is a good thing. And yet, it is, especially when muddled with orange slices like that. 

Service: we had reservations for 8:15, for a specific table. The people before us were very slow to leave, so we ended up hanging out at the bar for about 35 minutes while we waited for them. The manager (or whatever his title is) in charge that night offered us a complimentary appetizer and our drinks were on the house as a result. He checked back with us several times during our meal to be sure everything was copacetic.

I make a point of not holding the restaurant responsible for things that are truly beyond their control. As long as they make a good effort to make things right, I'm a happy camper.

But seriously: did that guy really think he was going to get on my good side by comping our appetizer and cocktails?? 

Yes, he did. 

And he was right.
author: Tim B.

description:
liked it a lot, ate at the bar.  The 'old vine' Zinfandel was excellent.  I had the beet salad, very enticing.  Then the ahi tuna was splendid.  Finally, the mud pie was a bit unorthodox but very good: chocolate almond ice cream on a brownie - I always thought it was coffee ice cream on a thin crust... oh well, live and learn.

The service was very good, the bar tender was not too busy to serve me (as I have seen at some places.)  

The buildng is very intersting - a restored brick schoolhouse type of thing.  The paintings inside are fun and the decor is satisfying.  It was a bit on the dark side until it started to clear out.  All in all I really liked the place, the menu was small but very good.
author: mike r.

description:
Good food, had fun, slightly noisy.  The cocktails were great, the first course amazing, the entree filling and yummy, and the desserts looked great, I was just too full to have any. The coffee was great.  And I mean especially great.   

The atmosphere was a bit noisy, and our table location was not great. We were a group of 8 so it was hard to seat us, but still, that was my one thing preventing it from being a 5 star restaurant.
author: Heidi P.

description:
We came here last night to celebrate my good friend's birthday. It was also girls night so we were looking forward to a night of indulgence! The restaurant looks cool and trendy with a pretty big bar and some outdoor seating.  We got 7:30 reservations and were seated promptly.  The weird thing was, it was a Friday night and the restaurant was only half full.  Not sure why. 

We started with 2 appetizers: the softshell crab with guacamole and mango salsa, and fried oysters.  Both were delicious and great starters.  I could not get enough of the mango salsa! For some reason, I also could not stop eating the bread.  It must have been the super soft and spreadable butter. 

For our entrees, we decided to each pick one thing and just share amongst the 4 of us.  We decided on the fried chicken, bacon wrapped quail, pork chop, and st louis BBQ ribs. For our sides, we got the corn bread and tater tots.  Everything was so good! I especially loved the ribs (even though I'm not usually into saucy ribs).  The fried chicken was juicy and the batter was nice and crispy. The quail was good but different and not what I had expected.  I was expecting a full quail with wings and all but instead it looked more like a quail cake? The pork chop was good even though I'm usually not a fan of thick cut pork chop.  The fried grits that came with it though was amazing.  So crispy on the outside, but soft on the inside.  The sides were delicious as well. I loved the corn bread even though I couldn't really taste the jalapeno.  They came in little finger sized pieces - very cute. The tater tots came with this spicy BBQ sauce for dipping.  Loved the sauce! 

For dessert, we ordered the mini doughnuts with blue bottle ice cream, the butterscotch & chocolate pot de creme, and lemon souffle. All were fantastic but my favorite was the mini doughnuts.  The souffle was nice and light, almost like a lemon sorbet - very refreshing! Since it was my friend's birthday, they also gave us 3 mini cupcakes on the house. That was very nice! 

Overall, the food was yummy and the ambiance was laid back but still nice. The service was attentive.  They also had some specialty cocktails.  I liked the corpse reviver #2 - refreshing and fruity.  I would definitely come back again for another great dinner.
author: Kat M.

description:
Holiday party in the private room and there's no _____ in the private room (Chris Rock Reference)

3 stars because they did everything you'd expect a restaurant to do.  Another star because drinks and all were on the company.  :o)

My favorite dishes from the menu, which is below, were the Mixed greens and tuna tartare .  I enjoyed the party, but I'll have to come again to get a feel for the place.  All and all it was good.

THE MENU FOR THE NIGHT

First Course 

Mixed greens, Fuyu persimmons, goat cheese and citrus vinaigrette
or
Roasted baby beets, fennel, frise and lemon horseradish crme frache

Second Course

Smoked andouille sausage jambalaya with sauted shrimp and Creole sauce
or
Tuna tartare with fried green tomato and green onion Tabasco vinaigrette

Entre

Filet mignon with horseradish grits, rainbow chard and bordelaise sauce
or
Roasted salmon with celery root apple puree, potato leeks, butternut squash and black truffle sauce
or
Wild mushroom risotto with red wine gastrique
Dessert 

Butterscotch and chocolate pot de crme
or
Pear upside down cake with ginger ice cream
author: Po L.

description:
This place is indeed loud. The food is fantastic though.... If you can get it, I recommend Faith's ham and cheese "toast" (it's a sandwich!) with jalapeno cream and a poached egg....... too good for words!! I split one last week and have been craving one more bite ever since!

Also the sticky toffee cake is out of this world, caramel is truly underrated!!

The servers and staff are nice, but they rush through narrow walkways and don't yield the right of way to customers. 

Minus one star for: treating customers like road cones, the noise level, and the extended journey to the restrooms.
author: Stephanie T.

description: I'd say it was pretty fantastic. Mainly because we were in the large private room upstairs, it was paid for by someone else and the wine kept flowing. The jambalaya was almost too spicy to eat, but the filet minion and the desserts were excellent.
author: Scott M.

description: I've been to this restaurant twice now and I like this place. The atmosphere is fun and lively and great for young people. Some people complain about the noise, and yes it is loud but the atmosphere is fun so just don't go here if you are looking for a quiet, romantic dinner. The menu is mostly quality, upscale comfort food and it's something different for San Francisco. Think amazing fried chicken and maybe some type of steak. We were definitely full at the end of our meal but didn't feel terrible like you would with lesser quality comfort food. Not a huge fan of the location of this place but I guess it is standard for the soma area so not too much of a complaint. The service was good, no complaints there either. Overall a great place to go for a nice but casual meal.
author: Kate N.

description:
Yes, yes, I know I'm going to screw up their average rating with my low score, but just hear me out:

I called to make a lunch reservation for 11 people. The receptionist who answered the phone told me they didn't take reservations for parties of more than 10. Then she promptly hung up on me. No suggestions, no options for me to work it out, no nothing. Made me mad enough to swear never to go there again.
author: Anna G.

description:
I can only rate this place on what I've experienced so far. "Best $14 Burger in the Soma area", in my opinion. Better than 21st Amendment's for sure. Cooked perfectly to a nice and juicy medium. Meat crumbles without having to actually chew, just press down with your jaw and taadow! Brie cheese and some bacon makes it oh so scarfable. The roasted tomatoes are really roasted tomatoes and not something heated out of a can. The aoili and frites are more of a French style feel to the burger and fries combo than what most people are used from American joints. Had to remember to pace myself cuz it was a marathon, not a race given that I went there with my coworkers for a company lunch thing. Oh well, not there to talk about work, I was there to eat red meat!!!

Oh yea, other parts of the restaurant. The layout is cool. They have a small patio area in the front. The front bar area allows for some standing room as well as within the length of the bar. As you head towards the middle and back area more formal seating and tables become evident. It can get busy during lunch and early happy hour. The service is impeccable though and they are very attentive, but not overbearing. Well trained and  make you feel that what you are paying for and tipping is worth all the overtime and boring meetings. Yup-yup...
author: Nick V.

description: This is my go-to date place with my husband. We always have a wonderful time. The food and service are consistently excellent. Don't miss dessert!
author: Joanna H.

description:
I went here with a bunch of coworkers. It was convenient since it's a 5 minute walk from where we work. I was surprised to how busy it got. I got the ale battered fish and chips, which was pretty good. I liked the fries. Maybe next time I will try the duck enchilada since it looked good and it's something different to try out. The atmosphere was nice but it can be sort of hard to hear everyone since it was so busy.

The restaurant is a part of Dine About Town so I think I will take some friends the next time Dine About Town comes around again.
author: Jenn D.

description:
Beware of the Cougar Lair!!!
Came here for dinner on a Thursday at the tail end of happy hour.  This is for sure an after work business people spot.  
Maybe it was only this night, but there was an extra high amount of cougars on the prowel.  I witnessed multiple packs of 3 or 4 laughing very loudly to eachothers jokes while they were sipping martinis all the while scoping the scene for fresh meat.
After a while I stopped paying attention to the life around me and got to my food. It was very good.  The appetizers were excelent and the fried chicken was very good, just not for the $24 price.  These are things you dont think of until you pass by a KFC on your way home and think "man, I just payed $24 for fried chicken".  Maybe I was paying too much attention to the cougars.
author: Robert S.

description:
Reviewing Town Hall seems redundant at this point, fuck it - I'm putting in my two cents because that's how I roll.

Everything is quite good, if not excellent at Town Hall.  It's one of those few places where one really can't go wrong and everyone can find something to eat. 

This is all jolly until 1AM rolls around and your projectile vomiting from both ends every hour and half hour so bad that you have to sleep on the mat in your bathroom for fear of leakage.

Don't get the trout.

I can't give this place too bad of a rating, it was the third time I'd been there that I got food poisoning, but my sphincter hasn't let me go back since.
author: Lauren G.

description:
I only have two words for this place:  appetizers, dessert

Indeed the grilled ham and cheese with poached egg and jalapeno cream is insanely delicious!!!  I normally don't like cream nor poached eggs, but I had to make an exception for this dish.

The seafood crostini appetizer was pretty good, but tasted a bit on the salty side.

I had the Hawaiian mahi mahi (?) entree.  It was tasty, but the temp was a bit cold, prob cuz it was waiting while my dining parters' entrees were being completed :(

But then dessert was served *sound the trumpets*
Butterscotch cake - sweet delicious, topped with walnuts and vanilla ice cream, swimming in butterscotch sauce... O-M-freakin-G

Chocolate-butterscotch pot du creme - creamy chocolately, butterscotchy goodness - oh my!  and that candy thing it was topped with... ooh, i can still taste it stuck to my teeth... yum!

It's really loud in there tho... I wish the acoustics weren't like a Benihana inside.  And I wish my fish was the right temperature.  But just for that toast and the desserts, this place is worth a trip!!!
author: Shelley H.

description:
I don't know if I have anything more to add to what's already been said about this restaurant. The food is good. (mmm.. sweet corn... I love corn!) The decor is nice. The service was great, but gets a little crowded and loud at times.

So maybe I'll impart this little bit of info that I think will be useful: 

When you enter the restaurant, in the bar area, there is a self-effacing door all the way to your right, in the corner. Upon entering the door, you will encounter a set of stairs. Climb these stairs (about 3 flights) to the 2nd floor. Turn left. (On the right is the private dining area.) The bathrooms are straight ahead. Not that the bathrooms are anything to look at, but they're hard to find! The bathrooms are not old-worldly and town hall-ish in decor as one might hope. They are like a bathroom you might find in a subway station, only cleaner, and dressed up with a picture or two.

But still  a good restaurant, that I would eat at again!
author: Hue L.

description:
Tip 1: Going after the chi chi lunch crowd gets you a seat. It must be a like herd: 11:30 - mmmmmoOOOOOOOOO trample trample trample eat eat eat talk talk talk. 1:15 - mmmmmMMMMMMmOOOOOOOO trample trample trample back to work. i:30 - uh, table for four? Why yes sir, choose which table where you would like to sit. 

Tip 2: Tartare and fired green tomatoes. Yep, that worked well. As someone mentioned below, the tomatoes kicked butt.

Tip 3: They will grill your burger to your liking. YES! I know I can get sick, I know I can die, but I love it when my cow is still moo-ing between the buns. And this one was. The foccica bread worked breat and the big yellow tomato was yummers.

My table mates ordered a salad and veggie sandwich, both which looked good. Another ordered the beef sandwich, big and juicy with a mound of meat. 

Second time eating here. Yes the service is mediocre but the food was egg-salad.
author: Art H.

description:
Some friends and I ventured to Town Hall after enjoying a few happy hour drinks elsewhere.  I was rather excited after having read the raving reviews on yelp.  BUT boy was I in for a surprised...  We arrived around 8:15pm and had to search for a host to speak to.  We were told that a table should be available in 30 minutes, which was alright with us.  After 30 minutes, we hunted down the host and inquired about our table.  We were told that it should be ready in 15 minutes.  After waiting another 25 minutes, we asked again.  After over an hour of waiting and being told that our table will almost be ready, I was ready to just call it a night.  We were finally seat only AFTER speaking with the manager. (Strike 1)

After finally settling at our table at 9:40, we glanced over the menu.  The choices where a little on the limited side.  Our server came over to greet us and most of us ordered the famous fried chicken. He disappeared into the darkly lit room.  Only to reappear 20 minutes later with our drinks and bread.  The bread was cold.... It took another 30 minutes for our entrees to be served.  When we were finally presented with our foods, I was quite excited.  The fried chicken looked delicious.  The chicken was just average.  Nothing special.  The biscuits were ICE COLD and HARD enough to use as a golf ball....I was SOO disappointed. (Strike 2)  

Throughout our entire meal, NO ONE came to check on us. (Strike 3)
Absolutely ridiculous!  We could have gone to somewhere else for a fraction of the price and better service.   

3 Strikes, You're OUT!

  Ridiculously long wait, terrible Service, and disappointing food.  I will NEVER return.  I'd rather go to a restaurant who values their patrons.
author: E C.

description:
We ordered the tuna tartare, veal meatballs, and lobster fondue appetizers for the table - they were all fantastic.  
My entree (slow roasted duck with toasted wild rice...) was sheer pleasure on a plate. 
For all that, let's chalk up 3 stars.
However, others at the table did complain that the fish dishes were too salty.
And now for the desserts: I guess I went with such incredibly high expectations that it couldn't have been anything but a let down.  The desserts were nice (yes, we did order the chocolate butterscotch cups) but nothing earth shattering.
I was also somewhat ticked off that we had to wait for more than 30 minutes to be seated DESPITE a reservation made weeks in advance.
author: Godot -.

description:
Good food, but the crowd is a little older for my taste (and the ambiance caters to that crowd). The service was good and pretty fast. I had the following:
Dozen oysters (tasty)
Tuna Tartare (yum, accompanied by fried green tomatoes)
Mac n Cheese Croquettes (awesome)
Pork oso bucco (fall off the bone tender)
butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme (delicious)
chocolate tart (meh)
author: Nicolas H.

description:
This was the best meal I've had in a long time. From the amazing appetizer (the jalapeno tuna tartar was an unbelievable fusion of flavors), to the incredible main dish (everyone ate from my plate - the Alaskan halibut was mouth watering) to the desserts - we had to order four different and shared them with the table. 

I'm not really into fine dining. My brother has worked at some of the best restaurants in the country including French Laundry, Ad Hoc, Payards, and Murray Circle, and I have to say (although not to him) this was a superior meal to the places I have eaten before.
author: crystal diamond r.

description:
Good food, nice building, and sexy waitresses :)
The main drawbacks were the noise level and the fact that the desert I picked (Caramel Apple Crisp) was too sugary - although it looked like the "lightest" one from their menu...
author: Max V.

description:
if you couldn't tell, i am not one to turn down a free meal. 
  so low and behold, i find myself at Town Hall for lunch (on the company dime). 

i guess the 424 reviews can tell you that this is one of *the* downtown lunch spots. great to be seen, to be heard, and all that. 
  and oh yes, FiDi yuppies. i heard you. loud and clear. 
   trying to talk over the din of the lunching suits wasn't easy. 

and i felt that Town Hall's take on "casual modern renovated chic" was trying just a little too hard. 
   i mean, the bill in the book? oh please. 

regardless, food wasn't bad. wasn't great, just had no complaints I guess. so a nice middle-of-the-road 3. 
  our table of 6 all had different entrees: bbq shrimp, jambalaya, cobb salad, burger, beef sandwich, and fish+chips. no one was raving over their food, but at least no one was gagging either. always a good thing, I guess.

for the price, I doubt I'd come here again. 
   unless, of course, I'm not paying. 
    I am always a sucker for free food.
author: Vic C.

description: This was one of the most reserved places on Open Table.  It was a while ago that I was there  and from what I recall the food was average and the service sucked.  I might have to go back and try it again, but definately not in a hurry.  I think they just cater to the corporate expense accounts that work nearby and have no where else close by to go to.
author: James H.

description:
This place was so hyped up for so long, why you may ask?  I think it's because they weren't afriad to serve up big hearty, comfort food in a land dominated by Cali Cuisine types that serve up pretty, dainty pieces of meat on a bed of cute young farmer's market greens.  

They used to have homemade donut holes injected with rich, sinful chocolate served along side a cappucino milkshake, it was so good I called the restaurant to ask why they stopped serving it.  Apparently they didn't get enough calls as the donuts have yet to resurface.  If you need a sweet, indulgent dessert get their ramen sized bowl of butterscotch pot de creme.  I would recommend their fish and chips as well since it's done well and they give you more fish than chips, I know that's awesome!  The jalapeno cornbread is so yummy but that's hard to screw up.
author: Amber L.

description:
Town Hall is without a doubt, my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Although it is a pricier menu, everything is high quality and tastes fantastic. I have never been disappointed with anything I've ordered. 
They always have a great oyster selection, and the bloody mary oyster shooters are spicy and fantastic.  I've had almost every entree on the menu, but my favorite is probably the pork chop served with cheesy grits... it's FANTASTIC!  Their fried okra and jalepano corn bread are two fantastic sides. The desserts are exceptional. Pot de creme is rich and smooth; a chocolate and carmel heaven. 
Service is always attentive without being annoying.  
They have a great speciality drinks menu, and very good wine list. 
The ambience is very trendy and classy. The dining room can sometimes get a little loud, but not terrible.  Parking is usually pretty easy around the area. 
I would highly recommend Town Hall to any connoisseur of fine dining with a more modern, laid-back atmosphere!
author: Rachyl U.

description:
If there's one thing I learned from this place is that "Well, the salad had a little too much dressing on it" may not have been a valid response to our waiter's "How was it?" He just gave me a shrug and said some forgettable cliche before walking off. Everybody else's salad looked good...maybe we shouldn't have had them split ours. Oh well.

It's an interesting looking place and it seemed hip enough, but I just can't shake this feeling of being a little bit disappointed. Maybe my being honest about the salad killed the kharma? Perhaps it's my husband's cynicism rubbing off on me?

Hmm...I do recall enjoying my fried chicken. Dessert went well. The staff was quite attentive. 

Maybe I'm drawing a little too much negativity from our experience with our salad and my husband's unmet expectation of what he envisioned his pancetta-wrapped rainbow trout to look like. I guess we both pictured the trout to come as a fillet instead of a whole fish complete with skin. 

His reaction:
"How am I supposed to eat this? Ugh! Am I supposed to eat the skin? Like a peasant?!"

No offense to all the peasants out there.

Perhaps, next time we could drown out all that cynicism with more alcohol.
author: April B.

description:
This was my second visit to town hall and it just was as good as i remembered... not to say that it was bad, but the food at my first experience was alittle better. i didn't make reservations (don't do this here it's always busy) and luckily got seated at the outdoor patio (actually not bad) i ordered the shoestring potatoes...salty. i ordered the prime rib...salty. the scallop dish on the other hand...great! so if you order the fries or steak, ask for no salt! 
a pretty nice wine list.
when going to the restroom, i saw the private group room. it's pretty nice if you want to throw a get together. overall, a good restaurant.
author: carlos l.

description:
Really decent food, but overpriced. Too loud to have an enjoyable or productive business lunch, though we've done it. They do have private rooms for bigger business deals/private parties. Very nice decor, but  could use a little more character. 
I enjoyed the broccoli rabe more than anything else. Excellent beer selection, ok wines by the glass. They have some 'amazing' hot chocolate that's $10 a cup. I decided to not try on principle, it even though I was on an expense account. The staff seemed rushed and had their minds elsewhere, from the host down to the server...
author: Colleen B.

description:
I had read a lot of good reviews of Town Hall, so we decided to try it out one night. I can't say I was overly impressed, although a few things stood out over the others.

The appetizers were good. We tried the ham and biscuits with jalapeno jelly. Not too rich and just enough. I can't remember what I had as an entree (which isn't good, because I remember everything and this entree left no impression with me). BF had the duck and was pleased with the intricate layer of flavors.

Then it came to dessert. Oh my. I had heard of the butterscotch chocolate pot de creme. Not being a big chocolate lover, I gave in since the BF is a huge chocolate eater. This bowl could quite easily make me a chocolate convert for life. Our waitress said there have been customers who have hit her hand as she's tried to take the empty bowl away! They want to lick it all off!!! I have to admit, there is no shame in wanting to do that, it is THAT good!
author: Kittenheel S.

description:
Went on a weeknight,. The place was pretty full, therefore first impression was it must be decent.

Often that first impression never lies.

They do food good. Top it off with a lively atmosphere and you get comfortable eating there real quickly.
author: Stanley L.

description:
I will remain politically active in this Town Hall for years.  In fact, I feel like eating here regularly could almost become a patriotic duty.  Disregarding the fact that I'm surrounded by people who look like they just came from a game of shuffleboard, I feel right at home.  American as apple pie, the menu doesn't shortchange on flavorful food.  And true to our heritage, this place will undoubtedly put you into the 64.5% of the American population that is currently obese. Laced with as much pork product as my southern heart could possibly desire, the menu is downright delicious.  But for all you foreign tongues and terrorists out there be forewarned, it's neither light nor "lite."  A meal here will leave your stomach bulging for hours, though the memory of the food will carry on for days.  

The highlight of this institution is undoubtedly the finale.  We're talking about serious proportion issues among the dessert plates.  Pound for pound, my bread pudding and my friend's sticky toffee cake outweighed both of our entrees.  Now that's what I'm talking about; save the best for last and supersize it!  Not only was it gianormous, but it was true heaven on the tastebuds.  Citizen cake ...puh-lease.  If I want a real piece of the pie, I'm headin' to Town Hall.
author: Dubs W.

description:
The last time I was at Town Hall completely ruined the place for me. I had previously been a few times and it was always a good meal. Unfortunately, my latest visit didn't resemble any of the previous meals. The food was under seasoned, bland, and dry. 3 of us got the duck, there was no sauce and the duck was overcooked. My mom ordered the halibut and they brought her salmon. Which starts the discussion on how HORRIBLE the service was. Our waiter was inattentive and took almost 30 minutes just to bring our drinks. The manager came over and apologized about the entree mistake, but when the bill came both the wrong entree and the halibut were on the bill. Talk about not paying any attention!

Definitely will not be returning anytime soon. There's so many other restaurants in the city at this price range to get a great meal, I'd much rather go to those. The worst $500 meal we've ever had (5 person party).
author: Josh M.

description:
We loved the food here.

My husand had veal meatballs in mashed potatoes and gravy for an appetizer and I had the tomato fondue with broccoli, mozzarella cheese balls, and (2 small garlic breadsticks).  Also I ordered the warm jalapeno cornbread, which came to us in a small cast iron tray and looked like small ladyfingers.  The appetizers were delicious!

For the main course my husband had steak, and I (being a vegetarian), had the risotto with mushrooms.  

I have to say that I'm not a big fan of mushrooms, but the risotto was great!  I even tried the mushrooms and they weren't bad.  The risotto tasted as if it were in a creamy cheese sauce.

Town Hall is known for "comfort foods" also for American style food and we were not disappointed.  

The dessert was great as well.  We tried the jelly doughnut and I had the hot chocolate with homemade cookies (chocolate chip).

The only reason I'm giving it 4 stars instead of 5 is, even though the waitress was great, she wasn't around as much as we wanted.  After we finished dinner we waited for 20 minutes for her to come back so we could order dessert.  The busboy came by (he was wonderful) and actually took our order instead of the waitress.  

But, given that, we'd still go back!    If you go it's probably best to try and get reservations or else you'll be on the patio (and it's cold!).

EDIT - went back a 2nd time with reservations and had great service and great food!  Changing this now to 5 stars!
author: Ruth L.

description:
"Would you like some food with that salt?"

This place drowns their ingredients in salt to the point it was hard to finish my meal, because I had to drink so much water to keep hydrated. The food was OK at best, and way overpriced for what it was (or wasn't in this case)
author: Joyce S.

description:
Ok you probably know town hall.  It was the new hotness a few years ago and is still pretty heavily trafficked.  I've never had a bad dish here, some things have changed on the menu over the past couple years but the one constant the the chocolate & butterscotch pudding for dessert.

Beware, I do suspect some sort of evil is at work as after the last time I ate there my alternator died on the way home and the time before that I fell asleep as soon as I got home.  I think they may me draining the delicious energy out of things near and dear to you and feeding it back to you in a delicious entree.
author: steve a.

description:
this spot is close to a few places i work, so i almost always go here for work related meals.....work can be pleasurable but its not pleasure.  it could be that i've been here too many times, but i would not go here on a date or with a group of friends....there are too many better places for that.  it feels like an business crowd to me and if you listen closely, you can hear about the less than thrilling discussion that many of us have.  i will say the bar is a nice little spot for a meal and you can scoot on up and visit with one of their excellent bartenders.  the place is almost always packed....always a plus.  the wine list is a bit pricey, but that is because of the clientele.  work related....great.  if you are with friends....head to the salt house just down the way.  i believe that is their sister restaurant or at least i was told that and i believe everything i am told.  

all that said, the food is solid and is consistent every time i go there.  i've had many dishes and many bites of what others ordered.  its a mainstay.  its a sure fire good meal.
author: Dustin S.

description:
Seriously, I would give it 6 stars if I could! It is truly gastronomically delight!
We had "Splendid in a Glass" cocktail, oysters for starters and Tai Snapper for main dish.  The cocktail is finely crafted! It's one of those dangerous one that you'll keep drinking, b/c it tastes so damn good!

Both Oysters and snapper dish were so yummy! the sauce for raw oyster was ridiculously tasty - simple, but really good!  And tai snapper, the sauce bedding was .... heavenly!  

I know it's pricy.. but it was worth every penny!
author: N. C.

description: Seat punctually.  Drinks were very good, altough took a while.  had the fried chicken, was good.  I would probably give the food three stars, although I am not sure I would ever rate southern food higher than that.  My company enjoyed the short ribs.  Atmoshere is good.
author: Glenn S.

description:
All of the sudden I had been hearing "Town Hall" everywhere, so I figured it was about time to try it. "Town Hall" not to be confused with the City Hall, ha! is located in SOMA so I figured I would give it a try for lunch.

Arrived at noon, we were not seated right away, had to wait a few minutes, no big deal.

The décor is typical SOMA, brick walls, upscale, some random artwork on the walls, overall has kind of an east coast feel to it. Hard to describe.

I ordered the blackened salmon sandwich & my friend ordered the duck enchiladas & a salad. We were brought some whole wheat French bread & butter, which I loved. By the time I got my lunch, I was full from the bread!

The salmon sandwich was very good, the salmon had a really good flavor & the bread was soft, it was served with a small salad, which I was too full to eat. The duck enchiladas were very rich, I do not think I could handle eating a full order of them, but they were good.

Overall good comfort food, slow service & great atmosphere. They even bring your bill in a book, but that doesn't quite make up for the fairly steep prices!
author: Elaine S.

description:
I prefer The Salt House, their sister restaurant in the financial district, but I have to say that the fried mac n cheese bites are ridiculously good, as were the lovely vodka/champagne martinis i was drinking.
Town Hall was written up in Gourmet Magazine for their amazing Key Lime Pie, so check it out if it's on the menu.
author: Erin J.

description: I had the food here when my good friend has his wedding reception here.  We had the whole bottom floor, liked the bar and service. The fried chicken here is the bomb for sure.  Seafood was real fresh, I will definitely come back again.
author: Chris L.

description: Food was delicious. Had the steak. Perfect medium rare. Friend had the pork chops w/ cubed polenta. Delicious as well. Not dry at all.Staff was attentive, but not too overbearing. Ambiance was a bit noisy, but it was expected.
author: Kat N.

description: Rarely do I give 5 stars.  The food was really good and the service was as well.  I had the pork chop, tried Mom's fried chicken. The ginger beer "un-spirited" libation was interesting/good too!
author: John A.

description:
Good appi's and great desserts. Need to try the sticky toffee cake as that was the highlight of my meal. The pot de creme was good - but not worth $8.50

Entrees were disappointing. The seafood etoufee was far too salty. The rice was also really salty, but had some nice spices in it. The only part of the entree I enjoyed were the fried oysters. The fried chicken was good - however th collard greens to acidic and the mashed potatoes were luke warm. 

Service was very good. =)
author: Joyce T.

description:
I just can't enjoy good food when the service is horrible (and that's the nice way of putting it), especially when a restaurant expects you to spend a hundred bucks on dinner! 

We were hoping for BBQ at Memphis Minnie's on Haight, but realized they were closed on Monday (just as we were walking up and saw the bars drawn across the doorway, of course). Disappointed, we started walking towards Market and eventually down to Town Hall after gaining an appetite during our unexpected tour through the Financial District and remembered our Check Please Bay Area list and found Town Hall. 

So, we were dressed for BBQ on Haight and not for business-casual dining, but whatever; we walked in and felt out of place right away, but only had to wait about five minutes for a table. I don't think the host ever spoke to us and used his directional signals as his only means of communication.  It was still pretty crowded at 9pm and the crowd was pretty and upbeat (and on expense accounts)-- a convention in town from the looks of the swag bags and embroidered polo shirts all around.

The place is beautiful, with exposed beams and bricks as far as the eye can see. The lighting was dim even though there were about a dozen cool-looking chandeliers all along the dining room and enough candles to warrant a fire inspection.

Too bad the service couldn't keep up with the designers.  The waiter dropped off the water on the table without saying a word and returned five minutes later to tell us the soup of the day and left again for about ten minutes to take our drink order.  Five minutes later he dropped off the drinks and left while I practically begged for bread (twice!), which he refused to hear.  We ended up asking the nice guy refilling our waters and it was brought out right away.  When the waiter returned another five minutes later after we stared him down from the large table of convention-goers a few tables away, I asked for a suggestion for the main course and he basically said they were all good and wasn't too much help at all.  So, we started out with the soup (a wonderful gumbo) and the heirloom tomato salad with green colors and flavor.

The lack of service was suddenly replaced with overzealous table-clearing as the waiter took my soup with a good five spoonfuls left without saying a word!  Woah, that was a surprise.  A minute later another swooshed in and dropped the main courses.  Admittedly, the food was excellent.  We had the fried chicken with mashed potatoes and bacon gravy and seasoned vegetables and the fish with red wine sauce.  The chicken was moist and the breading was crispy!

Again, the waiter tried to pick up my dish before I was done!  Yikes; I protested and he apologized, but the damage was done.  Too bad.

We paid the (hefty) bill, full and satisfied, but left with a bad taste in our mouths.  Great food; horrible service.
author: Fernando C.

description: Oh...my.....lord...I l.o.v.e. this place. Took my dad there for his 69th birthday with my roommate and it was heavenly. We started with the butter lettuce salad with Pt. Reyes blue cheese, yum. I had the scallops with risotto for dinner and I might as well have licked the bowl clean. My dad had the steak and it was better than most steaks I have ever tried in the Midwest....yes that is right, I said it. If you want to impress  your honey or treat someone to a special dinner, then this is the place to go. I have also heard they have a good lunch menu. Once I scrounge my pennies together again, I will be back.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Waiting tables is hard. How do I know this? I spent two grueling weeks working the meager lunch shift at a now-defunct Financial District restobar. It sucked, and I sucked. Barely scraping by on $3 tips, I took full advantage of the comp food, earning disapproving glances from the tightass owner. Mercifully, they laid me off one Friday, whereupon I accidentally spilled red wine on a patron before finishing my last shift. Skillz.

Hence, I am the last person who would begrudge a harried waiter an artificial pick-me-up to help them through their shift. But you've got to keep a lid on it and maintain a professional appearance, which our Town Hall waiter failed to do. Sweating heavily, dude was so jacked he couldn't stand still. We had to corral him back to the table once. He talked faster than the voice-over dude at the end of radio commercials. While entertaining, the performance didn't make my wallet feel like it was being used effectively.

Food? The biscuits with ham, butter, and marmalade were outstanding. and the heirloom tomato salad was tasty too. The trout entree, though, lacked appealing characteristics and was dry.
author: Jimmy G.

description:
My friends and I had a reason to celebrate as we got to enjoy a little tipple in the outdoor patio. Should have brought a thicker jacket since it was freezing because of the slight breeze which turned into a forceful one.

Prices for drinks during happy hour are decent compared to Americano. Scene is less hipster/wanna-be and more down home. Check out the indoor bar if you can't stand sitting outside. We ended up there after the winds picked up.
author: S L.

description:
In the interest of full disclosure, I must admit that my review for Town Hall may be bias because I dined here under the most amazing circumstances. This was my celebratory meal the night I found out that I passed the California Bar Exam. So truth be told, I could have eaten a round table pizza and proclaimed it the best meal of my life - I was THAT happy. 

We started with a bunch of appetizers, and while they were all tasty, the biggest star was the BBQ shrimp. It was so savory and delicious and the yummy sauce was soaked up by the toasted bread on the bottom. The sauce itself tastes like homemade chex mix (and I mean that in the best possible way) because of all the butter and worshishire. 

The fried chicken was delicious. I am not going to say that it was quite as good as Ad Hoc's, but it is way less of a drive. The desserts were GREAT and huge! The butterscotch pudding was divine and strangely addictive. At the end of the meal I was stuffed, I could not have eaten another bite! Our waiter was so nice after he found out my good news and even put a candle in my dessert. It was a great evening.
author: Dana H.

description:
After hearing about this place, I finally went and tried it.
I was dissapointed. I'll go to Salt House and Anchor & Hope anytime over this place!

The food was just mediocre and it's way over-priced for mediocre tasting food. The pork chop was a little over cooked and the side dish I ordered was just ok, it was cooked down greens. How can one go wrong.

The service was not great either, she took my order and I never saw her again until the time to deliver the check. I had to flag down the bussboy to get some water. No one came to ask if everything was ok.

The floor is uneven, walk carefully ladies with heels. Also be prepared to have a field trip if you need to visit the ladies room upstairs and around.

The atmosphere. It was a Sunday night, this place was extremely noisy and loud. Definately not a place for a date (thank god I wasn't on a date), maybe go with a  big group so you can try to see who's louder? Or go with someone you've been trying to get rid of, so you don't have to talk nor pay attn and he can pay the pricey tab and hope he won't call you again.
author: Florence W.

description: I usually like this place - and the food is quite decent although not super - but this last time we had a TERRIBLE EXPERIENCE. We came with a very large group and it took almost 4 hours to eat dinner. Really. We arrived at 645 pm and we left around 1030 pm. Everyone was tired and in a bad mood by the end. Also, what HORRIBLE SERVICE. Waitress spilled water all over the table and DID NOT APOLOGIZE. She said, "oh good thing it was over there" (i.e., "oh good thing it didn't go right into your chest and just went on your right leg"). Then she threw a napkin on the table over the water and left. I couldn't believe it. By the way the mahi mahi was tasteless and the ribs were covered in sugary sauce. We are hearty eaters and did not finish our food. The chocolate pot de creme seemed good but I was in such a lousy mood at that point and had chewed on so much hard dry bread that I couldn't eat and didn't finish it. I WOULD NOT GO BACK.
author: p v.

description:
Yummmm!!!!!

We ordered the Tuna tartar...Yum. It was a very generous portion. We also order those cornbread thingies...they were ok. The thing I loved was the pork chop! yummy. I ordered the duck and it wasn't as tasty as I expected. The pork chop is what the hubby ordered and i think I ate half his portion!  We also ordered some sort of shrimp appetizers...I didn't care of it too much.  

I'm going back. 

We aren't big wine consumers but they have a very extensive wine list.
author: Leena C.

description: Great restaurant that was recommended by a friend. The food was fantastic! Our favorite was the veal meatballs, the warm ham and cheese, and THE very best donuts I have ever had!! Pure heaven!!
author: Joni V.

description: This place is a class act and the food is always great.  I have had lunch in the restaurant and am also a regular at their summer BBQ/sandwich spot on the side of the building.  The folks that run that are always having a good time and are friendly, and the ribs, chicken sandwiches and sausage are great for a quick lunch.   On top of this, they have La Fin du Monde on tap.  How can you go wrong?
author: Claytonian C.

description: We had a reservation for 8:45 but didn't really get seated til little after 9pm.. However, the food and service was impeccable and worth the wait!   The tuna tartare and fried green tomatos made a great appetizer...and the jalenpeno corn bread is a must have, too.    For dinner, the Salmon and andouille sausage in tomato broth was an interesting pairing but delicious!   It is a hopping place for happy hour and weekday dining
author: Mimi T.

description: Hands down the chocolate and butterscotch pot de creme was the highlight of our evening! I'd go back just to try the rest of the dessert selections. My friend's duck entree was also tasty -- generous portions without the bone. My only gripe is that the place can get pretty noisy which makes it difficult for conversation.
author: Helen Y.

description:
I had heard so many mixed opinions on this place, I didn't know what to expect.
I have to admit, i was pleasantly surprised.
Although, it didn't start well.
We were running a little late, so i called to make sure it wouldn't be a problem. The woman on the phone assured me it wasn't a big deal, and we would be seated when we arrived.
Well, when we got there it was a whole other story. I told the hostess about the conversation I'd had with the woman on the phone, (which was not her.) She informed me that our table had been given away, and they only hold the reservation for 15 mins. That's fine, and understandable, but not it f you don't mention it on the phone. She went on to tell me that the woman i spoke to is very clear about explaining that.Whatever, like I'm going to lie to her? That annoyed me beyond belief. I thought she was incredibly stuck-up and rude. I was ready to leave, but someone higher in command than her found us a table. He did tell us we had to be out by 8, (which was an hour and a half away.) I appreciated his effort, and we gave it shot.
I'm so glad we did! The appetizer of poached egg and ham toast was amazing! I would order that again without thinking twice!
Our entrees took a very long time to get there. I had the bacon wrapped trout, with lemony potatoes. 
This was a different preparation of trout than I 'd ever had. The components of the dish separately aren't that impressive.Although, when you have a bite of the salty bacon with the lemony potatoes, the flavors are amazing. I couldn't believe how well they worked together! I'm just more accustomed to eating my meal in sections. There was something that did strike me as odd about the fish,it's from Scotland. Why wouldn't they use local fish? With such a bounty of fresh fish available in the bay area, i see no reason to use fish from another country. They probably doesn't bother most people though. Maybe it's just me.
For dessert we had the pot de creme. We were told it was one  their signature items. I didn't think I'd be too crazy about it, but i loved it!

The prices here are a little high, and the service isn't great. Although, the food is interesting,creative and well executed.
The noise level is another reason I couldn't give this place 5 stars. It seemed to increase as the night went on. We were seated off to the side,I can't imagine how loud it must have gotten in the center of the dining room.
I would go back at some point. Maybe on a weeknight it wouldn't be so loud.
author: Amanda G.

description:
came here for a business lunch.  

I ordered a hamburger and it came out juicy and tender.  it was really good, but if they charge $12 for a burger, it has to be damn good.  i was disappointed with the service.  we waited 30 minutes for our meal even though it wasn't even crowded.  when we asked the waitress where our meal was, she gave us some lame ass excuse... saying that because we didn't order appetitzers so that's why it seems long--the entrees will come out the same time with or without appetitizers.  WTH?!   does she think we're retards??
author: Jannie Q.

description: 3.25 stars. I like Town Hall. A lot. I crave their fried chicken ALL THE TIME. The jalapeno cornbread is also very good. I love comfort food. Gourmet comfort food, that is. Town Hall is it.
author: Betty N.

description: So maybe it was me, but I just thought is was ok.  I came here with a friend who was visiting from the east coast for dinner because I had heard so much about it and thought it would be a great experience for us.  It turned out to not be a good idea.  Not only could we not hear each other, I don't think the wait staff could hear us either.  I say that because I ordered my steak medium rare and it came well done.  I didn't send it back because I just wanted to get out of there by that time so I could spend some time actually talking to my friend.  The food was ok, but I won't recommend it if you plan on speaking during your meal.
author: Karen C.

description: This place was good.. 3.5 stars.  I like the decor.  Open in the front, clean and inviting, pretty loud.  I can see how it'd be a popular business lunch/dinner/afterwork-drinks spot.  The food was pretty good.    In general, it's upscale comfort food.  I liked the red pepper jelly a lot for the biscuits.  I liked the trout I got.  I tried the ribs, they were good.  We got a moonpie for dessert... it was OK...  While the food was good and the prices were pretty standard... it came out to an expensive meal (mostly b/c of drinks) for homey-comfort food that wasn't that unique or outstanding.
author: Easter E.

description:
I am amending an earlier review of a policy only, because I have since eaten there and enjoyed the lunch I had immensely, and found the service excellent and the ambience just lovely.  One note in particular was that my friend's tuna tartare didn't come with anything to eat it on, and they quickly brought some crostini-like morsels without any attitude at all -- a rarity in SF, I'm sure you can agree.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:  We may or may not be dining here on Sunday, but I want to point out an egregious reservations policy that should be disclosed, in writing, up front, wherever Town Hall advertises or garners customers.  Parties of more than 6 require a credit card (including expiration date) to be given, but you have to ask three separate questions to learn that if you are a no-show, your card will be charged $20 per person (PER PERSON?!?!!!!), which will be "credited" back to you in a gift certificate to Town Hall.  

I know times are hard in the restaurant business, but seriously?  That's a lotta b.s. right there.
author: L D.

description:
I absolutely loved this place and am so glad I picked it for my birthday dinner. 

In terms of New American food in SF, this ranks up there with One Market for me, with a warmer, homey atmosphere. There's something on the menu to please everyone. Our waitress knew her stuff and was helpful with choosing what to order.

The Life of Riley cocktail is deliciously refreshing, and our food was fantastic, particularly the ribeye and bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin. 

The only thing that didn't blow us away was the desserts (butterscotch pot de creme, brown butter pound cake, and complimentary birthday cupcakes) but that was perhaps because we were already stuffed to the brim. 

Definitely coming back for the fried chicken!
author: S L.

description:
I was on the border the 4 star vs. 5 star cusp...but I just had to go with 5 stars! Plus, there's no option for 4.5 stars.

Anyway! The counting factor that pushed me to the full 5 stars was my starter course at Town Hall. The Deep Fried Squash Blossoms filled with 4 cheeses, served with a pesto dipping sauce and a red pepper salad/dip. It was the most magnificent pairing of cheese and vegetable I think I will ever taste! Since eating there this past Tuesday, I've been contemplating going back and ordering 5 plates of them...so delicious!

However, before my appetizer came out, I was enjoying the Eli Refresher, which was tasty. I was craving tropical fruits (especially guava) and some alcohol after my day at work and it definitely hit the spot!

So yadah, yah...then our entrees came out...GLORIOUS!!! I had ordered the Pork Chop and when it came out it made a statement! Sort of how the final dress of a designer at fashion week presents their  last outfit in the show and everyone gasp and jaws drop to the floor...that was my table's reaction to my pork chop. It was this huge, thick pork chop on top of a bed of spicy dirty rice, served with a pomegranate sauce. D-LISH! My two aunts both ordered the halibut, which I will admit I entertained the idea of ordering when menus were passed about, but I was far too happy with my pork chop decision. My mom ordered the famous fried chicken.

On a breakdown...it's obvious I loved my pork chop! My two aunts loved their halibut as well. The three of us scraped our plates clean..every morsel was taken prisoner. However, the famous chicken we'd heard so much about left my mom a little disappointed. I didn't try it...but she said the flavor was all in the crust and the actual meat of the chicken was bland. This made me sad...but at the same time happy because I didn't order the chicken.

But when dessert came out, it made a fan out of all of us. My aunt ordered the date/toffee sticky bread - it was good, she killed it. My mom ordered the Butterscotch & Chocolate Pot de Creme, which totally made her experience worthwhile...and everyone else cause we all tried it and loved it! And I ordered the Donuts with Espresso Ice Cream...which was tasty but the donuts just didn't do it for me. Good thing mom ordered the Butterscotch & Chocolate Pot de Happiness!

We were all definitely happy when we left and very full. The food was amazing, despite a few faults. But overall, the 5 is deserved. The staff was very attentive and welcoming. The decor was casual and comfortable...yet rustic at the same time. Only thing that might bother people is the noise...but I'm young and don't mind yelling, so it was cool with me.

Would definitely say everyone has gotta at least eat here once...it's worth it. And if not...you can write something funny in one of their books that they bring the check in!
author: stefany f.

description:
My wife and I have been to Town Hall many times, beginning with one of our very first dates in 2006.  We still remember the duck from that particular evening -- the skin was perfectly crisp while the meat was still succulent -- as well as the chocolate cake and the beautiful artwork that we sat under in the corner of the dining room.  We were the last ones to leave, and nobody rushed us as we lingered well past closing time.

We've had more dates there, birthday parties, dinner parties, power lunches and tastings, and every time we come away raving about something, whether it's the fried green tomatoes or the bill at the end of the evening that comes tucked into an antique book.  God really is in the details.

Still, none of this compared to having our wedding there in December of 2009.  

We wanted an intimate party that centered around family and food.  Town Hall helped us nail it.  In particular, Colleen Booth, the Director of Public Relations & Events, was a major reason why we chose to go with Town Hall.  She was prompt in returning our barrage of emails, detail-oriented, and extremely patient as we built a timeline for our hors d'ouevres hour, tea ceremony and eight speeches.  All the staff were gracious and professional and discreet.  The food, as always, was brilliant.  

Five stars is not enough.  We can't wait to return.
author: Alex W.

description:
The food was good, but unremarkable (we only went two weeks ago and I already forgot what we ordered), and definitely not worth what we paid for it.

I didn't like the crowd here. It was like there was a dbag convention in town or something. My friend and I waited about 40 minutes for a table, and every five minutes we were getting hit on by a different half-drunk loser (who, after being shot down by us, would then move on to the hostess, the waitresses, and anything else with two legs and boobs). I guess I really shouldn't blame the restaurant for this, but still...if I wanted to get leg-humped, I'd go hang out at City Nights.
author: D E.

description: We had the fried chicken which was delicious and the ribs which was also very good.  Dessert was the strawberry cheesecake (shared it) and enjoyed the dessert.  Overall the food and service was very good.  Can be a bit noisy if you want a quiet dinner.
author: Em D.

description:
Think back: Spring 2005, lovely dinner at Town Hall fueled by a gift certificate. Delicious pork chop, veal meatballs to die for, heavenly pot de creme, impeccable service. Erin tells everyone who will listen (and some that wouldn't) that Town Hall is the restaurant to end all restaurants. 

Fast Forward: July 2006. So-so service, waitstaff was rushed and seemed to be annoyed that we were seated in their section. Overpowering sauces covering mediocre meat. Tepid white wine. 

Thankfully, I still love the vibe and the interior of Town Hall. I think I talked it up a bit too much in my brain and the return trip was an off-night. I'll wouldn't hesitate to return, but it's no longer first on my list.
author: Erin M.

description:
Minus a point for having had plenty of opportunities to tell me what the f-ing soup of the day was, and not telling me what it was. And minus a point for taking forever to bring us our food, when it was way past the lunch rush.

Otherwise, the food was good- My trusty dining partner and I had the spinach + bacon salad, which though it looked overdressed, wasn't soggy. The dressing was different- not your typical vinaigrette. We also had the tuna tartare, which though I'm sick of seeing on every other menu, decided to try because I was in the mood, and was totally happy that I did. It came with fried green tomatoes and a pepper sauce. For the main, I had the bacon wrapped trout, which was ridiculously tasty. And my partner had the fish and chips, which I never go for, but had a bite and it was yum.
author: Nina H.

description: Second time having dinner at Town Hall.  I really liked it the first time I went.  This time, it was just okay.  Everything on the menu sounds really good.  The food was solid, but nothing memorable or that I'm dying to go back and have.  The staff is always very nice and friendly which is a huge plus in San Francisco where most places the staff is rude.  Overall, I would recommend it as a solid nice meal to have in a city where most of the restaurants are mostly hype and not really that great overall.  I think next time I would go sit at the bar, have a drink and some BBQ shrimp and be quite happy...maybe dessert if I was feeling decadent.
author: Amy H.

description: I love this place with my whole heart. Pricey but worth it.
author: S. L.

description:
You can count on the pot de creme (chocolate and butterscotch) here, but the duck is something you have to get lucky with since it's usually a special. A very special special. (Like Christmas time on NBC back in the 80s before Punky Brewster got a Glomer.)

You need reservations and the crowd is a little pretentious, but the din and clatter are pretty fun all in all. I think you could impress people by taking them here, if that's the kind of thing you get into.
author: Tyler S.

description:
After missing out on several dinners at Town Hall, I finally ate hear 2 weekends ago. It fulfilled all of my expectations but maybe its just because of what I ordered. Not everyone at the table seemed entirely impressed. Dishes that I ate or tasted that I thought were absolutely delish: 

-ahi tuna tartare with fried tomatoes
-stuffed pork chop over a bed of greens and spicy rice
-sticky toffee cake
-cheese cake 

I would go back again just for the pork chop. It was that good.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Faith's warm ham and cheese toast with poached egg and jalapeno cream was fantastic. Who doesn't love runny egg yolk on buttery bread with ham and cheese??! The jalapeno corn bread was very charming as it was presented in the hot corn-on-the-cob shaped iron mold it was baked in. For the entree I had the short ribs with grits and english peas. The meat was very tender and fatty. The grits were anson mills and were creamy. My only complaint was that I wish I could get seconds of the grits. Hmph. For dessert I had the butterscotch chocolate pot de creme. It tasted like a fancy rich pudding. My fiance got the vanilla malt (vanilla and chocolate ice cream with malted milk??) which wasn't sweet but was very refreshing and creamy. It was perfect with their homemade peanut butter cookies.  

The space itself is a little strange. Their bathrooms are on the second floor by the private dining area. There is a nursery school of some sort in the building, too. It's a very narrow space with all the chairs and tables they have packed in there. This place is not for people who walk slow! The servers deserve extra tips for quickly maneuvering their way through a teeny tiny narrow walkway. 

And yes, it really is very loud inside.
author: Tin-Tin E.

description:
Every couple of months the fiance and I put enough scratch together to enjoy someplace on the upper crust of society side of dining. T. asked me to make reservations for a Sunday night foodie adventure so I tried to think of someplace that would seem memorable. I actually went through the list of restaurants reviewed on "Check Please Bay Area" and when I saw Town Halls name it immediately came to mind as a place to try. I made reservations and the fix was in!!!

So we arrived at 530 for our 545 reservations and had to wait maybe 5 minutes before being seated. I had seen the menu on line and was pretty sure what I was going to order. It's American style food which could mean almost anything. I had a Niman Ranch Ribeye steak which was seasoned and cooked perfectly. We tried a unique appy that had a poached egg on ham on toast. Kind of reminiscent of a croque monsieur but definitely Americanized. The service was not overbearing but attentive checking in on us every so often.

A great occasion place for me. 

What else can I say but that it was money well spent on a great experience. 

Ohhh where shall we go next!!!!!!!
author: Johnny J.

description:
Did you know that Taylor Caldwell was a woman?  Well, if you did, you know more about literature than I do.  Perhaps, you're more cultured, more intelligent and even a better person that I.  Give yourself a gold star.

Yan G. has lost it, you might say.  Well, not really.  Please keep reading . . .

I took my friend to Town Hall for lunch to celebrate his passing the California Bar Exam (insert your favorite lawyer joke here).  We parked at the meter right in front of the entrance and walked in.  It was 11:30 am, so the place was pretty empty.  It filled up quickly, though; people just kept piling in.

The decor is beautiful in its simplicity: exposed brick, white wood siding, wooden tables and chairs, metal lighting fixtures.  It had that "I bought a house on Cape Cod, remodeled it and moved it to SOMA" feel.  The two styles were a bit eclectic for my taste, but it seemed to work for Town Hall.  I loved the water glasses and water pitcher they gave us: simple clear glasses with a gilded edge and a pitcher with a similar gilded pattern.  They made me think of my parents' dinner table from the days of yore.  Nostalgia at its best.  

Alas, the food itself was neither eclectic nor original.  I had a butter lettuce salad with candied walnuts, radishes, bleu cheese and Fuji apples.  The dressing was bland, although there was a lot of it.  My friend had the tuna tartare . . .  I think my salad was a better value for the money.  The tuna was good, but . . . I'd compare it to sashimi from Todai, not tuna tartare from Aqua.  Trust me on that.

For my main course, I went with a Town Hall cheesesteak with french fries.  Tender, thinly sliced steak was topped with bell peppers and sauteed onions and drenched in white cheese.  All this cheesy, meaty goodness was served on a nice roll with a side of french fries.  The cheesesteak was delicious, but the french fries were not my cup of tea.  They were too crispy and too salty.  My friend had a pork chop, which was obviously overcooked.  I tried a piece, and it was not as tender as I would have expected.  The pork chop was served on the bed of spicy organic grits.  They were OK, but almost too spicy for that bland pork chop.

Our waiter seemed somewhat disinterested in helping us, although the service wasn't bad.  They refilled my iced tea and my friend's Arnold Palmer promptly, but our request for more bread seemed to annoy them.  Interesting note: to refill my friend's Arnold Palmer, the waiter brought two pitchers--one with iced tea and one with lemonade--and poured them in a glass at the table.  I mean, I understand how the drink is made, but you don't see that every day.

They brought our check in . . . an old book.  It was an old, dog-eared hardcover edition of  "Let Love Come Last" by Taylor Caldwell.  What a cute, fun idea, to bring a check in an old book.  Almost made me feel like I didn't just spend $80 on lunch!  Apparently, the previous customers signed the first few pages of the book, much like one would sign a guestbook at a wedding.  

I, too, am guilty of scribbling my note on page 3.  Let me know if you find it!
author: Yan G.

description:
A recently culinary tour of San Francisco with a couple girlfriends found us dining at Town Hall for a Wednesday night dinner. One of our party had been here before, not long after its 2003 opening, and had remembered it as being something special.

We began the evening with the standard basket of bread (nice and crusty)  while we shared a bottle of 2007 Copain 'Tous Ensemble' Viognier. 

Then our appetizer appeared: crispy squash blossoms, four cheese filling, basil pesto and tomato vinaigrette. It was perfectly crispy and the cheese nice and gooey. It was a beautiful medley of tastes and textures! 

Soon after, we received our soup and salad. The soup of the day was a delectable vichyssoise (a cold, creamy, potato-leek soup) that was topped with a light sprinkling of chopped chives. The texture was silky smooth and the soup itself was exquisitely seasoned. The salad we chose to share was the Chopped Vegetable Salad with English peas, artichokes, Brentwood corn, parmesan and sherry vinaigrette. Again, this dish was perfectly seasoned and the vegetables provided just the right amount of crunch.

When it came time for the entrees, we ordered the halibut, short ribs and gnocchi. The Roasted Alaskan Halibut was served over a serving of corn pudding along with porcini mushrooms, fava beans and bay shrimp salsa verde. The flavors were wonderful and the sear on the halibut was a beautiful caramel color with the slightest hint of a crunch. The Creekstone Beef Short Ribs were served with an array of potato gnocchi, artichokes, carrots, spring garlic and red wine jus. It was very flavorful and tender - just as short ribs should be! Finally, the House-made Potato Gnocchi. It was mixed with Brentwood corn, morels, English peas and shaved Umbria truffles. The marbled appearance of the truffles was beautiful and the flavor of the dish was rich without being overpowering (in other words, no heavy sauce).

Now, although we all had enjoyed our dinner immensely up until this point, the creme de la creme really came at dessert time. Although several dishes caught our eye, one in particular seemed to call to us: the Sticky Toffee Cake. The cake was presented before us and our eyes about popped out of their sockets. It was a beautiful, spongy caramel colored cake swimming in a sea of thick, delicious caramel, topped with a scoop of vanilla ice cream and a sprinkling of chopped nuts. It was completely decadent and it was the one thing we found ourselves talking about for the rest of the evening and the next day!

I would highly recommend this restaurant to others, my only gripes being that it was a pretty noisy room and although our server was quite knowledgeable, after taking our orders, we didn't see much of him...
author: Nicole D.

description: This place is always SO good!  Nice ambiance for a date, catch-up with friends, dinner with the family...the decor reminds me of Prospect in that there is low lighting, dark wood, modern/classic decor, but Town Hall is not as pretentious as Prospect and the food is much better :)  The menu changes based on the season, but it always consists of a creative mix of seafood and meat (with a Southern/comfort food twist).  Last night I had the Tuna tartare, cornmeal fried green tomatoes, garlic chips, Tabasco green onion vinaigrette ($15), Piquillo peppers, blue crab-Bienville stuffing, vermouth lobster cream ($15), and BBQ shrimp, Worcestershire sauce, garlic herb toast ($15) for appetizers.  Every bite was delicious with such a interesting mix of flavors.  Town Hall definitely takes normal food and puts a new spin on them.  For entrees I had the monk catfish and the Alaskan Halibut.  Both were about $25 I think and both cooked to perfection.  The catfish was actually the better of the two IMO - it was in some delicious sauce that reminded me of  gumbo and also was accompanied by mussels.  For dessert we had a Rhubarb pastry dish that is not listed on the menu so I couldn't even tell you the details of it, but it devine.  I will definitely be returning :)
author: Naomi P.

description:
4 Stars = Yay! I'm a Fan.

Yup - I am indeed a fan.  I went for a business lunch last week and was blown away at the quality of the food, in many respects.  I believe Iron Chef judges cuisines by 3 factors (assuming the food quality itself is of the highest standard already, which it is at Town Hall):

1) Taste
2) Plating
3) Originality

This place scores high in all 3 categories.


I'm a tuna fan and when I saw the tuna tartar on the starters menu I knew this would be the quick acid  test of whether or not this place could hold it's own.  Two words: it did.  The tuna was fresh and tender, and the fried green tomatoes were actually crispy without being either mushy or too salty - just perfect!  The fried green tomatoes matched perfectly with the spiciness of the Tabasco vinaigrette and tuna.  Bravo!

The bbq shrimp gumbo with bacon grits did not let me down either, as I ended up scraping the bowl like the walls of a non-vacant forgotten prison on a desert island. 

Needless to say I returned 2 days later, unable to escape the lure of the tuna tartar, I succumbed once again.   I rescued my own originality by trying the day boat sea scallops and soon thereafter lost my ability to speak coherently.  

Well done Town Hall, I'll definitely be back.

...only downside - the service can be spotty.
author: S M.

description: Gosh I just love this place!  Their menu selection is always amazing and their portions are of good size. Great place for double dates or romantic night out.
author: A J.

description:
Preface: I realized that I wrote this review about a Dine About Town lunch I had here. My wife ordered a la carte. I have subsequently read scathing reviews for other places, Rubicon, for one, solely based on D.A.T. To criticize a place, to thoroughly take it apart, I believe, unless something truly unusual happens, you must pay the full price of admission. I do not expect the kitchen "A" list ingredients for DAT and what sane individual would. I do expect good preparations, but with less expensive products. For goodness sake's, my three course lunch here was $19.99, give or take $.04. To remedy this oversight, I am amending my original four star rating to five stars.

Original review: You know the food was great. I was so looking forward to this lunch, but I left feeling like I had lunch alone, because it was just loud enough to be very intrusive. The service was good and the dishes tasty. In the end I rounded them up to four stars, because it was my first visit.
author: Alex C.

description:
Had an excellent lunch at Town Hall today.  Ordered the Tuna tartar with fried green tomatoes as a starter and had the duck confit with white beans.  Shared a bottle of a sauvignon blanc wine from South Africa (fleur du cap), which was equally excellent.

The tomatoes were very flavorful and firm.  The duck was cook perfect.  The environment was very enjoyable as well.  Subtle decor touches give this place a nice warm yet modern feel.

Service was friendly and helpful, but a tad on the slow side. Looking forward to my next meal here.
author: shaun l.

description:
This place was just ok for me..  It was good, but not knock your socks off great..  To be honest, I can't even recall what we had.. so needless to say it was not so memorable..  
We heard the same from fellow foodie friends and will more than likely not go back there..
author: Rose C R.

description:
The experience in Town Hall is anti-climatic.

The appetizers are pretty darned good. The asparagus-puree soup was surprisingly delicious... despite the fact that I am anti-veggie. Tuna tartar was fresh and above average. Unfortunately the main course is a big disappointment. I ordered my steak medium-rare and it came out medium-well (I can swear to God that it's not because of my bad accent). My friend ordered the pork chop and it's certainly not seasoned uniformly. Town Hall even managed to screw up the fish dish. The service is a total mess. Our server never showed up to check how we are doing.

In a nutshell, this place is over rated. Not worth spending $ unless you want to taste good soup.
author: Fred F.

description:
WOW .. Barbecued shirmp, worcestershire and parsely garlic sauce Appetizer is mouth watering and one of the best things I have EVER tasted!

UN-B-e-l-i-e-v-e-a-b-l-y tasty every last bite, and the sauce,...ooohhh...ahhhh....the sauce is killer! The secret is all in that sauce baby! It really is that amazing!

Also, one of the waiters is sooo..cute, he offered to escort me to the ladies rooms as he held his masculine arm out for me to hold and cling to. Now, that is Service..with a capital "S"!!
author: Kristina A.

description:
I frickin love this place.  I have loved every single dish I've ever had, but here are my favorites: 

- Tuna tartare w/ fried green tomatos - the BEST tartare ever
- Seafood etouffee - complex, spicy sauce
- toffee sticky cake - need I say more?? 

Also, there is something about just their plain bread and butter that is above and beyond other restaurants too... or maybe I'm nuts.  Bottom line, great place for a special occasion dinner or a "business" lunch (business may or may not be discussed, but at least it's on the company dime)... and it's a block away from my office, so 5 stars for proximity, and the fact that I've never had to make reservations for lunch - they've always fit us in (sometimes at the big communal table at the front - but I don't mind that, and actually kinda dig it).... just go and try for yourself - eat, drink and be merry!
author: A B.

description:
The food was great, the service alternated from amazing (really great waiter who was super helpful in selecting our wine) to negligent (i swear she went on break when we were ready to order dessert). Regardless, go for the food and the atmosphere. We had reservations for two but two became four  (boys - they always want to tag-along!) but they seated us promptly without blinking. The food was great - I had a tuna tartare app + the trout. The trout was tasty, but needed lemon (which i asked for and they delivered). others got the short ribs (yum) oysters (they loved them) and the rib-eye steak (also loved). We ordered wine -- it was awesome, great selection by our chief wino. 

The best was the desert -- which my cousin had been raving about: Sticky Date pudding. It was just that sticky + date + pudding. Defn worth it. 

Net-net: fun night out due to great company in a wonderful location with delicious food.
author: Natala M.

description: Great food, ambience, bar, and location in SOMA. My course of action starts with a Firestone Pale 31 at the bar. Then it's off to the table to order the warm jalapeno bread. The oysters are also really good. For the entree, I recommend the Idaho trout or the fried chicken. Both rule. And for the best part, I highly advise ordering the butterscotch pie for dessert. Mouth orgasm. Get a port to cap things off.
author: Rick W.

description:
Good but not great--and pricey for the quality. Everything was fine or okay, but nothing really knocked our socks off. Seems like it would be more impressive at lunchtime.
