We had dinner w/friends and I felt most of the dishes lacked a bit of flavor. We had four appetizers and split two entrees between four people + dessert, cocktails/wine/beer. The bill came to just under $400, which seemed pricey, given nothing was really outstanding.
author: Gym W.

description:
Let me start with this, and get it out of the way: I had the butterscotch pot de creme.  It was good - didn't blow me away, and I'm a dessert person, but certainly a solid rendition.  Definitely portioned to share.

If I were rating on food alone, I might be tempted to give 3 stars.  I started with a very nice butter lettuce salad (not liking blue cheese, I opted for a vinaigrette, which was excellent).  For my main, I had the duck.  Good, tasty, with some sort of pecan rice and some overly-heavy and too salty sauce on the side.  But again, not anything terribly memorable.  My dining companions rated their Arctic char excellent, while the petite decapitated quail wrapped, Michelin man-like, in bacon strips around his (her?) waist was pronounced "good."   Same with the cheese fondue.  The wine?  Fine.  So it's all pretty good, but doesn't quite live up to the hype.

What I really liked about this place was the atmosphere- hence the extra star.  The service was warm, professional, and friendly.  The dining room and bar area were busy and lively without being loud and obnoxious.  And waiting near the bar for our drinks, there was a really friendly vibe - lots of smiles, chatting with strangers.  It was a very convivial place, and kind of homey (of course, I come from Boston, so the familiar New England-style decor had something to do with the comfy vibe as well.)

So I would, definitely, go back, and maybe try a different main course.  The crowd, the service, the vibe, all contribute to a really nice night out.
author: Liz O.

description:
Lunch- 4stars
Dude, the burgers here are worth every penny!  It's clean tasting and i swear it was some top sirloin that they just grounded up.  I also tried the tri tip sandwich that was also on point, although slightly bloody for us Primitive Carnivores!
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Dinner- 3stars
1st off I didn't get to try the Butterscotch\Chocolate pot de creme.  I gave up chocolate for lent.  The food was innovative, but it didn't translate to great taste.  We had the Arctic char and the fried chicken dish, both dishes weren't like damn can I get another.  The appetizers were a little better except for the rabbit enchiladas.  Those enchiladas were really sour tasting.  The Toffee sticky cake was good and it was the highlight of my meal.  Great atmosphere and service just not the food or the 2nd floor bathrooms!
author: Jason A.

description:
This is what I think about when I think of Soma restaurant -- old yet refurbished.  I truly enjoyed my finely executed meal and considering the large crowd I was with that there were no time lags and the meal came out quite timely.  There was no food or wine headliners but i will go back again and see what i might discover.

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
I went to a training class yesterday and was stuck with a bunch of people that I didn't know (well most of them). It was a full day of training but included dinner. Dinner last night was more of an obligation than a treat but there really wasn't a choice on my part. A good thing I did -- we went to Town Hall.

I was able to have a good time in spite of the "work" situation --- I blame it on the scene/ambiance (and a few stiff drinks. Thanks Bartender!)

Drinks were good and strong; Food was fab  (well those that I've tried) and Service was excellent. I especially loved the veal meatballs (starter) and the Thai snapper. Both very yummy! I wasn't impressed, however, with the pot de creme that came highly recommended. I guess I'm not that into butterscotch. It reminded me of butterscotch jello pudding. Bleh!

I also didn't like that the restrooms were 2 flights up. But at least it was nice and clean.

In summary, Town Hall deserved 4 stars because:
1) one of the guys scored a date from a lawyer (and he's a geeky software guy!)
2) we were able to talk the hostess into allowing us to have dinner in the bar area where there was a big table that can fit 10 comfortably
3) one of the guys was able to persuade those last stubborn bar folks to vacate the table (see above) so that our whole group could  be seated together

I would definitely go back but it would have to be on the company's dime!
author: Vanessa J.

description:
I'm giving Town Hall four stars; however, I'm considering moving it up to five upon my next visit.   Because we ran 21 miles (Read: Training for Marathon) the day we visited, I'm not sure if dinner was really as good as I recall or if I was just starved:-)

My partner and our two friends had a wonderful dinner.  The appetizers (especially the oysters) were great!  The salads were equally tantalizing.  For dinner, I had the rib eye.  Our friend, Don, had the fried chicken.  Both dishes were fantastic!  Although pants-popping full, we still ordered dessert.  The dessert on its own might be worth a five star rating.  Definitely have the butterscotch dessert on your visit (I'm not a butterscotch fan, but absolutely loved this dish).  

My only compliant is with the bar staff.  Please take this feedback lightly as we came in right as Town Hall was opening, but the bar staff seemed very bothered by the fact we had to think about our drink choice.  Still, once we ordered, the drinks were prepared promptly and were very tasty.  I'm hoping we just caught the staff at a bad moment.

I promise to reevaluate my rating on my next visit.  I don't plan on running 21 miles before dinner!!!
author: Shawn S.

description:
Town Hall is located at the corner of Fremont & Howard Street in an old brick building.  It was packed for lunch, lucky for us we had a reservations for eight.  

The team ordered Rib-eye steak, Salmon Panini, Town Burger, and Fish & Chips.  Everything was delicious!  Service was good - the busboys kept us hydrated with plenty of water and ice tea.  The waitress was new and forgot to bring us bread.  I've heard that their fried chicken is out of this world - I'm gonna call ahead to try it next time.
author: Rich W.

description: Had the BBQ pulled chicken sandwich (no bun) sub sweet potato fries for the chips. Also had a spritzer drink (can't remember the name). Food was good; food was slow coming out of the kitchen-  waitress told us that lunch would take a while since we didn't order an appetizer (??).
author: jamie j.

description: I love this place. The food is inventive and absolutely phenomenal. Don't be scared to ask the staff to choose a good wine to pair with your meal, it could improve the food and the wine (like it needs it). Food to try:egg sandwhich appetizer, oysters, all the meals are great, but you need to try the coffee and housemade doughnutsThe restaurant is a bit loud but its worth it.
author: Braun S.

description:
With so many hyped of reviews on yelp, I expected a lot more.  A solid dinner meal but I had set my hopes exceedingly high.  

Ambiance: The dining room is warm, woodsy, very high ceilings.  A bit too big/open for my taste. I prefer more intimate/cozy (lower ceilings).  Dark wood interior.  Reminded me of a done up mess hall from a private school back east, or something from Dead Poet's Society.

The peeps: dressed in all sorts of attire, from t-s/jeans/sneakers (SF cool, not big ol' white tennies) to men w/jackets and one lady w/a sparkly dress (she was overdressed).

The food: fried oyster appetizer was pretty good.  We split the rainbow trout and the scallops-- both were ok.  Not the best I've had in SF.  The best part was the dessert-- I know everyone raves about their pot de creme, but I like flour in my dessert.  So, we got the sticky toffee break pudding (or was it cake) something or other and man it was delicious.  Drowned in a sweet caramel/sticky sauce, the dessert was HUGE.  The best part of the meal.
author: Caroline I.

description: This place is awesome! It's all about Southern Food here. Rich, Filling, and delicious. We had the Stuffed Crab Peppers, and Garlic Shrimp to start. Very good - but very rich. We finished with the Donuts & Coffee desert and the Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot De Creme - which was out of this world. Portions were a good size. Service was helpful. Loved it!
author: J W.

description:
Great on the taste buds, yet hard on the ears...

Lots of nice touches from tables to old books holding the checks to pay for your food. Great eats, especially the filet. Some of the best in the city. Desserts are something to write home about as well. Town Hal suffers from the same issues found at Perbacco. Sound bounces off all the hard surfaces, making it hard to hear conversations with someone sitting next to you. This is the one point keeping me from giving this place the extra star. Every time I go here I feel the need for a hearing aid or possibly group lessons in sign language. 

Food is great, pass the ear plugs please...
author: Steve S.

description:
A total bummer.  I put this same review on open table, but it was yelp that got me excited about trying it, so here's my take:
I was really excited to try Town Hall.  The menu looked great, filled with classic American high calorie goodness, which I love.  Unfortunately, the food was below marginal.  Everything was insanely salty.  Fried chicken batter was light and flaky, but meat itself was fatty and chewy.  Jambalaya was an inedible mass of salt, meatballs were not much better.  Drinks were good (god knows you needed them), decor was right for the type of food on the menu.  But obviously none of that matters when the food is on par with Popeye's.  It made me wish there were a Roscoes nearby!
author: RP C.

description:
Town Hall is a great restaurant, one of my favorites in fact. The space is great, especially if you like exposed brick and high ceilings. The wine selection is adequate and the bartenders are great, if you can get their attention.

Insider Tips
-Skip making a reservation and sit at the big community table. Reservations are tough to come by and eating at the community table is a great experience.
-Have the ribeye or the duck as those are the two best entrees.

My one complaint is that the service can be a bit spotty at times.
author: Charles H.

description:
I'd probably give this place four stars, but I've been giving out too many of those lately.  

The food here was pretty solid, but a bit on the heavy side.  There was excess everywhere: too much lime in the ceviche, too much sauce around the fish, too much corn piled around the pork chop, way too much cream in the desert pudding (it wasn't called a pudding but it did come across as a classed-up jell-o)... Still, it was all tasty enough, and large enough that you certainly won't go hungry.
author: Steve O.

description:
Like Natalie E., I've been here a couple of time for work lunches and actually enjoyed the pork loin for my lunch today. 

The restaurant is nicely decorated, wood paneling, antiques, and black and white turn-of-the-century photos create a cozy, old southern feel, with big brass light fixtures and one long, high table at the entrance. Nothing too cluttered and it almost feels homey. Reminds me of a higher end Black Eyed Pea, if anyone's been to one of those. 

It's bustling at lunch but not overly crowded or deafeningly loud. The fish and chips have a great reputation but ultimately are about average. I LOVE their butter lettuce salad. It seems every rest-o these days has ahi tuna on the menu to start - this place is no exception- however, it's probably the smallest portion I've seen yet, complete with 3 small slices of fried green tomatoes. 

They menu primarily consists of upscale hearty, comfort food, but lacks the $16 dish of mac & cheese most restaurants along these lines are doing these days. Menu options are varied and move beyond run-of-the-mill. 

The service is decent but don't expect to dine here on a severe time crunch. The desserts are good, I highly recommend the apple crumble and butterscotch and chocolate pots de creme. 

As mentioned below, the bill is presented in an old book, which lends a nice touch of warmth and elegance to the experience.
author: Angela N.

description:
I was excited to try this place because I'd heard good things about it. Unfortunately, I found this restaurant did not live up to the hype. For the price you pay, I would expect a more memorable dining experience. When I really like a restaurant, I remember the dishes I had long after I've eaten there.  I don't recall what I ate, only that it tasted fine. 

On the upside, the service was good and I liked the decor: exposed brick, rustic-looking wood tables, a nice bar.
author: Jenny K.

description:
I went here weeks ago, and was so underwhelmed I couldn't even be bothered to rush to write a review.

Where to begin? Ok so I work at Howard and Spear and I walk past this place often and I think "wow this place looks so cool!" It reminds me of restaurants back east, in Boston or Providence. My bf and I took and out of town guest there for dinner thinking it would be a cool place to show off.

So we made reservations and arrived and were seated fairly promptly. I love the scene in the place, the energy is good. The bar looks great. In fact I would love to come here just to sit at the bar and maybe have like one snack. 

We were seated at a table with benches I believe. Wierd. I often ask the waitstaff for recommendations, or I do this "I am between this, that, and this fish thing, which is best?" and I often get steered in the right directions. Here, the waitstaff are busboys. They had no recommendations. They served us efficiently, which is good, but they didn't know much about the food. Hmm.

Friend ordered the fried chicken, which was really good. BF ordered the hangar steak, which was ok. I had the crawfish etouffe. SNOORRRR. It tasted like it came out of a box.

I feel like this place is a relic of a time when Emeril Lagasse just got big and people thought a little cayenne in something made it crazy. It was just bland and uninventive here. I wouldn't recommend this, with so many other places in the city, unless you were going to that bar area.

I recommend going to Salt House, it's sister restaurant.
author: Andrea S.

description:
The food was pretty good at Town Hall.  We has the tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes which was really yummy - the tomatoes were quite delicious.  Crab and artichoke dip was good, but nothing special.  I had the fried chicken which was good, but most fried chicken is.  Butterscotch Chocolate Pot de creme was yummy.  

The service, however, was questionable.  Maybe it was just our waiter, who combed his bangs back into a curvy spike that made him look like a Manga character.  My mother ordered a glass of wine when we arrived, and we made it through the bread, appetizers, and then the main dishes came - no wine.  I had to remind him to go get it.  Okay, one slip up isn't the end of the world.  But then our dessert took like 20 minutes to arrive.  Damn.  I mean, come on.  At least the comped the dessert.
author: Sara M.

description:
Finally, I can check off Town Hall as a place to try.  I went over there to catch up with a friend over lunch yesterday and thought the food was great!  I had the grilled salmon with some southern corn concoction, which I couldn't stop gobbling up.  My only major complaint is the lack of noise control.  Since Town Hall was retrofitted from an old warehouse of some sort, it's just one huge room inside.  Due the lack of sound barrier and close seating, it was hard to conversate with my friend without yelling and hearing your neighbor's conversation at the same time.  

Definitely check it out although don't go there if you want to have a business lunch/dinner.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
Love the decor of this place. They have some the most interesting and unusual lighting fixtures in the bar area.

I believe I had the duck which was ok, not bad. I'm actually having trouble remember specific points of the dish which means it wasn't a memorable meal. My friend had the porkchop and that was really good. Wish I had ordered that instead of the duck.
author: Christine D.

description:
Been here a few times in the past week and everything has been great.  The atmosphere was very warm and comfortable. Service was attentive and very friendly.  And the food was hot, timely and delicious!

One recommendation is be sure to have a reservation.   If not, then you have the option to sit at the community table which is great or you can wait for a table.

Can't wait for summertime as they usually have a great happy hour set up outside.
author: Aaron F.

description:
I've been to lunch here twice. This is my favorite lunch spot, someday I'll come eat dinner here but until then I just get to wow my lunch dates. I always get the fried green tomatoes and tuna tartare for an appetizer, last time I got the fried chicken for a main meal and it was pretty heavenly. This comes from a guy who grew up in Georgia -- it's pretty good fried chicken.

My judgement: If dinner is as good as lunch, I am going to be very poor soon.
author: Darren M.

description:
I don't have all day...
I came here for lunch with a few coworkers and we waited over 40 minutes for our food. I mean, really, does it take that long to make a sandwich? 
The brie sandwich was good, but nothing amazing. 
We didn't have time to even think about dessert, by the time we quickly shoved the food down our throats to get back to work, we wondered whether we'd make it back to our meetings in time.
The annoying thing about all of this is that the ENTIRE restaurant seemed to have sat, eaten and left- and we still hadn't gotten our food.
We were engulfed in conversation, ignoring the grumbling in our tummies, and as I reached for my wallet to leave, the waitress came by mumbling an apology. 
I have never been that close to walking out. It's really not worth that kind of wait.
author: Cindy D.

description:
Wasn't convinced the first time around, but I recall the ham and cheese toast w/ poached egg and jalapeno cream was delicious. The only other memorable thing from that dining experience was that it was LOUD - the dinner party next to us exacerbated the loudness, but it would have still been LOUD w/out them.

Our second, more recent visit failed to convince me again. Again, the starter we ordered was delicious - some cheesy, crabby fondue thing - but everything that followed was just okay. B got the ribeye and I got the fried chicken. Table service was lacking - it felt like it took ages for our entrees to come out, and then they proceeded to be served to the table next to us. Sigh. The server kept pushing a bottle of wine, but come on...I was already red-faced from the three cocktails earlier at 111, and the Dorothy Parker (fantastic, by the way) that I was nursing. Do ya really think we're ready for a bottle of wine? That being said, the hostess was wonderful, the buzz is buzzy, and I'd probably go back again...3.5 stars.
author: Lisa C.

description:
This is a great place for good old fashioned american food, with an elegant/ fine dining spin on it. They keep things simple, but not too elegant or elaborate, just the way I like it. 

Portions are pretty good considered to a lot of places, I was stuffed after one entree and one appetizer. This being said I weigh about 240 pounds so I like my food, and a lot of it. Especially the dessert, it was almost too much, but since when is a lot of sweets too much. I suggest four people to have a maximum of 2. Maybe even one since dinner is so big also. 

Service is good, atmosphere is great as well.
author: Steven C.

description:
Everyone seems to LOVVEE this place. However, I don't think it has lived up to its hype (oops, did I say that?). The food is good, nothing crazzzy good. I've had the burger, which is a decently good gourmet burger, I like the bread that they use.
The cornbread comes in cute little platters, the consistency is pretty good. 

Cons: It gets busy really quickly and can be hard to get a seat. They do have a community table, but it gets really noisy, so be prepared.
author: cat k.

description:
Town Hall Haiku 2

Expected much better.  
Food is overpriced and bland.
Come later, eat bread pudding!
author: Emily G.

description:
Town Hall gets a resounding "meh."  I was so excited about it, too, and I looked forward to my reservation for months.  When the time came, though, the bar was just overpriced (although they had some interesting cocktails), the food was equally overpriced, and it just wasn't that great.  The space was cramped, and the service was decent but not outstanding.  And those supposedly legendary short ribs?  Not so legendary after all.

I say if you're looking for something foodie but still solid, go down the street to Two instead.  It'll be cheaper and better.
author: Marco C.

description:
This place was great!

... if you really had something to talk about the wait for each dish was long, dinner took about a little less than 3 hrs. 

ANYWAY-We had a fondue appetizer.... and some some awesome main courses, I remember... I had a porkchop with some sort of squash chutney that was absolutely delicious... my friend had steak, and trout and wow, I just have to say, their food is amazing. Nothing like good hearty food in chilly sf weather. 

although it sucks to have the bathroom up like 3 flights of stairs, not to mention if youre sitting all the way in the restaurant you have to walk al the  way to the entrance and then around a table into a stairwell ... and yeah, BUT good food+ awesome friends =good times
author: Babs S.

description: Food is reliable, but not inspiring.  Prices for lunch and dinner are typical for San Francisco, ~$20 for entrees, ~$10 for appetizers.
author: Juan R.

description:
This place is amazing!

Order the Pot de Creme! Soooo yummy. Everytime I eat there I order it.

The fried oysters are delicious! I seem to always order the pork chop or fried chicken. Both of which are mouth watering. 

Everyone at the table raved about their food! Fun restaurant with 5 star food!
author: Alex M.

description:
Crowd:  very much an after-work business crowd.  Seems like all the financial district folks come here for dinner. 

Great place to take a small group.

Food:  I had the buttermilk biscuits as well as the pork chop.  Although the biscuits were to die for, the pork chop was decent.  It was slightly on the salty side but it was still good.  I tried a little bit of my friends dishes (swordfish, fried chicken) and they were all up to par as expected.  A very solid american food restaurant.
Service:  decent service but nothing exceptional.  Really liked the old books that they used as the receipt holders.  Nice touch.
author: Paul C.

description: Loved it,  but not everyone in my party was as impressed as I was.  I highly recommend the fried chicken, it was the best I've ever tasted...crunchy and savory on the outside, moist and tender on the inside. The mashed potatoes and squash accompaniments were also excellent.  The ribs were very flavorful, a little smoky.  Our waiter was somewhat aloof...not attentive enough...so that detracted from the experience.  I'll definitely go back, but it is very noisy, so don't go here if you're looking for a quiet romantic dinner.
author: Kevin O.

description: I've been here twice now and both times sat at the bar for lunch and both times I was very pleased. I've been particularly happy with their vegetable sides, whether it's the broccoli raab or the side salads. Also, the butterschotch pot de creme is divinely rich and delicious. Do NOT try to eat that thing alone, it's huge!
author: Kristen L.

description:
My work hosted a National Sales Meeting this week and the dinner and awards banquet was at Town Hall. So glad it was because it was free for me! But it definitely is going to bring me here again when the wallet is big enough...

The downstairs bar and dining area is lowly dimmed and it does have an old town/main street feel to it. We went downstairs for a drink before the dinner actually started and had some wine. My boss paid for the round and they served the bill inside an old book. Ha.. 

So upstairs it was nicely set up with 10 per table with candles in the center and the menu of our menu options. I got the Butter Lettuce Salad and the Short Ribs. A glass of wine was served with our meal and it was so delicious. The butter lettuce salad was HUGE and could have been a meal in and of itself. The dressing was not too creamy and there was a good enough amount of bleu cheese crumbles and toasted walnuts that made the salad very satisfying. The Short Ribs was perfect - nice flavor and served with pureed carrots, baby carrots and mushrooms. It was 2 large pieces of meat. Some of my coworkers had slabs that were really fatty, but I found that I didn't have any fat in mine so I couldn't complain. 

Dessert was ehh... it was a chocolate tart but was essentially a Brownie baked in a chocolate/oreo crust. I liked the crust better than the acutal cake/brownie and also liked the miniscule scoop of vanilla ice cream and the little choco cookie on the bottom.

Overall, great food. I looked at the menu online, and the price is a bit steep (20-30 a plate) but I definitely would love to come back here and experience again.
author: Alyson C.

description: OpenTable agreed and awarded me 500 points. Perhaps Town Hall will review it's policies vis-a-vis kitchen hours.
author: Gary C.

description:
So I think I have now visited all of this owner's restaurants:

Anchor & Hope (damn, forgot to write up on this one)
Salt House
Town Hall

Few things to note:  
-the floors are kind of uneven at one part of the restaurant - walk carefully.
-bathroom is alllll the way upstairs
-it gets really crowded and really loud, even on a Tuesday evening

I think out of the three restaurants above, I'd have to say this is not my favorite.  Good, but not first out of the three.  You should order the mac and cheese croquette, as that is the most fabulous thing ever.  If you hate brussel sprouts, you'll be a little delighted with these (they're not that bad).  There's a bit too much salt in some of the dishes (scallops, sole).  The cornbread is served interestingly: small, thin pieces in the pan.  

Dessert: the butterscotch pudding is a must, the hot chocolate was wayyy too rich.  

And the check?  Appropriately placed in a 1950s book about exercises and looking good (how to make your buttocks look good was the bookmarked chapter).
author: Yosie G.

description:
My wife and I met a couple of friends for dinner at the Town Hall a few weeks ago.
My wife had researched restaurants in San Francisco to try to find something a little different and finally chose Town Hall.
What a good choice it turned out to be. 
The interior is nice with an incredible set of chandeliers and a nice decor.
The service was very good-very attentive without being pretentious.

The food is a stand-out. A fusion of seafood and hot spices with a cajun twist, make a delightful, zesty, and fun fare.

They also boast an exceptional wine list.

And don't skip dessert-you won't regret it. 

The prices are indeed a bit pricey, but considering the quality of food, the good service and great atmosphere with a cajun fine cuisine twist, it's definitely worth it.

So if you want some fine dining with a bit spicey, yet fine cuisine, the Town Hall is a good choice.

Can't wait to go back!

Greg
author: Gregory S.

description:
We had a terrific meal and positive overall experience at Town Hall. 

We arrived early on a Sunday evening and parked on the street just a few feet from the front door. Ordered up a couple of special whiskey cocktails (Sazerac and Driver 8). Both were strong and beautifully prepared. I would expect nothing less for $9 each!

Next up were the Roasted Veal Meatballs and the Warm Ham & Cheese Toast. The meatballs were very flavorful and served on a bed of mashed potato puree and an intense peppercorn sauce.  The Ham & Cheese Toast was simply fantastic. It was an unusual combination of flavors (spicy jalapeno and savory ham) and textures (soft poached egg, silky hollandaise with crunchy bread and ham). 

We chose to split the Etouffee Shrimp and rice for the main course. It comes with cornmeal fried oysters in a pool of salty, spicy Cajun sauce. The flavors were rich and strong, but I found the sauce was a little salty for my taste. 

For dessert, we chose to share the Butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Creme. A great dessert choice and mix of rich smooth textures. The chocolate was dark (not too sweet) with a thin tasty layer of butterscotch creme on top.

Overall, I thought the food was outstanding, and the service friendly and professional. While the cost was relatively high ($110 for two), the great cocktails and the unusual flavors and textures of the food made it worthwhile.
author: Pete Z.

description: I really enjoyed eating here.  The oysters were great and the menu had a wide variety of food - everything from fish to BBQ.  The service was great, our waitress was very nice and attentive.  I would eat here again if I was in the area and would recommend it.
author: KC K.

description:
Definitely my favorite out of the Town Hall, Salt House, Anchor and Hope trio.

  Rabbit enchiladas... I'm still thinking about them. They were so good. I'd never had rabbit. It's pretty tasty. Especially in pretend Mexican food form. I approve :) My client and I shared a toad in the hole for an appetizer which was awesome and, now that I think of it, I definitely need to order it again. I heart poached eggs and the toad in the hole is the perfect egg dish. My only complaint is the service. We were in there for over 2 hours because our server was missing for the majority of our meal. Normally I'll take the time to be out of the office, but when you want to leave, you want to leave. An absentee waiter is not happiness during that time. All in all I can't wait to return to Town Hall. I've completed the rounds of  it's sister restaurants and it's time to revisit a favorite.
author: chelsea b.

description: The food, wine and atmosphere were all great. The hanger steak was cooked perfectly...and the coffee ice cream/donut desert was awesome!!!
author: Dan H.

description: The rundown.  Blood Orange Soda, Oysters, The Ribs, Jalapeno Cornbread, Blue Bottle Coffee - Latte, Donuts and Ice Cream.  Yes, yes...tons of food, and I was with a few other folks that helped share it, but I had my fill of everything.  And I was definitely full afterwards, but in a good way. Everything was delicious.  The ribs could have been a bit more tender, but they were still pretty awesome.  Atmosphere was good and the service was great.  Long story short, I will be returning.  I hear I HAVE to try the fried chicken. So that is next up on the list!
author: John R.

description: On sunny days they have an outside to-go lunch stand setup behind on this patio area. Sandwiches from $8-10, sides and drinks are available too. They take ATM outside which is nice. I had the pulled pork sandwich with coleslaw on top. Very good flavor, nice and moist, just the right consistency of juicy pork, slaw and bread. I would recommend eating this asap because the juices will make the bun soggy.
author: Ryan D.

description:
Ooh, I am wishing for the 4.5 star option right now. I had a wonderful experience at Town Hall last night. There were four of us, we had a reservation for 6:45. Three of us arrived at 6:30 (no traffic from the East Bay!) and they seated us early. Service is typical in my experience of Southern cuisine restaurants, slow. But not rudely slow, intentionally slow so as not to rush people through their meal and let them enjoy their company. 

The only small critique I would make about service is that I agree with others that servers should ask if people are done eating before taking their plates. My plate was removed with a little piece of bread on it that I was still eating and a shared side dish was removed with a little bit of food left in it. I don't know if anyone wanted to eat it at that point, but I think a quick, "May I take this away?" is always appreciated.

Besides that, everything was excellent. I had a Louisiana Purchase cocktail that was delicious, sweet, spicy, and refreshing. The tuna tartar with fried green tomatoes was top notch though I could have done with a less creamy sauce drizzled on the tomatoes, they were so delicate that I thought even the small drizzle was overpowering.

I had the only vegetarian option for my main: Grits with truffles and fresh vegetables. I am not a vegetarian and was worried I would be missing out with this dish (but my love of grits pushed me to it). I was blown away. I tasted friends' Fried Chicken and Halibut, both were great. My husband's Seafood Etoufe was not my favorite but he loved it. The beignets and illy espresso ice cream were good but not as great as the rest of the meal.

I would certainly come back to Town Hall, it was a great dining experience!
author: Katrina L.

description: Town Hall was a delicious way to spend an evening. Although their menu changes regularly, we tried these items and each were delectable! Starters: fried okra with aioli; entrees: monkfish stuffed with dungeness crab and trout. Even with all of the restaurants San Francisco has to offer, I recommend you try this one.
author: Becca F.

description: Have had this restaurant on my radar since it opened, I'm not sure why I had never eaten at Town Hall before.  When I called to make the reservation for the party of 6, my personal information was already in their system!?!  Then I remembered I had made a reservation years ago, but had to cancel for some reason.  The service was professional and friendly, the food was good and other than the dining room being VERY loud, it was an okay experience.  I just think there are so many good restaurants in San Francisco, I can't imagine going out of my way to eat at one that is just, okay.  If I were meeting other people that wanted to eat at Town Hall I wouldn't try to suggest eating elsewhere, but I wouldn't go out of my way to have another meal at Town Hall.
author: Ed Y.

description:
Went back to Town Hall last night after going for the first time more than 2 years ago. I was disappointed the first time, and last night was even worse, sadly. 
This place has great potential, with a warm and welcoming space, a nice bar and patio area. The rest just doesnt follow. 
I could have got over the fact that my girlfriend could barely hear what I was saying throughout the meal if the food and/or the service would have been great.
It took more than 45 min for the main course to come after we were done with the starter. The first explanation was that the trout takes 45 min - It doesn't - It takes 5 min to grill a trout. Second explanation was that the kitchen prepares food for 6 tables at a time. Well, bad luck if you aren't in the first wave! 
The trout was actually not bad but the ravioli came cold - had to send them back - and were definitely not worth the wait. 
I appreciated that the ravioli (16$) were taken off the bill. Never going back there ever again anyway. If you are in the neighborhood, go to Salt House instead.
author: Davy C.

description:
i like restaurants where everything is orchestrated in harmony and seamlessly.  where you don't have to think too much, but you actually just enjoy your company and not worry about the service, food or other etc.

that's town hall for you.  everything is just like how you want it to be.  not pretentious, not over the top, not sloppy and not bad quality.

sure we got water spilled on our table, the person i gave the birthday cake to didn't bother to check or match my reservation name, and i waited for a while for my second cocktail.
however, none of these really bothered me nor my birthday friend.  we just had fun.   plain fun.

so service is good and professional to say the least.  if your goal is happiness, it will happen here.

food:
tuna tartare was a very playful dish with a side of fried tomatoes and little heat from peppers.

ham and cheese toast is a dream come true for an ideal brunch that was happening at our dinner moment.  interesting take a on a benedict.  the sauce was so good that i had to wipe the plate off with extra bread.  kinda like a hollandaise v2.0 :) a modern classic.

scallops were a lot smaller than i thought but very very tasty, and risotto and mushrooms complemented the dish nicely.

i was surprised with the slow cooked Alaskan Cod as well.  It's amazing what you can do with a piece cod i guess.  Again, nice touch with mushrooms.  And the almost raw brussel sprouts added a good texture to the dish.

desert, well i brought it.  :)

will come back. for sure.
author: Ziya A.

description:
I heart Town Hall!  Besides the fact that its literally across the street from my office, this place has some killer drinks (literally) and downright amazing food.  When in doubt, get a Mitcherita--its the perfect combination of Patron, lime juice, and some  X-Factor ingredient that makes a shitty day at work A-OK.  Also yummy is Eli's Refresher, a mix of rum and guava juice.  I usually ask for double rum, since the flavor of the guava is kind of overpowering.  And even though everyone makes fun of me for ordering these ("the last time I had a long island was as a sophomore in college"), their long islands are pretty much awesome.  

Other staples during our frequent office happy hours?

1. The Shrimp Toast.  The waitresses tell me they put literally a pound of butter in each dish, but holy hell, its good.  You'll need an extra side of bread to lap up every last drop of the gravy.  Yeah, its that good.

2. The Veal Meatballs over mashed potatoes and gravy.  Um, I don't think that one requires much explaining.  

3. My personal favorite: The Fried Chicken with brussell sprouts and mashed potatoes.  I consider myself a fried chicken connoisseur, and I kid you not--Town Hall has the best fried chicken in San Francisco.  Its so delectably juicy, and yet its not that greasy (how the hell do they do that?)... the outside is perfectly crispy... its my ultimate comfort food.  Combined with the brussel sprouts (cooked in butter, but believe me, WORTH it)... its heaven.

4.  The Sticky Toffee Cake.  I'm not a big dessert person.  But this, my friends, is, for lack of a better term, f-ckin amazing.  I always ask for an extra scoop of ice-cream on top... its pretty much sex on a plate, if you ask me.

Love T.H.!! Comfort food, and definitely comfort drinks :)
author: suzanne l.

description: Ehhh we were a group of 8 people from work. Nobody was impressed with what they ordered. I got a filet with duck fat roasted potatoes. They cut my filet. Don't cut my filet. Ever! Staff was helpful though.
author: The Y s.

description:
Meh! With so many other fantastic California-fresh restaurants opening, I think it's hard for places like Town Hall to stay innovative. But they're ok at what they do.

Downtown after dark is not my thing, so we were admittedly a little out of place, probably not Town Hall's bread-and-butter clientele, who all seemed to be in suits.

We walked in without reservations on a Thursday night, were charmed by a male host and disdained a bit by his female counterpart, then promptly seated at the bar despite the place being packed. Quirky service continued as the bartenders silently battled over who should serve us.

Appetizers were pretty tasty, but my pork entree was undercooked. They handled it well, bringing me a new one, but all-in-all, their selections are pretty standard and safe. Yummy if you're downtown and entertaining non-city clients, but not anything to swoon at.

Serpentine, Slow Club, Nopa and a gazillion others do it better, and with a better attitude.
author: Teresa A.

description: One of the few restaurants in SF to stay great for many years. No longer the new kid on the block, but still maintains great food and service. Town Hall has aged very well.
author: Swissie M.

description:
Absolutely Delicious. 

I ordered the following: 

Fried Oysters
Big juicy breaded and fried oyster on top of a bed of spinach puree, topped with a strip of bacon and a thin slice of lemon wedge. The crunch on the outside mixed with the zest and the flavor of crispy bacon followed by deep warm juicy bite into a fatty oyster- one of the most heavenly warm appetizers I've ever had.

Rib Eye
Great portion, I split it with my friend and we barely managed to finish. Medium rare, as all steak should be served as. Grill mark with a nice charcoal flavor, pink and juicy on the inside but not bloody, tender texture almost made me feel like I've ordered a tenderloin if not for the tendons. No additional seasoning needed. 

Mac n' Cheese Croquette
Whoever thought of breading and frying cubes of mac n' cheese is a genius. The thin but not solid breading gives the crunch most mac n' cheese aim for, without the extra burn some would get. Simple mac n' cheese on the inside, nice flavor without over powering, perfect cheddar-macaroni ratio. 

Overall, very, very happy and definitely go back again!!
author: Fiona S.

description:
Thank you yelpers for the advice about the ham/cheese toast appetizer.  I had never ordered that before since it didn't really jump out at me but it was like a little slice of tasty heaven.  It almost reminded me of eggs benedict.  We also tried the veil meatballs.  I thought they were wonderful but because they were so rich, I could really only try one.  Loved the sauce the came smothered in - perfect for bread dipping. 

We had the pork chop and fried chicken for our entrees. The fried chicken was buttermilky and certainly cooked perfectly, but had a bit of a bland flavor to it.  But I assume that's its thing - the buttermilk flavor.  The pork chop was excellent and also came with a great bold sauce.  

The pot de creme for dessert was mind-blowing.  Seriously.  No wonder its their signature. 

All in all, I think this place has consistently good food with very bold flavors (with the exception of the fried chicken, which is noticeably shy in the flavor department).  It can end up feeling a little pricey for what you get, particularly because of the ambiance (it's a bit loud and not exactly cozy) but it still provides a great dining experience.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
I've been here two times now, and I have yet to have anything that wasn't super-duper tasty.  But, by far, my favorite was the sea scallop jambalaya.  I'm still dreaming about it.  It's probably the costliest jambalaya I've ever had, but, man, was it worth it.  My friend ordered the pork chop and it was cooked to perfection.  I hate pork, and I even kind of liked it.  The service has been spectacular as well.  My last server (didn't catch her name, unfortunately) was extremely helpful with pairings and recommendations.
Only downside is that it can be a little noisy, but that could also just be perceived as boisterous and energy-filled - it all depends upon how you look at it, I suppose......
author: Kerry L.

description:
Hmmmm.. a bit of a mixed but overall a pretty good experience.  I settled in on Town Hall after doing a fair amount of research.  Alright, I came to Yelp and read a few reviews.  Anyway lets get to the review.  

Food - Solid (I had the tartare, grilled lamb and the potte de creme) I was bit envious of the meatballs, scallops and the fried chicken.. yes the fried chicken looked amazing.  

Scene - Good place to socialize for sure. Place was quite loud but that is exactly what I was looking for.. so they score high there.

Drinks - mine made to perfection but others in party were not so happy..but I'll give the bartender a pass for now.

Service at the table - awful at best.  Our boy had a smile on his face but had no clue what he was doing.  He was as slow as they come and kept getting drink orders wrong.  They need a training program over there or I need to dress better to get some respect!

Overall - Good experience and maybe next time I'll get a "good" waiter.
author: Tom C.

description:
Had lunch here yesterday on someone else's dime. Place was very packed but we were seated within a reasonable amount of time considering our party changed in size (minus one). A lot of the hipster crowd was here for lunch. Lots of people wearing $200 jeans.

Noise level wasn't too bad. But then we were seated in this little, teeny, tiny alcove. Think a square little room missing a wall and it's only big enough for a table for 4. It was cute but if you're not into tight spaces then not so much. Also the space was not easy for the waitstaff to serve at. They always had to cross over the 2 people sitting on the outside to get to the people on the inside. Half way through the meal I noticed that there was broken glass underneath the table. Not a big deal but it's a detail overlooked.

What was ordered:

butter lettuce salad 
fried calamari
tuna tartare
fish and chips
whole roasted trout
grilled rib eye
roast chicken

The fish and chips were awesome. The roasted fish was very good and they did a pretty good job of removing most of the bones. The rib eye was served smothered in mushromms and french fries. Roast chicken was tasty but the accompanying jambalaya was a tad too sweet for the person who ordered it.

We passed on dessert but it certainly did look good when it was marching past us.
author: cyndi L.

description:
Town Hall will have a place in stomach for all time.  The first recommended restaurant we tried when we moved here, and it's been one of our go to places ever since.  There has been nothing we've ordered that's ever been less than amazing.  

Friends and family in from out of town and we don't want to cook?  Town Hall.  Long week and we need a good comfort meal towards the end of the week?  Town Hall.  Someone else picking up the tab?  Town Hall.
author: Joe W.

description:
I was really looking forward to coming to this restaurant, I had heard it was amazing, of course it didn't live up to my expectations. The menu was great, they change it daily so there aren't any specials, but it was difficult to decide-it all all looked good. I went with the hamburger-I ordered it medium, it came rare. I asked for veggies instead of chips-it came with chips. The burger was good (it's kinda hard to screw up a burger) , and I got fontina melted on top, which made it extra yummy. 

Of course we got desert, and the chocolate butterscotch pot de creme did not disappoint.
author: Leesa P.

description:
Overall I was very satisfied with the food - my only complaint would be the mussells - the smll bland variety not prepared in any special way.  The meatballs and scallops were delicious.  

The dining room was a bit cramped and I could clearly hear a painful first-date conversation about different sorts of accounting to my left.  It is lively and loud inside which I much prefer over quiet spots.  Luckily we brought our own bottle of wine, they selection they had was on the pricier side.
author: Aileen N.

description:
Great place!   Food, Atmosphere, Customer Service has never let me down yet and I've been there mulitple times.  It's a friendly spot, where you can feel comfy and not around uptight stuffies!  Must trys are the Worshechire Shrimp  for an app and of course the Butterscotch Creme pot for dessert.. Yummm! Yes, some things on the menu can be somewhat heavy, but at least the portions get you full or you'll have something to bring home, so its worth it.

One time one of the servers knocked over my bf's cocktail (which was basically done already, mainly ice and a few sips left) and the staff cleaned up everything in 2 seconds flat, the waiter brought over a new, full cocktail for my bf AND for me too on the house.  They apologized, but we really didn't mind at all.. they responded perfectly!
author: Lelly L.

description:
Wilver, the bartender rocks! He made everyone sitting at the bar feel special. He suggested a scrumptious Syrah to go with the fried chicken. The toffeecake he suggested was out of this world and because I couldn't decide between the toffeecake and the chocolate drink, he brought out a sample chocolate drink, so I could still experience it. Between the food and service, I was in heaven...but I drank way too much and the world was spinning when I got home.

7/15/07 Update: I realize Saturday 6:00 pm is not the best time to come to Town Hall. 1. There's just too many tourists in shorts and t-shirts with unruly kids. (Am I at Fisherman's Wharf?) 2. Our waitress started off snooty, though she mellowed out. 

On the positive, the food was still just as solid. (Regarding the calamari and meatball dish, I could have licked the plate clean.) The sommelier was personable, attentitive, and knowleageable.

I'm coming back here, but only on weekday evenings.

Afterthought: I think nothing ruins a perfect meal more than bad service, especially when I consider how much money I spend for a good meal, good atmosphere, and good service. Is it rude or okay to tell the waiter/waitress that their service was lousy?
author: unhei k.

description:
I love, love, love the food at this place.   Although my first visit was not the best (they were really busy and short staffed), I am willing to give it another try because the good was phenomenal. 

Cons: 
- Our bubbly came way after the appetizers were served (we were celebrating my new job).
- Our waiter was a little snippy and impatient
- It was pretty loud
- We waited forever for a table so we decided to sit at the communal table - it didn't turn out to be so bad. 

Pros:
- Awesome food - hearty, well executed dishes, extensive selection
- The BBQ Shrimp with parsley and Worcestershire sauce - is to die for
- Great East Coast Restaurant vibe
- Love the exposed brick look

I can't wait to go back!
author: Clarice V.

description:
I had just gotten a promotion and wanted to take my girlfriend out to a nice dinner to celebrate. We had heard a lot of good things about this place and decided it was time to check it out. We called last minute and they said that they would fit us in that night.

When we got there they didn't have our reservation down, but they did sit us down within five minutes. We sat at this large, shared table. At first we weren't sure how it would be, but it proved to be fun. We ordered a nice bottle of wine from their massive wine list.  I had the Rib Eye which was excellent. I asked for medium-rare and they actually made it medium-rare, which is impossible to get most places to do. My girlfriend got this Thai Red Snapper which was good, but the pollenta that came with it was possibly the best pollenta either of us have ever had. For dessert we had the Chocolate Butterscotch with Soft Toffee. It was amazing!

The atmosphere was fun. It's not a place for a nice, quiet dinner. It's a fun, relaxing, upbeat place. We can't wait to go back.
author: Nick R.

description:
I went to Town Hall a few times when they first opened a couple of years ago. Back then, you'd call and they'd be reluctant to give anyone a reservation. I remember one time the receptionist saying, "Sorry, we're just a really popular restaurant" I guess they are still doing well as the place was packed.

The real reason I haven't been back is b'c they took the short rib off the menu. It was to die for! Apparently it took 10 hours to make so they took it off. Sheesh....just bring it back already! Started off with the chopped vegetable salad which was mediocre. The crab artichoke dip  served in a fondue pot was good. The tuna tartare with fried green tomato was the best appetizer by far. I had the fried chicken which was absolutely awesome! It had a nice crispy skin and the chicken was tender and juicy! 

Would definitely recommend it to ppl that live in the soma area or need a restaurant right off the bridge. There are much better places I would rather go to but appreciated coming back to this SF favorite.
author: Josephine H.

description:
This place if full of after business folks, esp. on a Thursday or Friday. The place can get pretty packed with people milling around the bar and increasing the noise level. This, in turn, makes it pretty difficult to talk even when you're standing next to one another. Moreover, the ceilings are pretty high, so that makes it an echo chamber.

The food is pretty good, despite the noise. The service is excellent. We will well attended to through out the meal. We ordered a few appetizers; the friend that I was with ordered the grilled duck with pistachio sausage - it was quite unique and awesome. For the main course, I had the slow roasted duck with gingersnap gravy. It's not often you see a gingersnap gravy and it proved to be worth the order. My friend had the day boat scallops. They were presented nicely, but the kitchen went overboard on the salt; it tasted like you were drinking seawater.
author: Dan M.

description:
We checked out this place a couple years ago when a friend was the pastry chef here.  Really enjoyed the atmosphere and service was very good.  Everything we tried was excellent if a touch pricey.  The deserts were amazing (thx Maria) and very creative!  We noticed at a later date that some of her creations stayed after she left... nice one.

It's a nice mix of comfort and fine dining overall, just not super value for money ultimately.  That said it is a good restaurant and we didn't find it so noisy like most others seemed to. Worth a try!
author: Steve S.

description:
I've been here twice...
The menu was a little pricey for lunch but the food we ordered was good.  I ordered their famous ham and cheese toast with egg & jalapeno cream, ymmy stuff!

The second time was with work and we had drinks (very tasty cocktails by the way) and appetizers.  Hands down the best meatballs ever.
author: Lauren S.

description:
This is a predictable restaurant witih predictable food and desserts, the tastes of foods are acceptable but "could have been better"; appetizers average below $15 and main entrees from $20-$30, good ambiance, service and nice selections of medium price range wines including many half bottles on the wine list. 
Three stars overall, it could have and should have been better!
author: J S.

description:
It was Valentine's and my husband and I didn't make reservations for dinner until he day before Valentine's. Yeah, we suck and don't plan ahead very well. Town Hall is no place for romance but I had wanted to come here and they had an opening for a Saturday night so this gave us the chance to try it out.

For the price (around $75 per person including a glass of wine for each of us) I could probably go somewhere else and have an amazing meal. The food here is pretty good but not amazing. What was really good was the Tuna Tartare appetizer and the Hot Chocolate for dessert. 

I watched the movie Chocolat the other week and have been craving a hot chocolate like the one in the movie and got it at Town Hall. The hot chocolate is like liquid heaven. I got increasingly happier each time I took a sip of it. It is humoungous so we only finished half of it even that. It's so rich though I don't think anyone should drink all of it. That's a big cup it comes in - lotsa heavenly goodness. It actually changed my mood it was so good. Happy Valentine's to me! I would have only given three stars but that hot chocolate pushed it to four!

We also had the Beet Salad, Rib Eye, Jalapeno Bread, Pot du Creme, and the Trout wrapped in Bacon. All okay. I didn't get a taste of the fish since my husband ate it in 4 bites and under 3 minutes. He was starving. I asked if it was good and he said it was okay. I can't tell if that was really good or what, but he ate it all up.

Atmosphere is lively and loud. I liked it. If  can get a pretty good meal wearing jeans I'm very happy. There were young couples, old couples, and even families here. Service was excellent and since it was a Saturday night we got free street parking across the street from the restaurant. Bonus! Ahhh, free easy parking, that makes me almost as happy as the hot chocolate.
author: Wendy B.

description:
I have been here a number of times but have finally found time to "yelp" about it. The food quality during each visit has been consistently good. I had the fondue appetizer for the first time and it was delicous, with huge chunks of real crab. Oh, I am drooling just thinking about it right now....

The only criticism I have with the restaurant is the noise level. One needs to engage in a screaming match to carry on a conversation in the restaurant.
author: Sandy Y.

description:
5 times in and I felt it safe to write this review.  Food was wholesome, well done and flavors were well matched.  The presentation is amazing.  Some foods - well make you inappropriately excited as others have noted here.  The Key Lime pie I had one night was the best I have had short of FL.  Each item I have tried, such as the Cheddar Croquets would be a killer app anywhere else, but are just another great item with a steak here.  Honestly one of the best places to eat in SF!  With only one downside - The noise. 

I have heard the noise of some places is a "style".  If thats true this place is the Carrot Top of fashion.  NOISE like this is annoying and distracting.  If they read this - remodel with sound panels.  

But still - I got there for the food, and I love it.
author: Stephen P.

description:
I've been twice and only eaten at the community table with friends.  I think the good company I had and good light in the place makes for a better rating.  First time in we went for desserts, we had variety at our table, all good, but my favorite was the Toffee Cake, which we have named "Sticky Gooey Goodness".  Actually went home thinking about it.

The next time in we actually had dinner.  I had the fried chicken with mash.  Very good, well seasoned, crispy.  Of course it was topped off with the sticky gooey goodness that did not disappoint.
author: diyosa c.

description:
I had been wanting to come here for ages and we finally made a reservation in honor of graduation, 30th birthdays, and family in town.

So, five stars on food, without a doubt. From the squash blossom app to the mussels to the halibut to the short ribs to the pot de creme, it was all fabulous. I loved the ambiance of the place too, great dishware/glassware, windows. Lovely food and space. All 10 of us loved the meal. Really.

BUT, I give it a 3-4 stars for service. Even though the place was empty, it took some time to seat us for our 5:30 reservation. We were a large party of 10, but our waitress didn't crack a smile once and seemed vaguely annoyed the whole time. Also servers brought out the wrong appetizers more than once, entrees didn't come out at once (not a huge deal, but a few people waited longer than they should have), then they gave us some other party's doggie bag...all minor snafus, but, still. Luckily, the food was amazing, otherwise I would have been disappointed.
author: Nima K.

description:
3 1/2 stars?

The food is good but didn't live up to the hype for me.  I didn't taste any inspired combinations although what was cooked was cooked pretty well.

Lots of yuppies here.
author: Angela Q.

description:
Came here for dinner on Saturday evening (with Olivia W!) and was pleasantly surprised.  I wasn't expecting too much as I've never heard of the place... I loved the decor and ambiance.  It felt like we were having dinner in someone's really fancy dining room... if that person had like some renovated barn for a house or something.  It was kinda like a Pottery Barn Americana style restaurant. Anyway! The service was great... the waitress was super helpful picking out wines and offering her suggestions for dinner.  I too decided on the friend chicken... and while it was juicy and pretty tasty, it wasn't out of this world.  But yeah, the creamed corn and biscuits definitely made up for it.

For dessert I ordered the chocolate cake with ice cream... wow. So rich. And I'm usually all about chocolatey richness... maybe it was the heaviness of the dinner. Or maybe it was the fact that we didn't eat dinner until like 10:30 pm.... hm... but that cake done did me in.  Food coma express. Wow.

So overall it was a decent place... kinda pricey but not too shabby.  The butterscotch and chocolate pudding was DEEEELICIOUS.  I'd definitely order that if I ever went to Town Hall again.

Price: Fried Chicken, Chocolate Cake, tax, tip = about $40
author: Christy H.

description:
Great place.  Hearty-type American fare.  Good wine selection as well.  

Good place to have a guy's night out with some hearty meals and some wine.  The atmosphere is great, noisy, but in a good energetic way.  It would be great place after a football game or some type of celebratory occasion.

The only downside is the bathroom, which was fairly detached from the dining hall.  Depending on the amount of wine consumed, one may need a GPS device to rejoin the table.
author: Mark C.

description:
A very solid 4-stars for Town Hall.  My SO and I rolled up at 7 p.m. without reservations and were immediately able to sit at the communal table near the entrance.  Surprisingly, we had no problem hearing each other.

The service was a bit slow getting started, but once we gave our orders the food came out quickly enough.  My persimmon salad was well dressed.  Many places drown the greens, but this was just right.  Unfortunately, the persimmon itself didn't have much flavor at all.  The biscuits, however, were amazing.  The cocktails - the "back in fashion" (old fashioned) and mitcharita - were a highlight as well.  

The trout was excellent and the scallops good, though the brussels sprouts with the scallops were undercooked.  The dessert was the most disappointing part of the meal.  The apple crisp wasn't bad, just unmemorable.  The coffee, I'm sad to say, was burnt and bitter, even if it was served in a tiny french press.  That's almost enough to knock it down to 3 stars.

The best part of the evening was chatting with the other people at the table.  I highly recommend trying the communal table out.
author: Tullia F.

description:
You know those shishi restaurants that serve main coursed that are portioned like appetizers? This ain't one of them. We started off with beer: La Fin du Monde and a Turbo Dog ale, followed by some nice sourdough bread (albeit cold). Our appetizer was fondue with soft pretzels, raw string beans, and andouille sausage--very rich and decadent. For the girl, scallops (gigantic!) with pureed squash and brussels sprouts. For me, the duck with wild rice and i-forget-what sauce. The duck was a bit too rare for me, but it was still very delish. A very generous serving of pot de creme, chocolate and butterscotch with pieces of toffeed chocolate--beyond decadent.

Very good service. The server even came by and folded my companion's napkin while she was in the loo--a bit anal, but appreciated. It's like soul food-meets-shishi. I want to come back to try the fried chicken next time--it looked good.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
i can't believe that only one other person has written about town hall bbq! 

i have come here on several occasions for lunch, cause let's face it, i cannot afford this place for lunch or dinner indoors. for bbq, their prices range from 8-12 bucks.

they serve bbq on non-rainy spring days every year, beginning in april, weather-permitting. 

what's on the menu? po-boys - sausage/shrimp, fried chicken, pulled pork, pastrami, grilled skirt steak sandwiches, jambalaya, and ribs! also, sides: home-made chips, potato salad, coleslaw. plus, desserts: chocolate chunk cookies, chocolate pot de creme. 

i've tried:
fried chicken sandwich ($8) (3 stars)
ribs (starting at $8) (5 stars)
pastrami sandwich ($9) (4 stars)
skirt steak sandwich ($9) (3.5 stars)
potato salad ($2) (5 stars)
cookies ($1.50 for two) (5 stars)

my coworker really hyped this place up, and he goes ALL the time. a good 3-4 times a week? 

first time, i had the fried chicken sandwich. it's bland, so order it with bbq sauce. i thought it would be a hot piece of meat, but it was actually cold chicken. :( however, it was a thick piece of chicken breast that was moist all the way through. points! the coleslaw has a bit too much celery for my liking, but that's just me. i'm a celery hater. :(

ribs. omg the ribs. i ordered the platter, which is a quarter rack (4 ribs) + 2 sides. i opted for the potato salad and asked them for cookies instead. the ribs are fall off the bone tender and flavored throughout. they'll give you extra bbq sauce, that's heavy of beer. the potato salad is orange from, i'm assuming paprika? they use small waxy potatoes, cut into big chunks, and there are eggs! it doesn't taste too fattening, which makes me feel less guilty about eating the entire thing. it's quite delicious and i've had it more than once now. 

the cookies, o wow, they're awesome! probably the best thing on the menu, albeit strange that baked goods are the best item at a bbq place. soft and chewy, but sometimes, you'll nibble at a piece which has caramelized brown sugar that oozed out during the baking process, and it's crispy. $1.50 for 2 cookies. GOOD deal. 

went halfsies today on the pastrami and steak sandwiches - their first day out today. the pastrami..... good texture, not too riddled with fat, good mustard, great choice of bread. however, it could have used more seasoning. not enough of a pastrami flavor as i'm used to. steak sandwich - again, could have used more seasoning. the grilled peppers were really sweet. the sandwich lacked char throughout too. i like the tri tip sandwich at pluto's on irving better. 

did i cover all of it? i think so. OH, and the bearded-chubby order caller is awesome - he wears a different threadless tee every day, and listen closely when he calls for a chicken sandwich - you'll smile and never get sick of it. oh! watch for your order. someone else later in line may end up getting your order first if you're not attentive.

bottom line is that i love being able to try town hall without town hall prices.
author: Melissa C.

description:
I have visited this place on two occasions and have enjoyed both times.  It is elegant yet there is not a "stuffy" attitude from staff.  Our server was perfectly friendly and knowledgable, the wine list is extensive, and the menu is varied.

At our table we had the steak , fish, and appetizers. All were prepared well.  The steak is among the best I've had in San Francisco. This place actually knows what medium rare means! You can tell that a skilled person was preparing the food.  At some places you get the idea the executive chef hires unskilled people to do the cooking, not here.

About the only small complaint is that sent them an e-mail through their website and never heard back.  I am big on customer service and this includes responding to e-mails. Oh well, the food is good so I will return.
author: John H.

description: Really enjoyed my experience here. The food was tasty, ambiance divine, and I was most pleased with the service. Busy night (during a conference or something)... packed to the brims... yet, when we let our server know that we were targeting leaving in 45 mins for a concert - she had no issue, despite the crowd, making sure the timing of everything was tightened up a wee notch to make sure we were on schedule. And, she did so with kindness and attention to detail. Oh, and the food (bacon wrapped quail!) was quite good, too! I'll be back!
author: Danny G.

description:
This place is a great place for a dinner of any sorts, if you're going casual or if you're taking a pretty gal on a date, the menu is great, a nice wine list, our waitress was great about answering questions, must recommend the fondue (not sure i spelled this right, i'm not an educated man) appetizer and the rib eye. All in all, i must say, excellent place to eat! you must go check it out.

Oh, and i almost forgot, they bring your check in a novel. They rock!!

Enjoy with friends!
author: Luis P.

description:
I showed up after reading reviews on this place really early.  While I tried the fried chicken because of the reviews I read, it was a little disappointing.  Paying around $20 for some fried chicken and vegetables seems a little ridiculous.  The chicken isn't seasoned that well, which is good for those who like a more 'natural' flavor.  There is a good crunch to it though.  This place was pretty packed even at the start of dinner service, so the noise level was high but okay.  

What I really loved about this place was the excellent service I got from the staff and the pot de creme for dessert.  So I recently moved in and showed up in a t-shirt and jeans after a long day of settling in.  While I looked rather out of place since most people were in business casual, the waiter I had was excellent.  He was thoughtful and very nice.  On top of that, even the hostess struck up a conversation with me (again, perhaps due to my clothes...)  The pot de creme was rich and delicious.  I don't really like butterscotch, but I couldn't help but eat it.  The chocolate beneath was rich and amazing.  I eat a lot, but I couldn't finish this dessert even with my strong sweet tooth.  Overall, mediocre food, excellent service and dessert.
author: Nate W.

description: The fried chicken was really good. The butterscotch and Chocolate Pot de Creme was really good for dessert.
author: Peter S.

description:
Gotta give this place a great review on the fact the bar tender gave me a bottomless glass of wine. We sat at the bar and he was very busy, but it was a packed house so I didn't mind. How could I when he kept refilling my glass and only charged me for 1. 

The best thing I had all night was the appetizer: Faith's warm ham and cheese toast, poached egg and jalapeno cream. Yeah...do I need to say more? I love eggs over easy for breakfast and dipping the toast in the runny yolk so this was that times a 100 with the salty melted cheese and warm ham.

I got the buttermilk fried chicken for my main course which was OK, I wouldn't recommend it though. If you want fried chicken, go to Ad Hoc which I'm about to review after this. I would probably get the gnocchi next time I'm back in San Francisco.

Ambiance was very warm- I loved the tube lighting.
author: Jay and Jenn O.

description:
Went there for the first time ever last week. 

The Great:
butter leaf salad.  wow that was fresh
Tuna tartare -- great flavor and very fresh
Cucumber infused vodka martini

The Good:
Buttermilk fried chicken -- very moist, but the crust lacked some flavor
Stuffed Petrale sole -- good flavors

The OK:
Service -- would have been great but we were going to a play (which we told them) and it was paced a little too slow.  Didn't have time for dessert
author: David S.

description:
Came here for lunch. Food was fantastic.

BF: got potato leek soup, pulled pork sandwich, and chocolate butterscotch creme brule

potato leek soup: very creamy, perfectly seasoned, although maybe a bit heavy for lunch. it would have been ideal for a dinner appetizer

pulled pork: definitely worth returning for!

creme brule: unreal good. i would go back just for dessert and order the chocolate butterscotch creme brule

me: i got the lamb with gnocchi. it was everything i could have asked for in a meal. i love gnocchi, i love lamb, and i loved this dish. it was hearty and definitely a great comfort food. the best part was that they actually used a gamey lamb, the gnocchi were soft, and it just had great flavor.

i will be coming back here
author: suz s.

description: I went to Town Hall today for a business lunch and was extremely disappointed. It was by far the worst service I've had in years. It took our waiter about 20 minutes to come by for our drink orders and then another 15 minutes to come by for our food order. Not once during our entire meal did he refill our drink glasses or check in to see how our meal was. He basically ignored us until 15 minutes after we finished eating to bring us the check. On top of that the best part of the food was the bread before my meal arrived. When you're out on a business lunch the last thing that you want is a restaurant to distract you with bad service and unappealing food, I will not be coming back here, there are so many better options in the area.
author: Christina L.

description: we're still fans of this restaurant, but generally prefer lighter fare.  I don't know if our stomachs are changing or what, but I'm not sure I'd go out of my way to come here again.  Probably would try for something else with a cleaner meal (I prefer simple dishes and this is just too rich for me now).
author: Libbi J.

description: Food is delicious, menu constantly changes and is full of exciting new things to try, dessert is a must.  Service quality does not match the food, but it's not going to deter me from going back!
author: Ben N.

description:
A PERFECT EVENING!  

Two friends and I went to Town Hall for dinner yesterday for a girls night out.  

Between the three of us we ordered
Warm ham and cheese toast with poached egg and jalepeno cream
BBQ squab with lentil and i forgot what else.
Smoked St Louis ribs with corn bread and cole slaw
Fried chicken with smashed potatos and collard greens
Butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme.
A bottle of Educated Guess cab.

Everything we ate was rich, delicious, waist widening goodness.  Ladies and gents, eat salad all week long if you must and have dinner at Town Hall on Saturday.  =]  

We started with the ham and cheese toast as recommended by our server.  SOO GOOOD.  Yeah it'll clog your arteries but that jalepeno cream sauce was freaking awesome.  My squab was soft, tender, juicy, the fried chicken was delicious with not too much grease and perfectly seasoned crunchy batter (batter? is that the right term?) , ribs were quite good too.  You HAVE to save room for the butterscotch chocolate pot de creme.  Ohh ho ho YEAH.  Comes out cold, yes it is sweet but really tasty.  Enough to share between three people.

Wonderful service, polite staff, attentive and knowledgeable waitress on top of their delicious food=5/5 

Yay!
author: H K.

description:
Went for NYE Dinner, as a friend said this place was very very good. She especially suggested the fried chicken.

Great place, great drinks but food was okay, considering how much it cost. The Fried Chicken that she recommend was not all that great...
author: Vincent L.

description:
I really like this place. The service was great as the waiter took the time to explain the menu and was very attentive. 

The food was awesome. The corn bread is really great. The portions were bigger than that I thought. It was an awesome dinner.
author: Magi Y.

description: I love the buzz...great weekday apres business place. order the appetizers, and awesome wines.
author: Bob L.

description:
had lunch at town hall probably a good 25 times...  Very good food, great corn bread oyster spinach salad, great burgers, soaps etc..  

Very east coast feel to the restuarant, much like boston on the inside.
author: Brent H.

description:
I was really looking forward to this dinner and my expectations were high--my roomate was taken here on a first date by a guy that I imagine has really good taste in everything--and they were definitely met and exceeded.  
Oh, it was SO nice.  I loved the decoration and the style of the place-- lots of exposed brick and cool lighting, high ceiling.  Great bartender, attentive waiter (but not TOO attentive), we brought our own wine but their wine list looked good-- pricy, but good.  And the food was amazing-- we had a butter lettuce salad and crab fondue (!) and I had rabbit cooked 3 ways.  (I know, rabbit?? But it was delicious.)  I definitely recommend it!
author: rachel l.

description:
Comfort food for foodies is how I'd describe their menu.  I've only been here for lunches but it's truly a treat when I go; sometimes I dance a jig while my office mates whistle on jugs.

Revision:  3.18.06
The wait here can be excruciatingly long whether its to be seated (even with a reservation) or while you're at the table.  I thought it was a fluke the first couple times but at this point, it seems to happen more often than not.
author: Jonny L.

description:
I frequently see Town Hall rated in the top 10 most visited restaurants on opentable.com. My experience, unfortunately, countered that rating fairly negatively. 

We arrived early to find out reservation "wasn't on the list." But, to their credit, they immediately seated us. Dinner began with a fantastic appetizer, but followed with a dissappointment with the entree. Fortunately, the dessert follow up was solid, with Chocolate-Butterscotch Pot de Creme to die for. 

With a strong backswing, weak connection with the ball, and great follow through, Town Hall is a decent experience. Reasonable prices make it a solid bet any given night. And, I look forward to the next experience to sell up one more star.
author: Dave M.

description:
I finally made it here! I had been dying to go for ages, and it was definitely good. Worshechire shrimp were absolutely amazing and the pulled duck with gingersnap gravy & rabbit & eggplant entrees were also exceptional. Ahi tartare & fried green tomatoes were the only thing that I thought was a little off--only because the two didn't really go together. 

 However, I am worried that everything on the menu is so rich and delicious  that you either want to keel over from a heart attack by the time you are done with it or just feel confused as to why you ate 2 incredible dishes that by themselves were amazing but together made you want to vomit. I say town hall needs some more veggies (None on the duck dish) and a little less butter. (I couldn't even eat dessert!!!) Regardless, I give it 4 stars. Food was delicious, service was great, and the space and decor were really cool.
author: Nicole S.

description:
I've been hearing about this place for the last 2 years, so we finally dragged ourselves over there after the gym this week.  The food was 4 star good, but I had sticker shock when the bill came.

5 starters and 2 drinks each came out to $140 with a decent tip!  As they say in the south, Oh Lordy!  

The ham and egg toast was a near niss.  good sauce, great okra, well fried with a cornmeal crust and without a hint of that slimyness you can get from that oddest of all veggies, and would have been great if the egg was still runny (and we broke that sucker the second it came to table)... but $14?  and the fried okra was just that -1 okra, cut into 5 pieces and fried!  C'mon people!  lets put a bit more on the plate or think about cutting prices a tad!

And the evening continued - crab cake appie, well done, but 1 small crabcake?  5 shrimp on a toastie... thats like $3 bucks a shrimp if you toss in the sauce and toast gratis!  Veal meatballs were a letdown... the veal flavor was rubbed out by the blah demi sauce and potato puree.  For yucky meatballs at 1/10 the price see my review of the Subs, Inc!

Anyways, the food was generally good but the prices were unseemly... The menu reminded me of Magnolia Grill in Durham, North Carolina, which executes this southern fried haute cuisine in the same price range with much more care (check the rabbit trio, since when did SF bite dishes from Durham?!?)... of course, you have to go to NC for the original.
