Bonus points to the bar for a proper rye manhattan!  As always, a good drink makes the meal better!
author: evan J.

description:
Upper class food without the pretentious attitude. Perfect place to take your semi-racist grandparents. 

The best on the menu (I think so).
Butter lettuce salad for appetizer, slow roasted duck for dinner, with a side of warm jalapeo cornbread. Any light fruity red wine will pair well with the duck. I had Abbot's Table last I was there.

Town Hall can be a slight pricey, but is well worth the money the day the welfare check comes in.
author: F B.

description:
Really nothing special.  Our waiter was very pushy to the point that he wasn't even listening to us.  We had to repeat ourselves numerous times to avoid ordering items that we were asking questions about.  Our waiter seemed very rushed and couldn't have really cared less about us.  
Food was good.  Nothing outrageous or delicious and definitely not worth the prices paid.  I had the BBQ shrimp appetizer, which was good, but overly salty.  A big stretch at $15.  I also had the ham/cheese appetizer which was tasty and rich...but also not worth the $15 tag.
The butter lettuce salad had about 3 cups too much dressing on it...It was actually gross.  The duck was good, although a little bland, and the steak was decent.  
Overall, the food was just OK and too expensive for what we got.  Our waiter was what really ruined our experience...

Will I go back???    No.
author: Matt V.

description:
Yup, it's LOUD and the service can be "inefficient" sometimes, but if you are with a group of people out to have a good time, you won't notice some of their shortcomings.
I've been there a few times now, and their appetizers and desserts are truly great.  Sadly, their dinner entrees have not impressed me.  I've been satisfied, but not wowed. :(
Soo, you pay for the ambiance, apps, and drinks.  I'm cool with that sometimes.  I'll check out other entrees you yelpers have recommended.
Not sure if they still bring out your bill in books, but I think that's cute.
author: Francine S.

description:
My first time at Town Hall and I had a fabulous experience. I loved the homey atmosphere and decor, and the professional, yet casual staff.

The food was amazing. I had the duck with rice, pecans, dates and gingersnap gravy. It was to die for. (They also had an entree of bacon wrapped trout which I was considering for the only reason that I could brag that I once had bacon wrapped trout).

An amazing experience all-around. Definitely going back again. Love getting the check in an old book!
author: Lisa R.

description:
Oh crap, the meter has a 30 minute limit.  Well, maybe we can make it...45 minutes later.. WOOT, the parking Gods are with me.  

This is a great lunch place.  If you don't have reservations you have to sit at the kids table, I mean community table or outside.  The egg/ham/cheese dish is heavenly.  The spinach salad and strawberry shortcake are pretty spectacular too.  But I think my fav is the Eli's refresher (nothing like a cocktail before noon).  A bit overpriced, but spectacular none the less.  All in all bring your wallet and your parking Karma and you won't be disappointed.
author: Chris W J.

description:
A few of us made an impromptu trip here after happy hour for dinner and drinks, and while we walked right in off the street we were able to quickly be seated at the communal table.  I'm glad we did.

The communal table turns out to be one of my favorite restaurant ideas, and I'd only experienced it before at Suppenkuche (next on the list: Nopa and Salt house).  First off, being seated right away was fantastic.  But more than that, meeting the neighbors turned out to be not only good for conversation, but also for entertainment.

The food was certainly above average (The duck was fantastic), and about right for the price.  The drinks were well poured and some of the selections off the special drink menu looked great.  Yes, the place is loud, but I think that's half the charm.  Recommended for anyone who wants a good, but not super adventurous meal.
author: james s.

description:
Wonderful food, good service, bit noisy.  The bit noisy part isn't a problem at all if you're in the mood for a good scene. 

Worry about catching a cab- the rest. is on a street that is quieter after dark. Talking about the lack of cabs in this city though is a completely different problem all together.
author: Rob J.

description:
I have mixed feelings about Town Hall.  The service was spotty, but the entrees were memorable.  I like the ambiance -- lively and funky -- making this a decent date place.  

Here are my picks from their Summer menu. 
1. BBQ shrimps Worchester sauce and garlic bread 
2. risotto with peas in truffle oil
3. Alaskan halibut

The BBQ shrimps were bold, flavorful and worked well with a glass of Pinot Gris. (I can't remember the name.)
author: TK W.

description:
This place was fantastic!  After getting recommendations for this place from friends and reading the reviews on yelp, I was very glad that we decided to go here.  The food was delicious.  For starters we had the fried squash blossoms with pesto and the toast with eggs and a jalapeno cream sauce.  For our dinners we had the stuffed pork chop and the fried chicken.  We were both impressed with the quality and consistency of the food.  

I would agree with everyone else that the place can get very noisy.  Our reservations weren't until 8:30, so toward the end of our meal the place quieted down a bit, which was a nice change.  So I would suggest having a later meal if you want to chat.
author: Sari O.

description:
This is Home with more upmarket drinks, food, patrons and prices.  
Red threshold, exposed brick and high white wainscotting decor give the place a refreshed New England feel.  Tucking the bill in an old book is a nice detail.  

Decibels were still loud on a Tuesday night at 9pm.  
Water was dripping in a steady stream from the ceiling onto a fellow patron's table.  Maybe it was a one time flukey plumbing thing.  If it was my table, maybe my review wouldn't be so favorable.

Sweet Pea Risotto was good.  
Stuffed Zucchini Blossoms better.  
Strawberry Shortcake, the best.
author: K W.

description:
I wasn't expecting to like Town Hall - thought it would be another overpriced, underwhelming restaurant. However, it really blew me away. The shrimp appetizer in worcestershire sauce was unbelievable! Everything else I tried was excellent. 

The atmosphere is friendly and relaxed. The service was great. I'll definitely go back again.
author: Amanda S.

description:
The brick building outside makes this restaurant at first glance like a hall but once you walk in the decor just stands out.  There is a large communal table to the right - great way to meet new friends & share what each others are having.  The long bar is a place people (like me) who didn't make reservation try to grab a seat or two -- you gotta have the eye for who is finishing up their meals then plant yourself literally right behind them!  That way when they start to get out of their seats it's your cue to slide on in with "oh are you leaving".  I've eaten here by myself (like I said I don't cook) at the bar and it's great.  The bartenders are extremely nice & attentive and some remember who you are so it makes you want to go back for that greeting of "hey great to see you again".  

The Tuna Tartare is different but delicious with the fried green tomatoes.  Barbecued shrimp are a must have - YUM! and of course the veal meatballs with potato puree.  I usually have a bunch of starters with glasses of red wine.  Wine selections are extensive - both by the glass and by bottles.  

Definitely a happy hour scene - always pack.  Oh, not sure if they still do this but on tax due date they have happy hour of $1.00 drinks!!!  Yes, it definitely helps to coat the fact that you just pay too much to uncle sam
author: Lily W.

description:
(I can't believe it's taken me this long to write a review for Town Hall!)

I absolutely LOVE this restaurant. Although I don't want to consider myself a "foodie," I have tried many nice places in and around the city over the past few years and Town Hall has NEVER ceased to impress me each and every time. I have also recommended this place to every one under the sun.

The converted town hall offers a fun ambiance: not too loud so you can't hear yourself think, but amped up enough for you to feel like you're at a grand family gathering all around. The waiters are incredibly knowledgeable and honest about the dishes on the menu (must not be too hard when everything is incredibly scrumptious), and your water glass is never half empty. ;)

Now onto the food ... MARVELOUS. I can't think of enough adjectives to describe Town Hall. Some of my favorite dishes include the barbecued shrimp on garlic herb toast; braised short ribs; bacon and cheddar croquettes; and buttermilk fried chicken, just to name a few. And you absolutely cannot leave without trying their heavenly sticky toffee cake - warm, decadent and uber moist toffee cake topped with a scoop of vanilla ice cream and drizzled with caramel sauce.
author: Grace C.

description:
Since I love the Salt House so much, I was expecting a lot more from Town Hall. The food wasn't horrible, but the service was sub-par. We dined outside on a Monday evening and waited over an hour for our food... and it wasn't even that busy. And sadly for them, I forgot what I had.

Ouch.

I'll give it another try.
author: Eric G.

description:
This place was very good. It's certainly not the best place in SF, but I'd go there again. The host was kind of snooty, and our reservation wasn't ready for 20 minutes, but it was alright because we got to rub elbows with big-wigs in thousand-dollar suits at the bar, one of them being Gavin Newsome. Well I guess we didn't really rub elbows per se, we just sat there in the corner feeling poor.

I took my girlfriend there for her birthday, and we thoroughly enjoyed our meal. I say meal, because we always share everything. Anyways I thought some of the staff was on coke, but they did a good job. Whatever floats your boat, I guess. The highlight of the meal was the pot de creme dessert. In this case the English pronunciation was more accurate, because it was huge.
author: Berg W.

description:
I went for dinner the other day. The Bohemian drink was amazing!! Like a liquefied sour patch kid, but alcoholic. 
The tuna tartare...amazing. 
I don't know what everyone's complaining about, yeah the restaurant was loud, but I didn't have to shout to let myself be heard. The ambiance was great.
The entrees were sub par. The ribeye was over done and had no real flavor and the potatoes it was served with were yuck. The duck was totally misflavored. 
Dessert was spot on, but by the time the butterscotch chocolate pudding arrived I was so stuffed.
I probably would only go back/recommend this place for drinks and appetizers.
author: prachi v.

description:
A great place for special occasions. It's a bit pricey, but it's worth it. The food is near perfect, the wine list is great and the service is pinpoint. 

My only (slight) negative is the ambiance; it's a bit plain looking for such a great spot. But the food and service are so good that this is barely noticeable.

I will definitely be going back.
author: K F.

description:
this place, had excellent food and service was great . It is pricey, but that's what you would expect from the presentation and quality of the food. The atmosphere was quiet, and we had a table in the back, so they gave us space . It was by the kitchen door, but it conveniently sat 5  so it was acceptable. Our waitress was super nice, however, my friend thought she was being a little rude, because of her laid back tone with us because we were younger looking. So the decorations was pretty plain , chairs were not all that great for the price you pay for food , one would think  it would be nicer. The food, Pork chops were excellent, beer list  decent  and the yummy tuna tar tars, were insanely good. I would definitely eat there again. 

Update: I often compare all my food quality to this place. I don't know why I gave it 4 stars initially...this is 5 no doubt
author: Radiospank D.

description:
This place is very close to my house, I've driven by it, walked by it and crawled by it at least a million times.  But for some reason it has taken me almost two and half years to actually walk inside.  I have really been missing out!  This has become one of my new san francisco favorites.  I try to go every other week, if not every week.

The decor is bright, airy and comfortable.  When you walk in you just want to sit down, drink some good wine and eat yourself into a coma.  I have to say, as good as the food is here, it could be served out of the trunk of a car and I would be sitting right there in a lawn chair, drinking wine from a box, and once again eating myself into a coma.

I love to go to a place and order many things as I usually can't just decide on one.  Especially when it comes to appetizers.  I've had recently or ordered in past:
Heirloom Tomato Salad - delicious
Tuna Tartare - not really a big fan of the tartares, but this was seasoned wonderfully and pretty darn good
Mussels with spicy sausage - to die for
Ham and Cheese Toast - yum, yum, yum
Jambalaya - awesome, although it's pretty spicy, doesn't bother me, but might be too much for some.
and my all time favorite...
the Barbecued Shrimp - A single tear slowly ran down my cheek with each bite.

As for the entrees I've had recently or ordered in the past:
Fried Chicken - delicious, juicy, could use a wee bit more crunch on the outside but that won't stop me from ordering again.
Scallops - ridiculous!  so good, will possibly make you run home and slap yo mama!
The seafood etoufee - WOOWWWWWWW!!  unfortunately I haven't seen this on the menu in awhile
We've had some fish dishes that were GREAT and some steak dishes that will melt in your mouth, it would take me an hour to fully describe everything.

The have an awesome wine selection and really great bartenders.  Also, the wait staff is very informative and courteous.  I just can't say enough good about Town Hall.  It will put a good sized dent in your wallet, but for me, it is completely worth it!
author: Jamie B.

description:
Comfort food chic - someone finally gets it right. 

When every other restaurant in town is serving their patented variety of mac 'n cheese, Town Hall is a welcome reminder that there's more to it than that. The menu is positively outstanding. They walk the brilliant fine line between inventive yet inviting, and interesting yet reliable. When you see fried chicken with biscuits and bacon gravy, accompanied by creamed corn...you know you're not going to be disappointed. Yet when it arrives at the table, it's so much more than *just* what the menu said - the flavors are much more complex.

Appetizers even hit it out of the park, with such delights as biscuits with pepper jelly and ham; butter lettuce salad with blue cheese, fiji apples and candied walnuts; and jalapeno cornbread...just to name a few. Whenever I move to the entrees, I'm intrigued by just about everything offered, but find it really hard to steer clear of the piping hot, perfectly crisped fried chicken, which I believe to be the best in the City (other greats include 1300 Fillmore, Maverick, and Powell's - if it's still around).

Now some places like this manage to do a face-plant when it comes to desserts, but not Town Hall. If you like yours rich and delicious, you'll be satisfied. I find San Francisco's Best Cup of Hot Chocolate to be out of this world, and am saddened it is considered a "winter" item only (hello, August in San Francisco IS winter). My husband can't get enough of the Butterscotch Chocolate Pot de Creme, which is so rich it makes your eyes burn. Sticky toffee chocolate cake is also good...and I think you're getting the idea. Now pile on attentive service, a solid wine list, a great and lively atmosphere, and the opportunity to eat at the communal table or bar when OpenTable laughs at your reservation request, and this is easily one of the best spots in town. 

My single issue with the place (and mind you, not enough of an issue to bring it down from 5 stars) is the 10-person reservation limit for the public dining room. Beyond that number, you have to go private with a $1000 minimum, which I find absolutely absurd - for lunch, mind you! Boulevard's minimum is $350 for 12 people...take that as a cue, Town Hall. But I still love you.
author: Kiesha R.

description:
Really liked this place!  Went on a Friday night at like 10:30, the place was packed and I expected it to be a long wait with slow service, but we actually got seated within 5 minutes and the service was great!  

To be honest, when going over the menu, there was nothing that really jumped out at me and I was feeling a lil' disappointed, until I stumbled on the fried chicken with biscuits and gravy....like, where did that come from?  Had to get it and it was awesome!  The chicken ws crispy and juicy, the biscuits and gravy were buttery, all around, it was a great meal.  

Tried my friend's halibut and the salmon dish, both were good.  All around, I recommend this place.
author: Melissa A.

description:
just as the yelp star rating says... "Meh. I've experiened better."

we already knew not to expect their website was updated with recent wines.  however we thought we'd ask anyway just to see.  honestly, i don't remember what wine we were looking for (i just remember it was an australian shiraz, which i am a MAJOR fan of).  they didn't, but brought out a substitute to my request.  at the end of the day, i don't even remember what the hell i had or if it was good.

this goes for everything else we had.  we started with the shrimp appetizer on texas toast:
1) too salty
2) too saucy
3) too overcooked
4)too buttery - the sauce really killed it.  you wouldn't even know it was shrimp if you had your eyes closed.

my boyfriend had the fried chicken for entree.  our thoughts going into this was, "well.. if they're charging this much for fried chicken it has to be better than kfc right?"

wrong.  there was absolutely nothing spectacular... it was just fried chicken... not even the special 16 spice blend that kfc can offer.  bleh.

i had the lamb dish, i think it was lamb done 2 or 3 different ways?  yea. i don't remember.  obviously it wasn't anything amazing.

surprisingly, my friend from ny LOVED this place.  maybe she was just being nice, because she kept saying how good everything tasted.  she got the wairess-recommended pork chop, and she finished everything on her plate.

for dessert we all shared the donuts.  we just got it only because the "bacon" part of it sounded interesting... and it was.  i don't know if i'd order it again though.
author: Jade K.

description:
Believe it or not, this place has one of the best fried chicken in SF.  It's hard to imagine that a fancy place like this can produce better chicken than Hard Knox, which offers the best bang for your buck and Mavericks, which I think is a bit over priced for what you get.  Last but not least, The Front Porch is also very good!!!  Good price to food ratio!

Aside from these fancy places, there are other good fried chicken out there such as Jollibee (so juicy and spicy and comes with gravy), Poppey's (So so, but for the price...hayyy!), Church's and of course Louisiana's Fried Chicken!

I have not yet tried 1300 Fillmore, but I hear they have really good fried chicken!  On a good note, right accross the street from there (Eddy & Fillmore), there is a new restaurant called Gussie's Chicken & Waffles opening soon which will serve chicken & waffles!!! Yum!!!  I can't wait until that place opens!  Although I'm not sure when it will open...
author: Rico d.

description:
sit at the community table if you don't want to wait or don't have reservations. 

cocktails are awesome. all the food is as well. 

still have not tried the outdoor lunchtime bbq but it's a great idea.

if you want slightly cheaper by same owner go to Salt House down the street.
author: Crutonic L.

description:
i always have fun at townhall.  lots of action, not impossible to get a table and the patio is nice (even in the rain).

ive enjoyed nearly everything ive had here.  standouts include the sole, fried oysters and the pot de creme.  YUM!  the cocktails are a treat as well.

WARNINGS: don't get the mac n cheese croquettes!  totally flavorless and would have even been disappointing from mels or loris or etc or etc.  also!  if you get opt for a more simple drink (rum and coke perhaps?) be prepared to pay $12, as opposed to the $9-$10 specialty cocktails.
author: Christy C.

description: When you walk into this business area of SOMA, you will be surprised by the old plus new decoration of the restaurant.  The menu will also surprise you a bit with southern flair and new twist of American classics.
author: Eric C.

description: Came here on first day of Dine About Town for lunch. Only four items to choose from and we ordered them all since we were a party of 2. Everything was quite tasty but my favorite was the chicken pot pie and gumbo. Not bad for $17.95.
author: Roger H.

description: came here for a work dinner. it was loud. waiter was ok. food was good.
author: BenHur C.

description: I really liked this place. Love the natural light and the friendly staff. I ordered the hanger steak and our waitress said the chef likes to prepare it medium but it really came out medium rare, which is what I preferred anyway, so that was good. The sauce on the corn on the cob was delicious!
author: S W.

description: Went here for a friend's birthday. Got a duck dish and it was delicious! I like the ambiance and menu although it's a strange mix of comfort food and gourmet.
author: Jamie W.

description:
After reading some yelps comments, 6 of us Scorpios decided to have our November birthday lunch gathering here... frankly it was a big disappointment  for us.
 Food was okay..the 2 types soups was the only nice, hot dish (it was seafood chowder, and some sort of squash or pumpkin ,I think) service was "REAL" slow and our waitress keeps on forgetting our order plus we had order alot (bill was$230 plus tips) when we had finished appetizer and salad  we had to stack the dishes on top of each other and we didn't get spoons for our soups.. AND they weren't even that busy that afternoon (I had made resevations for 1:15pm)!!  Maybe we should have gone for dinner instead!! 
The dessert we order were some cooked pear thing ,cheesecake,and pumpkin coffee/toffee cake "to me" the cake was good...because it came with ice cream!! :)
author: anny g.

description: The veal meatballs were still good, but everything else was so lacking in luster (e.g., tough overcooked steak, bad oysters, overpriced etoufee) that I can no longer speak about this restaurant with the same enthusiasm I once had.
author: Wakako U.

description: Townhall has a number of unique dishes to offer. Their service is excellent. After I trailed off with the cloth napkin on the way to the restroom, I found a freshly folded napkin at my place when I returned. Great job! The dishes attempt at a creative twist to home comfort food. They are a bit heavy on the butter but I appreciate the attempt.
author: Kathleen T.

description:
The picture with the coy smirk was taken at Town Hall.  Now if that's not the face of a satisfied diner (holding a box of take home stuff no less), well I don't know what is.

The food was fantastic, the wine was more so, and the sommelier and server were absolutely great and super attentive.  Lots and lots of pretty people too!  There are always celebs there (though that doesn't really impress me).

Of course, it all comes with a price tag.  But when you're gonna splurge, this ain't a bad joint to splurge at.
author: abdullah s.

description:
Ho Hum.

I don't understand all the big fuss about this restaurant.  The food is solid but not particularly intersting  Even the popular dishes, such as the veal meatballs and the ribs aren't particularly memorable.  The famous butterscotch pudding is tastey but,  ultimately, just butterscotch pudding.

Maybe I'm just jaded, but I expect a little more from a destination restaurant in San Francisco.  I'd easily choose One Market, Boulevard or Lulu over Town Hall, and all are in the same neighborhood, both price-wise and geographically.

Or so I've been told. Unfortunately, San Francisco's unfair and discriminatory health codes prohibit me from actually entering this restaurant.
author: spot d.

description:
Incredible.  The food and the service were absolutely impeccable.  I can't remember the last time I had a meal like this.  I ordered the duck which was served over wild rice with a gingersnap gravy.  The duck was a little dry but still totally delicious.  The rice mixed with the gravy made for an incredible flavor combination - the nuttiness of the rice and the sweetness of the gravy was just too much.  It's been a month since my meal there and I still can't stop thinking about it and wishing I could taste it again.  I will be back for it soon!

We ordered a side of (delicious!) croquttes with our meal.  When they didn't arrive, we asked our waitress about them, and she ran back to the kitchen.  They came out shortly thereafter, hot, fresh, and free of charge.

We went for my boyfriend's birthday and I called ahead and let them know to stick a candle in whatever dessert he orders.  We couldn't agree on a dessert and we were way too full to get one each, so I just asked for the check.  The waitress brought out the butterscotch/chocolate pot de creme with a candle in it anyway, on the house.  Now that's service!
author: Frankie D.

description:
The Food is great and on a nice night just going for a drink and appetizer outside is a treat.  The Pork Chops are fantastic!  One night we ate at the big picnic table in the front, which is just a big mashup of people and had a great time meeting new people.  Tough place to get into, so make sure you make reservations.  The Bathrooms are an adventure to find, but you are rewarded with a great picture in there of French people burning themselves four different ways.  Don't miss that.

Last night we started with the BBQ Shrimp for $13...very good.  A plate of yummy Oysters and a big bowl of Mussels...all very good.  For an Entree I got the lamb shank for $22.50 and it was really good.  

We sat outside where the service is no where near as good as inside.  Out of sight, out of mind with our waiter.  But it was a nice night, so it was fine.  We all loved our food and while we thought it was a bit pricey, it was worth it.
author: Pele N.

description:
Save your money.  It was good, but nothing to write home about.  As a Salt House devotee, I was hoping that the original would be even better, but I was disappointed.  

First of all, my friend and I had a 5:45pm reservation which worked perfectly for us timing wise, but the place looked more like an Outback Steakhouse with the amount of children dining there.  I was so surprised.  Not a good place for dirty girl talk and catching up.  

I ordered the Hama Hama oysters for a starter and they were good.  I have had smaller, more flavorful Hama Hamas though.  I don't think they got first pick of the bunch.

For my main I ordered the scallops on jambalaya with crab butter.  Now, I LOVE spicy food, and I was duly warned that the dish was spicy.  That was not the problem.  The problem was that the scallops were so overpowered by the jambalaya that I couldn't taste them.  I ended up taking them off of the top of the dish and eating them separately and then finishing with the Jambalaya.  It was easier just pretending they were two dishes because separately they were both good on their own.  

The cocktails were great though.  I would definitely go back for the cocktails alone.  My Manhattan was perfect, and my friend got a Cosmopolitan that she really liked.

Overall, there are so many GREAT places to eat in the city, I wouldn't go back here again unless my other options weren't available.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Due to its proximity to my workplace, Town Hall is more of a lunch spot than a dinner spot in my mind.  And for lunch, I LOVE the cobb salad.  

Cobb salad?  You might think me someone who eats healthily.  Well, not when you see how DRENCHED it is in DELICIOUS dressing!  Something about the way Town Hall prepares its chicken makes this salad memorable.  YUM!
author: Marcus C.

description:
I have never had a bad experience here, corporate account or an impromptu lunch with my friends.  The food has always been consistently good and the service top notch.  Prices are very reasonable, in my opinion.

Latest venture had me going for the tuna tartare appetizer...fabulous.   The bacon wrapped trout is de-vine!  It looked huge on the plate, but I ate everything because it all tasted so good.

My tummy is always very happy after a meal at Town Hall.
author: Maggie K.

description:
I really enjoyed Town Hall. It had a very mellow laid-back attitude. And it was so nice to see so many families with children out enjoying a nice dinner. I feel like I don't see that too often in LA. 

For appetizers, we shared oysters (ok... I ate them all and didn't share with the BF).  And we shared the barbecued shrimp appetizer.  The shrimp was good but I wasn't really down with the garlic herb toast... There were way too many flavors going on. 

For our main courses, we enjoyed the pork chop and the bacon wrapped fish (i think it was halibut... don't remember).  I'm still convinced anything wrapped in bacon tastes 10x better.

Get the Jalapeo Corn Bread, my friend recommended it to me and I wasn't going to order it since we had already ordered a lot of food, but the waiter mentioned and I was easily convinced. 

Was way too full for dessert even though I really wanted the pots de creme.  Next time want to sit at the bar and try some of their cocktails.
author: Susie M.

description:
The grilled ham and cheese sandwich with jalapeno creme will make you think you've died and gone to heaven.  And you just might die after consuming all of that fat but who cares?  You will die ridiculously happy.  It's one of the best things I've ever eaten.

Everything else was good too, the service was friendly and attentive, and the atmosphere was cozy.  The only negative is that it took absolutely forever for our food to arrive.  But when it did, it was incredibly delicious so I'll give them a pass.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Bette K.

description:
Dunno what took me so long to check this place out, but was finally able to swing by this place last night with a couple of out of town friends. I was a bit shocked that it was so crowded at 8:30 on a Sunday, but was glad we waited because the food here was fantastic!

We split the ham and poached egg toast with jalapeno cream which was pretty dang awesome and the veal meatballs that were melt in your mouth good.

I had the duck breast with duck leg over a succotashy mix of veggies along with some very tasty hushpuppies.

The waitstaff was great and I'd have to agree with some other reviewers that it was a bit loud, but all in all it was a fantastic meal. will definitely be back.
author: Joe C.

description:
Verdict: Overpriced for lunch.

Sooo I passed by Togos on my way to going to Town Hall for lunch, and you know I would have enjoyed my meal so much more if I had just eaten there! However my friend wanted to try out Town Hall...

I ordered the heirloom tomato panini/salad/soup-of-the-day combo ($16 - ouch!!), which was my first mistake. In describing my order choice to the guy at the bar seating area, he thought I wanted a bowl of the soup-of-the-day in addition to my entree. I didn't know any better, so I ate the soup when it arrived before the entree (Cream of corn... too sweet and heavy. Ug). I realized the mistake when my entree arrived - panini, salad, and... another cup of soup? Nonono, I had to ask the server to remove the bowl of soup from our bill. 

From then on, the meal was tainted. The panini was overly greasy, and the salad had an unappetizing bitter dressing on it so I didn't eat it. Overall, I only ate half of the bowl of soup, and the panini. Salad and cup of soup untouched. 

Unsatisfying, especially for the price. My stomach now feels very heavy from all that grease. Ug!!! 

Maybe this place is better at dinner, who knows. I will not be coming back.
author: Nicole C.

description:
A shocking event inspired me to start writing reviews on yelp - Townhall took the sticky toffee cake (and the short ribs to make it worse)  off the menu!?!? 

I had been to Townhall at least five times before with my fiance.  It's the type of place I request to go for my birthday and anytime someone comes to town.  We booked the reservation for the sticky toffee cake (and my guy was looking forward to short ribs).. saved room during the meal especially for dessert... and GASP!  It was gone!  The pastry chef had left and the new one doesn't want to make the other's signature dish?!?!?  Why not it was FANTASTIC!?   We had another reservation booked for 1.5 weeks later to take another friend, but now we are searching for some where else.   Shouldn't take your best items off the menu!

Townhall has a good atmosphere, somewhat noisy, BBQ appetizer is always a must have for us (I hope they are not thinking of removing it from the menu!), great attentive servers that can make good recommendations and know the food.   

If you are wondering what ordered :

appetizers- BBQ shrimp (YUM), and the pulled pork sliders - they made 3 sandwiches and skipped the side ribs that came with is so we could each have one which was really nice.. they were pretty good.

dinners - mom: Buttermilk fried chicken (she seemed to enjoy it, and my guy at the left overs so it must have been good), and he and I both had the pork chop - not a big fan of grits but it was really tasty, tender, and nice clean flavors.  

Dessert - doughnuts and chocolate chunk cake.  eh.  I didn't really notice the chunks in the cake, it was basically chocolate cake with a scoop of ice cream, and the doughnuts were good, but neither blew me away.  (Unlike the sticky toffee cake....)

Wines by the glass were fantastic - my fiance and I had the shiraz by the glass, very good.      

I think we spent near $200 for the three of us, all having a glass (or two) of wine.  I absolutely recommend this place.
author: Erica L.

description:
I had the fried chicken, it was the best I've ever had. The waitress said "I'll have you know this is the best in the city". I haven't sampled a wide variety of fried chicken in the city but I'm inclined to believe her.

They serve Acme bread (my favorite). The service was great and I prefered it to Salt House, where they kinda looked at me funny for not knowing anything about oysters.
author: Nathan M.

description:
It reminds me of a New England Library, with the wood features and the check being brought in an old book. 

The charm is beautiful. The service is great. The crowds have slowed a little since it's opening, but it is still a restaurant to consider for a night on the town. After dinner, you can easily go to a movie or a nice walk on the Embarcadero. 

As to the food, it is consistent. It has some great flavors. I love the shrimp appetizer and the fried chicken. The pork chop is tender and juicy as well.  I have missed the "World's Best Hot Chocolate" dessert, which really is delicious. I can't wait for it's return. 

Give it a try, you won't be upset.
author: Christopher W.

description:
Yum!   I don't know that I should have started off with the fondue, because I didn't really want to stop eating it.  If that fondue were a man, I would have taken him home right then.  The beets were pretty good, too, but nothing special.  

I was a little jealous after sampling my friend's duck etoufee, but my short ribs were perfectly done and delicious.  My only disappointment was that the portion of chard that came with my short ribs was limited to about 1/16 of a leaf, and it was pretty damn delicious, and I could have used more.  How expensive is chard, anyway?  No need to be stingy!

Overall, the service was wonderful (one of the waitresses was so excited about the bottle of wine we ordered that she felt the need to leave her table and top off our glasses).
author: Rebecca M.

description: Great place for Lunch. Great service and ppl. Had the burger rare. Lunch came out to be $62 inc Tip for two. My friend had the Shrimp Po-boy, Soda, and coffee.
author: Johnson H.

description: Good, but with the right choices and attention, both of which were lacking on my visit. Service was only fair, and not frequently present.  Fried oyster app was not warm, salad was good but nothing special. Fried chicken was as good as Front Porch, pork loin was tiny and the pork belly was disgusting.  Dessert was best part of the meal; sinfully rich pot au creme and spot-on warm beignets. Cool interior, kinda loud, bar looks like more fun than dining room. I'd heard people rave about this place, but it didn't grab me.
author: shane o.

description: Went for dinner with a friend.  Every time I am in the city I am told to dine here. I finally did...and won't again.  We ordered several items to share and the only item we could say was good was the jambalaya.  The guests next to us had there entire check comped because of how poorly they felt about both their meals.
author: D s.

description:
HOT SPOT CALLING...

Town Hall (a place of gathering) is certainly worth gathering! It's southern comfort food combined with fresh, modern cuisine in a great dining space.  Formerly an old ship manufacturing co., the restaurant is warm and inviting with brick walls and soft lighting and chic chandeliers. The restaurant borders between casual and elegant and has a very relaxed vibe.  There is plenty of street parking outside the restaurant, which is a rarity in san francisco!

As us 4 girls entered for our 8:45 reservation (yes, I couldn't get one earlier), I realized that perhaps the red dress and oversized black clutch I had with me were perhaps too dressy for fried chicken, but the sophistication of the restaurant was just at the right level to give a gal an excuse to get dressed up!

 We arrived a bit early hoping they could seat us earlier and were accomodated so by the friendly front staff who sat us about 20 min's earlier.  

Appetizers we ordered included cornmeal fried oysters with spinach puree and bacon, buttermilk biscutis with country ham and peaches, and yellowtail sashimi with melon. For an entree I ordered trout stuffed with crab and also tried the buttermilk fried chicken with gravy and mash potatoes and the scallop dish my friends had ordered. Everything was delicious and we found ourselves finishing every bite on the plates. 

My top picks of must orders:

APPETIZERS: The buttermilk biscuits with the country ham and peach compote. The biscuits were too die for and the prosciutto style ham is an interesting pairing, but worked well.

ENTREE:  Buttermilk Fried chicken with mash potatoes and gravy. It was crispy without being oily and was perfectly cooked.

Overall, the staff was friendly and helpful. We were dining with a friend who was gluten intolerant and they were able to make some suggestions and check with the chef on ingredients. 

Some negatives:

The service was a bit slow on the night we went. It took about 40 min's for our main dishes to arrive after the appetizers. 

The bar area is great, but it's small and if you arrive late you won't find a seat. The restaurant itself gets very crowded and crammed. We learned this the hard way.

The acoustics are incredibly loud. It's great for groups, but a bit loud for intimate conversations.

Overall, great place, great food and great atmosphere. It's worth the reservation.
author: Laura L.

description: Delicious as always. Highly recommend the shrimp starter and petrale sole. Service was good - they noticed we had brought flowers for our friend and guessed it was her birthday!
author: GS M.

description: I'm never going back here again. The scallops came totally crunchy! Yes, crunchy! Yuck! The drinks were mediocre and the service was terrible. It took forever to get our food. By the time they got to my appetizer order, my friends were already finished with their entrees. Awful!
author: Mei F.

description: been here severely times throughout the years.  i remember last valentine's day was pretty bad, everything was salty.  wait shit, i went there last night and the duck leg confit was super salty.  so saltiness is a factor here.  had wagyu beef cheeks, was very excited but not when it came.  i thought it would be fatty and flavorful, instead it was dry and bland.  veal meatballs always good, but it was a bit too salty again.  bbq shrimp not too special.  that's all me and my friend had.
author: Kevin L.

description:
The food at Town Hall is American Comfort food with a twist, and the atmosphere fits. It's elegant, but they keep it comfortable, unpretentious, and fun, with little twists like bills that come to you in vintage books, recipe card bookmarks instead of business cards, and so on.  

I've only come here for drinks and bar food, but the service was solid--attentive and professional.  The specialty drinks are fun and consistently well-made. The Driver 8 (Bulleit Bourbon with brandied cherries and honey) is a favorite, and they also make a modified capirinha with kumquat.  My friend is partial to the Louisiana Purchase, a spicy Domaine de Canton cocktail that comes with a touch of cayenne.

I can't evaluate the food in the restaurant, just at the bar, but the country ham on buttermilk biscuits with pepper jelly literally melts in your mouth...There is also usually a superb selection of soups and salads, and the jalapeno cornbread is the perfect complement to any of these!
author: Bear S.

description: This is actually one of my favorite restaurants in the world, I had some of the menu items replicated at our wedding.  Do not leave without trying the BBQ shrimp.  The Tuna tartare, raw oysters, and fried oysters are also excellent, as is the wine list.  The biscuits and meatballs are also very good.  We typically order several appetizers and one main course to split, try the sea bass, salmon, fried chicken, or pork tenderloin.  This is not a restaurant to miss if you go to San Francisco or Napa.
author: Matteo M.

description:
must haves: the burger, the gnocchi, the scallops, and absolutely DO NOT LEAVE without the butterscotch pots de creme. the toffee cake is a distant second. its excellent, but nothing approaches the perfection of the pots de creme.

Service is always friendly and efficient. Genuine people doing good work serving good food. Nuff said. 

Classy, comfortable downtown-type decor. Love the communal table! Nice spot for a classic san francisco lunch. Get the gnocchi!
author: Dama J.

description:
I just got back from lunch here and it was omg so good. 

I came here a few years ago for dinner and had been meaning to go back, but it wasn't until today that I made the leap. 

I had the blackened catfish with oyster and andouille rice. The catfish was perfectly cooked and seasoned. It was super moist, but had a great outer crust. awesome. The rice was delish as well, and I loved the little bites of oyster. For dessert, my lunch partner and I split the pot de creme and the sweet potato pie. Both were excellent. The service was also fantastic. 

So why only 4 stars? I have to subtract one for the fact that I found not one but two bones in my catfish, which is kind of Food Prep 101. However, the restaurant was so gracious about it that they gave us our desserts for free, and the manager came over to personally apologize.

I will definitely not let another 3 years go by before I come back.
author: Kathleen D.

description: We had an enjoyable Friday dinner at Town Hall.  The interior is such that you might expect Ben Franklin to walk by.  The bar area was packed.  My pork medallions were properly cooked and flavorful.  The fried chicken had a nice crispy crust but was still moist.  The duck comfit was melt in your mouth good.  The BBQ shrimp were also very good.  Our server had just a bit of attitude.  I moved the bread basket to the side of the table to make room for the coming appetizers.  The next time he passed the table he moved the bread back to the center of the table.  After that plates were set down on the table rather briskly.
author: Tim K.

description: This is one of those new restaurants that I think is overly hyped.  The food was good, yes.  The service, however,  was AWFUL though and pretty much ruined the experience!  We were there for a very early dinner and it felt like we were being RUSHED out, even though it was empty.  I hate those experiences and this gets 3 stars for that reason!
author: Ani N.

description:
I made an online reservation at Town Hall in SOMA - a place I had been to once or twice before but only for lunch. My memories were fond (especially as they centered around butterscotch pudding) and I knew S had never been so I was really looking forward to being wow'd once again by the great culinary workings of the kitchen staff. Unfortunately, we were wow'd but not in a positive way. We should have seen the foreshadowing on the wall with our first encounter with the restaurant as it wasn't a necessarily positive one.

Our reservation was at 6pm and traffic through the city was heavier than we expected (Fleet week plus the Blue Angles makes for heavy congestion). I decide perhaps we should call the restaurant to let them know that we may be a few minutes late (I'm Ms. Punctuality, can you tell?). It was maybe 5:50 at this point and my guess was that we were probably going to get there at ten after - at the latest. S calls (as a courtesy I'm sure because many people don't call when running late) and is told by the hostess that we better get there before 6:15 or they'll give our table away. Ok - I'm really excited to spend a lot of money at your restaurant with that lovely precursor.

We arrive (at 6:08) and are brought to our table. The restaurant is really very lovely - very American, very SOMA, very quirky, nice. Lots of wood accents, brick walls, hardwood floors which are beautiful but which also make it difficult to hear the person sitting across from you. I digress. I love the atmosphere - it's hip yet comfortable and even the pipe jutting out of the wall directly to my right only added to the loft-like vibe happening at Town Hall. S and I look over the menu and what strikes us is how every single starter looks amazing and yet none of the main entrees is catching either of our sets of eyes. Is it possible one could craft an entire meal from appetizers alone? If I had had it my way, we would have but in the interest of being civilized we decided to share two starters and then we'd each order a entrée. We choose the barbecue shrimp dish which sounded a lot like the shrimp recipe that's one of my favorite dishes of all times and the vermouth, blue cheese fondue.

At this point in our dining experience, all was going well except that after our waiter dropped off our drinks we didn't see him for a good 25 minutes (we hadn't even placed our starter orders yet). I overlooked this as I was just happy sitting and talking with S but still - 25 minutes! He returns, we place our orders and very shortly thereafter out come our starters.

Next out came our entrees and I was excited. I ordered the buttermilk fried chicken with Brussels sprouts, mashed potatoes and bacon gravy. S ordered the seafood etoufee and it all looked sublime. I dove right into my dish and was immediately stopped short by iodine shock I received from my first bite of crisp, chicken skin. I tried it once more thinking I had probably just eaten an "off" piece but again I was shocked by the levels of salt. I started thinking that my taste buds were off kilter so I asked S to try. He did and couldn't finish the piece I had given him. I tried the skin on the other pieces on my plate and they were fine so I was happy to push the offending piece aside and try again. This time, I wasted no time with the skin and cut right into the chicken thigh. My fork and knife seemed to penetrate the chicken a little too easily so I look a little closer. Wouldn't you know my chicken was raw. Not pink, not rare, but raw. Apparently it was cooked to perfection on the outside but not on the inside which is quite easy to do with fried chicken especially as a novice home chef. Not quite what one would expect at a fine dining establishment. We called the waiter over, he rushed the dish away and 20 minutes later, long after S had finished his dinner, my chicken arrived with a bit of a scolding from our waiter. He let me know that usually chicken is a little pink near the bone. Oh really? That I could handle. What I can't handle is pink far from the bone. A tell tale sign that the meat hadn't been cooked!

We ordered dessert next. S ordered the Mud Pie and I ordered "San Francisco's Best Hot Chocolate." We also ordered a butterscotch pudding to go for S's sister who was watching T and a glass or port for S to enjoy with his chocolate concoction. When they brought out our desserts all looked fine but fine it was not. Mine was essentially room temperature and so rich that it was undrinkable - almost like a runny pudding, but not quite. S found part of the port label floating in his glass and it was then we surrendered. Tonight was just not going to be our night. When we got the bill, the waiter let us know he "took a couple things off for us" which included the port and butterscotch pudding (one of the only things that was fine).

All in all, I loved having two, wonderful uninterrupted hours with S but having to pay nearly $200 for mediocrity at best is not high on my list.
author: Erin H.

description: This place was really fantastic.  Went here for lunch with my parents on Saint Patrick's day since I had been wanting to go here for a while and they gave me a good excuse.  My scallop ceviche was yummers and my cocktail was to die for.  The only reason I am knocking it a star is because my pork tenderloin was overcooked and really dry.  Luckily they gave you lots of sauce, caramelized pears and creamy polenta to compensate.  The accompaniments were all really fantastic, especially the creamy polenta....YUM!  I could have eaten just a bowl of that!  I will for sure give them a second try and hopefully this time they wont overcook anything so I can give them the five stars they probably deserve!
author: Caleb R.

description: After all the hype I have heard over the years I was excited to finally be eating at Town Hall but unfortunately I must say it is over rated.  I loved the energy of the restaurant and our server was attentive but the food was a real disappointment.  I had the fried oysters as a starter and when they arrived at the table they were barely tepid, like they should have been picked up from the kitchen 10 minutes ago.  We tried the veal meatballs and the one I had was grisly.  The duck liver pate was pretty good though.  I ordered the short ribs for my entree and I was surprised when the waiter brought me a steak knife before my entree arrived.  Guess what though, I needed it.  The short ribs arrived at about the same temperature as the oysters and they were over cooked, dry, and tough.  Properly cooked short ribs should be fork tender and these required a steak knife - enough said.  I had the pot de creme for desert and it was very good.  All in all, there are at least 100 restaurants in SF better than Town Hall so I would not waste my time going here again.
author: Bryan M.

description:
Great American food with a New Orleans twist and an even better two-floor contemporary design. Jalapeno corn bread is a must.
http://www.lipglossculture.com/2011/street-pop-san-francisco-local-favorites-where-to-shop-eat-and-party/3/
author: Katie G.

description:
Just had lunch at Town Hall today.  Thank you Google reps!  

It's a very nice place for lunch and they've got some tasty sandwich options.  Dinner there is tasty as well.  Although the time I went with my fam it was super loud in there.  So much so that the parents were complaining about it.  Today, I had the salmon which was cooked to perfection along with a yummy corn ragout.  I like how they give your your check inside an old book, it's fun.
author: Steve S.

description:
My favorite venue for client lunches.  Conveniently located, with good food at reasonable prices and quick service.

The only knock is that it is loud as hell, so try and get a table in one of the back corners, and not along the walk way.

Fried oysters, duck breast, cornbread, butter lettuce salad and fried green tomatoes are my favorite.

The hot chocolate is the best in the city!  But order one for two.
author: Jacob J.

description:
Great Lunch spot. I haven't tried dinner.

Lives up to the rep.

Good for Client lunches.
author: Isaac N.

description:
I'm disappointed to see so many negative reviews although I certainly understand.  However, for me, Town Hall was AMAZING every time we have gone.  Started last year for our 3 year anniversary and have been back a few times since.

FIRST: The waitress on Saturday nights with shorter blonde hair. She is the best waitress, hands down, I have ever had, with the one exception at Chez Spencer on Valentines Day 2005. She is fun, jubilant, on top her shit, and actually remembered us on our next visit.

SECOND: The crab fondue is YUUMBO!  It's like it's not even fondue, it's more like a thick mushroom soup thing I can't explain. And then you dip Andouille sausage and potatoes in it. 

THIRD: They serve jalapeno cornbread in these adorable little cast iron corn shape molds.  

FOURTH: They have a really great wine list and one of our favorite wines is only $28.

FIFTH: The bar makes excellent drinks. The food is good and hearty (American cuisine w/ New Orleans influence).

Drawbacks: gets crowded so the wait WITH reservations is sometimes too long for my taste but I don't really care since I know I'm in for a great time whenever I finally sit down.
author: Jerkey J.

description:
I had a few co-workers visiting from out of town tonight so I took them to Town Hall and we had a lovely meal. Although it was a little loud I thought  the food, the service and the atmosphere was great.  

Yep, I would definitely go back.
author: christine c.

description:
Town Hall deserves 5 stars alone for its soups.  I know, this sounds crazy to most of you...  Go for lunch or dinner, it doesn't matter which - and order the soup du jour.   You will be simply amazed.  How does heirloom tomato puree with cream and drizzled basil-infused olive oil sound?  Yep.

Now move down the menu... you'll still be impressed.  Even their fish and chips, on the lunch menu, will surprise you.

Great wine list to boot.

Tip:  great lunch spot, and for those who dare not drink during lunch, they have great non-alcoholic refreshers.
author: Dave K.

description:
What a night!! This place met all my expectations. My boyfriend actually 'yelp' before we left and said there were lots of mixed reviews and not to expect good service. Well contrast to many 'yelpers', we experienced great service. The waiter was attentive but didn't rush us. All of his suggestions were a grand-slam! We loved the tempura squash blossoms, ham and cheese toast with jalapeo cream, and this skillet with calamari and chorizo. The only mediocre part was the main course. The bacon wrapped trout was good but the halibut was served in this super heavy cream sauce and was just too rich and I have a hard time admitting that because I love rich food.
The dessert was out-of-this-world. This chocolate heath custard goodness. So Yummy!!
 My my my. I needed to be rolled home but sure was worth it!!!
author: Gina C.

description:
LOVEEEEE TOWN HALL!!!! As I frequent here after work with my trusted dine about co-workers, i will definately recommend this place! Service is great and food is soooooooo GOOD!!! The menu has FRIED CHICKEN on it...lol but don't let that discourage you from the type of restaurant this place might be...okay you know what, i can't even describe this place to give it its right recognition.
Try the Oysters,Fried Chicken,Prime Rib,Cajun style shrimp - and um ALL the desserts...haha bec it's just that good but can be on the pricier side.. AHH!, but what can i say - it's worth it!!!

Kitty's tip - don't get cheap and order just one thing - go all out and order it ALL!!! haha because everything on the menu is YUMMMMY! Its so cute inside with the chandeliers and the brick walls - Its cozy and great for entertaining with friends - but DEFINATELY make reservations because it gets packed FAST. Good for happy hour too! =)
author: Kay C.

description:
I have been incredibly impressed by this restaurant on several occassions. I tend to take my out of town friends here for dinner, and love popping in for lunch when I'm playing hooky (or one of my three hour lunch breaks) from work. I have to say that  the last time was one of the best experiences I've ever had at a San Francisco restaurant. 

First, atmosphere is killer. You can sit at the communal table if you want, but I prefer to a comfy table towards the back, or plop on a barstool sippin; on a Woodford Reserve Manhatten. The clientele is great here, it's trendy and San Francisco for sure, but it's a lot of more down to Earth people in jeans and H&M shirts. I wish it was slightly darker inside, but that's a personal preference, doesn't really hurt.

The service is an A+++++ every time. I forget our waitresses name, but she was friendly outgoing, talked to the sommelier about my wine choice and helped me pick a great bottle of Two Hands from Australia. They know the menu, they make great recommendations and for a restaurant of this high caliber they are super unpretentious and make you feel right at home as you blow 300  bucks. Their sister restaurant The Salt House, which is OK, should take a service cue from Town Hall because them and ISA have the best service in the city.

OK,OK, you are going here for the food and the wine, and both are just resplendent. The tuna Tartar is the best I've ever had, and the veal meatballs are not to be missed. I had the halibut last time and is was to die for, my date had the slow roasted duck and it was so succulent I was overly impressed. They also do a good ol' fashioned fried chicken, which is just heavenly. The wine list is well thought out, and is more in line with new world wines. I tend to drink Aussie, New Zealand and Santa  Lucia wines from here., though they do have some good Burgundies. 

All in all this truly is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco, and if you read my reviews I'm a food snob. Highly, highly recommended!!!!
author: Steve l.

description:
Hype can be a bad thing because rarely does a place measure up to it and this was definitley the case for me with Town Hall.  I thought the ambiance was so, so, but I would have expected more given the prices.  The tuna tartar appetizer was delicious and unique but I found the entrees to be entirely forgetable.  

Having moved to SF recently from NYC this restaurant had been on my "to try" list for a while, but I can't say I'd make huge effort to go back because there are too many better restaurants in this town (including sister restaurants Salt House and Anchor & Hope, but of which I enjoyed more than this place).
author: Raj-Ann R.

description:
Has a split personality...

Jekyll: Appetizers were very good: Squash blossoms perfectly cooked, tuna tartare surprising - not the usual Asian flavor profile, and a soft shell crab BLT (but only a couple of bites did the fantasy justice). Dessert DE-lish: butterscotch pot de crème (love me, love me, SAY THAT YOU LOVE ME) and Sticky Date (bread) pudding. Service: Honest dessert choice help and I was allowed to taste two different pinots to make decision- appropriately right before the entrée after I'd finished my 'first course' glass without a second request to do so, charge for a problem in the dessert removed without asking. 4 stars.

Hyde: Food: THE vegetarian entrée only so so, both entrées not appropriately hot, LARGE DATE PIT (the size of an almond for those of you not experienced with unknowingly biting onto one) found in otherwise delicious gooey dessert (and the way it was handled was a bit odd: first shocked and apologetic -I believe his exact words were 'Mercy' - think Scarlet O'Hara in New Orleans, then after its removal, nothing - and the guy said he was going to the kitchen to look into it and would return). The rest: Whole restaurant quite chilly, service was, with a few exceptions, nice but fake (not necessarily theatrical but definitely out of a bag - and no this is not the first restaurant I've ever been to). Nearly untouched entrée LEFTOVERS NOT RETURNED to us with the rest - so, essentially, we paid for an uneaten entrée (and clearly we forked out for this meal). 1.5 stars

Still, if it were less expensive I would go back and try to find that menu combination that puts Town Hall on SF Gate's TOP100.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Let me start with a disclaimer: my 5 is for lunch, which is the only thing I've eaten here (4 times).  The lunch prices are not cheap but the money is totally worth it.  Because the dinner menu is so much more expensive I can't speak to whether it's worth it (although I assume it would be).  

The atmosphere is really nice, and all the waiters I've had have been good.  I especially love when I ask a waiter for help choosing between 2 things and they give you a definite answer, which my waiter did last time!  Fish tacos or duck enchiladas?  Duck enchiladas, no doubt.  I still haven't tried the fish tacos, but the enchiladas were awesome.  Actually, it was the tangy tomatillo sauce that was awesome.  I've also had the open face ham sandwich with a poached egg and jalapeno cream and LOVED it.  They also have the most delicious fries which I tried from my friend's Town Hall burger plate that she said was great.

Highly recommended.
author: Erin D.

description:
I didn't want to like this place, but it won me over with excellent service and good food.

The hostess, waiter, bus people, and other staff couldn't have given our group of eight better service.  It was a Friday night and they were busy, but the service didn't suffer for one second.  Our water glasses were never empty, something few restaurants seem to be able to accomplish.

I wasn't going to order the pork chop, but the waiter recommended it and it was very good.  The fried oysters were good (and I don't normally like that sort of thing) and the brussel sprouts were great.  The ham and cheese sandwich may not sound like much, but it is fantastic - crunchy as can be, with a wonderful sauce.  

We ordered every dessert on the menu.  The parfait was a loser - not one of us liked it.  I didn't see the point of the donuts, other than they fit the New Orleans style.  The best was the pot de creme, but I found the chocolate half of it to be too harsh.  

The staff accomodated all of our requests - sharing of appetizers, ordering every dessert, asking for a flight of all the ports.  This resulted in a lot of plates on the table, but it was never a problem because they were whisked away the moment they were empty.

Minus one star for noise (like most restaurants in SF, they need to do something to dampen the echo), rock hard uncomfortable chairs, and below par desserts.
author: Bay G.

description: Good food. Terrible service. We frankly thought our waiter was either drunk or stoned. You really should not come back to the table 3 times to clarify a drink order that consisted of vodka on the rocks with no garnish--and even then the drink came with olives. Same with the food order. It was so lame it ended up being funny.
author: Michael L.

description: Town Hall Fried Chicken was sooo much better than Fried Chicken at Jollibee!!!!!! 1000x better! -Matt
author: Matthew C.

description: Our server was very attentive, explained and talked to us with so much professionalism and detailed information about the menu and wine.   We had ribs & seafoods. The Mac & cheese was mouth watering (I've never liked mac & cheese except for the way it was prepared there) and so was the jambalaya (with just enough spicy kick in it).  The wine selection was good, too.   I like this restaurant.  Even though the food is not the best, the ambience and service was great.
author: Cristina T.

description: I have been there before and remembered that it was just okay. This last experience has confirmed that. The food was average and the service was non-existant. I did bring it up to the manager and he was helpful and gave us free dessert. Won't go back.
author: Heidi C.

description: I had such a wonderful time at Town Hall I had to write a review to make sure they get the credit they deserve. My girlfriend and I had dinner last night with reservations at 9pm. Upon arriving we were greeted by a super nice and attentive staff and seated within 2-3 minutes. The menu was delicious. We ordered two appitizers and one entreee to share. From the tuna tartar to the aparagus salad with carmelized strawberries I was a lady in food heaven. The catfish as our main entree was mouth watering. Too bad we had no room for dessert. I will be back and ready to try another evening with Town Hall as well as the plentiful options for a delightful dinner in the city.
author: Megan G.

description: I really enjoyed my meal here. For my entree I got the Beeler Farms pork chop, fingerling potatoes, Fuji apples, peanut tasso butter, and apple cider jus for a mere $27. This was probably one of the best dishes I've had in San Francisco yet, and it was definitely the best pork chop I've ever had in my life. It's quite pricey, but worth it in my opinion. I wasn't so much a fan of my dessert  a butterscotch and chocolate Pot de Creme, but everything else was fantastic. I also had to sign my name somewhere in the book that they bring you for your checks. Everyone writes such interesting things in there! Check out my full review here  http://veiwtifuljoe.wordpress.com/2010/10/10/joe-convenes-at-town-hall/
author: Joseph F.

description:
Fantastic southern/comfort food!  We loved the fried oysters (outstanding), ribs, and fried chicken.  The okra was fresh and tasty (and also fried).  The cocktails and service were perfect.

Town hall has a nice atmosphere and good, accessible location. We want to come back to this restaurant!!
author: Sarah W.

description:
Love this place.  If you are looking for "New American" food done right, look no more, this place is it.

Cool space, good service, great food.
author: Adam J.

description: The service is getting worse and worse.  Food stays good.  But last time they could not figure out how to calculate sales tax.
author: Patty M.

description:
Went here for my birthday with my wife, and loved it.

Great decor with laid back feel that still felt intimate and energetic. You could tell the place was a happening spot but didn't feel overly trendy; instead it was just really comfortable from the time you walked in.

The wine list was great and the two glasses we ordered were both really good. We started with the BBQ shrimp, which we both loved and finished in about three seconds. It was unlike anything I'd had before.

I had the fried chicken, which was filling and delicious. The collared greens with it were perfect and sweet. I'm not a huge grits fan, but they tasted pretty good. My wife had the etouiffee (sp?) and really liked it. 

The service was a tad slow, but it didn't bother us since we were there on a busy Saturday night. 

I really liked the mix between high quality simple food in a cool looking restaurant that was not pretentious or over the top. Everyone there seemed to be having a good time. I'd go back for sure. The bar area looked pretty nice too, if you just want to get a drink.
author: Scott G.

description: My girlfriend and I went there last Friday, before Bill T. Jones, so it was a sweet date night. The food was fine, I had bacon wrapped trout, so I was happy. And, they had blue bottle coffee and a really great bus boy and waiter. The main reason they get two stars is because they charged us $400+ for dinner--ours was $136--and they swiped someone else's $268 dinner, with no apology, no graciousness for the mistake, and it still has not been taken off...her bank is dealing with it, but it's been almost two weeks. For this, we will not return--the food wasn't worth it.
author: andreana c.

description: I'm a chocolate lover.  If the dessert isn't chocolate, I usually pass.  Luckily, my friend ordered for us the first time I had dinner at Town Hall.  Dessert was their "Donuts and Coffee', which is comprised of freshly made, mini donut holes, coffee ice cream, and chicory strusel.  AMAZING!  Remember Meg Ryan in the dinner scene from When Harry Met Sally?  I'm guessing a table or two asked to have what I was having.  Yum, yummy.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Heard about Town Hall from a friend, and went there for a business dinner this week.  Great experience, and certainly lived up to any expectations that I might have had.

The ambiance is clean, classic...almost a mix of loft and chabby chic.  Lofted ceilings, brick interior, hardwood floors, white wood walls, slightly worn to give a softer feel.

The menu seems California Classic with a slightly French touch.  They offered a wide selection of meat dishes, several seafood dishes, and a Vegetarian risotto.  I opted for the Vegetarian risotto, which very well may have been the greatest risotto I've ever had in my life.  Truffle oil, yes please!

We started with a mix of the fresh raw oysters and shared the BBQ'd shrimp w/ Worchestershire sauce and garlic herb toast as an appetizer.  The description sounded intense, but man...was that sauce awesome!  I had to hold back from polishing off the fresh baked bread they give for the table just to mop up the rest of the sauce.  

The wine list is extensive enough to give you plenty of options, but isn't overwhelming.  

The service was really fantastic!  Our server was clearly a professional.  Incredibly friendly, attentive, great timing, and made sure that all the glasses were filled with wine and water before you could even give it a 2nd thought.

The menu and prices overall are about $20-$28/entree.  So, it's in a good zone to be a special occasion dinner without completely breaking the bank.  No doubt that I'll be a repeat customer.
author: Heather W.

description: I came here on a fun date; it was a party of 20; food was limited to a fixed menu; average to slightly above average given the fact that it is always difficult to cook for a large group; good atmosphere; restaurant is a renovated 1907 warehouse on the fringe of SoMa; great for a big group as they sat us on the heated patio at a large communal table.
author: Ashley E.

description: Had a business dinner here last night... food was uniformly excellent; the noise level was nearly unbearable.   Good place, but desperately in need of some acoustic damping.
author: Michael G.

description: The single best decision my husband and I made while wedding planning was to have our reception at Town Hall.  We had never gone to the restaurant before, but stumbled upon it one day while touring various possible wedding venue sites in San Francisco.  We instantly fell in love with the décor and overall vibe of the place.  The next step, of course, was to sample their food, and it did not disappoint.  Their pork risotto was so simple, homey, and delicious that it literally brought a man tear to my husband's eye.  When they said we could have a whole pig roast for our reception dinner, it pretty much sealed the deal.  Those of you who are currently or have ever planned a wedding know how stressful such an undertaking can be.  I think one of the best wedding advice we can give having just gone through the process ourselves is this: liking your vendors and getting along with them makes a world of difference!  Fortunately Marissa, Town Hall's event coordinator, was a pleasure to work with.  She is incredibly friendly, patient, responsive, and professional.  She worked great with our wedding coordinator, and together, they made sure that our event was executed perfectly.  All of Town Hall's staff is top notch.  You can tell that they take great pride in their work.  Our guests had a wonderful time and even now, weeks after the event, mention how great the food, service, and venue is.  Highly recommended!
author: Jax L.

description:
We dined at Town Hall, in a party of 4, on a Wednesday night and I must say that, having never heard of the restaurant before, we came away fairly impressed.  Service was prompt, friendly and good, (it's nice that they refold your napkins when you leave the table), but the quality of the food is the real stand-out.  The starters, particularly the ham & cheese "sandwich", were absolutely fantastic, though you should know they are a bit rich and - for us - a bit too generous.  The mains were equally impressive.  My trout was cooked to perfection, and very delicious, and the fried chicken was another stand-out.  Deserts were creative and yummy.  In short, we had a really excellent meal.

Having said that . . . and this is completely subjective . . . I didn't much care for the room itself.  The entry, through some kind of an outdoor tent area, was weird.  Then, you had to fight your way through a crowded, narrow bar area, to get into the dining room, which was really just a large, sparse space with heavy wooden tables and no tablecloths.  I get the hip "bistro" vibe . . . it just didn't appeal to me, particularly at this price point.

A few minor nits, too.  Service had a "process" feel to it.  For example, we intentionally delayed ordering so that we could enjoy cocktails at the table first and catch up with our friends.  The bus station was near our table and we could see the bus person waiting to bring bread to our table, which would have been nice with our drinks, but their process clearly says that bread is not served until after you order.  Sure enough, the minute we placed our dinner order, wham . . . the bread finally appeared.  Another item . . . there is a standing ashtray just outside the front door.  It was overflowing with fast-food cups and banana peels, which no one bothered to clean . . . As your first impression, it was a bit trashy.  But, as I said, these are just nits.

In sum, the food was outstanding, the location and parking are good, and we will probably return when we next are looking for an easy downtown dinner spot.
author: Sebastian T.

description: The outdoor BBQ is great, in particular the crispy/fried chicken sandwich with a side of BBQ sauce. It is only a summer deal and sometimes they run out of it after the lunch rush. They have the supplies for an Arnold Palmer as well, and a good one at that. Price is a little high for the size of the sandwich but not bad.
author: Captain B.

description: This place as the best tuna tar tar, the BEST! So good. It can get very loud here as the space is pretty open and voices just get amplified. Gets a big lunch and dinner crowd, make reservations!  Their fried chicken entree is quite tasty, well seasoned & juicy.  Good Service. Don't take your honey on a romantic dinner here, it's too loud to be intimate but the food here is very good.
author: Ka C.

description: This is a good American food restaurant good wine list and the service is good not excellent it can get very loud and crowded so if your dinning next to the bar and have a date wont be very pleasant but overall food is simple and good i find the cooking bit bland
author: SAMAY A.

description:
You know why I like Town Hall, because they like you.  The staff is sophisticated not snobby.  You know how you are sometimes treated by the hostess like they can barely stand to let you in and let you pay them $200 bucks for bottle of wine and two entrees - this is not the case at Town Hall.  Pair the warm service with the, super low maintenance and friendly bartenders - your first impressions will leave a pleasant taste in your mouth through dinner and dessert.  

The food is a solid good - not Boulevard great but consistent and delicious.  Save room, the pudding is peerless.  Or plan a very fun/sexy date and go there for a bottle of red and pot of pudding for two.  

If you don't want to wait go between lunch and dinner around 5 or 5:30.
author: Wendy F.

description:
The staff at the Mandarian Oriental recommended Town Hall for a birthday celebration.  What a great recommendation!   The room is large and open.  Busy and hectic, but in a fun, urban feel.  The staff was friendly and were able to help with suggestions.  Somebody was always there to check on us.  
We all loved our meals.  My partner had the pork chop and loved it, the kids both had steak and loved it.  We all had Butterscotch Pot de Creme for dessert and it was something I will think about for a long time - YUM, YUM, YUM!   We loved it.   Service, food and decor - all get an A+!
author: James S.

description:
I had dinner here with 2 friends on Saturday (July 21), and it was a mixed bag.  Not the greatest location...  once dusk arrives, it doesn't feel that safe walking there from Market Street, and it's not easy to flag a cab from that location.

I liked the fact that the room got a lot of light, the ceilings were pretty high, and the casual vibe makes for a relaxed room.  Chairs are comfortable.  Service was attentive, and (to their credit) honest.  When we asked about recommendations, there were a couple of dishes that our server implied weren't that good... so we steered away from those.

On the plus side, the heirloom tomato salad and the heirloom tomato soup were GREAT.   As were the oysters and the cornbread.  The toffee cake was a lovely lovely thing to eat... just like the other reviewers have said (but I needed to cut the sweetness with coffee).  And my friend really loved her cheesecake.   And overall (with the exception below), the prices were fair.

I loved the diver scallops and shrimp entree... it was beautifully cooked, beautifully plated and beautifully seasoned.  But at $27, 2 scallops and 2 shrimp just don't cut it.  Maybe if they served monster-sized scallops, but these were less than 1-1/2" in diameter.  You'd need to add at least another scallop and/or shrimp to the plate, or a lot more "sides" to make it worthwhile.

The noise level wasn't as bad as I'd anticipated.  We were seated very near to the kitchen, and almost right next to the bar (so you'd expect the noise level to be crazy).
author: Lana C.

description:
mmmmmm barbecue shrimp with spicy worcestershire sauce.  That was me licking the plate.  If they ever take that dish off the menu--I'm out!

Town Hall is a great expense-account restaurant. You can work the wine and cocktail list if you've got money to burn and enjoy a truly remarkable meal.  The menu is full of comfort with gourmet touches. Regardless of  the pedigree of the cheese and the spicy flourishes, cheese toast is still cheese toast at heart, and fried chicken is fried chicken, but you can enjoy both with impunity. 

I've had up and down service at the front of the house, but the wait staff has always been prompt, attentive, helpful, knowledgeable, and professional.
