Not a great place for an intimate conversation,  even in the few booths, the place just gets noisy.  But if you're into the rousing, high-energy, people-watching, shouting conversation kind of experience, this is your place.
author: Matt M.

description:
Great place. Good crowd. Delicious plates.

We sat at the communal table with drinks while we waited for our dinner table. Met an older couple that was awesome. When our table was ready the hostess had no problem returning in a few minutes when we asked to finish our drinks with our new friends. 

We ordered the Kona Kampachi and tomato fondue. The GF loved the kamachi. I thought it was spicy pico de gallo with a few slices of tuna on top. I had no problems eating the tomato fondue with a spoon right out of the bowl. It was amazing.

I ordered the swordfish, she ordered the quail. Both were amazing. The swordfish wasn't fishy at all and was wrapped with ham, with gave it a great great and flavor. The quail was tender and looked great. 

The portions are great, the service was swift and generous and the ambiance was perfect. 

Only bummer was the restrooms were far away and up three flights of stairs. A minor drawback to such a great place. And one of the female bartenders was a wench. But we didn't deal with her that much.
author: B B.

description: I've been here once with a group of friends and ate the BBQ gulf shrimp (with Worcestershire sauce & toast). Definitely a drool-worthy dish. I ended up asking for more bread to soak up the sauce with. Great interior and atmosphere but it can get a little too overcrowded.
author: Maricel B.

description: I went to Town Hall for my "last meal" before starting a two-week cleanse and it was everything I had hoped for.  We started with the Fried Oysters and the Ham and Cheese Toast - fabulous but almost too much for an appetizer.  The pork Osso Buco was sublime and my partner couldn't stop raving about the ribs he had.  The toffee cake dessert was rich and decadent, a perfect finish to the meal.  Our waiter was fantastic, attentive, and went above and beyond to make us happy.  When I asked for a specific bottle of wine, he suggested I try it first as it likely wouldn't be what I expected.  After the taste I agreed and ordered his recommendation, which was much better.  For dessert, I had hoped for a madeira that would pair perfectly with the toffee cake, and though it wasn't on the menu he was able to find some for me.  Can't wait to go back when I'm done cleansing!
author: kerry l.

description: So I only went once, and I know that having just one dish on one visit isn't really good enough for an overall review.  Here's what I do know: This place had the BEST buttermilk fried chicken that I've ever had in my life.  That alone get 4 stars.
author: Casey R.

description: I've been to Town Hall twice more since my last review and I'm not impressed.  They have one of the few menus in the city on which I can't find anything that I want to eat.  It's really had to get a table, yet I can't figure out why.  The service is uninspired and the food is mediocre.
author: David G.

description: Went here for my birthday last October after hearing how yummy it was from many friends.  We were not let down!  The tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes were delicious, and you have to try the shrimp appetizer.  So good!  I had some type of fish for dinner that was great, and my boyfriend had a meat dish  (can't remember what it was but he loved it).  Service was wonderful, wine was delicious, ambiance was great.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Kristen V.

description: This was my second visit and was no more memorable than the first.  I ordered a hamburger well done and it was quite red.  Rather than send it back I tried to eat around the red part only to be horrified by several hard fat globules.
author: Susan J.

description:
Unbelievable experience each and every time.  

Lunch
Burger with bleu cheese is a great choice, even the fries are amazing.

Dinner
Duck is one the best I've ever had and even the bread is top notch.

Dessert
Pot de Creme.  That's all you need to know.
author: Jake B.

description:
This place has been one of  the Chronicle's "Top 100 Restaurants" for the past four years.  The reason why is pretty obvious - consistency.

I recommend Town Hall as a great spot to gather before hitting the bars and nightclubs in SoMa.  The drinks are amazing, the mood is convivial, and the atmosphere is vibrant.  Although, take that recommendation with a grain of salt.  A big one, in fact.  Because the entrees can be fairly substantive and it can, at times, be difficult to drink copious amounts of booze with a belly full of buttermilk fried chicken, short ribs, etc.

My favorite dish on the menu, though, is the slow-roasted duck.  YUM!!  Arguably the best in San Francisco.  A restaurant specializing in American cuisine with a perfect duck offering...take THAT Frenchies!!
author: Johnny P.

description:
My experience at Town Hall was fantastic. On a whim one Friday night we decided to walk in without reservations. The main dinning room was booked for hours but we were able to sit outside near the bar and yet the service was still good.

Our food was outstanding. The portions were actually too big, which is rare these days. Each entrée came with a wonderfully paired side and the specialty drink menu was truly unique. The two of us split the chop veggie salad and veal meatballs over mashed potatoes as an appetizer. We then shared the Niman's Ranch pork chop and lamb t-bone. 

The only downside was that we ate too much. We'll be returning!
author: Tiffany S.

description: Had the outdoor lunch BBQ, specifically the Kielbasa sausage with a side of potato salad.  The Kielbasa was on a hard roll with sweet peppers.  While tasty, the Kielbasa should be spicier to counterbalance the sweetness of the peppers.   Love the fact that it's homemade and the casing bits really easily, a hot kaiser bun would be great, but the grease from the sausage soften the roll.  As for the potato salad, just average!  I can tell they mixed in either BBQ sauce or some grease from the sausage to give it the color, I was surprised to see green onion and red onion mixed together, the green onion did nothing for it.  Overall, tasty lunch...it is BBQ California style.
author: Krissy A.

description:
Have been here numerous times with co-workers for lunch and also for dinner with some friends.  Overall, the decor is very rustic and the food is very hearty.  Service is generally pretty good but it tends to be very slow in getting the food out.  The items I like are:
1) The burger - great burger but a little pricier than most.  French fries make it worthwhile but not the best burger I've ever had.
2) The fried chicken plate - Just the right amount of crust and very juicy meat.  I'm from Texas and this is probably in the top 15 which is saying alot.
3) The tuna tartare appetizer - comes with Fried tomato slices.  Very southern and surprisingly spicy in a good way.
4) Seafood chowder - Wow, not too creamy but full of delicious seafood and great flavor
5) Ham sandwich with poached egg on top - Okay waaaaay decadent.  They literally pour a cup of cream on top of your sandwich.  So if you can get over the heart-clogging thoughts, enjoy that creamy jalapeno goodness!
6) Pot de Creme - Their signature, top things to eat in SF dessert.  I don't even like Pot de creme in general but this was pretty good especially with the pieces of butterscotch stuck in there
7) The chocolate dessert with almonds is my favorite by far!

A few things to note are that their dine about town menus are decent and usually include the Pot de Creme but I usually just end up ordering off of the usual menu.  Also during this period the service is RIDICULOUSLY slow.

If you are thinking about this place for an after work happy hour, I would discourage it because there are absolutely no nibblies offered during this period.  The manager wouldnt' even let us order appetizers off the main menu for some reason.

Other than that, usually not difficult to make a last minute reservation at this place given the large size and parking during dinner is extremely easy but expect to pay at least $50-$100 per person.  Dress is pretty casual though.
author: Susan L.

description: The food is amazing here.  The service is 4 stars only because its hit or miss.  Sometimes its really good and other times its only so-so.  The reason it gets 5 stars overall is because of the "to die for" egg toast with Jalapeno Sauce.  It may not sound good to most people, but its one of the most unique and tasty dishes I've ever tried.  Additionally, if you can afford the extra calories the dessert here is delicious as well.
author: Ash S.

description: omg beckies, the fried chicken .. to die for. nuff' said.
author: George Alberto R.

description:
it was AAAIIIIGHHHHT...............................

nothing too special. I would recommend Home if you want good american food. You will pay half the price for comparable if not better food.
author: Anna T.

description:
Referred here by a friend in the City who said food and service were great. We apparently got them on a bad night. :) The first three courses were great - oysters were in the top 2 I've ever had, appetizers and salad were both extremely fresh and tasty. Somehow after that...things got bad. In retrospect, it was a combination of the server and the kitchen. I asked for a bit of a break between appetizers and entree. Server said he would wait 5 minutes to place order...then it would be 15 minutes. Perfect. 20 minutes came and went. Another 10 with limited information. About 40 minutes into it, we got our food. 

My wife had the lamb (perfectly done) and I was handed a medium rare New York steak - bad news is I ordered medium. Immediately sent it back. 10 minutes later got the same thing back only drier and browner. Sent it back for new. BTW, it was sliced - and was not expecting that. Another LONG time before I finally got a version that was still not right but at that point, when asked if it was better I just said no but that I was hungry and wanted to eat. Pathetic for a place with this reputation. Server blamed the kitchen - which should have been my clue - but as it was a birthday celebration and we had already decanted an Opus, hard to dash! :)

Everyone was nice but kinda missed the point. Manager told me at end of dinner that she wouldn't order the New York steak - at which point I asked 'why is it on the menu?' 

There are too many good food places in SF and elsewhere to have this on my 'go back to' list. Unfortunate because I'm sure it's good ALL the other times. This is my buyer beware caution to you all if you're planning to try this for a first time. If you want GREAT food and service, this did not stand up to what is expected at a highly-regarded restaurant. 

Good luck.
author: Patrick G.

description:
I want to give this 3.5 stars, but that's not allowed... so, it gets 3.

my boyfriend and i went here on a wednesday night - the place is pretty big, so it wasn't crowded at all. we got the tuna tartare to start, excellent! highly recommend.

Then he got the duck, which wasn't too big of a portion, but very tasty.  I got the ribs, which were a decent portion, but ehh, I wouldn't really say they were anything special. The cornbread it came with was good, althuogh i think it's just because it had some butter on it. 

Then we had a pear tart for dessert... it was big! you have to really like pears though, it was a flaky pastry bottom, with lots of thin pear slices on top of it, and then a small scoop of ice cream. I think I would have rather had it with apples, mmm.

Oh and they bring you a bread basket - it wasn't anything special, but it's always a nice plus.

We sat inside, but they did have outdoor seating with heat lamps & those plastic drape things to stop the wind.

I've heard good things about this restaurant, so maybe I'll go back and choose something new.
author: Caitlin B.

description: I like how they put up a tent and outdoor heaters so that their outdoor dining area is still a viable option in winter (where I ate today). However, I don't think their food differs from much of the overpriced, bland fare that pervades FiDi. I chose this place for a professional interview, though, and it's perfectly suited to that type of event. Fancy enough without breaking the bank, solicitous yet non-intrusive service, and plenty of non-messy entree options. I had the catfish, which was nicely presented and not too tiny of a portion. Too bad I can't really remember what it tasted like. Oh well.
author: Angela X.

description:
Welcome to the first ever openly collaborative effort by Ben P. and the Wifey, as we review our meal at Town Hall.  The statements and opinions expressed herein are those of the authors only, and not their beloved spouses, who may or may not agree.

Ben sez:

We picked Town Hall because the Chronicle had it on its list of the Top 100 Restaurants, and TH had availability on the day we wanted to go out and eat.  Because dinner was recently, it was hella raining when we visited (and yes, I'm over 30, and yes, I said hella, and yes, you can kiss my black ass, and yes, I'm not black).  The interior was bright and shining and welcoming and WARM (I'm stunned how many restaurants in the city are cold when the weather is cold---if you can't keep a restaurant warm, you're doing something wrong).  We were early, indeed, we showed up before the dining room officially opened, yet we were greeted and shown to our seats.  No coat check, which is one of several things keeping this from being a 5-star review.  I've said it before, and I'll say it again: 5-star restaurants take your coat and bag.  I won't 5-star a place that doesn't.  Sorry, but you're on notice (Colbert-style).

Our waitress was really nice, friendly, helpful, and prompt.  Very knowledgeable about the food (I got a 30 second lesson on the awesomeness of my quail), and the wine.  Really, one of the nicer waiters/waitresses I've encountered in SF.

We shared an appetizer of buttermilk biscuits and ham.  The biscuits were a little too doughy for me, but the ham was wonderful.

I had the quail, as previously alluded.  The quail was stuffed, which is a bit surprising in and of itself (quail is usually considered by restaurants to be too small to stuff).  The stuffing was good (tiny minced carrots abounded).  The quail was entirely decent, not transcendent.

For dessert, I had the apple pie.  SURGEON GENERAL'S WARNING: THE APPLE PIE DESSERT WILL FEED 4 PEOPLE.  This is the one ball our waitress dropped.  This dessert is freaking huge.  It was wonderful, but huge.  I asked for extra ice cream, which was necessary: extra only meant 2 scoops, which was barely enough for me to eat half the pie.

So, my bottom line: very good, great service, solidly 4 stars.

Wifey sez:

Wow.  I actually get to type my own answer instead of having it transcribed for me.

Anyway.....Yes the ham was tasty, but the appetizer was barely big enough to share.  Personally I thought the biscuits were tasty too -- I like doughy biscuits.

My entree was a pork chop the size of a grapefruit.  And almost as round.  It was crusted with a peanut sauce of some sort -- good, but almost too many flavors were present.  It had a spicy, make-your-gums-tingle sorta kick to it that caught up with you after the first couple of bites.  Accompanying it was some patty pan squash and apples.  With the spicy chop, I would have liked more apple than squash, but overall I was pleased.

Dessert....Key Lime pie.  Mmmmmm....Key Lime pie.  It was tangy and tart (and delightful).  Like the apple pie, it was quite large -- easily a two-person dessert.  Somehow, through the pain and guilt, I was able to eat most of it.
author: Ben P.

description:
the simple design of this place makes it welcoming to come in for lunch or happy hour.  

i had the day off so taking a two hour lunch was absolute decadence.  

with the tech convention so close by, i was pressed to get a cab so i ended up driving.  without any quarters in my pocket (hold the jokes pls), i was forced to pony up 17 bucks for lot parking a block away on howard and 1st.

geez, i am such a food whore...i mean enthusiast.  
i got to sample the fries, the buttermilk biscuits, and the baby beet salad was a very nice citrus medley.

the meatloaf was a solid homestyle classic but i have to say that the rabbit, shrimp and crawfish etouffee was excellent.  
i never eat leftovers since i go out almost every single day but i did take the leftovers home and am writing this with it in my distended but happy belly. 

well, my mother always said that no meal is complete without dessert.  and yes, i was a fat kid growing up but i digress.

the end to the lovely meal was the cheesecake with sugared kumquats.  

the bill was discreetly tucked away in an old hardcover book which i found amusingly creative.

hmmmm, now, i wish i took the dessert leftovers home.
author: Anh V.

description: My wife and I have eaten here twice, most recently with a friend who was visiting from out of town.  We really like the biscuits with pepper jelly and ham as an appetizer - a neat collection of tastes with just a bit of a spicy edge to it.  For dinner we have tried blackened catfish (terrific), BBQ ribs and sole.  Our friend had the steak and it was excellent (I got to try a piece).  The sides that come with the dishes all go really well with the main courses.  We only had room for dessert once - had the mini-beignets with ice cream.  Mmm...
author: Richard M.

description: I'll be honest, I'm not really sure why this place is a miss for me but it is. The steak was good, as was the service, but that's where it ended. There's something about this place that makes me feel like it should be filled with stuffy, old men. I think this place just has an old vibe to it. It reminds me a lot of Perbacco but that's is in the heart of the financial so you can understand why it has a hoity toity feel to it.. I can't believe I just used the phrase hoity toity...anyway, I guess I'd recommend Town Hall for the food but don't go in expecting a young, fresh feel to the place.
author: Shreya C.

description:
Last night while in SF visiting friends we went to eat at Town Hall.  I was told ahead of time that we were coming here so  I looked it up on Yelp.  After seeing the pictures I understood why it is called "Town Hall", but I didn't truly absorb it until I got there.  It has this old time feel that seemed sorta like you were in an old school or converted barn, but with an up-to-date trendier feel.  i can't quite explain it with the right words.  You just have to go and look.  And they also bring you the bill in a very old book/novel, which added to the ambiance.  

Our reservations were at 9pm and we were promptly seated, but we didn't finish eating until  11:15pm.  That was partly due to the fact that one of the friends didn't show up until about 20-30 minutes later and we waited for him before we ordered.  The other part was because it took probably 45 minutes to receive our main course after finishing our appetizers.  That is the only thing I would complain about, but my friends who have eaten here many times said it was not normal.  Besides that, our waiter was very attentive and even took my friend's shirt to soak after my friend bit into his fried chicken and grease squirt all over his $200 shirt.  The manager even came by to tell my friend to send the dry cleaning bill to him, which was very nice.  

We started with 2 appetizers, which were AMAZING.  The first was the Heirloom Tomato salad with feta cheese and two sprigs of watercress in a buttermilk garlic dressing.  The tomatoes were SO sweet and they melted in your mouth.  I kept eating bread just to sop up the dressing, which had a bit of a zing to it because of the garlic.  Our 2nd appetizer was the Faith's Warm Ham and Cheese Toast, served with a poached egg on top in a jalapeno cream sauce.  We cut it in fours and all let out groans of pure and utter satisfaction once the first bite hit our mouths.  The jalapeno cream sauce definitely had a bite to it, but it's not so spicey that you can't enjoy it.  I like food with strong flavors and these two appetizers definitely captured it. 

For our main courses, 3 of us ordered the Buttermilk Fried Chicken, which came with white corn, cherry tomatoes, biscuits and gravy.  This was clearly NOT the night to start dieting!  And even though my friend got chicken grease on his shirt after biting into the chicken leg, I did not and nor did his girlfriend. You get 3 pieces of friend chicken, which is more than enough, as I did not finish my 3rd piece.  You get dark and white meat, but I prefer dark anyway. The 4th person ordered the Chimay Braised Short Ribs, which I did not try, but he loved it, as did my other two friends who tried a piece.  

While the appetizers were unbelieavable and the main courses were fantastic, NOTHING compares to my NEW favorite dessert!!!! OMFG!!!  The Butterscotch  Pot de Creme is soooooooooo DAMN good that I have to curse and say it's FUCKING ORGASMIC!  It was a mix of white and chocolatey type mousse and normally I don't like white chocolate.  And out of the bowl was what I can only assume was homemade butterscotch pieces sticking out of it.  It was very sweet, but left a little salty taste in your mouth.  I am drooling while writing about it....literally Pavlov's Dog here!!!  I dreamt of it last night and I will dream of it tonight and tomorrow night and the night after that.  I would fly to SF just to have this dessert and nothing else.  I will beg them to send it overnight to me in LA!  I will pay whatever price!  I must have it!!!  Have I made my point clear on this dessert, yet?!  I could hate everything else I ate here (which I didn't) and I would still give this place 4 stars, simply because of this dessert alone!  It was love at first bite!  I'm smitten...
author: Zalina V.

description:
I FUCKED CONAN O'BRIEN SATURDAY NIGHT.  OK, actually, I ate dinner "with" him.  You know, at the table one table removed from him.  Peg S. spotted him and queried in her sultry Dorothy Parker, "Hey, isn't that Conan O'Brien?"   To which, I had to ask my friend Anita, frantically, head a-bobbing, "Where?!!!  Where????"  And the sea of obtrusive heads parted; and there He was.  Oh, Conan.

Down to the yelp:  They pack this place in like it's a town hall or something:  tables everywhere.  Our hostess was very accommodating (hmmm.. imagine that.. for a hostess) and seated us fairly quickly.  We ended up at the large table in the back (party of 9) near the kitchen (boo), which was drafty for some reason.  The person who took down my initial reservation was acommodating as well.  And after negotiating with a bunch of other places to seat a party of (initially) 10, I was pleasantly surprised that Town Hall was able to do it.

Savories here are De-Lish!  I stuck my fork in pretty much everything that everyone else had.  I had the ham and cheese toast w/ poached egg and jalapeno cream with bits of breaded, fried okra(?) and the apple beignets with prosciutto(?).  The beignets were fluffy, not greasy, and not overly sweet -- complimented the tasty prosciutto well.  The Ham and Cheese toast was my favorite -- the jalapeno cream was spicy and complimented the ham & cheese toast well.  ***** for creativity in the kitchen, particularly with this genre of food, blending unexpected flavors into a sincerely pleasurable experience.  Ah yes, the fondue was good as well.

Second course:  The pork chop was succulent and tender.  Its pumpkin side was savory and sweet.  The jambalaya was also good.  I also tried the fried chicken w/ biscuits and gravy and brussel sprouts -- so much chicken.  Gemini g. made a valiant effort to finish the chicken.  I was impressed.  For a tiny little thing, she made some serious headway.  The chicken was moist and the breading tasty.  While the mini biscuits were tasty, for some reason they were cold.  Gemini g. commented, "The coldness detracts from the yummyness."  Gemini g. is wise and well-versed in the use of -ness words.  I contemplated getting the lobster and rabbit pot pie.  To which, sis whispered in her pictionary voice, "(but do you like rabbit?)"  I declared, "I'm getting two appetizers!"

Drinks, we tried the samba and something else that I can't remem the name of. But both were good, too.

Dessert:  For the love of god, get the Butterscotch chocolate pot de creme.  Served in a giant bowl with butterscotch-chocolate brittle, this pot de creme circulated our table as we greedily spooned in yummy mouthful after mouthful moaning culinary ecstasy.  SPOILER: For the love of god, do NOT get the hot chocolate or the devil's food cake.  I understand that there are some chocolate fiends out there, but this hot choc was too much.  The consistency was more like choc. fondue.  The ginger cookie that came with it was good tho.  The cake was REALLY disappointing.  The look of it was fabulous.  But it tasted and felt like chalk.  Strike that, refrigerated chalk.  But it looked so good, with its layers of chocolate cake and chocolate frosting.  It beckoned.  So we ate it.  It was like that bad date you keep going back to that initially looks so good and perfect.  You think, "It can't be THAT bad."  Oh, but it is:  It's dry, stale, crumbly and day-old.  But you keep going back for more.  And after you've coughed up yet another dry mouthful, you think, "Never again" . . .  as you reach for another forkful.  *sigh*.  We also had the pumpkin cheesecake -- not really sweet for you sweet fans and custardy / eggy texture and flavor.

RECAP:  WE SAW CONAN O'BRIEN.  No one can take that away from me.  No one.
author: Natasha S.

description:
What a great night - seeing my little girlie "JC".......... 
What a disappointment - eating such mediocre food.

I have wanted to go to Town Hall for awhile now -  but never got the chance for one reason or another.  So when Jacey and I wanted to go to dinner - we decided upon this place and frankly, I was excited to try it out.

A multitude of things went wrong.

First -  we ordered wine.
The first bottle was a 94 Campillo Tempranillo - - $100+, can't remember how much exactly.  I think it was 125.  But the wine was 13 years old, and this was a good night, happy occasion - so I figured why not, especially since I forgot to bring a bottle of wine that I had wanted Jacey to try.  They decanted it upon bringing it to the table - and I tasted it, and something about it was not right.  I thought I'd let it breathe for a bit, but after some 15 minutes - - it tasted even more off.  I never, ever do this - but for the first time, I decided to return the wine and order something else.

Now here is where things went sour.
I was on the phone when the server came by - and JC tells her that this wine is not good.  The server asked if it was bad, or not good. (???)  JC answered that it was bad.  The server then takes the bottle and says she will go to the back and try it.  Now, I could care less if she chugged the whole thing - but if the customer tells you it's no good, then take it as that and offer something new - - her tasting it and then claiming it as superb is not going to make what we think is a wine-gone-bad into a great wine.  It just won't.  If we were people wanting to get more wine after downing 3/4 of the bottle, I get it.  Butwwe're barely able to finish one glass of wine each - - and we gave it a chance, and STILL, it sucked.  So then the sommelier comes over - - and tells us the wine is fine.  "That's nice, I still don't like it," I tell him.
Now, I won't knock the sommelier - - he informed us that wines from the Campillo winery simply taste like this, and so forth, while offering to exchange for us but recommending a different choice, some Spanish wine.  Coincidentally, that was what I had wanted - - but the server had told me that if it's a Rioja that I want, I best go with the 13 year old Rioja rather than that Spanish wine, which was my first choice.  He brought it out, decanted again -  and this one, we accepted.  It was alright - - but nothing anywhere near the caliber of wines I have at my house, costing 1/10th the price.  
OH WELL, bad wine night.

Second, we ordered food.
I'll say - the bread was good, the butter was good.
The beet salad we ordered had really good beets, but to get any flavor at all - - - we had to pour the salt on.  After eating about half, I look at Jacey and ask, "WTF, is this bland or is it me?"  She starts cracking up and we went nuts w/ the salt.  Ahhh... better.
The tuna tartare appetizer..... bland again, no appeal, and just nothing remotely memorable about it!  It came with some fried tomatoes that tasted like fried squash or something.... also bland.  "GIMME THE SALT".....


Then came our entrees.  Jacey could not pick one to save her life - so she ended up ordering the second of the two choices I had been pondering, which was scallops.  I ordered the ribeye, medium-rare ($34?).  The steak was good - it was cooked exactly as requested, but accompanying it were really soggy tater-tot type of things, and string beans -  and this great hunk of meat was drowning in the sauce that accompanied it.  The sauce on its own was tasty, but the steak soooo did not need it.  What did strike me was that unlike the appetizers - -  this was nearing the point of being salty!  Hence, it had more flavor, and it was a good cut of meat w/ great marbling and very little CHUNKS of fat - - but I noted the inconsistency.  
The scallops.....
Well, for some $28 (?), call me silly but I expect either really large scallops - - or if it's the average scallop size you're offering (which they are) - - give enough to make the person eating it not gawk.  THREE SCALLOPS with a mass of a barley concoction?  NO.  NO, NO, NO.

Turned off.

Third - dessert.
Now WHY would we bother ordering dessert?  
Don't be silly.............  I know how to take a hint.  Besides - by this point, JC was tipsied-out and laughing so much - and her laugh was cracking me up..... it started looking like delirium.

Off to the Redwood Room we went to party it up, Mojito-style!  And as always, Redwood did not disappoint.  :-)  GOOD TIMES, girlie - - good to see you!
author: Grace K.

description:
Gracie Unni & J's Adventure #1

for surely my gracie unni (www.gracekeh.yelp.com) *spoiled* me BIG TIME!!! it was like, where the night go? ooh, i love these nights, where you can have that sisterly connection, tapping 2 bottles of wine, and not give a wild chocolate *fudge* about the chaos in the world...

i got there prolly 10 mins before unni showed up (i swear, we shouldve totally done a raincheck, but thanks for comin out for moi all the way from stockton! stupid cali drivers, and having u to sit in the nasty bay bridge traffic, i owe u long long time unni) scoping out the ambiance and service ...  ambiance is real nice, the whole christmasy theme going on ... the high ceilings and the bricks throughout def had a nice "new englander touch." this casual, modern atmosphere is quite inviting, *BUT*

-1 food wasn't all that spectacular ... come back later (if you see that my profile says "new reviews" it means i'll update on the the names of the wine we ordered ... it was some spanish wine ... hmm...crap!) aish.. moji?

ok, for the wine...first we ordered the 1. 94 Campillo Tempranillo which was roughly $100, and 2. the Pinto Pesquera Alejandro Fernandez for $70-80.  Both Gracie unni & i DID NOT appreciate the first one, and told the server that it was "bad." I'll be honest with you, both Gracie unni & I were very much upset when the server took the wine with her, stating that she was going to test the wine and come back. I have to say, if a customer does not appreciate it, you simply take it back, no questions, no buts whatsoever. So, let's say the server DID like it, in fact, the manager came back saying that was how it was supposed to taste like. given that, we are not happy campers, everyone's taste buds are different, so who gives if you like it and we didn't? ahn gurae unni? We're not difficult people, i'm sure you would the same... 

we shared a tuna tartare $14 (fried green tomatos, garlic chips & tabasco green vinagrette) i give 3. nothing awesome.. edible to say the very least ...

we also shared the roasted baby beets which was arugula, goat cheese, and sliced apricots for $10 ... sry town hall, i give 1. not your everyday treat... PASS.

onto our entrees: 
-blackened rib eye steak, corn, crispy onions and w/ garlic sauce $28.50 (the cute baby lookin tater tots were yum, fried with perfection, w/a side of french carrots and horseradish jus). the ribs were delish, meat cooked perfectly.. 5 stars.
-sauteed scallops smoked w/jambalaya, scallons & crab butter $27. (do not, I REPEAT! do NOT order this sucker! it's a big disappointment! you only get 3, yes, 3, T-H-R-E-E SCALLOPS! that's so sad. taste? 2.5 stars...

-1 hella loud, the noise factor was truly a killer for me, and could barely hear what unni was saying, it was like, "say what?" but i did hear her silly ass korean remarks from "jjun nae" to "mi chuh suh" to "mongchungee" hahahahha, good times tho unni.. 

-1 having the restrooms on the 2nd floor, that was a major trip and a half, considering the fact that i was drunk before we even made it over to our 2nd half of the evening ... 

thank ya unni...
author: Jennifer S.

description: A new mom still has to eat, and, as a self-diagnosed foodie, I need to eat well.  Town Hall is not only a great place for food but it's kid-friendly as well. Really.  Yes, I am THAT mom that brings her baby in a stroller to restaurants.  All the time.  And I like places that have the stroller space and amped-up noise level. Town Hall has both.  Not that my kid makes any noise (he's the quiet-type), but if he does make a peep no one can hear it.  With that said, this place is not for a romantic night out filled with quiet conversation. You must yell to be heard in this place.  But that's what us new moms love about it.  Oh, and table #50 is the place to be.  It's a quiet little corner table with easy back door access. Go for it, new moms. You deserve it!
author: Aimee G.

description: Came here for a meeting. Lucky I didn't pay for it.  Good appetizers but main entry so-so.  As usual, the servers were average, giving the SF vibe of wanting to be somewhere else
author: Ariel W.

description: My best friends celebrated an anniversaryf or my husband and I. It was awesome service! Our server  was full of energy and the nicest a server could be! I ordered the gnocchi with truffle oil and mushrooms. My friends had a pork chop, short ribs, and steak. The appetizers were delicious as well, we got the fondue,sliders and the BBQ shrimp (had to be the best appetizer we've ever had). Dessert was a butterscotch chocolate cream and their Pumpkin Spice Sticky Toffee pudding was amazing! We cleaned all of our plates the night. We also couldn't stop talking about the best dinner EVER!!!  If you visit San Francisco, this is a must go-to place! No lies! :) *****
author: Kristine C.

description: I love this place! The food, service and casual ambience are what keep me coming back here. Their apps and entrees are so good- just pick one and you won't be dissapointed although the last two times I've been here I had to get the lamb with arugula and goat cheese. Also, don't forget to try their hot chocolate or pot de creme for dessert... delish!
author: Donna V.

description: The food at Town Hall is consistently amazing.  We shared the fried chicken and pork belly tenderloin entrees.  Couldn't be better.  Love, love, love the food.  For such a heralded spot, though, I was surprised at how slow the service was.  They need to step it up in that area, especially for a Monday night when the restaurant was half-empty.  Seriously, pick up the pace.
author: catherine g.

description: Town Hall is the epitome of San Francisco dining. It's social, always packed, and the food is as good as it gets. Everything on the menu is delicious but highlights include the veal meatballs and the bbq shrimp from the appetizers and either the pork chop or ahi tuni from the entree selection. For dessert, the chocolote-butterscotch pot de creme is phenomenal. Excellent wine list. If I had to register one complaint it's that the bar area can get way too cramped on busy nights.
author: Nish N.

description: The food was delicious, and I was impressed how the menu was suited to the season.  The atmosphere and decor just seemed a bit off to me though.  I'll probably give this place another chance since it is in a convenient location.  However, next time I will be sure to make a reservation so that I'm not sitting in the uncomfortable bar stools at the communal table.  I recommend you do the same if you want to try Town Hall.
author: Christena T.

description: Had the ham cheese toast. It was ok, nothing special. Got there before noon so was easy to get seated and was served promptly.
author: Roshan M.

description: I work across the street from Town Hall... have only been for lunch, both business and pleasure.  Without a lot of hyperbole, the food is very good, the service is great and the sound is over the top loud so minus 1 star for that.  I have tried the burger, fish & chips, ham & cheese toast w/poached egg, all were excellent.  I took my mom to lunch once and she loved it.
author: Brenda G.

description: Huge disappointment. I ordered the entree size garden salad with chicken today for lunch. What I got was half a head of iceberg lettuce chopped in quarters with radish and the chicken was some kind of warm shredded chicken with melted cheese that they plopped on the side. Disgusting. And my guest ordered a burger medium well and seriously it was red (not pink) in the middle. Never again.
author: Rick B.

description: This is one of those spots you know you can always rely one.  Quality food, inventive, solid service, warm and interesting space.  Need to go back a couple more times to sample the rest of the menu, but eveything my fellow diners and I got each time was excellent.
author: Rudro S.

description:
The end is the beginning is the end. 
It's really all about meal endings here. Get the butterscotch chocolate pot de creme with toffee shards as your final course, and any earlier transgressions will be forgotten. Creamy, rich and deeply chocolatey, this is what most pot de cremes dream of being when they grow up. 
Not that the rest of our dinner was bad. In truth, I really enjoyed my entree. The spring vegetable risotto was a lovely combination of asparagus, pea tendrils, watermelon radishes and squash. My husband's fried chicken and biscuits was the clear winner of the evening, though. I didn't taste it, but I think that made him even happier. I do need to say that our friend didn't really enjoy his steak (he said it was dry), and my vegetarian self takes his word for this fact.
Appetizers were a bit hit or miss, although the tuna tartare was excellent and mac-n-cheese croquettes were everything they needed to be. 
Mildly distant server. But good wine. So, good times.
author: Purnima M.

description: Debbie Adler may have had an intimate and meaningful relationship with Town Hall's bananas foster bread pudding, but I suspect that her relationship with said pudding will be tested if she tastes the chocolate butterscotch pot de creme.  Five well-deserved stars simply for the pot de creme.
author: shoba d.

description:
Mileu:
Brick building- kinda New York style.  Cute, Quaint. I must say the people are a little pretty and hampton-esque.  

Service:
EXCELLENT.  Shout out to Apollo.  He was one of the better waiters I have had in a long while.  Dude, he was on top of it.  My friend asked for extra olives.  I think he brought us the whole bottle.  Our waters were always filled.  I think he had a bar with him cuz our drinks were served so freakin' fast.  He recommended the best wine for my friend for dessert.  He had knowledge of the food and it was great.  He was very friendly and assertive in what we should order.  It was great.  

Food:
Amazing!  Probably so orgasmic, it has topped one of my top three restaurants in the city.  I do miss the friend chicken at the Cafeteria and Chat N Chew in NYC, but dude, I found a great replacement.  I can now finally live in SF without the yearnings of good chicken in NYC.  WOOHOO.  Okay, their french fries were amazing.   It was so crsipy on the outside.  Yum.  Their tuna tar tar was good, but not great, but with the fried green tomato, it was damn good.  Then we got their hush puppy fried potato croquette.  OMG, to die for.  Anything fried eh?    My friend got this fish dish with stuffing.  It had this asparagas sauce.  SOOOO GOOD.  Dip the bread with it.  So good.  Actually, eat it by itself with your fingers.  I swear, Just as good.   So I thought I was in heaven, but then I ate their recommended dessert (Chocolate Butterscotch Pot de Creme) I was stuffed, but man, their desserts were so good, we even convinced the people next to us to get some.  They were so glad they ate it.  The dessert was so good.  Dude.  You HAVE to try it.  Overall, an excellent restaurant.  Pricey, but all worth it in my shoes.  I would mos definitely go back and I recommend it to EVERYONE who can't decide where to go.  If I ever want to entertain someone from out of the city, I know one place I can count on to be assured of a good meal.  Thanks Town Hall for an amazing meal.
author: M L.

description:
When asked to attend Town Hall, I nearly urinated in my neatly pressed, freshly starched Fruit of the Loom undies.  I accepted the invitation under the pretense that I'd get to air my waxing list of grievances (in true Festivus fashion) to that popinjay Mayor Gavin Newsom.  Lord Mayor, the homeless situation in San Francisco is egregious and unconscionable, as are the astronomical housing prices.  Don't even get me started, Your Eminence, on our fair city's public transportation system.  Yes, sir, we're going to Town Hall, for the time for rebellion is nigh!  What a glorious coup we'll stage (a la the Pakistani or Thai system of government), and when the dust settles and the beer bottles are cleaned up, we can look upon our shiny new Utopia with the sense of satisfaction earned from a job well done!

Wait, what do you mean "City Hall"?  A restaurant?

Sumumma bitch.

My dissatisfaction with municipal politics notwithstanding, Town Hall was a fantastic dining experience.  The service was efficient and friendly, the decor rustic yet chic.  The food was excellent by all measures.  Beware, vegetarians: there is little on the menu you can enjoy (without feeling as though you've betrayed your sacred covenant with Shiva), but even these few dishes were quite delicious.  The wild mushroom risotto was incredibly savory and flavorful, though perhaps was steeped a tad too long in truffle oil.  The jalapeno corn bread really is all that (cum bag of chips).  Delightfully light and sweet, with a hint of fresh, crispy jalapeno flavor.  The butter lettuce salad was also worthy of note, drizzled with the right amount of sacre bleu cheese dressing and adorned with walnuts and apple slices.  Save room for the Sticky Toffee Cake (a.k.a. Rejoice For I Am Now Inside Your Mouth), truly a masterfully wrought dessert forged from both the beautiful and the sublime.

Perhaps as San Francisco grows, Town Hall will graduate into a full-fledged City Hall, where one might be able to influence policy on the Peninsula a bit more efficiently.  Until then, good eats abound at this gourmet southern food establishment.
author: Rajiv B.

description: I'm going back for more chocolate butterscotch pot de creme. It's absolutely divine. Hot spot for happy hour - more of the financial district crowd. Reservations are a must.
author: Connie C.

description: What else can I add to the 532 other ravishing reviews of this place that has not already been said...NOTHING other than I concur as review number 533....thank you and the end!!
author: Karen B.

description: The duck is so good it brings a tear to my eye, and one time I had a green apple and onion soup that I'm sure will be waiting for me in Heaven. And if that wasn't enough, the first time I ate there a man (who I assume was a manager or owner) told me I was the "most beautiful woman" who ever ate there. You had me at green apple and onion soup. Aaanyway, if you like delicious food and over-the-top compliments, Town Hall is for you.
author: rachel m.

description: AHHH...Macallan's Scotch....Oh, what was that?...They have food here also?..I guess I'll have to try the fried chicken and the croque madame with the jalapeno cream sauce!! Man it was good!!! But back to the Macallan's.......
author: patrick w j.

description: I've only had a sandwich from the take-out counter, but I really LOVED the fried chicken sandwich with spicy slaw.  Service was quick and quirky.  It cracks me up everytime I walk by and hear the guy scream "CHICKEN!" and "PORK!"  I'm probably the only person in the Bay Area who hasn't had the chicken sandwich at Bakesale Betty's, but friends tell me Town Hall's fried chicken sandwich is basically the same.  Okay...
author: Kevin W.

description: Had to be the fattest, plumpest duck breast of my life there.  It was no joke!  Overall, everything was above average on taste but nothing wowed me.
author: Tron D.

description:
Given the food quality we had, this ought to be a 3-star review, but I'm giving them the benefit of the doubt given the circumstances.
We were there as part of a large group, in the private room upstairs.  The place is definately pretty cool and reasonably fancy, though not too much so.  We had an open bar, and they were quite generous with the mixing.  And service was quite good.
But the food disappointed.  The salad was nice (with crumbly goat cheese and thin slices of persimmon).  But the salmon I had for the main course was not very flavorful (and thus probably farmed) and just a hint on the fishy side, indicating that it wasn't terribly fresh.  And with a restaurant that's supposed to be high end, serving fish that isn't fresh really shouldn't happen.  The roast was good, tender, and nicely medium rare, but the potato & bacon croquettes which accompanied it seemed distinctly lacking in the bacon department, and were virtually indistinguishable from ordinary tater tots, which was a disappointment to everyone who got them.

Anyway, I'd like to return for a normal, non-large-group dinner on the assumption that they can improve on these issues.  But for now, this is a 3-star review that I'm pushing to 4 because I trust the folks who took us there.
author: Don H.

description: Again, noisy. I love an converted industrial space as much as the next foodie or whatever we are this century but would it kill you to put some fabric somewhere? Food? So damn good. I especially loved the asparagus fondue with andouille sausage to dip. And the balsamic strawberries on silky cheesecake tart was the best dessert so far, 2005.
author: patrick g.

description: It is insanely loud in here, but the thing that really got me yelling is the lack of vegetarian entrees on the menu.  It is 2007 and we're in San Francisco!  HELLO?!  This place is surrounded by office buildings.  There are going to be tons of vegetarians like myself who end up dining here for business meetings.  It would be great to have at least one choice on the menu instead of having to try to negotiate with the chef to make some vegetarian mystery dish.  I will never voluntarily come here again.
author: Squirrel L.

description: I've been here a few times with different groups of friends.  I'm still not sure what the hype is all about.  The food is o-k.  I haven't been wowed by the tastes on many of their dishes.   The fried chicken is one of my favorites, but a bit pricey for chicken.  The noise level is very high.  We had a group of 6 once and had to yell across the table to each other.
author: Stacey L.

description: Comfortably swank--it was nice enough to take my mom and sisters and feel like ladies on the town. Our late reservation turned out to be much later--it was a Satruday night, so it was understandable--but they were rad because they kept pouring us free champagne and apologizing. This attentiveness continued through an excellent dinner-- the 4 of us got 4 different things, employing useful suggestions from our server.  They checked on so much that my mom insisted the (female) manager was flirting with her. She probably will not live this down, ever.
author: Shannon V.

description: "Journey To the Far Pacific" by Thomas E. Dewey - that's the old hardcover in which the bill arrived. A cool touch from a great restaurant. Love the space and all the food hit the mark. Overall, it's a higher-end angle on old southern, creole dishes. For starters we had the squash blossoms, the bbq gulf shrimp, and the dayboat scallops. Creole dishes tend to be sooooo rich but somehow they pull off the flavors without being overwhelming. Then I went out on a limb and had the buttermilk fried chicken with biscuits & country bacon gravy. Nothing to say except "wow". For dessert we had the pineapple brown-butter cake with cinnamon ice cream. Like my fried chicken, perfect mix of crunch and sweet tenderness. There was so much on the menu I wanted to try so I can't wait to get back here.
author: Bill R.

description: My first time was actually with Captain Tom Steele, but this is my first Yelp review. Town Hall is a true classic. Surprising charm for how big the space is and the service and food were phenomenal. Took two of my best friends here on their visit from nyc and we all agreed it was one of the best all around meals any of us have had in a long time. Veal meatballs and bbq shrimp to start, pork osso buco and fried chicken entrees lived up to the hype. And the butterscotch pot de creme made my pot de creme. Awesome. Period.
author: Kris B.

description: Forget the first and second courses. Go straight to dessert for their Butterscotch Chocolate Pot de Creme!!
author: Sara N.

description: They serve great comfort food here. Two people at my table ordered the fried chicken and it looked and smelled wonderful. I wish I had ordered that instead of the steak. The meatballs i were also very good. The only thing I didn't love was desert. They're supposed to be famous for their butterscotch and chocolate pudding, but the chocolate was too bitter for my palate. I ordered a chocolate cake, but I didn't love that either.
author: The Jazz Master M.

description: Why is it called town hall?Does anybody know?Do the people of the city gather to have the town meetings in the hall?Whatever,the food's good and that's all that matters.Simple food done right.Started with an amazing salad with god knows what.I think it was a tomato.But it was the best freakin tomato I've ever encountered.Followed up by a fried chicken.The chicken breast was tender and juicy and  that's a sign of good cookin.The dessert was phenomenal .Caramel pot de creme came in a huge cup that even the three of us could barely finish.But you know we did.The check came in a old novel,Cute!
author: Sophia C.

description: I found the food good, but not memorable.  My favorite part of the meal was actually the complementary bread and butter.  The dining area was too loud.  The price was too high for the whole experience.
author: Anonymous P.

description: Great experience at Town Hall Restaurant!  Drinks and drink list were unique and refreshing, the food was perfect - between four of us we tried a lot of different dishes - the warm ham and cheese toast with poached egg and jalapeno sauce appetizer was fantastic!  The best part of this meal, however, was the service.  I haven't had service like this in a long time - the server was spot on when it came to reading our table and knowing when to check in and when to let us chat it up.  Knew the menu inside and out and all of his suggestions were wonderful.  I highly recommend Town Hall.
author: Isabel M.

description: Boring food, boring presentation, terrible vegetarian selection, "I'd rather not be here" service. I guess when you're close to FiDi, anything that isn't take-away falafel makes you the bee's knees. My portabello sandwich was half a giant roasted red pepper with a tiny slice of portabello mushroom tucked underneath. Both sides of the bread were globbed with mayo. A 14 year-old's vision of a fine eatery. Ya u kpy, k thx. Bai!
author: aaron f.

description:
It had been some time since I'd visited Town Hall, while my boyfriend had never been. My past visits had been impromptu and had always taken place on their heated outdoor patio. The food had always been good, and the service efficient and friendly - that is, from what I could remember, as it had been many months since my last visit.

We arrived about 10 minutes early for our 8:15 reservation - we weren't seated until after 8:30 as the party before us continued to linger well after paying their check. I ultimately recognize situations like this are beyond the restaurant's control, so while not ideal I certainly didn't start off with a bad impression.

Bad impressions, however, started to form after sitting down.

Our waiter stopped by and asked if we wanted water while we looked over the menu - he returned about 5 minutes later with water and informed us they were out of a couple of items. My bf and I then needed a little bit of extra time deciding. When he returned we had a couple of questions: we asked for a recommendation between a couple of starters, asked what the substitution would be for one of the main courses as they were out of one of the items, and I asked about the preparation of one of the mains. Upon being asked the third question the waiter somewhat huffed and rolled his eyes: I tried to play it down as a non-issue, as I had prefaced the questions with "I'm going to be a pain for a moment" in a friendly way. I initially took his response as just sarcasm. As for drinks, the bf and I have been drinking a lot of wine lately, so we decided to skip alcohol for the evening: he stuck with water, I had an iced tea.

We ended up ordering the following:

Faith's warm Smithfield ham and cheese toast with poached egg and jalapeno cream (shared)

Tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes, garlic chips, and green onion Tabasco vinaigrette (shared)

Fried buttermilk chicken with snap peas, mashed Yukon Gold potatoes, and bacon gravy (mine)

Stuffed pork chop with sun-dried tomatoes, fontina and mozzarella, dirty rice and bitter greens (bf's)

The food was "good," not great. The ham and cheese toast was very good, just as I remembered it. I did use extra bread to soak up the cream. It was probably the best item we ordered. The tartare was decent: the flavors pleasant, the fish very fresh... however it was fairly boring in overall complexity. The fried chicken was very moist, though the skin wasn't nearly as crispy as I like (and was a bit on the greasy side). The sides were particularly skimpy, however the snap peas were perfectly cooked and the potatoes/gravy tasty. I tried the bf's pork chop: it was cooked to medium, moist and tender. He liked it, though wasn't particularly impressed.

Food, overall, was good - I'd give it 2 - 2.5 stars ala Bauer's scale.

The service, however, was another story. After we placed our order we didn't see our waiter again until after we were done eating. The host brought out the appetizers - the busser essentially barked "Are you done?" before taking our plates. The mains were plopped in front of us - no one ever came by to ask how things were or whether or not we needed anything else. We sat with empty plates in front of us for quite some time. The waiter finally came by after the plates were cleared to present us with dessert menus: we'd already decided that we didn't care to remain through dessert.

Mind you, the restaurant was busy, though no more busy than usual. I frankly think the waiter "sized us up" after we asked questions/didn't order drinks and probably thought he could maximize his tip pull from other tables - so he ignored us.

The tab came to $94, including tax and tip. The tip, mind you, was just barely 15% - this was the first time in a VERY long time I considered leaving less. I typically leave 20-25% (or sometimes more for impeccable service). I'd probably give the service 1 star.

This was disappointing for me: I really enjoy Town Hall's younger sister, Salt House. It looks like I'll simply take my business there instead.
author: Jesse H.

description:
Service was ok I liked that Blue Bottle Coffee was served. Salad had to much dressing. Fried chicken was a bit dry. Ribs really lacked flavor. They were the most dissapointing dish. They tasted like they were just boiled with sauce on top. I expected more for $200 for 2 people...

Maybe this was just an off night.
author: Roger R.

description: At Town Hall I had great wine, great food, and great company, what more could one want.  I had some of the most amazing Halibut ever here, among many other extra tasty dishes.  My only regret is that I didn't ask for a box to take home all the extra shoestring potatoes... would have made a wonderful snack for my starving stomach.  I can't wait to experience such a wonderful meal again.
author: P H I L H.

description:
Just driving by Town Hall in the early evening, glowing warm light glittering through the big brick box on the corner, makes you want to go inside. I'd felt like the last of my friends to make it here, so when my mom offered to take my friend, Jersey Pride Molly and I out to dinner, I instantly knew. 
Town Hall. 
Molly and I met early at the bar, opening a tab and sipping glasses of wine. 
"Okay, Molls." I said. I've been neglecting Yelp, so I'll be writing a review. I'll need observations."
"Like that bird on the lamp?"
She pointed to what appeared to be a stuffed small bird emerging from a table lamp behind the bar.
"Yes. Like that bird on the lamp."
Looking around, the space was cool. High ceilings, chic art, snazzy folks. 
"We don't have this in Trenton." Molly said. "I mean, look at the lighting."
Overhead hung a series of "chandeliers" looking very much like the fixtures Julia Roberts created in The Runaway Bride. (Like you haven't watched The Runaway Bride.)
Mom soon joined us, and we were immediately seated as soon as mom paid our bar tab, presented in a hardcover, vintage-y book entitled "The Three Passions" which we like to think applied to us. 
It took a little while for anyone to come over and bring us water and offer us (more) drinks, but once he did it didn't matter. I don't know his name and I have no idea what shifts he works, but you will know him when you see him. 
Ding Dong. 
We ordered 2 starters to share, the veal meatballs and the sweet onion fondue. The meatballs, which my mom had somehow read about, were spectacular. The fondue, on the other hand, was really weird. We were given bland potatoes, dry sausage and broccolini to dip in a thin but great tasting sauce. 
Eh. Pass the meatballs. 
Molly excused herself to the ladies room and returned. 
"Alright, Spots." She Jersey-accented me as she sat down. "I've got a comment for your big Yalk review. Getting to the bathroom is weird. It's all warm and cozy and cool in the restaurant, and then you've got to walk into some office building with fluorescent lighting and wall to wall carpeting to get to the bathroom. It ruins the vibe real fucking fast."
I later learned she was right. The bathroom experience, in my twisted mind, speaks volumes about an establishment. Not only do you walk into some office space, you swing right past the "private" room, across the blinding white hall from the ladies. So, in addition to my eyes having to adjust, 35 people at a private party got to know that I had to pee at 8:42pm last night. 
Note to self: easily crash-able party upstairs. 
Dinner was great, although I only tasted mine. I had the lamb, which comes two ways. Either I'm dense (highly possible) or the menu doesn't make that appallingly clear. It was spectacular though, and came with a goat cheese potato gratin. 
Hey gorgeous, keep that Pinot coming. 
As we ordered dessert, splitting the apple crisp, mom leaned across the table. "Beth, you are flirting with that waiter."
"No shit, mother. Look at him."
"Well," she coyly replied. "His hair IS fabulous."
Molly and I looked at each other and responded in unison, "It's his ACCENT."
Cheers to that.
The crisp was great, although stuffed, I sipped my coffee and observed mom pay the bill, which arrived in another old book, this time a tattered cookbook. Lingering in the fabulous ambiance, we flipped the pages to find the equivalent of a dive bar bathroom wall, phone numbers and poems, praise and complaints, gorgeous doodles and dirty pictures. 
I grabbed mom's pen. 
Find the right book at Town Hall, folks, and you'll find not only my thoughts on the disarming ladies room experience, you'll also find a new phone number...
author: Beth S.

description: I had an intimate and meaningful relationship with the bananas foster bread pudding.
author: Debbie A.

description: Just spent $500.00 buckaroos here for 5 of us, and we were all totally disappointed.  the tuna tartare with the fried green tomatoes was the highlight.  the seafood etouffe was just okay-it had one big chunk of crab and the rest was undercooked rice with a few bay shrimp.  Two guys at my table ordered the rib-eye, and both just kind of picked at it, too polite to send it back.  the salads were good, but come on, you better get that right for those prices.  my margarita was nice and strong.  the wine selection was mediocre.  the service was also uninspired.  we won't be going back.
author: Betsy K.

description: This was our second time there. The food is very good. The service was spotty. We asked for a glass of wine after a half bottle. Our server, who was very nice, was distracted and completely forgot it. This is excusable. What isn't and what prompted me to write the review was the check. At the end of our meal, which wasn't cheap for what we got I reviewed the bill only to find that the house had tacked on an extra 4% to the bill. This was to pay for " the San Francisco healthy alternative". I dine quite a bit throughout the city and have never been forced to absorb the fact that the restaurant had to pay for health care for their employees. I resent the fact that a 4% surcharge is hidden. I won't be eating here again...
author: Jeff K.

description:
has become one of my favorite spots in town. a place i can reserve for a special night out but frequent it a bit more often as i love it so much.

the duck leg continues to be one of my most cherished plates. you can not deny yourself the jalepeno cornbread either.

great wine list and excellent service
author: Jorge E.

description: Noisy, expense account crowd, food reminded me of an 1980's microwaved T.V. dinner.
author: Niall M.

description: This is the Jennifer Aniston of restaraunts.  Very nice, total package kind of place, but at $15 million per picture, I'd rather have something a little more crazy/sexy/cool...like Angelina.  Yummy.
author: Jason S.

description:
town hall is a lovely place that i often forget about!  i have had a few nice dinners there, and recently went for lunch for the first time.  their food is very classic - great flavors, always tough to choose what to order.  i love the atmosphere at town hall, very new england and kind of rustic and homey.  for lunch, i ordered the cobb salad (sans egg) and was delighted to see how unique it was.  the chicken was more of a salad, with a light dressing and the tomatoes were roasted.  the dressing on the salad itself was also light and complemented the other ingredients nicely.  we shared the pepper potato chips which were so good!  my friends both got sandwiches and really enjoyed them- the brie sandwich with apples, and the ham and cheese toast (which was a twist on a croque monsieur).  
i highly recommend visiting town hall if you havent been - its a trusty place for a great meal.
author: Carolyn B.

description:
Right off the Fremont exit off of the Bay Bridge, stands the large and luminous brick building which is Town Hall. Having watched a re-run of Check Please last week that featured Town Hall and all 3 guests agreed to a unanimous thumbs up, I coaxed my co-workers into eating here for lunch today... even though I knew it was probably a bit upscale to expense. 

With no reservations, we were offered either the communal table or the bar. We chose the bar where I was able to sit on the side corner which I was pleased with since it allowed me to still be able to make good eye contact with both other members of my party. I ordered the soup of the day and the frisee salad w/arugula and blood oranges. I think soup is usually a good test of a restaurant's abilities in the kitchen and this soup was awesome. It was a creamy celery leek (pretty sure?) soup w/a dash of chives on top. I ate up every last spoon full- super duper yummy. The salad was also delicious, salty but not overwhelmingly so, the blood oranges brought the perfect amount of tarty sweetness, it was light yet when paired with a couple pieces of their delicious wheat sourdough, very satisfying. Unfortunately due to it being a business lunch, I was unable to partake in a alcoholic beverage but their wine list looked impressive. My ice tea was delicious and was refilled several times. My co-workers enjoyed the mushroom risotto, and the blackened salmon sandwich. Both said they were delightful and they would order it again. I was told the salmon was extraordinarily fresh and cooked perfectly tender & moist but not too flaky. 

Although I was really tempted to try one of their famous desserts, due to a pretty hefty wait from when we ordered to when our meals arrived (30 minutes?) we decided to get our check. Checks arrive in books which is a nice touch. Upon leaving we were thanked and invited back by the bartender(who waited on us), the hostess, as well as another guy standing by the door. This always makes me feel noted & appreciated- another nice touch which sadly, rarely seems to happen these days. Overall, 4 1/2 stars. Nice &  airy space, with classic touches. Random mix of locals, families, a few stuffies, and several yuppie-ish couples.  

I'll be back for dinner, drinks, & dessert as soon as I can afford it!
author: Callie K.

description: Town Hall is pretty good, though I'm not sure it lives up to all of the hype. I have eaten here a few times and have had some great dishes (BBQ Shrimp, woah mama!) but some main dishes that were just okay. I think select items are awesome and some are just as you would expect, but overall the restaurant is a tasty one.
author: Amber P.

description:
i didn't know we had to wait so long (1 hour) for a table for 2 that i reserved a month back. 

aside from the perfect gin martini i had there and the consistently good dessert selections offered here, the level of noise, the reservation faux pas, and the slightly overpriced food really left me... wanting. 

wanting a hug 
wanting a kleenex
or some free bread 
or some form of consolalation...

... what time does baraka close?
author: Vanessa D.

description:
The wine selection is pretty good, with plenty to choose from.  We ordered; crispy squash blossoms with four cheese stuffing, pesto, and a roasted cherry tomato vinaigrette, tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes, garlic chips, and Tabasco green onion vinaigrette, Buttermilk biscuits with Johnston family country ham and Dry Creek peach marmalade, and finally, smoked anduoille sausage with green garlic onion marmalade and Zataran's mustard, and the jalapeno corn bread.  Every single dish had amazing flavors.  The biscuits were unbelievably mouthwatering and moist; the contrast of the sweet succulent jam and the salty ham is perfect.  The tartare is on point in all its glory, and ended up being a few of my fellow diners favorite.  The squash blossoms are superior, however the flavors rely heavily on the cheeses and it's nearly impossible to disappoint with high quality cheeses as an ingredient in any dish. The sausage is juicy and hearty just as expected and accompanies the biscuits to lend a great Southern feel to the experience. 
 
The starters were filling but, we had come here to eat a hearty meal, and in keeping with that intention, we all decided to continue our community style of ordering for the table.  We all shared a perfectly seasoned Blackened Cedar River rib-eye accompanied with corn maque choux, crispy onions and a brown butter garlic sauce.  This dish was beloved by all members of the dinner party!  We also tried the buttermilk fried chicken, which is what had lured us to the Hall in the first place.  It lived up to any expectations I may have had.  Crispy on the outside, and tender inside with sweet Brentwood white corn and Yukon gold smashed potatoes that were amazing, all accompanied by bacon gravy that was nothing less than perfect.  

At this point we could have stopped, but there was no way we were going finish up without dessert.  I absolutely love butterscotch and was delighted to order the butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme topped with butter crunch.  We also shared the Breton shortbread strawberry shortcake with chantilly cream, and the sticky toffee cake with vanilla ice cream and toffee sauce.  At this point there was no doubt the desserts would be perfect.  Upon arrival the strawberry shortcake is huge.  We could have all split this one dessert, which was filling but sweet and light all at the same time.  The butterscotch was everything I has imagined and more.  It was smooth and rich just like I like it.  The butter crunch on top was a true highlight.  I thought that nothing could top pot de creme for me that night, but I had judged too quickly.  The sticky toffee cake is amazing.  It's delicious. Perfectly warm, soft, saucy, and oh so insanely devilish.  I attempted to consume every bite until I reached a gluttonous state of full.  It doesn't hit me until the server brings our check inside of an old book that I realize they have taken some desserts off our bill for the inconvenience with the fire alarm.  Not only does this make me a very happy customer, but also it makes me believe in Town Halls positive vibe. 


This place is really good.
author: Rachel P.

description: Cool looking restaurant, and offers a fun but expensive happy hour.  Also good for a casual business dinner or East Bayers because its a block from the Bridge.  East Bayers love the Bay Bridge.  I recommend going, but heads up, there really no bars to walk to after dins, it kind of stands alone.
author: Andrew R.

description:
this place rocks!  we had dinner here on a friday night- which we had to make the reservation for about a month in advance!  when we arrive it was full but it didn't seem packed.  it had a good, lazy feel about it.  the front bar area is a cool space with tall communal tables where people are sat as a group or with other strangers.  the back area has individual tables- which is where we sat.

our waitress was really good.  she knew her menu and she was attentive but not overly so.  she gave us time to look over the menu- which i was needing a lot of because i couldn't for the life of me decide on what to get!  we ended up getting a few apps and a couple entrees.  

for appetizers we ordered the barbecue shrimp with worcestershire and parsley garlic sauce, smoked salmon with chiogga beets, warm goat cheese and lemon herb vinaigrette, and the tuna tartare with fried tomatoes and green onion tabasco vinaigrette.  all of them were amazing- but in rank order i was say the tartare and shrimp were tied for first and then the smoked salmon came in for a close second.  

for entrees we shared the sauteed alaskan halibut with crispy potatoes, baby spinach and porcini jus and the cedar planked wild king salmon with corn and shrimp hash, cherry tomatoes and hush puppies.  both of these dishes were to die for!  we were having a seafood fix that night ;)

we opted out of dessert- way too full!  i had a couple great reds by the glass (cannot remember what they were) and my boyfriend had a couple dirty martinis.  the drinks were nice pours and tasty.  and when we ordered the martinis dirty with extra olives- they came dirty with extra olives.  that may seem obvious- but i am finding that is not the case at some places.  so it's nice when people listen to you.

5 stars for sure!  i'll be back- maybe as a walk in sometime so we don't have to make the reservation a month earlier though.
author: Harmony R.

description:
This place was great. Took my mom here for her birthday. We arrived early so it wasn't that busy. Would recommend arriving after 6pm though because parking before that is difficult because many of the streets are no parking from 4pm-6pm.

Drinks, dinner, and dessert were all amazing. I loved the pork loin. The creamy grits were the best I've had since living in the south. We tried 4 of the desserts on the menu and shared amongst the group, they were all phenomenal.
author: heather v.

description: I've been to TH a couple of times, and I have to admit, I just don't think it's that special.  In my opinion, there's always something a little off about the food.  The concept is great, but the food hinders its ability to self-actualize.  I've also never cared for the interior design...I hate communal tables. In that neighborhood, I think Salt House, or Bacar,  are much better choices.  The food and vibe at Town Hall are both tired.
author: Emily M.

description: Hooray for open kitchens! That is one hot line of boys playing with fire and knives.
author: Autumn R.

description: Not much more to say than WOW OUTSTANDING!!! I find myself craving their shrimp appetizer all the time. It's a little pricey but hey you get what you pay for!!! :)
author: Haley R.

description: Ate at Town Hall just this morning with a few family members, visiting San Francisco and looking for brunch before hitting the road. Did not have a very good experience. Although the food was well done, the portions left much to be desired and the service was simply unacceptable. Our waiter took quite a long time to even make his way to the table (the restaurant was half empty) and proceeded to spill coffee grinds all over our table. Although the food was good, it was not worth the price. Overall disappointing.
author: Katherine Q.

description: who knew this place would make such a great place for a party.  one of my dearest friends had her wedding here over labor day weekend and let me tell you it was an absolute delight.  the actual ceremony was held outside against the exposed brick backdrop of the building.  after the ceremony we were treated to copious amounts of champagne, open bar, cheese, and other bites from the kitchen.  The dining was open seating...and then, the party really began.  Overall a GREAT SF venue for a terrific SF wedding.
author: Angela N.

description:
4.25 stars.

My friend treated me here for my *ahem* 21st bday!! =)

We shared the roast pork appetizer, and my entree was the steak.

The pork itself was delicious, but a little dry and also accompanied with BEANS (which I don't like).  The steak was excellent, moist and very tender, a little more peppery than I thought, but definitely delicious.  It came with maybe 2 large crispy onion rings which were also yum yum.

My friend's halibut was very fresh with a light, delicate flavor.  

I probably didn't enjoy the food here as much as I could've since I was already so full from a day of wine and cheese tasting.  But I'd definitely come back!  =)
author: Junkfoodie Q.

description: I came here almost two years ago so I can't give a detailed review...but I just remember I really liked their meatloaf! And the service, and the atmosphere, and the fairly short wait for a lunch table on a weekday. I think I'm a fan - definitely looking back to going back  sometimes.
author: April Z.

description:
While it's easy for some top-tier restaurants to lose their step or get a little complacent, we haven't noticed it from Town Hall.  We always have had a quality dining experience -- the food is well prepared, the staff is friendly and knowledgeable and the atmosphere is lively.  Our only knock (albeit a small one) is that even when you have reservation they normally seat you 15-20 minutes past your set time. 

We had a friend visiting from out of town and brought him here for dinner and Town Hall did not disappoint.

For our appetizers, we had the butter lettuce salad and tuna tartare.  The blue cheese dressing complemented the apples and walnuts and didn't overpower the salad.  For our main dishes, I had the blackened catfish, my fiance had the fried chicken and our friend had the BBQ spare ribs.  

The catfish with okra and rice was excellent.  I don't usually eat catfish, but I couldn't pass this up after reading previous reviews and hearing from friends.  It was well seasoned and it melted in your mouth.  My fiance's fried chicken also was quite tasty -- it was flavorful and juicy inside, while maintaining that crispy outside.  We didn't try the spareribs, but given how quickly our friend ate his dinner, I think he liked his dish.  Lastly, the cocktails are quite strong and their wine selection is diverse enough for almost every dish and every palate.
author: S Y.

description:
Diver scallops atop brussels sprouts, mushrooms, and root veggies. 

It's the best dish I've had from anywhere in a while, no joke. 

I went to a nice restaurant in Monterey offering something very similar just yesterday. Craving this dish, I ordered it but was ultimately disappointed, as Town Hall set an impossibly high bar. I dream of going back to order it again...
author: Kan L.

description:
meet the fellas here for a beer at the bar, on the step-patio out front, or at the communal table. grab a seat and get to work.

the ceviche can start you off, then get to the good stuff like the rib-eye (the best cut of moo) and lamb.

this is like upscale caveman eating here, folks. nice, airy rooms. bathrooms upstairs (so you won't get stuck sitting next to one), and a pretty chill downtown crowd. but... old people alert! you want hipster-doofus or marina-ites? not here, unless it's immediately after work.

not digging the scene inside? go outside and take a seat on one of the stones in the outdoor entrance area of the office building next door. the worst time to come is during rush hour traffic. it's noisy.

all in all, not-to-pretentious place to grub with the fellas.

rating: two dishwashers and a dishwasher
author: dave tastic fantasmo x.

description: Decor, most specifically the lighting, is very nice. Though the food was completely unmemorable. Regrettably average.
author: Sandia O.

description: Very good food, very good service. A bit noisy but aren't all SF restaurants? :)
author: J J.

description: I went Town Hall to last night for the second time.  I love the vibe at Town Hall.  It is the perfect mix between upscale and casual.  You can wear jeans and get a little loud, but you still feel like you are in a nice restaurant.  We were there with a big group, and it seemed like we tried almost everything on the menu.  And everything was excellent.   Including the service.  I highly recomment the ham and cheese appetizer (I could not disagree more with Anita's review that is tastes like something from TGI Friday's), as well as the pork chop.
