I have had these both times I was there, and will likely order them the next time I go back as well.
author: Erica G.

description:
what is up the the hype surrounded by this restaurant? the place was busling, financial dist types stopping to have a drink after work. nice floral arrangements. but my food was SO salty. for the price of the food, i would def go to a different restaurant. i can't even recall the meal i had b/c all i could remember was that my rib eye was so salty. 

the crab cakes were decent. but it is not enough for me to want to come back here. 

decor was ok, and what is up w/ the bathroom being clear across the restaurant and on the 2nd floor? 

this was one of my first dates, what an awkward trek i had to make to the bathroom.... at least it was a clean bathroom. some other restaurants can't even say that. but then again it was probably clean b/c no one used it b/c its so damn far!!!!
author: Irene C.

description: The best upscale dining option in my office area hands down. You really can't go wrong with most anything you order, but the one "must order": butterscotch chocolate pot de creme. It doesn't sound glamorous, but you will take one spoon full and the angels will start to sing. You'll be torn between gobbling it all down and trying to savor, while balancing the right amount of butterscotch and chocolate on each spoonful. I try to share to conserve calories, but good luck not fighting over the last bite.
author: Shoshana D.

description: No, no, no!  Not fair to Town Hall--Beautiful bartentress made us fabulous margaritas and recommended tuna tartar and bbq prawns--fabulous!!  Waitress Jessica showed up long enough to take our order, encouraging us to order everything--starter and dinnere entrees.  We never saw her again--someone else delivered our dinner, and until we asked for the the check, we had not seen her for an hour.  Fried chicken was very bland, steak mediocre.  The butterscotch dessert....hello....jello pudding.  $156 dollar for two..$45 for wine.  That's not good.............
author: Marina F.

description: What's most impressive about Town Hall is the decor and service: impeccable. We were promptly greeted upon our arrival, our table was ready (yay open table!), and service followed at an equal level. Tablewear was quickly replaced, drinks were refilled, and our waiter was able to answer all of our questions...honestly. I'm in agreement with everyone else: the veal meatballs are a "must eat" and so are the fried green tomatoes that join the tuna tartar. Yum!
author: jodes l.

description: Town Hall is phenomenal. In such a foodie town, not many restaurants live up to the hype. Town Hall delivers--consistently--and earns the right to endure. The ambiance reminds me of the best Georgetown New American places with the brick walls and white-painted accents. And, oh yes, the food... delicious. My suggestion is to go there hungry as you'll want to eat, eat, eat. The outdoor seating seems like a nice touch (especially if you don't have a reservation), but inside is where the real experience is.
author: Aaron L.

description:
This is one of my top restaurants in San Francisco.  It's not as high value as Chapeau, but the food is just so good that I keep going back.  Yes, I love the butterscotch pot du creme, but the poached egg with jalapeno cream is just amazing.  I appreciate the "comfort food with a twist" theme, including all the kitchy touches like the receipt in a book.  

I've been coming here for a few years now....it's still where I like to go to celebrate in my "hood."

Update:  Just went back.  The service is MUCH improved.  Long waits seem to be a thing of the past.  Yay!  The wait staff was extremely knowledgeable about my wine pairings, and the roasted trout was to DIE for.  Reiterate 5 stars for value!  They give you a good amout of excellent food for the money.
author: Mel B.

description:
I can't wait to come again.  the appetizers were so hard to choose from, so i opted for 3 instead of a main course.   damn i am so FULL.  i'm pretty sure i will wake up tomorrow and still feel incredibly full.  next time i will definitely have to share some of the dishes with my friends/family.

Great service and atmosphere.  Loud but not noticably loud; it was easy to make conversation at our table of 6.  Had a very nice evening!  I honestly don't have any complaints.
author: J B.

description:
after all the hype and talk about town hall, i finally got to go.  thankfully it completely lived up to the hype!

the decor of town hall is very nice and homely.  the dining area is pretty packed up but you don't feel like you're too close to the table next to you.  some people might be annoyed by the bathroom being on the 2nd floor but i didn't mind it.  our waiter, thomas, looked spot on like sayid from lost.  that aside, he was very friendly and informative.  he had good knowledge of the wine list and the menu and what paired well w/ what.  his suggestions were spot on and we loved everything.

we started with the fried squash blossoms and the tuna tartare.  the blossoms were nice, crispy and light.  the goat cheese and the pesto that accompanied it were tasty and created a nice and balanced dish.  the tuna tartare, which was good on its own, was accompanied by some great fried green tomatoes.

for the entree portion of the meal, i got the slow roasted duck w/ dates, wild rice and a ginger reduction sauce.  i was just so in love w/ this dish.  the dates and the sauce went so well w/ the duck and the rice made a good base for the dish.  the suggestion of the mill valley pinot noir was excellent and paired very well with the dish.  the wife and our friend both got the risotto with asparagus and mushrooms which was topped with frisee.  they were both very happy w/ the dish and enjoyed the sauvignon blanc that was recommended.

we had no room for dessert there so we decided to call it a night.  we definitely will go back for the other items on the ever-changing menu and i also owe thomas a shot of tequila!
author: Swarup B.

description:
Decent but nothing stood out. Good food is all.
Pricey comfort food but nothing worth mentioning.
It's popular because it's close to a bunch of law offices. That's it.
Ordinary for San Francisco.
You can do better.
author: Faisal M.

description: We reserved the entire front communal table for a recent work dinner. Our server was very attentive and prompt, and she helped me to order a custom vegetarian entree, since there isn't an official one on the entree menu. I told her I wanted to try the brussel sprouts and jalapeno cornbread and other than that, they could make me whatever they wanted. I ended up getting a combination of grits, spinach and shredded brussel sprouts, a mushroom concoction, and a celery puree- which I thought was both novel and tasty. The portion was not heavy or overwhelming, which turned out to be fantastic because it was ALLLL about the DESSERT. I ordered the pumpkin cheesecake with candied pumpkin seeds, bourbon whipped cream and 2 little cookies shaped like Halloween bats!! I also really wanted the Blue Bottle coffee ice cream that came with "coffee and donuts", so I ordered a side of that, which turned out to be like a whole dessert in itself, but hey- the more the merrier! They were both sooooo good! I had to do a Facebook status update about them when I got home. It was a great experience, and there was never an empty wineglass in front of me the whole nite!
author: Libbi K.

description: One of the few restaurants I've been to where the reality lives up to the hype.  We got there for a 9pm reservation and were seated after a few minutes... I know some reviewers get all pissy for having to wait longer than 10 seconds, but I view a busy restaurant as a good sign that I'm in for a real treat. In any case, the food was excellent and the ambience reminded me of Cape Cod/New England. Definitely try the tuna tartare, and the shoestring fries are excellent (albeit nutrionally void). For dessert, we had some sort of toffee cake (forgot the exact name!) that was heaven on a plate. Great wine list too.
author: Chris B.

description:
Update 12/14/7: My parents, who are nototriously unwilling to try new places, were up for the weekend. We convinced them that Town Hall would impress. Apps (muscles, ham and egg, jalepeno cornbread) were on point, just as before. Dad and I opted for the fried chicken, which I touted as THE DISH.  Chicken came. Dad cut into a breast piece and... it was RAW IN THE MIDDLE. I checked mine, same issue. We flagged down a nearby runner, and he took it back. Minutes later, our waiter returned and said to my father "just so you know, it wasn't raw, it was just dark meat." Um, NO. Breast meat, as we all know, is white meat , but regardless, dark meat is dark, not cool to the touch, trancelucent and pink. I couldn't believe that our server had the audacity to argue. Just accept the complaint, appologize and fix it.  Second round of chicken comes out and....wait for it... RAW AGAIN.. we lost our appetite, and my parents lost their confidance in Town Hall. The establishment does retain two stars because they did comp the apps and, naturally, the chicken.  But raw chicken twice just isn't acceptable. Sorry, Town Hall.

Previous Review: Just like our knowledgeable, engaging waiter said... "yum!"  
"Yum" epitomizes my experience at Town Hall!  From the Guinness fondue, served with generous portions of spicy sausage, cauliflower and potatoes to the surprisingly light and fluffy cheesecake dessert- I'm coming back, but only if I'm really, really hungry.  This was in no way, shape or form a light meal. 

Fried chicken was rich, buttery and not at all over-battered. So juicy was this chicken that I'd actually return to pay the $19 price tag.  Boyfriend's pork chop was solid- smoky, touch of salt, cooked well. Jalapeno cornbread was ambrosia!  

Between the service (really great), the decor (exposed red brick and cool, sparkly chandeliers), the food (yum yum yum) and the bottle of cakebread zin that we brought- it might very well become my favorite restaurant in the City!
author: Jenni D.

description: I had been dying to go to Town Hall for forever because of all the buzz.  I finally went and now, a few months later as I'm writing this review, I can't even remember what I ordered (and I rarely forget a meal).  It was that mediocre.  I was unimpressed, and not just because I had built it up for so long.  The portions are small for the price, the service was average, the food was unremarkable.  Gorgeous space, but I was also kind of annoyed at having to take a 2 mile hike to get to the bathroom.  Probably won't go back.
author: Alyssa W.

description: Town Hall is outstanding!!!  I wasn't sure what to expect when I made the reservation, which may I add is highly recommended. I thought I'd have a nice upscale meal but instead I got a meal that made smile from beginning to end. The service was great and our waitress was attentive. The hostess was welcoming and friendly. I had the scallops with butternut squash sauce. Go her just for that!!! Dessert was amazing. Go if you're a tourist and go if you're locale. Just go!
author: Lisa A.

description:
Town Hall surprised me. I figured it would be a place filled with skinny white bitches (which it was), and that me in my red plaid hunting cap would be frowned upon. Oddly enough, everything turned out alright.

To start, my girlfriend and I split the mac and cheese croquettes, which were really delicious. They came with a simple marinara-type sauce, which didn't really do anything for the flavor, but it still was delicious. My entree was the buttermilk fried chicken, which I found hilarious because I probably could've gone to Farmerbrown or Hard Knox if I wanted chicken for significantly less, but Town Hall didn't disappoint.  The bacon gravy definitely added a star on its own.

The wait staff was surprisingly not stuck up at all, which one might expect from this kind of yuppie bastard establishment. Our waiter looked like he was straight out of TV on the Radio, and I think we both win awards for the most awesome beards in the joint. We asked if we could get my Turbo Dog beer to go (my girlfriend suggested a sippy cup, I suggested a paper bag), and he started laughing and told us a story about how he almost beat the shit out of some bouncer for not letting him do the same (he's from New Orleans, and that shit is somehow legal there). Needless to say, this guy is now my new best friend.

This place is fancy pants expensive, but I bet you already knew that. I'm glad it wasn't my turn to pay, that's for sure.
author: Alexis C.

description: Highly, highly recommend the pork chops. The most tender, mouth-watering pork chops I've ever had. My date got the rib-eye steak and it was good, but nothing special. Great ambiance and service. A little on the noisy side and the bathroom is really inconvenient.
author: Annie C.

description: Had a great meal here with good company; really enjoyed the pork chop and the panna cotta.  Not a huge fan of the oysters -- they came recommended, but I found them a little bland.  The cocktails were generally great.  I had an excellent rye manhattan, and the driver 8 was also pretty good, but I would not recommend the sazerac.  The restaurant itself was very pleasant, although a touch loud, and the service was right on with recommendations and very friendly.
author: Danielle G.

description: Very impressive meal; Southern-style fare is rich and delicious, but the main event are the desserts.. Highly recommended.
author: Rob G.

description: My first experience @ Town hall was not very memorable. It was a party of 10 and the service was not good. Plus at the end of the evening we were asked to leave because we were too loud. Food was OK but I'm sure the alcohol had a lot to do with me not remembering what we actually ate. Decided never to come again but over time decided to give it another try. Service was very good this time around and the food was pretty good. The appetizers are innovative and tasty and the short ribs hit the spot for a chilly city night.
author: Mani R.

description: nice place, great service, great wine list, pricey, nice crowd but food is average.
author: Tina F.

description: Overall, pretty good but not exactly memorable. The highlights were the ahi tuna and bbq shrimp appetizers. The lamb entree was prepared nicely - not gamy at all. Dessert was disappointing - not sure what all the hype is about the pot de creme? I am a a dessert junkie and it was just...weird. It was definitely worthy trying but we won't be back anytime soon.
author: Joy A.

description: My drink was delightfully strong, the biscuits were delicious and the service was friendly. Not very vegetarian-friendly, but that wasn't a surprise. I'd be willing to go back, but it all seemed overpriced for what it was.
author: Tamara M.

description: Oh my God...so good!  The brownie dessert is one of the absolute best desserts I have ever had.  My entire meal was really extraordinary.  If you go for lunch try the tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes, duck confit and again don't miss the brownie sundae!!
author: Diane R.

description: I have to agree with a lot of folks - Town Hall just didn't do anything for me food-wise.  The atmosphere is not romantic at all.  I guess it's good for a group lunch or dinner or a casual night out.  I gave TH 3 stars instead of 2 because I did have an exceptional heirloom tomato dish there a few years ago.  In fact, I just told someone I'd only go back to Town Hall during heirloom tomato season.  Take or leave my advice, tomato lovers.
author: Denise G.

description: Had dinner at Town Hall last night with my BFFs.  Loved it!  Service was great, dinner was de-lish!  I had the fried chicken, YUM, the mashers were so tastey.  We shared a bunch of appetizers, all interesting and YUM.  I would definitely go again.  Only caveat is it is really loud there, so not a good place for a quiet, intimate dinner.  Otherwise, GO!
author: L W.

description: I haven't written a review in months because I had a baby back in July and, well, time just gets away from you after that.  But our dinner at Town Hall last night was so good I'm still drooling over it today and I had to pull myself away to write about it.  Everything was great, but really I have two words for you:  Fried Chicken.  It was the most delicious fried chicken I had ever had.  Ever.  You have to go now and get it.  Run as fast as you can.  4 stars because the service, though pleasant, was super slow.  But fried chicken so definitely worth the wait.
author: Jen T.

description: The food was great but the service at lunch was a bit slower than I'd have liked.  Maybe I was in a hurry and that's why it seemed slower than it was.  The heirloom tomoato salad, the butter lettuce salad (which my friend had) and the alaskan halibut were fantastic.  The toffee cake was also a favorite among people.
author: Chaz N.

description:
I have wanted to try this place for quite some time now and although I'm glad I did, I had a really horrible customer service experience that I think others, including the management, should know about. 

The good-
The food is really excellent, New American with southern influence. They did a nice job of working with the rustic industrial look, while still creating a nice warm feeling with good lighting and fun fixtures. I love that they serve you a bill in an old american literature book.

The bad- 
I have to say, I eat out at restaurants high and low end all the time and get great service, but this was a joke. I just about walked out and left the place. 

When I arrived, I was about 10 minutes early, the bar was crowded but there were many open tables. I wandered in the door and no one greeted me, the staff were busy, or looked away and completely ignored. I thought I must have come in the wrong door, so I walked through the restaurant to find I had indeed come in the front door. There was a woman with dark hair in an updo studying the reservation schedule, who saw me, and kept her back to me going over the schedule, never said hello, never said please wait a moment, completely ignored me. I found this very strange. I was a host about 20 years ago and I would have been fired if I wasn't on my toes to please every guest at the restaurant. 

Eventually I was able to locate the hostess, a woman with a blonde french twist. I though, surely this woman with dark hair is a guest and she should be helped first, I insisted, and the hostess simply replied that they knew each other and she did not need help. I let her know I was early, checking in, could be seated first although my dining companion was running late, and would love to sit outside. She said that would be fine and tables would be set. Large parties came and were seated, tables outside were set for other small and large parties and others were seated as well. I patiently waited, knowing that I had come early, but wondered if my table was going to be given to someone else.

My patience had worn out, there were no seats at the bar, there was no where to sit in the entry and I had been standing already, waiting for 30 minutes! I was starving and completely sober, so that really seemed like an eternity. I checked in with the receptionist again and told her I'd been waiting, it was passed my reservation time, there were open tables outside and I'd like to be seated right away. She checked with the bus staff, who, after another 10 minutes, got around to setting a table for me. I waited, waited, waited, and the hostess never once checked on me, offered me a drink, a menu, a chair, anything! I could not find her anywhere. Completely exasperated, I seated myself at the table, The waiter gave me a funny look and I explained I had waited an inordinately long time to be seated at a table that had been empty the entire time.  Without welcome or apology, he came back with menus and my dining companion arrived. I was infuriated at the process and lack of service and respect. My dining companion asked me if I wanted to leave, I told him the food looked good and I'd already waited too long to not at least get a meal. 

1 star- for the 5 star food, really! If the service matched the food, I'd give this place 5 stars.
1 star- for the slow service by our waiter, who was less than charming, but at least got the job done.
0 stars- for the hostess and all the other staff who provided the opposite of service and hospitality when I arrived.

I'd be in a hurry to come back for the food here, but the experience was truly unacceptable. Maybe I was cranky hungry, maybe I needed to wear a suit to get service at this "casual dress" (I checked ahead of time) establishment, in the end, I was simply happy to have eaten.
author: J B.

description: I've been for both work & play all were perfect.  They can host a work dinner in a private dining room with ease and are very accommodating.  When I finally went on my own & sat in the main dining room, they exceeded my expectations yet again.  They really do have the best hot chocolate in the world.
author: Liz V.

description: Having only dined here once on a whim, maybe I shouldn't be giving it 4 stars. But we had a damned good meal - from the stuffed squash blossoms to the perfect pork chop. The food was straight forward, approachable, inventive and spot on. Maybe we got lucky that night, considering some of the 3 star ratings. Maybe I need to try it again when I'm up in the City to see if it really warrants the rating I gave it.
author: A. P.

description: I've only had business or semi-business lunches here, but I've had a lot of them, and I have loved the food each time.  While it's different than the old Stars, it reminds me of that era, and the Cafe at Chez Panisse (with a bit of  N.O. twist).  And the one time we had wine (around the New Year), the sommelier's recommendations were interesting and fun and challenging and terrific.
author: Laurel B.

description:
Adorable little building with great decor...but something was keeping this place from being...fantastic?  Don't get me wrong, it was GOOD, but after I finished my meal I asked myself, "would I come back?" and the resounding answer was "enh. no not really."

maybe the food was yummy but not mind blowing, maybe it was the fact that i felt ignored by our waitress (who took FOREVER and a day to get us bread and when we asked for our cornbread which I thought came with our appetizer she charged us the extra $6 for the order.  but hey , i coulda been wrong)...either way I have no plans on coming back.

Entrees seemed to run around $25, appetizers around $13.
author: jozilla w.

description: Terrible service.  Or waiter was rude and surly.  We waited forever to order, then had a long wait for the appetizers and even longer for our main courses.  Food was ok, but by the time it arrive, one no longer cared.  One can find food that is as good with much better service.
author: Ben Y.

description:
i was pleasantly surprised but not overly impressed.  that's why i give it 4 stars instead of 3 or 5.  

pleasantly surprised, because it wasn't super-crowded and the wait staff was very nice and provided good service.  for some reason i had certain expectations of this restaurant and thought it may be very hoity-toity and upscale but it felt down to earth and casual.  the food was priced ok, not cheap but not completely unaffordable. 

i had the scallops and jambalaya, which was pretty dang spicy.  even for me, a lover of spicy foods.  my friend had the alaskan halibut which i  tried a bite, it was quite good.  we both had appetizers of oysters on the half shell and they were excellent.  

overall a great experience.  definitely worth more than 3 stars, it's on that level.  can't quite give it 5 stars because i've been too spoiled.  i don't think you can go wrong here.
author: Christy I.

description: I took my husband to Town Hall for his birthday, since it was on his list of must-try restaurants in the city.  We could not have been more pleased!  Dinner was absolutely wonderful!  We sat at the bar before our reservation (we were early) and enjoyed a drink.  When we were seated at our table, I think we got the best table in the place - in the very back in the corner.  I was worried about the noise level, based on the other reviews...and it is noisy, but it makes it a fun atmosphere.  Our waiter, Thomas, was perfect.  Our food was excellent...from the heirloom tomato fondue appetizer, to the fried chicken (YUM)...and of couse dessert...everything was topnotch.  We will DEFINITELY be dining at Town Hall again!
author: Ann W.

description:
i liked everything about this place, including the water glasses they had. they were cheapy looking but i still dug them cause they had fleur de lys on them. 

we ordered the tuna tartar appetizer and they split it in two automatically without us asking them to. bonus points for you, miss server!

then came my short ribs which were succulent as hell. the gnocchi on the plate wasn't that great but i'm not one to ask about gnocchi anyway. 

my friend ordered the fried chicken. seasoned to perfection and ungreasy. creamed corn, good. biscuits and gravy were okay although the hint of bacon in the gravy makes me think that all gravies should have cured pig in it.

STICKY TOFFEE PUDDING!!!! SO good! it's gi-normous. probably the size of 2/3 a roll of toilet paper. i don't really know what to say except it was SO good. i ate the whole thing by myself after eating that already large meal.
author: Regina C.

description: Took clients for lunch this week.  When your in the business of fine dining clients certainly expect the most out of the restaurants you choose.  Couldn't have been more pleased with the food and level of service we received.  Friendly from the moment we entered the door.  Loved the ahi and fried green tomatoes!  Will definely return.
author: Jaclyn D.

description: Good place but nothing overly special.  Serves up great comfort food, entrees have been hit or miss for me, service has always been good, can get crowded, and the bar is small with very little wiggle room.
author: Brian J.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the city.  If you're looking for delicious comfort food in a warm atmosphere, look no further than Town Hall.  Lunchtime can get  a little too busy/noisy and the crowd very corporate CEO-ish, but the food/ambiance/service will make you forget everything except for the people you're eating w/ and the food itself.  Dinner has a much more relaxed feel to it.  Try the gnocchi and the game hen.  Make sure to call in for reservations unless you happen to find yourself there on a Sunday or Monday.
author: Jenny K.

description: i had a huge headache when I went there, didn't have reservation either.  ate at the communal table.  got a salad, just ok.  Duck dish was just awful.  don't get the duck!!  didn't try the desserts.  Too expensive for me.
author: Ann L.

description: My bf and I went to dinner here on a weeknight to celebrate our 8th year dating together.  I had heard from coworkers that it's one of the restaurants where people make reservations a lot so we decided to try it thinking it was good.  The place was easy to find as it was right off the freeway, but the parking wasn't widely available.  We had to circle around and park on the street near what I think was a Greyhound station.  We had reservations for 8:15.  We got there a little early, but they sat us promptly at 8:15 which was nice.  We sat down next to a brick wall in the corner, but noticed that it was a noisy restaurant.  We could barely hear each other talk as most tables had groups of people.  The crowd tended to be a little older than what I expected.  I was a little disappointed that the menu didn't seem too appealing.  Not the kind of food I was looking for or in the mood for.  For appetizers, we had some fresh oysters and crab salad.  The crab salad was good as it included real fresh Dungeness crab meat with butter lettuce.  For dinner, I had the snapper which came with polenta, mushrooms, and spinach.  The portions were big as any American-style restaurant.  The food was okay.  For dessert, we tried the toffee cake with vanilla ice cream, but it was not very good.  It was too sweet.  At least the service was good.  Overall, the food was not worth what we paid foor.
author: Erica S.

description:
this was my second time there and it wasn't really memorable. well, it kind of was because one of the co-workers i was with was quite upset at the amount of time it took for us to be served during the lunch hour.  (by the way, the front half of the restaurant was empty so they didn't have a full house.) some of us had ordered the DAT menu and others hadn't so some were left waiting while we finished our appetizers. then, it was a more than half an hour wait between appetizer and entrees which really wasn't acceptable. 

the food was okay, nothing exciting. i've had better bisque soup from the soup area at safeway and while my entree had a good amount of yummy shrimp, the sauce itself was a bit too salty. the dessert, a pot de creme of chocolate and i forgot what else, was a bit too sweet.
author: ML N.

description:
Town Hall is the "go to" quasi-fancy workday lunch spot, so I have eaten there 15-20 times for lunch and a few times for dinner.  It is a solid choice and I believe it has one of the best burgers in town (homemade pickles!).  The service is always friendly and I swear one of the regular lunch waiters is psychic, arriving with a new beverage as I am taking the last sip or more condiments just as I am about to run out.  For dinner, my expectations are slightly higher and although I have never been disappointed it seems just a smidge too expensive - I expect a twist or a bit more presentation or something.

I think for my next visit I will check-out Town Hall's take-out station behind the restaurant - I spied a delicious-looking fried chicken sandwich, so that is on my list!
author: Lori G.

description: Housed in a converted industrial space, Town Hall features one of the most well designed interiors in the city, a mixture of rough hewn industrial and classically elegant detail. If you like American food done well, than you'll love Town Hall.  The flavors are big, though the portions are medium. I've only been for lunch so far, and I'm not sure I'd be moved to try it for dinner, however, it's a great place for a business lunch, as the sea of business casual clad diners will attest. The tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes was a highlight, as was the thoughtfully chosen wine list.
author: Stellah D.

description:
I really like Town Hall.  It's terribly hard to get a reservation at the last minute, so it's a good thing we plan a couple of weeks in advance!  My pork chops were really good and I loved the sweet white corn that came with it!  I wanted to eat it all up, but they filled the entire bottom of my plate with it and I couldn't fit another bite in if I wanted to save a little bit of room for dessert.  The feel of the restaurant is very town hall-ish.  The bathroom is like ten million miles away, so if you're hunting for it after having more than just a few drinks in you - good luck!  We left a little before 10pm on a Friday night and it was still packed.  There was still a line of people waiting for tables and a couple layers of people milling about the bar.  Their problem with that is it's really hard for the diners to leave the restaurant with all the people at the bar blocking the path to the exit!

12.02.2007 Update: Came here for dinner last night with family.  Got a 6pm reservation and got in without any problems.  The restaurant was pretty empty at that time.  HOWEVER, we sat there (a table of 5!) for over 30 minutes completely unnoticed!  Nobody stopped by to see how we were doing, give us some glasses of water, or take our order!  It was ridiculous.  We were pretty PEEVED, especially since the restaurant was nowhere near full.  My dad finally was able to flag someone down (the front of the house guy) and asked him for some waters while my sister asked if someone could take our order.  Great person to flag down because after that, the service was IMPECCABLE.  He was extremely apologetic and after we got our orders in, he comped us some sides and an appetizer.  I now totally LOVE the Jalapeno Cornbread!!!  I must have the recipe because it's so yummy!!!  The food was excellent and the service afterward was more than excellent.  He even offered to comp us an extra dessert if we wanted, but we were so full we couldn't fit another bite in.  Minus 2 stars from original review for the 30 minute wait, but plus 1 for the great way they apologized for it.
author: Kris L.

description: Delicious and enticing food, atmosphere and staff!  And let's just say, the  pot de creme is every bit of divine as you have heard.  I became a little emotional.
author: Beth G.

description:
monday night at town hall was a great experience.  it was packed!  we were a group of eight and our server did an awesome job managing all of us.  

good: wine, all the art on the wall, everything on the menu, hot chocolate (more like a melted chocolate, it was so good and evil at the same time), and service

not so great: parking, virtually none, bathroom (you have to exit the restaurant and go up stairs), and its name
author: Dee Y.

description: After going to Town Hall the 2nd time, I popped up my rating to 5 stars from 3. After my 4th time, I'm giving 5 SUPER stars :) The chicken continued to be amazing but the appetizers blew me away. Town Hall is now one of my favorite places for dinner in the city.
author: Han C.

description:
knowledgable and attentive wait staff.  good recomendations.
tasty dishes.  i had a rabbit trio.
mmm the desserts were rich and yummie.
atmosphere was cozy and it didn't feel too loud or noisy
left the place really stuffed and happy.
author: charlotte s.

description:
This review is a little overdue, but considering the amazing evening I had, I just had to make time to get it up.  
     I heard about the restaurant from my roommate.  I was looking for somewhere nice to go out to dinner in the city and he told me Town Hall had fantastic new American food.  It sounded interesting.  I went online and booked a table through their Open Table Reservation system, very convenient.  They were almost booked for the evening but I managed to get a table for two.  I was meeting a good friend who I had not seen in 10 years, and was greatly looking forward to a nice evening. I was already impressed with their website, and ease of reservations, but it was not to stop there.  
     My friend had a change of plans and we were forced to dine later in the evening.  She called the restaurant and they were able to change our reservation for a half our later.  By the time I had picked her up and we got to the restaurant, it was 15 minutes past our reservation and I was worried we would be out of luck.  
     I walked in to their entrance on Howard Street and was immediately amazed.  Their main dining room stretched out away from me with a beautiful bar along the left wall.  Rich hardwood floors met elegant white crown molding on the walls, supporting lovely windows that accented the rich redbrick walls.  And it was packed.  Servers were quickly weaving through the dining room rush, but I was immediately aware of the restaurant manager.  Her appraising gaze and calm demeanor instantly identified her.  Our hostess was a sweetheart.  Although she had marked us as a no show, she had us seated at a table in 4 minutes.   WOW.
     The table was simply but ideally lain out, and we were soon seated amidst the rest of the well dressed and hungry guests.  Our server (Theodorus?sp) was fantastic, as was his support staff.  He was knowledgeable about the menu, was able to recommend a few items over others which I tremendously respect. It shows a server knows the menu and how to pair the guest with items they will love. I found a nice bottle of Spanish red for $50 and we settled in to catch up.  As a starter, we ordered the BBQ Gulf Shrimp with a Worcestershire sauce and garlic toast.  The kitchen split the appetizer for us and it was still a substantial portion.  3 large shrimp each, an the sauce was SOOOO good.  I would kill for the recipe.  Next, we decided to split a salad of butter lettuce, sliced pear, walnuts and Point Reyes blue cheese dressing. Split again and fantastic.  An elegant take on blue cheese dressing, it was lite but flavorful, and allowed the rest of the items to really shine.  We followed that with an entree each.  I had the Rabbit cooked 3 ways, served with greens, mashed potatoes and a coffee jus.  My friend had the porkchop.  The portions were great, as was the presentation.  The food was arranged elegantly without being molested into an awkward position on the plate.  The highlight of my plate was the rabbit saddle.  I could eat this every day.  Tender, rich, soft... I am lost for words.  The greens on the plate were perfectly cooked, the sauce was amazing.  I was hesitant at first about a coffee jus, but our server convinced me to try.  Im very glad I did.  The other preparation was a shredded rabbit that was molded, battered and deep fried. It was all right, I liked the textural difference that it added in the dish, having something nice and crisp.  I was slightly unimpressed with the 3rd preparation, which was a bone in rack of rabbit.  It was less than one bite.  Still, interesting and tasty.  My friends pork chop was huge, and faced the same problems any pork chop does... getting cooked enough without being dry.  I had a few bites and found it to be ok.  Nothing I would order again. We finished with a rocky road desert, which was amazing.  Rich, decadent, lush.  A great way to finish the evening.  I sat there with my double espresso wishing I could eat like this every day.  So, 1 appetizer, 1 salad, 2 entrees, 1 desert, 1 bottle of wine, 1 double espresso and 20% tip, out the door for $200.  Very reasonable for the quality of the evening.  I will certainly be back, and looking forward to the new items the chef features.  Ive frequently been going to their web site and noticing that they change up their menu quite frequently.  FANTASTIC. :)
author: Beau S.

description: A favorite comfort food spot. Rich flavors but delicious and well balanced (like the bacon with quail - must love bacon). Nice wine list. Great place to dine or hang at the bar with a nice bottle of bubbly. Fun people watching perch.
author: Lizelle G.

description: I've been to this restaurant a handful of times and everytime it has been absolutely superb!  It's a great place to have tapas at the bar with a friend.  The staff has always been very friendly and the service is wonderful.
author: Kattya B.

description: I must have had a bad experience, because compared to the other positive reviews, I wasn't particularly impressed with this place. Considering the price of the entrees ($20-25), the service was fine and the food (I ordered a seafood etouffee) was decent. It met my expectations, but nothing more. You can definitely find better food for less money in San Francisco.
author: John C.

description: So, I popped in while waiting for a friend to get off work from Schwab around the corner to have a drink. I found the clientele to be a bit off putting and the waitress wasn't very efficient. I was looking for a whiskey that was advertised on the menu and she couldn't find it. I sat outside and waited for my friend and watched the other waitress walk in and out and she didn't offer a scintilla of assitance, not even a "Can I get you anything else." Overall, bad service, great decor, bathroom was quite a hike up a few floors, but clean. It's basically a corporate restaurant and not some place I'd ever visit again.
author: Martin H.

description: Very unique and wonderful food. I loved the duck.
author: Sam r.

description: I quite liked this place.  We made reservations and had to wait for our table but the service was excellent the entire time.  I really liked how diverse the menu was with regards to entree selections - rabbit, pork chops, steak, chicken, sea bass, scallops, duck...there's something for everybody!  The ambiance was pleasant despite the hustle and bustle, my only complaint is how confusing a trip to the bathroom can be.  It's through an unmarked door near the bar, up the stairs, around the corner...and after a glass or two of wine this can be a bit of a trek.
author: Ky W.

description:
So apparently the cool kids have turned on Town Hall. Whatever. The place is solid. It is a yuppie hotspot so be prepared for that. The inside is fine but full of insipid chatter about pointless bullshit and yuppies trying to impress one another with crap that no normal human being should care about. Fortunately the spice that the environment and people lack is made up for by the food. If you can't handle this level of spice, you're a pussy. Plain and simple. Go have a hot dog and let the rest of us use our taste buds. Had the following dishes:
1) Tuna tartare - Delicious. I think there was a seared fingerling potato with it or something. Don't remember since I was on a date where I was batting way out of my league and needed to stay on my toes. 
2) Seafood etoufee - Had a little spice to it. Shrimp were decent quality. The rice was a little dry but Basmati is as Basmati does.
3) Pot de creme - Made my teeth hurt it was so sweet. And rich. Actually I blame that for the chest pains I'm having today. Or maybe it was the pack of Camel Lights I tore through. Ah well.
Anyways, without rambling, the place is a winner as long as you know what you're getting into. Good food, good wine, decent decor, bland-ass people. Enjoy with a crew that can add some flavor to the place. Out.
author: Ahsan M.

description: You cannot go wrong at Town Hall.  I've been there about 5 times and each time, I've loved all that I tasted.  The only thing I don't like about this place is that its hard to decide what to order because the entire menu sounds delish.  No doubt I'll be back.
author: Erin K.

description: I'm not sure why I'm adding my voice to the multitudes, but I liked Town Hall a lot.  It is SOOOO NOISY though.  It wasn't make-you-cry-tears-of-ecstasy food, but it was simpler and better prepared than at a lot of restaurants of its type.  I didn't leave feeling as stuffed and sick as I sometimes do after work lunches despite the enormous portions.  Maybe I was just in a good mood the day we went, but I thought it was pleasant chaos and that the waitstaff were friendly and accommodating.   Only my very favorites get 5 stars, but I thought it had a lovely (sort of elegant pub?  something about all the glass reminded me of train stations in London) space, great staff, and solidly well-prepared food.
author: Marie K.

description: I have been here a few times now for lunch, and the food is really good, especially for a place that is a "trendy" spot. They have a limited lunch menu but there is something for everyone. The heirloom tomato panini is excellent, and the appetizers are very good. Somehow I have always ended up with the same waiter, and he's always smiling and helpful. The only thing I haven't been that happy with was the dessert - the chocolate cake kind of tasted like Betty Crocker mix (lovely presentation though!) and the summer fruit tart was...meh. I have been told that the bread pudding is phenomenal, but have yet to try it. Overall, great lunch, minus one star for the so-so desserts.
author: Alessandra J.

description:
A solid 4 stars for this place.  However, it still cannot top the House.  For the same amount of money, I'd make reservations at the House anyday.  

Regardless, I'll continue on with the review.  This place is more about home cookin' than creating Californian masterpieces.  You'll find items like short ribs, fried chicken, and steak on the menu.  Most menu items are very seasonal, which is a great sign.  

I ordered the rabbit stew which was full of flavor without the need for salt.  My wife had the dayboat scallops, which were cooked correctly.  They weren't overcooked and filling.  I also tried a bit of a friend's short ribs.  I would probably order this item again whenever I come back.  The porkchop was otherwise uninspired.  

The wine here is rather pricey.  They definitely charge a very high premium per bottle.  I enjoyed dinner but overall, the cost wasn't as worth it.  It's hard to live up to the House and this one comes up fairly short.  I'd recommend it but not as my first or second choice.
author: Scott L.

description:
We thoroughly enjoyed our meal here and chose this restaurant for a night of amazing food and atmosphere - we were not disappointed. We dined on raw and fried oysters and the table had everything to the fried chicken, ribs, catfish, and sturgeon. All delicious. 

The service was fantastic and we were never without drink and water refills.

The atmosphere is also fantastic, a homestyle chatty feel with a lovely bar. Town Hall is not stuffy or pretentious but a lovely restaurant with decadent food in a chill atmsophere.
author: Fog N.

description: I don't understand what the hype is about. It's pretty decent food, but I don't think it's worth the price. The decor is pretty nice. Their water glasses are gorgeous!!! It's a good power lunch place to talk business and to network, but I'm a little sick and tired of places like this. Nothing special that stands out (in my opinion). I will say that it's a very safe and reliable place. When in doubt, Town Hall will be there for you.
author: Su K.

description:
Good food in parts. The halibut entree was good. The yellowtail sashimi appetizer was ok - didnt fancy the sweet fruit juice/sauce with the yellowtail. The fish itself was was great, but fruit juice and melon and peach bits with sashimi? 

My colleague had the steak and was raving about it.
author: Getafix O.

description: I really didn't like this place at all. It was incredibly noisy and cold- my friend and I wore our coats during the entire meal. Drinks were tasty, and the butterscotch-chocolate thing was definitely a high point, but the food was just okay. Our waiter, on the other hand, was not okay at all. And, while I'm complaining, I really didn't dig hiking up all those stairs to the ladies room. Enough said.
author: Lisa L.

description: I had an awful experience here!  Making a reservation two weeks in advance, I still had to wait 20 minutes for my table.  When we finally were seated, we were put in the back by the kitchen in a corner.  Our waitress knocked over my friends glass of wine and while she replaced it, she never apologized.  We waited for an eternity to get our food and when it finally did come out it was cold.  We spoke to the manager about our experience who was very gracious about the whole thing and comped our meal.   But my friend and I would have preferred a great meal with great service (per the excellent reviews this place had been getting) as opposed to a sub-par free meal.  I will eventually get around to trying it again, but it is not at the top of my list.
author: Katie P.

description:
I was excited to try Town Hall after hearing all the hype, but I left slightly disappointed... the interior is fun, bright and airy. I didn't think the restaurant was too noisy. The food though was kinda average. Not offensive, but not impressive or particularly tasty. I had the fried cornmeal oysters followed by the pine nut crusted white fish. I'm Asian so I'm big on flavor and I found the food to taste kinda bland. I wanted to smother ketchup on my fish to give it some flavor! Now, maybe if you don't like your food to be very spicy or flavorful, you will enjoy the food more. But I like flavor, so I don't think I would be making a return visit to Town Hall.

*I must add that their butterscotch/chocolate dessert was pretty yummy. That was definitely the best part of my meal!

10/06 Update---
I made a second visit (out of location convenience) and was surprised at how much I enjoyed the food. They had an updated menu, which is nice to see. My ahi tuna was very tasty.
author: Mama L.

description: Finally, a hugely hyped restaurant that actually lives up to it. The food is top notch and the service is phenomenal. I haven't had a better dining experience in years.
author: Ziad E.

description:
i had a really good meal here about a year ago with clients.  i would go back again.  i had really fantastic steak and the pot de creme was so good that it should probably be illegal.  

only drawback was the noise.  if you have difficulty hearing in crowded restaurants, you might want to reconsider.  the sound bounces off the walls like crazy!
author: Melissa Y.

description:
I am not sure how I feel about this place.  The fire alarm was going off when we sat down and it took the fire department over five minutes to arrive and turn it off.  That was an annoying way to start dinner.  Appetizers were off the hook... The buttermilk biscuits with marmalade and Virgina ham were yummy as were the veal meatballs.  Our entrees left a little to be desired.  I had the duck over gingerbread which tasted like a giant fried funnel cake.  Very sweet, not enough salt balance of the duck in my opinion.  My hubby had the pork chop which was good but not great.  The best part of his dish was the dirty rice the pork chop was served over.  The gentleman sitting next too us kept raving about the rib-eye.  He said it was the best he had ever had.  Maybe I should have ordered that.  The dessert was amazing, by far the best part of the meal.  Get the sticky toffee cake.  I repeat, get the sticky toffee cake.  Truly amazing.  

It was crowded and loud yes, but we enjoyed it and could have a conversation just fine.  Staff was very friendly and accommodating.  We were comped our dessert because of the fire alarm inconvenience.  There is great people watching here!  After work crowd of suits and ties, tourists, wanna-be-foodies (of which I am admittedly one), and several too old men with hot young chick couples... 

Would I go back?  Maybe... with out of towners, but I must admit that I have prepared better entrees at home for far cheaper, but oh the sticky toffee cake...
author: Michelle C.

description:
Went here with my co-workers for a holiday party, so I was able to sample a pretty wide range of appetizers and entrees. From start to finish, I was blown away by just how amazingly tasty and well prepared everything was. Highlights include: BBQ Gulf Shrimp, Grilled Rib Eye and the Hot Chocolate. Damnit, I'm getting hungry just thinking about it!

Hands down the best meal I've had in the many years I have lived in San Francisco!
author: Anthony D.

description:
lol! 
anyone who says the portions at town hall are too small is probably used to eating canned of lard from a trough. 
the food is amazing and everyone always seems to be having a good time. this place is everything i want when i go out.
author: gertie s.

description: Good food, good-looking restaurant. I wouldn't say I was wowed, but we had a really solid meal. I can understand why this is a go-to retsaurant for so many San Franciscans. Randomly the one thing we really loved was the ham and cheese toast (not the fanciest thing on the menu, but totally delicious.)
author: m t.

description:
I guess it is my lot in life, that my opinions will always be against the grain. Frankly, I really don't 'get' what everyone else on yelp loves about Town Hall.  I had lunch there with coworkers yesterday and I think it was "fine" but not outstanding. Service was weird, the server tackled us to take our order before we were even fully seated and then when we said we wanted to at least LOOK at the menu first, she smiled and walked away
NEVER TO RETURN AGAIN.
Okay, I exaggerate, but seriously we waited a long long long time for her to come back.   The food was tasty, (when we finally got a chance to order, and receive our choices) if not a little fried-heavy for my taste but nothing 'miraculous.  We asked for a recommendation for dessert, and the server suggested the sticky toffee cake and the bread pudding,which would have been fine  ( a little too sweet), but they tasted EXACTLY the same . Why would a server recommend 2  identical desserts ?  Another small pet peeve of mine, when the server brought dessert, she brought the check with it.  That always seems tacky to me, as if they are suggesting you wolf down your sweets and beat it out of there. 
All and all there was nothing offensive, or terribly wrong with Town Hall it just fell  way short of the glowing reviews I've read on Yelp.  I don't think I will bother going back again, there are too many fantastic places to try to give Town Hall a second chance.
author: cynthia a.

description: One of the most delicious meals I've ever had with the best service I've truly ever encountered. The staff was amazingly attentive, engaged with us without being overbearing, and delightfully friendly. Every course was a delight, but the fried chicken definitely stood out. I would recommend Town Hall to anyone who wants to have their mind blown by a dining experience.
author: emalie h.

description:
I've been going to this restaurant for years, and have written reviews before, but just had to post one that's up to date.  

This is still my all time fave in the city.  I love the people, the food,  everything!  The veal meatballs, and bbq shrimp are still one of the best things I've ever tasted in my life.  

Looking forward to many more years of great dining.
author: Meghan L.

description:
I am not sure what all the hype is about went to Town Hall for dinner a few months ago and I was not impressed with anything...from the staff to the food everything was boring to say the most. This place caters to San Francisco snobs at their greatest. The hostess never looked us in the eye or smiled when we walked in for our 9pm reservation. She simply said "follow me" dropped us off at the table and left...there were no pleasantries to be had with her because obviously she was waiting for the next young rich man to walk in and sweep her off her ummmmm "overworked feet"....Our server had the same boring assed I could care less attitude and while he was able to muster up an ounce of personality to engage with us for a nano second it took a lot. The food itself was under seasoned and lackluster....after all this hype I expected so much more that what I got.

Actually I take that back the Fried Chicken was really good although it lacked actual flavor but for bland foodies this seems the place to be.  I guess i like highly seasoned food that tastes great...what a concept. The appetizers were great and we thought that we were in for the meal of our lives if the appetizers were on point. I had the seafood chowder and it was truly amazing. After our appetizers were served it took a full 30-40 minutes for our meal to arrive we were never checked in on by our server....I guess he was too busy boring himself in the kitchen or something...we began to feel that they forgot to turn in our order. We were starving and we could not understand what on earth could take a kitchen that long to bring out some food. And really a restaurant that seemingly believes that it caters to "classy" customers would at least offer up an explanation as to why things were taking as long as they did. 

When the food arrived my ribs were luke warm while everyone else's Fried Chicken was piping hot....I am guessing this was the hold up but let a sistah know that the chicken would be cooking for like 30 mins. I wanted to send back my ribs but I was afraid to wait another 30mins. Overall based on the service and cost of the food not to mention the taste factor I would never return. We spent $120 dollars per person on god knows what!! I guess the pretentious San Francsico Foodies can all find each other here and compliment each other on their bland tasting food...but I won't be there nor would it be on my places to eat in the city!! Go there maybe for appetizers and their desserts but skip the meal itself!!
author: T H.

description: I really dont think I can say anything new among the numerous reviews others have said about this establishment but my gf and I loved this place.  We went here for dinner without a reservation so we ate at the bar.  Everything about this place, from the atmosphere to the service is great.  Its basically a really nice rest. with great service but without any of the stuffyness.  Its a great social place as well and the bartenders here are better than most places.  Food here is on par with some of the better rests in sf.  Well done, well proportioned and just very satisfying.  I admit, a little on the pricey side but pretty much on par in price with rests in the city on the same caliber.  Would def. recommend coming here to anyone intersted in good solid american food.  Its the type of place where I would go back for dinner anytime.
author: Charles C.

description: I have to say this is one of my favorite restaurants in the City. The sauteed dayboat scallops on andouille sausage  jambalaya with crab butter is one of my all time favorite dishes. The chocolate caramel pot de creme will make you want to lick the bowl clean like a dog.!  Great cocktails in a very cool environment. I send friends here all the time and they love it.
author: Greg S.

description:
After waiting to dine here I finally had a chance to have a special dinner there with my family on New Year's Day. Yes that was 6 months ago. 
I was very disappointed by my experience.
The hostess if you could call her that was sitting at the bar when we entered and appeared to be very angry that we dared to enter the restaurant and bother her. After getting a look from her which obviously meant who are you and why are you here I mentioned we had reservations. Begrudgingly she showed us to our party which had already been seated. 
The server, rude does not begin to explain. No hello, no happy new year, no how are you, no would you like a cocktail to start. Just can I get you a drink. 
Cocktails were great!
The starters were ok.
I had the etoufe, not sure if that's correct, which had the flavor of flour and that's about it. 
The only and I mean only redeeming part of the dinner was the butterscotch pot de creme. So amazing!!! The dessert is the only reason I gave the place 3 stars. 
If you enjoy eating at a restaurant where the staff judges you and treats you according to their made up opinion go to Town Hall. 
Otherwise if you never eat here you would not miss anything. If you do want to try Town Hall I would suggest going there for dessert, squeezing in at the bar and ordering the Pot de Creme it is worth it.
author: Matthew B.

description: I was very impressed with the appetizer--Lemon cucumber and heirloom tomato salad, feta cheese, nicoise olive, tomato crostini, with lemon vinaigrette. The crostini was really flavorful and brought all the flavors together. For the main course, I ordered the snapper. The tomato sauce it was in was delicious. The fish itself, maybe inherently is the nature of this fish's flesh, it seemed firm. I guess a thinner cut may have worked better with the thin sauce. Great service staff!
author: Olivia A.

description:
I had gone to Town Hall once before for lunch and was not that impressed, but my dinner last night was simply amazing. Friendly service, nice ambiance and wonderful food. My only complaint was that they did not bring my side of squash. =(

- BBQ Gulf Shrimp, Worcestershire sauce and garlic herb toast - So good, the bread in the sauce was amazing, I ate the entire basket of bread!
 - Peanut tasso crusted pork chop - Oh my, this was simply amazing! The peanut crust on top of the pork chop was amazing!
 - "Coffee & Donuts" - Heaven on earth, fresh beignets with Illy espresso ice cream, gaaaah!!!
author: Matt K.

description:
so working in the financial district can be both good and bad.  good in that there's a TON of stuff to eat. but in that the ton of stuff that costs a lot to eat is EXPENSIVE!  

although WLB and i have been gallivanting around town to find cheap eats, i was lucky enough to get treated to lunch by my mentor to town hall...and what a treat it was...

the fish tacos were delish...perfectly grilled fish, warm tortillas, and fresh salsa to top...even the bread was perfection...

looking forward to the next time an occasion calls for an expensive fancy lunch during the work week!
author: Grace O.

description:
My Wife and I love this place!!! Everything about this place is great. From the food to the wine list to the service, it's great!! The cool thing about this place is it doesn't have that stuffy feel that several popular SF restaurants have. It's very relaxed and comfortable but still very classy. 

Must haves:
- Tuna Tartar.. It's the best in SF!
- The Butterscotch/chocolate desert - Best in SF!
author: Scott R.

description: The portion of the food served in this place is small compared to the price paid. Service is neglected for the most part if not stiff.
author: francis p.

description: One of my absolute favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  What do I love about it?  Well, the food is great...but the service is even better - especially Jen and Armando behind the bar.  Can't get a table?  Don't sweat it and eat at the bar!
author: Glenn G.

description:
My second birthday dinner (a romantic outing with the 'boy') was an amazingly enjoyable experience here.  I actually feel that the other 5 stars I have given to some things in my reviewing past are now invalidated with the exception of The Village Pub.  
Let me start by saying that the service was fabulous.  We were met by the hostess with a warm smile and taken to our lovely corner table immediately.  Our waitress was a little busy but we did not feel neglected in the least.  
We shared some appetizers and then an entree...I suggest this is better route to to go here.  I would come back here for the roasted shrimp appetizer alone and make a meal of that!!! we also had the Tuna tartare and the sausage appetizer (we have to order any sausage on the menu at any eatery...I have been told it is a Wisconsin code of ethics rule...is that true?)
For the entree we shared the rib eye.  Everything was incredible.  However the shrimp stands alone!  
we were too full for dessert but I can imagine the desserts being fabulous, judging by the food.
Yes you pay for it, but its worth every penny!
We might have found a new favorite SF 'go to' place!
author: Nilu r.

description: Rolled in around 9 PM without a reservation and managed to score several seats at the bar within 30 minutes on a Saturday night. We brought a bottle of red, which they corked for a reasonable fee. Atmosphere is pretty laid back, and the drinks list is great. Started off with the specialty Manhattan, which was good, before moving onto wine. First course was the ham and cheese toast topped with a large poached egg and finished with jalapeno cream. Heavy but d%^m good. All the components of breakfast you love sitting in a bath of spicy dairy fat. Woohoo! After that healthy helping of swine, I had to swap out my bacon-wrapped trout the bartender recommended for the tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes appetizer , which was also very good. The crowd was a pretty diverse mix of people, but my buddy did turn to me at one point during dinner and say, "Is this Cougarville or what?" ;)
author: Michael R.

description: Good food that got spoiled by extreme use of salt.  That's how i'd describe the food here.  Started with tasty appetizers:  meat balls, corn bread and mac n cheese.  Buttery but tasty.   For an entree i had the Steak, nicely done, but the veggies and sides were way too salty.  To the point where I just wanted to had to stop eating to avoid the salt.  It was bascially good food that got ruined by too much salt.  I was incredibly thirsty afterwards.  Service was good and attentive.
author: jhon k.

description:
The food was great!

Unfortunately, the entire dining experience was AWFUL.   

The restaurant wasn't even full and we ended waiting forever for our entree.  I could have lived with this except for the table of 6 men who thought they were at a sports bar instead of Town Hall.

The table exhibited behavior that we don't find acceptable from our 1 year old.  They were banging on the table, screaming from one end of the table to the next and leading cheers.

I asked the manager Zeke if he could ask them to not bang on the table.  He told us that he couldn't because at Town Hall they encourage the patrons to have a "good time".

I would warn anyone about going to Town Hall.  The food is great but dining experience is sketch.  The worst part is that the management doesn't even care.
author: San Francisco P.

description: SHORT & SWEET: 874 reviews?  Jeez, what's all the fuss about?  It's crowded, service is slow and zombie-esque, and food is the definition of OK; the following dishes were equally average: oh, sorry, I ate there three weeks ago, went online to refresh my memory, and I can't recognize anything on the web site's menu (is that a good sign?)  Wait, one thing - the veal meatballs, which came out undercooked twice.  How could I forget those?
author: Corey S.

description: This large restaurant serves trendy American food.  This was probably the  first upscale comfort food place in the city.  While I am usually disdainful of of overpriced American food, Town Hall is quite good.  A nice place to enjoy a bottle of wine with a friend over some solid food.
author: apple r.

description: Had some really good food here. Have I mentioned my love of all things jam/jelly? Well, the biscuits with Smithfield ham and pepper jelly rocked my preserve-loving world.  It's not the best setting for an intimate dinner, as the space gets really, really loud, but I would go back for lunch or with a group without hesitation.
author: L W.

description: Yet another happy hour spot that's pop with the downtowners.  The bar (physical bar counter, I mean) is in a really stupid place. Rather, the place to stand for the excruciating long wait to get a drink is a main thoroughfare for the waitstaff.  The bartenders are slow and unfriendly, meaning, they looked me in the eyes several times without acknowledging me... until finally one just stayed.  I guess I was supposed to introduce myself first.  Now, I'm no customer service expert, but usually an order is preceded by, "Hi. What can I get you?"  Manners are an invaluable life skill that these people have yet to grasp.
author: Jessica M.

description: Chocolate Butterscotch pot de creme - thats all I have to say.  This is the BEST DESSERT EVER.  It is the most compelling reason to go to Town Hall.  The food is fine, pretty standard 4 star American cuisine in SF.  But the dessert is insane. Sometimes we go there just for wine and the pot de creme.  I would recommend you do the same.
author: Jake A.

description: We came in on a Sunday night at about 6:30 with no reservation and the restaurant filled up pretty quickly after that. The service was quite good - exceptional, even, except that our bread and appetizer plates were taken before we were done with them. Anyway, the tuna tartare was delicious and the bread was very good. The sweet onion fondue was fine - the dipping components (pretzels, green beans, and sausage) were tasty but I found the fondue overly sweet. My main disappointment was the stuffed sole, which I thought was too rich. The sole itself was good but everything in/around it took away from it, in my opinion. Again, I also found many of the components a bit sweet for my taste. The waitress was very accommodating about a companion having an appetizer and side as a main dish - the pork slider and ribs, which were quite good. So, nothing was actively *bad*, but I would try other places instead of going back.
author: Lisa K.

description: Food was terrific, but found it noisy.  When we sat at an outside table, we heard all the traffic on Howard.  We moved inside and the acoustics were such that we overheard all the conversations next to us, making it hard to have a relaxing meal.
author: Mary B.

description: We went here with some friends and had a great time.  We ordered a lot of the appetizers and one main dish the gnocchi.  Everything was very tasty.  My favorite was the crab salad YUM!
author: Michelle M.

description: Overall, very solid place.  The kind of food I could eat almost everyday....if I had that kind of money.  When I went, we had the oysters to start which were very fresh.  We also had the scallops which were pretty good.  I sorta of regretted my entree of the Etouffee, not because it wasn't good, but because everyone else's at the table looked better.  My friend kept raving about his fried chicken which yes was very good and my other friend had the pork osso bucco which was also very good.  I could have had all 3 things and had been just fine.  The bread pudding we had was excellent as well.  As for service, I didn't get the type of negative service other readers had.  Our servers were attentive without being intrusive.
author: Ming L.

description: The food is soooo good and this place has the service to match it - I've never been disappointed and just thinking about it gives me the warm tinglies all over.
author: Bridget W.

description:
i thought everything was delicious and worth the wait and the price.  

appetizer: 
roasted baby beets and shaved fennel paled in comparison to the barbecued shrimp and crab fondue.

dinner:
the tuna dish and the halibut were fabulous. i don't eat meat, but my friend's pork chop looked awesome. 

dessert: 
rocky road - dry, but with the ice cream great.
author: Lindsay T.

description: Okay, so the atmosphere is lovely (if a bit cramped), and the food was pretty good.  SF Gate reviews it so well, we were expecting amazing.  HOWEVER, never have I had such rude service.  Even the manager was the opposite of accommodating.  We did ask to move tables at the very beginning, and were begrudgingly granted that request by the surly manager.  The server did his best to ignore us the rest of the evening, and we all left pretty much feeling like second-class citizens.  Generally I am a very easy-going restaurant patron, but this experience has stuck with me for months!  Hope you all have a better experience!
author: Kate M.

description: RE: Sidewalk Barbecue....First let me say I will eat here again.  With that said, it will be to see if they can put the "bam" back in the "Q".  I tasted that "bam" the first day when they were giving out free samples. But, on the 2 visits after that they have taken two steps back IMHO.  I am a Q-er, so you must come correct!  I was pleasantly surprised on day one as I said but as BB said..."The thrill is gone, the thrill is gone away"
author: John S.

description:
Usually, I do not eat ham or egg yolks. But for Town Hall, I was willing to make an exception.

On Thursday afternoon, my dad and me had lunch there. My favorite dish, which appears as an appetizer on the dinner menu, is offered as a sandwich for lunch. The warm Smithfield ham and cheese toast with poached egg and jalapeno cream sauce is definitely one of my top 10 lunches. Town Hall uses a whole wheat sourdough, drapes the ham on top, then blankets the whole thing in this delicious, rich jalapeno cream sauce, and tops it with a poached egg. The tang of the sourdough marries perfectly with the smoky saltiness of the ham. The jalapeno cream sauce is made by steaming some jalapenos to take out some of the heat but leave a little bit of bite and flavor, then adding lots of cream and butter and a little parmesan. Pierce the egg yolk on top of the sandwich and the combination is positively decadent. This is comfort food at its best and most fattening. 

But I get ahead of myself. To start, we had the butter lettuce salad with candied walnuts, radishes and blue cheese vinaigrette. It's a generous portion; we split it and there was plenty for the two of us. I don't eat butter lettuce often, but this salad makes me want. It was covered in a rich blue cheese dressing, and candied walnuts added a nice, sweet crunch.

I like the Town Hall dining room, too. It's got a nice, casual, even celebratory feel to it. The diners seem happy. (And with that jalapeno cream sauce, who wouldn't be?) When we were there, we saw the chef, Mitch Rosenthal, having his picture taken in the dining room for Gourmet magazine.
author: Deb K.

description: I would give them more stars if it wasn't for the noise level and occasional inconsistencies in service. As to the menu, I love their bbq shrimp and butterscotch chocolate pot de creme.
author: Alina B.

description:
Finally went to town hall after hearing about it for years. I had the beet salad which was great to start, my husband had the roquefort/pecan salad which was also great. The entrees were good but not great. My husband had the ribs and I had the bay scallops. I always forget that the bay scallops are the tiny little ones and that annoys me when restaurants use these, so that was a bit of a bummer but they were cooked properly and not overdone so they tasted good. The truffled mac & cheese was to die for, awesome awesome awesome. Lastly we had the chocolate & butterscotch pot de creme, it was literally the most delicious finale to a meal ever. So scrumptious! mmmmmm  

Service was great at the beginning but then our waitress totally disappeared forever during the middle of our meal. Nothing too distressing but just odd. Great wine list & awesome desserts.

I'd go back again, but there are other places I'd prefer to go before TH, such as Frascati or A16. I'm just glad we had a gift card from a friend, or it would have been a much more expensive meal.
author: Kristin L.

description:
We were very disappointed with this restaurant. We have heard so
much about it.  To be frank, the food is far over priced for what you
get....tid bits.....and everything is too spicey and  -  The place is
jam packed...so maybe there is something wrong with me.  Yuppies
that like to drink and then eat...and they don't know the difference.
Price is no object...and they obviously were not brought up eating
good, delicious food.  The place is so noisy, you have to yell to
hear each other. Not a place to relax.  What is all the hype about
this restaurant?  I cannot believe they would serve such tiny portions
and charge so much.  I would never go back to this place, that is\
for sure.  Sorry!
author: Girly Foodie F.

description:
I ADORE Town Hall.  After having lunch here last month, I totally understand the hype around this mystical place!  The food is not to be missed.  And the wine list is equally impressive.  

This place is packed - all day long!  It's about as recession-proof a place as I've seen in this city.  Must be the awesome service, welcoming atmosphere, and great bites.

If you can come for lunch, you'll get great food at a lower price.  Their dinner entrees look fabulous, but the ham and cheese toast with jalapeno cream is NOT to be missed!  I loved the butter lettuce salad (which probably took 3 months off my life with its cholesterol-infused bleu cheese dressing) and they were kind enough to split the order for 2.  We both got heaping plates of salad and remarked that we couldn't possibly believe that together our plates could have totaled a single order.  Those Town Hall chefs are mighty generous people!

Come here, try the wine, stay as long as they'll let you, savor the memories fondly, and then come back later and try another dish from their American-inspired menu of classics and comfort food.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
A good albeit very, very noisy restaurant with a hip crowd.  The food is fine and I really enjoyed the biscuits and the meatballs.

Good bar scene and it's great that they have outdoor seating.  Unfortunately their indoor seating is noisy (did I mention that once before?), wine selection is limited and on at least one occasion came corked.

Fine place but I wouldn't go out of my way to go back.
author: Joe S.

description: It has been quite a while since I have been here(about a year) but the one thing that stood out was the great service.  For that alone, it earns 3 stars but I also remember some really exquisitely seasoned pork chops.  The chef does a great job of integrating not so common ingredients with everyday type fare. One of the true San Francisco eating experiences. Maybe this place earned 5 stars, Ill have to go back and see.
author: GourMand X.

description: Great food and the ambiance just makes you feel at home.  I had the heirloom tomato salad with the buttercream dressing - an amazing starter.  I don't keep track of my tomato eating habits, but I'd say the tomatoes in the salad were as good as they get.  I had the Halibut as an entree which was extremely solid.  Service was attentive.  Btw, we didn't need a reservation for this Sunday evening dinner for two.
author: Mamoon H.

description: Simple deco, good place for simple business lunch but slow service. Had the signature TH burger and it was nothing special. Also, they ran out of tea pots so they can't even serve tea!
author: T L.

description:
Town Hall meets all of the A-grade criteria: near-perfect execution, distinct flavor, pushes American cuisine to another level, fluid and varied menu selection--it only misses on one level and that's my personal flavor profile.

Butter lettuce salad with Fuji apples, candied walnuts and blue cheese dressing 9.50
Barbecued shrimp with Worcestershire and parsley garlic sauce 14.00
Sauted sea scallops with smoked andouille sausage jambalaya and Dungeness crab butter 26.50
Banana Pudding Parfait with Madeira glazed bananas and coffe dipped lady fingers 8.00

With the exception of our salad [which was overly dressed], each dish was delicately seasoned, cooked to exacting perfection, and invigorating for my nearly virginal taste buds [it's been over a month since I've been to a new restaurant]. I was surprised that the heavy and bold flavors common to American cusine didn't mask the quality of the main ingredients. As they should have, the sauces and sides accented the main dish without taking away from its grandeur. To the dismay of my company, our salad came out drenched in blue cheese dressing, which he describes as "stale ranch." Although the butter lettuces had a great crunch to them, it was unfortunate that the dressing weighed down the individual leaves, making them soggy and inedible. I thought that maybe the heavy-handed dressing reflected the material excess of American culture, but probably should have sent it back [yes, it had that much dressing on it.]

From my childhood memory, I vividly remember the experience of biting into an overcooked shrimp and feeling the individual body segments separate in my mouth--I stopped eating them for ten years. The anxiety of taking that first bite often crosses my mind now, but each of our five Worcestershire beauties ran contrary to all those bad impressions I've developed over the years. There's only a 30-second window of cooking when good shrimp turns bads and Town Hall managed to find that balance with precision.

Our three jumbo sea scallops reminded me that scallops do not have to come in cream and cheese sauces. I tend to think scallops are extra chewy in a good way, but I now know what the true flavor and texture of a scallop is. These scallops were less "flaky" than I'm normally accustomed to and sans the cheese, I was finally able to perceive their subtle flavoring.
