Although the jambalaya was good and didn't overwhelm the scallops, it felt a little makeshift--as if they just mixed bbq sauce into rice. It was kind of a goopy mess.

By this time, my taste buds were telling me to give them a break and so I was a bit disappointed that there were no sorbets or light fruit options on the menu--only the decadance and indulgence of the heavy American palette. We opted to go with the bananas, since strawberry rhubarb was trite and since butterscotch&chocolate, marshmallow&peanut butter, and toffee&buttercream were all too much for our stuffed appetites. The pudding was very thick and although I felt like every bite was sending me to glutton hell, it was a successful marriage of two foods that I don't usually order for dessert.

I would come back to Town Hall, even though I tend to prefer milder food. It feels good to be back on the restaurant scene.
author: Monica T.

description: Great service, pretty good food. Friends took me here for my b-day had a great time.  I treated some friends for thier b-day... it was excellent.  It is a bit pricey though....    Been here at least a half a dozen times already.... this place works for me:)
author: Demanding T.

description: Last night I had unquestionably one of the best meals in my life.  I decided to go for the grits even though my sister gave me the "are you sure" look.  I agree, grits generally taste like baby food, but the description sounded so good I had to give them a try.  WOW!  The flavors, the colors, the combinations, the presentation, everything, everything about this dish was spectacular.  NOW I know what grits are supposed to taste like!  The black truffles and the wild mushrooms mixed with the fresh vegetables were amazing.  Combined with the normal outstanding service, this was a truly memorable meal!
author: D H.

description: We had to wait 15 minutes before being seated even though we had reservations. The service was SLOW. It was unbelievably loud and filled with the least desirable of the financial district. My food was decent, the appetizer was the best part of the meal, I got BBQ shrimp but why should 4 shrimp cost $13.50? For the price and the hype I expected much more and was disappointed. I kinda feel like there are way too many fantastic restaurants in SF to warrant this place being as crowded as it was.
author: kristen l.

description: Classic American Cuisine. Love the atmosphere--it's very east of the Mississippi feeling, and that they save one huge table in the bar for drop ins. Geez I love communal seating. You just don't find enough of that in the US. The Salmon at lunch was great, my friend was a little blaise about the burger.
author: N B.

description:
i really loved this place. had corn risotto, meatballs with mashed potatoes and then a chocolate/caramel pudding for desert. Everything was described on the menu perfectly (i don't like surprises) and all the flavors were good. It actually ended up being cheaper than I had expected which was nice. 

We had to wait about 15 minutes for our reservation on a Tuesday night, but there were two empty seats at the bar so it was fine to wait. 

All in all, it was good, and I would definitely go back. The atmosphere was fun and casual. You could go there wearing pretty much anything and wouldn't feel out of place. 

Only minus (but not worth taking a star away) was the bathroom was through a weird hallway a bit of a walk away. Not a huge deal but maybe worth mentioning!
author: Katie G.

description:
took the husband here for his birthday meal this year. as usual the service was great, friendly and just attentive enough. we had a delish malbec that at around $40 was an ok value. their wine list is on the pricier side tho. which in SF, is totally unncessary and kind of pretentious. there's great wine in the $30-50 range. and most of their list seems to be $50 and up. 

we really blew it out on the food. appetizers, mains and dessert. my favorite part of the meal were the starters. we shared the corn soup, which was buttery sweet. we also shared the ham and cheese toast with poached egg and jalapeno creme. this was fantastic, the spice was just right and a terrific complement to the thick ham. very rich tho, so unless it's your entree, i would share it. 

i went with the halibut served on a bed of corn pudding and fava beans. it was good, but again, rich, and i have to say, a bit forgettable. the husband went with the pork chop, and i was disappointed that it was slightly overcooked. it could have been juicier. the red pepper jelly glaze was a bit lacking also, and could have helped deflect the dryness. and overall, it was another heavy dish. the dirty rice didn't do much to help it out either. (as a side note, the best pork chop i've had in SF is at foreign cinema)

the dessert we shared was a cobbler, and again, wasn't all that impressive. altho i have had other desserts here that have been excellent. i stick with my original review and say to just go for the apps and drinks. you can't go wrong there.
author: rachel p.

description: What  a great meal! The server was awesome.. get the guy with glasses and a beard he was funny and new his stuff! The food was so good the veal meatballs and lamb entree were out of this world. It's been a quite some time where i can say this was worth the money... eating out that is. Highly suggest this joint.
author: thomas P.

description: This should be 2.5 stars.  We came here with high expectations especially for a birthday celebration.  Fried Chicken was awesome. Three pieces of chicken crisp and slightly reminiscent of a crunchy fast food variety though I wished the potato side was mashed with gravy instead of baked.  Butter lettuce salad with Maytag blue dressing is huge and great way to start to my foray into fried chicken wonderland.  However, my husband's rib eye steak, though nicely rare, was salted way too much that he had to send it back.  His sardine appetizer stole the show with a trio of the fish plated and drizzled with rosemary, garlic, and pepper "oil" so good you could sop it up the remains with French bread.  We had the requisite chocolate butterscotch pot de creme which was divine.  Dear Chefs and kitchen staff:  please lightly season the meats you are cooking.  Didn't you learn this in cooking school? You can always add salt, but you can't take it away.  Staff was extremely accommodating, wine list extensive and I would go back to give the place a second chance.  It kind of sucks in this economy when you pay good money ($188 for 2 with cocktails and a bottle of wine) to have to send an over salted steak back and wait while your dining companions finish their meals.
author: Sfgpgirl G.

description: Sometimes I prefer their lunch menu, but Mitchell, Steven and Doug have a hit on their hands. Did you see their story on the Fine Living Channel's Opening Soon program? "Mitchel creates the dishes in his mind and Steven makes it all possible."
author: Philip M.

description: It is unbelievable that this restaurant is affiliated with Salt House. I would rather go to Salt House hands down. We had our holiday luncheon here and the food was undercooked, served luke warm and unimpressive. If a restaurant is going to cater to a large group they need to be more prepared. 2-4 servers for 40 people? Hardly adequate. Perhaps I will get my courage up and try this place with a more intimate group...
author: Becky M.

description: It's been over 3 years since I have eaten here, but I remember the food being really good.  I probably would give the place 5 stars if I could remember the dishes I had.  LOL
author: Christopher D.

description: Maybe I wasn't in the mood or had some higher expectation of Town Hall. I heard so many great things about it, and thought it was good-pretty good. I wasn't super impressed with the decor, although I understood what the owner was going for - casual, yet chic. The menu is down to earth food. i must say, the mac-n-cheese and fried chicken was pretty good.  Overall, I think this is a good restaurant to bring a group of friends to, but not the best place for a date. it's super loud and kind of crowded.
author: A.L. S.

description:
Buttermilk fried chicken - yummy.
Table service - disappointing.

During my Saturday Dinner visit, we were seated 30 minutes late.  During our dessert course, the waiter brings us the check and says, "My Manager told me to bring you this (check)."  Rude!  I guess we stayed past our time even though we were seated 30 minutes late.

Next time, for chicken, eat at Popeyes.
author: Jordan L.

description: This place definitely has it's fair share of perks but the food isn't one of them.  Modern decor, great cocktails, a great view (when I say view I mean good looking men and women), definitely a great place to hang out and mingle.  The food however can use a little work.  It certainly wasn't bad but I don't think it was worth the $30 per entree.  For example the scallop appetizer was drenched in some kind of cheese sauce which completely took away from the flavor of the scallops themselves.  The normally succulent bivalve mollusk was also over cooked and chewy.   The seafood etouffe was overly seasoned and the steak was not seasoned enough.  Maybe the chefs were just having an off night but I don't think the food was worth it.
author: Phil Y.

description:
wow, what an absolutely lovely dining experience! everything in this place was fabolous. the food (tuna tartar,butter lettuce salad, porkchops, and donuts with shafenberger aka hersheys chocolate) interior, wine list, quality of service was impeccable and satisfying. 

i havent dined like this in a while. town hall lives up to the hype!
author: Christian S.

description: Thanks Yelpers for the great reviews of Town Hall and the great recommendations....I went with many of you and had the Tuna Tartare, Rib Eye and Butterscotch Pot for dessert...all were wonderful.  The only sad part of my dinner was that I ate EXACTLY half of my Rib Eye so I could have a yummy dinner the next day as well....and the waiter never brought it back to me to go...I was very sad.  The crowd is very loud and young.  Make sure to ask for the specialty drink menu, everything on it looks AWESOME ($9-12).  Make Reservations, this place is packed.  The Mojito-ish drink (I forget the name...) rocked my socks off. YUM!
author: Cathleya G.

description: Nice converted industrial place with high ceiling and brick walls....good food and nice crowd...mostly crowded and noisy and great for happy hours.
author: Yan M.

description: Pretty good but boring. Veal meatballs were one-dimensional, my duck confit couldve been more flavorful. The only thing I was amazed by was the dessert: omg their chocolate butterscotch mousse!! amazing amazing
author: Amy D.

description: Referred to this place by a local pal gal,  we took some out of town guests to dine and unwind. The staff was courteous and the meal was homey and not fatty. App-ed the veal meatballs. Delish, but not extraordinary to where I'd order from out of town private shipments. I ordered the halibut and tasted the scallops. Tender Love.  Good for groups. Good place to dine outskirts of Financial D. Call for reservations on the weekends.
author: Peter N.

description: Town Hall is a social place - it's definitely on the loud side. I went for dinner and had the roasted rainbow trout.  It scared me at first since the entire fish (including head) was on my plate but it ended up being very delicious. The best part was the desert. I'm not a big desert person myself but the chocolate-butterscotch pot de creme was AMAZING!!! SO GOOD!
author: Barney M.

description: Solid food, nothing extraordinary, but very good.  Love the friend chicken dish, perfectly crispy, but even better, I wanted to jump into the mashed potatoes, which were creamy and had delicious gravy.  The cheese fondue appetizer is also good.  I would have to say that if I were just rating on the food, I'd probably do 4 stars, but each time I've been, the service is just okay.  Last night, our waiter acted as though there 200 places he'd rather be, but he did his job, so it wasn't too bad.  I would go back, but likely explore other places first....unless I want fancy, expensive fried chicken.
author: Jessica L.

description: My good friend took me to this restaurant on my birthday. I had heard a lot about this place so I had very high expectations. Thankfully, Town Hall lived up to them. The hostess was friendly and so was our waiter. Their wine list was extensive and our meal was fantastic. The restaurant did get a bit noisy; tables were too close to each other and considering it was St. Patrick's Day people were out celebrating. Overall it was a fantastic experience, check it out for yourself!
author: Matin N.

description: Spinach salad topped with fried succulent oysters and bits of thick, crispy bacon. Faith's ham and cheese toast (basically their version of croque madame) with a perfectly poached egg and that addicting jalapeno cream that is a step above regular bechamel sauce. Fish and chips with malt vinegar. And best of all...STICKY TOFFEE PUDDING worth every single butter-rich, sugar-laden calorie. I love this place.
author: Deb I.

description: Wow.  I haven't gotten my sheet together and made proper reservations to this place, but the communal table works for me.  Add the words of wisdom scrawled on the chalkboards, and I really don't think you're paying too much for the strong service and the savory food.  Now if I can only make reservations to this place, I could really be more critical...
author: Edward K.

description:
Wow. The food was absolutely 5 stars. I loved everything I ordered. Took one star off just for the noise factor. While the large room with high ceilings set-up was definitely aesthetically pleasing, I had to shout at my dining partner to have a conversation.

The service was excellent. We arrived an hour before our 8:15 reservation and killed time at the bar with a glass of wine and some appetizers. The barbecue shrimp in worcheshire sauce on a crostini was unbelievable. I couldn't take a bite without making an audible 'Mmmmm' sound. It was very 'What About Bob'. I lost my cool, but regained it so as not to frighten all of the middle aged Caucasian men in suits that shared the dining experience with me.  We then got to our table and ordered the veal meatballs (to DIE for!) and the dish I had come here for in the first place: Buttermilk Fried Chicken. Best fried chicken I've ever had. So flavorful, so crispy outside, so juicy inside. They have got it down. The service was also great, the server apologized for not being able to bring over my shrimp appetizer from the bar before it got thrown out  (there was only a little crostini left on the plate) and got me a glass of wine to make up for it. Thank you Town Hall, I will be back the next time I want to pay $20 for the best fried chicken in the world and not hear the person I am dining with. This could actually be useful in certain situations, think about it.....
author: Magi C.

description:
The night was New Years Day... the occasion was my birthday and of course, the new year!  I was running late and didn't want to drive downtown to fight the mad crowds, so I caught a cab. What a bad idea.  First, it was pretty impossible to get one in North Beach, and second, the guy I got, had to go to the bathroom - so the entire ride, I was on the phone (THANK GOD!!!) and having to listen to Mr. Cabbie make weird noises. I wanted him just to pull over so I could get out and just walk the rest of the way, but I sat in the backseat, praying he wouldn't pee on himself... 

Arriving at there restaurant - it was romantical. The atmosphere was sophisticated and the noise bounced nicely off the walls.  We sat by a window... in the back and the menu didn't have TOO many options, which made for an easy decision.  All of the guys at the table had the steak, Leslie had the oysters, and I had chicken.  We ordered a number of appetizers, to kick off the evening - meatballs and shrimp -- there may have been a third, but I can't recall at the moment.  I am always cautious of eating at places that get rave reviews because then I set my expectations so high that they come crashing down into a huge puddle of disappointment!  Kind of like movies I really really want to watch and end up not liking it as much as I thought I would, or guys that I end up developing feelings for, and then they become jerks and a-holes... I didn't want Town Hall to be that kind of an experience to have engraved in my memory... 

So the food, up until the entree was excellent. For dessert, we also went for 3 choices, the butterscotch, the chocolate s'more looking one and again, I forget the third... obviously they weren't THAT important. I must say, the butterscotch, to my surprise was light, fluffy and amazing!  I got a whiff of it and wasn't that impressed by first smell, but WOWzers - the taste was heaven on my buds! And the house Sauvignon Blanc wasn't bad either... 

Overall, great birthday dinner with great company, good food in a nice place.  Downside -- service was a little slow for my liking... but it WAS New Years, and I'm sure, even the wait staff was a "tad" bit hung over, like the rest of the world :)
author: Lisa L.

description: I am giving an extra star for the HH because it is right by my company and I like their HH appetizer.
author: Ervinna L.

description: had a really nice meal here, but the service was spotty and the space, while beautiful, was big and packed w/ tables.  I prefer a more intimate setting
author: James R.

description:
I had high expectations of this place and all of the hype proved worthy.  The ambiance is warm and cozy, with large family-style tables and big windows.  Sadly, we sat in a corner that contained a breeze -- likely from the small slat in the wall leading out to the freezing cold san francisco night.  But even the draft couldn't spoil the incredible food and service.

We ordered an exquisite bottle of Willamette Valley Pinot Noir.  It was pricey -- but worth every penny.  For starters, we shared a tuna tartar -- the tuna worked nicely with the fried heirloom tomatoes.  Next, I ordered the fried chicken.  I've made it a custom to order fried chicken in every nice restaurant -- in hopes of finding my fried chicken soul mate.  Oh i did -- they served up the best fried chicken i have ever tasted.  the breading was made with buttermilk and was rich and perfectly crispy.  the meat was tender.  it didn't matter what they served with it - the chicken itself made it a winner.  But, to be thorough, the chicken was served with collard greens that had been stewed in some sort of mystery seasoning.  nobody could guess -- it was a bit tart, but also a little sweet.  The mashed potatoes and gravy were also quite tasty.  For dessert, I chose a lovely apple crisp.  Sadly, the crisp was not piping hot, but the flavors were so nice, I couldn't really complain.

The service was excellent.  The waiter was helpful and funny.  He was very professional and open to criticism.  

All in all, it was an excellent dinner and I will definitely put it on my list of local fine dining favorites.
author: Courtaney W.

description:
i went here just about 2 months ago and what stands out most in my memory was the mac and cheese croquettes. they are cube-shaped mac and cheese chunks, with a bit of tomato sauce on the side. 

i loved the decor of this place, it was warm and friendly, with lots of wood, classy and a touch romantic. the perfect birthday dinner.
author: Marla W.

description:
i would like to give this a 3.5, but yelp is yelp.
very good food. good ambiance. classy.

get the halibut.
author: Taesu B.

description:
came here for an early dinner after work on a wednesday, and even though the dining area was completely empty the hostess gave us a crappy table because we didn't make a reservation. yeah, it's one of those kind of places.

the food was ok, nothing spectacular. a waiter shattered a glass right behind us and knocked some cutlery off our table but the manager gave us free dessert as a result which was nice (although expected). it must have been one of those days... but i probably won't be going back any time soon.
author: David P.

description: Food quality is overall quite good.  The fried chicken is ridiculously good and is probably the most common order based on how many people I saw eating it.  It's good, but really, $23 for fried chicken?  The rest of the menu was a little too buttered up or pork-infused (down with swine) for my taste.  Don't waste your money on the three itty-bitty biscuits and jam in the appetizers menu.  Added nothing to the meal except making the bill larger.
author: Aldo K.

description: That egg/jalepeno cream sauce appetizer deliciousness is worth going back for! Yum. Love that the Dead is always playing in the restaurant.
author: Kelly F.

description:
I am a repeat customer of Town Hall, having been at least 5-6 times in the past few years.  I think the food is excellent, and location is convenient.  The most recent time I ate there was for dinner on Monday, May 11.  While I've never been impressed by the service, this most recent time was the worst service I've received in a very long time at any restaurant.  It was actually offensive.  My party showed up around 8pm for dinner.  It was a spur of the decision moment, and we hadn't made reservations so we were prepared for some wait/inconvenience.  I was just surprised at how awful the service was.  First off, when we showed up the hostess at the front of the house ignored us for several minutes.  Then when we were finally talking to her, in the midst of our requesting a table, a friend of hers (and apparently of the restaurant personnel in general) showed up and cut right in front of us as we were talking to the host mid-sentence and gave her a hug and started talking to her.  The host did return to help us after a few minutes, and let us know that the wait was about 15-20 minutes which we were happy to wait.  In the mean time, several other parties showed up.  But the hostess had disappeared and didn't return for over 10 minutes.  At some point several of the customers went back into the restaurant to find someone on staff, which seems pretty embarassing for the restaurant.  The various parties that were waiting spent a lot of time standing around with us.  I felt worse for them, because it was clear they had made reservations.    I noticed that the hostess gave them complimentary champagne, which I assumed was because they had to wait for so long.  It did not take 15-20 minutes to be seated.  I still think that we couldn't get upset by this since we didn't have reservations, although I think at a restaurant of Town Hall's caliber that they should at least periodically update us on the status of the table.  My party and I finally decided to eat at the bar about 45 minutes after we had arrived.  

The bar service was decent.  The male bartender working that night was really busy, and worked very hard.  Kudos to him.  He kept our water and bread basket filled.  He had a second female bartender helping out who seemed to disappear often.  The bar staff did end up getting our order wrong. We had ordered a side dish, which never came.  When we asked for it the staff seemed confused about what we had ordered, and it came 15 minutes after we had gotten our main course and well after we had finished the bulk of our main course.   I also noticed that several of the other bar patrons had to spend time flagging down the staff to pay their bill.  And throughout the evening, the hostess was more often not there then there.  

Although I can understand some of the problems with the service was a result of a busy night, some of the problems I encountered were just poor front of the house management.  I like the food at Town Hall, but given this most recent dismal experience I will likely think twice about returning to Town Hall.  There are plenty more restaurants with good food AND good service.  The food was great as usual, but I was really disappointed in this experience.  

However, I did end up sending an email to the staff about this through their website after the fact.  I was impressed that the management contacted me immediately to apologize and to follow-up on our poor experience.  While I thought that this experience was bad, I was pleased that the management cared enough to contact me afterwards and personally apologize.  I thought that this was classy.
author: Christie O.

description: Had lunch here today and was very impressed. The food was artfully done and served in generous portions. Interesting, creative takes on non-threatening favorites such as seafood chowder or duck enchiladas. Tasteful, low-key decor somewhere between bistro and gastro-pub with a lunchtime clientele comprised of business types and civilians. Wait staff were great and it was an overall very positive experience for a very reasonable price. Highly recommended.
author: Kev B.

description: Good but a bit overhyped.  The food is good, no doubt - I really enjoyed the tartare and the short ribs.  But it's not out of this world delicious.  It's expensive American comfort food in a nice setting.  Nice that they have half bottles of wine on the wine list, though.
author: Melinda C.

description:
-My $12 cocktail was all ice and weak.
-Food itself was 4 stars: nothing wow, but pretty good.
-Waited FOREVER between courses. Got some apologies and some disgusting stale jalapeno bread--should have given us a free round of drinks instead or at least free dessert
-Felt like we were being delayed so that we would order more drinks and more wine while waiting
-Bill was through the roof bc of two bottles of wine
-Got one of those obnoxious "fire sale" wine lists where the wines start at $70 and most are over $100...WTF? that's not a sale.
author: Monster R.

description:
I had dinner here this past Friday. One of my girlfriends took me out for a belated birthday dinner. I choose the restaurant because of all the good reviews it had on Yelp and the menu looked really good. 
When we arrived we were promptly seated by the hostess. Once our server, an older man, arrived everything seemed to go down hill. He was very cold and did not even introduce himself to us. He asked us what we wanted to drink and took that order and walked away. After disappearing for quite sometimes he came and got our appetizer and dinner order, I asked him what he suggested and his opinion on the Seafood etouffee, he just said everything is ok and the seafood is fine; he had a total whatever attitude. I ordered the Seafood, which was really delicious. The sauce that it comes in has a little bit of a kick to it! My friend had their fried chicken plate, I tried a piece of the chicken and it was not that flavorful, the biscuits were not good either. 
We decided to share the dessert, which was the pink lady, an apple galette with blue cheese ice cream. When our server bought it to our table he said I don't know whose birthday it is but here is your dessert; and then he walked away. 
I don't know if I would go again. I enjoyed my food but the service was so terrible that I would rather go to another restaurant.
author: Marie-Claire R.

description: Wow this place is good! The restaurant is a bit "old" but who cares, it's delicious quality food in a nice setting. Take your parents, they'll love it!
author: Sara W.

description: Whoah, the lunchtime BBQ rocks.  This place is doing everything right by my book.
author: Reality Check S.

description:
We found it by mistake; been back; highly recommend.
1. Trendy yet easy to find and FREE STREET PARKING!! (Almost unheard of in SF).
2. Excellent dishes...they can't really advertise that it's high-class Southern style, but that's what it is and it's wonderful!
3. The first night we went they were SO helpful when we dropped in by mistake... the service was great.
4. A little noisy but seems all new restaurants are...turn your hearing  aid  up to "stun".
author: barton l.

description: Go straight to the fried chicken!!  This was the winner of 3 entrees we tried.  The bacon-wrapped and stuffed roasted quail was dry.  The pork ribs were alright (go to Houston's for that).  We had the homemade tater tots which were amusing but pricey and the fried okra was very good.  Both sides were very small.  The fried chicken was light and crunchy on the outside, moist and hot on the inside.  It was served with a nice arugula bread salad that helped balance the chicken out.  Farmer Brown's can compete with it...
author: win c.

description: Townhall gives anyone dressed in formal attire an excuse to eat fried chicken - tasty AND expensive.  I will admit, the best burger I have ever had has been at Townhall for lunch, and the hot chocolate (listed as its own item on the dessert menu) is to die for.  Wouldn't really recommend this place for dinner as it's stuffy, crowded, and frankly, the menu isn't that interesting to justify a night in SoMa.  But if you work in the area and need to impress someone, then it works!
author: Maulie D.

description: The chocolate/butterscotch pot de creme was amazing. Basically, the entire menu was a smash hit, but I'm a pushover for any restaurant with two options for blue cheese on the appetizer menu.
author: Heidi L.

description: Eh. Run of the mill duck confit with a pretty good risotto cake. That's the kind of food I had.
author: David Y.

description: Great Pot de Creme, extensive wine list, great apps. I love the atmosphere here also- v. warm and cozy.
author: Carson H.

description: This is the kind of place that if I came more would be one of my favorites. I like the brick exterior, the friendly staff and the menu which I consider very San Francisco. The barbeque shrimp was awesome and with corn bread I felt like I was back in Louisiana. Desserts are awesome too with a mix of hominess that I like.
author: Keith R.

description: It was a pity that I didn't get to pull out my camera for some food porn but this place did a great job with both the presentation and quality of the dishes. The place is filled with the after-work crowd milled over from the Financial district. With dark soothing lighting, and comfy dark colours, the place had a nice attitude to it. Bartender did a great job with my dirty martini too. Definitely another place I would revisit and recommend.
author: Steffy W.

description: I love this place!  Great food, fancy without the fanciness, good service.  And three words for dessert not to be missed: pot de creme.
author: Ross W.

description: Not necessarily on the beaten path (unless of course, you work in SOMA), Town Hall is an eatery that I would definitely seek out for an evening out. The popping bar is a nice compliment to the high and low indoor tables, but be sure to request an outside seat in the June --- October months... there's an overhang for shade/dryness, and evenly spaced heat lamps to warm the crown of your head. Definitely hit up a smattering of appetizers for the table, and the seafood choices are always good. Oysters, bbq shrimp, mussels and the tartars are excellent, and the salads looked great as well, though we didn't order them. As well, I highly recommend the pork chops and lamb as an entre, though the steak was fattier than I would have liked, and carries the highest price point. Be sure to request the fancy drink menu... wild cocktails should be on your list. And literally any of the deserts a solid.
author: Ankarino L.

description: Lunched here and imagined I was back in NYC. Faith's warm...oh yummy...not just another sandwich. I just wished it were bigger because it was THAT amazing. I tasted my friend's burger and it too was divinity.
author: Whit P.

description: All I remember was that it was very crowded and loud when we had dinner here on a Friday. The homestyle country cooking was ok, even though I can't exactly remember what I had since the cosmos kicked in by then. Did I mention it was crowded.
author: Michelle G.

description: I went there on a Wednesday and I have to say there was a lively happy hour going on at and around the bar.  I had the halibut which was very good.  I like the ambience of the place too.
author: Julia H.

description: Loud and chaotic most of the time.  Not bad for a business lunch but certainly not a romantic dinner.  Food is great, portions are generally too small, prices are a little too high.  Don't bother sitting outside- Seems like a good idea except  it smells like urine from all of the homeless people peeing nearby.  This isn't a destination spot but when I'm working with a client that's nearby I might stop in.
author: Spidermonkey J.

description: Town Hall is exactly what you'd expect -- everything tastes fine. However, unlike the love of my life, Zuni Cafe, it isn't exceptional considering the word-of-mouth this restaurant gets. Although I wasn't truly disappointed in anything I ordered, I guess what it came down to was just being bored. I mean, the decor isn't anything to write home about (actually, I can't really remember what it looks like), the starters I had were just okay (I can't remember what we had, either), Town Hall Burger was just that, a nicer version of a burger, and my drink, their signature Eli's Refresher, was just blah. This place strikes me as a very business lunch kind of place; seeing as I have no job and don't really want to get dressed up to have lunch, I'll have to pass next time.
author: Tuyet N.

description: The oversized room didn't bother me, but the overdressed salad, the oversalted fish, and the overpriced menu did.  I wouldn't go back.
author: Alison C.

description: OK, I went back for the second time now, and I still think this place is overrated. The food is good, but not great. I always find that the appetizers are very good, but am always looking for a higher quality of food for the entrees. The two times I have gone, i have found the entrees to be a little bland.
author: Alden H.

description: I can see why Town Hall has been rated as one of people's most favorite restaurants in S.F.  From the amazingly creative and fresh tasting food, i.e. the bbq'd shrimp and tuna tartare, to the friendly and knowledgeable waitstaff.  Our waiter Matteo suggested a wine, which we didn't end up liking, and he had no problem suggesting another one which we all loved.  He gave us the perfect amount of attentiveness without being overbearing.  Plus the hostess Cielo is just cute as a button! :-)
author: Stacy M.

description: 4 stars for food, service and ambiance.  Well, ok part of that last star is due to the fact that my table was right next to Willie Brown and uh umm his "girlfriend".
author: Amanda P.

description: As a child I was once punished for cursing by being forced to take a shot of Tabasco.  It was dinner at Town Hall that allowed me to overcome my taste aversion to the hot sauce.  A friend of the chefs tells me its their secret ingredient.  They put it in everything, and now so do I...
author: Kevin G.

description: My girlfriend and I dined for lunch.  It was a wonderful experience.  I ordered the tuna melt and she had the rib eye.  Both were very delicious, but the most amazing dish was the hot chocolate dessert.  The chocolate was mouth watering, rich and tasty and even better with the whipped cream and shortbread cookies.
author: Lisa C.

description: I've been here a number of times and the food and service are normally excellent.  This last time two in our party ordered the buffalo (based on the waiter's recommendation that theirs was much like Filet Mignon) and returned the meals.  I had the etouffee and the rice was hard but the flavor of the dish was good.  They have a great wine selection, just as you would expect from one of the better known spots in the city.
author: Curtis C.

description: It a great restaurant, the entire dinner from wine till dessert very happy with. I like the decor, service, and most customers have well manner.  will come again.
author: Elisa C.

description:
Great food, terrible service!

We had a lunch today here with my team to celebrate the end of our project.  The food was wonderful, especially the desserts.  But the service was incredibly slow.

I started with the butter lettuce salad, which was enormous and really tasty (although I believe there were supposed to be apples on it and definitely didn't taste any).  And I had the hamburger with blue cheese which was wonderful -- perfectly cooked, very juicy and tasty.  It came with a giant mound of fries, which was pretty obscene, but nothing compared to my colleague's fish and chips which was the largest amount of fried food I have seen in a while.  Dessert was equally gluttenous.  Everyone else ordered the butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme, which they all raved about -- but I don't like foods that I can't chew, so I had the sticky toffee cake.  It was enormous -- seriously enough dessert for 3-4 people, and I actually ate 2/3 of it.  So now, it's 5 hours later, and I should be hungry for dinner, but I still feel like I might throw up.  Perhaps I should have stopped after the burger?

As I mentioned above though, the service was dreadful.  We had an 11:30am reservation, so you'd think that we'd have been able to order before the lunch rush.  Our waitress was so slow, it took her 20 minutes just to bring the wine we had selected, and I don't think we ordered our food until 12:30.  Our water glasses weren't refilled throughout the meal, nor were our wine glasses.  No one ever came to ask how the food was, or I would have commented on the missing apples in my salad. We had to ask a bus boy to bring the dessert menu, otherwise we'd still probably be sitting in the restaurant now...

We had a great lunch, but luckily we could afford to spend 2 1/2 hours of our day at Town Hall, otherwise it would have been a real problem.

Go for a great meal, but budget the time for it.
author: Kimberly G.

description: Delicious!  Just went there for dinner, and it was amazing.  The veal meatball appetizer was to die for, we'll go back just for that.  The entree's were great as well, and the desert (bread pudding) was the best we've ever had.  Service was impeccable, except for the neighbors who spilled water on me, but you can't control that.  5 stars, we're looking forward to going back for another special occasion!
author: Benji J.

description: I always enjoy coming here, as the ambiance is great and service is always friendly and effecient. I got the gumbo and a couple of other sides. I also tried their fish special. Overall the food quality is high and portions are decent, but be ready to pony up the dolla dolla bills yall...It's not cheap, but then again it's no French Laundry either, but be prepared to approach the triple digits per person with wine etc.
author: Joseph C.

description: Mmm, to start, I have to mention the tuna tartare, as it's excellent.  I've been here a few times, sometimes just for drinks & apps, and other times for a full meal, and I've always left feeling very satisfied.  Nice bar too, so it's a great place to come for drinks with friends.
author: Jenn K.

description: I've never had a bad meal at this restaurant and it definitely has staying power. I enjoy sitting at the communal table for a spontaneous meal. The staff is always pleasant and accommodating. You can't leave without trying one of their desserts. I'm a true fan.
author: Maria C.

description: Ambiance was great and I actually love the fact that it's a bit distant from the main part of the financial district.  I've walked by this place and finally got to have dinner here. The appetizer menu was amazing, I actually thought it was better then the actually main course menu.  I had the heirloom tomato's and mozzarella cheese for a starter, which was worth $$$$. The waitress recommend the fried chicken, which was honestly a bit disappointing. The chicken was perfectly fried, crispy and juicy, but lacked flavor (I honestly would give this 3 stars). But the biscuits and cream of corn rocked. I also tried the chocolate pot Du cream with butterscotch and it's made up for the tasteless chicken. I guess this desert is part of the regular menu, so I guess I'm coming back!
author: Olivia W.

description:
went here for a business lunch earlier in the summer, and it was passable.  it's a little on the loud side to carry on a good business discussion though.

I tried the soup of the day and salad with buttered lettuce, candied walnuts and blue cheese vinaigrette.  the salad was decent, but the soup was too heavy.  It's a decent enough place with a nice atmosphere, but nothing that really stood out.
author: Robyn F.

description:
town hall has the best dessert i have ever tried.  although i am full of hyperboles, i do not lie about this one.  its called butterscotch chocolate pots de creme.  its a layer of butterscotch and a layer of chocolate with a brittle cookie thing sticking up in it, served in an oversized mug.  its probably the most decadent dessert you could possibly have.

oh sorry...food is also good, i tried like a pork chop thing with like fried onions and fava beans maybe?  seems to be very savory, great atmosphere, and not too expensive. up there with one market and quince as my favorite sf restaurants.
author: Robert S.

description: Can't get enough of this place for it's margaritas, and Fried Chicken and pork chop.  Just wish I didn't have to shell out $180 for 2 people (with 4 top shelf margaritas).  The food and bar are great.  I haven't been able to get a table in the dining area, but eating at the bar has just been fun.   They should expand the bar area.
author: James W.

description: DUDE.....I was pleasantly surprised!  A buddy & I came for dinner, and both have been hearing all kinds of good things about this restaurant.  The place is comfortable, and the setting is homely.  Our server was VERY helpful and had a good sense of humor.  I forgot his name, but it was a tall DUDE with glasses.  He greeted us and asked us what we'd like to drink and my buddy says "DUDE, what would you like to drink" (mind you, my buddy & I been pals for over 20 years, so we comfortably say "DUDE" around each other a lot) so the servers then starts saying "DUDE" and made our experience easy going & pleasant.  He made great suggestions on our drinks, and the entrees as well.  I had the St. Louis Style Ribs and started out with a ButterLeaf Salad w/ apple slices, walnuts, and bleu Cheese. My buddy had the Ribeye with Bone marrow and potates.  The food was good, and for this type of restaurant the prices were reasonable.  We were not impressed with the Smoked Bone Marrow.  But everything else was just about as good as expected. But, DUDE....our waiter made the experience 4-star to me.
author: Gio G.

description:
I had dinner there tonight for the first time.  Great service, good food.  
The buttermillk fried chicken was the best.   We'll be coming back for more.
author: John H.

description:
The food was delicious and the atmosphere lively. I'm usually not a fan of scallops, but they were perfectly cooked.

We had reservations and it was nice to be seated promptly. The service was a little slow and too casual at times. All in all, fun place.
author: Happy N.

description: I've been here a couple times for lunch and have always enjoyed the food and the service. What prompted me to write a review though was my recent outing for happy hour - bartender was great and the drinks were excellent. I'd never been there for happy hour before and to be quite honest, never really even noticed the bar (even though it's right smack in front of you when you enter the building).
author: Dawn L.

description:
my fiance and I went here recently to celebrate our anniversary. we made early reservations, which i highly suggest. 
service was excellent-water refilled immediately, food came out timely, friendly servers...etc.

FOOD:
tuna tartar-small portion, but so yummy!
bbq ribs w/jalapeno cornbread-so much flavor
catfish-really good
fried okra-delicious 
jambalaya-nothing new, typical


I would come back to here to eat again. It can get pricy. We were fortunate to be one of the first seated for dinner, because by the time we left, it was almost packed and really noisy.
author: cy e.

description: I highly anticipated going to Town Hall with my wife, but alas it was not going to happen and if I can help it will never happen in the future. We arrived around 11:30 AM to see that the restaurant was largely empty and the bar area relatively busy. We were asked if we had reservations which we politely responded that we didn't. In a matter of fact tone, the hostess exclaimed that the bar was full and that there would be availability at noon. She did check the reservation list and reiterated that there would be availability at noon. The obvious question was how can the restaurant be nearly empty yet have no availability immediately yet space would be available at noon when the restaurant would likely be much busier. However rather asking the question we decided to take our business elsewhere. BTW,  the hostess didn't try to apologize, didn't encourage us to make reservations in the future, or many other options. In a nutshell, if the hostess is rude, it is not likely a good sign for the rest of the experience. So I'll pass on this restaurant in the future.
author: Darrin J.

description: I thought this place was excellent! The service was great and the atmosphere was casual/elegant/fun. We ordered the Dungeness crab Guinness stout fondue and it was super yummy...too bad the portions wasn't big enough...but we managed to eat up the rest of the fondue with bread :). For main course I had the slow roasted duck and my hubby had the Grilled Creekstone rib-eye (both were also excellent). We finished our meal off with German chocolate cheesecake and my god that was a big piece of cake! :) It's not a cheap place but it was definitely worth it!
author: JenJen W.

description: 2nd time here for dinner with an overall opinion that the food is pretty good but way over priced for what you get. I went here for dinner on Thursday and was not impressed with the service this trip either. Took 10 minutes to get water, another 10 to get our glasses of wine and 45 minutes to get our dinner. Won't be going back for a 3rd visit
author: laury g.

description: Eaten here many times, less frequently recently. Went back recently, still great. Had excellent Kushi Oysters, and awesome meal with standouts being the chopped salad, Jalapeno Cornbread, Mac-n-Cheese, "coffee and doughnuts" dessert. Great wine & reasonable and well thought-out selection + helpful, friendly staff. Yay!
author: Logan C.

description: We figured we'd have a pretty decent meal at Town Hall based on what we knew about the place, but we weren't prepared to be blown away. Our first appetizer -- the warm ham and cheese toast with a poached egg and jalapeno cream -- set the bar ridiculously high, but everything we tried from that point forward had no problem clearing it. The shrimp and scallop appetizers were also impressive, and all our entrees -- the peanut tasso crusted pork chop, the tender ribeye, the buttermilk fried chicken and the tai snapper -- were deeply satisfying. We also enjoyed great specialty cocktails (try the cucumber-tinged Rose's 44) and desserts (the butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme is decadent). Service was fantastic and the atmosphere was warm and lively. I'm in town visiting from the South, where I grew up, and I have to say this is the best Southern-style food I've had in ages. (3/23/2009)
author: Rommie J.

description: I think Willie Brown lives here.  No, seriously. I've seen him here three times, head-to-toe LV and all (twice with someone who must have been his very attractive niece because she certainly was cute, and not a day over 30). But I digress. The food is fabulous. I love the spinach salad with oysters -- not sure if it makes it to the dinner menu. Definitely give the app's a whirl. I haven't been disappointed yet. I tough place for a biz meeting because it's fairly noisy, but I love this place!
author: Lindsey B.

description: Normally I am loath to disagree with my friends, but I've consistantly had terrible dining experiences here. Although the ingredients of the meals may be top notch, the meals themselves suffer from poor preparation and execution. The food here always tastes like a bunch of line cooks prepare everything with no regard to the patron. Want any piece of meat cooked well done? Forget about it. In fact, everything I've had here has been undercooked, from the pink chicken to the rock hard potatoes. Meh.
author: Tal K.

description: Great food, great service. The only thing that was a drag was the noise. Wow, it was really difficult to have a normal conversation in there!
author: Pierre K.

description: This place has the best service of any restaurant in the city.  they always seem genuinely delighted to have you there.  They also seem to be looking for any reason to give you free stuff.  I've never had a meal there without having something comped - dessert, a bottle of champagne, our entire check.  Besides, the food is sublime.  The insanely rich ham and egg thingie will make you weep with joy.
author: Robyn H.

description: The thing that I remember most about Town Hall is the chocolate/butterscotch pot de creme. In fact, whenever I am at a restaurant and the time comes to choose a dessert, most of the time I just wish I could be back at Town Hall. I'll have to go back again for dinner, because after eating that pot de creme, I honestly don't remember what else I ate that night!
author: Naomi F.

description:
the butterscotch pot de creme is too large.  There, I said it, the emperor is naked afterall.  Seriously folks, it comes in a bathtub sized vessel that, if you've had a reasonably filling meal to date, will confound the combined guts of all but the most horrifyingly obese couples.  Might fly in omaha, but it's proportion is actually rather profane this side of the rockies.

there's a lot to like here, even if I'm growing increasingly annoyed by this culinary movement toward comfort food that has distincly non-comforting pricing.  Wasn't the whole point of meatloaf that it was inexpensive to make, so that you could feed a whole clan with not all too much?  Aside from that philosophical dislike of this place, the food is excellent.  Very good fried chicken (very good for a restaurant, I should say), and solid preparation of steak.  I have to say that the apps, although intellectually interesting, were rather disappointing.  The apple beignets with ham (great idea) were less than stellar because the kitchen had used whole apple slices (sounds like a great idea) which tended to fall apart when cut into (better to use a small dice guys!).  Little croquets (forgotten what was supposed to be in them) were a tad bland, and served with mustard.  Mustard aoli?  Mustard sauce?  nope, just plain dijon.  hmmm...the exec chef's imagination just isn't working very hard.   

The wine list is solid and well priced, with a good selection of things from all around.  I hit a kim crawford pinot gris and a scheurebe to start things off, then delved into some other glasses from there.  The reserve list had a few interesting items, but ultimately not the most compelling.

I did hate where they had their bathroom, which is up a fluorescently lit corridor upstairs--a jarring movement which ruins the fantasy of where you were and makes you feel like you're back in your office again.  Whoever worked on that particular piece of design, bravo for maximizing the amount of floor space on the ground floor...now go shoot yourself for pandering to the buck and making the restrooms an unpleasant, extended journey.

The long and short...I can see why people really like this place, and I'll rate it accordingly.  It was good, and does a lot of things right.  Still, I have to say, it didn't hit me on the heartstrings, and really failed to address all those things for which I enjoy going out.  Objectively, a good place, but I jut didn't like it all that much.
author: Kosuke I.

description: Town Hall you are so good.  I got to sample their tuna tartare (YES!), ham and cheese toast with poached egg and jalapeno cream (not too hot but so creamy) and their halibut (fresh and light).  I don't remember what wine we got but remember it was very good too.  This place is a bit pricey so I'd suggest it for a fun or special occassion.
author: Julie K.

description: Woooooooo woooooo, finally made it this place!  Food was excellent, love the quotes on the walls and the bar bill being passed out in a hard back book.  Food was excellent, drink were ok, and the bill was HUGE aka $200 for 2 of us and I was drinking alone.  Thanks for the meal el jefe!
author: Porfirio R.

description: Interesting setup but not as interesting as some of the food creations.  Their menu has such a large variety of different types of food that are fused together that I had a difficult time choosing what I had.  I was there for a business dinner so each of us sampled a little bit of everything.  Everything was great, food was unique and definitely a fun place to go.
author: Eli Z.

description: Lovely dinning experience.  We called ahead to get a res. with no luck.  Went down there anyway at about 620 and got a table.  Conditions being we finish by 815.  Staff was very friendly.  My boyfriend got the lamb and I ordered the duck.  We ended up switching as the duck wasn't as rich as I was hoping.  I'm going to get the rabbit next time.  We accompanied our meal with a nice syrah (I think). The decor was nice, simple and reminded me of New England.  The Sommelier was very friendly as well and after dinner, let us taste a wine my boyfriend has been curious about.
author: Cassie D.

description: I'm not sure why this place always gets solid reviews.  I came here for lunch the other day and was disappointed with the whole menu.  There were six in our group and I'm not sure anyone liked what they had.
author: Jennee D.

description: Given the reviews we'd read, we were really looking forward to our dinner at Town Hall. What a disappointment. The food was so overseasoned that, if it was meant to have any flavor underneath, we couldn't tell. The short rib was a slab of fat and the rib eye was like eating a salt lick. Our waiter was off his game all night long but seemed to be used to making up for his shortcomings with overbearing charm, which got tiring after an hour. It's one thing to pay $130 (we brought our own wine) for dinner and be disappointed, but following such glowing reviews made it even worse.  Even dessert was overdone.
author: David Z.

description: Good tasty food, fun dinner, awesome brick building and pretty ambiance, but nothing so special as worth the price, exactly.  Mainstream trendy good.  So So..... but kept finding fun, friendly other diners.
author: Today Y.

description:
the food and service were great! our waitress was really attentive and funny without being annoying. 

we started with the crab fondue- yum! it was delicious! i was dipping my bread after all the sausages and potatoes were gone. everything else was tasty- we had the duck, pork chop and fried chicken. we were stuffed but ordered the butterscotch pudding  to share and it was out of this world- we only needed one or two bites each because it was so rich and creamy.

get on opentable and make reservations because it was jumpin even on a monday night.
author: pancakegirl l.

description: Loved it. Gorgeous interior: warm and stylish without pretension. The service was incredible (our server was impeccably kind and professional about my question re: the free-rangeness of the chicken). The food was great, down to the bread-and-butter (one of the true markers of a great restaurant, in my book). A little too much food, and just shy of  *there* but so, so close. The butterscotch-y  pudding at the end really made my night.
author: Emmy M.

description: The food was kind of blah. The location and service was the best part. It was part old-english-town-pub and part elegant-parisian-chic. Again, the food was nothing to die for and it's somewhat pricey. Not my favorite restaurant nor a place I'd likely go back when there are so many great restaurants in the city.
author: Suzy Q.

description:
We got invited to a small reception for a friend of ours and the private dining area is up on the 2nd floor with it's own bar service on a Thursday night. Dinner starts at 6:30 so we get there a little before and we help ourselves to the bar. We mingle a bit and it is NOW 8:30 and we are just barely getting seated. 5 minutes goes by, 10 minutes, 15 minutes...NO FOOD coming out as this was suppose to be a 3 course meal. What the F is taking so long for some pre-made appetizers of tuna tartare or salad for a party of 40?! It's getting very close to 9 and the appetizers finally comes out as most of the guests are peeved and dying of hunger. We all scarf down our food and it seemed like those who were down, the wait staff immediately whisked your plates away and out comes the entree of what I picked, rib eye steak. Guess they realize what time it was so they started to pick up the pace. I'm guessing by the time we all got our entree it was 9:30 and dessert came shortly after. Needless to say, a dinner time of 6:30 ended up to be a 4 hour ordeal. 

2 stars for such poor service and wait time. In a fair statement, their food was good but it would have been even better if we all had not waited for so long to eat. We might go back eventually but never for a party or maybe not even a group event.
author: Karen R.

description: So just went to Town Hall finally. Been wanting to check it out. So got there early and ordered a drink. Ordered a Negroni on the rocks. I know its an old man drink whatever I'm an old man.  Had the ribs with pulled pork slider for an apetizer. Good not amazing but still good. The service was great. It is loud there.  So ordered the halibut and the shrimp salsa thing on the fish seemed totally unneccesary and I didn't get how it went with the dish but the corn pudding the Halibut rested on was sooo good with the porcinni mushrooms. Yumm. The desert was awsome too. I definitely would go back since I heard they have the best Fried Chicken.
author: Hyung L.

description: I have been to town hall twice for dinner and have thoroughly  enjoyey my meal both times.  The food is well thought out and flavorfull and the staff was friendly and attentive.  The atmosphere is upscale but casual, one would be comfortable in jeans or a suit.  My only negative is that is really lives up to it's name.  Town Hall is very loud!
author: Kaylee T.

description:
things that matter: the service and the food really, everything else is nitpicking
service here was great, the waitress knew the menu and wine list very well and had opinions on everything as well as recommendations. she was very attentive even though our table was towards the rear, so good job.
the food: was great. nuff said. had the summer melon and suckling pig apps, both quite tasty. had quail and sea bass entrees, both exceptional.
author: Rich B.

description: Went here early on a Sunday evening for dinner with a friend -- the place quickly became packed shortly after we arrived.  Outstanding service from the moment we walked in til the moment we left -- everyone was friendly, knowledgeable, and quick.  We had the bbq shrimp to start -- amazing sauce!  Fried chicken the best I've had in the city (though not the best ever -- that's at Kingfish Cafe in Seattle), short ribs so tender they melted in your mouth.  Ordered a side of the jalapeno cornbread -- delicious!  Butterscotch-chocolate pot de creme was fabulous -- we probably would have been licking the bowl clean if it weren't for our completely overstuffed stomachs and good manners!  Since we'd never been here before, we asked our waitress for recommendations, and we absolutely loved everything.  Highly recommended, I'd love to go back here in a heartbeat!
author: Caroline P.

description: Town Hall is a good location for the business crowd but it's very noisy so rather difficult to have a conversion with dinner companions.  Food is mediocre and portions are a bit on the small side.
author: Lev E.

description:
if i could marry this restaurant... i would!  thanks to town hall, i now truly believe that new american is actually a cuisine.

everything about this meal was wonderful!  even the table bread!  we ate more than half of it before we even got the appetizer and salad.  after the meal i asked one of the hosts where it's from - everyone make a run for acme bread company in the ferry building!!!

the veal meatballs are a must!  the blue cheese and the blue cheese dressing on the butter lettuce salad w/ fuji's was killer!

grilled pork chop - a twist on one of my favorites.  the grits were so creamy and mixed so well with the juices from the chop.  candied apples had those crusty, crunchy candied bits that offered a slight crunch after biting the tender chop.

i'm coming back for the scallop entree.  mark my word!  i'm usually not a scallop fan, but these took by breath away!

rib eye - very simply done.  just the way i liked it.  the meat spoke for itself.

desserts - wasn't too crazy about the fig and berry parfait, but the pot de creme... you are insane if you don't order it.  TRUST ME!  the bitterness of the dark chocolate creme combined with the butterscotch so deliciously.  and i'm not much of a butterscotch fan either!  

service was phenomenal!  hilliary was awesome, friendly, patient!  she was the perfect waitress!  she even gave me my coffee on the house because it arrived after the desserts.  now that's attentive!  

the inside reminded me of a real town hall i've been to!  the bead board.  real hardwood floors that make that distinct hallow sound when you walk with boots on.  i loved every step i took in there!  =)

can't wait until the next visit!
author: Christine P.

description: Loved the Shrimp in BQ, the fried chicken and pork chops were OK.  The ambiance was cool and the services was very nice but slow.
author: ein bier bitte k.

description: The food was good.  The space is crowded.  I thought the waiter was going to hit my husband's head with a plate when she walked by - that's how crowded the restaurant is.
author: Air D.

description: Place is good, not fantastic.  Service was average and the food was OK...  Just nothing over the top.
author: Jason M.

description: Great place to have dinner with friends.  The drink I had while waiting for our table was excellent, it was mixed drink with absinthe.  We had wine, appetizers, entrees, and even dessert.  Everything was good, but my wife didn't like the bbq ribs she had for her entree.  The deep fried oyster appetizers were excellent - even for my wife who doesn't like oysters.  I will definitely have to come back.
author: emelito d.

description: My family and went here for my Mother's birthday dinner. We had a great time, great food, and really great service. There is a great little bar to have a drink while you wait, and when we got to our table our waiter (Troy) did a great job of suggesting wine and cocktails to compliment the meal. He also helped us narrow down the appetizers since we could have ordered them all. One member of our party ordered the fried chicken since we saw it at every other table in the restaurant, and it was great, but I have to say the ribs are not to be missed either. Throw in a neat building in a great downtown location and its quite a night out.
author: Post R.

description: Town Hall was great, but not amazingly great. I cam here with a bunch of wine connoisseurs after a wine tasting in downtown SF. This was a large party and our  service was nothing but spectacular but unfortunately the food wasn't up to par. To start I had the Ahi Tuna Tartare which was pretty good, but then again it's hard to mess up Ahi Tuna Tartare. I regret not ordering the bisquets which is something I will have to do if I make it back to Town Hall. For my main course I had the quail which came with fried oysters. OMG those fried oysters were TO DIE. Those fried oysters totally took away from the quail and stole the show! I would have been happy having an order of just those! The quail overall was just O-K. I ended up eating most of my friends rib-eye and mushrooms instead of my dish. We left before we had time to glance at the dessert menu although I can imagine the dessert was probably just OK along with everything else at Town Hall.
author: Sarah T.

description: solid chicken. i heard ham toast was good. so was the trout. pot de creme dessert was very nice. some in my party weren't that excited about the cuban panini. steak, i hear, was just all right.
author: dima y.

description: Very good food, good atmosphere, attentive waitress. Overall, a nice setting for a solid dinner. My girlfriend and I were seated promptly, and the waitress was very helpful throughout the entire meal. Whatever you do, DO NOT forget to order Faith's warm ham and cheese toast, poached egg and jalapeno cream. A friend recommended it to me, and he was right on point. Seriously, make sure you order this when going to Town Hall!
author: PM M.

description: Fried chicken - thats all you need to know
author: Michael C.

description:
I really wanted to like this place.  No, I really wanted to LOVE this place as it came highly recommended by my boyfriend who said he ate the best pork chop of his life here ( and he doesn't like pork).
The decor is nice, the vibe is great and the service is good.  So no complaints there.
The low rating comes from the fact that my pork chop was completely over-salted.  I like salty food but I stopped eating after 3 bites and downed a half litre of water (no exagerration) in 30 mins.  I should have had my order re-made but I didn't want to be a pain ( I know, it's silly that I didn't want to be a pain and here I am complaining!)  It's too bad bc I could tell that underneath all that salt, the flavours were amazing.  Also, having read the reviews on Yelp and Citysearch, there seems to be a large number of ppl who have had the same issue. I wish someone in their kitchen would read the reviews and remedy this.
Had the key lime pie for dessert and it was alright if not a bit too sweet but maybe that's only bc the main was too salty.
Will go back and order the pork chop again and hope for better luck ( I'll probably place the order with an "easy salt" request!)
author: sachiko W.

description:
Townhall makes simple, familiar, comfort dishes into something extraordinary and special. The buttermilk fried chicken was very tender, juicy and absolutely delicious. The size per serving was reasonable and very satisfying. The dessert, butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme has just the right sweetness and richness.

I would have rated Townhall 5 star if only the tables and chairs are not too crammed. The overall decor is homey and comforting; however, the place is very noisy and one can hear their neighbors' conversation!

It may be ideal for a family dine out, but it may lack the atmosphere conducive for a business meeting or romantic first date (unless one would rather not pay attention to the conversation and just stare at one's date all night ;)

In summary, the food, decor, service, and pricing are great! One star less due to noise and overall layout.
author: Jane D.

description: I was here probably two years ago and don't remember exactly what we ate that night but I do know it was delicious.  Everything was very fresh...
author: Cameron A.

description: Slamming the service!!!  we walked in at 5:00 for a quick appi and a drink, and were told that the food is not being served until 5:30.  My client had no time to wait and needed to jet out of the city to catch a flight, and I had to take my client elsewhere, we went to RN74, literally around the corner on Mission St.  I asked if they would bend the rule and at least allow us to order anything that was ready and didn't require prep, but still no go.  I'm tired of the gestapo rules some places still maintain in San Francisco, particularly because they would rather see a customer leave, then oblige.  Needless to say, I'm not taking my clients here a again., sad.
author: Steven M.

description: Great place for groups and for dining with friends. The food is fantastic. Good quality and fresh ingredients, local for the most part. I've tried most of the things on the menu and you can't really go wrong with anything over here. This is not the place to go for romantic dinners though, as the atmosphere and dining room are very noisy. Kids can be ok-- if they are well behaved and you go for an early seating.
author: Jennifer S.

description: One fave for Happy Hour glass of wine and friendly atmosphere with financial district type clientele.
author: Natalie E.

description: Quite possibly the best desserts in the city. As a son of the South, it's nice to see a Bay Area restaurant not afraid to indulge in the use of cream, butter, and other heavy ingredients in their menu. Not a cheap meal by any stretch, but this is a place to treat yourself. Enjoy and don't watch your weight.
author: Mike P.

description: I expected to love town hall, but it turned out to be nothing special. Overall, the food is really good (not excellent), but generally overpriced.  The ceviche was some of the best I've had, but the portion was pretty small.  Don't try to share it (or most of the appetizers) with more than one person or you won't get much more than a taste. The ambiance is ok, but nothing special, kind of boring, definitely not romantic.  It's pretty crowded and the bussers kept running into our chairs when they were walking by the table (although they didn't seem to notice). The service was inattentive, average at best. I'm glad I finally checked this place out, but I don't think I'll be going back.
author: Jen S.

description: Definitely worth a trip... the food is phenonmenal... (try the fried chicken... delicious!) and a great place to catch up with friends. let's just say we started at 8:30pm and had the waiters kickin' us out at midnight. wonderful atmosphere and vibe.. brick walls, high ceilings, & great art.
author: Monica N.

description:
Went for a work dinner.

Had the tuna tartare, halibut and then the mudpie desert. 

Everything was really good, though the halibut lacked something, not sure what though.

ANyway, great meal, fun atmosphere. I'll be back!
author: Kay T.

description:
OMG!!!  They were AWESOME last night!!  I was there for their Mardi Gras Party to raise funds for Edible Schoolyard New Orleans and had a blast!  The ticket for the event is $75, but the food, the drinks and the entertainments provided were a lot more!  The raw bar was awesome!! 3 different types of oysters, shrimp and crab cocktails, all sooo fresh and tasty!  They had 4 people at the raw bar opening oysters nonstop from 5pm to about 9pm.  There were still oysters left when I left around 10:30pm.  The fried chicken was delicious!!  Crispy, but not greasy, the meat was tender and tasty with great flavor!  I had two pieces.  I wish I had the stomach for more!  I'm definitely going back to Town Hall just for their fried chicken!  The BBQ shrimp was another dish that was amazing!  Very tender and flavored!  This is all buffet style with staffs serving behind the tables.  The chef was able to prepare them to be so tasty even after sitting out for awhile.  There were a lot of people.  I think more than 200 people showed up.  I guess the turnover was fast enough to keep the food fresh and tasty.  They never ran out of food!!  By the time I left around 10:30pm, they were still serving food!  Here's the menu from last night.  I think the only item missing was the crawfish.  That's the only disappointment.

. Fresh Crawfish
. Raw Bar with Louisiana & California Oysters
. Gumbo and Jambalaya Stations 
. Etouffe
. Fried Chicken
. Abita Beer, Wine, Caipirinhas and N'awlins Fare Hurricanes, 
a cocktail synonymous with Mardi Gras  

All drinks on the menu above were unlimited.  There were Samba dancers, tap dancers and a a New Orleans Dixie band.  They were all good and lived up the party!  They also had girls at the party drawing face art and a balloon artist for balloon hats, balloon jewelries!  

One more thing I want to complement is the Town Hall staffs.  I'm not sure if the organizer of the party also helped or not, but the staffs were friendly and seemed to be having a great spirit and time too!  They constantly cleaning away the empty bottles, glasses and plates to maintain a clean and safe condition of the party.  I give them a 5 stars for that for a party that crowded.  It was a very crowded party and they were able to work around that and quickly!
author: Gina W.
Jimmy F.

description: Wow, this place was great.  I wasn't sure what to expect on a Monday, as some of the best chefs only work on the weekends, but is was really good!  I had the duck, and it was perfectly moist.  I tried my friend's quail, and her's was too.  Her grits were nice and cheesey.  (Yes, I know I pick off everyone's food.)  My apple crumble was good, too, but not as great as the entrees.  Oh yeah, and biscuits with spiced jam was awesome.
author: Natasha L.

description: I had dinner there last night and I had a great time.  The decor is comfy but modern and their food was pretty good.  I would recommend the veal meatballs, FRIED CHICKEN, jalepeno cornbread, and sticky toffee cake.  I also enjoyed their jambalaya but the BBQ flavor was a little too sweet for me to eat very much of it.  However, the scallops that were placed on top of it was well prepared.  I will definitely be back for more.
author: Nina L.

description: I really loved this place, Town Hall was pretty chill and I had an awesome Ribeye.  But what I loved most about this place was the great eyecandy.  Waitstaff and patrons were all easy on the eyes, or was it the bottle of Pinot Noir we all had.  All in all tastetastic!
author: Rossi C.

description: Town Hall has an easy location to meet for a semi-spendy,  semi-hip dinner.  One of the women in our group loved this restaurant and wanted us to try it together.  We went with 3 other couples on a Saturday night and had a great time.  All in all, the food, service and ambiance was good, but at the end of the meal, with cocktails, apps, dinner, 2 bottles of wine, coffees and tip, we left feeling like we all paid a bit more than it was worth.  That is not to say it was massively over-priced, just that a bit more rent was in the prices than the meal we had.  We will probably go back.
author: Michael B.

description: 5 starts just for the biscuits with ham and red pepper jelly. Oh, so, good.  5 stars for the cornbread.  5 stars for the fried chicken. 5 stars for the butterscotch pot de creme. Decent wine list,  innovative mixed drinks. And I wonder why I have junk in the trunk. Yikes!  Great place to come with friends, and a nice communal table for walk-ins that is spacious enough not to feel like the weird communal table where no one wants to sit.  These guys are good.  I would agree it is the best out of their mini empire.
author: Tristan C.

description: Amazing decor and friendly staff. We went in a small group which was cozy as this is not a group style restaurant. I will diffidently go back again based upon my experience. The artichoke, duck and fried chicken are amazing! At the end of dinner you sign your signature in a classic book.
author: leah p.

description: My husband and I went to dinner at Town Hall to celebrate our 2nd wedding anniversary and were very unimpressed with the restaurant. The music was way too loud and the food was way below average. My husband started with the jambalaya which was much too spicy, even for him (the man eats habaneros raw) and not at all authentic. His main dish was the pork chop which was way too overcooked and tasted overwhelmingly of pepper. I started with the cream of corn soup, which was actually quite good and the only delicious thing either of us ate that night. That said, the soup was so hot that I had to wait at least 20 minutes before I could actually eat a whole spoonful without burning my mouth. Even the spoon was scorching hot. I then had the ribs at our waitresses' suggestion. When I asked for her opinion about what to order, I told her that I can't eat spicy food because of a health condition and she assured me that the ribs were not spicy. When I took my first bite, my lips felt like they were on fire. I then tried to quell the spice with the cornbread that came with my dish, which, it turned out, was also spicy and made things worse. Do they know how to make anything that isn't uncomfortably spicy? After a less than impressive dinner, we hoped that dessert might make the situation better. We chose the "Coffee and Doughnuts", which consisted of espresso ice cream and mini beignets. The ice cream was fairly good but the beignets were stale. I'm more than a bit confused as to why this restaurant feels they can charge almost $100 for two people and serve food that is not even worth $10. Thank goodness my husband and I were able to maintain our sense of humor and chock the evening up to a learning experience.
author: Sandi S.

description: Food was good, but the service was shockingly bad. Other than taking our order, we barely saw our server. Here was the worst part: After our appetizers were taken away, it was nearly _one hour_ before entrees were brought to the table. No apologies from Town Hall or anything. Just excuses about it being late in the evening (9:30pm is late??). Perhaps this was a one off, but it will definitely make me think twice before going back for a while.
author: Joel S.

description:
what is everyone smoking?? this place is NOT THAT GOOD.

buttermilk biscuit appetizers were dry and tasteless, and the jelly was too sticky - 1/5.

buttermilk fried chicken was also dry and tasteless. you want good fried chicken??? go to popeyes. save yourself a lot of $$ and hassle. 1/5

jalepeno cornbread - tasted like cornstarch with dried, shriveled jalepeno in it. 1/5

absolute WORST beignets i have ever had in my life. again, didn't taste like a damn thing. 1/5

chocolate mousse bomb. not bad actually. tasted somewhat as had probably been intended to taste. 3/5

ambiance: so noisy you can't hear yourself think. too crowded to feel comfortable.

service: we waited 45 mins to be seated AFTER having made reservations.

waste of my time, waste of my money, waste of my calories.
author: nawabzadi h.

description: This restaurant was wonderful!  We went with a group of eight and every single one of us thought the food was outstanding.  Highly recommended!  (a few entrees/appetizers the group had are: Pan roasted stuffed pork chops; Pan roasted Alaskan halibut; Sauteed dayboat scallops; Tuna tartare; Barbequed Shrimp)
author: Kat C.

description: Service was slow.  Food was only just warm.  Sweet potato chips are a winner.  Wouldn't return.
author: Phyllis B.

description: This place is solid and tasty.  I'm not sure I would say its very exciting but sometimes you want a fancier well executed meal that isn't trying to hard.  Na'mean?
author: b s.

description: Now that the hype has died down and the SaltHouse has opened, Townhall is much easier to get in. Dessert is still what Townhall does best. For entrees- the lamb is hearty and good value while the fried chicken is just OK.
