Despite what the servers will tell you, the fried chicken is not half of a chicken, but merely a small drumstick, thigh and breast. Don't get the jambalaya side- way too much spices that you cannot taste anything.
author: Lily C.

description: Yummy overall with delicious appetizers especially the one with Shrimp (there's only one). The place was buzzing & it's quite hard to get a spot without reservations. We ate at the communcal table and that's a unique experience. I'd go there again any day.
author: Bharat J.

description: Went here on Friday after drinks some place else. I may have been intoxicated and hungry but the food was really good. Seafood chowder was solid, not as thick as I thought (which is good). Trout wrapped in bacon was great. It's meat wrapped by bacon, how could it be bad? Drinks there were good. People at the large table were fairly interesting to talk to. Did get a bit loud but I project well so I think people heard me.
author: Mike C.

description: I went here for a lunch meeting and found it to be a great spot.  It was walking distance from the office and wasn't extremely loud.  I thought the cornbread was an odd choice by my manager, but after trying it, I am believer.  I had the duck enchiladas, which were surprisingly delicious.  Again, odd flavor combinations, but I thought it worked.  After lunch we had a tour of the banquet room upstairs (for a future work event) and I thought it was a great space.  The staff was very helpful and friendly.
author: Jessica T.

description: Nice space. Food was good, but we expected better. I gave the Fried Chicken a shot (which was recommended by the waiter) - which was probably the wrong thing on the eve'. They do have a nice wine selection.
author: Seann G.

description: I went here with my girlfriend a couple months ago and it was great. It was really busy and service was a bit slow, but the food and atmosphere were great! The clientele seemed to be in the 30+ range, but had good energy. The restaurant, as one might imagine, has an old "Town Hall" kind of feeling. The lighting isn't a blaring bright white, but more like a warm yellow. The restaurant definitely has a lot of character. If you're looking for a place that has an old American, warm feel to it, this is the place. Plus, the oysters I got for an appetizer were fantastic.
author: Brian O.

description:
Overall, a little disappointing given the reviews and the prices.
The service was not great, with a pretty inattentive waitress, a very slow bartender, but nice, concerned managers circulating the floor.  Atmosphere is a little too bright and crowded, with a kind of colonial feel to it.
I ate there a week ago and can't remember the appetizers we got, that was how unmemorable they were.  I know we got the ham biscuits, which were tasty.  My entree was the ribeye, which was mediocre.  Everyone else thought their meal was fine, but I kind of feel like it should have been outstanding, given the price ($270 for 4).
author: Kristi S.

description: Took a long time after the reservation before I was eating here The place looked casual and servers were very friendly. The food just alright, maybe I was putting too much expectation with people's recommendations. I just think their foods are little bit overpricing. I was expecting something even better.
author: Jess F.

description: Girlfriend and I came here for an anniversary dinner. It was pretty good, the service was great, very knowledgeable and attentive. The food was pretty good and came in nice large portions. For appetizers we got the tomato fondue which was really good! She had the fried chicken and I had the rib-eye. I thought both were really good, and both were cooked perfectly. The fried chicken breast was moist and tender which really impressed me. The main entrees had very nice pairings, very flavorful. For dessert, we had the sorbet which really didn't taste like anything we had before, but it was good. Overall, it was a great experience, would come here again.
author: A N.

description: You can tell Town Hall is from the same folks as Salt House.  The atmosphere and experience are very similar.  But that isn't a bad thing.  I enjoyed everything we had, including the wine.  The service was solid and atmosphere quintessential city.  As with Salt House, I can't identify one thing that was over the top but everything was up to par.  Good spot!
author: Bryan G.

description: Good food, good service, always a good night.  Its hard to find a place where you can always go and know you are going to have a solid meal with a great wine list.  Some of the better apps I have eaten in a long time, and the service is very orchestrated in making sure everything is taken care of.  I would recommend this place to anyone.  I would consider Town Hall top 5 in the city.
author: Cal H.

description: A little disappointed with the food given the reputation and potential. I had the risotto with butternut squash and truffles and still can't believe that I didn't like it. It was satisfying but nothing special really. Two people at my table had the petrole sole and they really liked the food, so maybe try that one instead. The worst part about the restaurant were the acoustics. Once the place started to fill up (to about 2/3 full) I couldn't hear anything from the other side of my table. Given there were only 6 of us this is pretty remarkable. I'd likely go here for happy hour because it was fun and they had a nice bar area, but not likely to go for dinner again.
author: jess c.

description: This place was touted by some SF locals as a the place for New American. Either my friend's have impaired taste or NYC kicks SF's behind on New American. This, like several of the others recommended, left me feeling disappointed and like I'd overpaid.
author: Randall K.

description: Delightful service from the front desk, to the bar, to the table. Took a client to Town Hall and had a great time. Delicious food, relaxed atmosphere and, even though we lingered far too long discussing business, no one ever made us feel like we had to give up the table. Excellent.
author: Ken M.

description: Food good.  Dozens of bugs in dozens of drinks bad.
author: Ashley K.

description: Dinner service, Friday night, 5:45 reservation.  Service was sparkling and much of the reason that the rating was brought up to 3 stars. Tip extra to sit in Taylor's section, she was top notch. Food wise is where Town Hall lacks. Don't get me wrong, it's good just not great. For the two of us with one and a half bottles of wine, dinner ran $250 and for that price I want to be WOWED. Is that too much to ask? I think I actually enjoyed the appetizers more than the main courses to be honest. We started with the veal meatballs over pureed potatoes and the intriguing cheese toast with prosciutto and beschamel sauce. Both very, very good...but worth $15 each, mmmm not really. Then onto roasted sea bass with cuttlefish for me and ribs for the lady. Again, not wowed. And for $30 each entree...I guess I was maybe expecting too much. Summary: stellar service but overpriced for food that was glorified diner/comfort food. Maybe I just didn't get it. Will not be making any special efforts to come back.
author: Mark C.

description:
I ate here for dinner about six months ago and was underwhelmed.   I decided to give it another chance and returned for lunch with a co-worker this last week.  It was not a good experience.

First, it seems our waiter forgot to place our orders.  It was 45 minutes at least before we received our food (a ham and cheese "toast" and a hamburger).  And that was after about three requests for updates on why it was taking so long.  When you are serving lunch to a business crowd on weekdays, a 45 delay is not cool.  Also, our waiter disappeared after our first request for an update -- he didn't return until after we got  our food.  All of our questions had to go through the bus boys and hostess.

Then my ham and cheese toast came.  I am not exaggerating when I say it had ONE piece of very thinly sliced ham in it.  For $13, this is ridiculous.  The hostess saw me inspecting the sandwich and immediately apologized and sent it back.  They made me a new one and waived it from my bill, but by the time we got the second one it was already more than an hour after we started and I didn't have time to eat it.  

All in all, a lame experience.  The hostess was very friendly and nice (saving it from one star), but everything else was unpleasant.  And this is coming from someone who really likes Salt House.
author: Darin S.

description: Service was very good. BBQ shrimp appetizer and a couple of the other appetizers were good. Thought the pork chop was supposed to come with a peanut sauce on it but it came out covered with an overabundance of chopped peanuts on top which really took away from the dish.
author: JM K.

description: I enjoyed everything about this restaurant. The food was outstanding (the veal meatballs and bbq shrimp) along with the wine list. Only complaints...a bit loud and the bar was slammed for those interested in happy hour.
author: A D.

description: I love the food here.  I've been here once in the winter and once in the spring, so the menu was slightly different each time but both times I really enjoyed everything I tasted. I needed a place to take my parents for a special occasion but they aren't the scenester - who- like- snobby - restaurant types.  Town Hall is perfect because the vibe is warm and welcoming, (and beautiful decor) and the staff is friendly, but the food is the real deal.
author: L C.

description: The food is great. The service is not. Both times I have eaten at Town Hall I have been treated to a wonderful meal that unfortunately left a sour taste in my mouth due to the service (or lack thereof)... Slow, unattentive, seemingly rushed waitstaff, and all after being seated 30 minutes after our scheduled reservation... ugh.
author: Ryan Y.

description: Starve yourself for the entire day before you go there.  The food is that rich that you don't want to ruin the experience by getting prematurely full.
author: david b.

description: I liked the food, the service as decent but not great.   Went on a business lunch, so the atmosphere was perfect.... vibrant but not too loud, while at the same time enough activity to keep you occupied until the food comes.  not overly pricey as its' reputation would suggest.
author: Tony S.

description:
It was a very disappointing dining experience.  I was expecting something spectacular because of all the fanfare, but didn't really do anything for my palate.  The duck I ordered came out a bit dry and very salty.  The sauce was so salty it was bordering on being bitter.  Other dishes we simply not very innovative.  

The service was great, too bad the food wasn't better.
author: Art W.

description: Delish!  Some highlights include the BBQ shrimp appetizer - we sopped up all the sauce with bread; halibut - so light and tender; and dessert - we had the butterscotch pot de creme, which tasted more pudding-y then dense and the sticky toffee cake, which was out of this world.  Love the atmosphere - huge ceilings and the tables are spaced well.  Forget the name of our server, but he was a hoot!  Would definitely go back again.
author: JP D.

description:
with all the recent bad reviews, i feel compelled to add a positive one.

this has been one of my favorite restaurants in the city for at least the past 4 years.  granted i only make it there a couple times a year, but it consistently delivers amazing food that i talk about for weeks after a visit.

the veal meatball appetizer is what i call "an eye closer" - meaning it tastes so delicious that you close your eyes upon tasting to savor the flavors.  i had the fried chicken for the first time this weekend and wow - enormous portion, with incredible flavor, and the accompanying potatoes & snap peas did not disappoint either.  the pork chop is always delicous as well.  and the butterscotch pot de creme - wow!

the service is always just okay, but nice enough.  and the food makes up for any lacking in the hospitality.  

plan ahead, make your reservations, and enjoy the deliciousness that is Town Hall.

*5-27-08 Update*
my new favorite thing on the menu... the Sticky Toffee Cake dessert.  holy moses, i'm in heaven with this dessert!

and another note from my recent visit... the short ribs were practically inedible - way more fat than meat.  they didn't even question me when i let them know, just apologized several times and removed it from our bill.  excellent service!
author: brittany z.

description:
i'm a fan of Town Hall by mere proximity alone (one block from work!).  when this place opened up a few years ago, this was THE spot all-around.  since the area south of market has "trendified" over the past few years with dozens of new and hip AND great tasting restaurants, it's dropped a few notches in rank.  as a local 'foodie' (in the loosest sense of the word!) these guys need to revamp or update their menu more frequently.  honestly think the menus have been static for at least 2-3 years!  

hopefully the owners don't make the same mistake with Salt House........ no one's more fickle than the restaurant consumer.
author: ellelle l.

description:
My wife and I came here two weeks ago for her birthday and it did not dissapoint.

When we arrived at around 6:30 on Thursday the place was busy .. not packed, which we actually were happy about. Most of the people at that point were the after work crowd, which I am sure is most of their patrons until a bit later.

The food was very good, and service okay. We were in a highly trafficked area, but had no one sitting on either side, which was nice - the tables are pretty packed in.

I would say the ambiance is city chic, not necessarily formal or too casual either. Very easy to relax and have good conversation - when it's not too packed, that is! By the time we left it got crowded and loud - I am not sure that I would have necessarily enjoyed the experience as much in that atmosphere (as an intimate dinner).

The food was very good - we both started with the Butter lettuce salad. We both agreed that it was very good, but a bit heavy on the dressing (a bit too wet). Still very tasty.

I had the buttermilk chicken as this seemed to be a favorite in reviews. It was good - considering this was the first time I had fried chicken (not a food I normally would eat) in a couple of years that is a compliment.

A downer were the deserts we ordered. We had the chocolate cake and a peanut butter ice cream type dish (can't remember specifically what it was). My wife and I agreed that they weren't worth getting.

All-in-all, I would come back here for sure! It's a great place to come with a group of people especially. As for a special place two - I can think of more intimate settings where its a bit more quiet. Definitely one of the better restaurants here in the city towards the top of my list!
author: Marin G.

description: I heard many good things about this place, so my friend said, let's go there and try their southern foods. We sat at the bar before we could get our seats. I had an Italian drink and my friend ordered a beer. The place seems very noisy, and way too crowded. I could barely hear myself. The waiter was extremely nice to us, came back and ask if we needed anything. We had the dozen oysters for appetizer.  Delicious. My friend ordered the fried chicken, and I had the Alaskan halibut. The halibut was cooked nicely but whatever it was on the side off balance the flavor of the fish. There was a certain sweetness I didn't like that counterbalance of the fish. Seasoned well, but overall a disappointment. My friend did seem to like the fried chicken. We had a side of collard greens, cause my friend is from the South. The only problem is how dark it can get inside the restaurant, and I have to scream everytime I have to say something. Which is a turn off to me. The waiter did suggest a really great merlot, which was really good and smooth. We didnt ordered the dessert, by then...we were pretty full. One more mention was the bathroom is located in the second floor which had many entrances and was a drag to walked thru the whole place looking for the restroom.
author: Jenny W.

description: Hmmm.... a lot of great reviews for this place, so we thought to check it out.  Although we were seated right away, our hostess was, well, cold, at best.  It was a Monday night, and it was surprisingly busy and loud.  Our waitress was really nice the first quarter of the meal, but maybe got overwhelmed with how busy they were (?).  Our entire meal took 2.5 hours.  Wait!  Before you judge:  we ONLY ordered entrees, no appetizers, and no dessert!!  Sure, we like to take our time when we eat, but...we would like to have SOMETHING to eat while we take our time...know what I mean?  I mean, we ARE at a restaurant after all!  No apologies from our server, at this point, a lame excuse would have even been better...but nada!  When she gave us our bill, she didn't even say thank you...what the f***?!??!  Zip.  Strangely, the table next to us seemed to have a slew of managers, cooks, servers, and such apologizing for how long they had to wait for their fried chicken entree.  Hmmm..maybe my husband and I just aren't up to the caliber of people who dine here?  Strange....'coz I thought we paid the same $$ for the fried chicken the damn table next to us had...they prolly had it comped...f**kers.  The food was alright, I had the ribs which were dry and tough, maybe saved a little by the flavor of the bbq sauce, but who gets bbq sauce wrong?!?  Aaaarghh... lame!!!
author: Grace K.

description:
The food was excellent, but the service left a lot to be desired.  When we walked in, the staff ignored us - never a good sign.  Then, once we told the (frantic) hostess our names for the reservation, we proceeded to wait...and wait....and were seated 1/2 hour after our reservation.  Not a big deal...they have a great wine list...only problem, their bar wasn't adequately staffed and we were never able to get a drink while we were waiting.  

When we were finally seated, our waiter couldn't have been more arrogant or useless.  After taking our order - without any detail of the dishes - he proceeded to take the order of the table in back of us and was a whole different person.  He gave them lenghty details of each dish and recommendations on the wine - not so much with our dining experience.  I know it wasn't us, because we've been raised to say please and thank you, so we were not rude to him - he was just a jerk.  

All in all, the food was great, but the service was so bad we'll never go back.  There are a lot of really great places to eat in SF where you don't have to deal with the personality issues of the staff.
author: lauren s.

description:
The food was excellent, but poor service prevented me from giving this place a 5-star.  We ordered our food and wine twice because our waiter had short term memory.  In fact, I think he forgot he had our table!

Anyway, the appetizers are excellent -- my fav was the tuna tartar.  Maybe it was an off night for service.  I would return for the food.
author: Diem O.

description:
Ok, first a caveat, disclaimer, and waiver of future liability:

The hostess was really nice. Sally K booked a reservation for 8:15 on a Tuesday, the occasion was Shezilla's birthday. We all arrived around 8:00, checked in, then drank a few glasses of exceedingly expensive wine from the fully occupied bar. We stood for about 25 minutes, during which the hostess apologized for the wait twice, offering us champagne for the birthday girl the second time. We sat down when some seats opened up at the small plates table, then were shown to our table around 8:30. We ordered a $74 bottle of Cabernet, which was outstanding, and the crab dip for an appetizer. As is my custom, I asked  our waitress for her recommendations and choose the pork chop accordingly. Our entrees were finally served at 9:30 after the ladies I was accompanying gently prodded the waitstaff. Everything was delicious, very well prepared with nice presentation. However, the slow service certainly impacted my enjoyment of the meat and I would consider myself to be a relatively patient individual. Therefore, I submit, for the review of the yelp community, the following; while great cuisine is the cornerstone of a successfull restaurant, the service must be of at least passable quality or the effect is lost. As mentioned, the hostess was extremely pleasant and apologetic, our waitress was also at least moderately responsive, therefore I must fault the management of the restaurant for their apparent lack of direction regarding appropriate client scheduling and effective management of the workload and staffing of the kitchen staff. 

Humbly submitted,
a dissatisfied diner
author: hugh f.

description: Good food and great desserts. A great place to take out-of-towners. It's a bit noisy, but not obscenely so. Definitely pricey!
author: Emmy B.

description: very attentive service, great food, alright atmosphere. Only downside is that the bathroom is two floors up. Definately will go back.
author: annie a.

description:
Ordered the quail entree and oysters as apetizers (each of every variety they offered which was 5).

Their wine selection is OK, by the glass so-so.

The quail skin was not that crispy (which is how I think many prefer their birds cooked) and the mashed potatoes was in a mixture of potatoes and a latin "masa" (dough used to make tamales) that mdea for an interesting texture, but didn't taste as good as good ol' mashed potaters.

Oysters came with cocktail sauce but no horseradish. Freshness was 7 out of 10.

Service was like one was in a cafe. Two female friends next to me were speaking rather loudly of guys who like "twenty two year old bitches.." they were in their forties.. Good thing for them too, because I didn't see many twenty-something's here.
author: service p.

description: Pricey but great fried chicken.  I am a fan.  But I have to admit, I was not a fan until I went on  a limb and ordered the fried chicken.  I felt that every time I went there on the request of others, it did not do it for me, it was just okay, nothing to start raving about.  Yeah the place is nice and has a good vibe and the service is friendly, but you are paying the price.  I have to go with 3 stars because I only go there for the fried chicken!
author: christy o.

description: I recently went there for my third time and it lived up to the very high expectations of my first two visits. The food is incredible. The service is friendly and knowledgeable. And the space is both comfy and lively. If you are up for something different and a little spicy, try the Faith's warm ham and cheese toast with jalepeno appetizer.
author: Sean F.

description: I really like Town Hall.  Lively, good atmosphere, great food and beverages, good service.  The is one of the best all around restaurants in the City although in a pioneering location.  I've dined several times here plus held a great party upstairs.  Super food with a satisfying experience.  A winner.
author: Charles G.

description: When I dine out, I prefer to find the best bang for my buck.  This place was a bit pricey for me, buuuuut I loved it.  The ambiance could come off a bit stuffy.  The menu counters the stuffiness.  To me, it's like fancy down home cooking.  I had the bacon wrapped pork loins.  My date had the salmon.  Our friends had the duck confit and the trout.  Every dish was freakin delicious.  The salmon might be the best I've ever tasted.
author: Nick K.

description: This restaurant is top notch. The service is friendly and approachable, and the food does not disappoint. The dessert list is amazing - save room! Some of my most favorite memories out for dinner have been at Town Hall.
author: M L.

description:
i think it has jumped the shark. We have had several really nice experiences there in the past but last night kind of sucked.First courses of salads ,soup and worcestire shrimp, in particular, were good. But its hard to mess up salad too badly. Main courses of roast beef , thai snapper and and risotto were not so good. The fish was dried out badly and almost tasteless. The risotto was bad-it was way too rich,too much cheese or something. The roast beef was kind of good to the taste buds of this cheating vegetarian. 

It's too bad because itb really was special the few prior times we visited. But alas i guess that's how it goes in the restraunt biz---you make a name with good food and attention to detail, fill the tables each night then slowly shift toward maximiing profit --- bla bla bla---we now need a new fave as $400 town hall meals are so last year
author: Steve P.

description: Stick to desserts at Town Hall.  The entrees taste like your standard American fare.  However, their butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme dessert is worth killing over !  Enough said.
author: John c.

description: Food and service is good.  I highly recommend the veal meatballs as an appetizer.  Town Hall can get cramped and very loud when busy.  The noise gives it lively atmosphere, but can be hard to have a conversation at your own table.  I've also had a bad seating placement near a little area where they hide the light switches and thermostat.  Someone from the restaurant kept having to reach behind us to adjust something.  Although he made up for it by recommending  a great wine that they just got.
author: Greg L.

description:
I checked this place out a few weeks ago and was not impressed then. I decided to give it one more try this last Saturday since a couple of friends really wanted to go. The food, particularly the stuffed pork, was a little bland. The atmosphere is nice but it's just very loud and impossible to carry on a conversation at your table without screaming at the top of your lungs. The dessert was quite dissappointing. We ordered a peach dessert which had a bit of a burnt crust, strawberry shortcake- the whipped cream tasted rancid, and a butterscotch pudding which tasted the best of the three. 

Overall, I think this restaurant is hype and way overpriced based on my personal opinion. Aesthetically, it's a nice place but I wouldn't waste my money here again.
author: nicki c.

description:
You know how you really look forward to a place then try it only to find it an unpleasant experience?  That's how it was w/ me at Town Hall last Monday.  My boss was in from the East Coast and I thought that would be a great place to take her for dinner--not too fussy, not too plain.  And, really, it would've fit the bill had not the service been so pushy.  First, I'll admit we were late for our reservation.  Got stuck on the bay bridge, yada, yada, yada, then pulled up to the restaurant to find they don't have valet parking--which I was told they did when I called in my reservation.  No matter, I kicked my boss out on the curb, asked her to get our table, then found a parking spot.  We were 15 minutes late.  

When I joined her at the table, she informed me that the waitress said we had to vacate the spot by 8:15 as they'd need the table.  Okay, it was 6:30, we were fine.  When the waitress arrived w/ a bottle of water she told me the same thing--we need to be out by 8:15.  Okay.  Got it.  When my boss perused the appetizer list, the waitress looked at her watch and said, hmmm....you do need to be out of here by 8:15....to which my boss inquired if the kitchen was backed up?  No.  Service just slow?  No.  Whatever.  Bafflement.  We proceeded straight to a main course, ordering at 6:45.  Risotto for her; salmon for me.  Do we have time for a salad?  Well, you could--but you have to be out by 8:15.  A couple of minutes after 7:00 our dishes were served.   My fish was overcooked, as though it was waiting in the oven.  I didn't ask about her risotto.  We ate, we talked (it's a noisy place--know that going in), a bus boy came along five minutes later to remove the bread. Left the butter.  My boss asked for it back.  He arrive 5 minutes after that and inquired--while my boss still had her fork in one hand and a piece of bread in the other (I know, I know--don't judge her) if she was done with her plate.  Another five minutes and the bread AND butter were removed.  Then the water glasses.  Then the salt and pepper shakers.  Item, by item the table was cleared.  It was 7:20.  We still had 55 minutes before they needed the table, but the incessant slow clearing left us with almost nothing left to touch.  The tables on either side of us were offered dessert--we were given the check.  Rude, rude, rude.  

Mediocre food, unacceptable attitude--I won't be going back.
author: Marc O.

description: I had delicous meals here but I didnt enjoy the desserts every time I dined at  Town Hall.  I guess my expectations were high then I get something that I could make at home.....nice ambiance tho
author: freewill m.

description:
I finally made my first visit to Town Hall last Thursday evening to celebrate a friend's birthday. I used Open table to make the reservation and had no trouble. 
We enjoyed stellar service and an excellent meal!
I had heard they had great service and can now say from personal experience that the staff provided exceptional service from beginning to end.
And the food was simply delicious! I had a terrible time deciding between the rib-eye and the fried chicken. Three of us ultimately decided on the rib-eye and one went with the duck.
Not one of us took issue with the pricing; the meal was well worth it and we couldn't even finish the portions. The staff happily boxed up our leftovers so we could take them home with us.
I know I'll be going back again and again and plan to make my way through their entire menu.
author: Jenny J.

description:
I was really looking forward to my lunch at Town Hall, as a close friend of mine had trained here in the past, and I have heard excellent things about it.  

Unfortunately, the experience was completely underwhelming as it took over an hour for our group to receive our main dishes, which seemed odd given that the crowd had thinned out by the time we seated (1:30).  While my burger was fine, it was overdone (far from the medium rare I requested) and not particularly exceptional.  I enjoyed the focaccia it went on, and the roma tomatoes, but the patty lacked any particularly discernable flavor.  

All in all, given its distance from my office, and the subpar service, I doubt that I would put this on my "go to" list.
author: Jayne L.

description: Went here for my sister's B-day.  The food was good but will I go back for seconds probably not.  The ambiance was not cozy, more on the drafty end.  I heard so much about this place and about the desserts but I really can't remember what i had for dessert.  Will see if Salthouse is any better.
author: Yen T.

description: Finally made it to Town Hall for lunch. A lot of people from work like to go on biz lunches so I wanted to check out what all the buzz was about. The corn/jalapeno soup was AWESOME. It was creamy and spicy--delicious. Had the salmon as my main course and have to give it 3.5 stars. The person I went with had the steak and his cut of meat was really poor quality. For that reason I have to give his meal a 2.5. So, I'm going to split the difference and give it a 3 overall. The only other comment would be that since we went there without a reservation for lunch it was a little annoying that they made us sit at the bar when there were clearly tables available. No reservation, no table. I'll give this one another shot...maybe for dinner this time.
author: Rachel A.

description:
I was excited to visit Town Hall after reading the many favorable reviews on Yelp and having the concierge at my hotel strongly recommend the place. However, the disappointment began the moment I got there.

The hostess wouldn't give me a table since I was dining alone. My options were a community table or the bar. I chose the community table, but there was something about it that was just, well, awkward. Kind of like being at the kids table at Thanksgiving. It was right by the entrance so it was a combination of a draft from outside mixed with the flood of people entering and leaving mixed with awkward conversation with strangers. The table was too high off the ground and the seats were uncomfortable.

My waiter was really aloof. He seemed like a nice guy and all, but didn't give me any helpful advice. The whole dining experience took well over two hours -- and not because I was slow to eat or make up my mind, but rather because he would drift in and out of existence. 20-30 minutes would go by after a simple request for a water refill. He never even asked me if I liked my dinner.

The food was reasonable. I liked the tomato and cheese fondue. Neat concept, but the dipping options that came with it were just okay -- lukewarm green beans, hard garlic bread, and greasy eggplant?

My waiter strongly recommended the pork chop. It came in a really great potato and white corn sauce with sauteed spinach, but the cut of meat wasn't very good and was undercooked.

I had the butterscotch and chocolate pot de creme for dessert. As some other people have mentioned, it is really good. So good that I'd consider going back and just getting that dessert. It is pretty rich. I should have gotten coffee with it -- but I was a bit flustered by the experience and forgot to order some. And, of course, my waiter never even asked me if I wanted any.

The wines that were available by the glass were mediocre and overpriced. I had a glass of Bordeaux and a glass of Meritage. In both cases, I thought the servings were small and overpriced ($14 per glass) given the lack of flavor.

All and all, I'd say it was like a $90 dinner for one at Cracker Barrel -- without the friendly service.
author: Andrew S.

description: our third-- and thus far the best-- stop on our "chronicle top 100" tour. two words: veal meatballs. two more words: fried chicken. four words: best meal in months.
author: Brett W.

description: It's called Town Hall because the owners wanted a communal atmosphere where it is a diverse crowd and everyone is treated equally.
author: Kimber R.

description:
Perfect for a date or small group. Try the fried chicken and roasted duck. 

The service was wonderful. Pretty place. Great wine. Will go back again!
author: Leah P.

description: Trendy, average food, great bar, staff basically non welcoming.  Would never go back again.  When a friend joined us late in the meal, we were told she would have to go outside and wait at a table; something about a fire code..instead of offering to bring up a chair, we were basically told to leave.  Inhospitable at the very least!
author: Peggy M.

description:
Sometimes I wish you could give a place half a star, because I would much rather give Town Hall three and a half stars than three stars.  

1. Ambiance: First of all the place is easy to find with lots of street parking.  The inside is really nice, and although a bit loud, has a very exposed brick modern art type interior.  It's not that big, but if you all ahead for a reservation they could probably accommodate a group.
2. Service: This accounts for much of the low score.  We spent a total of two and a half hours at Town Hall simply because it took two and a half hours for drinks, appetizers, entrees, and desserts to come out.  Very very slow.  
3. Food:
Drinks- Lots of good cocktail options, our waiter recommended the one with Pimms which was delicious.  
Appetizers- The soup of the day (roasted corn soup) was very good, as was the tomato and feta salad.  I also hear great things about the grilled cheese and the tuna tartare.  
Entrees: My dining companions really liked the ribs and sea bass that they ordered.  The rest of us got the fried chicken.  While I loved the sides (smothered greens and grits), the actual fried chicken was not very flavorful or juicy.  A serious let down, especially because it's sort of hard to screw up fried chicken.  
Desserts: These are definitely phenomenal.  I had the pot de creme like everyone recommended which great (basically a good chocolate pudding), and the smores tart was also good, but my favorite was the olive oil cake with the cranberry compote.  

All in all this is a good place for a fancy (albeit expensive dinner).  If you bring some friends you want to talk to for three hours, you'll have a reasonably delicious and fabulous time at Town Hall.
author: Kelley B.

description: this could very well be the most boring restaurant review i've ever written.... i don't like writing bad reviews, but occasionally there's just no way around it. i know a few people who actually like Town Hall, but it just doesn't do anything for me. at all. to summarize: the atmosphere? boring beyond belief. the food? not very exciting. the service? dont remember the waiter. so that's basically it.... really not too much to say about it except i was bored out of my mind here. so bored in fact that i fell asleep under the table. just kidding. you get the picture.
author: Michelle I.

description: Went here this past Friday night with a bunch of friends from work.  One of my friends and I went ahead to stake out a table for the 8 of us and we stood in front of the bar for a few minutes before anyone even acknowledged our presence.  We asked for a table outside under the heaters and found a nice place for our group.  We were immediately provided with a drink list and ordered.  At least 10 minutes went by before we had our drinks and there was next to no one there - it was only 5:10.  No happy hour menu here either - its either tiny little sides like the mac and cheese bites (which were delicious) or 30 bucks for a filet mignon.  No happy hour specials for drinks either and its majorly old people central... Once all our friends were here we had a great time laughing and joking and waiting waiting waiting for our food to arrive.  Drinks were also hugely overpriced for what you received in return. Pass.  Boo hiss.
author: Jamie B.

description: Hip San Francisco blends with homey New England, and the twain meet with mixed results. The dining room, with a long mahogany bar stretching from the entry, is a mix of old-fashioned cream-colored wainscoting, exposed-brick walls with gilt-framed portraits from grandma's parlor, straight-backed wooden chairs, and starburst chandeliers salvaged from 1930s Spanish Harlem. The menu is a fusion of traditional American flavors from both coasts and points in-between. A baby spinach salad garnished with cornmeal-fried oysters or Ahi tuna paired with fried green tomatoes are unusual but excellent starters. Both the grilled rib-eye steak, medium rare as requested, with caramelized onions and potatoes in a flood of red-wine sauce that turned the meant-to-be crispy spuds soggy, and a thick pork chop coated with New Orleans-style tasso and peanuts, suffered from far too much salt, a complaint I've heard from others no matter what they've ordered. (Why can't chefs realize salt isn't necessary at all with all the other seasonings available? I never use it, and never miss it.) The highly-touted butterscotch pot au creme, not as heavenly as I had heard, is so rich it should be shared. Even with reservations, we waited nearly twenty-five minutes before being shown to our table. (Those without reservations may be seated quickly if they don't mind being placed at a large communal table, perfect for those who find socializing with strangers an enjoyable experience, less ideal for couples in search of a romantic interlude.) Our brusque waiter took a while to make his first appearance, and was MIA for most of the meal. All in all, it's an attractive but very noisy dining spot that falls short of its promise.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I had always wondered what Town Hall was on Howard and Fremont as I came off the bridge.  As we were getting together for a birthday celebration, my friend suggested Town Hall and there I was.  As I walked in, I loved the place -- the ambience and atmosphere.  It was already packed with people at the bar and at the waiting area.  We had reservations at 6:30 PM and were promptly seated.  Upon our server's suggestions, we started off with the Broccoli fonduc, Guinness Stout, andouille sausage, crispy potato, and romanesco..  For our main courses, the birthday girl had Grilled rib-eye, charred jalapeno cheddar twice baked potato, broccoli rabe and brown butter garlic sauce, which was awesome and cooked to perfection and very tasty; green garlic ravioli, hedgehog mushrooms, frisee and red wine gastrique, which was also delicious; and Niman Ranch pork osso bucco, black-eyed peas, shaved truffles and herb bread crumbs, which was cooked for 4 hours and melted off the bone.  I normally don't care for black-eye peas, but I devoured everything in my dish.  The dishes were delicious and so was the presentation.  For dessert, we shared a sticky toffee cake with vanilla ice cream and a butterscotch/chocolate pot de crme.  As it was a celebration, a lighted candle was in the butterscotch upon presentation to the birthday girl.  You are in a relaxed atmosphere and not rushed.  We were there for almost 3 hours.  We all agreed the food was good and that the server was very good -- provided great recommendations and very attentive.  The only thing is that it is so noisey you had to talk loud to hear each other.
author: Mary C.

description: This restaurant is like a luxury time machine. The industrial yet plush decor gives you a feel of San Francisco as it was at the turn of the last century with all the comforts of the next. The oysters libretto was light and tintillating, the main movement of the halibut entree was orchestrated well and full of flavor, and the bread pudding rounded up with a comforting sweetness.   But - this is the reason why I am not giving it five stars like many others did: people, they use books to bring you the check. You are supposed to put your money in it and maybe write a few ridiculous phrases on the title page (like, "fab food!") and pass it to the waiter. What a failed attempt at cleverness, and how tacky. It offends both the author and the patron. Sure, they use old and pathetic books cum money holders but it does not add any good manners to the establishment. Also, the $8 promised "best cup of hot chocolate in SF" lost the bet to the $3  Burdick's in Jeremy's tasting competition. These a bit pretentious and awkward touches make me feel like Town Hall aspires to be a sexy bride instead of being the perfectly respectable matron of honor that it is.
author: Elena Z.

description: I just had lunch at Town Hall and it was awful. There was a bug in my water. My salmon was undercooked and I had to send it back. The strawberry shortcake was bad. Two store bought sugar cookies with what tasted like Ready Whip and strawberries with sugar. A pre-schooler could have made that. Although the wait staff were nice, they just weren't good at service. They poured me coffee out of a carafe that was filthy and had what appeared to be chocolate smeared on the outside of it. Very disappoined ;( I will not patronize Town Hall again.
author: Yayne A.

description: Another one of few places in which I could probably eat the entire menu. No really. I finally had to just blindly point at something because the whole damn menu looked amazing. Because that is such, go with a large group, each order something different, and share family style. What did I settle on? Duck with the gingerbread. I don't know how it works, but it does. Their butterscotch pudding thingie is pretty awesome too...so awesome that one of the girls with us, a former stripper from Jersey with a sugar daddy and expensive breasts who had four pints of cadillac margaritas before dinner, knocked a whole glass of zinfandel on me, and forced me to take off my layers of shirts in order to reveal that I was wearing a bra under my tank top. She then went off on how I was so nice and natural looking and that I didn't need a bra...she then pulled over the water guy and asked him (in Spanish) to tell me that I had nice breasts. Yeah, if the pudding wasn't so good, she would've been in big trouble. Nonetheless, I have to go back and try the rest of the entrees that our party didn't order.
author: Zulu Q.

description: I have only been for business lunch days but each experience at Town Hall has been positive.  The food is consistently delicious, the staff attentive... the only drawback is the fact that it is not a reasonably priced lunch ($$$).   I have had the heirloom tomato soup and it was outstanding! Made me change my mind about tomato soup, not kidding.
author: J R.

description: Really Town Hall, you can't make a decent vegetarian entree?  I went to Town Hall recently for a friend's birthday dinner where we had sort of a prix fixe dinner.  They were friendly enough about making a vegetarian entree for me.  However, it turned out to be about 1/2 cup of flavorless quinoa, two steamed carrots and two steamed asparagus stalks.  Pretty underwhelming and not even remotely sufficient for dinner.  The location was lovely (especially since we were in the private room upstairs), and perhaps it's great for meat eaters.  But I can't recommend this place for those who don't eat meat.
author: M. S.

description:
Mark and I went to Town Hall on Thursday night for my Birthday and as always, we just loved it. What I loved most is that I requested a private table not in the middle of the room (as I always do and never get) and when I arrived, they stuck us in this private little corner at the most perfect table. That NEVER happens with us. The service was superb and the food. Well...... let us tell you. We started with the Ahi Tuna and fried green tomatoes which were to die for. The fried green tomatoes were definitely better than the movie!!! I had the peanut & tasso crusted pork chop with buttermilk mashed potatoes and fava beans. It was so scrumptious. Mark had the seafood souffl which he enjoyed as well. Sorry for the lack of description but I was face down in my own food and was too busy enjoying to stop and take a bite of Mark's. But we did have the bacon & cheese fried potatoes which were like an upscale tater tot only MUCH BETTER. Mmmm. 
What I loved about this restaurant is that they had a great selection of wines by the glass. There is nothing worse than seeing a great wine list and than looking at your selections by the glass and seeing BV or Robert Mondavi (No offense to BV or Robert). I was so impressed. It was a great way to celebrate my Birthday.
author: Melissa P.

description:
Check it. First review as an ELITE. I'm not sure who got me into this elite mess, but when I find out... SMACK!

Totally kidding. 

Anyway, Town Hall.

I have been to this restaurant about four times. Twice I have had a decent experience; twice an excellent one. Most recently I took the Brewer there for his birthday dinner and it was very nearly stellar across the board. 

First off, if you haven't at least enjoyed a cocktail or five in the vast, warm dining room with the most beautiful chandeliers ever gracing the ceiling and the best mood music (old-school blues), then you really haven't had the opportunity to truly appreciate the place. It is a lovely, welcoming place that is pleasantly loud, daresay boisterous. 

While the food waxed and waned between pretty darn good and pretty fuckin great on previous visits, this most recent one boasted dishes that satisfied every sense, top to bottom. From the barbecued shrimp in Worcestershire sauce and the pulled pork slider and spare ribs, to the succulent buffalo steak with gnocchi and the slow braised duck in ginger sauce, the warm English toffee cake not to be forgotten. All these dishes rocked in their own individual way. The shrimp were crisp and the sauce they swam in was worthy of being mercilessly mopped up with warm bread that was readily replenished by the saintly bus boy. The pulled pork slider and the spare ribs were glories of all things swine. The only thing missing was bacon, but truth told, I barely missed it. The buffalo was a fabulous change from dreary old steak, though they were a bit stingy on the gnocchis that came astride it. And the duck! Oh glorious duck, cooked so perfectly I might mistake you for that far more truculent meat, pork. The ginger sauce, which may have overpowered a lesser dish, was perfection--the sweetness not too strong and enough spice to keep you guessing. 

The meal was finished off with the toffee cake, recommended by our so sweet waitress. We ordered it dubiously, neither of us sure about this toffee nonsense. What a delight! What a fabulous orgasm of savory sweet deliciousness! 

And above all, we were not scoffed at for bringing an excellent bottle of beer to pop open. Many restaurants poo-poo even the finest and rarest 750s of Belgian ales simply because it is merely beer--still worthy of a $20 corkage, but not worthy enough to be tended to and certainly frowned upon by snooty waitpersons. This is a trend that would not be missed. Our waitress possessed no such snobbery. She graciously opened it for us (though it took her a bit to get around to it.... I think she thought we didn't want to drink a martini AND beer at the same time. Silly lady. 

All in all, Town Hall is very good and worthy of your patronage, if for nothing more than a couple of drinks and an appetizer to enjoy the atmosphere.
author: Sage R.

description: Winding my way up to the second floor to use the little girl's room at Town Hall I reflected that I was indeed enjoying my little drinks and snacks session with my coworkers.  That's a nice feeling.  That all eight of us were able to seat ourselves comfortably at a table, joke about the macabre drink selections (both the Dorothy Parker and The Vicious Circle- homage to a suicidal alcoholic, but also ostensibly an allusion to a lively, fun time in cocktail culture), and pick tiny cornbreads out of their tiny, cast iron corn cob-shaped molds, eat oysters and fork into cheese filled, deep friend squash blossoms right in the comfort of our otherwise barren SOMA workhood is something to be thankful for.  Was my mind blown by the fantastical cocktail creations?  No.  But they were nice, solid libations.  Have I sampled the menu and can I vouch for the quality of the food?  Not really.  Having not eaten much I can't speak at length about the food, but the snacks I did sample were well-prepared and tasty.  Will I go back one day for another drink and snack session?  Sure I would.
author: Chalk A.

description: Cool location, great food. I had the pork osso bucco...very good. Friend had fried chicken, she said it was good, but not the best she ever had. Had a bit of delay between our appetizers and entrees but I was entertaining a group of people from out of state and we had a lot to talk about. I had some sort of pumpkin sticky pudding for dessert. It was a huge portion, could easily have split it. It was very, very good. I will definitely go back.
author: John W.

description: I cannot stress this enough.  Get the bbq shrimp on toast appetizer.  I had it two weeks ago, and my mind remains blown.  End review.
author: Matt M.

description: I was very impressed by this place.  Our server was very knowledgable of the wine list .  Started with the Veal meantballs - a must for everyone!  The duck confit and steak were also great, I plan on going back for the fried chicken
author: jake n.

description: Great spot, good service, but very pricey considering the bite sized portions. The one redeeming quality the waiter suggested I try Pliny the Elder, which has since become one of my favs.
author: Bill K.

description: This place is super close to my job which counts.  We had no reservation on a Saturday night and walked over after trying to go to the Salt House, which was too crowded.  At the bar we sat next to some friendly tourists.  Fast, friendly service led us to trying the bartenders favorite dishes.  The sauce for the BBQ shrimp was tasty.  I ate way too much super fresh bread trying to savor the sauce.  The veal meatballs were cooked perfectly, crispy on the outside and still a little rare in the middle.  After this we were full but had already ordered the sashimi.  It was fresh and I would definitely have it again but maybe in the summer.  The glasses of wine we had were expensive and not very impressive.  The Americano coffees were delicious and went awesome with the surprise butterscotch/chocolate pudding the bartender brought out for my birthday.  For 3 appetizers it was expensive but delightful.  It was more like a full dinner.
author: erin k.

description: okay, had to bump the stars for the free ribs, sausage, cole slaw all to promote their rib take-out for lunch for the soma and financial district folk.  so, not only did i start my 1/2 day fridays at work...but i get to have a rib, some slaw, and iced tea for FREE?  my stars must've been aligned!
author: Marjie T.

description: American food done right.  This restaurant picks up were Ella's left off and carries the torch with aplomb. The food is exquisite, flavors robust and savory, and Town Hall might just represent the apotheosis of American cuisine.  Unswayed by the notion that abundance can stand in for quality, the portions are manageable in size, but every bite rewards you with a sophistication rarely seen in classical American fare.  Yes, try the shrimp.  The duck is amazing as a main course as well. The place should seethe loud downtown post-work investment banker glam, but despite the business casual attire, the unpretentious atmosphere and a genuinely friendly staff seem unfazed by daunting crowds of eager clients.  Amazingly, reservations are fulfilled very near the appointed hour and they do a pretty good job of accommodating walk-ins.  Have a drink on the patio and get your taste buds ready.  It's worth it.
author: Gabriel S.

description: Really awesome Fat Tuesday Dinner buffet complete with unlimited alcoholic beverages. The etouffe, friend chicken, ribs and links were great. The jambalaya was decent. The oysters were just ehhh but overall, the experience was a whole lot of fun. The servers and other help were very obviously frantic because of the size of the crowd so additional staff would have made a difference for the customers who, like me, must've felt like they were just getting shoved left and right.
author: Vincent L.

description: I give this restaurant a 3.5. Service by far was excellent. Appetizers came out in a timely fashion however I wasn't too pleased with the 40 minute wait for the main course. The hamachi sashimi appetizer was fresh and had an hint of jalapeno- that I liked but if your not a fan of the slight essence of jalapeno then I'd avoid this dish.  The rib-eye steak with the croquettes was quite tasty, the wonderful reduction that it was sitting in really brought the whole dish together with the croquettes and broccolini. As for dessert, we had the butterscotch pot de creme as well their  hot chocolate since they claim to have the "best "San Francisco hot chocolate. I feel their claim to having the best hot chocolate is a bit of an overstatement. It was good but a bit heavy, it was served luke warm which I think is the idea but thought that it would be better hot. The butterscotch pot de creme was quite good once you dipped into the chocolate type mouse at the bottom with your toffee chips however after the meal that we had I could barely eat a couple of spoonfuls. The atmosphere is a bit noisy, but it is definitely a fun place to go with friends. The great service,good, fun, hearty meal is what gets the points.
author: christine t.

description: Town hall has a small but hopping bar that seemed to be filled with an after-work crowd. The menu is interesting and eclectic in ingredients; but not in culinary style. The service was excellent. The food was prepared well and tasted great.
author: Patrick L.

description:
So my husband and I planned a date night last Saturday but were simply exhausted so we said....ahhh....let's just go out on Sunday night. Ya right?!!? Almost every good restaurant in SF is actually closed on Sunday! We were in awe! 
Well. the only place we did find open on a Sunday night was Town Hall. That definitely a positive! 
I ordered the shrimp app and my husband ordered the scallops. Both of these dishes were smothered in sauces. It was actually strange because I have never been served a dish other than pasta where the sauce outweighs the main item on the dish. The sauces were rather heavy and salty. If you love simple items soaked in sauce then this is a place for you. For us, it was too much over the top.Perhaps it is the style of cooking that you either love or hate. 
For the main course, I ordered the tri tip (I think that what it was) because I love beef. It was marinated which made it quite flavorful but the veggies seemed like they were saturated in the same marinade, which made them really salty. My husband had the salmon and it was nothing special about it. 
Atmosphere was a little rowdy - another thing you either love or hate. perhaps that is why they call ti town hall... 
Bottom line - not memorable. i would not crave going back. 
Sorry peeps of Town Hall but its the truth.
author: Caroline K.

description: Service was slow, Food was OK but the Waitress was good. She gave us honest information and what not to get, which is good but then when she tells you what is good, it only leaves you with about 2-3 items in each category to choose from. I ordered the Osso Bucco, it was full of fat and had a small amount of dry meat. The creamy grits underneath were the best part. Others at our table had the ribs (very dry), the Sole (ok but made the person's stomach upset for the rest of the night) and the Buttermilk Fried Chicken (it was ok). I've eaten at many places and feel that for my money, you could find better food elsewhere. Oh, the one saving grace was Faith's Warm Ham and Cheese...That was worth coming back for, but only for that.
author: Devin F.

description: If I had to pick, I'd say Town Hall is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  I like everything about it.  Location is close to home.  Atmosphere is great.  Staff is friendly and helpful.  Drinks are unique and pack a punch and although not cheap, are not crazy expensive.  I could have a meal of just the appetizers (the toast with egg and jalapeno cream is my favorite, oysters are great, tuna, mmmm...).  The entrees are worth it, creative, very tasty and make good use of local and seasonal ingredients.  Then there are the desserts - the pot de creme is a feat of greatness on its own.  My husband and I went there last night for this very reason, pot de creme and a cocktail.  Sitting outside under a heatlamp on the patio on a chilly Thursday evening.  Perfection.  Worth every penny every time.
author: Margaret S.

description: As I am never on the forefront of anything, I am now finally going to offer my review of Town Hall.  We had a very early reservation, 5:45, and were seated at 5:35, when we arrived.  It is very true that this place can get pretty loud, and the tables are fairly close together.  We had a great server, and everything we ordered came out in good timing.  We started with the mixed greens, pear, and goat cheese salad (sooo delish, with a honey thyme vinaigrette), and an absolutely wonderful tuna tartare (i usually shy away from tuna tartare because its done almost everywhere, but this version, with fried green tomatoes, was sooo delicate and tasty).  We also had the ribeye (very large portion, cooked a little more than the requested medium rare, served with these cheesy bacony tater tots and some slightly undercooked haricot verts) and the fried chicken (apparently encrusted with panko, nice twist, served with mashed potatoes and white corn).  Both dishes were great.  We ended with the sticky toffee cake, which was to die for.  The only thing that could make it better is a larger scoop of ice cream.  All and all, Town Hall is a reasonably priced, chic, casual dining experience.  Comfortable food, comfortable service.
author: Emily X.

description: i give this 5 starts for their fried chicken.  best fried chicken ever.  or as my friend sue would say....fry cheeken.  Mmmmmm.  oh and the little corn bread dressed up as little pieces of corn.  Cute!
author: Ann F.

description: I usually love Town Hall BBQ, but it tastes like they changed the recipe to their slaw this year. Now you get a choice: mild or spicy slaw. I unfortunately got the mild slaw on my fried chicken sandwich and was very disappointed. There wasn't a choice last year so I didn't ask for spicy slaw. Now I am afraid to get the chicken sando again with spicy slaw and still be disappointed. Change it back! I don't mind paying the $8 for a yummy fried chicken sandwich, but don't disappoint. Also, your chips used to be better; what happened? Did someone complain about the seasoning or did you forget to add the seasoning the second day you had the BBQ open this year?  I hope you change back to your old ways soon. I will wait until the office lunch crew tells me that you have improved before going there again.
author: Michelle M.

description: What's with all the hype?  The food here is definitely overpriced considering what you get.  The only plate that was memorable were the scallops w/barley in beer broth, but even that didn't blow me away at first.  After about 15 bites, this dish grew on me, but now that I've discovered the Cafe Majestic in Pac Heights, I will be going there to satisfy any scallops cravings.
author: Helen K.

description: Town Hall Restaurant at 342 Howard St. in San Francisco is seriously overrated.  Last night my cousin and I went there for a nice birthday dinner and the menu looked lovely.  The dishes sounded great and we knew the prices were going to run around $25 - $30 per entree.  One of the entrees ordered was the Liberty Duck Breast, with hibiscus golden syrup, red cabbage marmelade and chestnut puree for $28.  Yum, we were hungry and this restaurant is known for having good food.  It arrived - we stared at the big white bowl and then at each other... where was the food?  Seriously - the poor little fowl must have been one of the sparrows snagged from a tree near by - tiny tiny little drumstick and almost no body whatsoever - it could not have been more than two bites total - for $28!  We ended up having a good laugh, ordered more bread and vowed not to return.  Methinks Town Hall is getting just a bit too big for its britches.
author: Margaret S.

description:
i walked in with high expectations because of the yelp reviews and it was in eater sf's top 38.  unfortunately, it was very disappointing.  the scallops, fried chicken, and beignets all were below average.  throw in a glass of wine and the bill came out to $96 for 2 people, without a single above average dish.  a few blocks away you have Zare at the Fly Trap, One Market, and some other great restaurants.

go save your money and go somewhere else.
author: Jay M.

description: like toro e. i cannot give a full review since we only sat at the bar and ordered desserts. this was our third and final stop in checking out venues for our company holiday party. we got here around 2:30 pm when they pretty much close down to get ready for dinner. they do provide a very limited menu for those in between hours. i love the red running all throughout and LOVE LOVE LOVE the cool modern looking chandeliers. where can i get one of those? my coworker knew one of the owners, doug,  who was warm and friendly and such a gracious host! the private dining upstairs is nice and simple (fits up to 40) hear the room is used quite frequently for meetings, birthday's, bachelorette parties, etc. the CARAMEL CHOCOLATE BUTTERSCOTCH POT DE CREME was huge and good. i would have enjoyed it more if it was ALL chocolate! the STRAWBERRY SHORTCAKE was just okay for me...i think i can make it better. look forward to having a real meal here. they're planning to open a sister restaurant soon!
author: Jane Y.

description: Solid consistent food, good service.  Been there about 6 times over the past 5 years and it's always been great.  A bit loud at times but that's what your there for.  good atmosphere for friends.
author: jimmy c.

description: i love everything about town hall from the ambience to the space to of course, the food!!  i try to get short ribs wherever i go, and the ones here were cooked just right!  you must save room for dessert, b/c the sticky toffee cake was to die for!  the dining room is pretty noisy, so it's probably not the best place to go on a first date.
author: Helen T.

description: Town Hall is one of those spaces that other restaurateurs kick themselves about and think, "Now why didn't I think of opening something like this HERE!"  Just outside financial district and adjacent to the Greyhound bus station, Town Hall is packed every day by 5pm.  All the suits and city officials make this their stopping ground before heading out and one can usually spot the Mayor--Willie or Gavin, or both.  The bar is always filled with activity and the ideal spot to watch all the people check in.  The food is simple and pretty good, but watch out for those mussels-- sometimes they come out undercooked or of poor quality (shells not opened?  send them back!). The staff is attentive, but certain bartenders with personality of door-knobs sure can dull your experience at this otherwise happening spot.  Ask for Doug Washington, he is the resident charmer and partner--always ready to flash that smile and shake your hand.
author: Jaena G.

description: Came here for a business lunch and lunches on the expense account are always nice. I was super excited to come here since I'd heard such good things about the place. I started by splitting the tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes. It was really tasty, especially the fried green tomatoes. It's hard to find them on a menu in the Bay Area and I'm a big fan of them. Then I had the rabbit and crawfish ettouffee which was really good but I had a bit of my friend's meatloaf which was AMAZING. It's so amazing that three days later I'm still thinking about it. I really want to go back and gorge on the meatloaf and check out their desserts which unfortunately we didn't have time to get dessert. One thing I will say as lovely and beautiful and inviting as the space is the acoustics are TERRIBLE. It's literally a wall of sound when you sit down and I even had trouble hearing the people across the table from me. If you're going to go for business maybe shoot for a an off peak time.
author: Cathy T.

description:
town hall was decent and i will definitely go back. the bf and i went there on a saturday night without reservations and got sat right away in the nicely heated patio. trust when i say nicely heated. i'm from LA, so anything below 75 degrees is met with my equally icy stare and some very dramatic shivers. granted we were there earlier than most people eat on a saturday night (around 7 PM) but the pation didn't fill up until we were leaving a couple hours later. the shared table for non reservationers was also pretty empty when we got there.

as for the food, we pretty much pigged out. bottle of wine from their "firesale!" was good and decently priced. we split the tuna tartare with fried green tomatoes and their bbq shrimp app. the tartare was pretty decent but i didn't like the fried green tomatoes for some reason. the breading kept sliding off of them and i prefer them to be cooked a little more. the bbq shrimp confused me. it came looking like something that i didn't think i would lie with all that gravy on it but it tasted phenomenal. the shrimp were slightly overcooked and a little chewy but the flavors were great. i had a scallops dish with butternut squash puree and brussel srouts. it was pretty super. the bf kept trying to take some and i had to fend him off with my fork. although he loved his peanut crusted pork chop and our forkful trades were well received on both ends. we finished the meal with a fruit crumble of some sort. i can't remember because the wine was empty at this point, but i do remember we polished it off. the desserts listed on the website were not the ones we had a choice of that night but it was roughly the same number of options and variation of flavors.

i think we spent around $160 - $170, which i don't consider to be too high for a nicer restaurant with a bottle of wine, two apps, two entrees, and a dessert. i'll definitely go back for more of that shrimp and the scallops!
author: marisa g.

description:
upon walking in the door and seeing the menu i thought this is going to be special
i was taking my team to lunch for the holidays
we were seated and allowed the horrible service to begin
thanks for the water and bread but wait !!! are you coming back?
we sat and waited and then after 15 minutes our server was quick to get to ordering and not so fond of questions.
tsk tsk ...
for the price of the food i expect more
everything was delicious
love those biscuits
but the chocolate/butterscotch pudding - c'mon !!  that is one step up from a jello snack pak.  not worth 8 bucks
author: MMC I.

description: I went there last weekend after a play, and it was my first time. We ordered three appetizers. The BBQ shrimp w/ 1' inch piece of toasted bread, that was DELICIOUS. I will order two of those on my next visit. Then we had the tuna tartare that was good, would have liked more tuna, and last we had the beet salad, that was OK, I don't think I would order that again.  I had the scallops with brussel sprouts. THat  dish was OK. I did try my dining companion's dish, the fried chicken. I thought that the chicken needed more seasoning, salt or pepper, maybe? I did try the butter scotch dessert everyone's raved about, The was OK, in my opinion. Will go back for more BBQ shrimp. I got the recipe for that dish. Can't wait to make at home! The only thing I didn't like was the layout of the restaurant. It's very narrow and the doors were open the night I was there so it got cold inside. And the tables are really close to each other.
author: lola s.

description: We went on a Monday night at 9pm. It wasn't crowded but there were people there. We shared the Tuna Tartare starter which was wonderful. It would be called poke with fried green tomatoes in Hawaii. Spicy. We had the Peanut Tasso crusted pork chop served with collared greens, squash and pomegranate seeds. A lovely combination of flavors. For desert Butterscotch & Chocolate Pot de Creme topped with butter crunch. Silky, creamy and divine. Very rich. All in all a most enjoyable evening. They even had little recipe cards by the entrance for some of their starters. Now I can try to make the Tuna Tartare at home. Yummy.
author: Suzanne S.

description: Great Place!!!!. We were visting from southern cal and we loved Town Hall. Great vibe inside and the food was awesome. Service was outstanding and when my wife had to go feed our small infant daughter they gave her a private room and brought her a drink . Little things like this make all the difference for us.Everything we ordered was delcious. Fried chicken was sooo tasty. We will be back for sure!
author: Evan M.

description: This place is simply phenomenal all the way around.  Enough said.
author: Michael S.

description: Went for dinner last night, it was average.  The service and wine were both great so neither of those things got in the way of the experience.  The appetizer list is really creative and we should have made our meal out of 3-4 of those.  Instead we tried some main dishes that were seasoned really well, but bwere overcooked.  There's really nothing worse than $30 dried out pork.  I just think that as far as the main courses, I've seen it all somewhere else before.  If I go back, I'd stick to the top 1/2 of the menu to get a good sampling of starters.
author: Netsirk P.

description: One of our favorite dinner spots in the neighborhood. Fantastic wine list, amazing flavor profiles sometimes in the form of very simple concepts. The BBQ shrimp app is to die for. I came this close to licking the plate last time we ordered it.
author: John B.

description: About a year ago we had dined at town hall a few times and loved it (a thumbs up/ 5 stars). We hadn't been back since as we're hardly in those neck of the woods but we went there recently for dinner. We were disappointed and surprised at the changes. Our cocktails were too sweet, the salad was gritty, and the squid ink risotto (sigh!). The squid did not seem to be fresh and the rice was underdone. The catfish dirty rice entree was better but hardly redeeming. We ordered dessert - pot de creme - which was nice. We asked our server if the chef had changed in the last year and the answer was yes. We shared our thoughts about our meal and she was warm and obliging. She comped a couple of items for us which we had not anticipated. We would give town hall another try down the road but hope it will be much better next time.
author: Missy D.

description: When this place first opened, it was fresh and different. It feels really stale and contrived now. The last two times I've been --- both times for dinner -- the hostess was really bitchy. Ditto when we called beforehand to ask if it was ok to add one more person to our party of 8. She didn't hesitate and said No. Our party ended up only being 5 people. When we requested a different seat (they put us by the back kitchen door), the response was curt and exasperated. Attitude, again was that frigid, United airlines hostess chill. I guess this restaurant has gotten used to people coming and spending over $500 and ordering three bottles of $87.00 wine. Let's all remember that this is a competitive restaurant town and we don't have to accept haughty hostesses or servers. The food? Still good, but with the service, it sometimes doesnt make a difference.
author: Etienne D.

description: Creamy butternut squash soup, excellent trout, and the best hot chocolate I have ever had in my life.  More like melted chocolate with a little cream.  Too much to have on your own, but a good shared item.  Service was excellent, amibience was loud and busy.   My dinner companions had fried chicken and biscuits, a rabbit dish, and the risotto, which they all agreed were very tasty.
author: Lea H.

description: sumptuous but casual atmosphere meets some of the best fried chicken in town. the best place at 9:15 on a tuesday to get instant reservations and to enjoy ahi tartare with fried green tomatoes and some kind of wicked jalapeno reduction/sauce, a decadent croque madame-stylee thingy, and a most excellent fried chicken. you know it's good when i just accidentally mentioned the fried chicken twice in a paragraph.
author: Winter R.

description:
My family and I went to Town Hall which I haven't been to in over a year since I did not really enjoy my last visit. The food was not memorable and the volume level in the restaurant made it difficult to have a conversation without yelling. Well my brother really wanted to check it out so we agreed. I am glad that we did. The food was excellent and there were a few that I need to mention. For a starter, Faith's warm ham and cheese toast with poached egg was delicious! Not something you will normally find on a dinner menu and the waiter recommended it and I am glad we tried it. Unexpected and hit the spot. On the mains, I had the bay scallops with squash risotto which was cooked perfectly. My boyfriend laughed and thought I was going to lick the bowl! He had the cod which was also very good. We ordered 3 desserts and the 2 that stood out were the warm beignets (so light and tasty) and the chocolate mousse bomb - sinful! 

The only thing that was strange was that on the starters, they apparently forgot to put in one of our orders and we had to ask for it. Then when it was brought out, there was no apology at all even though everyone had almost already finished theirs. This was a bit annoying but as the night went on soon faded as a slight misstep.

The acoustics in the restaurant are still bad, and the bathrooms a bit of a trek (up 2 flights of stairs), but the food and ambience are worth a visit. I will be back.
author: M S.

description: great little place. fun, good food. on the noisy side of life. butterscotch chocolate pot de creme is a great end to any meal. the books are  a cute touch.
author: heather m.

description: A little disappointing, I have to say. Maybe because this place is so hyped up, maybe because its expensive, maybe because it has this ultra trendy ambiance, whatever it is, I expected the food to taste better then it did. It definitely wasn't bad, but it wasn't great either. I got the fried chicken with mashed potatoes and the chicken was good/very good, the potatoes a little bland. I tried a few of the other dishes and they were good too....but I thought the pork osso bucco was kind of flavorless. Service wasn't overly solicitous (good) but the staff also didn't seem that knowledgeable on the dishes (bad).
author: Caedmon P.

description: Definitely in my top 5 restaurants, if not #1.  I have been going to Town Hall since it opened and have had consistently wonderful food and great service.  Last night was no exception, but I felt I needed to give the place some props for my new favorite dish which I had last night.  Now normally, this place is known for its Duck (Ze Duck?!, With this stock portfolio?) and Pork which are signature items on the menu and are always there.  I usually order one or the other and that's just fine for me.  Until now.  Last night I ordered a little piece of fried heaven, otherwise known as the buttermilk fried chicken.  It was served over Au gratin potatoes with chard, and it was pretty much perfection on a plate.  Its my new fav, and I would highly recommend it to anyone especially if you haven't had some good fried chicken in a while.  Special thanks to Raegan, our server, who managed to convince me to stray from my usual order.  Fan-tas-tic!
author: Barrett F.

description: Not bad considering we didn't have reservations and had a big party. They seated us within 15 minutes. The food was not super or anything special but it was good. I guess it's hard for me to consider any American food serving joint to be excellent. The service was excellent though, the atmosphere felt chic but not pretentious. I would go back.
author: Hmmm W.

description: A very nice restaurant, but somehow none of us found it extraordinary. Seating took a while. I had the polenta and it was excellent. The others had hallibut, swordfish and ribs and they found it just to be ok. We tried as well the cornbread and the pot du creme which was both less exciting than some of the reviews had indicated.
author: Bettina O.

description:
We had dinner here Saturday 11/28 and I was somewhat disappointed, having had a much better experience here about a year ago.  Our party of six (4 adults and a 9 and 11 yr old) ordered:

The biscuits, ham, and pepper jam - very good

BBQ shrimp - pretty tasty, but you must love Worcestershire, because basically the sauce tastes like thickened Lea & Perrins.

Jambalaya - not good.  My husband ordered it but would not eat it.  I tasted it, thought it too tomatoey and spiced in an unappealing way.  Nothing like any jambalaya I've eaten in New Orleans.

Pork chop - the chop itself was very tasty and cooked just right.  My husband thought the peanut/tasso crust was unnecessary and the pomegranate was just strange.
