Sea bass - good.  The fish was cooked properly and the clam/bean/broth that it came with was good as well.  It was topped with a piquillo pepper which, according to the menu, was supposed to be stuffed, but the stuffing must have been made of a massless, colorless, flavorless substance, because I couldn't find it.  An all right dish, but not memorable.

Jalapeno corn bread - very good, and rich

Dorothy Parker cocktail - yum.  The best part of my evening.

Also ordered, but not tasted by me were the bay scallops, the ham/cheese/egg toast, and the fried chicken.  The consumers of these dishes seemed reasonably satisfied, but I didn't hear any raves.

We didn't order any desserts (although I had originally planned to) because we ran out of stomach capacity and patience before dessert-ordering time rolled around.

The worst part of the evening was that our service was not very good.  Our waitress was reasonably nice but absent most of the time.  She may have been avoiding our table because our entrees took a very long time - they arrived AN HOUR AND A HALF after we were seated.  Finally a service person (not our waitress) arrived at our table with a dish of macaroni and cheese (very tasty but exceedingly rich) which was intended to tide us over due to the long delay.  That was a nice gesture, but after the appetizers and bread (which was very good BTW), the last thing we really needed was more food to spoil our entrees.  I would rather they had comped something we'd actually ordered, or might like later, like desserts or coffees.  Also, neither the macaroni deliverer nor our waitress (when she reappeared at the end of the meal) offered any sort of explanation for the delay or much of an apology (the waitress tossed out a half-hearted "Sorry for the wait" as she picked up our check).  One of the odd things about the poor service was that we were actually the first people seated in the restaurant that evening, so it wasn't even particularly busy for the first 45 minutes or so.  Perhaps the fact that we did not order any wine (we had had too much for the 3 days previous) made us lower priority customers.  However, on my previous visit I got great service with just 2 adults and 2 kids, and only wine by the glass ordered.

It seems like it is a bit of a crap shoot to dine here - it might be great, or really disappointing.  I was a little embarrassed, and would not bring guests here again.  My general feeling is that this place has slipped.  It seems a lot of the food is either not very interesting or includes combinations that don't really work.  Also, some of the best tasting dishes were obviously loaded with salt and fat.  It's not that hard to make food taste good when you put lots of fat in it, so I don't find these types of dishes all that impressive.

I might give this place another chance someday, but not before I get to lots of other places I want to try/return to.  There are plenty of places in the city where your odds of a good experience are better than 50/50.
author: Jo A.

description: A-OK.  Thats how I would characterize Town Hall.  I've been here 3/4 times, but yet to call it my favorite neighborhood restaurant.  Its a beautiful space and the staff has always been courteous when I've visited.  The menu with a southern flavor looks appetizing and draws one in, but the food has not always been consistent.  The resto is always packed, and it strikes me as the place one would go when one stays at a hotel (i.e., business travellers), just because hotel food reeks :-)  So not particularly a destination in my mind for a special occasion etc.  Last had the Pork Chop.  It was well prepared, but the accoutrements that accompanied the chop on the plate were heavily salted.  So not the most pleasant meal by any means, and meal seemed 'heavy'.  Another appetizer we ordered was also heavily salted.  I peeked in the kitchen while walking by and the pace was frantic..  it seems like an issue of quality control of the meals leaving the kitchen?  Unsure and hope its looked into..  I would feel sick if I ate here often enough with that nauseating feeling one gets with consuming  'heavy' unhealthy food.  Its been at least a week and I can still taste that last meal in my mouth.. ack ack..  I'll probably pass on a subsequent visit..
author: Leroy R.

description: One of my favoriet restaurants in the city.  I've been here five or six times.  Had one very dissapointing meal.  DEFINITELY get the friend chicken if you like that sort of thing, it's fantastic, so are the brussels sprouts and the jalapeno cornbread.  The service is ALWAYS fantastic as well.
author: Debbie M.

description: This is one of my new favorite restuarants in the city.  Yeah their tables aren't covered with white table cloths or occupied buy uber rich people but if you want to go somewhere fun with friends and have a non-romantic evening then this is your place.  I have been telling all my fat friends to give this place a try.  I know this isn't a popular restuarant on yelp or with the michelin guide but some of the recommendations I have conjured from yelp including front porch and oola was a crap.  But I do like the Cheesecake Factory (don't de-fan me please) which I know 85% of yelp probably hate because they are a chain.  Therefore it is my turn to defend one of the underdogs.  The tuna ahi tartar with fried green tomatoes and BBQ shrimp appetizers were awesome.  The stuff pork chop with spicy rice was also very good.  The best dish I tried was the swordfish.  Usually this fish eats like steak.  But this fish was light and flakey.  Words couldn't describe it.  The only negative reflection I had of the dishes were the sauces for the BBQ shrimp and pork chop were on the salty side.  But the sticky toffee cake made up for it.  Bascially I am justifying eating here by comparing the price you pay for food here compared to Houstons on Embarcadero and Francisco.  $20-$30/dish at both resturants but one is a chain and the other is authentic SF cuisine.  Trust me people I eat alot.
author: Fatty A.

description: I have been to Town Hall about 6 times now - generally I won't review a restaurant unless I have been there at least a couple of times - and have had somewhat varying experiences, especially on service, which does seem to have gone downhill of late, but all in all, I still really like this place.  I don't know too many places in the city that have a wine list like they do (unusually, varied from around the world, and not out of this world spendy) and their location is cool - love that big turn of century loft feel and I especially like it at lunch when it is sunny and buzzing in the main room.  Their meats I think are their high point - the ribeye they have done, the skirt steak, they seem to excel at those dishes and at fish.  I don't know that I have ever had a bad fish there.  That being said, this is not food for super subtlety and maybe at the price point people are expecting fancy, complex dishes, but that is not really how the brother chefs that run this place roll. I get what they are doing in a way that if you are not an east coaster you might not as it is sort of anti-precious food.  They do big bold, hearty food and if you don't like that, you might call the food salty, saucy etc. They have a great private room upstairs for events, the communal table at the bar is a particularly cool place to hang and I like the small patio they have as well.  The atmosphere is great and the bartenders friendly and laid back - there really is way more to love about this place rather than hate.  Not a perfect spot, but one that is unique in SF, and got a chic, urban feel and vision that is fun to drop in on.  Try it yourself with an open mind, but do expect to spend some $$ for the privilege...
author: Kirsten M.

description: There seems to be a history of really bad reviews for this place, but I really enjoyed my experience at town hall.  We went later, so maybe that is why it wasn't that loud.  Our waitress didn't do very much and the service itself was OK, but it wasn't terrible, I have certainly had worse.  The food was really good.  There have been few memorable meals for me in SF, and this one is one that I liked a lot.  I had the tuna tartare and I thought it was great.  I then had the rainbow trout, which was good, but wasn't great.  IT was totally overpowered by the slab of bacon covering it, but it was still pretty good.  My husband had the trio of pork and I thought that was great.  The sticky toffee cake was also fantastic.  This is one menu were I was actually torn between several of the choices.  Typically I see one item and immediately I am drawn to that one.  I struggled with this menu.  I will go back, atmosphere was old barn house feel.  I really liked the whole experience.
author: Jaime C.

description:
this place is ridiculously overpriced for the type of food it serves.  it is especially a rip off because the food isn't even good.

everything was overly salty... the chilled asparagus soup w/ shrimp ceviche was salty (the shrimp was especially salty), the crawfish etouffee was so salty that the salt was overpowering... and even the butter was really salty that comes with the bread!  the flavors otherwise were good so i think if they put less salt in everything, they might come closer to making the meal worth the money (still overpriced... but closer).

My boyfriend got the ny strip and it was basically all fat and poorly cooked (the steak was cold when he got it and tough).  he only ended up eating half of it.

The service was fine but for some reason it took them an hour to get our food out when it wasn't all that busy.
author: jean m.

description: My friends and I enjoyed an early dinner here before going to see 'Wicked' at the Orpheum.  Oh. My. God.  The food here was amazing -- especially the tuna tartare, which was so friggin' good we had to order another.  A few of us started off with the oysters, which were truly unbelievable. I can honestly say that I've never, in all my life, tasted oysters that good.  One of my friends had the ham and egg on toast thingy, which was so delicious, all of us were taking bites off of her plate.  The service was excellent - our waiter was friendly, knowledgeable, and not bad looking.  It was a bit pricey, but definitely worth it.  I'm already looking forward to a return visit.
author: Heather C.

description: Had an absolutely wonderful annivesary dinner last night.  We were seated promply and the service was first rate.  The drinks, food and wine were also wonderful.  Before leaving for our drive back to Walnut Creek we ordered coffiee and were brought a nice french press with enough for the two of us.  As we usually do, we asked for  refill and were promptly brought another pot.  Charge for coffee service is $8.00 for two.  However here is where they got greedy.  They charged us an additional $8.00 for the refill....$16.00 for coffee for two.  This is after drinks, wine, starters, entrees and dessert.  I saw nothing on the menu warning of of this addional charge nor did our waitperson forewarn us.  Nothing that ruined a really enjoyable evening, but the bad taste lingers,.
author: Harvey T.

description: Went to Town Hall after hearing great things about it. Overall, I was a little disappointed. The food was neither amazing nor memorable. The service was great, but it was extremely noisy. I will not be going back.
author: Benjamin B.

description: I love Town Hall restaurant but beware...twice they did NOT award my 100 dining points when I booked my reservation through Open Table.  I called and e-mailed the restaurant to inquire but they never responded.
author: Deborah M.

description: The food was fabulous, the ambience was great BUT the waiter so obviously was looking for a quick turnover.  Too bad too because I'm usually a very good tipper!
author: Misti L.

description: town hall is by far one of my favorite restaurants in SF. there's already 200+ reviews of this restaurant so no need to elaborate further. this fine dining establishment definitely lives up to its hype.
author: Amy H.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants. I love their biscuits and ham, I also like their amazing steaks. They tend to have good desserts too, however they tend to change their dessert menu often. This is a great restaurant that I would recommend to anyone.
author: jackson s.

description: This has got to be by far my favorite San Francisco restaurant. When people ask me where to go for a nice dinner, I always recommend Town Hall. The inside is really nice with all the old bricks and the food is fantastic.  Whether you're just having apps at the bar or a sit down dinner with a honey, or a big celebration with friends,  I love, love LOVE it there!!!
author: elena r.

description: Splendid!  Everything from the service to the background blues music to the smoked ribs was excellent.
author: Mike G.

description: This place is good but not the second coming.  They make the drinks fresh, no mixes.  The food is decent.  The BBQ shrimp are not Prudhomme quality but if you don't know better they're o.k. The pecan/tasso pork chop is good but if it weren't for the smokiness of the tasso it would be your regular grilled pork chop.  The ribeye w/crispy potatoes is a misnomer since the potatoes are usually in the gravy which makes them soggy.  The duck dish is just bad.  Overseasoned is as bad as underseasoned.  The butterscotch/choc pot de creme (it's pudding people) is good.  The cheesecake was o.k., marred by the crust which wasn't.  The server steered me away from the brownie saying it was too sweet.  When the servers say the pudding is the place's best dessert, I am not impressed.
author: danielle b.

description: i think Town Hall is in my Top 3 favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  appetizer with the eggs and the toast and the jalapeno cream.  damn it's good.  this restaurant just never disappoints.
author: a g.

description: Went there recently, because a friend had given us a gift certificate. We had heard alot of buzz so we went and checked it out. i looked on yelp and didnt see as many good reviews as i thought i would. i figured i have a gift certificate, i might as well give it a try... and im really glad i did. alot of people on yelp knocked the service, our waiter was great! he recommended good food options and helped us pick a nice bottle of wine to start with. Every seat in the place was taken, and i didnt find it overly loud at all. maybe i just had a good seat, but i dont see what everyone is talking about. i could hear the waiter and my date just fine. the place isnt perfect, its alittle out of my price range for a usual dinner spot, so ill save it for more special occasions. props for having squash blossoms on the menu though! i love those! and the egg, toast, jalapeno dealio is beyond fantasitc! this is a place i will go to again. it would be fun to take people here from out of town.
author: clint e.

description: I showed up at 11:55 am for my Noon reservation.  I was instantly impressed with the ambiance and decor.  For some reason I felt a little like I was in the Napa Valley.  My client had not arrived yet.  At 12:10 pm I was feeling a little nervous that she still had not materialized.  The host and hostess were extremely gracious and went out of their way to make me feel comfortable.  They offered me a glass of champagne.  When 12:30 hit and my client still had not arrived, I asked to be seated.  They were kind enough to make every effort not to give away my table.  After a few more minutes my client arrived, apologized, and we ordered.  To start off, I ordered the tuna tartar with fried green tomatoes.  The tuna was perfectly seasoned, and the tomatoes were not greasy in the least.   For the main course I had the pork dish.  It came with tasty little brussels sprouts, with just a touch of a maple glaze, as well as small cubes of cooked apple and potato.  The client loved her meal.  I spent about $75 including tax and tip.  I can't wait to return to Town Hall!  It might be my new favorite place.  Next time I will try a dessert!
author: Kandi K.

description: Came here for dinner last night with the BF.  Literally came in 5min before the restaurant closed.  We were shooed to the bar which was fine with us. I'd rather be there with the bartender than servers disappearing to do their sidework. We found out that the kitchen was closing soon and the manager had to check with the kitchen to make sure we could still order.  The service was great... the food however subpar.  There was definitely sand and grit in the frisee salad.  The hamachi sashimi was slimy and smelled quite fishy, but the accompanied herb salad was great. My veal meatballs were really salty and the brown gravy looked and tasted like it was made out of the McCormick's Brown gravy seasoning packet.  We came here because an friend recommended the fried chicken here.  My BF had it and it was not all that great.  Meat was juicy but the exterior could have used another coating of batter to make it more crisp.  If we're going to eat fried chicken we want it to be finger lickin good. Beautiful space, excellent service, food is run of the mill.  Maybe it's because we came so late...
author: H V.

description: I like the atmosphere and the food.  Everything on the menu is tempting, which makes it hard to decide.  My only complaint is that the short ribs were dry.  The wait staff is very friendly, in fact my friend fell in love with every single waitress there.
author: LT B.

description: Nice restaurant and as expected in SF, it was pricey but well worth it. I've been there twice and the food was excellent both times. Love the pork chop dish. Sat at the bar for lunch this time and Armondo, the bartender took good care of us. He topped my wine glass and offered a taste of the Rose. And best of all, he made us laugh... Actually, I think we made him laugh and then he offered more wine. It seems friendliness goes a long way...
author: Michelle R.

description: I've been twice and I love it! I love the oysters on the half shell! They are so fresh and never gritty. Plus, they have a great sauce that you put on the oysters. The fondue is great and so is the duck! Fabulous!
author: Christi B.

description: We were invited to a birthday dinner at the town hall.  Our reservation was at 8:30pm but we had to wait a bit longer because they were "unexpectely" busy.  In order not to make us wait too long, they cramp 7 of us into a smaller table meant for 5.  A friend of ours and I both ordered the seafood dish and neither of us enjoyed it.  The sauce was too thick and the so call seafood was just few pieces of shrimp.  My husband ordered the pork and turns out to be excellent.  I think if you are a meat eater, this is  a great place to go but if you are looking for seafood...think twice.
author: chih l.

description:
My boyfriend planned a surprise date night last night, and dinner was at Town Hall.  We have heard so many great things about this place and couldn't wait to try it out.  The food was good... but shouldn't it be in San Francisco?  It was everything else at Town Hall that made it something memorable but not necessarily in a good way.  The service- whether it was a kitchen problem or a server problem or a combination was awful!  Our server was overly anxious to get our entire order- we ordered oysters and our appetizer (bbq shrimp).  He wanted us to order entrees then as well but it was fairly early on a Friday night and we wanted to take our time... little did we know there was going to be plenty of that.  Our oysters on the half shell came out at the same time as the BBQ shrimp.  The smell of the BBQ shrimp overwhelmed the oysters.  Plus when asked which oysters were which the person was clueless... no idea what we ordered.  Really???  Also, who wants raw oysters at the same time as hot bbq shrimp?  If we ordered our entrees when our waiter wanted would it have come then too?  The time between our oysters/app and when our meal arrived was 45 minutes+.  

I will say I was thankful for the person who brought my dinner to the table because he suggested the perfect white wine(viognier, lambert bridge 2007) with my red snapper.  The red snapper was excellently prepared, and the wine was the perfect compliment.  It's a shame there were blatant restaurant miss-haps because it really killed the dinner flow- of what could have been an incredible dinner.  I really wanted to love this place.
author: Lauren G.

description: Good place.  Only drawback is that it is a trendy place to eat right now.  So it gets crowded.
author: James B.

description: i've been to several business lunches here, everything always rocks.  massive menu to chose from, everything is always fantastic.  last night we had dinner here and dispite my near perfect past experiences, the service flubs are enough to make me take my star down a notch.  after wordering a glass of wine and a bottle for the table, our appetiser arrived and still no sign of our drinks.  i had to ask our server to bring our wine (who likes to begin drinking without their wine?!), and at that time it was finally brought over 5 minutes later.  also, whenever any plates were brought over, they were either brought to the table next to use when they were ours, or entrees were placed in the wrong spots.  this clumsy service took away from what is normally a fantastic experience, i hope things get back on track next time i visit.
author: e w.

description: service = A+ food = A+ overall = A+....simplicity at its best...love it when they have the fried chicken on the menu..MmMmMMmM...
author: shannon b.

description:
Being from New Orleans and having worked in the restaurant business for over twenty years, I am often extremely disappointed in restaurants outside of my hometown that attempt to recreate Creole or Cajun influenced food. There are many potential downfalls starting with the scarcity of the proper ingredients, the recipes and cooking techniques, as well as the general concept of what the cuisine is all about, for starters. Town Hall wisely avoids all of the potential pitfalls in a variety of novel ways.
For starters the restaurant itself has a charming, rustic feel, with sturdy tables and wooden chairs and spectacular light fixtures. The crowd is a dressy but unpretentious  downtown sort that seem to have made this place a regular destination. The art is chic and appropriate, the music is fun, and the waitstaff is mostly efficient and attentive.
I couldn't resist the starters so we had three course of them, six in all. An amazing tuna tartare studded with garlic chips and spiked with a red pepper hot sauce that was a perfect foil for the impeccably fresh tuna. The fried oysters were served on the half shell with an interesting take on several classic combinations (spinach puree...a nod to Oysters Rockefeller and bacon hinting at the Galatoire's classic Oysters En Brochette...it was a dish Emeril would have been happy happy happy to serve.) It was also delicious. 
Next we had a course of outstanding BBQ Shrimp (peeled!) with a creative take on the classic...it almost reminded me of a spiked Red Eye Gravy...although the sourdough crouton was a mismatch. Thankfully, we also had a plate of the best biscuits I've ever tasted in my life nearby for proper sopping. The country style ham and pepper jelly that accompanied the biscuits were top notch as well.
Our only misfire came with the pork rillette (?) which sounded good on paper...Anson Mills grits! Hello! The grits were lost amongst a rather bland pork 'square' but it was still okay, just not great. The pork slider and ribs were spot on, though.
We also enjoyed a round of proper cocktails and a half bottle of Antinori's Super Tuscan Sangiovese/Cab/Merlot/Syrah blend. The only beverage ding was the fact that the water glasses are so small that one gulp and the glass is empty.
Desserts were delicious, too. The butterscotch and chocolate pot a creme was insanely rich and silky. The German Chocolate Cheesecake had great flavor but the texture was a little too dense. We also had a wonderful glass of Sauternes and French Press Coffee.
A dining experience I wouldn't hesitate to experience again. Love the check presenters too!
author: Michael D.

description: Contemporary American cuisine. This place reminds me of an English manor inside, except for the chandeliers which gave it a quirky feel and kept it from feeling staid/uptight. Food was good but what was really worth mentioning in my opinion were the veal meatballs and the buttercrunch custard. These two dishes were outstanding and very memorable. I wasn't overly impressed by the place but I wasn't disappointed either.
author: carolina d.

description: Town hall is great!  The poached egg on the toast with Jalapeos is one of my favorite things to eat there, as are the veal meatballs.  Eat at a table or sit at the bar the food is solid, the drinks are strong and the crowd is well...loud, but that aside the restaurant is one of my favorite in SF.
author: Grant M.

description:
We dined at Town Hall twice last week, which is amazing as we live in Santa Cruz and rarely visit San Francisco.  The first time was for lunch.  We were in a bit of a rush, ordered quickly and then waited and waited for our food, even though we had told our server we were in a hurry.  Finally the maitre d' came over and explained that our ticket had been lost.  We again explained that we were in a rush and he said he would get our food out ASAP.  He brought us two delicious cups of asparagus soup to tide us over.  Finally our food arrived.  It was pretty good, although my husband said his salmon tasted not so fresh.  My portabella mushroom sandwich was quite tasty and the housemade chips were excellent.  We asked for the bill when the food arrived to speed things up.  The bill came and it was for $6.  I asked if there were a mistake and the server said, "No we lost your order so you don't have to pay for the food!"  I was quite amazed as we have never been comped all of a meal just because the service was slow.  A big star for Town Hall there.

Move on to last night.  We had a reservation for a party of 6 and we turned out to be 7.  No problem, even though they were busy.  Then another friend showed up, again no problem.  The service was very prompt, and the manager even found a bottle of a new type of gin that I had been craving, but was not on the bar shelf.  Another big star!! We ordered lots of appetizers, all of which were excellent, especially the buttermilk biscuits with peach marmalade and the crab and artichoke dip.  The wine list had a lot of good selections for under $50.  We ordered a bottle which I tasted.  I allowed the server to pour it but when my daughter, who is a wine "snob" tasted hers, she said it was corked.  The manager brought a new bottle with no attitude whatsoever, even though I should have refused the bottle upon tasting it.  Our entrees arrived just after we had fininshed the appetizers, and they were great.  My halibut with fava beans was extemely fresh and cooked perfectly.  Several of us ordered the fried chicken which was pronounced "fabulous".  I can't remember all the entrees, but everyone was very happy.  Dessert was ordered and came quickly.  The strawberry shortcake was a real hit as was the pots de creme.  We were completely satisfied, well taken care of, and left very happy.  The room is a bit noisy, but we were able to carry on a conversation at a reasonable level.  I am not sure why there are so many complaints of servive on this site, but we found the service excellent.
author: June H.

description: Who would have imagined fried green tomatoes with tuna tartar? They said it was to give the starter a 'southern slant.'  I don't know how southern it was, but the fresh tuna alongside that tangy / savory flavor combination and crispy texture really worked.  The decadent duck entree was beautifully cooked with a rich figgy sauce that was full of flavor, served over a nutty rice pilaf.  Wonderful.  No vegetables were present and I don't think they could have competed with the flavor of the sauce.  The rib-eye steak was a fine cut, tender and flavorful and accompanied by some fun little tater tot thingies and green beans.  Generous portions, big on flavor, and enough of a meat n potatoes theme to satisfy the type that doesn't go for a froo froo California menu. For dessert we had the pear and cherry crisp with a small but dreamy scoop of homemade ginger ice cream.  I wish they had gone much lighter on the sugar and let the cherries and pears do the talking.  The service was 100% professional.  Our waiter was knowledgeable about the menu and had a good answer for any question we had about food or wine, and kindly offered to work to our timeline as we had a performance to make after dinner.  Both the waiter and the host even remembered say 'enjoy your show' when we left.  If only my friends paid that much attention!  The dcor is tasteful and unassuming - a brandy-drinking man's man would be perfectly comfortable here.  The acoustics are too LOUD.
author: Laura C.

description:
ate here awhile ago, late 2007, in which i believe was during a time of changeover, but still... my experience was HORRIBLE!

it took us 30 minutes to be seated, although we had reservations. for a two-top at 9:30pm, i wouldn't expect to wait at all... 

waitress doesn't arrive for 15 minutes, not even to ask us if we'd like a drink. table next to us has already ordered, has water and bread. 

finally order, waitress cannot recommend a wine to accompany my 1st course. LAME. 

15 minutes AFTER ordering... no bread or water. table next to us, already receiving 1st course. LAME.

finally ask for water. no bread is brought. 1st courses arrive. so-so, tastebuds probably jaded by horrible service.

ask for bread (we love our carbs), drinks are empty, glasses strategically placed by the edge of the table. waitress walks by many times. drinks remain empty.

manager walks by several times to attend to group of 6 nearby. 

1st courses are cleared, drink glasses remain on the table.

manager walks by again.

20-30 minutes go by. no new drinks. starting to get very angry.

complain to manager. he apologizes for our waitress, she's new he says. new round of drinks "on him" for the inconvenience and says he will take care of us the rest of the night.

entrees arrive. food is appalling. i ordered the scallops with jambalaya, thinking that since the jambalaya is also listed as a side dish, it must be good. the spices tasted like they were thrown in at the last minute (aka raw spice taste= nasty), not cooked in. scallops and jambalaya is a horrible combination, the raw spice taste totally overpowered the delicate sweetness of the scallops. barely eat half. drinks still empty.  waitress (who isn't supposed to stop by anymore) comes by to check in on us. "free round of drinks" haven't arrived yet. 

do not order dessert, want to leave as soon as possible.

will never go back there. 

plus side: beautiful dining room, communal table and bar are cool.
author: Status K.

description: I've now been here twice in 3 weeks. Both times my meal was excellent. Started with Tomato Fondue, BBQ Shrimp, Slider and Tuna Tartare appertizers (4 of us total both times) - then went with the Fried Chicken entree and finally the Pot De Creme dessert. Everything was up to par and I'd recommend this spot again in a heart beat - Our server Beth the was very cute, so that was a plus - only downside is that their restrooms are two flights of stairs up from the restaurant
author: Anon Y.

description: Don't know why.......... but whenever we go to these SO called "fancy restaurants", I always feel like I can prepare  simple cuts of meat, like steak, chicken or pork chops etc, a lot tastier than theirs......I got it..... I think I buy better quality meats! Their service was good, the food was just OK, & they comped us for some appetizers as their food wasn't going to ready on time.
author: Dino D.

description: Fancy southern food.  The stuffed rainbow trout and veal meatballs were good.  The chocolate butterscotch pot de creme was very tasty.
author: Jake T.

description: if you love cajun/creole this is the place for you.   appetizers are fantastic and the cocktails deserve to be served in the big easy.  entrees are HUGE and kinda all over the place in taste - think big and think southern.  the two brothers that found it were supposed to meld creole and california gourmet but really its a fancier, trendier version of pj's oysterbed.  although the butterscotch pot de creme will have you drooling the next morning.
author: M B.

description: Fun, festive atmosphere any day of the week, apparently!  My husband and I went with our good friends for a special dinner.  3 out of the 4 dishes we ordered were amazing!  Great apps and the desserts are to die for!
author: Andi B.

description: Had the pumpkin sticky toffee dessert.  It was absolutely terrible.  The original stick toffee cake was great, have no idea why someone would want to change it.  Perhaps they have someone who lacks creativity doing their desserts now.
author: isabelle r.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  This is where I bring all my out of town guests to impress them.   I have been here 8 times and the food and service have always been excellent.  They even serve delicious cocktails - LOVE the "Town Hall Cooler"!  Dinner here is always special and you will never feel rushed.  I can't say enough good things about this place.
author: esme m.

description: I took my GF here for her birthday and we both really enjoyed our experience. The atmosphere is elegant but casual and surprisingly cozy considering how big the space is. The staff, and our server in particular, was very attentive and friendly. At first glance, the menu doesn't impress - it's comprised of some basic dishes (classic American comfort food). Having said that, they execute on creating these dishes like no where else. My GF and me had the mussels appetizer, rib-eye steak, jambalaya, asparagus side, and cookie plate dessert. Everything was delicious. Portions were a little smaller than what I'm used to so I docked them 1 star.  Otherwise, I had a perfect dinner - I can't wait to come back.
author: Tom N.

description: I've only eaten here once and will eventually go back and try it again with all the good things I've heard, but I was not impressed with the menu selection or the preparation.
author: Rob P.

description: horrible...can't believe i paid $45 for popeyes chicken and a drink...totally worthless..
author: Urvish T.

description: so many people rave about this place, but i don't think it's that great. my friend and i just ordered a bunch of appertizers...the tuna tartar looked plain, but was very tasty. it came with a fried green tomato, which didn't match the flavors w/ the tuna. the scallops are good, but super salty, the chopped salad was very refreshing, but it had peas in it and i hate peas..it didn't say on the menu that it had peas. the raw oysters are to die for. we kept ordering more. it was so fresh. also the friend cornmeal orysters were hella good too. i don't usually like cooked oysters, but it was delicious. also the fried macaroni and cheese is huge. it comes in a gaint cube, but we were so full we couldn't eat much of it. for dessert we ordered this butterscoth cream thing, which was super swt! the service was not great. our waiter did not really care about us and also when the bus boy came to clean are table we told him to pack the mac n cheese up for us and he said okie. he never did. they "threw" it away. im glad i tried this place, but i would not come back
author: Karen H.

description: i so wanted to love this place.  we went for an early dinner (6:30pm) on sunday night and were surprised to find the place packed to the gills.  seated at a cozy table in the corner by the entrance to the kitchen.  bread and butter were wonderful.  husband had the veal meatballs which were pretty good.  i started with the tuna tartare on fried green tomatoes which were also pretty tasty.  then it went downhill...he finished with the halibut which was flavorless over this really interesting mashed potato mixture which was the highlight of the dish.  i had the lamb which was bland, humongous, and chewy over potato gratin (yum!) and something else i can't remember   since it was our anniversary, we also split a bottle of veuve clicquot.  it was overall ok...not amazing.  we both felt like everything was just bland and not seasoned enough.  so no need for me to go back i think.  lots of other restaurants out there with better food doing more interesting things but i'm glad we can say we tried it.
author: Cyn B.

description: we went there friday night for a 5:45-reservation (it was either that or 9:45).  pretty empty.  nice warm atmosphere, though definitely not "dressy" (they should change that on their profile because i was all like what should i wear??).  i got their ham + cheese sandwich w/a poached egg (it's called something fancier, though) to start with, and then their fish + polenta, but i could NOT finish it for some reason.  it's not like their portions were super big.  maybe it was all the bread i ate, and the fact that i had half my friend's deep fried goat cheese appetizer, too, or something.  i was sad they didn't have any dessert i liked--it was mainly things involving chocolate, pudding, and cooked fruit--so we had to go somewhere else for that.  also, i didn't like that they put their crowded-est part in the front (bar and kitchen pick-up window), so you have to like squeeze through on your way out which is twice as awkward when you're trying to put on your jacket at the same time (or maybe i just have bad manners).  oh, and they put your check in a book when they give it to you, like a real book with stories inside.  i don't get it, but it's kinda cute.
author: Janice C.

description: I went to Town Hall with such great expectations and feel cheated that it was so disappointing.  Dining out is about great food but it's also ambiance and service.  All three are what makes the experience memorable. And for me, they struck out.  First, the ambiance: it's beautifully decorated in an old brick building but LOUD and crowded.  It looked like a great drinking spot for crowds after work but was so rowdy the night we were there that I felt like I was at a college frat party.  It was almost impossible to hold a conversation at the dining tables because of the bar noise.  Second, the service: our waitress was horrible. She was unfriendly, certainly inexperienced and just plain awful.  She practically threw the menu at us, never asked how our meal was and was just sour.  I noticed the waiter at the table next to us (I think his name was Thomas) who was remarkable and the exact opposite of her!  A true professional who treated his customers so well.  I commented to him as we were leaving that he needed to take our waitress under his wing because she was not at all up to the job. You could just feel a vibe from her that she didn't want to be there.  Finally, the food:  the gulf shrimp appetizer was spot on but our entrees were so overcooked that I couldn't tell if my fish was halibut or snapper, absolutely no flavor.  It was cooked to a crisp and chewy.  My husband's pork chop was so dry it tasted like cardboard.  While the "flavors" (sauces,  etc.) were good on both dishes,  the meat was seriously overcooked.  Of course, we could never get the waitress back to express our displeasure so we just marked it up as a bad experience and saved some money by hardly tipping her.  Hope they learn to train their staff (kitchen and floor) and do something to curb the rowdiness in the bar.
author: Chris G.

description: i went to this place for a friends bday. there was a lot of hype about it but i wasn't too impressed. could be that i wasn't that hungry. the portion was HUGE. i enjoyed the company i was with but i could have done without the food. probably wouldn't go back.
author: Miss O.

description: ok so the service was good.  however, i got the chicken and when i started to eat it i noticed that it was bloody in the middle.  i had to send it back to get it recooked.  after they brought it back it was still bloody.  the waiter ended up comping the meal but i find it hard it hard it hard to give a restaurant even two stars if i cant enjoy my meal.
author: Popojo R.

description: After having been to Town Hall once several years ago my husband and I decided to try again last night.   With reservations we were seated immediately but that is all the attention we received the rest of the evening.   Water came right away but it took at least 10-12 minutes before a server arrived.  After finally ordering the wait time for the food was reasonable.  We started with a half dozen oysters that came before our starting cocktails--but they arrived shortly there after.   Our waiter was nowhere to be found.  Our wine arrived along with the appetizers of Faith's warm ham & cheese toastand the veal meatballs.   Both were excellent. but still no sign of the waiter.   The bottle of wine was placed on the back shelf behind my husband's head and not once did someone come over to replenish our glasses.  My husband had to reach behind him for the bottle.  Our main courses were also excellent--etouffee for me and osso bucco for my husband.   But still no sign of our waiter.  Plates were cleared and we were left with the last of our wine.  Ordinarily we would receive the dessert list but nothing...I finally spotted our waiter across the resturant and appeared to be flirting with one of the food runners.  No one even offered us dessert---after another 15 minutes we simply de
author: Susan R.

description: went here again after 1-2 years, not sure what it would be like.  very solid restaurant.  i had oysters, white wine (roshambo was the name, a blend of muscat and some others i forget), tons of their bread, and a pork chop with squash and greens and nuts.  everything was very good.  my co-diner ordered the fried chicken and I liked that too, though it wasn't as phenomenal as she said it would be.  very moist, but not enough crunch or thickness in the breading (obviously varies from person to person).  it was good though.  i wasn't a huge fan of the wine I ordered, but my wife liked her chardonnay.  the bread is fantastic.  so in summary, it cements this place as a dependable standard in this area.  comfortable environment, a little on the loud side, good service, and excellent food.
author: Oren B.
